site_title: Korean lender said to seek sale of 16 ships returned by Hanjin
summary: Korea Development Bank plans to sell up to 16 ships from failed container line Hanjin Shipping Co as collateral for loans. The lender, which provided most of Hanjin's funding, is seeking an arranger to help sell the vessels. The ships, including container and bulk carriers, have been returned to owners by Hanjin since the company filed for bankruptcy in late August. The sale is part of Hanjin's efforts to wind down its operations and raise funds.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Tuesday, influenced by lower oil prices and US presidential election jitters. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.30% to 17,373.44, while the Topix index declined 0.27% to 1,389.23.

site_title: Singapore companies have improved risk transparency: ISCA-KPMG study
summary: A study by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) and KPMG found significant improvements in corporate governance disclosures among Singapore-listed companies since 2013. However, areas such as strategic risk, cyber risk, and fraud risk management require more attention. Large market-capitalization companies tend to have more disclosures, but emerging areas of risk governance, like risk tolerance and risk culture, are underreported. The study suggests incorporating more behavioral elements, like risk culture, into the Corporate Governance Code to better manage risks and mitigate adverse outcomes.

site_title: US markets on edge for more election surprises
summary: US stock markets remain uncertain ahead of the November 8 presidential election, with analysts predicting a potential crash if Donald Trump wins. MIT economist Simon Johnson warns that Trump's anti-trade policies would likely cause a sharp slowdown in the US economy, potentially leading to a global recession. Despite this, some analysts believe the market reaction will be short-lived, citing historical data showing that stock market performance is not significantly impacted by the party in power. The Dow Jones has already shown a mixed reaction to surprise revelations during the campaign, with shares rebounding quickly after each shock.

site_title: Tablet market shrinks as demand grows for hybrids
summary: The tablet market declined 14.7% in the recent quarter, with 43 million units shipped, down from 50 million in the same period last year. Detachable computers, priced under $200, saw a surge in shipments, while Apple maintained its lead with a 21.5% market share. Samsung and Amazon also performed well, with Samsung's shipments down 19.3% and Amazon's Fire tablets shipping 3.1 million units. The market shift towards detachables and low prices may pose a threat to the market's long-term sustainability.

site_title: Oil tumbles to one-month low as Opec accord remains unresolved
summary: Oil prices plummeted to a one-month low, falling 3.8% in New York, as Opec and non-Opec producers failed to reach a concrete agreement on reducing the global crude surplus. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) ended talks without an agreement, with Iraq, Iran, Nigeria, and Libya seeking exemptions from output cuts. Prices have been volatile, with the global benchmark Brent falling to a 15-month high above $50 a barrel earlier this month.

site_title: Prosecutors detain woman at core of South Korea political crisis
summary: Prosecutors in South Korea have detained 60-year-old Choi Soon Sil, a close friend of President Park Geun Hye, due to her alleged involvement in a corruption scandal. Choi faces allegations of fraud and meddling in state affairs, and has been placed under emergency detention for 48 hours due to concerns she may destroy evidence and is a flight risk. The scandal has led to public outrage and mass protests, with Park's approval ratings plummeting. The investigation is ongoing, and Park is considering forming a neutral cabinet to restore public trust.

site_title: Saudi finance minister sacked by royal decree
summary: Saudi Arabia sacked its finance minister, Ibrahim al-Assaf, by royal decree, amid a major economic restructuring due to lower oil revenues. Al-Assaf, 67, was replaced by Mohammed Aljadaan, head of the Capital Market Authority. The move is part of a series of austerity measures to cover a projected US$87 billion budget deficit, with global oil prices having collapsed by about half since 2014. The kingdom has drawn on foreign reserves and issued domestic bonds to finance its operations.

site_title: Australia, Indonesia mull joint South China Sea patrols
summary: Australia and Indonesia are considering joint patrols in the disputed South China Sea, with Foreign Minister Julie Bishop stating the move aims to increase maritime cooperation and protect freedom of navigation. The proposal, proposed by Indonesia, is seen as a response to China's expansive claims in the region. The joint patrols would not disrupt relations with China, but rather aim to bring "peace" and protect shared fishing grounds. This move comes amid uncertainty in the region, with the Philippines signaling a shift towards Beijing and the US sailing a warship near disputed territory.

site_title: Clinton aides rip 'double standard' as quick action vowed
summary: Hillary Clinton's campaign accuses FBI Director James Comey of a double standard after he disclosed a renewed inquiry into her emails, just hours after the Justice Department promised to act "expeditiously" on the matter. The FBI is investigating e-mails found on Anthony Weiner's computer, the estranged husband of Clinton aide Huma Abedin. The move has raised concerns about Comey's motives and the potential impact on the presidential election. The Justice Department has vowed to work quickly on the probe, but details about the investigation remain scarce, fueling criticism from both Democrats and Republicans.

site_title: US denounces latest Turkish media crackdown
summary: The US has strongly condemned Turkey's media crackdown, with State Department spokesman John Kirby expressing concern over the detention of Cumhuriyet newspaper's editor and the closure of 15 other outlets. The US calls Turkey's actions an increase in official pressure on opposition media, criticizing the government's treatment of journalists. Kirby urged Turkey to ensure the rule of law and fundamental freedoms are protected, while maintaining a friendly stance towards Turkey and its fight against terrorism.

site_title: China deepens economic ties with Indonesia as investment doubles
summary: China's investment in Indonesia has more than doubled to US$1.6 billion from January to September, surpassing the US as the third-largest investor. This marks a significant milestone in the country's deepening economic ties with Indonesia, with China becoming the nation's biggest trading partner five years ago. The increased investment is expected to remain high in the coming years, with potential for further growth in key sectors such as mining, cement, automotive, and steel.

site_title: China to transfer US$26.3b in value-added tax revenue to local govts
summary: China's central government plans to transfer US$26.3 billion in value-added tax (VAT) revenues to local governments this year due to a change in the share of tax revenues between the central and local governments. The VAT reform aims to cut taxes by more than 500 billion yuan (S$102.6 billion) in 2016, with each government receiving 50% of the VAT revenues. This change affects local governments, which were previously reliant on business tax revenue.

site_title: China services sector picks up steam in October: official PMI
summary: China's services sector growth accelerated in October, with the official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reaching 54, above the 50-point mark. This growth is expected to offset persistent weakness in exports and help the economy meet its full-year target of 6.7% expansion. The services sector's recovery is attributed to stronger government spending, record bank lending, and a booming property market. Despite this, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Growth in China's services sector accelerated in October at a faster pace than in the previous month, an official survey showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Vornado to spin off its Washington unit in US$8.4b deal
summary: Vornado Realty Trust agreed to spin off its Washington real estate unit, valued at $8.4 billion, and merge it with JBG Cos to form JBG Smith Properties. The combined company will be the largest landlord in the Washington area, focusing on office and multifamily properties. Vornado will retain a 74% stake, while JBG limited partners will own 20% and JBG management 6%. The deal is expected to be completed in the second quarter, with JBG Smith having projects under construction and planned for development totaling over 20 million square feet.

site_title: Hong Kong leader raises prospect of controversial legal request to Beijing
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Leung Chun-ying, has signaled he may request Beijing to use a rarely invoked power to interpret the city's Basic Law to end a political crisis over a fledgling independence movement. The move would raise concerns about Hong Kong's autonomy and legal system. A court hearing is scheduled to review the swearing-in of two pro-independence lawmakers, who could be barred from the legislature. Leung's remarks come ahead of the hearing, which could lead to Beijing imposing new laws or curbing pro-independence legislators.

images.alt_text: Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying's remarks on Tuesday come ahead of a Hong Kong government-requested legal hearing that could effectively bar two recently-elected pro-independence lawmakers from the legislature of the global financial hub.

site_title: Australia home prices rise for 10th month in Oct
summary: Australian home prices rose for a 10th consecutive month in October, with the Reserve Bank of Australia citing concerns about an overheating housing market. The CoreLogic index showed a 0.5% increase in combined capital cities, with annual growth accelerating to 7.5%. Sydney and Melbourne remained the hotspots, with annual growth at 10.6% and 9.1%, respectively. Experts consider further rate cuts unlikely due to the strong demand and high clearance rates at auctions, fueling concerns about excessive borrowing and affordability.

images.alt_text: Australian home prices rose for a 10th straight month in October as record-low borrowing costs kept demand hot in Melbourne and Sydney, one reason why further cuts in official rates are considered unlikely in the near term.

site_title: Hong Kong leads stock gains in Asia on China data
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.2% on Tuesday, driven by China's forecast-beating growth in factory activity, which indicated the country's economy is stabilizing. This boosted confidence, but uncertainty over the US presidential election kept investors cautious. Shanghai and Tokyo also rose, while Singapore and Sydney gained, but Seoul and Wellington fell. The Mexican peso strengthened against the dollar, and oil prices made meek gains.

site_title: Electric cars excite the world's biggest mining company
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, is optimistic about the surge in demand for its products due to the growing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) and renewable energy technologies. EVs require copper wiring, which BHP is well-positioned to benefit from, with copper accounting for 27% of its commodity sales. The company expects copper demand to grow at 3.3% annually in China up to 2020, driven by EVs and other lightweight transportation and new energy vehicle technologies.

site_title: Wreckage of Indonesian cargo plane found, no survivors
summary: Indonesian search teams found the wreckage of a cargo plane in Papua's mountainous region, with the bodies of four crew members recovered. The Caribou plane lost contact during a short flight on Monday, prompting a search and rescue mission. The aircraft was carrying construction materials and sent an emergency signal before disappearing. Indonesia has a poor aviation safety record, and the remote area's mountainous terrain and frequent poor weather made the rescue challenging. The incident is the latest in a series of aviation accidents in the country.

site_title: Don't let the FBI's e-mail surprise swing the election
summary: The FBI is investigating whether Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server contained classified information, following a letter from Director James Comey to congressional leaders. The investigation was sparked by a review of emails from a close Clinton aide, Anthony Weiner, who was being investigated for sexting with underage girls. The FBI's review raises questions about the mishandling of classified information and the potential consequences for Clinton. Critics argue that Comey's actions could influence the election and that the FBI should prioritize national security threats over individual wrongdoing.

site_title: Inferno crashes and burns at North American box office
summary: Inferno, the third installment of Dan Brown's conspiracy novels starring Tom Hanks, underperformed in its opening weekend in North America, earning $14.9 million, $10 million less than expected. Despite this, the film's low budget of $75 million and overseas sales are expected to keep the financial impact minimal. Boo! A Madea Halloween retained the number one spot, while Jack Reacher: Never Go Back took third place, and The Accountant held on to fourth.

images.alt_text: Inferno, the latest big screen installment of Dan Brown's conspiracy novels, fizzled out in its opening weekend in North America, industry data showed Monday, earning US$10 million less than expected.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise on China data as Japan shares swing after BOJ
summary: Asian stocks rose for a second day as China's manufacturing gauge topped estimates, signaling a stabilisation in the country's largest economy. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index increased 0.3% to 139.42, while Japan's Topix index fluctuated after the Bank of Japan maintained its monetary stimulus. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates unchanged, and Honda Motor Co raised its forecast for full-year profit.

site_title: Panasonic shares plunge after heavy spending causes weaker outlook
summary: Panasonic shares plummeted 8% after the company revised its profit forecast downward due to heavy spending on its automotive battery business, citing a strengthening yen and upfront investment in a Tesla Motors factory. The company now expects an operating profit of 245 billion yen for the full year, lower than its previous projection of 310 billion yen. Analysts express disappointment over Panasonic's slow growth rate, citing a need for the company to secure growth outside Japan across various products. The company's battery division is expected to log an operating loss in the current business year.

images.alt_text: Panasonic Corp shares plunged on Tuesday as investors reacted to a sharp downward revision of the electronics maker's profit forecast, brought about by heavy spending to build its automotive battery business.

site_title: Mel Gibson: 'It's time Hollywood forgave me'
summary: Mel Gibson, a once-sought-after Hollywood star, is seeking forgiveness from the film-making community after a decade of being ostracized due to an anti-Semitic tirade during a 2006 drunk-driving arrest. Gibson's new faith-based film, Hacksaw Ridge, tells the true story of a medic who refused to carry a gun during WWII, and its success may mark a turning point in Gibson's career, with critics praising his directorial chops.

images.alt_text: One of the most sought-after names in Hollywood at the height of his career, Oscar-winning Mel Gibson has been a pariah in the film-making community for a decade.

site_title: Opec chief says oil producers on course to deliver supply deal
summary: OPEC's Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo stated that the organization and other major oil producers are on track to meet their supply deal, set for November 30. The deal aims to reduce global oversupply and rebalance the oil market. Despite initial doubts and disagreements from non-member producers, including Russia and Iraq, Barkindo expressed optimism that the required supply cut will be achieved, with Iraq committed to implementing the agreement. OPEC agreed to reduce output by 900,000 barrels a day, the first output cut in eight years, to hasten the market's rebalancing.

site_title: Australia: Shares down ahead of central bank review, US election eyed
summary: Australian shares fell 0.73% to 5,278.7, driven by weak financial sector performance amid US election uncertainty and economic events. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to review its cash rate, expected to remain at 1.5%. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 39 points, while key sectors including energy, materials, and consumer discretionary fell. Manufacturing activity in China expanded at the fastest pace in over two years, but failed to boost stock prices.

site_title: Shell says quarterly net profit rebounds to US$1.4b
summary: Royal Dutch Shell announced a quarterly net profit of US$1.4 billion, rebounding from a net loss of US$7.4 billion last year due to write-downs. The company attributed the improvement to rising output and one-time write-offs not repeated this quarter. However, CEO Ben van Beurden warned that ultra-low oil prices remain a challenge and cast an uncertain outlook for the company.

images.alt_text: Energy major Royal Dutch Shell announced on Tuesday that it rebounded into the black in the third quarter, aided by rising output and write-offs that were not repeated.

site_title: Samsung Electronics CEO says firm must learn from crisis
summary: Samsung Electronics CEO Kwon Oh Hyun stated that the company must learn from its recent crisis, which was caused by the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone's fire-prone issues. He urged employees to re-examine their work and improve quality control systems. The company aims to quickly recover from the crisis, which has dragged its third-quarter mobile earnings to their lowest level in nearly eight years. Samsung is expanding its probe into the Note 7 fires, but no one has been publicly held responsible.

site_title: ST Telemedia portfolio company Level 3 to merge with CenturyLink
summary: Level 3 Communications, a US provider of ethernet services, is merging with CenturyLink, one of the largest phone companies in the US, in a stock-and-cash deal. Level 3 shareholders will receive $26.5 per share in cash and 1.4286 CenturyLink shares for each Level 3 share, valuing the deal at $66.50 per Level 3 share. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to close by the third quarter of 2016.

site_title: Japan offers to buy 153,156 tonnes food wheat via tender
summary: Japan's Ministry of Agriculture is seeking to buy 153,156 tonnes of food quality wheat from the US, Canada, and Australia in a regular tender that will close on Friday. This purchase is part of Japan's efforts to secure a steady supply of wheat, which is the country's second most important staple after rice. The tender is a routine process, typically issued three times a month, and is aimed at meeting Japan's growing demand for wheat.

site_title: New Zealand house prices rise at slower rate in October: QV
summary: New Zealand's house prices rose 12.7% in the year to October, according to Quotable Value. The rate of growth slowed from 14.3% in the previous month, attributed to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's lending restrictions. House prices in Auckland increased 13.8% in the year, with the index now 50.2% above its 2007 peak. The restrictions, which require a 40% deposit for investment purchases, came into effect in October, despite being announced in July.

site_title: BOJ keeps policy steady, cuts price forecast
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, leaving interest rates unchanged and its 10-year government bond yield target around zero percent. The BOJ cut its core consumer inflation forecast for the next fiscal year to 1.5 percent, down from 1.7 percent. The central bank also maintained its pledge to buy government bonds to increase its holdings at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen. The decision was seen as a cautious move to avoid disrupting the fragile recovery, with BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda to explain the policy at a news conference later.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan held off on expanding stimulus on Tuesday despite pushing back the time frame for hitting its 2 per cent inflation target, signalling that it will stand pat unless a severe market shock threatens to derail a fragile recovery.

site_title: Biggest Japan utilities see sales fall as competition rises
summary: Japan's biggest utilities, including Tokyo Electric Power Co Holdings Inc, saw revenue decline amid faltering demand and rising competition from new market entrants. Tepco posted a 4.8% drop in operating profit and a 13% fall in revenue, while rival utilities Kansai Electric Power Co and Chubu Electric Power Co also saw declines. However, Kyushu Electric Power Co and Shikoku Electric Power Co reported increased revenue, with sales rising 4.3% and 5.6% respectively. The liberalization of Japan's retail power market has led to over 1.9 million consumers switching to new suppliers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.470 points to 1,673.020. Volume was 20.129 million lots worth RM7.938 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 55 to 50.

site_title: Macau gaming revenue grows for third month on tourism boost
summary: Macau's gaming revenue grew 8.8% to 21.8 billion patacas in October, driven by a surge in visitors during China's Golden Week public holiday. The city's gaming industry has reversed a 26-month slump as it transforms into a family-friendly tourist destination with new resorts. Nearly a million Chinese tourists visited Macau during the holiday, marking the highest number in at least a decade. This growth is attributed to new projects targeting recreational gamblers, rather than high rollers.

site_title: China manufacturing index at highest in 2 years
summary: China's manufacturing index rose to 51.2 in October, its highest in over two years, indicating expanding activity. This improvement signals a boost to the world's second-largest economy, but also highlights ongoing downward pressures on imports and exports due to sluggish global growth. Experts note that while this expansion might be sustained, growth is likely to cool again in the coming months as the government continues to reorient the economy away from debt-fuelled investment.

site_title: Jho Low's relatives fight US forfeiture of 1MDB-linked assets
summary: Relatives of Jho Low, accused of siphoning $3.5 billion from Malaysia's 1MDB fund, are fighting US forfeiture of assets acquired with misappropriated funds. Four family members, including Low's brother and father, claim they are beneficiaries of a family-owned trust and filed claims to protect themselves from potential "criminal liability for participation in money laundering". The US Justice Department seeks to seize $1 billion in assets, while Low denies any wrongdoing and is listed as a beneficiary of the trusts.

site_title: US dollar surrenders gains on worries over FBI probe of Clinton emails
summary: The US dollar lost gains against a basket of major currencies on Monday due to renewed concerns over an FBI probe into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server, potentially impacting the US presidential election. The dollar initially rose but gave up gains as uncertainty over a potential Trump victory and its implications for US foreign policy and interest rates took hold. The US dollar index was mostly flat at 98.373, down from earlier gains, and the euro was set to lose about 2.3% in October, its worst month in five.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks decline in line with other Asian bourses
summary: Taiwan's stocks declined for a second straight session, following other Asian markets, amid caution ahead of the US presidential election. The main Taiex index fell 0.22% to 9,275.02, with HTC Corp and Hon Hai Precision Industry Co Ltd experiencing losses. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.574 per US dollar. Despite early Asian gains, investors remained cautious, driven by the acrimonious US election campaign.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Imperium Crown, Rickmers Maritime Trust, Ley Choon Group, iX Biopharma
summary: Imperium Crown plans to invest S$5 million in two Chinese cineplexes. Rickmers Maritime Trust reported a net loss of US$74.68 million for the third quarter due to impairment charges and reduced charter rates. Ley Choon Group's subsidiary Chin Kuan Engineering and Contractors won a S$4.8 million contract. iX Biopharma was granted a patent in Canada for its WaferiX drug delivery technology.

site_title: Vietnam to target power plants as privatisation process speeds up
summary: Vietnam is speeding up the privatisation of its state-controlled power plants, aiming to cut government ownership by 2020. The process, driven by Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc, involves the state-owned energy groups Vietnam Electricity, PetroVietnam, and Vinacomin, which will retain majority ownership until 2018. The government plans to review and reduce its ownership to below 50% within two years after privatisation. The move aims to raise funds and improve efficiency, with the energy groups expected to sell shares by 2020, according to a previously approved plan.

site_title: Bank of England boss Carney to stay until 2019
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney has announced he will stay in his position until June 2019, extending his contract by one year to help secure an "orderly transition" to Brexit. The decision comes amid speculation over his future and criticism from members of Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party. Hammond welcomed the decision, saying it would enable Carney to continue leading the bank through a critical period for the British economy. The decision does not fulfill the agreed eight-year term, but Carney had previously refused to rule out staying for the full term.

site_title: Australian dollar strengthens after RBA leaves rates unchanged
summary: The Australian dollar strengthened 0.6% to 76.54 US cents after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) left interest rates unchanged at 1.5%. Governor Philip Lowe said inflation was expected to pick up gradually over the next two years, with forecasts for output growth and inflation remaining little changed from three months ago. The decision was seen as relatively upbeat, with analysts noting the central bank had "conserve[d] energy and ammunition" and kept the door open for future rate cuts.

site_title: In rare move, China criticises Trump plan to exit climate change pact
summary: China criticized US presidential candidate Donald Trump's plan to exit the global climate change pact, calling it a "wise political leader" should make policy in line with global trends. China's top climate change negotiator, Xie Zhenhua, stated that resisting the trend would harm Trump's country's economic and social progress. China plans to launch a national carbon trading scheme in 2017, which is on track to become the largest in the world, and has already traded 120 million carbon allowances.

site_title: Australia and China agree to share financial crime intelligence
summary: Australia and China agreed to share financial crime intelligence to combat cross-border money laundering and terrorism financing. The deal, announced by Australian Justice Minister Michael Keenan, aims to target and disrupt organized criminal networks. The agreement follows China's efforts to crack down on corrupt officials who have fled overseas, dubbed "Operation Foxhunt." The move boosts cooperation between the two countries, despite concerns about human rights in China. The partnership is seen as a key step in tackling serious and organized crime, particularly given Australia's strong trading relationship with China.

images.alt_text: Australian Justice Minister Michael Keenan, who is in Beijing, said the agreement between Australian financial intelligence agency Austrac and its Chinese counterpart CAMLMAC would allow both countries to target and disrupt organised criminal networks.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.48 points to 2,819.35 on Tuesday, driven by gains from DBS and ComfortDelgro. The top gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 55, with 67.6 million shares changing hands. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains for the index.

site_title: China's Oct money demand sinks as PBOC seen curbing leverage
summary: China's money demand sank to an eight-month low in October as the People's Bank of China (PBOC) intensified efforts to reduce leverage in the financial system. Overnight repurchase agreements fell 18% to 32 trillion yuan, amid a selloff after the PBOC extended tenors of lending tools and sparked a decline in bond yields. The nation's total debt has ballooned to 247% of GDP, and policy makers are focusing on deleveraging the property sector, with at least 21 cities introducing purchase restrictions and toughening mortgage lending.

site_title: China manufacturing activity expands more than expected in October
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity expanded more than expected in October with a PMI reading of 51.2, surpassing the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction. This adds to views that China's economy is stabilizing, driven by a construction boom, government spending, and record bank lending. The economy is expected to hit Beijing's full-year target of 6.7% growth, despite rising debt concerns.

site_title: Sony H1 net profit dives on strong yen, unit sale
summary: Sony's fiscal first half net profit plummeted 78% to 26 billion yen (S$344.8 million) due to a strong yen and losses from the sale of its battery business. Revenue fell 10% to 3.3 trillion yen, primarily impacted by foreign exchange rates. The company's mobile communications business and memory chip sales suffered, but strong demand for PlayStation 4 games and the new PlayStation virtual reality headset partially offset the losses. Sony now expects a net profit of 60 billion yen for the year, down from an earlier forecast.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall for 6th day, Spain's Ibex underperforms
summary: European equities fell 0.5% on Monday, marking the sixth consecutive day of losses, as energy shares declined with crude oil prices and financial stocks suffered due to disappointing bank earnings. Spain's Ibex index fell 0.6%, despite Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy securing a second term, and is down 4.2% this year. The Stoxx 600 also fell, with the oil and gas sector index down 1.5% and financials down 0.7%.

site_title: SGX raps Swiber for misleading investors on US$710m project
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has formally reprimanded offshore contractor Swiber Holdings for misleading investors on a US$710 million project in West Africa. The firm failed to disclose material conditions that pre-requisites the project's progress and revenue recognition. Swiber's initial announcement presented favorable possibilities as certain, but the company later delayed the project due to oil and gas sector weakness. The reprimand is a rare one, but it may lead to enforcement actions against Swiber or its directors.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has formally rebuked troubled offshore contractor Swiber Holdings for misleading investors amid a probe that might lead to enforcement actions against the company or its directors.

site_title: China said to have started credit-default swap trading on Monday
summary: China has started trading credit-default swaps (CDS) on its interbank market, amid mounting bond failures. The move comes after the central bank approved trading by financial institutions in September. The CDS provide insurance against nonpayment on bonds, helping investors hedge against credit risks. Following 21 bond defaults this year, compared to seven in 2015, the trading allows institutions like Industrial Bank Co and Bank of China Ltd. to manage risks. The move aims to address growing credit risks, but may also be influenced by Premier Li Keqiang's pledge to weed out zombie companies.

images.alt_text: The move comes after separate people close to the matter said in September that the nation's central bank had approved such trading by financial institutions.

site_title: Indonesia's Oct inflation rate picks up, fastest in 4 months
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose to 3.31% in October, the fastest in four months, exceeding expectations. The core inflation rate cooled to 3.08% on an annual basis. Rising chilli prices contributed to the monthly increase. The central bank's benchmark rate remains at 4.75% as inflation targets 3-5% for 2016.

site_title: SingPost launches Centre of Innovation, opens eCommerce Logistics Hub
summary: SingPost launched a Centre of Innovation (COI) and opened an eCommerce Logistics Hub, a $182 million facility, to process parcels for delivery within Singapore and worldwide. The hub features automation, including a fully automated parcel sorting system, and is designed to be scalable for future upgrades. The COI focuses on new technologies like robotics and automation to meet future customer needs. This move aims to enhance the eCommerce logistics platform and customer experience, positioning SingPost for a sustainable future in urban logistics.

images.alt_text: Singapore Post (SingPost) on Tuesday launched a Centre of Innovation (COI) as it opened its S$182 million Regional eCommerce Logistics Hub to process parcels for delivery within Singapore and destinations worldwide.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up as China data beat forecast
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Tuesday, reversing early losses, after better-than-expected Chinese factory data and a Bank of Japan policy meeting that met expectations. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.10%, while the Topix index gained 0.01%. The reversal followed a mixed Asian session, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Australia holds key rate as house-price risk outweighs inflation
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates unchanged at 1.5% as Governor Philip Lowe signaled a willingness to tolerate weak inflation to prevent further house price growth and household debt. The decision reflects Lowe's concerns about the housing market and his confidence in the economy's growth, despite inflation being below target. A potentially stronger Australian dollar could also benefit services exports, such as tourism and education, and help mitigate the risks of a depreciating currency.

site_title: Oil prices rise from one-month lows after Opec approves strategy
summary: Oil prices rose from one-month lows after Opec approved a long-term strategy to manage production. The cartel agreed to return to its role in controlling the market and being more proactive in anticipating changes. However, the gains were limited due to record output from Opec, which raised concerns about the pace of price recovery. US WTI futures rose 10 cents to $46.96 a barrel, while Brent for January delivery increased 29 cents to $48.90 a barrel. Opec's output likely reached a record high in October, with the cartel's ability to control prices questioned.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged higher from one-month lows in early trading in Asia on Tuesday after Opec agreed on a long-term strategy that was seen as an indication the cartel was reaching a consensus on managing production.

site_title: Toshiba climbs as profit outlook improves on higher memory sales
summary: Toshiba raised its first-half operating profit forecast by 36% to 95 billion yen, driven by growth in memory chips and hard disk drives, as well as cost-cutting measures. Revenue was revised slightly higher to 2.58 trillion yen. The company's shares rose 1.2% to their highest in two months, up over 50% this year. Toshiba also boosted its net income forecast to 115 billion yen, marking the second earnings forecast upgrade since August.

site_title: Japan demands talks with UK government over Brexit strategy
summary: Japan has urged the UK government to improve its communication about Brexit, warning that inward investment could be at risk. Ambassador Koji Tsuruoka demanded regular meetings to discuss Britain's strategy, citing Japan's significant economic presence in the UK. The Japanese government expressed concerns that lack of transparency could lead to Japanese companies relocating to other countries. The UK's chief negotiator, David Davis, dismissed the warning, instead emphasizing the UK's attractiveness for foreign investment and its goal of a comprehensive trading relationship with the EU.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at 7-week low, won firms
summary: South Korean shares dropped to a seven-week low, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) falling 0.2% to 2,004.39 points, due to a political scandal involving President Park Geun Hye's government. The scandal, centered around President Park's friend Choi Soon Sil's alleged influence over state affairs, led to the resignation of several aides and the detention of Choi. Investors are also wary of trading ahead of central bank meetings this week, including the Bank of Japan's policy review and the Federal Open Market Committee's decision.

site_title: Americans worn out by presidential election
summary: The US presidential election has taken a toll on Americans, with over half feeling stressed due to the adversarial campaign. Candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton have fueled negative emotions with attacks and accusations, leading to feelings of hopelessness and anxiety. Experts note that the campaign's focus on fear and negativity has increased voter angst, particularly among Republicans concerned about the future of the Supreme Court and their party. Despite the intense campaign, the American Psychological Association advises against catastrophizing and maintaining a balanced perspective.

site_title: Imperium Crown to invest S$5m into two cineplexes in China
summary: Imperium Crown, a property investment firm, plans to invest S$5 million in two cineplexes in China. The company will buy 30% stakes in each of the two companies under Yinguang group for S$1.3 million and S$3.7 million. The cineplexes, located in Linyi City and Zaozhuang City, are expected to open in June and the second half of next year, respectively. CEO Jinn Woei sees huge potential for growth in the Chinese film industry, with 23 theatres per million residents compared to 100 in the US.

site_title: Update: Merger between ST Telemedia portfolio company Level 3 and CenturyLink worth US$34b
summary: US-based Level 3 Communications and CenturyLink will merge in a $34 billion deal, combining Level 3's global footprint with CenturyLink's larger enterprise customer base. The combined company will offer robust fibre network and high-speed data services to small businesses and consumers. Level 3 shareholders will receive $26.5 per share in cash and 1.4286 CenturyLink shares, implying a purchase price of $66.50 per Level 3 share, a 42% premium. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and expected to close by the third quarter of this year.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as presidential polls tighten
summary: US stocks declined on Monday as uncertainty over the presidential campaign intensified, despite gains from major acquisitions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.1% following the FBI's review of Hillary Clinton's private server, seen as a safer choice by Wall Street. Gains from the GE-GE merger and CenturyLink's acquisition of Level 3 Communications were offset by losses in petroleum-linked shares and a downgrade of Nike. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also fell, with the Dow at 18,142.42 and the S&P at 2,126.15.

site_title: Looking beyond silicon to squeeze more out of chips
summary: Researchers have made significant breakthroughs in developing alternative computing methods to overcome the limitations of silicon-based semiconductors. A team at the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence has successfully squeezed powerful artificial intelligence programs into a $5 computer, using 1/32 of the memory and operating 58 times faster than rival programs. This achievement marks a shift towards "inexact computing," where precision is traded off for energy efficiency, potentially leading to lower costs and improved privacy. The development is seen as a response to the slowdown in Moore's Law, which has led to a growing sense of urgency to explore alternative computing methods.

site_title: Apple cash trail exposed in Korea bond sale
summary: Korean bankers are concerned that Apple may avoid investing in the country's bond market after a local newspaper revealed that the company had attempted to invest in a local bank deal. Apple had placed an order for KEB Hana's three-year bonds but was not accepted at the final price. This incident has sparked concerns that Apple may shun the country's bond market, citing the company's sensitivity about revealing its cash management.

site_title: Fed to hold rates steady, put December hike firmly in view
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at its meeting on Wednesday, but set the stage for a potential hike in December amid signs the economy is strengthening. Chair Janet Yellen has stated a rate hike before the end of the year is likely if employment and inflation continue to grow. Data shows solid payrolls growth, rising consumer prices, and a 2.9% annual economic acceleration in the third quarter. The decision comes ahead of the US presidential election, with investors largely expecting a December rate hike.

site_title: Canada sets 300,000 annual immigration target
summary: Canada has set a minimum annual immigration target of 300,000 for 2017, aiming to ease economic pressures linked to an aging population. This target falls short of expectations, which had proposed a 50% increase to 450,000. The new target is 40,000 above the historic norm, with more than half of newcomers being job seekers and investors under an economic class. The move is intended to provide a foundation for future growth in immigration.

site_title: Japan life insurers look to diversify foreign bond holdings
summary: Japan's nine largest private life insurers plan to increase their foreign bond holdings in the second half of the fiscal year, shifting away from US Treasuries due to rising hedging costs. Insurers such as Nippon Life and Dai-ichi Life are diversifying their portfolios to include non-government debt instruments, while some are willing to buy foreign bonds without hedging depending on currency levels. The move is driven by the Bank of Japan's yield curve control scheme, which aims to keep benchmark yields around zero percent. Insurers aim to reduce their yen bond holdings and increase their foreign bond holdings.

site_title: Rural poor in China worst hit
summary: China is experiencing a severe water crisis, with nearly 20% of the world's population living in the country but only 7% of the world's fresh water. The capital city, Beijing, has an average annual rainfall of 500mm, providing only 100 cubic meters of water per resident annually. The situation is exacerbated by natural disasters, pollution, and industrialization, with over 20 million people in Beijing facing water scarcity. Efforts are being made to address the issue, including the construction of water desalination facilities and "sponge cities" to combat flooding and water shortages.

site_title: Qantas flags profit dip as airlines wage price war
summary: Qantas flags potential profit dip amid a global price war, warning that half-year profit could fall nearly a sixth due to cut-price international airfares. The airline joins Cathay Pacific, Emirates, and Air New Zealand in complaining about competition, and expects underlying profit before tax to be between A$800 million and A$850 million for the six months to Dec 31, 2016. Qantas shares rebounded 4% after the announcement, driven by a drop in oil prices and a cheap valuation compared to peers.

site_title: Clinton still frontrunner despite FBI emails letter: poll
summary: Hillary Clinton maintained her six-point national lead over Donald Trump in the US presidential election, despite renewed scrutiny of her private email server, according to a poll. The NBC News/SurveyMonkey weekly poll showed Clinton's 47% support, with Trump at 41%, and third-party candidates at 6% and 3% respectively. The FBI's announcement on Friday had little impact on voters, with 55% considering it an important issue and 44% a distraction. The poll of 40,816 likely voters showed Clinton's lead remaining unchanged since last week, with the election just a week away.

images.alt_text: Democrat Hillary Clinton maintained her lead over Republican Donald Trump in their race for the White House, even in the wake of renewed scrutiny of her use of a private email server, a poll showed Monday.

site_title: LME aims for China warehouse breakthrough with e-receipt system
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) is launching a one-year pilot scheme to use its electronic system, LMEshield, for tracking material stored in China outside its warehouses network. This is a significant development in the LME's ambitions to expand into mainland China, where it is currently not permitted to register warehouses. The pilot scheme will initially be used for material stored in bonded warehouses in Shanghai, with plans to expand to other locations. The aim is to allow other warehouse firms to issue LMEshield receipts in China by the end of the pilot programme.

images.alt_text: The LME, owned by Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd, will work with other warehouse companies and Chinese regulators to facilitate expansion to other locations in China.

site_title: Rickmers unitholders pave way for debt deal; trust posts quarterly loss
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust's unitholders approved a debt restructuring deal, paving the way for a potential deal with noteholders. The trust aims to restructure S$100 million of bonds by issuing 1.3 billion new units, offering a conversion price of 4.5474 Singapore cents per unit. If successful, the trust will also secure a new amortising term loan facility of up to US$260.2 million to refinance its outstanding bank debt. A quarterly loss of US$74.7 million was reported, putting the trust on track for its third straight loss-making year.

site_title: The US dilemma - a choice between two little-liked candidates
summary: The US is set to hold its presidential election on November 8, with incumbent Barack Obama leaving office. The country faces a dilemma between two unpopular candidates: Hillary Clinton, known for her perceived venality and questionable foreign policy decisions, and Donald Trump, a reality TV personality and businessman with an appeal to white underprivileged populations. The author expresses concern over the state of the US economy, which is propped up by foreign debt, and the potential consequences of the election, with the world's largest debt and international criticism of Obama's presidency.

site_title: Govt studying need for support measures in M&OE sector
summary: The Singapore government is studying the need for support measures in the marine & offshore engineering (M&OE) sector, amid a slowdown in funding for new projects and growing defaults among cash-strapped oil and gas firms. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran announced that the government aims to provide assistance to prevent the industry from losing key capabilities, but stressed that government help cannot be a panacea, and companies and financial institutions must take long-term measures to ensure their survival.

images.alt_text: Mr Iswaran says govt help "cannot be a panacea", urging businesses to take appropriate measures in their own long-term interests.

site_title: New York's dream of being virtual currency hub fades
summary: New York's bid to become a global hub for virtual currencies has stalled after the departure of its top regulator, leaving the state's licensing process in limbo. The BitLicense, introduced in 2015, required firms to hold customer funds and exchange virtual coins for dollars. The move was meant to attract companies like bitcoin exchanges, but rivals like London and Singapore have since caught up, making New York less competitive. The absence of a clear regulatory framework has hindered the state's efforts to capitalize on the growing virtual currency market.

images.alt_text: The bitcoin market is worth about US$10.7 billion, compared to less than US$1 billion three years ago, according to information site CoinDesk.

site_title: NYK, KKK and Mitsui OSK to merge their box business
summary: Japan's three largest shipping companies, NYK, KKK, and Mitsui OSK, agreed to merge their container operations to create the world's sixth-largest box carrier, controlling 7% of global trade. The combined entity will have approximately 2 trillion yen in sales and be Asia's largest box carrier after China Cosco Shipping Corp. The move is seen as a merger of survival in response to the shrinking global container-shipping industry and the recent bankruptcy of South Korea's Hanjin Shipping.

site_title: Firms opting to trim staff instead of freezing, cutting pay: consultant
summary: In Singapore, despite an economic slowdown, most employers plan to give workers a raise next year, with only 4% intending to freeze wages. Surveys by Mercer-HRBS and Willis Towers Watson show projected salary increases of 4.0% and 3.8% respectively, slightly lower than this year's 4.2%. Companies are instead opting to trim staff to save costs, with a tight labor market and staff poaching rates averaging 10-15% for senior managers. This approach aims to maintain morale and retain employees for future business growth.

site_title: Carney's future at BOE overshadows UK interest-rate decision
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney may announce his future plans, overshadowing the UK interest-rate decision on November 3. Carney, 51, has been criticized by Theresa May's Conservative government over his stance on Brexit, but May has expressed support for him. The Bank of England's growth data and the pound's drop to a 30-year low have led economists to revise their predictions, with many now expecting no interest rate cut. Carney may decide to stay in his role beyond his five-year term, which would be a significant move at a time of unprecedented change in the UK economy.

site_title: DBS CEO makes tentative guess on oil-and-gas trough
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta expressed hope that the oil-and-gas sector has reached its trough, despite a significant increase in bad-loan provisions at the bank. DBS reported a record income in the third quarter, driven by stellar performance from wealth management and cost cuts. The bank's exposure to oil-and-gas companies, particularly Swiber, led to a surge in provisions, but Gupta believes the worst is behind the sector. The production segment is still generating cash, and the bank expects its non-performing loan ratio to remain below 1.4% for the full year.

site_title: Wellness loses appeal against OSIM
summary: OSIM International won a two-year-long legal battle against The Wellness Group (Wellness) with the Court of Appeal ordering Wellness to pay additional legal costs. In 2016, the High Court dismissed claims against OSIM for oppressive conduct and conspiracy to injure, related to OSIM's shares in TWG Tea. The Court of Appeal found no basis for Wellness' claims that the rights issue pricing was unfair and rejected allegations that majority shareholders knew Wellness would not subscribe. OSIM is a majority shareholder in TWG Tea, owning 70% of shares.

site_title: US$ bounces back from FBI's e-mail shock
summary: The US dollar rebounded from a Friday night slide after news of the FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's private email server. A Clinton win in the US presidential election is seen as likely to be positive for the dollar, potentially leading to a second rise in US interest rates in December. In contrast, a Donald Trump victory would be expected to support the yen and other safe havens. The Mexican peso rose after falling as much as 2% on Friday, and the US dollar index added 0.3% to 98.61.

site_title: Stakes are rising in Google's antitrust fight with Europe
summary: Google is facing a six-year antitrust battle in Europe, with the stakes rising as the search giant's annual revenue from online advertising hangs in the balance. The European Commission has charged Google with hampering competitors and limiting consumer choice, citing its dominant mobile operating system, search services, and advertising products. Google's rebuttals are expected to begin, with a final decision not expected until mid-2017. A loss could result in fines totaling up to $7.5 billion and forced changes to Google's operations in Europe, potentially threatening its lucrative business model and dominance in the region's online search market.

site_title: Honda chooses Tokyo for AI research centre
summary: Honda will establish a new AI research centre in Tokyo, combining existing teams in Silicon Valley, Europe, and Japan. The move aims to facilitate collaboration with engineers to commercialize AI technology, with a focus on autonomous driving and robotics. Honda believes Japan's talent pool and its traditional strength in hardware will enable the development of AI-enabled products with real-world demand. The company plans to adopt a more flexible work and salary system to attract talent from outside the auto industry and may hire technical advisers from Silicon Valley.

site_title: London property: more reasons to buy and hold than sell even with Brexit
summary: The UK's decision to leave the EU has led to uncertainty in the London property market, with the pound experiencing volatility. Despite this, the long-term outlook for London residential property remains attractive, driven by the city's undersupply of housing, growing tech industry, and strong economy. London is expected to continue attracting people from around the world, putting pressure on housing levels. While a "hard" Brexit could negatively impact the economy, a "soft" Brexit or a swift exit could lead to improved property prices. As a result, many Asian investors are advised to hold or invest more in London property, with the potential for a once-in-a-generation entry point following the devaluation of the pound.

site_title: Role of US in the geostrategic order in South-east Asia
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has declared a "separation" from the US, citing Washington's unreliability over its claim on islands in the South China Sea. This decision comes after a 2012 standoff between the Philippines and China over the Scarborough Shoal, where Beijing sent armed ships to prevent the arrest of Chinese fishermen. The US initially brokered a deal for the withdrawal of both sides, but the Chinese vessels have remained, prompting Manila to distance itself from its treaty ally. Duterte's move is seen as a reflection of his conviction that the US is unreliable in defending its interests in the region.

site_title: S Korea to spend 11t won by 2020 to support shipbuilding
summary: South Korea plans to spend 11 trillion won (S$13.4 billion) by 2020 to support its struggling shipbuilding industry, which has seen losses from excess capacity and sluggish global trade. The government aims to order over 250 vessels and provide 6.5 trillion won in financing support to strengthen shipping companies' efficiency. Shipbuilders such as Hyundai Heavy Industries and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering will undergo restructuring, including job cuts and the sale of non-core businesses. The measures are expected to help the industry recover, but analysts caution that the pace and effectiveness of the support will be crucial.

site_title: US elections: Some really good news amid the bad
summary: The 2016 US presidential election has exposed a deepening social and political schism in the country, with Americans divided into two distinct groups. Despite campaign rhetoric, both Clinton and Trump are unlikely to govern from the extremes, instead governing from the political center. The election has also highlighted a wide gender gap among American voters, with women supporting Clinton and men supporting Trump. A divided nation is likely to result, with each side demonizing the other, and a lack of legitimacy in the presidency, potentially leading to violent protests and political infighting.

site_title: Market value of Singapore stocks eases in October
summary: Singapore stocks lost 0.7% in October, with the total value of listed companies falling to S$860.7 billion. The weak third-quarter GDP data and woes of the oil & gas sector were cited as reasons for the decline. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,813.87, down 0.08% from September. Market observers expect cautious trading in November due to the US presidential elections and monetary policy meetings.

site_title: OUE H-Trust's Q3 DPS falls 28.5% to 1.23 Singapore cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 28.5% to 1.23 Singapore cents in Q3 FY16 due to lower income and an enlarged number of stapled securities. Gross revenue rose 2% to S$33.31 million, driven by higher revenue from its hospitality segment. Net property income was 2.4% higher at S$29.45 million. The retail scene in Singapore remains challenging, with lower average occupancy at Mandarin Gallery.

site_title: 4 witnesses called on first day of 1MDB-linked trial
summary: Deputy public prosecutor Tan Kiat Pheng called four witnesses on the first day of Yeo Jiawei's 1MDB-linked trial, including a former BSI head of wealth management, to establish their case. Yeo, a former BSI banker, faces four charges of obstructing justice. The prosecution applied to "stand down" seven additional charges against Yeo, and plans to call Mr. Swampillai as the fifth witness on the second day. The trial, scheduled to last until November 11, is related to Yeo's alleged role in laundering large sums of money.

site_title: Singapore turns to machines at food courts to boost productivity
summary: Singapore is implementing automated food court systems to boost productivity, as the city-state grapples with a rapidly ageing population and falling fertility rates. The initiative, part of a broader effort to increase productivity, aims to reduce manpower costs and improve efficiency. Select Group, a Singapore-based operator, has seen significant cost reductions with its automated system, and Spring Singapore is conducting trial tenders to reward productivity gains. The goal is to increase productivity in the food industry by 2% annually over the next five years, with the government preparing citizens for potential job losses.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: There is no article to summarize. The provided content appears to be a collection of news headlines and articles from various sources, but none of them directly relate to a specific article that can be summarized.

site_title: Switzerland back to battling might of currency markets
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) has maintained a de facto currency cap on the Swiss franc, despite abandoning its official cap in 2015. The unofficial cap has helped stabilize the franc's value against the euro, with a threshold of 1.08 per euro. The SNB has intervened to buy euros to prevent a stronger franc, which could hurt the economy. The SNB's president, Thomas Jordan, has expressed concerns about the franc's value and has taken steps to manage its balance sheet. Analysts predict the franc will remain stable at 1.08 per euro through the year-end.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported Q1FY17 results with in-line gross revenue and DPU, driven by improved performance in its Singapore Retail portfolio. ComfortDelGro shares are expected to be impacted by a 4.2% public transport fare reduction, but the impact is minimal due to the fare revenue risk transfer to LTA. Sembcorp Industries' short-term performance is expected to be driven by its utilities segment, with a revised target price of S$3.40.

site_title: Steering through tough times with long and short-term measures
summary: Singapore's government can offer more support to businesses to seize opportunities and build resilience in a protracted slow-growth environment. The country has a strong economic structural foundation, but long-term measures need to be coupled with immediate measures to address areas of contraction. Off-Budget measures, such as tax rebates and foreign work levy reductions, could be re-introduced to help businesses retain employees and manage costs. The government can also consider temporary or permanent enhancements to tax legislation to defray tax costs, and financial assistance for startups and growth sectors.

site_title: SIAS takes up the cudgels for bondholders
summary: The Securities Investors' Association of Singapore (SIAS) is extending its services to represent bondholders in the local corporate sector, which is bracing for possible defaults by firms in the offshore and shipping sector. Some bondholders have approached SIAS for help, and the association plans to collectively represent them, advising on their rights. This move comes as several companies, including Rickmers Maritime Trust and Swiber Holdings, face restructuring challenges, and bondholders are unsure of their rights and how to seek redress.

site_title: Britain's MBA schools fear Brexit may hit enrolment of foreign students
summary: Britain's business schools fear a post-Brexit decline in foreign student enrollment, citing the UK government's push to decrease immigration and the potential for anti-immigration sentiment. The UK is home to three of the top 10 MBA programmes outside the US, relying heavily on international students. A potential change in law allowing EU students to study without a visa could have a broader impact on international students, and business schools worry about the backlash against immigration.

site_title: I know a rigged election. The US presidential election isn't one.
summary: Russian opposition leader Mikhail Khodorkovsky compares US presidential candidate Donald Trump's claims of a rigged election to his own experiences in Russia, where elections are heavily manipulated by the government. Khodorkovsky, who was imprisoned for supporting opposition groups, notes that Trump's accusations undermine the credibility of the US democratic process. He describes how he was forced to jump through hoops to participate in a fake election in Russia, and how the country's authoritarian leader, Vladimir Putin, uses disinformation and intimidation to maintain power. Khodorkovsky concludes that democracy can only be destroyed from within, and that Trump's actions are helping Putin to drag the US down to his level.

site_title: Local banks show their resilience
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, United Overseas Bank (UOB), and OCBC, reported better-than-expected profits in Q3 despite a deteriorating economy and higher bad loan provisions. DBS led with strong operating performance, while UOB saw healthy loan growth, but was offset by a decline in net interest margin. OCBC's wealth management sales and insurance unit helped the bank post higher earnings. All three banks attributed the increase in bad loans to oil and gas customers, with DBS more than doubling its allowances.

images.alt_text: The third-quarter results of the three local banks showed some things in common - they continued to defy predictions by posting better-than-expected profits despite sharply higher bad loan provisions.

site_title: Cyber threat needs urgent board level oversight
summary: A recent cyber attack on StarHub's home broadband network in Singapore highlights the need for listed companies to prioritize cybersecurity as a strategic issue. Experts warn that companies are unprepared for emerging threats, with 83% of Singapore firms feeling their current data protection solutions are insufficient. The average cost of data loss for organizations in Singapore is over $1.3 million, significantly higher than the global average. To combat cyber threats, companies should adopt a "high alert" strategy, investing in cybersecurity solutions and board-level oversight to stay ahead of evolving threats and technologies.

site_title: S'pore ultimate winner in selection of LNG importers
summary: Singapore has secured the ultimate winner in the selection of liquefied natural gas (LNG) importers, with Pavilion Energy and Shell clinching the import licence for the next tranche of LNG. The country's creditworthiness sets it apart from other new LNG buyers, and the deal is expected to provide stable cashflows and an outlet for Pavilion Energy's purchase deals. The franchise is estimated to be worth US$340 million a year, and will have a transformational effect on Pavilion Energy, while also marking Shell's first step into South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: It was a decision many years in the making. And while clinching the import licence for the next tranche of liquefied natural gas into Singapore was a huge win for Pavilion Energy and Shell, the country itself has become the ultimate winner through the new appointments announced last week.

site_title: Parc Riviera's unusual pricing scheme expected to stir interest
summary: Developer EL Development is adopting a "one-tier pricing" scheme for its Parc Riviera condominium project, where buyers of units from the 5th to 15th floor pay the same price as those on the lowest floor. This strategy aims to stimulate interest in the market, which has been affected by economic uncertainty. Under the scheme, the price difference between higher and lower floors is reduced, with an estimated average savings of $50 per square foot for initial buyers. The move is seen as a departure from industry norms and may eat into developer profit margins, but is intended to drum up excitement and sales momentum.

images.alt_text: The 752-unit Parc Riviera comprises two blocks of 36-storey apartments ranging from one-bedroom to four-bedroom units.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust reported a net loss of US$74.68 million for Q3 2016 due to a non-cash impairment charge of US$69.1 million. Mencast Holdings warned of a loss for its Q3 and nine-month results, citing industry weakness. iX Biopharma received a patent in Canada for its WaferiX drug delivery technology. Ley Choon Group's subsidiary won a contract worth approximately S$4.8 million from the Public Utilities Board.

site_title: Japan Tobacco profit forecast falls short of analyst estimates
summary: Japan Tobacco's profit forecast fell short of analyst estimates, with operating income expected to be 580 billion yen this year, lower than the 586 billion yen average estimate. Sales declined 4% in the first nine months due to a stronger yen, and the company cut its forecast for domestic sales volume by 1 billion units. The company's shares are down 11% this year, while demand for its electronic cigarette product, Ploom Tech, has outstripped supply since its introduction in March.

site_title: Stocks drift marginally lower
summary: Singapore stocks closed 2.39 points lower at 2,813.87, with turnover reaching S$978 million. The Straits Times Index ended slightly weaker, while the Dow futures rose about 40 points. DBS reported unchanged Q3 net profit, and UOB shares rose S$0.15. Analysts expect emerging Asia to be at a turning point, with tailwinds gathering momentum, including China's nominal growth rebound.

site_title: DBS scores coup on ANZ wealth and retail business in Asia
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has acquired ANZ's wealth and retail business in Asia for S$110 million, gaining S$23 billion of assets under management. The deal, which includes 30 branches in Indonesia and Taiwan, will allow DBS to tap into ANZ's mass affluent pool and expand its wealth asset base in the region. The acquisition is expected to boost DBS's revenue and improve its return on capital, with the bank's wealth management business having quadrupled revenue over the last five years. The deal is expected to close by early 2018.

images.alt_text: It was definitely not a case of Monday blues when DBS scored a coup by snapping up most of ANZ's wealth and retail business in Asia for a compelling price of S$110 million.

site_title: GE nears US$30b deal with Baker Hughes: WSJ
summary: General Electric (GE) is nearing a $30 billion deal with Baker Hughes to combine their oil and gas businesses, creating a publicly-traded entity controlled by GE. The transaction would enhance cooperation and boost value for both companies, mirroring industry efforts to fortify operations amid the oil-price slump. A new company could be formed by combining GE's specific oil and gas business lines with Baker Hughes, preserving GE's asset-light model while giving it access to new markets. The deal is expected to be announced, with shares in both companies rising following the talks.

site_title: Having your slice and eating it too
summary: Pezzo Pizza, a Singaporean pizza chain, was founded by Chiang Zhan Xiang in 2012 with a unique business model of selling pizza by the slice from kiosks. The company has since expanded to 30 stalls across Singapore and plans to reach 35. Chiang chose kiosks over full-size restaurants due to tight labor costs and flexibility, allowing for higher productivity and competitive wages. Pezzo has also expanded to other countries in the region, including Malaysia, Thailand, and China, and recently debuted in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: China artists seeking lower rent cut path outside Beijing
summary: Chinese artists are flocking to the city of Yanjiao, about an hour outside Beijing, to find affordable studio space due to high rents and demolition threats in the city. Many young graduates from Beijing's elite art schools are drawn to Yanjiao's cheap apartments, often in large, uninspired blocks, to pursue their artistic dreams. Despite lacking the charm of SoHo or Williamsburg, Yanjiao has become a hub for artists, with some even establishing experimental art galleries, such as On Space. The city's artists see Yanjiao as a temporary refuge before returning to Beijing, where they hope to make a name for themselves.

images.alt_text: A gallery in Yanjiao. Many of China's most famous contemporary artists emerged from so-called artist villages on the urban fringes of Beijing, where rent was low and distractions from making art were few.

site_title: Auditor casts doubt on Perwaja's going concern status
summary: An independent auditor has issued a disclaimer of opinion on Perwaja Holdings Bhd's financial statements due to "material uncertainties" regarding the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The steel group, which has incurred billions of ringgit in losses, is in the midst of restructuring its debts and has received a RM1.8 billion investment from a Chinese conglomerate. The auditor questioned whether Perwaja's ability to operate as a going concern should have been triggered in 2013, citing concerns over the company's bad track record and intense competition from cheaper Chinese steel imports.

site_title: Rights groups ask Facebook to clarify content removal policies
summary: Rights groups have urged Facebook to clarify its content removal policies, citing repeated censorship of posts documenting human rights violations. Over 70 organizations, including the American Civil Liberties Union, have signed a letter criticizing Facebook for deleting content on police violence and removing iconic imagery from the Vietnam war. The groups request clear policies, a public appeals platform, and an external audit of content censorship and data sharing policies. Facebook has yet to respond to the request.

site_title: After the Philippines, now Malaysia embraces China
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has strengthened ties with China, signing a defense deal for Chinese naval coastal patrol ships and calling himself a "true friend" of Beijing. This move comes after the Philippines recently adopted a similar approach, echoing the narrative of American decline and China's rise. The deal is seen as a strategic move by Malaysia to rebuild its image and secure investment, particularly with domestic politics strained due to corruption allegations. However, regional observers note that Malaysia's military has deeper ties with the US and that strategic balance between China and the West remains a priority for many nations.

site_title: McDonald's to pay US$3.75m in 1st settlement with franchise workers
summary: McDonald's has agreed to pay US$3.75 million to settle a lawsuit claiming labor law violations by a California franchisee. The settlement, which must be approved by a federal judge, includes US$1.75 million in back pay and damages and US$2 million in legal fees for about 800 employees at five restaurants. This is the first time McDonald's has settled a claim by a group of US workers at one of its franchises, and the company maintains it is not a joint employer of franchise workers.

site_title: Raising the bar for the private security industry
summary: Soverus, Singapore's first publicly-listed security firm, prioritizes the welfare of its officers, providing monetary and welfare benefits, bursaries, and career advancement opportunities. The company's strong middle management team and processes enable it to offer personalized advice and guidance to officers, setting it apart from competitors. With a focus on quality service, Soverus has expanded its range of services to include security guarding, cyber security, and homeland security. Despite facing a manpower shortage, Soverus aims to expand its team and increase operational efficiency to gain a competitive edge in the industry.

site_title: Lebanon's Aoun elected president: tally of televised vote count
summary: Lebanon's parliament elected Michel Aoun, a former army commander, as president on Monday, ending a 29-month presidential vacuum. Aoun secured the presidency with the support of at least 65 MPs, securing an absolute majority. The election marks a significant political deal that is expected to make Sunni leader Saad al-Hariri prime minister. The Lebanese presidency is reserved for a Maronite Christian, and Aoun is in his 80s.

site_title: Consumer spending makes biggest jump in three months
summary: US consumer spending increased by 0.5% in September, the largest gain in three months, exceeding a median forecast of 0.4%. This rise, which accounts for 70% of the economy, indicates momentum in the US economy. The increase follows a 0.1% decline in August, which was revised lower.

site_title: AirAsia India investigating former staff for financial irregularities
summary: AirAsia India is investigating former staff for alleged financial irregularities, including 220 million rupees (S$4.58 million) in "fraudulent transactions" involving "non-existent parties". The investigation follows a letter from ousted Tata Sons chairman Cyrus Mistry, who accused board members of being aware of "ethical concerns" with transactions. AirAsia India, along with its parent AirAsia and Tata Sons, will investigate allegations of impropriety and misappropriation, vowing to take "stern action" against perpetrators.

site_title: Creepy clown craze puts damper on Halloween in America
summary: A creepy clown craze has spread across the US and beyond, with over 20 states reporting clown incidents, including sightings of sinister clowns armed with knives. Cities and law enforcement are discouraging or banning clown costumes, with some schools and districts prohibiting them. Authorities warn that the trend could lead to a backlash, and some businesses, such as McDonald's and Target, have scaled back or halted clown-related appearances. The phenomenon has also sparked concerns about the impact on performers and the Halloween industry.

site_title: GE merges oilfield unit with Baker Hughes
summary: General Electric (GE) announced a merger with Baker Hughes, injecting its oilfield unit into the company and acquiring 62.5% ownership. The deal, valued at $7.4 billion, aims to position the combined company for the oil industry's rebound after the crude price crash. GE will retain its digital technologies, while Baker Hughes will retain its century-old experience in supporting oil and gas drillers. The merger is expected to create a stronger services company in the oil and gas exploration and production sector.

site_title: US inflation steady in September
summary: US inflation remained steady in September, with the personal consumption expenditures price index rising 0.2% and core PCE increasing 0.1%. Consumer spending grew 0.5% year-over-year, outpacing income growth of 0.3%. The data, released ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting, suggests inflation could rise faster than expected. Despite this, the Fed is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at least until next month.

site_title: Alibaba reshuffles entertainment units, to raise 10b yuan fund
summary: Alibaba Holdings Group Ltd has reorganized its media and entertainment businesses, forming a new Alibaba Digital Media and Entertainment Group headed by Yu Yongfu. The company plans to raise over 10 billion yuan for an affiliated investment fund. Victor Koo will step down as CEO of Youku Tudou and oversee the new fund. The new group will also include Alibaba Pictures Group Ltd. Yu Yongfu will keep his previous positions as head of AutoNavi and Alibaba Mobile Business Group.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime reports Q3 loss, hit by impairment charge
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust reported a net loss of $74.68 million for Q3 2016, compared to a net profit of $8.99 million in the same period last year. The loss was attributed to a non-cash impairment charge of $69.1 million, applied to 15 vessels, and reduced revenue of 43% to $15.64 million due to lower charter rates and vessel utilization. Loss per share was 8.49 US cents, down from 1.04 US cents a year earlier.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd, UASC seek EU approval for deal with concessions
summary: Hapag-Lloyd and UASC have submitted concessions to the European Commission in hopes of securing approval for their billion-euro merger. The merged company would be the fifth largest player globally, with access to key trade routes. The EU's competition body will seek feedback from customers and rivals before deciding on the next step, with a deadline of Nov. 23. The merger is part of a wave of consolidation in the container shipping industry, which has seen shippers try to tackle the industry's 50-year slump caused by overcapacity and weak global economic growth.

images.alt_text: German container shipping line Hapag-Lloyd and Kuwait-based United Arab Shipping Company (UASC) have submitted concessions aimed at securing EU antitrust approval for their billion-euro merger.

site_title: SIAS to collectively represent corporate bondholders
