summary: The Securities Investors' Association (Singapore) has agreed to collectively represent corporate bondholders who have been defaulted on or are undergoing restructuring. The investor lobby group aims to help these "stranded" holders navigate their rights and is also considering investor education on corporate bonds. This move is seen as a response to the growing needs of bondholders in Singapore.

site_title: Listening clubs enthrall London's audiophiles
summary: A series of listening clubs in London are offering audiophiles an immersive experience with high-quality sound systems, prioritizing audio quality over volume. The clubs, inspired by a 1970s New York party series, use custom-built rigs to deliver a clean and punchy sound to attendees. With the blessing of DJ David Mancuso, these events have gained popularity, spreading a trend of audiophile gatherings in the city, where music lovers can enjoy recorded music in a unique and intimate setting.

site_title: Eurozone GDP growth in Q3 as inflation picks up
summary: Eurozone GDP growth remained stable at 0.3% in Q3 2016, amid inflation rising to a 27-month high of 0.5%. The recovery is cautious due to Brexit and banking crisis fears. Analysts expected 0.4% growth and inflation of 0.4%. The European economy's growth is unlikely to create new jobs or boost inflation, despite the European Central Bank's monetary stimulus program.

site_title: Ley Choon subsidiary wins S$4.8m contract from PUB
summary: LEY Choon's subsidiary, Chin Kuan Engineering and Contractors, won a S$4.8 million contract from the Public Utilities Board to replace and enhance watermains in Singapore. The contract was announced by Ley Choon Group Holdings through a release to the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Thailand investment pledges more than double in Jan-Sept
summary: Thailand's investment applications more than doubled in the first nine months of 2016, reaching 369 billion baht, a 137% increase from the same period last year. The surge is attributed to the military government's efforts to promote investment in targeted sectors, including aviation and medical equipment. Despite actual investment being lower at 342 billion baht, the Board of Investment expects to meet its full-year target of 550 billion baht, with many countries still interested in investing in Thailand.

site_title: YuuZoo most active on movie studio buy
summary: YuuZoo, a Singapore-based company, announced a proposed acquisition of a majority stake in Beverly Hills-based movie studio Relativity Media for US$27.5 million. This deal will make YuuZoo the largest shareholder of Relativity Media, which comprises entertainment-related businesses. YuuZoo's chairman, Thomas Zilliacus, stated that the acquisition will enable the company to become a "full-service tech and content play" and launch a mobile streaming platform, YuuTV, which will offer films produced by Relativity Media. The deal is seen as an attractive price for a company that was previously preparing for an initial public offering.

site_title: Oil slides as non-Opec nations demure on output limit plan
summary: Oil prices slid on Monday as non-Opec nations failed to commit to joining Opec's output limit plan. London Brent crude fell 38 cents to $49.33 a barrel and US WTI crude fell 30 cents to $48.40 a barrel. The meeting between Opec and non-Opec countries in Vienna on Saturday did not produce an agreement, and experts predict downward pressure on prices due to potential oversupply. The failure to reach a deal for a global output limiting deal on November 30 has sparked concerns about a bearish market.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slid on Monday after non-Opec producers made no specific commitment to join Opec in limiting oil output levels to prop up prices, suggesting they want the oil producing group to solve its differences first.

site_title: Millennials' hunt for caffeine fix pushes coffee demand to record
summary: Millennials in the US are driving a record-high demand for coffee, accounting for 44% of the country's coffee demand. This cohort is increasing their daily consumption at a fast pace, offsetting declines among older adults. Droughts in Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, are crimping supplies, leading to a surge in prices and a tightening of coffee markets. Hedge funds are positioning for further gains, while coffee roasters are shifting to arabica beans, further increasing prices. Despite potential recovery in Brazilian production, tight supplies and rising demand are expected to continue.

images.alt_text: The coffee craze is also starting earlier in life. Younger millennials, born after 1995, started drinking coffee at about 14.7 years old, while older millennials, born closer to 1982, began at 17.1 years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore prosecutors plan to call nine witnesses to establish their case in the trial of an ex-BSI banker charged with perverting the course of justice in the 1MDB case. DBS Group reported a net profit of S$1.071 billion for the third quarter. About 70% of Singapore's manufacturing firms expect a stable business outlook in the next six months. OSIM International won a two-year-long legal battle against The Wellness Group, with the Court of Appeal ordering the latter to pay additional legal costs.

site_title: US stocks edge up on GE, CenturyLink deals
summary: US stocks edged higher in opening trade on Monday following deals by General Electric and CenturyLink. GE's planned merger with Baker Hughes, taking a 62.5% stake, boosted GE shares, while Level 3 Communications jumped 5.0% after CenturyLink's $34 billion acquisition. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 added less than 0.1% each, despite markets absorbing the latest US presidential campaign twists. The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2%.

site_title: Indonesia central bank beefs up requirements for large outgoing forex transfers
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has introduced a new regulation requiring banks to attach an underlying document for large outgoing foreign currency transfers exceeding $100,000, starting in November. The document must detail the purpose of the transfer. Banks that fail to comply will face fines of up to $5 million for each transfer. Customers who do not attach the document may be fined up to $50 million. The regulation aims to increase transparency and provide more information about foreign exchange traffic.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer for its data center business was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs imposed by President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, will become OCBC's new CEO. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Japan's negative rates prod megabanks to offshore wind loans
summary: Japan's megabanks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, are increasingly lending to renewable energy projects abroad due to negative interest rates at home. The banks are attracted to steady yields from offshore-wind projects in the North Sea, backed by government subsidies. This move helps them make up for a slowdown in the domestic market, where banks struggle to make money on loans. The banks' efforts are driven by governments' ambitions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 80% by 2050.

site_title: Singapore turns to machines at food courts to propel growth
summary: Singapore is implementing automated systems in food courts to boost productivity, following a rapidly aging population and falling fertility rates. The country is replacing low-end manpower with machines, seen as a key component of plans to increase productivity in the food industry by 2% annually for five years. The government has identified the food industry as one of 23 sectors to undergo a S$4.5 billion transformation plan, with Select Group and SPRING Singapore conducting trials for automated systems.

site_title: iX Biopharma granted patent in Canada for WaferiX
summary: iX Biopharma has been granted a patent in Canada for its WaferiX drug delivery technology, which is set to expire in 2030. The company cited a potential market size of C$515 million for opioids and C$97 million for sleep aids in Canada. This is the latest in a series of patent grants for WaferiX, which has also been granted patents in South Korea, Australia, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, and Singapore. WaferiX technology involves a small wafer that dissolves under the tongue, releasing active compounds within a minute.

site_title: China: Stocks ease on asset bubble, US election fears
summary: China's stocks fell 0.1% on Monday, with the CSI300 index at 3,336.28, amid warnings from President Xi Jinping about asset bubbles and uncertainties around the US presidential election. The market was also pressured by news of the FBI's review of Hillary Clinton's emails and a surge in safe haven stocks. However, fund managers remain optimistic about a rebound, citing signs of economic stability and a bubble in the bond market.

site_title: OUE H-Trust Q3FY16 distribution per security falls to 1.23 cents
summary: OUE H-Trust reported a distribution per stapled security of 1.23 Singapore cents for the third quarter, down from 1.72 cents a year ago, due to lower income and an enlarged number of securities. Gross revenue rose 2% to S$33.31 million, driven by higher revenue from its hospitality segment, while net property income was 2.4% higher at S$29.45 million. Distribution income fell 3.3% to S$22.3 million. The company attributed the decline to a weak global economy and will focus on active asset management.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Monday with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 2.19 points to close at 1,672.46, following a trading volume of 1.45 billion lots valued at RM1.89 billion. Losers beat gainers 521 to 290.

site_title: Switzerland back to battling might of currency markets
summary: The Swiss National Bank is reportedly defending a de facto currency cap of around 1.08 per euro, despite scrapping its official cap 21 months ago. This unofficial cap has helped the Swiss franc become one of the least-volatile major currencies versus the euro. The SNB's intervention to prevent a stronger franc could lead to higher interest rates, but may also pose risks to the economy. The SNB's President Thomas Jordan has expressed concerns that the franc is overvalued, and the central bank is under pressure to maintain stability.

site_title: Trek 2000's finance director steps down
summary: Trek 2000 International's finance director, Edward Tan Kew Poh, has stepped down after less than two months due to personal interests. This comes amid an ongoing investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department and a report lodged by auditors in April related to documentation deficiencies. The company had previously appointed external firms to review its accounting records and transactions. Poh's departure follows the company's announcement that its second-half revenue may be below target.

site_title: SGX reprimands Swiber for disclosure breaches on US$710m project
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a public reprimand to Swiber Holdings for disclosure breaches related to a US$710 million project award in 2014. The reprimand was issued after Swiber failed to provide investors with sufficient information about the project, which was dependent on several factors. The company had faced cash flow problems and defaulted on bond payments, leading to its stock being suspended from trading. The SGX has referred the case to relevant authorities.

site_title: Thailand 'making preparations' for Dec 1 succession
summary: Thailand is preparing for Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn's ascension to the throne on December 1, following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej on October 13. The prince's formal coronation is expected to take place after a year's time, following the king's cremation. The country is in a state of mourning, with strict lese-majeste laws limiting public discussion about the succession. The government is making preparations for the prince's formal ascension, which could occur within seven to 15 days of the king's death.

images.alt_text: Thailand is making preparations for Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn to ascend the throne on Dec 1, two senior military sources with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip over Clinton e-mail woes
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index fell 0.12% on Monday due to growing concerns over US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's email controversy. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 17,425.02, while the Topix index rose 0.04%. The market worries ahead of a central bank policy announcement, with investors also awaiting US GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Prosecutors quiz Choi Soon Sil, woman at core of Park's political crisis
summary: South Korean prosecutors questioned Choi Soon Sil, a woman at the center of a political scandal involving President Park Geun Hye, on Monday. Choi denied any wrongdoing and submitted to questioning a day after returning from Germany. Allegations of fraud, meddling in state affairs, and influence over Park's speeches and policy have sparked public outrage and pushed Park's approval ratings to a low. A task force is investigating the leak of presidential documents and Choi's alleged involvement in state affairs, including using her relationship to coerce corporate donations.

site_title: Rickmers unitholders agree to new issuance for debt, liquidation if deal falls through
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust unitholders have approved a debt restructuring deal, allowing the company to issue 1.3 billion new units and restructure S$100 million of bonds. If the deal falls through, unitholders want the trust to be liquidated. The proposal includes converting 60% of existing notes into new units, extending maturity, and cutting the coupon rate. Noteholders will vote on the restructuring on Nov 9. If successful, Rickmers will receive a new amortising term loan facility of up to US$260.2 million to refinance its bank debt.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower
summary: Europe's main stock index, FTSE 100, fell 0.4% to 6,969.67 points at the start of trading on Monday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also losing 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively. The decline follows a mixed day in US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The decline in Europe is attributed to mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks remain in focus.

site_title: China, Philippines in 'friendly' understanding on shoal: official
summary: The Philippines and China have reached a "friendly" understanding allowing Filipino fishermen to fish around Scarborough Shoal, a disputed territory seized by Beijing in 2012. The agreement was negotiated during President Rodrigo Duterte's meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing. Chinese coastguard vessels patrol the area, while the navy is absent, allowing fishermen to fish unmolested. Neither country dropped its claim to the shoal, with China insisting on its "historical rights." The agreement is seen as a win-win for both countries, with a focus on economic relations and trade.

images.alt_text: The Philippines and China have reached a "friendly" understanding allowing Filipinos to fish around a disputed shoal seized by Beijing in 2012, a senior aide to President Rodrigo Duterte said on Monday.

site_title: Thailand offers US$1b loan to struggling jasmine rice farmers
summary: Thailand's government has offered a US$1 billion loan to jasmine rice farmers struggling with falling prices, with the condition that they store their grain for six months. The loan scheme aims to curb an oversupply of jasmine rice and stabilize prices. Prices for Thai jasmine rice have hit their lowest level in years, at US$725 per tonne, and the government plans to implement additional measures to support rice prices. The loans will be provided to 2 million farm households and are expected to help improve rice prices during the annual harvest period.

images.alt_text: Thailand's rice management committee said on Monday it will offer loans worth US$1 billion to jasmine rice farmers struggling with falling prices, on a condition that they store the grain for six months to slow down market supply.

site_title: Japan Airlines cuts outlook as H1 net profit dives
summary: Japan Airlines cut its full-year earnings outlook due to a 30% drop in first-half net profit to 71.4 billion yen, mainly attributed to a slump in international business and a stronger yen. The carrier now expects a net profit of 161 billion yen, down from an earlier estimate of 192 billion yen. In contrast, rival ANA Holdings posted a 6.4% increase in net profit, citing cost-cutting efforts and a rise in business travel from Europe, North America, and Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares close marginally weaker
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.39 points to 2,813.87 on October 31, the last day of October, due to month-ending "portfolio rebalancing." The index was mixed, with 179 rises and 189 falls. Local bank DBS reported unchanged Q3 net profit of S$1.07 billion, while UOB's shares rose S$0.15 to S$18.78. This marked a slightly weaker day for Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, but US Dow futures rose 40 points before losing half of that by 5 pm.

site_title: Plastic pumpkin sellers face a big UK inflation scare
summary: UK plastic pumpkin sellers face a potential inflation scare as discount shops and online retailers gain popularity, with prices being the main consideration for consumers. The slump in the pound has led to higher sourcing costs, making it challenging for stores to charge more. Retailers such as Poundland and B&M are exposed to currency fluctuations, which could impact their margins. As inflation rises, consumers may trade down to cheaper alternatives, posing a threat to the discount sector.

images.alt_text: It's zombies versus ghouls on the British high street. Or more to the point, discount shops and big grocers. They're both headed for a fright.

site_title: Sony cuts annual profit outlook due to sale of battery business
summary: Sony Corp has cut its annual profit outlook due to impairment losses from the sale of its battery business to Murata Manufacturing Co. The company now expects 270 billion yen in operating profit for the year ending in March, down 30 billion yen from its previous forecast. Sony agreed to sell its battery business for 17.5 billion yen and will book an impairment charge of 33 billion yen related to the sale.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals rose to three-month high in September
summary: UK mortgage approvals reached a three-month high in September with 63,000 loans granted, exceeding economists' forecasts of 61,500. Consumer credit rose £1.4 billion, and business lending increased £1 billion, with annual loan growth at 3%. Mortgage lending surged £3.2 billion, driven by low borrowing costs, as the effective interest rate on new mortgages fell to 2.27%. The Bank of England suggests household demand for credit is holding up despite the Brexit vote, leading to a possible decision to refrain from cutting interest rates this week.

images.alt_text: UK mortgage approvals rose in September to a three-month high, the Bank of England said.

site_title: Singapore prosecutors to call nine witnesses in ex-BSI banker's trial in 1MDB case
summary: Singapore prosecutors will call nine witnesses to establish their case against Yeo Jiawei, a former BSI banker charged with perverting the course of justice in the 1MDB case. Yeo allegedly amassed S$26 million from illicit schemes while employed by BSI Singapore. He is accused of intentionally perverting the course of justice in March 2016 by contacting witnesses to suppress incriminating evidence. The trial, presided over by District Judge Ng Peng Hong, is scheduled to last until November 11.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE prosecutors plan to call nine witnesses to establish their case in the trial of ex-BSI banker charged with four counts of perverting the course of justice amid a probe into the money flows of 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB).

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher led by basic materials; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, driven by gains in basic materials and commodities, with gold stocks and iron ore prices contributing to the gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,317.73, after a subdued start. Newcrest Mining and OZ Minerals Ltd saw significant gains, while mining giants Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton also rose. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rebounded 0.3% after earlier losses, led by telecom stocks and financials.

site_title: Thai Sept consumption, investment rise
summary: Thailand's private consumption and investment increased in September, suggesting a slow economic growth. The Bank of Thailand's private consumption index rose 0.1% and private investment index rose 0.8%, after falling in the previous month. Exports, accounting for two-thirds of the economy, increased 3.5% in September, exceeding the central bank's forecast of a 2.5% decline. The economy is expected to grow close to 3.5% year-on-year in the third quarter, surpassing the central bank's projection of 3.2%.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise for 6th straight month in Sept: govt data
summary: Hong Kong home prices rose 2.78% in September, marking the sixth consecutive month of gains, according to government data. This increase brings home prices to their highest level in 11 months. Despite a 3.46% drop from the historic peak a year ago, the market remains among the most expensive in the world. Rental prices also rose for the sixth consecutive month, with a 0.83% increase from the previous month, and sales of second-hand private domestic homes are expected to hit a 20-month high for October.

site_title: Asia: Stocks struggle on US election worries
summary: Asian stocks struggled on Monday as the FBI's announcement that it would further investigate Hillary Clinton's emails fueled uncertainty about the US presidential election. US stocks tumbled, and the dollar took a hit, causing trading conditions to become "slippery and shifty" globally. Asian markets, including Tokyo's Nikkei, Shanghai, Seoul, and Taipei, ended lower, while Hong Kong and Sydney rose slightly. The uncertainty is expected to continue until the election on November 8, with potential implications for the stock market, dollar, and Treasuries.

site_title: About 7 in 10 manufacturing firms see stable business outlook in next 6 months: EDB
summary: About 70% of Singapore's manufacturing firms expect a stable business outlook over the next six months, with only 4% anticipating an improvement. The electronics cluster, particularly semiconductors, is the most optimistic, while computer peripherals and infocomms segments foresee a decline. Biomedical firms, however, expect sustained demand for medical devices and pharmaceutical exports to remain strong.

site_title: New York's bitcoin hub dreams fade with licensing backlog
summary: New York's efforts to establish itself as a global hub for bitcoin and other virtual currencies have stalled due to a licensing backlog. The state's Department of Financial Services (DFS) had adopted trailblazing virtual currency rules in 2015, but the agency's chief left soon after, causing a delay in issuing licenses. As a result, only two BitLicenses have been issued, with 15 applications pending, and several companies have opted not to pursue a license due to the lengthy and burdensome process.

site_title: China's yuan edges up, but set for 1.5% monthly loss vs US dollar
summary: China's yuan edged up to 6.7641 per US dollar, the strongest pace in over a month, but is still expected to lose nearly 1.5% against the US dollar this month. The People's Bank of China set the daily midpoint fixing higher due to a decline in the US dollar against a basket of major currencies.

site_title: Millennial caffeine fix hunt propels record coffee demand
summary: Millennials' growing demand for coffee is driving a record-high global demand, despite tightening supplies due to drought in Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer. US demand is particularly significant, with millennials accounting for 44% of coffee consumption, and daily consumption among 18-24 year-olds rising to 48% from 34% in 2008. This trend is also observed in other major coffee consumers, including Brazil and China. As a result, hedge funds are positioning for a rally in coffee prices, with the coffee net-long holding reaching its highest level in eight years.

site_title: Japan life insurers look to diversify foreign bond holdings
summary: Japan's nine largest private life insurers plan to increase their foreign bond holdings in the second half of the fiscal year, moving beyond traditional US Treasuries and into a wider variety of credit instruments. Insurers are seeking hedged foreign bond investments, such as residential mortgage-backed securities, due to rising currency hedging costs. Nippon Life and Dai-ichi Life are shifting funds to US agency and corporate bonds, while Asahi Mutual Life plans to invest in overseas infrastructure. Currency hedging costs have soared on expectations of higher US interest rates.

site_title: Russia ousted from UN Rights Council in historic vote
summary: Russia lost its bid to retain a seat on the UN Human Rights Council in a historic vote, with 112 votes against its candidacy. The 87 human rights groups that objected to Russia's candidacy likely influenced the outcome. The vote comes amid allegations of war crimes in Syria, where Russia supports President Bashar Al-Assad's assault on Aleppo, trapping 275,000 people. Russia's rejection marks a significant rebuke, with UN Deputy Director Akshaya Kumar calling it a "historic rejection."

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelgro pares early morning losses
summary: ComfortDelGro shares initially fell 2.7% after the Public Transport Council announced a 4.2% reduction in bus and train fares from Dec 30. However, the stock recovered to S$2.52 by 10:40am, paring some losses. The stock change hands for 12.7 million shares, making it one of the top-traded stocks on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks fall for fifth straight day
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a fifth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 0.09% to 22,934.54. The decline was attributed to news that the FBI was investigating Hillary Clinton's use of private emails while secretary of state. In mainland China, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.12%. The losses were part of a broader global market trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australian PM defends proposal to permanently bar boat people
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull defended a proposal to permanently bar asylum seekers who arrive in Australia by boat from re-entering the country, despite criticism from rights lawyers that it would breach the UN Refugee Convention. The plan, which has sparked speculation about a potential US resettlement deal, has been met with opposition from human rights groups. Currently, intercepted asylum seekers are sent to processing camps in Papua New Guinea and Nauru. Turnbull's proposal has raised concerns about the treatment of asylum seekers and potential breaches of international law.

site_title: British banker's defence cites sexual disorder in Hong Kong double murder trial
summary: A British investment banker, Rurik Jutting, is on trial in Hong Kong for murdering two Indonesian women, Sumarti Ningsih and Seneng Mujiasih. Defence lawyers claim Jutting suffered from recognised disorders of sexual sadism, narcissism, and substance abuse, which led to his actions. The trial has garnered international attention, with graphic footage of Jutting's torture and abuse of the victims presented in court. Jutting has pleaded not guilty to murder on grounds of diminished responsibility, but guilty to manslaughter, which carries a maximum life sentence.

site_title: Japan factory output, retail sales flat in September
summary: Japan's factory output and retail sales remained flat in September, disappointing forecasts and pointing to tepid economic growth. Industrial output was unchanged from the previous month, while retail sales missed expectations of a 0.2% rise. The Bank of Japan is set to announce a policy decision, aiming to boost inflation to 2% through monetary easing. The stagnant economic data raises concerns over Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic revival policy, which has struggled to kickstart growth and combat deflation. Japan's third-quarter growth figures are due later this month.

site_title: Huma Abedin, Hillary Clinton's close adviser, in new email row
summary: FBI director James Comey announced a new investigation into Hillary Clinton's emails, led by Huma Abedin, her close adviser. Abedin's husband, Anthony Weiner, was previously facing sexting allegations, and Abedin was separated from him in August. Abedin has been cooperative with authorities, and her team has defended her. Abedin has worked closely with Clinton for 20 years, serving as her chief of staff and personal assistant. The renewed investigation comes 11 days before the presidential election, sparking concerns about the campaign's momentum.

site_title: Clinton embraces Trump in grisly Japan Halloween
summary: In Tokyo, Japan, Halloween celebrations drew a massive crowd of 250,000 on a Monday, with many revelers embracing the spooky spirit and dressing up in creative costumes. The festivities, which are a billion-dollar industry in Japan, saw people enjoying pumpkin-flavored drinks and desserts, as well as haunted parties and parades. A peculiar sight was seen at a Tokyo pub, where a young man, dressed as a rooster, rode a hoverboard while promoting his anti-chicken eating message. Amidst the revelry, some attendees even showed a surprising willingness to put aside politics, with one reveller offering an olive branch to Donald Trump in a rubber Hillary Clinton mask.

images.alt_text: Tokyo nursed a giant pumpkin-sized hangover Monday after a weekend of Halloween revelry which saw blood-spattered ghouls, fluffy animals and fake presidential candidates cut loose.

site_title: Iron ore stockpiles at China's ports expand to highest since '14
summary: China's iron ore stockpiles have expanded to 106.75 million metric tons, the highest level since 2014, according to Shanghai Steelhome Information Technology Co. This surge in supplies signals robust demand despite prices surging to their highest level since April. Benchmark spot ore prices have climbed 47% in 2016, with forecasters disagreeing on future price movements. Morgan Stanley warns of a deteriorating outlook, while Toronto-Dominion Bank predicts prices will reach around $55 this quarter.

site_title: OSIM wins in Court of Appeal against The Wellness Group lawsuit
summary: OSIM International has won a two-year-long court battle against The Wellness Group, with the Court of Appeal ordering the latter to pay for additional legal costs. The court dismissed The Wellness Group's claims of oppressive conduct and conspiracy, finding that the rights issue was reasonably considered by OSIM's directors and that there were justifying reasons for raising capital. The court also rejected claims that majority shareholders knew The Wellness Group would not subscribe to the rights shares. The Wellness Group has been ordered to pay the costs of the unsuccessful appeal.

site_title: Clinton fends off FBI email fallout as polls narrow
summary: Hillary Clinton battled renewed FBI focus on her emails as the US presidential election nears. The FBI announced a probe into newly discovered emails, reviving allegations of Clinton's use of a private email server while secretary of state. Clinton's campaign hit back, calling the move "deeply troubling" and criticizing Trump's handling of the issue. Despite the controversy, polls show Clinton narrowing the gap with Trump, with a one-point lead in a recent ABC News/Washington Post survey. Clinton's campaign is focusing on early voting, with over 200 million Americans registered to vote.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton battled to contain renewed FBI focus on her emails Sunday as Donald Trump blitzed western states in the tightening race for the White House.

site_title: Singapore considers measures to help struggling marine sector
summary: Singapore's government is considering measures to support the struggling marine and offshore engineering (M&OE) sector, which has been hit by a prolonged downturn in the oil market. The sector's decline has prompted analyst expectations of government stimulus for the economy. The government is studying possible measures, including government-backed loans and a new research centre, valued at S$107 million. While assistance is being considered, it cannot be a panacea, and companies can also tap into existing measures to address cash flow concerns.

images.alt_text: The Singapore government is considering whether to help the city-state's marine and offshore engineering (M&OE) sector, which is facing a prolonged downturn due to the slump in the oil market, the trade and industry minister said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore Inc faces US$12b debt scramble
summary: Singapore companies face a US$12 billion debt scramble in 2017 due to a lacklustre commodity market and slowing global trade. Over US$12.4 billion of bonds falls due, with corporate balance sheets looking strained, and more than 74 companies having net debt five times their core profit. Banks are becoming wary of lending to the resources sector, and investors are seeking to renegotiate credit terms, signaling a refinancing confidence crisis across many sectors.

site_title: Singapore Sept bank lending dips on lower manufacturing loans
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in September decreased to S$603.4 billion, down from a nine-month high of S$603.9 billion in August. This decline was attributed to lower manufacturing loans. The data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore showed a decrease in lending compared to the previous month, marking a reversal of the previous month's increase.

site_title: Honda chooses Tokyo over Silicon Valley for AI research centre
summary: Honda Motor Co. will establish a new artificial intelligence research centre in Tokyo, combining existing teams in Silicon Valley, Europe, and Japan. The decision aims to foster closer collaboration between researchers and engineers to develop AI-enabled products with consumer demand. Honda believes Japan's talent pool and existing strengths in hardware can drive commercial applications for AI technology, differing from Toyota's approach of hiring experts from Silicon Valley.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.320 points to 1676.830. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 68, and volume reached 55.045 million lots worth RM23.926 million.

site_title: Foreigners seen putting US$48 billion in China bonds next year
summary: Foreign investors are expected to significantly increase their purchases of Chinese bonds over the next two years, with central banks and supranational organizations leading the buying. According to a Bloomberg News survey, foreign investors will buy around $48 billion in Chinese bonds in 2017 and 2018, more than four times the $12 billion they invested last year. This increased investment is driven by China's growing economic influence and its potential inclusion in major bond indexes, which could bring in an additional $750 billion in inflows over the next decade.

site_title: China developers face threat of funding cost jump amid new curbs
summary: China's developers face increased financing costs due to new curbs on borrowing, which may strain access to cash and prompt builders to seek money overseas. The Shanghai Stock Exchange raised the threshold for regulated property bonds, and curbs on home sales and mortgages will likely push up dollar note yields. The real estate industry, accounting for a third of economic output, is under pressure to prevent a bubble without broader fallout. Goldman Sachs advises investors to reduce exposure to Chinese property bonds amid the increased risks.

images.alt_text: China's developers face higher financing costs after regulators stepped up efforts to rein in the borrowing that has fueled a red-hot property market.

site_title: Singapore shares open down 20.39 points on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened lower on Monday, down 20.39 points to 2,795.87, amid concerns over US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's e-mail scandal. Top losers included ComfortDelgro, Singtel, and DBS. The market saw 105.4 million shares worth S$125.1 million change hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 81 to 50.

site_title: China Evergrande lifts stake in peer Langfang to 20%
summary: China Evergrande Group has raised its stake in Langfang Development Co Ltd to 20% in a 557.8 million yuan deal, up from 15%. The stake was acquired at an average price of 29.35 yuan per share. This move follows Evergrande's aggressive investment strategy, which includes accumulating stakes in larger companies like China Vanke. The move has led to a 1.2% decrease in Evergrande's Hong Kong shares, while Langfang's Shanghai shares were halted.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall Street slips
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, following Wall Street's losses last week due to concerns over Hillary Clinton's email scandal. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.39% and the Topix index dropped 0.31%. This comes ahead of the US presidential election, which may impact global markets.

site_title: ANZ still looking to exit Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos
summary: ANZ Banking Group is considering exiting its businesses in the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos, following the sale of its wealth and retail assets in five other Asian countries to DBS Group. Chief executive Shayne Elliott made the statement, but no specific timeline has been set for the potential exit. The decision is part of ANZ's ongoing review of its international operations.

images.alt_text: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group is looking to exit businesses in the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos which were not included in the sale to DBS Group of its wealth and retail businesses in five other Asian countries, chief executive Shayne Elliott said on Monday.

site_title: Asia: Stocks stutter as FBI probe of Clinton jolts markets
summary: Asian stocks started the week on a shaky note as a renewed FBI probe of Hillary Clinton's email server sparked uncertainty, just before the US presidential election. The Japanese yen rose against the US dollar, while the MSCI Asia-Pacific index slipped 0.2%. Japan's Nikkei fell 0.6%, but remains poised for a monthly gain of 5.4%. Markets are uncertain about a potential Trump victory, which could impact US foreign policy, trade deals, and the economy.

site_title: Coal price rally comes to the rescue of commodity trading giants
summary: Coal prices have surged to more than double their June levels, benefiting commodity trading giants Glencore and Noble. The companies are taking advantage of their mine production, storage facilities, and shipping fleets to provide users with cargoes at short notice and premium prices. Glencore's decision to sell 55 million tonnes of coal forward at $53 a tonne has likely increased in loss, but the firm still made a profit due to its low production cost base. The rally has been driven by China's decision to slash its coal production, and analysts predict continued strength through the peak-demand winter months.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit near 2-week low; TSMC drops
summary: Taiwan's stocks hit a near two-week low on Monday, with the main Taiex index falling 0.75% to 9,237.76, dragged down by heavyweights like TSMC. The electronics subindex slipped 0.8% and the financials subindex lost 0.8%. The decline was also influenced by broader Asian market downturns.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks edge down as Park faces deepening crisis
summary: South Korea's won and stocks weakened Monday due to investors' concerns over President Park Geun Hye's government crisis. The won fell 0.1% to 1,145.9, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 0.4% to 2,011.16 points. Five top presidential aides resigned, including the chief of staff, amid allegations of improper influence. The US presidential election uncertainty also contributed to market volatility, with offshore investors poised to buy Kospi shares.

site_title: Australia shares tepid on Wall Street losses; NZ down
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.11% on Monday, driven by gains in material stocks, despite losses in financials and a weak close on Wall Street on Friday. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,290.5 points. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.39% due to consumer discretionary stocks. Oil prices declined, affecting energy shares, while Rio Tinto rose 1.3% after announcing its exit from a project and a rally in spot iron ore prices.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Ezra, Emas Offshore, Mencast, YuuZoo, KLW
summary: DBS Bank acquired Australia & New Zealand Banking Group's retail and wealth management businesses for S$110 million above book value. Ezra Holdings delayed its unaudited full-year results due to uncertainties over potential impairment charges. Emas Offshore Limited reported a net loss of US$98.5 million in Q3, while Mencast Holdings warned of a loss for its Q3 and nine-month results. YuuZoo Corporation Limited planned a US$50-150 million investment in an American movie studio. KLW Holdings' two independent directors resigned amid an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: AIA shares fall after some HK insurance purchases barred
summary: AIA Group Ltd shares fell 6.8% after China UnionPay Co suspended credit and debt card payments for most insurance policies in Hong Kong, amid China's crackdown on capital outflows. This move affects about half of AIA's Hong Kong sales, which are largely generated from Chinese visitors. The suspension is part of China's efforts to curb the practice of using insurance policies to move money offshore. Despite this, Chinese buyers still purchased a record HK$16.9 billion of insurance policies in the three months through June.

site_title: Gold gains on haven demand as FBI's move ripples through markets
summary: Gold prices rose as investors sought safe-haven assets amid uncertainty following the FBI's intervention in the US presidential contest. Gold surged 1.3% to its highest price since October 4, reaching US$1,284.20 an ounce. The move came after polls showed Hillary Clinton may have lost some ground to Donald Trump, fueling concern among investors. The price gain was attributed to haven demand, with bullion prices trading at US$1,277.16 in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down on Clinton worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.78% due to concerns over Hillary Clinton's email investigation, which fueled fears about her presidential election chances. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped, with the Hang Seng falling 178.93 points to 22,775.88. The decline was attributed to traders' anxiety over Clinton's prospects, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: US dollar on the back foot as FBI's move on Clinton causes a stir
summary: The US dollar slipped against a basket of six major currencies following the FBI's new probe into Hillary Clinton's private email use, causing uncertainty ahead of the US presidential election. The dollar index fell to 98.369, edging down from a near nine-month high. Despite this, the dollar is still up 3% for the month, matching its largest monthly gain this year. Markets are pricing in a 70% chance of a Federal Reserve rate hike in December, but the political development is raising uncertainty, with investors preferring to wait until after the US elections.

site_title: Mencast Holdings warns of Q3 loss
summary: Mencast Holdings, an offshore services provider, warned of a loss for its third-quarter and nine-month results due to protracted weakness in the oil and gas industry. The company attributed the decline to its offshore and engineering segments. The firm will announce its results on November 4.

site_title: Lifebrandz's auditors flag risks to its "operational existence"
summary: AUDITORS for LifeBrandz have flagged concerns over the company's operational existence due to a net current liability of S$164,000 and a net total liability of S$158,000 as of July 31, 2016. The company incurred a net loss of S$1.07 million and net operating cashflows of S$987,000 for the financial year. If funds are not raised, the group and company may be unable to continue in operational existence for the foreseeable future, according to Mazars LLP.

site_title: Qantas sees 13% profit dip as international competition bites
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd reported a 13% dip in expected underlying first-half net profit due to declines in international airfares. The airline expects profit of between A$800 million and A$850 million, down from A$921 million in the same period last year. Qantas Chief Executive Officer Alan Joyce attributed the decline to international airfare competition, citing the airline's strong domestic position and diversified loyalty business as mitigating factors.

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways Ltd, Australia's No 1 airline, said it expected underlying first-half net profit to fall up to 13 per cent as it slashes costs to cope with declines in international airfares.

site_title: South Korea Sept factory output increases 0.3% m-o-m, better than expected
summary: South Korea's industrial output increased 0.3% seasonally adjusted in September from the previous month, beating expectations. This rebounded from a 2.4% fall in August. On an annual basis, industrial output fell 2% in September after a revised 2.2% gain in August. The service sector output also declined 0.6% seasonally adjusted in September, following a 0.8% rise in August. The better-than-expected industrial output is a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: FBI move, just before election, to dampen market
summary: The Singapore stock market may experience volatility ahead of the US presidential election on November 8, with the FBI's decision to investigate Hillary Clinton's email server potentially spooking investors. The reopening of the probe raises concerns about a Trump victory, which could impact interest rates and global economic conditions. Analysts predict a low likelihood of a Fed rate hike in November, with most expecting the next hike to occur in December. Despite this, pleasant corporate earnings surprises could provide some cheer, but economic conditions remain gloomy across major industries.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says govt to infuse funds to support local shipbuilders
summary: South Korea's finance minister announced plans to support local shipbuilders by providing 6.5 trillion Korean won (S$7.89 billion) in policy financing to acquire competitive vessels. The government aims to help local shipping firms meet a minimum order of 250 vessels by 2020. This move comes after the collapse of Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd, which applied for court receivership in August. The government's support is aimed at boosting the local shipbuilding and shipping industries.

site_title: Aussie dollar steady, kiwi slips amid US election uncertainty
summary: The Australian dollar remained steady on Monday ahead of a central bank policy meeting, amid US election uncertainty. The Aussie rose 0.2% against the New Zealand dollar, while the kiwi slipped 0.2% to US$0.7152. The US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates is expected to be influenced by the outcome of the US presidential election, which may impact international trade deals and the domestic economy. Economists predict the Reserve Bank of Australia will keep interest rates unchanged, citing accommodative rates and limited benefits from a rate cut.

site_title: Oil falls as non-Opec yet to pledge concrete oil output steps
summary: Oil prices declined further on Monday as non-Opec producers failed to commit to joining Opec in limiting oil output, leaving the decision to Opec countries first. Oil prices fell 0.7% to $49.35 a barrel, with Brent crude and NYMEX crude both down 36 US cents. Russia plans to increase oil output by 0.7% next year and 0.9% in 2018, despite record-high production forecasts. The lack of concrete commitment from non-Opec producers suggests a delay in a global output limiting deal.

site_title: Directors' buying down for 5th straight week
summary: Singapore directors' buying activity fell for the fifth straight week, with a total of four companies making seven purchases worth S$1.61 million in the fourth week of October. This marks a significant decrease from the previous week, when eight companies made 14 purchases worth S$3.12 million. The selling activity remained flat, with two firms making four disposals worth S$1.31 million.

site_title: Hong Kong HK$3.54t fund weighs investing in infrastructure
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is considering investing in infrastructure to boost returns, amid low interest rates on government bonds. The HKMA's Exchange Fund, worth HK$3.54 trillion, may invest in infrastructure debt, equity, or physical assets, with potential partners including the World Bank's International Finance Corp and private equity funds. The move aims to diversify the fund's portfolio and encourage investment in projects connected to China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative, estimated to require US$8 trillion in infrastructure investments by 2020.

site_title: New Italy quake sows terror, flattens historic church
summary: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck Italy's mountainous center, flattening a 600-year-old basilica in Norcia, leaving over 3,000 people temporarily homeless. Despite no reported deaths, 20 people were injured, and many buildings are in a critical state. The quake, Italy's most powerful in 36 years, was followed by over 50 aftershocks, including some magnitude 4 and 5. Prime Minister Matteo Renzi pledged to rebuild damaged houses and ensure remote communities don't become ghost towns.

site_title: Italy reels as earthquake sows terror
summary: A powerful 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck Italy's central region on October 30, 2016, causing widespread destruction and terrorizing residents. The quake, which was Italy's most powerful in 36 years, flattened a six-century-old church and injured around a dozen people. The epicentre was located at a shallow depth, and the impact was felt in Rome and Venice. The disaster is the latest in a series of devastating quakes to hit Italy in recent months, with nearly 300 people killed in an August quake and thousands more displaced.

site_title: South Korean President Park accepts Chief of Staff's resignation
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye accepted her chief of staff's resignation amid a public outcry over an influence-peddling scandal. The scandal involves allegations that Park's friend, Choi Soon Sil, meddled in state affairs. Park also accepted resignations of four other chief secretaries and apologized for consulting Choi on documents. The ruling party plans to seek a coalition government with parliamentary cabinet appointment power. Choi apologized and agreed to cooperate with investigators, but opposition parties called for an immediate arrest. Park named new chief advisers and plans to appoint other secretaries soon.

site_title: US campaign coverage a boon to cable networks
summary: US cable networks, including CNN, Fox News, and MSNBC, are expected to reap unprecedented profits this year due to nearly round-the-clock campaign coverage of the presidential election. CNN is projected to reach $1 billion in gross profit, while Fox News is expected to top $1.67 billion. MSNBC is growing faster in percentage terms, with a 19% growth rate, and its daily audience has averaged 597,000 viewers. The networks' focus on political coverage has led to improved ratings, with some critics arguing that excessive coverage contributed to Donald Trump's Republican nomination.

site_title: US polls narrow as Clinton grapples with email fallout
summary: The US presidential election between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump narrowed to a one-point lead for Clinton, with 46-45% in a four-way race, according to an ABC News/Washington Post poll. Clinton's campaign was jolted by a renewed FBI probe into her emails, with FBI boss James Comey announcing a review of newly discovered emails. Clinton and her campaign pushed back against the controversy, while Trump seized on the issue to deflect attention from his own scandal. The polls come just nine days before the election.

images.alt_text: The race for the White House narrowed noticeably on Sunday as Hillary Clinton sought to shake off a renewed FBI probe of her emails and Donald Trump blitzed western states nine days ahead of the vote.

site_title: Musk adds solar roofs to his clean energy vision
summary: Elon Musk unveiled new energy products from Tesla and SolarCity, combining electric cars, batteries, and solar panels. The products include solar-powered roof tiles and a longer-lasting home battery called the Powerwall. Musk aims to sell a fossil fuel-free lifestyle to consumers, citing the need for a seamless and integrated solution. The rollout is expected next summer, but analysts have questioned the deal's synergies, with some suggesting Tesla is trying to rescue money-losing SolarCity.

site_title: Australia's ANZ Bank requests trading halt ahead of Asia update
summary: Australia's ANZ Bank has requested a trading halt ahead of an update on a review of its retail and wealth business in Asia. The bank, which has been lowering its exposure to Asia over the past year, is due to release its annual financial results on November 3, which will include A$360 million in one-off charges. This move comes as ANZ has been reviewing its Asia operations and has been impacted by changes in its software capitalisation policy and employee termination payments.

images.alt_text: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) requested a trading halt on Monday, saying it planned to update the market on a review of its retail and wealth business in Asia.

site_title: DBS Q3 net profit at S$1.071b, buys ANZ's wealth, retail units in 5 Asian countries
summary: DBS Group reported a net profit of S$1.071 billion for the third quarter of 2016, driven by higher income and lower expenses. The bank also announced plans to acquire ANZ's wealth management and retail banking businesses in five Asian markets for S$110 million above book value, representing total deposits of S$17 billion. The transaction is expected to be return on equity and earnings accretive one year after completion, with a target for full completion in all markets by early 2018.

images.alt_text: (From left to right) Ms Pearlyn Phau, DBS Bank's deputy group head of consumer banking & wealth management, Ms Tan Su Shan, DBS Bank's group head of consumer banking & wealth management; Mr Piyush Gupta, DBS Group CEO with Mr David Hisco, ANZ group executive of Asia retail and wealth and Mr Sanjoy Sen, ANZ managing director of retail banking, Asia Pacific.

site_title: UBS faces possible suspension from IPO underwriting
summary: UBS Group AG may face fines and suspension from arranging Hong Kong initial public offerings due to its work on some IPOs. The Securities and Futures Commission has initiated an investigation, which could result in "financial ramifications" for UBS, including fines and restitution orders. This comes after Hong Kong tightened oversight of IPO underwriters following accounting scandals involving Chinese companies. UBS, once the top IPO underwriter, slipped to 20th this year, with Chinese firms dominating the market.

images.alt_text: UBS Group AG said it could be fined and suspended from arranging Hong Kong initial public offerings as the city's securities regulator moves to punish the Swiss bank for its work on some IPOs.

site_title: Oil's plunge dents prospects for Scottish independence
summary: Scotland's prospects for independence have been dented by the plunge in oil prices, which has led to a significant decline in tax revenue. The North Sea oil industry, a crucial factor in Scotland's economy, has been in long-term decline, with production peaking in 1999 and declining sharply since. This has resulted in job losses and a worsening public spending deficit, making it less likely that Scotland will achieve economic independence. The First Minister Nicola Sturgeon's commitment to a second independence referendum now seems uncertain.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton beats Rosberg in Mexico, keeps title bid alive
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his second consecutive win in the Mexican Grand Prix, beating Mercedes teammate Nico Rosberg by a 19-point margin with two races remaining in the season. The victory, Hamilton's eighth of the season, was marred by controversy, including a five-second penalty for Max Verstappen after a clash with Sebastian Vettel. Hamilton's win kept his title bid alive, with Rosberg needing a win in the Brazilian Grand Prix to clinch the championship.

site_title: Brexit brings on inflation fears while Remain camp protests
summary: The UK's barometer of consumer confidence fell by 2 points in October to minus 3, citing pessimism about the economy over the next year. Fears of inflation, exacerbated by the pound's 16% slide since June, have dampened consumer confidence. Consumer prices rose 1% in the year to September, the highest inflation rate since November 2014. Experts predict inflation will rise above the Bank of England's 2% target, squeezing household spending power. The Remain camp protests Brexit, with former PM Tony Blair calling it a "catastrophe."

site_title: Nurturing future leaders
summary: Hwa Chong Institution, a Singaporean school, stands out for its innovative approach to education, with a focus on empowering staff, fostering research and innovation, and developing global networks. The school has achieved 48 global accolades, including 24 world championship titles, and has been recognized with the Singapore Quality Award. With a strong emphasis on critical thinking and problem-solving, Hwa Chong Institution aims to nurture future leaders capable of addressing global challenges.

images.alt_text: HCI differentiates itself from other top educational institutes through a unique and personalised curriculum that nurtures critical thinkers and problem-solvers.

site_title: YuuZoo to invest up to US$150m in US film group
summary: YuuZoo Corporation Limited plans to invest between US$50 million and US$150 million in Relativity Holdings LLC, a US film studio that recently exited bankruptcy. In return, YuuZoo will receive a 33.3% stake in the company and all its film, television, sport, fashion, and music assets for distribution on its platform. The investment is part of YuuZoo's strategy to add high-quality media content to its social e-commerce platform.

site_title: Applications beyond games and amusement
summary: Virtual reality (VR) technology is expanding beyond gaming and entertainment, with applications in various fields such as education, travel, and medicine. VR experiences can provide immersive learning, allow travelers to explore destinations virtually, and aid in medical diagnosis and training. Theme parks are also incorporating VR coasters, while travel companies are using VR to market destinations. Additionally, VR and augmented reality (AR) are being used in medical treatment, education, and trading, with potential to disrupt traditional industries like advertising.

site_title: Fostering a spirit of discovery
summary: The National Library Board (NLB) aims to enhance library spaces for learning and collaboration, promoting self-discovery and learning through a self-service model. The NLB plans to increase digital reach and support self-directed learning through digital channels. Strategic partnerships and citizen engagement encourage knowledge sharing and appreciation of Singapore's history. Innovative initiatives, such as the Blackbox competition, drive innovation within the organisation, resulting in better services and content.

site_title: Singapore food courts are ground zero in productivity revolution
summary: Singapore is implementing a productivity revolution in its food courts, particularly at Changi Airport, by introducing automated systems such as self-service machines and vending systems. The goal is to increase productivity by 2% annually over the next five years, as the city-state grapples with a rapidly aging population and falling fertility rates. The move aims to reduce labor costs and increase efficiency, but may result in job losses. Authorities are preparing citizens for potential job losses, while the government sees this as a key component of plans to boost productivity in the food industry.

site_title: OCBC Bank integrates e-payment with Apple's Siri, iMessage
summary: OCBC Bank has integrated its e-payment services with Apple's Siri and iMessage, allowing customers to send money using voice commands and messaging. The feature, available on iOS 10 and the latest OCBC Mobile Banking app, uses mobile banking credentials for security. Since increasing the daily transfer limit to $1,000, e-payment transactions have risen 250%. The bank expects a multi-fold increase in e-payments and plans to add more payment channels. This move aims to embed banking services into customers' everyday lives, making transactions frictionless.

site_title: Non-Opec producers stay non-committal after meeting Opec
summary: Non-Opec oil producers met in Vienna on Saturday, but made no specific commitment to join Opec in limiting oil output. The meeting was a "positive development" towards a global output limiting deal on November 30, but Opec members themselves disagree on how to implement the deal, with Iran refusing to freeze its output. The deal aims to prop up oil prices, currently trading near US$50 a barrel, and comes after Opec agreed to modest production cuts in Algeria last month.

images.alt_text: Last month, Opec agreed at a meeting in Algeria to very modest production cuts, its first since 2008, in an effort to help prop up prices. But the cuts have yet to be finalised.

site_title: WhatsApp, Yahoo come under scrutiny of EU data protection authorities
summary: EU data protection authorities have warned WhatsApp over sharing user information with parent company Facebook, and cautioned Yahoo over a 2014 data breach and US intelligence scanning of customer e-mail. WhatsApp's new privacy policy has attracted scrutiny, with the Italian antitrust watchdog launching a separate probe into the sharing of personal data with Facebook. The EU's Article 29 Working Party has requested WhatsApp stop sharing data with Facebook until "appropriate legal protections" are assured. The watchdogs have also asked Yahoo to communicate the details of the 2014 data breach and cooperate with investigations.

site_title: Raising their game
summary: The Business Excellence (BE) initiative, launched in 1994, has helped thousands of local organisations assess their performance and improve it using an internationally benchmarked framework. The framework, reviewed regularly to reflect leading-edge management practices, enables organisations to capture growth opportunities and achieve higher performance. Companies such as Prime Structures Engineering and Kino Biotech have benefited from the programme, using it to challenge their in-house wisdom, foster innovation, and achieve business growth goals. The repositioned SQC as a single mark of excellence aims to gain customer trust and drive growth.

images.alt_text: Prime Structures Engineering staff at their annual off-site retreat where they review and refine the company's processes for the year ahead.

site_title: Taking a walk with the stars on court
summary: Twenty-two lucky children from Singapore were given the opportunity to walk out with top tennis stars at the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore. The children, aged 6-11, were selected through a social media contest and accompanied players such as Agnieszka Radwanska and Garbine Muguruza. The event, now in its second year, is part of a partnership between Tag International Tennis Academy and OCBC Bank. The tournament, held at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, featured the top eight singles players and doubles teams, with the top prize of US$7 million.

site_title: Dominant Dominika trounces Kerber in style
summary: Dominika Cibulkova won the WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global, defeating world No. 1 Angelique Kerber in straight sets, 6-3, 6-4. Cibulkova's dominant performance earned her the biggest title of her career, including the Billie Jean King trophy, $7 million in prize money, and a career-high world No. 5 ranking. The Slovakian's impressive serve and determination gave her the edge over the more experienced Kerber, who was coming off a stellar season.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Big 5 China banks post flat Q3 profits as they clean up bad loans
summary: China's top five banks reported flat third-quarter profits as they worked to clean up bad loans. The banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, Bank of China, and Bank of Communications, saw modest profit growth, with four of the five reporting a decline in net interest margins due to interest rate cuts and new tax rules. Non-performing loan ratios stabilized at the "Big Five" banks, but analysts predict bad debt formation will continue to grow. China reopened the bad loan securitization market in May to help banks clean up soured debt, with several banks issuing securities backed by non-performing loans.

site_title: Qantas plane with new livery lands in S'pore
summary: Qantas' new livery, designed by Marc Newson, made its international debut in Singapore at Changi Airport, featuring a modern look with a new typeface and the addition of the red Flying Kangaroo on the engine. The livery will be progressively rolled out on Qantas' Boeing 787 and the rest of its fleet next year. This marks the first international port of call for the new design, which was overseen by Qantas design consultant Marc Newson and Australian design agency Houston Group.

site_title: People power
summary: The Defence Science and Technology Agency (DSTA) in Singapore has implemented a staff development framework to foster a culture of open conversations and personalized career growth. The agency has achieved superior performance, resulting in the People Excellence Award at the Business Excellence Awards. DSTA's efforts include multiple career opportunities, integrated learning and development, and robust competency and leadership development. A unique traffic-light system allows staff to request posting changes and facilitates candid discussions between staff and supervisors, leading to fruitful results and a meaningful career for all employees.

images.alt_text: Mr Tan says: "Our strategy on developing and retaining talent in DSTA is anchored on providing a meaningful and rewarding career for all staff."

site_title: China puts its stamp on Georgia's economy
summary: China is investing heavily in Georgia's economy through the Tbilisi Sea New City project, a $1 billion development that includes 27 towers, a hotel, and a shopping center. The project, led by Hualing Group Georgia, is part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, a multibillion-dollar plan to expand its economic presence in the Caucasus region. The project has created jobs for Georgians and introduced Chinese-style economics to the country, despite initial doubts about its wisdom. The venture is expected to start making money within five years and is seen as a key part of China's efforts to expand its influence in the region.

site_title: Ezra seeks more time to announce full-year results
summary: Ezra Holdings' associate company Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Bhd faces financial trouble, with a notice from OCBC Al-Amin Bank Berhad for a loan default and a winding up petition by a bondholder. Perisai has defaulted on S$125 million worth of bonds, and Ezra is seeking more time to announce its unaudited full-year results due to uncertainties over impairment charges. Emas Offshore, a subsidiary of Ezra, has also posted a net loss for the fourth quarter, while the group is in talks with a financial institution to secure financing for debt restructuring.

site_title: China box office will dwarf Hollywood: Ang Lee
summary: Ang Lee predicts China's film market will surpass the US box office in a few years, dwarfing it in the years to come. China's box office is projected to rise from $4.3 billion in 2014 to $8.9 billion in 2019, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers. Hollywood studios are capitalizing on the market through partnerships with Chinese companies, such as Wanda's acquisition of Legendary Entertainment for $3.5 billion. Beijing aims to increase China's "soft power" by investing in Hollywood through such deals.

images.alt_text: Two-time Oscar winner Lee (right) receiving the John Schlesinger Britannia Award for excellence in directing from Gyllenhaal.

site_title: 2 China banks' bad-loan buffer below par
summary: China's two largest banks, ICBC and China Construction Bank, have reported loan-loss coverage ratios below the regulatory minimum of 150% due to increased bad loans. Despite the regulator's tolerance, banks may eventually face penalties for failing to meet the requirement. ICBC's ratio stands at 136.1%, while China Construction Bank's is 148.8%. The banking regulator has resisted pressure from lenders to lower the minimum ratio, and may take more serious action if the issue persists.

site_title: A world of difference
summary: Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) technologies allow users to experience new environments through high-resolution graphics and advanced devices. VR involves a goggle-type display that immerses users in a virtual space, while AR overlays computer graphics onto the real world, allowing for user mobility. Key features of VR include high-performance displays and the use of motion sensors, whereas AR utilizes computer graphics to appear as real images within real spaces.

images.alt_text: Children playing the AR game "Pokemon Go"; in AR, users view images and information while remaining aware of the real-world space.

site_title: Growing the culture of giving at Courts
summary: Courts Asia Limited, a Singaporean retailer, emphasizes community service as part of its corporate culture. The company, which has served the community for 42 years, supports various causes, including family-oriented initiatives. Under CEO Terry O'Connor, Courts incorporates employee bonding and charity outreach into its philanthropic efforts, resulting in positive impacts on its corporate culture and the community. The company's efforts have led to recognition, including the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre's President's Award for Philanthropy in 2014.

images.alt_text: Stan Kim (in blue), country CEO of Courts Singapore, presenting Mr Raghavan with a rice cooker and an oven, fulfilling his wish to host his family and friends with a Raya-ready home.

site_title: There's worse to come for Singapore's rigbuilders
summary: Singapore's rigbuilders, Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, face a tough fourth quarter due to the prolonged downturn in crude oil prices. Analysts warn of potential provisions and impairments, and few contract wins in the next few years. Both companies have announced significant job cuts, with Keppel's direct workforce reduced by 3,080 and SembMarine's layoffs totaling nearly 8,000. Earnings are expected to be near the bottom, with analysts noting that the industry outlook remains tough due to oversupply of rigs and offshore vessels.

site_title: Updating a roadmap for excellence
summary: Six Singapore organisations, including Hwa Chong Institution and the Maritime & Port Authority of Singapore, were awarded for their business excellence under Spring Singapore's Business Excellence (BE) framework. The awards, administered by the SQA Governing Council and managed by Spring, aim to provide a roadmap to achieving outstanding results. The winners demonstrated outstanding management practices, including visionary leadership, innovation, and customer service, and will join the ranks of 106 past winners. The BE framework will be refreshed to address an evolving commercial landscape, with a greater focus on people development and innovation capabilities.

site_title: After rally, emerging market bonds no longer cheap
summary: Emerging market bonds, which rallied in 2016, are no longer considered cheap, according to asset managers. Optimists point to strengthening fundamentals, receding fears of a China crash, and strong demand. However, spreads remain relatively wide, with EM government debt trading at 350 basis points above US Treasuries. Experts, such as Abbas Ameli-Renani and Owi Ruivivar, believe spreads can narrow to 250 basis points, indicating EM bonds are becoming more expensive. Despite pricey valuations, strong demand for Asian bonds persists, driven by external concerns and Chinese investors seeking to hedge against yuan depreciation.

site_title: Opportunities amid the downturn
summary: ABN AMRO Country Executive Hans Hanegraaf discusses the economic outlook for businesses and industries in Singapore, noting the shift towards a knowledge-based economy. Amid slow global growth and volatile markets, the bank is focusing on building intellectual capital and fintech capabilities to stay competitive. Hanegraaf emphasizes the need for agility and innovation to meet changing customer demands and create value for digitally savvy clients, balancing technological advancements with personal relationships in private banking.

site_title: US$ tumbles on FBI probe into Clinton's e-mail
summary: The US dollar tumbled against major currencies due to renewed uncertainty over the outcome of the presidential election, particularly with the FBI's review of Hillary Clinton's e-mail use. The dollar hit a three-week high against the Mexican peso but fell against the euro and yen. Analysts attributed the losses to uncertainty over a Trump victory, which could impact US foreign policy, international trade, and the domestic economy.

site_title: Wall Street looks beyond elite college degrees for coders
summary: Wall Street is shifting its focus from elite college degrees to objective coding skills, as the banking industry evaluates programmers based on measurable abilities rather than pedigree. A 30-year-old former shipping clerk, Gregory Furlong, was hired by JPMorgan Chase after completing a coding boot camp, showcasing the potential for non-traditional candidates to succeed in the tech industry. This trend suggests a new era of meritocracy in the tech world, where skills and performance take precedence over educational background.

site_title: Upholding a common set of values
summary: DBS Bank, headquartered in Singapore, attributes its business excellence to good leadership and a unique approach to banking "the Asian way." The bank's corporate values, represented by PRIDE, drive common behaviors among employees. CEO Piyush Gupta's vision and strategic priorities, such as embracing a digital strategy, have contributed to the bank's success. DBS differentiates itself from global competitors by understanding and adapting to Asia's cultural nuances. The bank's goal is to integrate banking into customers' everyday lives, making it simpler and more time-efficient. This approach has enabled DBS to become a leading financial services group in Asia.

site_title: Developing a nation of lifesavers
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) is leveraging innovation to enhance its operational effectiveness. Virtual reality, robotics, and data analytics are being utilized to improve response times and efficiency. SCDF Commissioner Eric Yap emphasizes the organization's commitment to its 2025 Vision of "A Nation of Lifesavers." This transformation journey aims to utilize innovation as a key enabler, propelling the SCDF towards its goal of fostering a nation of lifesavers.

site_title: Exxon may see biggest reserves reduction as slump persists
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp warned it may face the largest reserves revision in its history due to a prolonged slump in energy markets. The company's production sank to a seven-year low, and profit slid amid low energy prices. Approximately 3.6 billion barrels of reserves in the Canadian oil sands and 1 billion barrels of oil in other North American fields may be at risk, equivalent to 19% of Exxon's reserves. This would be the largest de-booking since the 1999 merger.

site_title: 1MDB case: ex-BSI banker's trial in Singapore kicks off
summary: The trial of former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei has begun in Singapore, connected to the 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) money trail. The nine-day trial, starting October 31, involves allegations of money laundering, cheating, and forgery, with prosecutors claiming Yeo played a central role in moving $3.5 billion to $4 billion in illicit funds. Yeo faces 11 charges, including perverting the course of justice, and has been held in custody since April. The trial is part of a massive-scale probe into 1MDB funds spanning six jurisdictions, including Switzerland and the US.

site_title: Private again, OSIM gets down to business
summary: OSIM International, a Singaporean health and wellness group, has become private again after delisting in 2000. Founder and CEO Ron Sim aims to strengthen corporate structures and grow the group's brands, focusing on lifestyle, well-being, and healthcare businesses. With the removal of listing obligations, Sim can now devote undivided attention to growth, potentially expanding the group's reach and increasing revenue. The company will maintain its core business while embracing digital disruption and exploring opportunities in China and other markets.

site_title: IoT integration improving Singapore's education sector
summary: IoT integration is transforming Singapore's education sector by providing a smarter learning experience. The use of technology, such as smart classrooms, video-conferencing, and online learning resources, is increasing efficiency and engagement. The Ministry of Education's fourth masterplan focuses on utilizing ICT to empower students to be future-ready and responsible digital learners. Institutions are investing in infrastructure to facilitate infocomm technology-enabled education, including robotics, smart classes, and 24×7 connectivity.
