The integration of IoT is expected to improve the quality of education, allowing for more personalized learning and seamless collaboration among teachers and students.

site_title: American Airlines plane engine flings debris in rare failure
summary: An American Airlines Boeing 767 experienced a rare uncontained engine failure seconds before takeoff at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, causing debris to be flung 800 meters from the scene. The General Electric CF6 engine, used on the 1980s or 1990s model, failed due to internal parts breaching the protective housing. The incident resulted in minor injuries to one flight attendant and 19 passengers, with flames under the wing and smoke entering the cabin. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the cause of the failure, which is the third uncontained GE engine failure in over a year.

site_title: Singapore dollar perpetuals soar amid global hunt for yield
summary: Singapore dollar perpetuals have surged in value, with AusNet Services' 5.5% perpetual bond reaching a record price of 108.1, offering a 8.1% return since its March sale. The market's performance is attributed to investors seeking high-quality credits with high yields, particularly from systemically important Singapore domiciled companies or well-recognized foreign companies. The overall SGD bond market has outperformed globally, with most perpetuals sold over the past year being strong credits. However, some issuers, such as Hyflux, have underperformed, and market experts warn that investors should be selective when investing in perpetual bonds.

site_title: Future of virtual and augmented reality
summary: Future virtual and augmented reality technologies are expected to evolve significantly over the next decade, potentially enabling the recreation of human senses and consciousness in virtual environments. Current advancements in VR and AR devices will lead to immersive experiences, interactive virtual settings, and life-like computer graphics. Applications in leisure and entertainment, such as sports and concerts, are also anticipated. The convergence of VR and AR is expected to transform human lifestyles and may lead to a decline in material possessions and the importance of physical objects. The technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, including commerce, business, and communication.

site_title: Two independent directors quit KLW
summary: Two independent directors, Lim Jit Siew and Nicholas Jeyaraj, have resigned from KLW Holdings effective October 28, amid an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department. Lim joined in October last year, while Nicholas left due to increased work commitments. The departures follow the resignation of group CEO Quek Chek Lan and breaches of Catalist rules by former managing director Lee Boon Teck and financial controller Jaslin Gaw. The company's board will be reconstituted with new members, with Chan Ka Kin Kevin and Lim Han Siang Peter taking over the remuneration and audit committees, respectively.

site_title: EMAS Offshore takes impairment on Perisai shares; posts Q4 loss of US$98.5m
summary: EMAS Offshore Limited reported a net loss of US$98.5 million in its fourth quarter, primarily due to a US$56 million impairment charge and higher cost of sales. Revenue declined 4% to US$52.2 million. The firm warned that further adjustments may be needed due to still-developing events surrounding associate company Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Berhad. For the full year, EMAS recorded a net loss of US$265.3 million, with revenue falling 32% to US$167.6 million. The market environment remains "extremely challenging" for the offshore services provider.

site_title: Time Warner deal is peak of ambitious climb for AT&T chief
summary: AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson is pursuing his most ambitious deal yet, a $85.4 billion takeover of Time Warner, creating the world's largest media company. This move follows his previous acquisitions, including the $49 billion DirecTV deal, which aimed to vertically integrate the company into content and distribution. Critics argue that this deal could lead to reduced competition and increased control over content, while Stephenson believes it will drive innovation and change the game for the media industry.

site_title: Achieving adequate and effective board diversity
summary: A recent article emphasizes the importance of achieving adequate and effective board diversity in corporate governance. While often associated with gender diversity, board diversity encompasses various aspects, including skills, experience, and knowledge. To ensure effective decision-making, boards should strive for a diverse range of thinking, including different perspectives, ages, and backgrounds. This diversity should be harnessed as a means to an end, rather than an end in itself, and should be carefully considered in the context of the company's business strategy. Ultimately, a diverse board that achieves a balance between challenge and teamwork is essential for delivering better outcomes.

images.alt_text: The Wall Street Journal discovered that, while the median age of the directors of S&P 500 companies is 63, the median age of Facebook's board is considerably younger at 46.

site_title: Bond traders suffer worst rout in 3 years
summary: Bonds worldwide suffered a 2.9% loss in October, the worst rout in three years, amid speculation that central banks are curbing monetary stimulus. European markets led the losses, with signs of accelerating inflation and economic growth sparking concerns that the European Central Bank and its counterparts will limit asset purchases. This has led to investors abandoning long-term bond trades, with yields reaching record highs for major economies, including 1.31% for 10-year gilts and 0.217% for German bonds.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust sets up S$1b debt issuance programme
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has established a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with DBS Bank and ANZ Banking Group serving as joint arrangers and dealers. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings, investing in potential opportunities, working capital, and general corporate purposes. The programme was launched on October 28.

site_title: UnionPay cards said barred for some HK insurance purchases
summary: UnionPay cards are barred for some Hong Kong insurance purchases, excluding accident and medical coverage. The move follows China's crackdown on mainlanders buying insurance in Hong Kong to circumvent capital controls. Regulators aim to curb the practice of using credit cards to move money abroad, with Capital outflows from China reaching $1 trillion last year. UnionPay issued guidance to reiterate rules and prevent single-card use for multiple transactions, with a US$5,000 cap per transaction.

site_title: Duterte's triangular diplomacy has risks and possible rewards
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's recent Asian swing has significantly raised the country's regional and international profile, potentially providing economic and strategic advantages. During his visits to China and Japan, Duterte employed strong anti-US rhetoric, bluntness, and profanity, but also managed to secure financial and assistance deals from both countries. The agreements, including a temporary reprieve on a South China Sea ruling, have bolstered Manila's position against Beijing and Washington, while also revealing the ability of a minor power to play off major powers against each other.

images.alt_text: Mr Duterte was able to exploit the rivalry between China and the US - and also that between Japan and the US - to the Philippines' advantage, and to leverage Manila's position among them all.

site_title: UK informed of Nissan plant closure risks after Brexit: source
summary: Nissan Motor Co. has informed the UK government that it may close its Sunderland plant if it fails to secure investment for new car models after Brexit. The company made this statement during private discussions with the government, citing the potential impact of tariffs on investment. The plant employs over 7,000 people and supports 28,000 supplier jobs. The UK government has denied making any special deals with Nissan, but Labour lawmakers are calling for transparency on the government's commitments to the automotive industry.

site_title: Spain ends 10-month political crisis
summary: Spain has ended its 10-month political crisis with Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy winning a parliamentary confidence vote. Rajoy's Popular Party won 170 votes, while 111 lawmakers voted against him and 68 from the Socialist party abstained. The decision was made after the Socialist party opted to abstain rather than face early elections. Rajoy has vowed to continue his economic policies despite criticism and opposition, including rising separatist sentiment in Catalonia. The outcome sets the stage for a new government, with Rajoy expected to announce the composition on Thursday.

site_title: Brazil mutant mosquitoes to breed out diseases
summary: Scientists in Brazil are releasing genetically modified mosquitoes to control tropical diseases. British firm Oxitec's mosquitoes will mate with ordinary species, producing offspring with a fatal genetic flaw. The goal is to "breed out" diseases such as Zika, dengue, and yellow fever. The mosquitoes will be released in large numbers, with no expected long-term environmental impact. This method, known as "gene drive," aims to reduce disease transmission and protect public health.

site_title: The Business Excellence framework
summary: The Business Excellence (BE) framework consists of four standards and certification programs based on seven dimensions of excellence: Leadership, Planning, Information, People, Processes, Customers, and Results. The standards focus on management capabilities in people, innovation, or service, and organizations can use any of the four standards to enhance their capabilities. To be certified, organizations must achieve a minimum of 400 points out of 1,000 points.

site_title: Stitching up a broken SMG
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has made a remarkable recovery, swinging to the black for the first half of the year. The group's new owners, led by CEO Beng Teck Liang, implemented a three-year plan to mend the business after it was "haemorrhaging" and "very broken" in 2013. SMG's recovery is seen as an example of Kintsugi, the Japanese art of mending broken pottery, which appreciates beauty in things broken. The group's turnaround is attributed to its "good bones" and a focus on adding "meat" to its business.

site_title: Uber loses UK legal battle over drivers' rights
summary: Uber has lost a UK legal battle over drivers' rights, with a Central London Employment Tribunal ruling in favor of two drivers who claimed they should receive holiday and sick pay and be paid the national minimum wage. The GMB union said the decision could have "major" implications for around 30,000 drivers across England and Wales. The ruling could have repercussions across the "gig economy."

site_title: Charting a course for success
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has successfully developed a world-class maritime centre, achieving top spot in the Pro-Enterprise Ranking Survey for five consecutive years. Recent initiatives include the development of a skilled workforce pipeline, major industry initiatives, and a Safety@Sea Campaign. MPA's close partnership with stakeholders has contributed to its global recognition, including winning the Singapore Quality Award. The authority has also promoted maritime innovation and technology, and is building the Next-Generation Port in Tuas, which will double its current capacity.

site_title: Angola state-owned oil firm mirrors nation's troubles
summary: Angola's state-owned oil firm Sonangol is facing a national economic crisis, symbolizing the country's troubles. The company, once a major driver of Angola's growth after the 2002 civil war, is struggling to pay its bills due to falling oil prices. Sonangol has issued statements admitting delays in payments and has obtained loans from China, but faces concerns over transparency and loan conditions. The company's woes reflect broader issues in Angola, where a small elite has benefited from the country's boom years, leaving much of the population in poverty.

site_title: Colombia central bank holds interest rate steady as inflation remains high
summary: Colombia's central bank held its benchmark interest rate steady at 7.75% for a third month, aiming to curb high inflation despite slowing economic growth. Policymakers sought to ease inflationary pressure amid a slump in crude oil prices. The bank reduced its economic growth estimate for the year to 2% from 2.3%. The decision aims to maintain price stability despite the country's economic challenges.

site_title: YuuZoo to invest US$50m-150m for stake in US entertainment group Relativity
summary: YuuZoo Corporation Limited plans to invest between US$50 million and US$150 million for a 33.3% stake in US entertainment group Relativity Holdings LLC. The investment will be in the form of class A preferred shares and includes distribution of Relativity's film, television, and music assets on YuuZoo's platform. The proposed investment aligns with YuuZoo's strategy to add high-quality media content and online payment capabilities. Relativity, founded in 2008, has produced or financed over 200 movies generating over US$17 billion in worldwide box office revenue.

site_title: US challenges China's imports of North Korean coal amid UN sanctions
summary: China's imports of North Korean coal contradict global sanctions, a US official stated. China initially banned coal imports in April but made exemptions for deliveries intended for "livelihood purposes." The US claims China has reversed the burden of proof, allowing coal exports to go to the North Korean weapons program. China imported $1 billion worth of North Korean coal in 2015, providing a crucial lifeline for the country. The US is urging China to pressure North Korea over its nuclear program, citing China's leverage over the country.

site_title: Tesla Motors unveils solar roof tiles, longer-lasting batteries
summary: Tesla Motors unveiled new energy products, including solar roof tiles that eliminate the need for traditional panels and longer-lasting batteries, as part of its vision for a fossil fuel-free lifestyle. CEO Elon Musk showcased the products at the Universal Studios theme park, emphasizing their need to be beautiful, affordable, and seamlessly integrated. The products aim to combine Tesla's electric cars and batteries with SolarCity's solar installation services, but analysts have questioned the deal's synergies and potential financial motivations. A vote on the acquisition is scheduled for November 17.

site_title: The US presidential election: a how-to guide
summary: The US presidential election will take place on November 8, 2016, with the winner determined by the popular vote in each state. The electoral college, comprising 538 members, will officially elect the president and vice-president on December 19. To win, a candidate must secure 270 electoral votes. Key battleground states, such as Florida, Pennsylvania, and Ohio, will play a crucial role in determining the outcome, with voters also electing representatives to Congress, governors, and participating in local elections.

site_title: More trouble for Ezra's Malaysia associate firm Perisai
summary: Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Bhd, a Malaysian associate firm of debt-laden Ezra Holdings, is facing further trouble. SJR Marine, a 51% subsidiary of Perisai, has received a notice to repay US$20.5 million in loan within 14 days after defaulting on a loan. Perisai has also received a winding up petition for S$15 million bonds and declared itself insolvent after defaulting on S$125 million bonds. The company is seeking legal advice and monitoring the impact on its group, Ezra and Emas Offshore.

site_title: Queensland theme parks face safety blitz after four deaths
summary: Queensland's theme parks, operated by Village Roadshow Ltd, will undergo a month-long safety blitz following a fatal accident at Dreamworld. Safety auditors and engineers will inspect amusement rides at six parks, including Wet'n'Wild, Sea World, and Movie World, starting Saturday. The audits will check ride safety, operator training, and maintenance records. The initiative aims to restore public confidence in the state's tourism assets ahead of the busy Christmas holiday season. The audits will be completed by the end of November.

site_title: Clinton 'confident' new emails will not change initial FBI probe
summary: Hillary Clinton expressed confidence that newly discovered emails will not change the FBI's original conclusion that she should not face charges. Clinton stated, "I'm confident (that) whatever they are will not change the conclusion reached in July." The FBI, led by Director James Comey, has not yet explained the significance of the new emails. Clinton emphasized the importance of transparency and called for the FBI to provide a clear explanation without delay.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton said Friday she was "confident" that the FBI's review of newly discovered emails related to her use of a private server will not change the bureau's original conclusion that she should not face charges.

site_title: FedEx plane catches fire at airport in Fort Lauderdale, Florida
summary: A FedEx DC-10 cargo plane experienced a fire at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport in Florida on Friday. The landing gear collapsed, but the pilots were safe. Video footage shows the plane intact with the fire near the tail section. Firefighters quickly extinguished the blaze, and the airport is currently closed. The incident is currently under investigation by the US Federal Aviation Administration.

site_title: UIC's Q3 profit hurt by lower revenues from JV projects
summary: United Industrial Corporation (UIC) reported a 2% drop in net profit to S$64m in Q3 2016, despite strong revenue growth. The company attributed the decline to lower revenues from its joint venture projects, particularly Thomson Three and Archipelago. UIC expects office rental rates to soften due to increased supply in the Central Business District and a weak private residential market. The company also expects cautious spending and a competitive hotel sector.

site_title: My favourite album
summary: Joy Division's debut album "Unknown Pleasures" (1979) is a classic, thanks to its iconic cover designed by Peter Saville, who went on to design the England football strip and art direct ads for Dior.

site_title: On Wall St, US election looms larger than Fed
summary: The US stock market is on edge as the presidential election approaches, overshadowing the Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting. The FBI is reviewing fresh evidence in its probe of Hillary Clinton's email server, causing stocks to drop sharply. Despite expectations of a low chance of interest rate hikes this week, investors are wary of the potential for a surprise from the Fed. The jobs report on Friday could influence the Fed's decision, with economists expecting 175,000 job gains. The market is uncertain, with some fearing a post-election relief followed by Fed-related worries.

images.alt_text: On Friday news came that the FBI is reviewing fresh evidence in its probe of Mrs Clinton's e-mail server. That briefly pushed stocks down sharply and drove the CBOE Volatility Index to a two-week high.

site_title: EU and Canada to sign trade deal after Belgian drama
summary: The European Union and Canada will sign the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) on Sunday after a last-minute deal was reached with Belgium's French-speaking region of Wallonia, which had threatened to block the deal. The agreement removes 99% of customs duties between the two sides and is seen as a relief for both the EU and Canada amid widespread uncertainty. The signing ceremony comes after Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau flew to Brussels to finalize the pact, and the EU is now set to endorse the deal, with all 28 member states expected to give their approval.

site_title: South Korean president struggles to contain scandal
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye faces mounting pressure as thousands gather for a mass rally calling for her resignation amid a scandal involving her long-time confidante Choi Soon Sil. Choi, who has no government position, allegedly coerced money from major conglomerates using her ties to Park, and vetted her presidential speeches. Park has apologized and resigned 10 senior advisers, but public approval ratings have hit record lows. Choi, 60, is being investigated and her lawyer claims she is willing to return home to face questioning and punishment if necessary.

images.alt_text: Pressure mounted on South Korean President Park Geun Hye on Saturday ahead of a large-scale protest over revelations that she allowed a personal friend, with no government position, to meddle in affairs of state.

site_title: US dollar tumbles against euro, surges against peso on FBI Clinton probe
summary: The US dollar tumbled against a basket of major currencies due to renewed uncertainty over the US presidential election, with the FBI's announcement that it would review more emails related to Hillary Clinton's private email use. The euro reached an eight-day peak against the US dollar, while the US dollar fell against the yen and Swiss franc. However, the dollar surged against the Mexican peso to a three-week high, potentially benefiting Donald Trump's campaign and posing a risk for the Mexican currency.

site_title: Driving ambitions
summary: Audi Singapore's managing director enjoyed a golf game at the Seletar Country Club, but the article does not provide further details about his performance. The article is unrelated to the provided content and appears to be a snippet from a news article about various events and economic news, including China's efforts to aid employment, US weekly jobless claims, and Ambani's Reliance Jio delaying its India IPO.

site_title: December Fed rate-hike odds slide below 70% on FBI Clinton probe
summary: The Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike odds have decreased to below 70% due to the FBI reopening its inquiry into Hillary Clinton's private e-mail use. This shift is reflected in Treasury two-year notes gaining for the first time in seven days. Futures data show a decrease in the probability of a December interest-rate hike from 74% to less than 70%. The announcement comes 11 days before the US presidential election.

images.alt_text: Bond traders pared wagers on tighter US monetary policy after the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it's reopening its inquiry into Hillary Clinton's use of private e-mail while secretary of state.

site_title: EU nations approve trade deal, 'ready to sign' with Canada: statement
summary: The European Union's 28 member states have approved a landmark free trade deal with Canada, known as Ceta, after years of negotiations. The deal, which requires endorsement from all EU member states, has been cleared by Belgian regional parliaments, paving the way for its signing. EU Prime Minister Robert Fico stated that the agreement represents a milestone in the EU's trade policy and its commitment to it, with the potential to set the way forward for future trade deals. The deal's signing was initially planned for a Brussels summit but was postponed due to concerns from Belgian regional governments.

site_title: Singapore Q3 retail vacancies rise to 5-year high of 8.4%
summary: Singapore's retail vacancies rose to a 5-year high of 8.4% in Q3, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The vacancy rate increased from 7.8% in Q2, with the amount of occupied retail space shrinking 26,000 sq m. Despite a decline in rents and prices, analysts expect no relief for retailers, citing a slow-moving economy and reduced household disposable income.

site_title: What Time Is Lunch?
summary: This article appears to be a collection of unrelated news summaries about various topics, including food, social causes, sustainability, finance, and design. There is no central theme or key event to summarize, and the articles seem to be from different sources and dates, with no clear connection between them.

site_title: Europe: Shares back in the red for October on weak results
summary: European shares fell on October 28, 2016, due to weak corporate results, with Novo Nordisk's 15% drop being the worst performance on the Stoxx 600. Investors have shown little tolerance for earnings disappointments, contributing to a record 38 weeks of outflows from European equity funds. Despite this, the financial sector showed resilience, with some banks reporting positive earnings and raising dividend payouts. The sector is expected to outperform in the long term, according to Philippe Gijsels, head of research at BNP Paribas Fortis.

site_title: 20 'minor injuries' after plane fire at Chicago airport
summary: A fire broke out on an American Airlines Boeing 767 at Chicago's O'Hare airport, injuring approximately 20 people with minor injuries. The incident occurred as the plane attempted to take off, with 161 passengers and nine crew on board. The cause of the fire is unclear, with the FAA citing a tire blowout and American Airlines blaming an "engine-related issue." Emergency crews responded to the scene, and the plane was re-accommodating passengers on another flight to Miami. An investigation is underway.

images.alt_text: Approximately 20 people were injured when an American Airlines Boeing 767 bound for Miami caught fire Friday as it attempted to take off from Chicago's O'Hare airport, emergency officials said.

site_title: Thousands queue outside Bangkok's Grand Palace to visit late Thai King
summary: Thousands of Thais flocked to Bangkok's Grand Palace on Saturday to pay tribute to late King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died two weeks ago at 88. The public was granted access to the throne hall where his body is lying in state, with 10,000 mourners allowed to enter per day. The event marks a year of official mourning, with the country observing strict dress codes and TV channels airing footage from the monarch's 70-year reign. Authorities have stepped up enforcement of lese majeste laws to curb criticism of the monarchy and its heir, Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn.

site_title: No writing off this predator
summary: Tiger Woods was asked by Charlie Rose if he aimed to equal Jack Nicklaus' record of 18 Majors, and Woods replied, "To be honest with you, no." This indicates Woods is no longer focused on achieving the record.

site_title: Oil ends week down on uncertainty over Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices ended the week below $50, marking their biggest weekly loss in six weeks, due to uncertainty over Opec's planned output cuts. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) failed to agree on output quotas, with Iran and Iraq opposing cuts. US oil drillers removed rigs from production for the first time since June, but the market remains cautious. Brent crude fell 1.5% to $49.71 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2% to $48.70 a barrel, with a weekly drop of 4%.

site_title: Britain could hold second EU vote, says ex-PM Blair
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair suggests that a second Brexit referendum is possible, citing the need for Britain to "scrutinize" its decision. Blair warns that the break-up of the EU will be "very, very tough" and that European leaders are in an "unforgiving mood." The UK government immediately rejects the idea of a second referendum, with Prime Minister Theresa May's office stating that the British people have spoken and the country will leave the EU.

site_title: Take10 years off
summary: Old Tom Morris, a renowned golfer, believed that taking cold baths, known as cold-immersion therapy, could extend his life by 10 years. According to his biography, Morris would often swim in the North Sea, which was considered cold and harsh. This practice was seen as a form of rejuvenation, with the cold waters believed to have health benefits. While the effectiveness of cold-immersion therapy remains unproven, Morris's approach to health and longevity has been noted as an intriguing aspect of his life.

site_title: China's crackdown on Crown creates uncertainty, says rival Star
summary: China's detention of 18 Crown Resorts Ltd employees has created uncertainty for Australian rival Star Entertainment Group, according to CEO Matt Bekier. The detentions, which occurred two weeks ago, have raised concerns about a potential crackdown on casino companies that promote gambling abroad. Star chairman John O'Neill stated that the company has no office in mainland China and no employees have been held or questioned by Chinese authorities. The impact on Star's revenue remains unclear, but the company will continue to monitor developments closely.

site_title: US: Markets hit by FBI probe of Clinton
summary: US stocks dropped on Friday after the FBI reopened a probe into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server, raising the chances of a Donald Trump win. The Dow Jones lost 0.1%, the S&P 500 declined 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.5%. Analysts believe the news will negatively impact the market, and health care stocks were particularly hit hard. The US economy grew at a 2.9% pace in the third quarter, but this data did little to boost the market.

site_title: The Els Club, Desaru Coast Course
summary: The Els Club, Desaru Coast Course is a 27-hole Ocean Course in Malaysia, featuring three distinct nine-hole loops and varying distances of 2,793-3,682 yards. The course offers four tee locations for all levels of play, meandering through natural wetlands and out towards the South China Sea.

site_title: Hometown Glory
summary: Singapore playwright Michael Chiang is featured in Louis Vuitton's new City Guides collection, alongside Takeshi Kitano and Lee Byung-Hun. Chiang recommends local dining spots and brands worth trying, stating that Singaporean food is a "food vigilante" that loudly declares its preferences. The City Guides are available at Louis Vuitton stores, bookshops, and as an app.

site_title: RBS posts Q3 loss of £469m on restructuring, litigation costs
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) posted a Q3 loss of £469m, mainly due to £894m in restructuring and litigation charges. Despite a pretax profit of £1.33 billion, the bank's progress in returning to annual profit remains hindered by looming US charges and delays in selling the Williams & Glyn consumer unit. The bank's core business results were good, with a 71% increase in adjusted revenue from its corporate and institutional banking division.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group Corp reported a 6% year-over-year decline in net profit to 89.32 million yuan, while revenue fell 10% to 1.49 billion yuan. The company aims to improve operational efficiencies through marketing and R&D. Oriental Group sold its subsidiary Wan Dormitory for S$24 million to fund working capital and debt repayment. OCBC Bank became the first Asian-Pacific bank to enable secure payments via Siri and iMessage.

site_title: Asset renovations hit Starhill's Q1
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 0.8% dip in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.3 Singapore cents in Q1, down 0.01 cent from a year ago. Asset renovations and tenant transitions in Australian and Chinese malls impacted performance, while Singapore assets continued to perform well. Net property income dropped 1.7% in Q1.

site_title: Residential land prices in China's first-tier cities soar 19.02% in Q3
summary: Residential land prices in China's first-tier cities surged 19.02% in Q3, reaching an average of 21,037 yuan (S$4,324) per square meter. In contrast, second- and third-tier cities experienced smaller gains of 5.69% and 3.71% respectively. The Ministry of Land and Resources attributed the stark price growth to first-tier cities and popular second-tier cities, while most second- and third-tier cities maintained stable prices. The trend is expected to continue in the short term.

site_title: An uber interesting ride home
summary: A man, in his late 30s, drives for Uber to supplement his income as a project manager in a shipping company. He is a missionary and pays for his ex-wife's studies to become a Buddhist nun, a calling she had since childhood. The couple was married for 20 years, had a 22-year-old son, and divorced after the ex-wife confessed her desire to become ordained. The man is open to the idea of finding a new partner, but doubts it will happen. He and his ex-wife remain friends, with him supporting her spiritual journey and paying for her expenses.

site_title: SingPost shares climb 4.6% after Alibaba deal approved
summary: Alibaba has received regulatory approval to raise its stake in Singapore Post to 14.4% from 10.2%, paying S$187.1 million for approximately 107.55 million new shares. This deal is expected to be completed by February 28, 2017. Analysts say the move solidifies SingPost's relationship with Alibaba and shifts attention to the group's dividend policy review, which is currently underway to ensure sustainability.

site_title: Ng Chee Meng and Ong Ye Kung promoted to full ministers
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the promotion of Ng Chee Meng and Ong Ye Kung to full ministers, effective Tuesday. Ng will become Minister for Education (Schools) and Second Minister at the Transport Ministry, while Ong will take on the roles of Minister for Education (Higher Education and Skills) and Second Minister at the Defence Ministry. The appointments are part of a leadership renewal process, with Lee emphasizing the need for a younger team to drive Singapore's future growth.

site_title: Drawing down retirement money
summary: Retirees face complex challenges during the withdrawal phase of retirement planning, requiring meticulous planning to ensure sufficient income. A bucketing approach can help, allocating assets into safe and higher-return buckets to balance risk and income. A hypothetical client, David, uses the RetireWell tool to allocate S$1.479 million into various buckets, ensuring a stable income stream and minimizing volatility. This approach allows for a mix of near-cash assets and higher-return portfolios, catering to different stages of retirement, and utilizing various instruments and government schemes. Proper planning is crucial for retirees to secure their golden years.

site_title: Higher Ground
summary: A multi-million dollar home in Singapore's Thomson Road area was designed by Red Bean Architects for a multi-generational family. The house features a unique facade made of perforated cream limestone and weathered steel trims, with a 'public' and 'private' entrance. The design prioritizes natural materials, functional spaces, and eco-friendly features, earning an Honourable Mention at the Singapore Institute of Architects Design Awards and a Building and Construction Authority Green Mark Gold Plus Award. The home's unique design provides a fantastic view of the surrounding greenery, proving that money can indeed buy happiness.

site_title: Retirement spending and investing: A primer on risks
summary: A recent paper from JP Morgan Asset Management addresses key risks in retirement spending and investing, including longevity, withdrawal rate, housing, inflation, and sequence of returns. A 6-7% annual return assumption may not be sufficient, as the timing of a bear market can impact retirement savings. The study emphasizes the need for a portfolio to generate both current income and sufficient growth to keep pace with rising costs over a long horizon. Poor market returns early in retirement can exacerbate the sequence of return risk, while strong returns can ease retirement funding.

site_title: Net office demand contracts in Q3, vacancy crosses 10%
summary: Occupied office space in Singapore decreased by 5,000 sq m in Q3, contrasting with a 30,000 sq m increase in Q2, according to Urban Redevelopment Authority data. This results in a net increase of 26,000 sq m in the first nine months, lower than the 72,000 sq m in the previous year. Market watchers attribute the decline to a sluggish economy and anaemic employment numbers.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Singaporean eateries now offer takeaway options. Dine Now provides a whole roast chicken, while Brotzeit offers a 10-sausage platter to celebrate its 10th anniversary. The article also highlights other dining spots, including a New York import gelato stand in Plaza Singapura, and various lifestyle articles on topics such as mod-Indian cuisine, zero-waste living, and financial literacy for women.

site_title: Kando man
summary: Sony CEO Kazuo Hirai aims to revive the company's brand by focusing on emotional value, or "kando," in its products and branding. He believes that Sony's Japanese heritage and American pragmatism can combine to create a unique approach to innovation. Hirai plans to bring cross-divisional collaboration to Sony's various departments, including entertainment, electronics, and professional equipment, to create a cohesive ecosystem. He's investing in emerging technologies like virtual reality, artificial intelligence, and robotics to drive growth. Despite past challenges, including a decline in value and struggles with the smartphone business, Hirai remains committed to making tough decisions to ensure Sony's long-term success.

site_title: Asset manager Brookfield in talks to buy £600m London office tower: sources
summary: Brookfield Asset Management Inc is in exclusive talks to acquire CityPoint Tower, a 36-storey London office building valued at £660 million, for less than £600 million. The building, located near the Bank of England, was previously owned by Beacon Capital Partners Inc, which defaulted on £429 million of loans in 2012. The acquisition would be the largest UK commercial property deal this year, according to Savills plc. Brookfield CEO Bruce Flatt has stated that despite Brexit uncertainty, quality properties with assured income may be valued higher due to investors' thirst for yield.

images.alt_text: Mr Flatt says there is much uncertainty about the effect of the Brexit vote on the 12 businesses Brookfield owns in the UK, particularly its offices.

site_title: Steeper fall in private home prices puts earlier signs of bottoming out more in doubt
summary: Singapore's private home prices experienced their steepest decline since 2013, falling 10.8% in Q3, driven by a 2.7% drop in landed properties and 1.2% decline in non-landed properties. Concerns over the economy and jobs market may be affecting buying sentiment, with foreigners bearing the brunt of job losses. While sales momentum held up, with 4,596 private residential units sold, analysts expect vacancy rates to remain high due to substantial upcoming completions. Public housing prices stabilized, but resale transactions slipped 5.5% in Q3.

site_title: A walking enigma
summary: The BauBax jacket, created by Washington product design firm BauBax, raised $9.19 million on Kickstarter, exceeding its $20,000 target. Despite delays and criticism, the jacket boasts 15 features, including an inflatable neck pillow, built-in gloves, hand-warming pockets, and a pen that can extend from 1-4 inches. The jacket also features a drink pocket, earphone holders, and an iPad pocket, transforming the way travelers carry essentials. However, concerns arise about the jacket's bulkiness, maintenance, and potential loss of items if the jacket is misplaced.

site_title: US$49t infrastructure problem may not get solved anytime soon
summary: A recent research report from Deutsche Bank warns that the US$49 trillion infrastructure funding gap may not be solved anytime soon due to a lack of investor-friendly investment vehicles. Despite abundant global savings and institutional investors' desire for positive, long-dated yields, unlisted infrastructure investments fail to deliver bang for the buck, with returns often meager and subject to mark-to-market and regulatory risks. Regulatory risks may further reduce the allure of infrastructure projects, making it difficult for investors to adequately compensate for credit risk.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Brokers have issued buy recommendations for Japfa Ltd and Sembcorp Industries. Japfa's FY15-18 forecast earnings growth justifies a 6.3 times forward enterprise value to Ebitda multiple, and its stock trades at a significant discount to its Indonesian-listed subsidiary. Sembcorp Industries reported a 10.8% year-on-year drop in revenue, but its recurring net profit is estimated to be around S$99 million. OCBC Bank has been downgraded to Neutral, citing continued weakness in the general economy.

images.alt_text: OCBC's customer loan book declined 1.9 per cent year-on-year but managed to squeeze a 1.5 per cent quarter-on-quarter increase after three consecutive quarters of decline.

site_title: Singapore, the fintech prodigy
summary: Singapore is poised to become the world's top fintech hub, driven by its pragmatic and calculated approach to innovation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up the Singapore FinTech Festival, a five-day event that brings together fintechs, bankers, regulators, and investors to solve problems in the banking sector. The festival aims to promote a culture of innovation and has set aside S$225 million for fintech experiments. Singapore's approach is distinct from London's laissez-faire approach, with MAS actively engaging with banks and fintechs to create a smart financial centre. The city-state is attracting both mature and young fintechs, including TransferWise and Stripe, and is expected to benefit from Brexit-related interest in its fintech hub.

site_title: Oil prices unlikely to revisit previous highs: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that oil prices are unlikely to return to previous highs, citing factors such as slowing global growth, especially in China, and the shale revolution, which have subdued demand for oil. Despite supply cuts, the IMF suggests that a "new normal" for oil prices has emerged, with prices likely to remain relatively bearish. The IMF notes that unexpected strong shale-oil production and Opec's decision to keep production unchanged contributed to the 2014 oil price collapse.

site_title: Twists & Turns
summary: Hong Kong noir thriller "Nessun Dorma" reunites screenwriter Erica Lee and director Herman Yau, starring Janice Man, Gordon Lam, and Andy Hui, about a kidnapper and his victim in a cat-and-mouse game. The film has screened at various festivals and won the Jury Award for Best Feature Film at the Indigo Moon Film Festival in North Carolina, USA.

site_title: I Want To Bake Free
summary: A group of amateur bakers, including Anthony Huang, Yasaki-Tan Rie, Siow-Ling Kong, and Sandra Lee, have gained popularity on social media for their stunning and creative baked goods. Despite having no formal training, they have developed their skills through trial and error, experimentation, and a passion for baking. Their Instagram accounts showcase their creations, which range from traditional cakes to intricate pastries and breads. The bakers attribute their success to their attention to detail, creativity, and a willingness to learn and adapt. While some consider turning their hobby into a full-time career, others prefer to keep it as a leisure activity, enjoying the process and sharing their creations with their online communities.

site_title: Breaking Deepavali's binary code
summary: Deepavali, the Hindu Festival of Lights, is often misunderstood as a celebration of good over evil, but the author argues that it's more complex. According to Hindu mythology, Lord Rama's battle with King Ravan was necessary for his growth and ultimately led to the triumph of good. The author shares a personal anecdote about her grandmother's dark dessert, wajid, made with gula melaka and coconut milk, which was initially met with disapproval but ultimately revealed to be an "antidote" to the author's questioning. The author concludes that understanding Deepavali requires looking beyond the binary opposition of light and darkness, and embracing the complexity of the human experience.

site_title: Play it
summary: Bali's Bali National Golf Club has elevated the island as a premier golf destination, boasting international-quality courses. This development marks a significant shift in the island's focus from surfing and its Bohemian culture. The club's presence is expected to attract more golf enthusiasts, further solidifying Bali's reputation as a top golfing destination in Southeast Asia.

site_title: The rise of job interviews via webcams
summary: The rise of job interviews via webcams is becoming increasingly common, with companies like NBC and large organizations like Deloitte, JPMorgan Chase, and Under Armour using video interview software. This "robo-interview" format allows hiring managers to review answers on their own schedule, without the need for in-person interviews. While candidates may find it awkward, the efficiency and convenience of video interviews are seen as benefits for both parties, with nearly 90% of video interviews being "on demand" with no human presence at the other end.

site_title: No sweat ahead for lovers of Michelin-starred soya sauce chicken
summary: Singapore's Michelin-starred soya sauce chicken stall, Liao Fan Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken Rice & Noodles, is opening its first quick service restaurant, Hawker Chan, in mid-November. The 80-seater air-conditioned restaurant is a partnership between stall owner Chan Hon Meng and Hersing Culinary, which owns the Asia-Pacific franchising rights to Tim Ho Wan. Hawker Chan will offer the signature dish and new creations, with prices higher than the stall but still affordable. The restaurant will be managed by chef Chan, who will split his time between the stall and the new restaurant.

site_title: Holding his own among pros
summary: Chinese professional Li Hao-tong won the 2016 Mission Hills World Celebrity Pro-Am, beating multiple-major winning golfers to collect a $250,000 prize. Li scored 78 stableford points, one ahead of women's world number 14 Anna Nordqvist. Major winners Mark O'Meara, Paula Creamer, and Rich Beem tied for third. The event, held at Mission Hills Haikou, raised $1 million for charity and was described by its vice-chairman as the "biggest and best" yet, inspiring a new audience to take up golf.

site_title: Getting up close and personal with Gary Player
summary: Legendary golfer Gary Player, a 14-major winner, expressed interest in Tiger Woods' return to the PGA Tour, saying it would be the most interesting thing in golf. Player believes Woods is needed to play well, but doubts he can win more majors than Jack Nicklaus' 18. Player, 81, attributes his success to dedication to fitness, citing his exercise routine and healthy eating. He also emphasized the need for amateur golf to grow worldwide, particularly in schools, to increase participation.

site_title: Sakae rejects allegations in letter of complaint sent by shareholder
summary: Sakae Holdings rejected allegations made by a shareholder in a June letter of complaint, stating that chairman Douglas Foo's personal interests and company actions did not align with the claims. An audit committee (AC) investigation found the allegations "not borne out by the evidence" and considered evidence from a High Court trial where Foo gave testimony. The High Court's decision has yet to be handed down. Sakae will keep shareholders updated on any material developments.

site_title: IndoAgri in the black for Q3 on stronger revenue, forex gains
summary: Indofood Agri Resources (IndoAgri) posted a net profit of 159 billion rupiah (S$16.9 million) for the third quarter of 2016, driven by 8.7% revenue growth and forex translation gains. The company attributed the increase to higher commodity prices and increased profits from operations, despite higher effective tax. The plantation division saw a 7% revenue growth, while the EBITDA grew 33.9% due to higher gross profit from palm products and a share of profit from a joint venture in Brazil.

site_title: Zombie machines and cyber attacks
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telecommunications company, experienced a cyber attack on its home broadband network, leaving some customers without internet access. The attack, attributed to "zombie" devices, was the first of its kind in Singapore. Hackers took control of customers' internet-connected devices, such as video cameras and routers, to launch cyber attacks. The outage occurred twice in three days, causing frustration among customers and prompting StarHub to reassess its cyber security policies. The incident highlights the growing threat of cyber attacks and the need for stronger online defenses, particularly in critical sectors.

site_title: Drinking Kakis
summary: In 1950s Singapore, two 12-year-old boys, Mohamed Mustafa and Rahim Nasir, lived on Pulau Bukom, a 1.45 sq km island home to 5,000 Shell employees and their families. The island offered a carefree lifestyle with access to free movies, fresh coconuts, and a simple, walkable community. The island's residents relied on foot, bicycles, and a few cars, with no concept of cars, Montessori, or enrichment classes. This idyllic setting provides a nostalgic glimpse into Singapore's past, highlighting the simplicity and community that defined island life at the time.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts' Q3 DPS up 3.4% at 2.44 S'pore cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts' (CDLHT) Q3 distribution per stapled security (DPSS) rose 3.4% to 2.44 Singapore cents, driven by its hotels in the UK and New Zealand. Gross revenue increased 10.5% to S$45.4 million, while net property income rose 5.3% to S$34.8 million. However, the Singapore hotel sector faced challenging operating conditions due to new rooms supply and softening corporate activities, resulting in a 7.2% decline in revenue per available room (RevPAR).

site_title: Rebirth of Bronx housing project aims to cut crime
summary: The Lambert Houses, a 1970s-era low-income housing project in the Bronx, is being redeveloped by Phipps Houses with a $32 million overhaul. The project will replace 14 buildings with 13 taller towers, increasing the number of apartments to 1,665, all of which will be affordable. The redevelopment aims to address issues with crime and safety, and will increase density in the area. The project has received positive reactions from local officials and residents, who see it as an opportunity to revitalize the neighborhood.

site_title: Oil sector woes cut UOB third-quarter profit by 7.8% to S$791 million
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 7.8% lower net profit for the third quarter of 2016, reaching S$791 million, due to higher allowances from the oil & gas segment and weaker non-interest income. Total allowances increased 15.7% to S$185 million, mainly from the oil & gas industry. Non-performing loan ratio rose to 1.6%, and net interest margin fell to 1.69%. The bank's results beat average forecasts, but shares closed down 31 cents at S$18.63.

images.alt_text: The oil rout has, as expected, hit United Overseas Bank (UOB).

site_title: Where have the fans gone?
summary: The world's top female tennis players are competing in the BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals Singapore, but the event is struggling to attract a full crowd, with empty chairs and flat atmospheres common during matches. The tournament, which features US$7 million in prize money, has seen high-quality matches, including three-set epics, but the lack of fans is disappointing. The event promoter, Lagardere Sports, has attributed the problem to a culture of last-minute ticket purchases, and the absence of top players like Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova due to injuries and suspensions.

site_title: Wall Street broker-dealer profits in 2016 to exceed last year's: watchdog
summary: Wall Street broker-dealer profits for 2016 are expected to surpass those of 2015, ending three years of consecutive declines, according to a report by New York state Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli. Despite a 18% decline in first-half profits to $9.3 billion, job growth in the securities industry has slowed, and bonuses are expected to decline for the third consecutive year. The industry has shrunk since the 2007-2008 financial crisis, with New York City representing 19% of securities industry jobs in 2015, down from 32% in 1990.

site_title: Development bank EBRD to shake up top positions
summary: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) is making significant changes to its top management, aiming to shift from investment to a more advisory role. First Vice President Philip Bennett will oversee main investment and policy divisions, with Finance Chief Andras Simor taking on a broader role including Chief Operating Officer. Three other vice presidents will report to Bennett or Simor, while President Suma Chakrabarti will oversee a central services division. The changes are set to take effect on November 15, as the EBRD seeks to encourage the development of the bank as both an adviser and investor.

site_title: Opec officials debate thorny issue of how to implement supply cut
summary: Opec officials in Vienna continue debating the implementation of their oil supply-cut agreement, which aims to reduce production to 32.5-33.0 million barrels per day. The deal faces potential setbacks, including Iraq's call for exemption and concerns from countries affected by sanctions or conflict. Despite challenges, Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo remains optimistic, stating that the committee's recommendations could have significant market and industry implications. The meeting, which began on Friday, will continue on Saturday with representatives from non-Opec nations in attendance.

site_title: Darius Cheung
summary: Darius Cheung, founder of 99.co, a property search portal, was motivated to create a platform after experiencing frustration while searching for a home to rent. Cheung, 35, had previously co-founded tenCube, a mobile security firm that sold to McAfee. He believes in filling perceived gaps in industries and has achieved success through his entrepreneurial spirit, instilled by his father, who ran a printing business and encouraged him to focus on finding growth markets. Cheung's short-term goal is to build 99.co into a great place to work, while his long-term goal is to focus on his daughter and build a lasting legacy.

images.alt_text: Darius Cheong at Burnt Ends on Teck Lim Road. The restaurant serves modern Australian barbeque. art direction chris foo. - ART DIRECTION CHRIS FOO. PHOTOGRAPHY KEVIN YANG

site_title: Cordlife's COO retires as executive director
summary: Cordlife Group announced the retirement of COO Tan Poh Lan as an executive director, effective immediately, during the company's annual general meeting on October 28, 2016. She will remain as COO. The announcement led to a slight decline in Cordlife shares to close at S$1.14.

site_title: Exxon Mobil profit slides as oil market extends slump
summary: Exxon Mobil reported its eighth consecutive quarter of declining profits, with a net income of $2.65 billion (63 cents per share) in the third quarter, down from $4.24 billion (1.01 dollars per share) in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to a prolonged slump in energy markets, with Brent crude averaging $46.99 a barrel, down 8.4% from the previous year. Exxon has been conserving cash by cutting outlays for drilling and refining, and has also faced challenges related to climate-science investigations and royalty payments.

site_title: SIAEC, Airbus set up joint venture
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) and Airbus have established a 65-35% joint venture, Heavy Maintenance Singapore Services (HMS Services), to provide airframe maintenance, cabin upgrade, and modification services for Airbus A380, A350, and A330 aircraft families in the Asia-Pacific region and beyond. Airbus aims to develop HMS Services as its Centre of Excellence for heavy maintenance in Asia.

site_title: STI drifts to 0.6% loss for week ahead of US elections
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 16 points or 0.6% to 2,816.26, as markets traded within narrow bands ahead of the US presidential elections on Nov 8. The index completed five consecutive days with dollar value below the S$1 billion threshold, with Friday's volume reaching S$878 million. Notable movers included Delong Holdings' 35% surge on Q3 profit expectations, and SingPost's 4.6% gain on Alibaba's stake increase. Analysts attributed the market's cautiousness to massive uncertainty surrounding Trump's presidency.

site_title: L Catterton bets on growth in China outlet malls (Amended)
summary: L Catterton and Ping An Real Estate have invested in Sasseur Group, a Chinese outlet mall operator, amid China's sluggish high-street retail market. The Sasseur Group has clocked 40% average annual growth in sales since entering the outlet mall business and plans to maintain a 30% growth rate through its "super outlet" concept, which incorporates entertainment, sports, and cuisine. The investment is part of a growing trend of international capital betting on the success of outlet malls in China, where the number of outlet malls is expected to increase with the rise of the middle class.

site_title: Exports boost Q3 growth rate to its fastest in 2 years
summary: The US economy grew at its fastest pace in two years in the third quarter, with a 2.9% annual rate, driven by a surge in exports and a rebound in inventory investment. Consumer spending slowed, increasing at a 2.1% rate, but still supported the economy. The trade deficit narrowed, with exports rising 10% and inventory investment contributing to growth. This could help alleviate concerns about the economy stalling and support a potential interest rate hike in December.

site_title: Clinton counting on swing state advantage through early voting
summary: Hillary Clinton's campaign is gaining momentum in early voting, particularly in North Carolina and Colorado, with Democrats casting more ballots than Republicans in these states. However, her campaign is struggling in Iowa and Ohio, where she trails Donald Trump in polls and has seen a decline in absentee ballot requests. Despite this, Clinton's campaign remains optimistic, with her husband Bill Clinton and surrogates promoting early voting in these states. The campaign is also taking encouragement from the results in Florida, where Democrats are outperforming Republicans in early voting.

site_title: ECB will provide stimulus until sustained inflation rebound
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will continue to provide stimulus until a sustained inflation rebound, despite concerns about diminishing costs and increasing side effects. Policymakers, including Benoit Coeure and Philip Lane, argue that the ECB's measures are working and will extend asset buys beyond March 2017 if necessary. The ECB aims to meet its 2% inflation target, which has been missed for three and a half years, and will decide on the future of its asset buys in December.

site_title: Joo Chiat with Dennis Tay
summary: Dennis Tay, a lifelong resident of Singapore's Joo Chiat neighborhood, reflects on the area's changing face. The Peranakan quarter, once known for its rich culture and history, is now attracting new businesses and international flavors. Tay reminisces about the past, remembering old landmarks like the book shop off Ceylon Road, but is also excited to see the area evolve, with new businesses like RetroCrates, a vinyl shop, and Dona Manis, a 20-year-old confectionery. Joo Chiat's transformation is a result of its unique blend of old and new, making it a vibrant and dynamic neighborhood.

site_title: UIC's Q3 profit dips as takings from joint venture fall
summary: United Industrial Corporation (UIC) reported a 2% dip in net profit to S$64.0 million for the third quarter of 2016, primarily due to a loss of S$3.9 million from its joint ventures. Revenue increased 38% year-over-year to S$262.0 million, but earnings per share dropped to 4.5 Singapore cents. UIC shares closed unchanged at S$2.78.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Private home prices and rents in Singapore fell 1.5% and 1.2% respectively in Q3, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. UBS Group AG faces possible suspension from IPO underwriting in Hong Kong for its work on some IPOs. SingPost shares surged 5% after the Info-communications Media Development Authority gave the nod for Alibaba to raise its stake. Acting Ministers Ong Ye Kung and Ng Chee Meng will become full ministers on Nov 1. The yuan is set for its biggest monthly drop since August 2015, amid China's economic slump.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Companies reported on their latest earnings and market trends. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In business news, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's CEO. Additionally, MAS and PBOC announced cooperation on green and transition finance, while Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: US: Amazon, health stocks weigh on S&P, Nasdaq; Chevron lifts Dow
summary: The US stock market experienced a mixed performance on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq weighed down by Amazon and healthcare stocks. Chevron, however, lifted the Dow, rising 2.7%. The S&P 500 is expected to rise 2.6% in the third quarter, driven by financial companies, while energy companies are expected to take a hit. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 43.28 points, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 8.83 points. The US economy grew at a 2.9% annual rate in the third quarter, according to the Commerce Department.

site_title: MasterCard profit beats as purchase volumes rise
summary: MasterCard reported a 21.2% increase in net income to $1.18 billion in the third quarter, beating analysts' expectations of $1.08 per share. Revenue rose 13.8% to $2.88 billion, driven by higher spending on its network, which saw a 9% increase in worldwide purchase volume to $882 billion. Cross-border volumes jumped 12%. The company's shares rose 1.8% in premarket trading, and the stock had gained 6.4% year-to-date.

site_title: Ong Ye Kung, Ng Chee Meng promoted to full ministers from Nov 1
summary: Singaporean Acting Ministers Ong Ye Kung and Ng Chee Meng will be promoted to full ministers on November 1. Ong will take on the role of Minister for Education (Higher Education and Skills) and Second Defence Minister, while Ng will become Minister for Education (Schools) and Second Minister at the Transport Ministry. The promotions are part of the government's leadership renewal efforts.

site_title: BMW limits lightweight carbon fibre use to juice profits
summary: BMW is limiting its use of costly carbon fibre in its cars to maintain profit margins, instead opting for cheaper lightweight materials like aluminium and steel. The company is combining carbon fibre with other materials to reduce weight without increasing costs. BMW's electric car offerings, which have struggled to gain traction, will not feature extensive use of carbon fibre. The company is working to reduce the costs of incorporating carbon components into mass production, with a two-year lead over rivals in carbon fibre mass production know-how.

site_title: Cabin crew union offers Lufthansa budget carriers new talks
summary: The German cabin crew union UFO has offered new talks to Lufthansa's budget carriers Eurowings and Germanwings after a 24-hour strike cancelled hundreds of flights. The union is seeking better pay and part-time contracts, citing a lack of agreement. Eurowings has proposed a 7% pay increase, and the union has threatened to call for two more days of strikes if management doesn't change its stance. New talks are seen as an opportunity to avert further strikes and resolve the dispute.

site_title: Myanmar authorities investigate report of plane crash: official
summary: Myanmar's Civil Aviation Department is investigating a report of an unidentified aircraft crashing into the sea off the west coast on Friday. According to a senior official, the aircraft is not from Myanmar's domestic airlines, and there are no reports of anything untoward from offshore companies operating in the area. Staff from the department are investigating the incident and are expected to report back later in the day. The cause of the crash is currently unknown.

site_title: Rise of private-jet ride sharing crimps orders for new airplanes
summary: Private jet ride-sharing companies are disrupting the industry by offering affordable access to private aviation, leading to a decline in new airplane orders. Manufacturers like Cessna and Bombardier Inc are throttling back production due to weaker demand. New jet deliveries are expected to drop 6.4% this year and another 3.7% next year. Charter activity has increased, with flight hours rising over 5% in the past three years, as new models and digital platforms make private aviation more accessible to a wider range of customers.

site_title: Apple increases prices of Macs in UK by 20%
summary: Apple has increased prices of Macs in the UK by 20% due to the Brexit vote, with some models seeing price hikes of up to 20%. The Mac Mini now costs £479, up from £399, and the Mac Pro costs £2,999, up from £2,499. The US prices for these models remain unchanged. Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment. This price increase affects existing models, not new releases.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q1 DPU dips on asset enhancements, tenant movements
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 0.8% dip in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.3 Singapore cents for Q1 2016, down from a year ago, due to lower contributions from its Australia, China, and Japan properties. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also fell 2.7% and 1.7% respectively, primarily attributed to lower occupancies and lease terminations.

site_title: German inflation further picks up in October, state data suggest
summary: German inflation accelerated further in October, with consumer prices rising by 0.9% in North Rhine-Westphalia and 0.8% in other states, according to preliminary data. This is a welcome sign for the European Central Bank, which has been using ultra-loose monetary policy to push up price pressures. The increase in inflation could give Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann more scope to argue for a reduction in the ECB's bond-buying program, which he has often criticized. The ECB expects the bloc-wide inflation figure to stay below its target of 2% for some time.

site_title: US labour costs increase 0.6% in Q3
summary: US labour costs increased 0.6% in the third quarter, maintaining a steady pace of increase. The year-on-year rate of increase stood at 2.3%. Despite wage growth being slow, economists expect tightening labor market conditions to lead to faster increases. Labour costs need to rise by at least 3% to push inflation closer to the US central bank's 2% target. Wages and salaries rose 0.5% in the third quarter, while benefits for all workers increased 0.7%. The steady increase in labour costs suggests little signs of significant wage inflation.

site_title: European stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.4% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also declining 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively.

site_title: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical's Q3 profit down 6%
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group Corp reported a 6% year-on-year decline in net profit to 89.32 million yuan for the third quarter, with revenue falling 10% to 1.49 billion yuan. Despite a 9% increase in gross profit to 473.15 million yuan, the company cited efforts to improve operational efficiencies and enhance competitiveness through research and development and cost management. The decline in earnings per share to 0.12 yuan also occurred.

site_title: Candy Crush creator King shuts down Singapore-based game studio
summary: King, the developer of Candy Crush, has shut down its Singapore-based studio NonStop Games, acquired in 2014 for up to $100 million. The decision was made after careful consideration, with the goal of retaining as many employees as possible. King stated that the studio had a "fantastic team and world-class talent." The closure is part of a larger restructuring effort by King.

site_title: Tata's alleged governance lapses said to be probed by India
summary: India's market regulator is investigating Tata Group for alleged governance lapses and breach of corporate governance rules. The Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) is examining a letter written by ousted chairman Cyrus Mistry, who alleged financial irregularities and corporate governance issues. Tata Group companies have lost over $3.3 billion in market value since Mistry's removal. The regulator is reviewing compliance with insider-trading rules and monitoring market-sensitive information. The investigation may lead to further deterioration of the group's market capitalization and potential writedowns of $18 billion due to unprofitable businesses.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust DPS falls 9.4% for Q4 to 1.19 cents
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 9.4% decline in distributable per stapled security (DPS) to 1.19 Singapore cents for Q4, due to a S$266.3 million rights issue. Distribution income fell 2.6% year-over-year, while revenue increased 8.6% to S$33.5 million. The trust's Australia portfolio reported 5.6% average revenue per available room growth, driven by higher average daily rates and occupancy. Despite this, the Singapore portfolio saw soft performance in Q4, and the full-year DPS declined 10.1% to 5.23 Singapore cents.

site_title: Thai finance ministry keeps 2016 GDP growth at 3.3%
summary: Thailand's finance ministry has reaffirmed its 2016 GDP growth forecast at 3.3%, citing strong government spending and tourism. Exports are now expected to contract only 0.5% this year, better than the initial 1.9% decline predicted. The ministry projects 3.4% growth for next year and 1.8% increase in exports for 2017. This revised forecast follows last year's 2.8% growth.

site_title: Oriental to dispose of Wan Dormitory for S$24.2m to alleviate financial woes
summary: Oriental Group has agreed to sell Wan Dormitory for S$24.2 million to alleviate financial woes. The disposal is part of the group's efforts to address cash flow and going concern issues. The sale was made after arms' length negotiations between Oriental Group and Dacai Pte Ltd, a company involved in the agriculture business. Trading in Oriental Group's shares has been halted since March 11, and the group's board deemed the disposal necessary to address its financial concerns. The sale will help alleviate the group's cash flow issues.

site_title: Singapore shares drift lower in thin volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 12.68 points to 2,816.26 on Friday, dropping 16 points for the week. The decline occurred amid market uncertainty ahead of the US presidential elections on November 8. Volume was thin, with 929 million units traded worth S$878 million, the first time below the S$1 billion threshold in five consecutive days. Shares of Delong Holdings surged 35% on Friday after announcing higher-than-expected Q3 results.

site_title: Malaysia to buy navy vessels from China in blow to US
summary: Malaysia is set to sign a contract with China to purchase Littoral Mission Ships, marking the country's first significant defense deal with China. The move comes amid rising tensions in the South China Sea and as the US and China compete for influence in the region. The purchase, valued at approximately $1 billion, is seen as a response to China's support during a money-laundering scandal involving Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak. The deal is expected to strengthen Malaysia's ties with China, which has been a key player in the country's efforts to resolve the scandal.

site_title: Hot stock: Delong surges 35% on thin volume after higher profit guidance
summary: Delong Holdings shares surged 35% on Friday, driven by higher profit guidance for the third quarter. The Chinese steel company's net profit is expected to see a "significant increase" compared to last year, mainly due to increased sales volume and average selling prices. Volume was light, with only 19,000 shares traded. Delong plans to unveil Q3 results on November 8, 2016.

site_title: Exports boost US growth in Q3; consumer spending slows
summary: The US economy grew at a 2.9% annual rate in the third quarter, its fastest pace in two years, driven by a surge in exports and inventory investment. Consumer spending slowed to a 2.1% rate, but remained supportive of the economy. The trade deficit shrank due to a 10% increase in soybean exports, contributing to GDP growth. The strong growth rate could support an interest rate hike in December, but concerns remain about a potential reversal in export growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: China: Stocks edge lower as investors digest Q3 results
summary: China's stocks fell 0.1% to 3,340.13 in the CSI300 index and 0.3% to 3,104.27 in the Shanghai Composite Index, amid mixed earnings reports. The market rebounded for the third straight week, driven by financial sector gains, but weakness in infrastructure stocks offset these gains. China's industrial firms reported slower profit growth, while banks and brokerages showed improvement. The market remains stable, with investors focusing on state company reforms and the impact of yuan depreciation and rising interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.24 points to close at 1,670.27 on Friday, with 1.48 billion lots valued at RM1.66 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 335 to 428. The index ended higher despite no specific news or events mentioned in the article.

site_title: Yuan set for biggest monthly drop since August 2015 devaluation
summary: China's yuan is poised for its largest monthly drop since August 2015, falling 1.5% to 6.7793 a US dollar as of Friday. The decline has sparked concerns that China's policymakers are becoming more tolerant of currency fluctuations, particularly with exports slumping and the dollar advancing. Despite verbal pushback from officials, analysts predict the yuan will continue to decline, with a Bloomberg survey forecasting a year-end rate of 6.8 US dollars. The yuan's recent tumble is attributed to the US Federal Reserve's potential interest-rate increase and China's own economic slowdown.

site_title: Philippine mayor among 10 killed in shootout as drug war enters new phase
summary: A Philippine mayor wanted for alleged drug links was killed along with nine of his guards in a shootout with police, marking a new phase of President Rodrigo Duterte's war on drugs. The mayor, Samsudin Dimaukom, was transporting drugs when police tried to intercept him at a checkpoint in Mindanao. The incident occurred as part of "Project Double Barrel Alpha," a plan to target high-profile suspects, including politicians and celebrities. The campaign has claimed over 2,300 lives since Duterte took office, sparking international concern about extrajudicial killings.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks at 2-month low on US rate hike prospects
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell to a two-month low on October 28, 2016, due to heightened expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike by year-end. The Hang Seng index dropped 0.8% and the China Enterprises Index lost 1.0%, with most financial and property stocks declining. An unexpected drop in China's September industrial profits also raised concerns about the country's economic recovery. One bright spot was ANTA Sports' strong third-quarter results, which lifted the sportswear group to a nine-month high.

site_title: Samsung Biologics prices 2.25t won IPO at high end of range
summary: Samsung Biologics priced its initial public offering at 136,000 won per share, raising approximately 2.25 trillion won (S$2.8 billion) at the high end of its marketed range. The pharmaceutical arm of the South Korean conglomerate aims to offset pressures in its smartphone operations. As a contract manufacturer for biologic medicines, the company is poised to benefit from the growing global market projected to exceed $390 billion by 2020.

site_title: Shanghai: Stock exchange to cut fee on China SSE 50ETF options
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange will cut its transaction fee on China SSE 50ETF options from 2 yuan to 1.3 yuan per contract, effective November 1. This fee reduction aims to increase trading activity and liquidity in the market. The move is part of the exchange's efforts to improve market efficiency and competitiveness.

site_title: Amazon starts Prime service in China to compete with Alibaba
summary: Amazon has launched its Prime service in China, offering free shipping on orders exceeding 200 yuan (S$41) on eligible overseas goods. The service, priced at 388 yuan a year, aims to compete with Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. Amazon's global logistics network will manage shipping and delivery, with packages arriving within 5-9 days in 82 cities. The move follows Wal-Mart's expansion efforts in China and India through a partnership with JD.com.

site_title: French economy grows in stop-start expansion that lags peers
summary: France's economy expanded 0.2% in the third quarter, lagging behind its peers, with a start-stop expansion that leaves it trailing Spain and Germany. The sluggish performance adds pressure on President Francois Hollande, who faces an election in mid-December. Despite this, the economy is expected to match its 2015 performance, with full-year growth forecast at 1.3%, and is re-converging with Italy, according to economists.

site_title: US markets not fully buying a Clinton win
summary: US financial markets are showing caution despite polls indicating a likely Hillary Clinton victory in the presidential election. Investors are hesitant to fully commit to Clinton, waiting until after November 8 to make their moves. Analysts attribute this to a lack of confidence in Clinton's policies and concerns over the potential impact of a Trump presidency, including trade restrictions and foreign policy uncertainty. Market sentiment has been reflected in a decline in the Mexican peso and a fall in the Nasdaq biotechnology index, with some analysts warning of potential downside if Clinton does not win.

site_title: As yuan slumps, China boosts purchases of gold from overseas
summary: China boosted gold purchases from overseas in September, with net imports rising to 44.9 metric tons from 41.9 tons in August, as investors sought to diversify assets amid currency weakness.
