The mainland bought 64.8 tons, while exports fell to 19.9 tons. The move comes as the offshore yuan hits a record low, and investors weigh concerns over China's property market. Goldman Sachs notes that further currency losses and investors' concerns may spur gold demand in China.

site_title: China's Crown crackdown throws up uncertainty, rival Star says
summary: China's detention of 18 Crown Resorts Ltd employees has raised uncertainty about the impact on business, with Australian rival Star Entertainment Group stating its potential effect on revenue isn't clear due to limited information. Star's revenue from high-priority gamblers, mostly from Asian junket operators, accounts for less than 30% of gross revenue. The company will continue to monitor developments and work with staff and external agents to understand the situation, with shares falling 2.5% following the news.

images.alt_text: China's detention of 18 Crown Resorts Ltd employees has created some uncertainty and it's tough to grasp how the crackdown might impact business, Australian rival Star Entertainment Group said.

site_title: China oil giant Sinopec Q3 net profit jumps sixfold
summary: China's largest oil refiner, Sinopec, reported a sixfold increase in its third-quarter net profit to 10.19 billion yuan, driven by low crude prices that lowered its costs. The firm attributed the surge to international crude prices hitting a "low level" in the third quarter, despite rebounding. Sinopec's shares rose 0.60% in Shanghai and 0.18% in Hong Kong. The company's profits were boosted by its purchase of most of the oil it processes from overseas. China's economic growth remained stable at 6.7% in the third quarter.

site_title: BOJ loses bark and bite under humbled Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has signaled that the central bank will not ease monetary policies further, instead adopting a more predictable approach. His term is winding down, and he has retreated from radical policies and rhetoric. The BOJ will keep policy unchanged despite downgraded forecasts, with inflation expected to reach the 2% target before his term ends in 2018. The shift in approach marks a departure from Kuroda's initial "shock and awe" tactics, which have been deemed less effective in achieving desired outcomes.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares finish lower amid political jitters
summary: The South Korean won edged down 0.2% to 1,144.9 to the US dollar, amid concerns over President Park Geun-hye's involvement in a scandal. The won's decline follows a survey showing her popularity at its lowest, 17.5%, since taking office in 2013. South Korean shares also fell 0.2% with the Kospi index closing at 2,019.42 points.

site_title: Michelle Obama stumps with Hillary, Pence in plane scare
summary: US First Lady Michelle Obama stumped for Democrat Hillary Clinton in North Carolina, urging voters to turn out for the election. Meanwhile, Republican candidate Mike Pence's plane skidded off the runway at LaGuardia Airport, causing a scare but no injuries. Trump dismissed the incident, saying Pence was fine and that he had spoken to him. The campaign has seen a series of controversies, including a 2005 video of Trump boasting about groping women, but Clinton remains ahead in polls, with a 5.4-point lead in a national race.

images.alt_text: US First Lady Michelle Obama implored voters to troop to the polls as she stumped on Thursday for Democrat Hillary Clinton, while the race suffered a scare when Donald Trump's running mate's plane skidded off the runway.

site_title: Asia: Most markets dip but Tokyo lifted by weak yen
summary: Japanese stocks rose on Friday driven by a weaker yen, as a weaker yen lifted the Nikkei 0.5% and Shanghai 0.4%. The dollar extended gains against Asia-Pacific currencies, while bond yields rose as traders shifted out of ultra-safe investments. A surprise jump in British economic growth and talk of a potential US interest rate hike by the end of the year also contributed to the market movements.

site_title: Update: UBS faces possible suspension from IPO underwriting in Hong Kong
summary: UBS Group AG may face a possible suspension from underwriting initial public offerings in Hong Kong due to a Securities and Futures Commission investigation. The Swiss bank has been fined and may face financial ramifications for its work on some IPOs. The city's regulator has tightened oversight of underwriters, introducing a new system to hold them accountable for untrue statements in offer documents. This comes as Chinese investment banks dominate the Hong Kong equity market, pushing Western firms like UBS out of the top spots.

site_title: Myanmar detects first Zika infection
summary: Myanmar has detected its first Zika infection, a mosquito-borne virus linked to birth defects, in a 32-year-old pregnant foreign woman in Yangon. The World Health Organization warned of the virus's spread in Asia, where cases have increased in recent months, including in Singapore and Thailand. There is no cure or vaccine for Zika, and pregnant women with the virus risk giving birth to babies with microcephaly. This is the first reported case of Zika in Myanmar, which is part of the Asia Pacific region at high risk of further spread.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei climbs to fresh 6-month high as rising yields help financial sector
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose to a fresh six-month high, ending at 17,446.41, as rising global bond yields boosted financials. The benchmark index gained 0.6% on Friday and 1.5% for the week, with the Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also rising. The gains reflect hopes of increased investments by financial institutions in overseas bonds, despite Japan's low bond yield environment.

site_title: Cassette tapes fast-forward to new following in Southeast Asia
summary: Cassette tapes have experienced a resurgence in popularity in Southeast Asia, particularly among music fans and collectors. The format, once thought to be extinct, is now being used by artists such as Kanye West and Justin Bieber to release music. Low production costs and a retro-cool image have made cassettes a staple in the region's underground music scene, with many struggling bands using them as a way to gain exposure. The affordable cost of cassettes, with manufacturing costs as low as RM4 (S$1.32) per tape, is a major advantage over vinyl records, which are more expensive to produce.

site_title: As China tackles corporate debt, risks spread wider
summary: China has unveiled guidelines to curb corporate debt, which may shift growing credit risks to private investors. The plan aims to lower the country's $18 trillion corporate debt by allowing stressed companies to swap part of their debt for equity investments. Two such deals have been announced, involving China Construction Bank Corp and Yunnan Tin Group Co, which will raise billions of dollars in debt from private investors, such as insurance funds and pension funds. Analysts warn that this shift may increase risk to individual investors, as the transactions push risk away from financial institutions and towards the broader economy.

images.alt_text: China's plan to curb spiralling bank debt at weak state-owned companies could shift growing credit risks away from financial institutions and to the country's private investors, analysts say.

site_title: Hanjin fate tested as Korea kicks off sale of Asia-US business
summary: A South Korean court has begun selling parts of Hanjin Shipping Co, the country's largest container line, as it navigates bankruptcy. The sale of its Asia-US business will determine the company's fate, with potential buyers invited to submit proposals by November 7. Hyundai Merchant Marine Co, owned by the state-owned Korea Development Bank, is considering bidding. The sale of Hanjin's assets could help bolster Hyundai Merchant's competitiveness and shape the future of South Korea's shipping industry.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit by AMP, ANZ profit warnings, biggest weekly loss in 4 months
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Friday, marking their biggest weekly loss in four months, due to profit warnings from AMP Ltd and ANZ Banking Group. AMP fell 9.1% to its lowest in over two years, while ANZ dropped 1.7% to a near two-month low. Despite gains in energy and mining sectors, losses in materials and consumer discretionary stocks offset gains in healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.2% to close at 5,283.8, down 2.7% for the week.

site_title: Michelin-starred soya sauce chicken stall to open restaurant
summary: Michelin-starred soya sauce chicken stall Liao Fan Hong Kong will open its first restaurant, Hawker Chan, in November. The 2,000 sq ft restaurant, a partnership between chef Chan and Hersing Culinary, will seat 80 people and serve the famous soya sauce chicken, as well as new dishes. Prices are still being worked out, but will be higher than the hawker stall yet affordable for the masses. The restaurant will offer a comfortable dining environment with air conditioning and a proper ordering and payment system. The investment is S$1 million.

site_title: Aussie dollar at 2-week lows, kiwi struggles ahead of US data
summary: The Australian dollar has fallen to a two-week low at US$0.7593, marking its second straight weekly loss, ahead of US third-quarter economic data. The Aussie had risen to US$0.7709 on Wednesday but fell back. A stronger US dollar, fueled by rising Treasury yields, has weighed down the Aussie. US data expected to show the economy expanded 2.5% in the third quarter could lead to interest rate hikes, setting a bearish tone for the Aussie. The New Zealand dollar has also fallen to 9-day lows.

site_title: China to unveil its J-20 stealth fighter at air show
summary: China is set to unveil its J-20 stealth fighter jet at the China International Aviation and Aerospace Exhibition in Zhuhai, marking the first public showing of the fifth-generation aircraft. The J-20 is part of China's efforts to narrow the military gap with the US and project air power in the region. The aircraft's production is proceeding according to plan, with a flight demonstration scheduled for next week. China hopes the J-20 will give its air force the capability to carry out both offensive and defensive operations, and compete with US-made F-35 stealth aircraft in the international market.

site_title: Brazil prosecutor says Trump franchise may have benefited from corruption
summary: A Brazilian prosecutor claims Donald Trump's real estate company may have benefited from corruption in the development of Rio de Janeiro's Porto Maravilha project, a $3.5 billion redevelopment of docklands ahead of the Olympics. The project involved the national employee severance fund paying upfront for building rights, which were then sold. The prosecutor is investigating the deal, which included five buildings under the Trump brand.

site_title: Baidu beats estimates on cost cuts amid first revenue slide
summary: Baidu Inc. reported its third-quarter earnings, beating analysts' estimates with a profit of $1.49 per share. However, the Chinese search giant saw its revenue decline for the first time, falling to 18.3 billion yuan. The decline is attributed to a crackdown on online advertising in China and Baidu's cost-cutting measures, including subsidies for its group-buying platform Nuomi. Despite this, Baidu's chairman, Robin Li, expects the company to return to growth in 2017 and sees potential for new revenue streams from its news feed service.

site_title: Deal struck for world's biggest marine reserve in Antarctica
summary: A deal has been reached to establish the world's largest marine reserve in Antarctica, covering over 1.55 million square kilometers. The Ross Sea reserve, with 1.12 million square kilometers as a no-fishing zone, aims to protect the pristine wilderness and ecosystems of the region, home to penguins, seals, whales, and krill. The agreement, reached after years of negotiations, was supported by the US and New Zealand, with Russia dropping its opposition. The move is considered a significant step in promoting world marine conservation and addressing the impacts of climate change on the ocean.

site_title: BNP Paribas beefs up capital buffer after a strong quarter
summary: BNP Paribas, France's largest bank, reported a strong third quarter with a 3.3% increase in net income to 1.89 billion euros, beating analyst estimates. The bank raised its capital buffer by 30 basis points to 11.4%, exceeding its target of 12% by end-2018. This move aims to reassure investors amid uncertainty over regulatory requirements. Revenue rose 2.4% to 10.59 billion euros, driven by strong bond trading and fixed income, currencies, and commodities trading revenue, which increased 41.3%. The bank's diversified business model helped maintain earnings despite struggles in its home markets.

site_title: Two senior Chinese officers expelled from Communist Party
summary: China's ruling Communist Party has expelled two senior military officers, Fan Changmi and Niu Zhizhong, for corruption as part of President Xi Jinping's anti-graft campaign. The expulsions come after a report confirmed "serious discipline violations," a euphemism for corruption. This is the latest in a series of high-profile purges, with a former deputy head of the Central Military Commission jailed for life in July. The move aims to modernize China's armed forces and combat widespread graft, which serving and retired officers say could undermine the country's military capabilities.

site_title: HDB resale prices unchanged in Q3 from Q2
summary: HDB resale prices remained unchanged in the third quarter from the second quarter, with 5,514 transactions recorded in Q3. Resale transactions slipped 5.5% from the second quarter, and applications for subletting flats decreased 8.8%. The HDB will offer 5,090 new flats in a Build-to-Order exercise next month, alongside 5,000 balance flats in a concurrent Sale of Balance Flats exercise.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.19% on Friday, extending losses for a fourth straight day, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped 43.52 points to 23,088.83, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.98 points to 2,067.11.

site_title: Hot stock: UOB down 2% as Q3 profit hit by bad-loan charges
summary: UOB shares fell 2% on Friday after the bank reported a 7.8% lower net profit for the third quarter, primarily due to higher bad-loan charges from its oil and gas exposure. Total allowances rose 15.7% to S$185 million, mainly from the oil and gas industry. The bank's net profit for the quarter was S$791 million, beating the average forecast of S$747 million.

site_title: Flash: HDB resale prices flat in Q3 from Q2
summary: HDB resale prices remained unchanged in Q3 from Q2, with no significant fluctuations reported. The flat market continues to be influenced by low mortgage rates, but experts caution against pursuing condo dreams due to an economic outlook that is weakening. The government is exploring ways to encourage the reuse of private housing blocks and increase their lifespan to over 50 years.

site_title: Taiwan Q3 preliminary GDP growth at 2.06%, fastest since Q1 2015
summary: Taiwan's economy grew 2.06% in the third quarter of 2016, the strongest growth rate since Q1 2015. This beats economists' forecast of 1.8% growth. The result is attributed to a robust manufacturing sector and a decline in imports. This growth rate is a positive indicator for the Taiwanese economy, suggesting a recovery from previous sluggish growth periods.

site_title: China embraces hybrids in pivot from plug-in path to clean cars
summary: China has set ambitious targets for conventional hybrids, aiming for 8% of total passenger vehicle sales by 2020 and 20% by 2025, as part of its pivot from promoting plug-in vehicles. The government seeks to have one in four vehicles be plug-less hybrids by 2030. This shift is expected to benefit Toyota and suppliers like Hunan Corun New Energy Co., which supplies batteries for Toyota's hybrids. The move represents a significant shift in China's auto industry policy, following years of excluding conventional hybrids from subsidies.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks shrug off early losses; GDP data spurs some buying
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% to 9,304.88 on Friday, following a 0.7% decline in the previous session, after government data showed the economy grew at its fastest pace in a year and a half. The data backs expectations that the central bank will hold interest rates steady for a second time at its December quarterly meeting, supporting a gradual recovery in the export-driven economy.

site_title: Broker's take: SingPost's second Alibaba investment takes time to digest
summary: SingPost's stock surged 5% after the postal and logistics firm announced Alibaba's regulatory approval for its second $187 million investment, increasing Alibaba's stake from 10.2% to 14.4%. This investment is expected to be completed by Feb 28, 2017. Additionally, Alibaba completed a joint venture with SingPost's logistics subsidiary, Quantium Solutions, investing $86.2 million for new shares. The report suggests SingPost will take time to digest these investments, despite the positive market reaction.

site_title: Australia: Shares set for biggest weekly loss in 8 months, AMP slumps; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell for a third straight session, on track for their biggest weekly loss in eight months, due to profit warnings from Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and AMP. AMP shares dropped 9.7% after announcing US$910 million in impairment charges, while ANZ shares declined 0.8%. However, Macquarie Group rose 1.7% after beating earnings estimates. Energy and mining stocks gained, offsetting losses, with iron ore futures reaching a 26-month high in China.

site_title: UPS puts US$5.3b in air power behind Asia, Europe expansion
summary: UPS is investing $5.3 billion in air power to expand its operations in Asia and Europe, with the order of 14 Boeing 747 jumbo jets. The international division's daily package volume has increased 58% over the past decade, driven by strong growth in the China and Hong Kong markets. Overseas operating profit jumped 14% in the past quarter, with the 747-8 freighters primarily used on routes between the US and Asia, Europe, and the Middle East. This expansion is expected to boost free cash flow, despite concerns about the underlying air market's strength.

site_title: Donald Trump throws counter punch after Joe Biden comments
summary: Donald Trump responded to Vice President Joe Biden's comment about taking him "behind the gym" to punish him for past comments on women. At a rally in Ohio, Trump laughed and blew air from his mouth, implying Biden would fall over if he tried to take him. Trump claimed the media would be outraged if he made similar comments about Biden, but instead, the media praised him. Trump also joked that he "dreams" about facing Biden.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump shrugged off tough talk from Vice President Joe Biden with a verbal counter punch of his own.

site_title: Flash: URA's office rental index down 1.1 % in Q3 2016 over Q2
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reported a 1.1% decline in its office rental index from Q2 to Q3 2016. The office vacancy rate surged to 10.4% at the end of Q3. This marks a significant increase from the previous quarter. The decline in office rental index suggests a decrease in demand for office spaces in Singapore.

site_title: Australian billionaire Rinehart pulls ahead in bid for major land holding
summary: Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart is poised to acquire the country's largest private land holding, S. Kidman & Co., after a rival bidder, the BBHO consortium, withdrew its A$386 million offer. Rinehart had pledged to buy the land outright if her joint bid with Shanghai CRED was rejected on national interest grounds. The decision follows a pledge by Rinehart to purchase the land holdings alone if necessary, killing off the BBHO bid. Bidders can still lodge competing offers before the Dec 9 deadline.

site_title: Flash: URA retail rental index down 1.5 % in Q3 2016 over Q2
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) retail rental index decreased by 1.5% in Q3 2016 compared to Q2, with a vacancy rate of 8.4% for retail space islandwide at the end of Q3.

site_title: Vacancy rate for retail space islandwide rises to 8.4% at end-Q3
summary: Singapore's retail space vacancy rate rose to 8.4% at the end of Q3 2016, up from 7.8% in Q2. The islandwide retail property rental index fell 1.5% in Q3, while the retail property price index eased 0.6%. Occupied retail space decreased by 26,000 sq m, while the stock of retail space increased by 17,000 sq m. A total of 652,000 sq m of retail space is currently under pipeline projects.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.600 points to 1669.610. Volume reached 85.836 million lots worth RM44.744 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 101 to 87.

site_title: GE in talks to buy Baker Hughes: report
summary: General Electric is in talks to acquire oilfield-services company Baker Hughes in a potential US$30 billion deal, according to The Wall Street Journal. This would be GE's largest acquisition, following its 2016 purchase of Alstom's power and grid businesses for 9.7 billion euros. The talks come after Baker Hughes' previous attempt to merge with Halliburton was blocked by the Justice Department in 2014. The deal, if successful, would dwarf GE's previous acquisition and give the US industrial giant a significant presence in the oil and gas sector.

site_title: Hot stock: SingPost surges 5% on regulatory nod for Alibaba to up stake
summary: SingPost shares surged 5% on Friday after the Info-communications Media Development Authority approved Alibaba's plan to increase its stake in the postal and logistics firm from 10.2% to 14.4%. Alibaba will also invest S$187.1 million in the group, with the deal targeted to be completed by February 28, 2017. This move will make Alibaba the second-largest shareholder, after Singtel.

site_title: Japan consumer prices fall for seventh straight month
summary: Japan's consumer prices fell 0.5% in September for the seventh consecutive month, missing the Bank of Japan's 2.0% inflation target. The decline puts pressure on the central bank to reconsider its inflation target deadline, currently set for March 2018. Analysts suggest the deadline may be delayed due to falling energy prices and a strong yen, which continue to pressure CPI figures. The government's economic stimulus package, dubbed Abenomics, has yet to show significant growth, leading some economists to write off the policy.

site_title: Pence's plane skids off runway at New York airport, no injuries
summary: US Vice Presidential nominee Mike Pence's campaign plane skidded off the runway at New York City's LaGuardia Airport on Thursday, but no one was injured. The incident occurred after the plane landed, and a Fox News producer on board reported the incident. The cause of the skid is not specified. Despite the incident, Pence's campaign continued without disruption.

site_title: Private home prices, rents fell more steeply in Q3 than Q2
summary: Private home prices and rents fell 1.5% and 1.2% respectively in Q3, marking a steeper decline than in Q2. The price decline reached 11% from the peak in Q3 2013. Landed properties led the price decline, followed by non-landed properties. Developers launched 1,609 uncompleted units and sold 1,981, with resales accounting for 53.9% of transactions. A total of 25,211 units, including ECs, remained unsold.

site_title: Singapore shares open down 5.84 points on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened lower on Friday, down 5.84 points to 2,823.10. Wall Street closed lower overnight, with top losers including UOB and Jardine C&C. Trading volume was moderate, with 39.2 million shares changing hands. The STI has had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but this loss may signal a shift in investor sentiment.

site_title: Seoul: Won at 3-1/2 month low on broad US dollar strength, Park's problems; stocks slip
summary: The South Korean won plummeted to a three-and-a-half month low, falling 0.2% against the US dollar, amid expectations of a US interest rate rise and President Park Geun-hye's political troubles. Park's popularity has slumped to 17.5%, the lowest since taking office in 2013. The won's weakness was also influenced by the ongoing scandal and a survey showing the president's low approval rating. Meanwhile, South Korean shares fell, with the Kospi index down 0.2% and foreign investors net selling Kospi shares worth 39 billion won.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, CDL Hospitality Trusts, IndoAgri
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 7.8% fall in net profit for the third quarter due to higher provisions for the oil and gas industry. In contrast, CDL Hospitality Trusts increased its distribution per stapled security by 3.4% due to stronger income. IndoAgri reversed into profit for the third quarter, driven by stronger revenue and forex translation gains, with a net profit of S$16 million.

site_title: China city migration to help economy rebalance, Dollar says
summary: China plans to encourage 100 million rural citizens to move to cities and obtain residency permits by 2020, a key step in reforming the country's restrictive labor mobility system. This move aims to boost consumer-led growth, reduce income inequality, and make the economy more productive. According to David Dollar, a Brookings Institution senior fellow, the shift could help alleviate excess housing in smaller cities and increase incomes for millions, but may not necessarily bring productive young workers to dynamic urban areas like Shanghai.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a weak yen that triggered buying of exporter shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.65% to 17,448.39, while the Topix index of all first-section issues rose 0.60%. The gains were attributed to a weak yen, which makes exporter shares more attractive.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts records 3.4% higher DPS for Q3
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 3.4% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q3, driven by stronger income. DPS rose to 2.44 Singapore cents, compared to 2.36 Singapore cents in the same period last year. Net property income increased 5.3% to S$34.8 million, primarily due to contributions from hotels in the UK and New Zealand.

site_title: Alphabet buries another math joke in share buyback
summary: Alphabet Inc. announced a US$7,019,340,976.83 share buyback, a math joke referencing the number of letters in the alphabet and the mathematical constant "e". This is the latest in a series of math-based financial decisions by the company, including a previous buyback of US$5,099,019,513.59. Alphabet's parent company, Google, has a history of incorporating mathematical references in its financial announcements, including a reference to pi in a failed bid to buy Nortel Network patents. The move is seen as part of the company's efforts to rein in spending.

site_title: Flash: Private residential prices down 1.5% in Q3
summary: Private residential prices in Singapore decreased by 1.5% in Q3, a sharper decline than the 1% drop in Q2. Low mortgage rates are attributed to the decrease. Despite economic concerns, the market remains attractive, with new private homes planned in Paterson and Newton areas. The Draft Master Plan 2025 aims to increase capacity, but success depends on developers and skilled migrants.

site_title: Office vacancy rate surges to 10.4% at end-Q3: URA
summary: The office vacancy rate in Singapore surged to 10.4% at the end of Q3, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. This is a significant increase from the previous quarter. The office rental index fell 1.1% and the office price index dropped 0.4% in Q3, both smaller declines than in Q2. The URA data suggests a decrease in demand for office space, but the exact causes are not specified.

site_title: Uber lays out vision for flying commuter transit
summary: Uber has released a 98-page white paper outlining a vision for on-demand aircraft that could transport commuters in a fraction of the time it takes by road. The "vertical take-off and landing" vehicles, also known as flying taxis, are being assessed for feasibility. Uber plans to collaborate with cities, manufacturers, and other partners to bring the concept to life, with the goal of reducing travel time and increasing accessibility.

site_title: Nintendo hints of bigger hardware plans for Switch
summary: Nintendo hints at larger plans for its Switch console, including more accessories and software, and potential tie-ups with other technologies. President Tatsumi Kimishima mentioned that details about add-ons will be revealed in the new year. The company will announce pricing and a launch date for Switch on January 13, followed by a public event to try it out.

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat after choppy day, Amec sinks 20%
summary: European shares ended flat on Thursday after a choppy day, with pharmaceutical and banking stocks offsetting losses in companies like Amec Foster and Berendsen. Amec Foster sank 20% after a strategy review, while Berendsen fell 16.3% after a profit warning. Gains in companies like STMicroelectronics, which rose 10%, and Deutsche Bank, which rose 0.6%, helped offset the losses. Pharmaceutical stocks, including Fresenius, also saw gains, with the company raising its earnings guidance.

site_title: Flash: UOB Q3 net profit down 7.8%
summary: UOB reported a 7.8% decline in its third-quarter net profit, marking a significant drop from previous quarters. This follows a 4.2% decline in the second quarter. The bank's Q3 profit was impacted by various factors, including higher operating costs and a decline in interest income. The decline in net profit is expected to have a negative impact on the bank's overall financial performance.

site_title: Trump insists he's going to win US election
summary: US Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump insisted he will win the White House on November 8, despite polls showing his opponent, Democrat Hillary Clinton, leading in the popular vote. Trump claimed he is winning in key states like Florida, North Carolina, and Ohio, and accused the media of being biased towards Clinton. The election is in its final stretch, with both candidates focusing on getting supporters out to the polls.

site_title: Oil prices dip on doubts Opec can coordinate output cut
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday due to doubts over Opec's ability to coordinate a significant output cut to address oversupply. International Brent crude oil futures fell to $50.39 per barrel, down 8 cents from the previous close. Traders expressed concerns that Opec's November 30 meeting may not yield a significant cut, with several members, including Iraq and Iran, and Russia, expressing reluctance to participate. Saudi Arabia is seen as the key player in rallying the group, but its efforts may be hindered by exemptions sought by other members.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dipped early on Friday, weighed down by lingering doubts over whether Opec can coordinate a crude production cut big enough to rein in oversupply that has dogged markets for two years.

site_title: Update: UOB's Q3 profit falls 7.8%, as oil rout lifts bad loan charges
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 7.8% decline in net profit for the third quarter, primarily due to higher allowances from the oil-and-gas segment and weaker non-interest income. Total allowances increased 15.7% to S$185 million, mainly from the oil-and-gas industry. Non-performing loan ratio rose to 1.6% from 1.3% a year ago. The bank's net interest margin fell to 1.69% from 1.77%. UOB's CEO attributed the decline to subdued global economic growth and volatile market conditions.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank on Friday posted 7.8 per cent lower net profit for the third quarter on higher allowances from the oil-and-gas segment, and weaker non-interest income.

site_title: Struggling Indian savers threaten Modi's growth ambition
summary: India's savings rate is expected to drop to 30.2% of GDP this year, the lowest since 2003, and further decline over the next two years, according to the International Monetary Fund. This decline poses a threat to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's economic growth ambitions, as low savings rates increase vulnerability to external risks and hinder job creation. Economists say India needs a savings rate of around 35% to harness its youth bulge and achieve sustainable growth.

site_title: Nissan defuses brexit tension with promise to build SUVs in UK
summary: Nissan has pledged to maintain production at its Sunderland plant in northern England, defusing Brexit-related tension with the British government. The Japanese automaker will start manufacturing the X-Trail SUV alongside the next-generation Qashqai, with no immediate plans to increase output or jobs. Nissan's CEO Carlos Ghosn credited "support and assurances" from the UK government for the decision, which employs over 7,000 people and supports 28,000 supplier jobs.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor Co, the biggest auto producer in the UK, promised to maintain production at its Sunderland plant in northern England, defusing tension with the British government over potential compensation connected to Brexit.

site_title: Bill Clinton 'for profit' income detailed in hacked email
summary: Former US President Bill Clinton earned over $50 million from "for-profit" activities while leading the Clinton family foundation, according to a 2011 memo released by WikiLeaks. The memo, written by close aide Douglas Band, details personal and foundation moneymaking efforts. This latest disclosure adds to the growing WikiLeaks revelations affecting Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as bond yields spike, retailers drop
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as bond yields surged, reaching a 3.0% increase, the highest since June, amid expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December. Retailers also declined, with a trade group citing the US presidential campaign as a factor. Market analysts attributed the downturn to the rising yields, not earnings, which is weighing on stocks.

site_title: US lawyer says Supreme Court justice groped her: report
summary: A US lawyer, Moira Smith, has accused Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas of making unwanted sexual advances in 1999. Smith, 23 at the time, claims Thomas groped her buttocks at a dinner party, suggesting she sit next to him. Thomas denied the allegations, calling them "preposterous" and stating they never happened. Smith made public her allegations after hearing Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's comments about groping women, stating that silence on such incidents is no longer defensible.

site_title: Mobile, video pump up profit at Google parent Alphabet
summary: Google parent Alphabet delivered higher profits for the third quarter, driven by gains in mobile and video advertising, with net profit climbing 27% to $5.1 billion. Revenue rose 19% to $22.5 billion. Alphabet's "moonshots," including self-driving cars and internet balloons, reported a loss of $865 million. The company expects to spend more on marketing in the year-end quarter due to new hardware products. Shares rose nearly 1% in after-market trades following the stronger-than-expected earnings figures.

site_title: Italy in 'miraculous' earthquake escape
summary: Italy has narrowly escaped a potentially deadly earthquake, with two powerful quakes causing widespread destruction but miraculously resulting in no fatalities. The 5.5 and 6.1 magnitude tremors struck a mountainous region, leaving over 4,000 people unable to return to their homes and causing significant damage. The government has pledged to rebuild every home destroyed, with a 40 million euro fund released to support the effort. Despite the scale of the disaster, Interior Minister Angelino Alfano described the absence of fatalities as "miraculous."

site_title: Xi team weighs biggest opening for private business since 1990s
summary: China is considering its biggest opening to private business since the 1990s, following weak investment figures that raised concerns about the country's economy. The government's policy-making body commissioned a study that proposed allowing private companies greater access to restricted industries, introducing rules to protect private investors, and reducing official meddling. The recommendations aim to bolster the economy, which is set for its slowest expansion in more than two decades, and would mark a sharp acceleration of reforms under President Xi Jinping's government.

site_title: UN votes to launch talks on nuclear weapons ban
summary: The UN General Assembly voted 123-38 with 16 abstentions to launch talks on a new treaty banning nuclear weapons, despite opposition from nuclear powers. The non-binding resolution, presented by Austria, Ireland, and others, aims to address the "catastrophic humanitarian consequences" of nuclear use. Negotiations are set to begin in March 2023. The measure is expected to be voted on by the full General Assembly in November or December. The treaty won't eliminate nuclear weapons immediately, but it will establish a new international legal standard and encourage disarmament.

site_title: Tata's Taj Hotels loses bid to extend lease on iconic Delhi site
summary: The Delhi High Court rejected a plea by Indian Hotels Co to extend the lease on the iconic Taj Hotel in New Delhi, a decision that adds to the company's woes following Cyrus Mistry's ouster as chairman of Tata Sons Ltd. The lease on the property, which overlooks India's presidential palace, ended in 2011, and the court upheld a single-judge bench order that Indian Hotels was not entitled to oppose the auction by the New Delhi Municipal Council. This decision comes just days after Mistry's ouster, further complicating Indian Hotels' situation.

site_title: Measuring economic progress is wading into murky water
summary: Measuring economic progress is becoming increasingly challenging. Per capita income, often used to gauge living standards, may not accurately reflect a country's overall well-being. Factors such as income inequality, access to education and healthcare, and environmental sustainability are also essential considerations. As the global economy continues to evolve, new metrics and approaches will be needed to accurately assess economic progress and ensure that all individuals and communities are thriving.

site_title: IndoAgri returns to the black in Q3 on higher revenue, forex gain
summary: Indofood Agri Resources (IndoAgri) posted a net profit of 159 billion rupiah (S$16 million) for the third quarter, reversing a net loss of 213 billion rupiah from the same period last year. Revenue rose 8.7% to 3.55 trillion rupiah, driven by a recovery in commodity prices and a 40.3 billion rupiah gain in forex translation. The company's turnaround is attributed to stronger revenue and forex gains, contributing to its return to profitability for the third consecutive quarter.

site_title: Apple ramps up MacBook infused with touch controls
summary: Apple unveiled new MacBook Pro laptops with touch control features, including a "Touch Bar" that adapts to display relevant controls and "Touch ID" fingerprint sensors built into power buttons. The new models start at $1,799 for a 13-inch screen and $2,399 for a 15-inch screen. The introduction comes as Microsoft unveiled a high-end computer with similar features, and shipments of Apple computers declined by 8% in the same period last year. The new MacBook Pro models are aimed at guarding Mac user loyalty and winning new fans to the Apple ecosystem.

site_title: IMF chief Lagarde says Egypt in currency 'crisis'
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated that Egypt is facing a currency crisis due to a widening gap between official and black market rates. The country needs to address this issue to boost investor confidence and meet conditions for a $12 billion IMF loan. Egypt's foreign currency reserves stood at $19.6 billion in September, less than 50% of the level in early 2011. Lagarde supports the government's austerity program and is ready to provide support if the conditions for the loan are met.

images.alt_text: IMF chief Christine Lagarde said on Thursday that Egypt is going through a currency "crisis," suggesting a quick devaluation to tackle a widening gap between the official and black market rates.

site_title: Singapore employment dips in Q3 as resident joblessness stays flat
summary: Singapore's employment declined by 3,300 in the July-September quarter, marking the second time since the 2009 global financial crisis. The contraction is attributed to a decline in the construction and manufacturing sectors, primarily affecting work permit holders. This marks a reversal from the 12,600 job growth in the previous quarter.

site_title: Kenya drought threatens output target in world's biggest tea exporter
summary: Kenya's tea production may miss its 25% target due to an extended dry spell caused by the La Nina weather phenomenon. The drought, which has damaged the crop, may also hurt coffee output, with the tea leaves becoming dry and falling off. The country, the world's largest tea exporter, relies heavily on exports, and a decline in revenue is expected if prices at the auction don't pick up. The drought has also led to food insecurity for about 1.3 million people in Kenya, with the country's average African tea price dropping 16% this year.

site_title: Five years after Gaddafi fall, Libya on brink
summary: Libya marks five years since the fall of Muammar Gaddafi, facing significant economic, political, and security challenges. The country's oil production has declined to 551,000 barrels per day, with the World Bank warning of a "near collapse" economy due to inflation and lack of production. International concern has risen, with the US and Western powers pledging to support the UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA) and roll back the Islamic State (IS) presence in the country. A potential "window of opportunity" for greater order in Libya has been identified, with the US and allies committed to militarily, politically, and economically supporting the GNA.

site_title: SingPost gets nod for Alibaba to raise stake
summary: Alibaba has received approval from the Info-communications Media Development Authority to increase its stake in Singapore Post (SingPost) to 14.4% from 10.2%, with a further investment of S$187.1 million. The investment is expected to be completed by February 28, 2017. The deal, which was first announced in 2015, has been delayed multiple times due to regulatory approvals. The new stake will make Alibaba the second-largest shareholder of SingPost, behind Singtel.

site_title: Flying Dutchman soars
summary: Local soprano Kathleen Parker shines in her debut as Senta in Wagner's The Flying Dutchman, a production presented by Richard Wagner Association (Singapore) and OperaViva. Parker exudes strength and emotional delicacy, accompanied by a talented cast and orchestra. The opera, relocated to South-east Asia, features a visually stunning set and lighting design. Director Chong Tze Chien and Glen Goei successfully bring the story to life, with the orchestra's playing adding to the production's excellence. Parker's performance is a promising start to her career, solidifying her position as a rising star in the world opera scene.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: A week when S'pore unveiled strides in world of new energy
summary: Singapore unveiled significant progress in the new-energy world during the Singapore International Energy Week. The government announced new measures to shape both the supply and demand side of the energy equation, aiming to deliver more secure, cheaper, and sustainable energy to consumers. These initiatives include updates for the electricity, renewables, and liquefied natural gas (LNG) sectors. The moves are part of Singapore's efforts to transition towards cleaner fuels and smart meters, positioning the city-state as a leader in the transition to a new-energy world.

site_title: The bitcoin lesson for banks: come to terms with digital payment networks - or else
summary: Banks must adapt to the growing trend of digital payment networks, as traditional intermediaries face disruption from distributed ledgers, digital signatures, and virtual currencies. The potential loss of $300 trillion in transactions and $150-200 billion in revenues is significant, with 60% of corporate treasurers dissatisfied with payment services provided by banks. The adoption of distributed ledgers will likely occur in two waves, with international payments and domestic fiat currencies potentially destroying the market for checking accounts and credit cards.

site_title: Your weekend smorgasbord of life
summary: A Singaporean newspaper, The Business Times Weekend, explores various topics including amateur chefs, fintech, and lifestyle. The main paper features a brunch section on Singapore's fintech hub, while an offbeat column shares surprising stories from an Uber ride. The weekend edition also includes articles on food, volunteering, zero-waste living, and design solutions for unique homes. The newspaper is available in print or online at www.businesstimes.com.sg.

site_title: Spring to review criteria for key suite of business awards
summary: SPRING Singapore plans to review its business awards criteria to emphasize people development and innovation capabilities. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran announced the review, citing the need for organizations to adapt to the fast-changing economic landscape. The review will focus on leveraging disruptive models and technologies, driving innovation values, and building talent. The refreshed framework is expected to be announced in early 2017, with a new single mark of excellence, the Singapore Quality Class, replacing the Business Excellence (BE) recognition.

site_title: Core capital goods orders fall unexpectedly in September
summary: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly fell 1.2% in September, contradicting expectations of a 0.3% increase, amid weak demand for computers and electronics. This decline may temper expectations for business spending in the fourth quarter. Shipments of core capital goods rose 0.3% last month, but business spending on equipment likely remained weak. The decline in capital goods orders follows a subdued equipment spending trend since late 2015, driven by a strong US dollar and lower oil prices.

site_title: Deutsche Bank promises faster revamp as it braces for US fine
summary: Deutsche Bank has pledged to accelerate its restructuring efforts amid uncertainty over a multi-billion dollar fine from the US Department of Justice for mis-selling toxic mortgage-backed securities. The bank posted an unexpected quarterly profit of 278 million euros, but clients withdrew 9 billion euros in the third quarter, affecting its retail and wealth management business. Deutsche Bank has liquidity reserves of 200 billion euros and has set aside more money for its legal bill, with the bank working to wrap up negotiations for the fine "as soon as possible".

site_title: Enjoy great European fare at Senso Ristorante & Bar
summary: Senso Ristorante & Bar in Chinatown is offering a one-for-one deal on main courses from Oct 31 to Nov 4 as part of The Business Times' 40th Anniversary celebration. The restaurant serves creative European cuisine with seasonal Italian produce, including dishes such as Pappardelle XXLong and Ravioli al Vitello. Located in a heritage building, Senso Ristorante & Bar combines contemporary design with historical charm. Readers can enjoy the offer by getting a copy of The Business Times Weekend edition.

site_title: Microsoft launches its first desktop computer
summary: Microsoft launched its first desktop computer, the Surface Studio, featuring a touch-screen monitor and 3D simulation capabilities. The company also announced a free upgrade to Windows 10, allowing users to create 3D graphics and edits in 3D simulations. Despite declining sales, Microsoft aims to reinvigorate its computing business and appeal to creative users. The Surface Studio will be priced at $2,999, while Windows 10 upgrades will be available for free, targeting gamers and users who can take advantage of the new 3D features.

site_title: Belgium gets deal to allow signing of EU-Canada trade pact
summary: Belgium has reached a deal with regional parliaments to approve a trade agreement between the European Union and Canada, ending a deadlock that delayed the accord's signature. The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) aims to boost EU economic output by 12 billion euros a year and expand trade by a quarter. However, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau warned that the EU must prove its viability by passing the deal, while Belgium's federal government had been unable to persuade the Walloon regional parliament to sign up to the pact, citing concerns about employment and consumer standards.

site_title: Effortless display of smooth moves
summary: The Batsheva Dance Company, under artistic director Ohad Naharin, performed its acclaimed Deca-dance at Singapore's Esplanade's Da:ns Festival. Deca-dance is a 16-year-old collection of works showcasing Naharin's choreography, blending traditional and modern dance styles. The performance featured the dancers' athleticism and control, as well as their ability to convey emotions through movement. The audience was also invited to dance with the performers in one segment, highlighting the joy of movement. Naharin's Gaga philosophy emphasizes reconnecting to movement and sensation, which was evident in the performance.

images.alt_text: The dancers were strong and flexible, and switched between calm grace and sporadic twitches in the blink of an eye.

site_title: Singapore makes headway in tapping silver workers
summary: Singapore has made significant progress in tapping into the skills and experience of older workers, with a 67.2% employment rate for residents aged 55-64. The government's policies, such as the Retirement and Re-employment Act, and initiatives like WorkPro Job Redesign and Age Management grants, have encouraged employers like Maybank Singapore and Singapore General Hospital (SGH) to adopt age-friendly HR practices. These efforts have resulted in declining age-related complaints and have made Maybank and SGH exemplary employers, with the latter retaining staff for over 60 years.

site_title: Sembcorp Q3 profit falls 56% as all divisions but utilities turn red
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 56% decline in net profit to S$53.9 million in Q3, primarily due to losses in all divisions except utilities. Revenue dropped 11% to S$2.1 billion, with utilities being the only division to show growth. This marks a significant downturn for the company, with a year-over-year decline in net profit of 56%.

site_title: Snapchat expected to raise as much as US$4 billion in IPO
summary: Snapchat plans to raise up to $4 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at $25-35 billion, with a potential maximum valuation of $40 billion. The company aims to sell shares in the first quarter of 2022 and will file confidential IPO documents with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. This IPO could be the largest of a social media company since Twitter's 2013 listing, with Snapchat expected to generate over $350 million in advertising revenue this year.

site_title: Public transport fares to be 4.2% lower from Dec 30
summary: Singapore's Public Transport Council (PTC) has announced a 4.2% reduction in public transport fares starting December 30, driven by lower energy costs. This move will cut fare revenue for LTA, SMRT, and SBS Transit by approximately S$79 million annually. The reduction will benefit about 2.2 million commuters, with adults saving one to 27 cents, senior citizens saving 1 to 7 cents, and student card fares saving one cent. Monthly concession passes and travel passes remain unchanged.

images.alt_text: Underpinned by lower energy costs, commuter fares will come down from Dec 30 in a move that translates to a combined reduction of about S$79 million a year in fare revenue for the Land Transport Authority (LTA), SMRT and SBS Transit.

site_title: Singapore industrial rents slide further in Q3
summary: Singapore industrial rents have continued their decline for the sixth consecutive quarter, falling 2% in Q3 from Q2, with a 6.3% decline for the first nine months of 2016. The decline is attributed to weak manufacturing and trading conditions, as well as increased industrial space supply. Warehouse rents have been particularly affected, falling 4.4% quarter-on-quarter. Analysts predict a steeper decline in industrial rents, with some predicting a 7-10% fall for the full year, and expect the oversupply of industrial space to continue to exert downward pressure on occupancy rates and prices.

site_title: China ruling party elevates Xi's status ahead of reshuffle
summary: China's ruling party has declared President Xi Jinping as its "core", elevating his status ahead of a twice-a-decade power reshuffle next year. This move strengthens Xi's hand and gives him an elevated status, lacking by his predecessor Hu Jintao. The designation was announced at a four-day Communist Party conclave in Beijing, where new disciplinary measures were also approved to bolster anti-graft efforts and institutionalize Xi's four-year-old campaign. The move is seen as paving the way for Xi to install his people in key positions before the 2022 party congress.

site_title: Second-tier superhero makes an impression
summary: Doctor Strange, directed by Scott Derrickson, is a worthwhile trip in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, blending Eastern mysticism and spiritual awakenings with eye-popping special effects. Benedict Cumberbatch stars as Stephen Strange, a brilliant but arrogant neurosurgeon who travels to Nepal to learn the mystic arts after a car accident. With a sharp narrative, ample humor, and impressive action sequences, the film follows Strange's transformation into a magic-cloak-wearing, potential Sorcerer Supreme. Despite deviations from the original comic-book storyline, Tilda Swinton's performance as the Ancient One shines, making the film an entertaining and mind-bending experience.

site_title: Philippines could join sea exercises with Japan: Duterte
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has expressed interest in joining Japan in naval exercises, but ruled out further cooperation with the US, citing "dogs on a leash" treatment and lecturing on human rights. Duterte's comments come amid jitters about his foreign policy, following weeks of verbal attacks on the US and overtures towards China. Despite announcing an "independent foreign policy", the Philippines is still scheduled to participate in joint exercises with the US next month, with preparations underway for drills on the island of Palawan.

site_title: Singapore strikes gold at cooking Olympics - twice!
summary: The Singapore National Culinary Team won gold medals in both the Cold Display and Hot Cooking categories at the 2016 Culinary Olympics in Germany. The team, comprising six members, trained for up to a year and represented Singapore in the best way possible. Chef Louis Tay praised the team's sacrifice and hard work, saying they were proud of their performance. This is the first victory for Singapore in the competition, which is held every four years and attracts 30 of the world's top national teams.

site_title: Raising a toast to pinot noir
summary: A wine tasting comparison of Pinot Noir from various regions, including the Cote d'Or, Sonoma Valley, and Central Otago, reveals differences in ripeness, texture, and aroma. Burgundian Pinots tend to be more transparent and complex, while non-Burgundian Pinots, such as those from Mt Difficulty in Central Otago, are often more intense and full-bodied. The article concludes that while non-Burgundian Pinots may lack the finesse of Burgundies, they offer a more accessible and affordable alternative.

site_title: AA Reit posts 1.8% drop in fiscal Q2 DPU
summary: AA Reit, a Singapore-based industrial real estate investment trust, reported a 1.8% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.75 Singapore cents in its fiscal Q2. Gross revenue decreased 4.3% to S$29.91 million, mainly due to lower rental contributions and redevelopment losses. Despite this, the Reit secured 17 new and renewal leases, maintaining a portfolio occupancy rate of 92.7%. The Reit manager expects the industrial leasing market to remain challenging, but is exploring opportunities for organic growth and risk-adjusted yield accretive investments.

site_title: Boeing sees cash growth even if sales, production slow
summary: Boeing reported a profit beat in the third quarter, with cost-cutting offsetting declining revenue. The company delivered more commercial planes than planned and expects cash flow to rise through the end of the decade. Boeing held off cutting 777 production and raised its jetliner delivery target to 745-750 planes for the year. Despite this, shares fell initially but rose 4.7% to $145.52. The company reaffirmed its target of $10 billion or more in operating cash flow this year.

site_title: Coming up just a tad short
summary: Plentyfull, a new restaurant in Singapore, offers healthy and honest cooking options but falls short in creating a cohesive dining experience. The restaurant features a mini-grocery section where customers can purchase ingredients for future meals. Despite its unique concept, the reviewer found the space and offerings to be somewhat disjointed, making it difficult to fully appreciate the restaurant's potential.

site_title: Super smooth saloon
summary: Lexus has reintroduced the GS350 to its lineup, featuring a 3.5-litre V6 engine with a D-4S fuel injection system, optimizing air/fuel ratio and combustion for enhanced fuel economy and smoothness. This move comes after the previous GS250 and GS Turbo models were replaced, addressing the concerns of enthusiasts who prefer a larger engine. The GS350 is part of Lexus' efforts to cater to loyal customers who value a powerful and smooth driving experience.

site_title: Currency woes, taxes cut Mapletree GCCT's Q2 DPU
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 2.4% decline in its second-quarter distributable per unit (DPU) to 1.765 Singapore cents, due to a strengthening Singapore dollar and additional taxes at one of its properties. Net property income fell 3.2% to S$67.3 million, while gross revenue decreased 1.9% to S$83.1 million. The trust's portfolio consists of three commercial properties in Greater China, with a total valuation of S$5.8 billion. Despite a higher half-year distribution, the trust's performance is expected to be impacted by currency volatility and weak global growth.

site_title: Tripartite effort needed to help workers navigate new job market
summary: Singapore's depressed labour market continues to affect workers, with 9,510 redundancies reported in the first six months of 2016. Companies such as Keppel Corp and Singapore Press Holdings have cut thousands of jobs due to weak economic conditions. The government, unions, and employers must work together to help workers navigate the changing job market. The National Jobs Bank has 70,000 vacancies, and the Monetary Authority of Singapore has highlighted the need for workers to acquire in-demand skills. Individuals must take initiative to improve themselves and be resilient, while businesses can invest in employee training to minimize the impact of restructuring.

site_title: Where should the line between profit and regulation be drawn?
summary: Singapore's stock market has faced dire conditions, with the Straits Times Index down 15% for the year and daily liquidity averaging below S$1 billion. Conditions worsened from 2015, when 1,225 trading representatives signed a petition to the Finance Minister, with daily volume falling from S$1.4 billion to below S$1 billion. The article reflects on the need to draw a line between profit and regulation in the market.

images.alt_text: SGX will have to ponder over what kind of market we want - should business friendliness or strict discipline take precedence?

site_title: PLife Reit posts lower Q3 DPU on absence of one-off gain
summary: Parks Life Reit posted an 8.8% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.06 Singapore cents in Q3 due to the absence of one-off distribution from divestment gain in 2014. Despite the lower DPU, underlying earnings improved, with gross revenue growing 8.2% and net property income rising 8% year-over-year. The trust's gearing remains healthy at 38.2%, and the manager expects a 4.7% rent increase from its Japan portfolio. Despite economic challenges, the CEO remains optimistic about the trust's prospects in the medium to longer term.

site_title: Aussie banks to repay customers mischarged fees
summary: Australia's Big Four banks will repay at least A$178m to over 200,000 customers for mischarging fees for financial advice not provided. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission ordered the repayment, with the bulk of the payments to come from Commonwealth Bank of Australia, estimated at A$105m. The move follows scandals involving misleading financial advice, insurance fraud, and interest-rate rigging, and comes as the industry faces reforms introduced in 2013.

site_title: Good things come in small packages
summary: A 35-year-old entrepreneur, Agatha Xavier, runs a small online cake shop, Lucia Cakes, from her shophouse kitchen. The shop offers four unique cakes and two types of brownies, which can be ordered in advance and delivered or collected. Xavier, who previously worked in banking, uses her financial skills to manage the business. She started baking at a young age and decided to quit banking to pursue her passion. Her cakes are priced between S$35 and S$45 and are available for special occasions or everyday treats.

site_title: Major pork consumer China turns to hog futures to hedge risks
summary: China, the world's largest pork consumer, is introducing a hog futures contract to hedge against price swings, which have hurt domestic producers and consumers. The Dalian Commodity Exchange plans to start trading in hogs next year, which could generate trading valued at $411 billion annually. The contract aims to provide a viable hedging tool, similar to the US Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and encourage consolidation in the industry, reducing financial risks for producers and costs for consumers.

site_title: Tesla posts first profit in eight quarters
summary: Tesla Motors Inc. posted its first profit in eight quarters, with a profit of $139 million in the third quarter. The company expects to get through the rest of the year without raising cash as it prepares to acquire money-losing SolarCity Corp. CEO Elon Musk said Tesla doesn't need more money to get the Model 3 to market, but may raise cash to "de-risk" the business and shield it in case of an unexpected negative event. The company plans to deliver 25,000 cars in the fourth quarter, with a goal of making 500,000 cars per year in 2018.

site_title: Unusual Asian stories and more
summary: The 27th Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) features a diverse lineup of films, including local and international productions. Director K Rajagopal's feature film "A Yellow Bird" premiered at Cannes earlier this year and will have its Singapore premiere at SGIFF. The film explores the darker side of Singapore through its story of an ex-convict searching for his family. Malaysian writer and filmmaker Dain Iskandar Said's noir-fantasy thriller "Interchange" will also make its Asian premiere at the festival. Additionally, Nikkatsu is rebooting the "Roman Porno" genre with five new films, including Akihiko Shiota's "Wet Woman in the Wind," which premiered at the Locarno Film Festival.

images.alt_text: Veteran local actor Palakrishnan in a scene from A Yellow Bird.
The cast of A Yellow Bird - (from left) Biswas, Huang, Rajagopal, Palakrishnan, and Udaya Soundari.
Detective Man (Shaheizy Sam) arriving at the crime scene in Interchange.

Dain spent about seven years "(going) deep" into his research about the mythologies, folklore and culture of tribal folks before making Interchange to explore the connection between the physical and spiritual worlds in the plot.
Mamiya and Nagaoka in Wet Woman in the Wind (above).
Director Shiota (above) says he jumped at the opportunity to make his own "Roman Porno" film when the offer came along from Nikkatsu.

site_title: Nokia Q3 sales beat estimates on resilient broadband demand
summary: Nokia reported a smaller-than-expected drop in third-quarter sales, falling 6% to 6 billion euros, driven by strong demand for broadband-network equipment following its acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent. Adjusted earnings matched the average analyst estimate of 4 cents a share. The company's results beat expectations, with sales beating the average estimate of 5.86 billion euros.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singaporean companies reported varying financial results for the first quarter of 2016. Wing Tai's net profit halved to S$1.06 million, while Sunningdale Tech's dropped 35.9% to S$10.2 million. 800 Super Holdings secured a S$134 million contract, and Creative Technology narrowed its net loss to US$6.2 million. Other companies, including Hiap Hoe, Tuan Sing, and Swiber, also reported financial updates. The week's market news includes a Singapore public offer of NTT DC Reit being 9.8 times oversubscribed and a potential fee hike at London's Heathrow airport.

site_title: NetLink Trust fined S$500k for failing to meet service standards
summary: NetLink Trust, Singapore's national high-speed fibre network operator, has been fined S$500,000 for failing to meet service standards, including Quality of Service (QoS) requirements for residential and business customers. The fine, imposed by the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA), follows previous QoS failures and acknowledges efforts to improve performance. NLT plans to invest S$150 million to upgrade its fibre network and IT systems to meet IMDA expectations.

site_title: Chinese ride-sharing king Didi Chuxing could go global
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's ride-sharing king, plans to expand globally with its expertise and knowledge gained in the Chinese market. The company, which controls almost 90% of the Chinese ride-hailing market, aims to collaborate with local ride-sharing companies or launch its own operations in new markets. Didi has good partnerships with Lyft and Uber in the US and has a rich trove of driving data to analyze, which will help it adapt to self-driving cars. The company's president, Jean Liu, stated that Didi aspires to be a global company and sees its China expertise as a key advantage.

images.alt_text: "We aspire to be a global company; we think it's our mission," Didi Chuxing president Jean Liu said at a WSJD Live global technology conference.

site_title: ST Index flat in thin trading
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 0.37 points to 2,828.94, with a weak trading volume of 1.3 billion units. Penny stocks dominated the market, while blue chips saw soft interest. Overseas markets offered little direction, with Wall Street's Dow futures falling on Thursday. Analysts expect a potential slowdown in the domestic economy and uncertainty surrounding the US presidential elections, which may impact monetary policy and global markets.

site_title: IBM's Watson creates customer-specific business insights
summary: IBM's Watson creates customer-specific business insights by combining proprietary data with artificial intelligence (AI) technology. CEO Ginni Rometty believes this approach will be the competitive advantage for companies, allowing clients to retain their unique data and intellectual property. Watson has been trained in 20 industries and is used by hundreds of millions of people, with the goal of reaching 1 billion users by the end of next year. The technology is seen as a key driver for IBM's long-term growth, contributing to its existing operations and helping to automate business processes and improve productivity.

images.alt_text: Ms Rometty envisions a future in which all enterprises will add artificial intelligence to help automate business processes.

site_title: Hand-picked goodness from Japan
summary: A Singapore-based company, Chitose Agriculture Initiative (CAI), offers a weekly subscription service delivering fresh, seasonal Japanese fruits and vegetables to customers' homes. For S$162.50, a box of seven to nine varieties of produce is delivered within 48 hours of harvest. CAI partners with over 50 artisan farms across Japan and Malaysia, using sustainable agriculture methods and adhering to Japanese Agricultural Standards. The company aims to support ethical and sustainable agriculture, and its produce is said to be tastier than supermarket options due to its focus on "kanjuku" (fully riped) produce.

images.alt_text: For a weekly fee of S$162.50, customers can get a box of produce from Chitose Agriculture Initiative (above).
Pumpkin from Noraya Farm, Hokkaido can be used to make gnocchi (above).

site_title: Going back to old-school music values
summary: Singer-songwriter Kevin Mathews, founding member of Singapore's iconic musical act Watchmen, has released his latest album "I AM" after a 20-year hiatus. The album, made using GarageBand, is a "declaration of intent" and a return to the band's retro pop sound. Mathews, 55, hopes to leverage the Watchmen brand and tie back to his solo work, which he felt was underappreciated. He plans to release two to three albums a year, motivated by the passing of his father six years ago and a desire to focus on music.

site_title: Swedish crown hits 6 1/2-year low against euro
summary: Sweden's crown hit a 6 1/2-year low against the euro, trading at 9.8000 crowns per euro, after the Riksbank announced it would expand quantitative easing and increase interest rate cuts, citing subdued inflation. The central bank said it would take longer to hit its target and would buy 40% of outstanding government bonds by year-end. The dollar rose to a 7 1/2-year low against the yen, driven by expectations of a US interest rate hike by the end of the year.

site_title: Asia through art's lens
summary: The fifth Singapore Biennale, "Atlas of Mirrors," has opened with a cohesive vision addressing Asia's history of wars, colonialism, and social conflicts. The exhibition features 63 artists and art collectives from 19 countries, including Indonesian artist Titarubi's installation "History Repeats Itself," Pakistani artist Adeela Suleman's subverted traditional miniature paintings, and Japanese artist Nobuaki Takekawa's confrontation with Japan's violent past. The biennale also introduces the Benesse Art Prize, with a cash prize of three million yen, to recognize contemporary Asian art.

site_title: Integration begins at CMA CGM, post NOL buyout
summary: CMA CGM has integrated about 20 liner services acquired from Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) and is seeking to raise about US$1 billion from the sales of NOL's container terminals in the US, Japan, and Taiwan. The company aims to offload terminal assets to deleverage its balance sheet post-acquisition. CMA CGM plans to set up a training centre in Singapore, aiming to train hundreds of staff in Asia to become managers and future leaders of its shore-based operations.

site_title: Britain will leave the single market: UK minister for Scotland
summary: Britain's decision to leave the European Union will also result in leaving the single market, according to UK Secretary of State for Scotland David Mundell. This decision will impact Britain's access to the single market's 500-million consumer base. The implications of this move remain unclear.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long was a former DBS veteran. The company's current CEO Helen Wong will retire, and Tan Teck Long has been named as her successor. Singapore's affluents require approximately $1.39 million to retire comfortably.

site_title: Verizon acquires startup Vessel in mobile-video push
summary: Verizon agreed to acquire Vessel, a mobile-video startup led by former Hulu chief Jason Kilar, in a bid to expand its presence in the mobile-advertising market. The deal, terms of which were not disclosed, follows Verizon's acquisition of AOL and Yahoo. Vessel features short-form video from traditional media partners and personalities, and offers a subscription service for $2.99 a month. The acquisition aims to help Verizon compete with Alphabet's Google and Facebook in the digital ad market, where it has struggled to gain traction with its go90 video-streaming service.

site_title: Samsung scion joins board as profits plunge on Note 7 crisis
summary: Samsung's mobile unit reported a 30% profit plunge following a highly damaging smartphone recall crisis, including the Note 7 issue. JY Lee, the 48-year-old heir apparent, joined the board as the company focuses on regaining consumer confidence. Lee's influence has grown since his father, Lee Kun-hee, suffered a heart attack in 2014. The move is seen as a coronation of sorts, solidifying Lee's control over the family-run conglomerate. Samsung's mobile unit will concentrate on regaining trust with consumers after the crisis.

site_title: On Syria, Clinton would not lead from behind
summary: US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton is expected to pursue a more activist and aggressive foreign policy approach if elected, reversing President Barack Obama's "global retrenchment" strategy. Clinton, who has promoted interventionist policies in the Middle East, particularly in Syria, and has called for the establishment of "safe zones" protected by US military force, would likely step up military action to deter President Assad and Russian forces. This approach is expected to be in contrast to President Trump's more isolationist stance, and has been endorsed by some Republican foreign policy experts.

site_title: Guocoland, Eco World pool expertise in IPO candidate (Amended)
summary: Guocoland and Eco World Development Group Bhd are pooling their expertise to support Eco World International Bhd's (EWI) initial public offering (IPO), scheduled for early next year. Guocoland will subscribe for 640,000 EWI shares, giving them a 27% stake in the enlarged paid-up capital. The IPO aims to raise over RM2 billion to fund three projects in London and one in Sydney. The partnership will allow Guocoland to expand into two "scalable" markets and provide EWI with access to GuocoLand's financial power and reputation.

site_title: Lifebrandz ends Papua New Guinea buy, eyes firm with Mongolia business
summary: LifeBrandz, an entertainment group, has ended plans to acquire Tolukuma Gold Mines in Papua New Guinea for $212 million, citing unfinalized agreements. Instead, the company will pursue a potential acquisition of Three Crystals Hong Kong Limited for $70 million, which would give it a stake in an Inner Mongolia-based company exploring industrial-grade garnet.

images.alt_text: LIFEBRANDZ, an entertainment group, said on Thursday it will not proceed with a proposed acquisition of a company based in Papua New Guinea, and will instead try to buy a company with business in Mongolia.

site_title: ARA Asset Mgt surges more than 8% on Shanghai property investment
summary: ARA Asset Management's shares surged over 8% after announcing a S$4.1 billion investment in a Shanghai commercial property, Century Link. The fund, ARA Harmony VI, will be managed by ARA and backed by China Life. This deal is the largest single-asset property transaction in the Asia-Pacific this year, and analysts predict further upside for the company, with a target price of S$1.76 per unit. The partnership with China Life is seen as a significant coup, providing access to large deals and establishing strong relationships with capital partners.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US charges dozens in India-based call centre fraud racket
summary: The US Justice Department has charged dozens of individuals and five Indian call centers in a widespread fraud racket that targeted victims in the US with millions of dollars. The scammers posed as US tax or immigration officials, threatening arrest and deportation unless victims paid "fines" through prepaid debit cards or wire transfers. The scheme, which used informal money transfer businesses, resulted in hundreds of millions of dollars being laundered out of the country, with victims primarily being immigrants and the elderly. 56 people and five companies have been charged in total.

site_title: Aussie dairy firms up farmers' returns on rising rebound hopes
summary: Australia's two largest dairy producers, Fonterra and Murray Goulburn, have announced plans to raise farmers' returns amid rising hopes for a dairy price rebound. Fonterra lifted its farmgate payout by $0.35, while Murray Goulburn set aside $80m to pay farmers more for milk and fund loans. Prices have been falling for over two years due to a global oversupply, but average global auction prices have risen 26% since July, and Fonterra's farmgate milk price has increased to $5.10 per kilogram of milk solids.

site_title: Germany halts Osram unit sale to Chinese buyer: WirtschaftsWoche
summary: Germany has rejected a Chinese request for approval of a planned takeover of Osram's Ledvance unit, a lighting business worth over 400 million euros. The decision comes after the German government put on hold a similar sale of Aixtron to China's Fujian Grand Chip Investment Fund due to security concerns. The rejection may impact China's plans to expand its presence in the European lighting market.

site_title: Record amount of empty space on Fifth Avenue as retailers balk at rent hikes
summary: Manhattan's Fifth Avenue is experiencing a record 15.9% availability rate, with retailers hesitating to commit to expensive new leases. This increase is attributed to rising leasing costs, which are outpacing gains in merchandise sales. The area, known for luxury brands like Saks Fifth Avenue and Tiffany & Co, has seen its availability rate climb steadily this year, surpassing its prior peak of 11.3% in 2014.

images.alt_text: On the stretch of Fifth Avenue from 49th to 60th streets, which commands the world's highest rents, landlords are asking an average of US$3,213 a square foot, up from US$2,075 a square foot in 2011, Cushman data show.

site_title: Barclays posts bumper Q3 pre-tax profits on bond-trading boom
summary: Barclays reported a 20% increase in third-quarter pre-tax profits to £1.7 billion, driven by a 40% rise in investment banking trading income, particularly from bond trading.
