The performance supports CEO Jes Staley's restructuring plan, which aims to grow the investment banking business despite global economic uncertainty. The bank's common equity tier one ratio remains unchanged at 11.6%, but it is on track to close its non-core unit in 2017, addressing capital concerns.

site_title: AirAsia CEO says good interest in leasing unit sale
summary: AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes said there is good interest in leasing arm Asia Aviation Capital (AAC), valued at around $1 billion, following the release of an information memo. The airline is considering options for the leasing arm, which could include a sale. Fernandes also expressed his desire to expand AirAsiaX into new long-haul destinations in Europe, the US, and Africa.

site_title: OCBC surprises with 5% rise in net profit after tax for Q3
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 5% rise in net profit after tax for the third quarter, driven by higher wealth-management fees and insurance earnings. Despite expectations of a decline, the bank's core banking lending business saw a 6% drop in net interest income due to a slowing economy. OCBC's non-performing loans (NPLs) increased to S$2.48 billion, mainly due to the oil and gas sector. The bank expects low single-digit growth for the full year and is watching the retail and food-and-beverage sectors. Positive drivers include the wealth-management business, insurance unit, and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: OCBC Bank on Thursday reported an unexpected rise in net profit after tax for the third quarter - up 5 per cent to S$943 million - boosted by higher wealth-management fees and increased earnings from insurance.

site_title: Flat loan growth heralds more ECB easing: analysts
summary: The European Central Bank reported flat growth in eurozone lending in September, with 1.8% overall growth and 2.0% credit growth, fueling expectations of extended unconventional monetary policy beyond its current deadlines. Analysts believe the ECB will take further stimulative action in December, possibly extending its asset purchases and loosening rules on bond purchases to ensure its inflation target is met. This could lead to more easing of monetary policy and support for the still-fragile eurozone economy.

site_title: A thinking man's modern Western
summary: A bank robbery duo, Toby and Tanner Howard, drive across Texas to launder stolen money, evading a Texas Ranger and his deputy. The brothers, bound by shared goals but differing morals, navigate the American West's recession-ravaged landscape. Directed by David Mackenzie and written by Taylor Sheridan, the film blends chase and morality tale elements, challenging the line between good and bad. With standout performances and gritty dialogue, "Hell or High Water" becomes a thought-provoking, slow-burning Western.

site_title: UK economy proves resilient to Brexit
summary: The UK economy showed resilience in the quarter following the Brexit vote, expanding 0.5% due to a surge in services, exceeding economists' forecast of 0.3%. The services sector grew 0.8%, driven by box-office receipts from summer movies. This performance countered declines in construction and production, supporting critics of Brexit's economic impact.

site_title: Apple expected to refresh ageing computer line with new MacBook Pro
summary: Apple is expected to unveil a revamped MacBook Pro with a fingerprint reader, faster ports, and a return to the product line that built the company on. The new MacBook Pro is expected to remain the workhorse of the notebook computer line while getting updates like a fingerprint reader and high-speed USB ports. This comes after Apple reported declining iPhone sales and a 10% drop in Mac sales to 18.5 million units in the fiscal year. Analysts hope the new MacBook Pro will help Apple regain market share and grow sales.

site_title: Tiffany's timekeeping prowess
summary: Tiffany & Co. is set to present a curated watch archival collection in Singapore, marking its first time showcasing its extensive watchmaking legacy. The exhibition, as the official jewellery partner of Singapore Fashion Week, features rare timepieces from the 19th century, including those worn by US presidents and celebrities. The collection dates back to 1847 and includes pieces like the Apple Blossom Lapel Watch and the Atlas Watch, modelled after the iconic nine-foot Atlas clock. This marks a significant showcase of Tiffany's watchmaking expertise, which dates back to the 19th century.

site_title: CNOOC quarterly sales drop 15% as output falls
summary: CNOOC Ltd, China's largest offshore oil and gas producer, reported a 15% drop in third-quarter sales as output declined 7.7% due to lower oil prices and maintenance issues. Revenue fell to 30.75 billion yuan, with capital spending decreasing 21% to 11.7 billion yuan. Analysts expect fourth-quarter output to be similar to the third quarter, and CNOOC may continue to pay high dividends to shareholders in the low-crude environment.

site_title: US: Healthcare, tech stocks drive Wall Street higher
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Thursday due to strong corporate results from healthcare companies and a multi-billion dollar technology deal. Profits at S&P 500 companies have exceeded analysts' estimates, setting up for the first profit growth since 2015. Overall earnings are expected to rise 2.2% for the latest quarter. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: TPG said to exit race for US$2b McDonald's China rights
summary: TPG Capital has dropped out of the bidding process for McDonald's China operations, leaving Bain Capital and Carlyle Group to compete with local bidders, including Chinese hotelier GreenTree Hospitality and Beijing-based conglomerate Citic Group Corp. The sale could fetch up to $2 billion and is part of McDonald's efforts to streamline its global operations and return to growth. Two-thirds of McDonald's revenue comes from outside the US, with China being a key high-growth unit. A winner is expected to be chosen by mid-November.

site_title: Australian red meat straight from the farm
summary: The Meat Club, an Australian online store, delivers fresh, restaurant-quality meat to Singapore residents, including Grass Fed Beef, Hormone Free Chicken, and Free Range Pork. Founded by former lawyer Amy Bell, the club aims to bring high-quality produce to everyone, regardless of income. With 500 members and plans to expand to South-east Asia, The Meat Club sources products from local farms in Victoria, Queensland, and New South Wales, using Meats Standard Australia's grading system to ensure consistency. Members can choose from various cuts and subscription options, including a monthly "Autopilot" delivery model.

site_title: Hiap Hoe to sell Cavenagh Properties for S$31.1m to controlling shareholder
summary: Property group Hiap Hoe Ltd plans to sell its legal rights to Cavenagh Properties Pte Ltd for S$31.1m to its controlling shareholder. Cavenagh Properties owns several property units on Cavenagh Road, including the residential project Waterscape at Cavenagh. The sale comes amid property cooling measures, which have led to a shift in investments from Singapore to other markets. Hiap Hoe cited the cooling measures as a reason for the sale, which will help the company adjust to the current market conditions.

site_title: US business spending tepid; labour market firming
summary: US business spending on capital goods unexpectedly fell 1.2% in September, tempering expectations for an acceleration in spending in the fourth quarter. The decline was attributed to weak demand for computers and electronic products. Meanwhile, initial claims for state unemployment benefits decreased to 258,000, marking 86 straight weeks below the 300,000 threshold, indicating a firming labour market. The labour market strength and economic growth are expected to continue, with growth estimates for the third quarter currently at 3.3% annualized rate.

site_title: Creative Technology's Q1 loss narrows on lower expenses
summary: Creative Technology reported a narrowing net loss of US$6.2 million in its fiscal Q1, down from US$13.9 million a year ago. Sales fell 23% to US$17.3 million, while costs decreased 37% to US$11.2 million, resulting in a 16% decline in gross profit to US$4.83 million. Despite a lower revenue, the company kept expenses lower, which helped reduce the net loss.

site_title: Swiber unable to pay upcoming coupon on S$50m of 6.25% debt due 2017
summary: Swiber Holdings, an oil and gas contractor under judicial management, is unable to pay the upcoming S$50 million coupon on its 6.25% Trust certificates due 2017, set to mature on October 30. This marks a significant financial challenge for the company, which is struggling to meet its debt obligations.

site_title: Strong UK GDP data prompts global bond sell off on frets over central bank step-back
summary: The UK released strong GDP data, prompting a global bond sell-off due to concerns the Bank of England may not cut rates at its upcoming policy meeting. Investors believe the central bank is stepping back from ultra-accommodative measures. Benchmark bonds in Europe and the US reached their highest levels since the Brexit vote in June. The sell-off was fueled by speculation that the BoE will not provide further stimulus, according to Rabobank strategist Richard McGuire.

site_title: Kitchen Culture to crowdfund S$2m bond issue
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings, a Singapore-based kitchen systems seller, plans to crowdfund a S$2 million non-convertible bond issue with a 9% annual coupon. The 24-month debt includes a 50% repayment in the first year and the rest in the second year. Investors will earn a 2.25% administration fee. The company's CEO, Lim Wee Li, will pledge 50% of his shares to the bond trustee. Kitchen Culture has a history of material uncertainties in its financial health, posting a net loss of S$6 million in 2015.

site_title: Ballistic missile
summary: The McLaren 675LT is a limited edition, track-focused model based on the 650S. The "LT" in its name refers to the Longtail airbrake, which increases downforce by 40%. The car has a dry weight of 1,230 kg, thanks to a weight loss program that includes the use of titanium and polycarbonate. The 675LT produces 675 hp and 700 Nm, and features a revised powertrain with new components. It boasts exceptional handling and grip, making it a guided missile on the track. Its performance is impressive, with a 0-100 kmh time of 2.9 seconds and a top speed of 330 kmh.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.89 points to close at 1,669.03, with 1.49 billion lots valued at RM1.61 billion traded. Losers outpaced gainers 396 to 339.

site_title: Oil rises on Opec cut comments, draw of US crude at Cushing
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday as US crude inventories at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub dropped and Opec members agreed to reduce peak oil output by up to 4%. Brent crude increased by 65 cents to $50.66 a barrel. The commitment from Saudi Arabia and Gulf allies to cooperate on oil production alleviated market concerns. The move is seen as a step towards Opec's goal of trimming oil demand for the next four years.

site_title: French parliament rejects new palm oil tax proposal
summary: France's National Assembly rejected a proposed 300-900 euro tax on palm oil, citing concerns over its impact on food and cosmetics manufacturers. The tax, aimed at reducing deforestation, was met with opposition from the government and main parties. The move follows previous attempts to introduce a special levy on palm oil, which is favored by manufacturers due to its low cost and chemical properties. The French government plans to propose a new scheme to harmonize taxes on vegetable oils by February, with an exemption for sustainably produced oils.

images.alt_text: France's National Assembly on Thursday rejected the latest move to introduce an additional levy on palm oil, the widely used food and cosmetics ingredient that has been blamed for encouraging deforestation and posing health concerns.

site_title: EU-Canada trade summit 'cancelled'
summary: The EU and Canada have cancelled their planned summit in Brussels to sign the Comprehensive Economic Trade Agreement (CETA), a landmark transatlantic trade deal. The summit was cancelled due to Belgium's need for more time to iron out technical issues and overcome objections from French-speaking communities. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau had planned to attend the summit, but his office has postponed his trip. The agreement must be endorsed by all 28 EU member states, and Belgium's blockage has effectively stalled the deal's progress.

site_title: SingPost gets nod for Alibaba to raise stake to 14.4%
summary: Alibaba has secured approval from the Info-communications Media Development Authority to raise its stake in Singapore Post from 10.2% to 14.4%. The deal, which includes an additional S$187.1 million investment, is set to be completed by February 28, 2017. This marks a significant development after multiple delays.

site_title: Japfa Q3 profit surges on stronger margins, fair value gain
summary: Japfa Ltd posted a six-time jump in net profit for the third quarter, reaching US$48 million, driven by stronger margins and a gain in fair value of biological assets. Gross profit increased by 35% to US$187 million, outpacing revenue growth. This marks a significant turnaround from the previous year, when Japfa recorded a fair-value loss for its biological assets. The company's improved performance is attributed to revenue growth and cost management.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end down on profit taking
summary: Tokyo shares fell on Thursday, closing 0.32% lower due to profit taking after a six-month high the previous day. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 55.42 points to 17,336.42, while the Topix index fell 0.05% to 1,382.01. Investors locked in gains amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares close mostly higher, albeit with unchanged STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.37 points to 2,828.94 on Thursday, its lowest volume week in months. Penny stocks continued to be traded, while blue chip interest remained soft. Overseas markets showed little direction, with Wall Street rising on Wednesday but Dow futures falling on Thursday. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors stayed positive, driving the STI 0.4% higher on Wednesday.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q3 profit falls 60%
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 60% fall in net profit for the third quarter, with net profit at S$6.43 million, down from S$16.2 million a year ago. Revenue also decreased by half to S$90.3 million, primarily due to the completion of several projects. The decrease was attributed to the certificate of statutory completion of Seletar Park Residence in January 2016 and temporary occupation permits for Sennett Residence and Cluny Park Residence in June and July 2016, respectively.

site_title: Belgium makes breakthrough in talks for EU-Canada trade deal
summary: Belgium has reached a breakthrough in EU-Canada trade deal talks, winning over the leaders of a recalcitrant Belgian region, potentially ending a deadlock that threatened European credibility. The agreement, announced by Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel, requires all 28 EU members to approve the Comprehensive Economic Trade Agreement (CETA). The deal, which links the EU's single market with Canada's economy, was hindered by opposition from Wallonia's government, but a compromise has been reached. The European Council's Donald Tusk has hailed the news and plans to contact Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau once all procedures are finalized for EU signing.

images.alt_text: Belgium announced Thursday a breakthrough in talks to secure a landmark EU-Canada trade deal by winning over the leaders of a recalcitrant Belgian region, potentially snapping a deadlock which threatened European credibility anew.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries Q3 profit falls 55.9%
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 55.9% decline in net profit to S$53.9 million in its third quarter, mainly due to losses in the marine segment and an impairment for Gallant Venture. Revenue fell 10.8% to S$2.1 billion. The decline was attributed to lower contributions from the marine business and specialized construction activities.

site_title: Wing Tai Q1 profit down on lower contribution from development properties
summary: Wing Tai's Q1 net profit halves to S$1.06 million from S$2.03 million in the same quarter last year, due to a 59% decline in revenue to S$70.19 million. The decline was mainly attributed to lower contributions from the development properties division. Operating profit shrank 87% to S$2.3 million. Despite this, the group's net asset value per share increased to S$4.05 and the counter ended half a Singapore cent higher at S$1.71.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust Q2 DPU down 2.4% to 1.765 cents
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 2.4% decline in its second-quarter distributable per unit (DPU) to 1.765 Singapore cents. Total half-year DPU was 3.61 cents, a 3.2% increase from the same period last year. The decline was attributed to a change in property tax basis and a strengthening of the Singapore dollar against the Hong Kong and Chinese yuan, which reduced net property income by 3.2%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer fourth straight loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.83% to 23,132.35, following a broad downturn in New York and a sell-off in oil prices. Energy firms were particularly hard hit. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index saw smaller declines. The sell-off continues a trend of market volatility, with global economic uncertainty and trade tensions contributing to investor caution.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech posts 35.9% drop in profit for Q3
summary: Sunningdale Tech reported a 35.9% drop in net profit to S$10.2 million for the Q3 2016 quarter, down from S$15.9 million the previous year. Revenues slipped 2.3% year-over-year to S$172.5 million, mainly due to lower orders from its healthcare and mould fabrication business segments. Earnings per share decreased to 5.34 Singapore cents from 8.39 Singapore cents. The company remains cautious about business conditions, citing challenging market conditions.

site_title: 'Accept the offer and go for cash', Innovalues shareholders told
summary: Innovalues Limited received a S$331.4 million takeover offer from private equity firm Northstar Advisor. Analysts recommend shareholders accept the offer and opt for the cash option due to unclear upside in holding unlisted shares of Precision Solutions Group. The offer price of S$1.01 per share values the company at 3% above its 12 times FY17 price-to-earnings ratio. The offeror has the right to launch a voluntary conditional cash offer with similar or better terms if a competing offer arises.

site_title: VW brand profit plunges, Porsche lifts group
summary: Volkswagen's core brand saw a significant drop in third-quarter operating profit, falling to 363 million euros (S$550.25 million) from 801 million euros last year, or 1.5% of sales. This marks a significant decline, exceeding analyst expectations. The decline adds weight to calls for cutbacks at the brand's biggest division.

site_title: Twitter cuts 9% of workforce as revenue growth slows
summary: Twitter reported a 9% workforce reduction as revenue growth slowed in the third quarter. The company's user base increased 3% to 317 million average monthly active users. Revenue rose 8% to $616 million, beating expectations. Twitter has struggled to attract new users amid competition from Instagram and Snapchat, despite a 20% revenue increase in the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: Twitter Inc reported a sharp slowdown in quarterly revenue growth on Thursday and said it would cut 9 per cent of its global workforce.

site_title: Hot stock: ARA Asset Mgt surges more than 4% on Shanghai property investment
summary: ARA Asset Management surged 4.07% to S$1.410 after announcing the launch of ARA Harmony VI, a S$4.1 billion China commercial property investment fund. The fund will be managed by ARA and backed by China Life as a core investor, with Peninsular Investment Partners also participating. The news drove up the company's stock price, with shares reaching a high of S$1.405.

site_title: 800 Super unit wins S$133.65m PUB contract
summary: 800 Super Holdings, a Catalist-listed environmental services provider, has won a S$133.65 million contract with the Public Utilities Board (PUB) for 15.5 years to treat and dispose of sludge from water reclamation plants, starting from November 7, 2016. The contract is not expected to impact the company's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending June 30, 2017.

site_title: A-Reit sells Shanghai business park for S$228m
summary: A-Reit's manager will sell its Shanghai business park, A-Reit City @ Jinqiao, to Wkland Investments II Limited for S$228 million, including an assignment of a shareholder loan. The sale is expected to be completed in the fiscal third quarter and comes with a divestment fee of S$1.1 million. The business park's sale marks A-Reit's exit from the Chinese market, following a trend of A-REITs divesting from the country amid regulatory changes.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund opens Hong Kong office
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, ADIA, has opened an office in Hong Kong to pursue investment opportunities in China and other Asian markets. This is ADIA's first international office after closing its London base last year. The move reflects confidence in Asia's growth and long-term commitment to the region. ADIA has been investing in Asia for over three decades and has appointed Dong-Sinh Ngo as chief representative for Asia-Pacific to be based in Hong Kong.

site_title: European stocks slide for a fourth day on underwhelming results
summary: European stocks fell for a fourth day, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index dropping 0.4% as underwhelming results from companies like ABB and ASM International NV dragged the market down. Deutsche Bank AG rose after reporting a return to profit. The benchmark is down 0.7% in October, its first back-to-back monthly drop since the start of the year. Speculation about the European Central Bank's stimulus and the Federal Reserve's interest-rate increase weighed on the market.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib aims to take China ties to "new highs" on visit
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is set to visit China next week to strengthen ties and seek investment. He stated that Malaysia aims to push ties to "new highs" and sign numerous agreements. This visit comes amid increased competition between China and the US in Southeast Asia, following a push by Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte to bolster China ties. Najib's visit is seen as an attempt to further dent US aims in the region.

site_title: Spain Q3 unemployment rate at 18.9%, lowest in nearly seven years
summary: Spain's unemployment rate dropped to 18.9% in Q3, its lowest level in nearly seven years, according to the National Statistics Institute. This follows a record summer for tourist arrivals, which boosted hiring. The rate is still the second-highest in the European Union, and the next government may need to implement further measures to cement the recovery, which has been hindered by a 10-month political deadlock.

site_title: UK economy defies fears of quick Brexit hit, grows solidly in Q3
summary: The UK economy grew solidly in the third quarter, expanding by 0.5% despite the Brexit vote shock, surpassing economists' median forecast of 0.3%. The services sector, driven by strong box office receipts, accounted for the growth, while industrial production and construction contracted. The figures support claims made by Brexit supporters that warnings of a big economic hit were overblown. The Bank of England is unlikely to cut interest rates further next week, citing concerns over inflation and the pound's value.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Total employment in Singapore contracted in the third quarter of 2016, marking the second time since the 2008/2009 recession. Bus and rail fares in Singapore will decrease by 4.2% from December 30. Innovalues Limited shareholders were advised to accept a takeover offer by Northstar Advisor. GuocoLand Limited will take a 27% stake in Eco World International's IPO in Malaysia. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) fined NetLink Trust S$500,000 for not meeting service standards, while HDB CEO Cheong Koon Hean received two international awards for urban development.

site_title: GuocoLand to take 27% stake in EcoWorld International's IPO
summary: GuocoLand Limited agreed to take a 27% stake in EcoWorld International Berhad's initial public offering (IPO) in Malaysia, expanding its global footprint into the UK and Australia. EWI aims to raise over RM2 billion to develop four projects in London and Sydney. GuocoLand will be one of the two largest shareholders, holding an equal stake as EW Berhad, with a right to nominate up to three directors to EWI's board. The investment will be funded by internally generated funds, with no impact on GuocoLand's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down tracking overseas markets, ahead of GDP data
summary: Taiwan's stocks declined 0.6% on Thursday, tracking overseas market falls, ahead of the release of GDP data. The main Taiex index closed at 9,315.21. Foreign investors have seen-sawed in buying and selling this week, while the electronics subindex dropped 0.7% and the financials subindex lost 0.2%. The economy is expected to have expanded 1.8% year-on-year in the third quarter, according to a Reuters poll.

site_title: Deutsche Bank posts Q3 profit, hikes legal provisions
summary: Deutsche Bank posted a net profit of 278 million euros in Q3, driven by a surge in bond trading. However, the positive earnings were overshadowed by ongoing negotiations with the US Department of Justice over Residential Mortgage Backed Securities. The bank increased its litigation reserves to 5.9 billion euros, up from 5.5 billion euros at the end of June. Revenues rose slightly to 7.5 billion euros, ahead of analyst expectations. Despite the positive earnings, the bank's CEO, John Cryan, noted that the recent developments had an unsettling effect.

site_title: Dutch 'JFK' aims to thwart far-right's election hopes
summary: Dutch Green party leader Jesse Klaver, 30, aims to counter far-right politics ahead of 2017 elections. As the only child of Moroccan and Dutch-Indonesian parents, Klaver identifies with the immigrant experience and seeks to stop "the right-wing wind" blowing through Europe. With his party gaining momentum, Klaver could play a key role in the elections, potentially forming a coalition against the ruling Liberals. Inspired by John F. Kennedy, Klaver campaigns on stopping inequality and making Europe work for all, rather than just the wealthy.

site_title: Hundreds of flights cancelled in Lufthansa budget unit strike
summary: Cabin crews at Lufthansa budget units Eurowings and Germanwings went on strike for 24 hours, canceling hundreds of flights in Germany and Europe. The strike, which began on Thursday, was over pay and conditions, with the union citing a lack of agreement on part-time contracts. Lufthansa has seen a series of strikes in recent years as it battles to reduce costs. Almost 400 flights were canceled out of around 550 planned for the day, with queues forming at airports like Duesseldorf as passengers sought to rebook tickets.

images.alt_text: Cabin crews at Lufthansa budget units Eurowings and Germanwings started a walkout on Thursday in a row over pay and conditions, forcing the carrier to cancel hundreds of short-haul flights in Germany and Europe.

site_title: Groupon buys rival LivingSocial after reporting loss
summary: Groupon has acquired rival LivingSocial in a deal worth an immaterial amount. The move aims to widen Groupon's customer base, but investors were unconvinced, with shares dropping over 10% in extended trading. Both companies have struggled in recent years, with Groupon reporting a third-quarter net loss of $38 million and LivingSocial's value depreciating sharply to around $6 billion. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to boost Groupon's customer base, but its impact on the company's financials remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The daily deals ecommerce operator Groupon will buy its rival LivingSocial, the companies announced on Wednesday.

site_title: HDB CEO conferred double international honours for role in urban development
summary: HDB CEO Cheong Koon Hean has received two internationally acclaimed awards in urban development, the Urban Land Institute's JC Nichols Prize for Visionaries in Urban Development and the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat's Lynn S Beedle Lifetime Achievement Award. She is the first Asian and first Singaporean to receive both awards, and the only female to receive the CTBUH award. Cheong's contributions to urban development include transforming Marina Bay and guiding the development of major growth areas. She has steered HDB in adopting new approaches to providing liveable and sustainable homes, and plans to continue making Singapore a great place to live.

images.alt_text: THE chief executive officer of the Housing & Development Board (HDB), Cheong Koon Hean, has become the first Asian and first Singaporean - as well as the only female - to receive two internationally acclaimed awards in urban development.

site_title: Abe has chance to be Japan's longest-ruling PM after rule change
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has a chance to become the country's longest-ruling leader after his party decided to allow its presidents to serve a third consecutive three-year term. The rule change, set to be formalized in March 2018, could give Abe a better chance to achieve his goal of revising Japan's post-war pacifist constitution. Abe, currently serving a second consecutive term as LDP president, could stay in power until September 2021, making him the longest-serving leader in Japan's history.

site_title: Asia: Markets ease as oil prices struggle
summary: Asian markets eased on Thursday, with energy firms struggling after oil prices fell to three-month lows amid concerns about an Opec output cut. Iraq and Russia expressed doubts about participating in a potential output reduction, raising uncertainty. Regional energy firms, such as CNOOC and PetroChina, lost ground, while Samsung Electronics' surge boosted Seoul. The dollar strengthened against major currencies as a US services sector survey reinforced expectations of a Fed interest rate hike.

site_title: Australia banks to repay at least A$178m to clients for mischarged fees: regulator
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, Asic, ordered the "Big Four" banks to repay at least A$178 million to over 200,000 customers for mischarging fees for financial advice without providing it. A total of A$23 million has already been repaid, with A$154 million more expected in the future, plus interest. The banks, including Commonwealth Bank, ANZ, National Australia Bank, and Westpac, will pay compensation for past practices of charging fees without providing financial advice.

site_title: Ousted Tata boss's hostile defence takes boardroom battle public
summary: Cyrus Mistry, ousted chairman of Tata Sons, has released a hostile 5-page letter criticizing the company's governance, accusing the board of failing to give him "room to move" and Ratan Tata of acting as an alternative power centre. Mistry also claims Tata Motors extended credit too easily and failed to act on fraudulent dealings at AirAsia India. The letter has sparked a public spat, with shares in Tata's major listed companies falling. Experts say Tata must tackle the allegations, or risk losing its reputation as one of India's best-governed companies.

site_title: CMA CGM said to seek US$1b Neptune Orient terminal sale
summary: CMA CGM, the French company that acquired Neptune Orient Lines, is seeking to sell its terminal business in the US, Japan, Taiwan, Vietnam, Thailand, China, and the Netherlands for approximately US$1 billion. The company has requested first-round bids by next month, with the sale process remaining private.

images.alt_text: CMA CGM SA, the French company that bought Neptune Orient Lines this year, has started a sale of the Singapore shipping company's terminal business in a deal that could raise about US$1 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Australia's Dreamworld defends safety standards after deaths
summary: A malfunctioning ride at Australia's Dreamworld theme park resulted in the deaths of four people on Tuesday. The Thunder River Rapids ride's collision caused crushing or drowning, with two women and two men killed. A 10-year-old boy and a 12-year-old girl survived. Dreamworld defended its safety standards, stating it had passed annual tests and followed international best practices. Police are investigating, and the park remains closed. The company's CEO admitted to not contacting grieving relatives and offered to speak with them soon.

site_title: TPG said to exit race for US$2b McDonald's China business
summary: TPG Capital has withdrawn from the bidding process for McDonald's China operations, leaving Bain Capital and Carlyle Group to compete with local bidders for the potential $2 billion sale. Wumart, a Chinese grocery operator and TPG's erstwhile partner, is also bidding on its own. The sale process is ongoing, with two foreign buyout firms partnering with local companies to secure their offers.

site_title: Singapore bus, rail fares to come down 4.2% from Dec 30
summary: The Public Transport Council (PTC) in Singapore has announced a 4.2% reduction in bus and rail fares starting December 30, 2016. This adjustment aims to offset lower energy costs. The total fare reduction for 2016 is 5.7%, with the remaining 1.5% to be carried forward to the next year's review. The PTC also plans to simplify the fare structure to benefit commuters, particularly by making underground fares more competitive with other modes of transport.

site_title: Toyota trails VW as China boom set to spur global sales shake-up
summary: Toyota trails Volkswagen in global sales, with Volkswagen's sales rising 2.4% to 7.61 million vehicles in the first nine months. Toyota's sales rose 0.4% to 7.53 million. Volkswagen's leading position in China, where it outsells Toyota by a 3-to-1 margin, and a tax cut in the country are major contributors to its sales growth. Toyota's US sales have slowed due to low gasoline prices, while industry-wide deliveries are expected to expand 7% to a record 26.3 million this year.

site_title: Opec can't succeed alone as cuts would barely drain oil surplus
summary: Opec aims to implement its first production cut in eight years to shrink record oil inventories. However, even a maximum reduction would barely drain the surplus, making cooperation from competitors, particularly Russia, crucial. The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries' (Opec) Secretary-General, Mohammed Barkindo, emphasized the need for help from non-Opec countries to end the glut. Opec's output cuts are expected to have a limited impact, highlighting the need for broader cooperation to address the global oil surplus.

site_title: Samsung says Note 7 probe goes beyond batteries
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd will examine all aspects of the Galaxy Note 7, including hardware, software, and manufacturing, to determine the root cause of fires that led to the phone's cancellation. The company sold 1.47 million replacement phones and secured 90 devices following 119 incidents of fire, with 55 relevant to the battery issue. Samsung is working with regulators and third-party experts to conduct a thorough investigation. The company aims to identify the cause of the fires and prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Industrial rents continue decline in third quarter: JTC
summary: Industrial property rentals declined 2% in the third quarter, with warehouses seeing a 4.4% drop, and year-over-year declines of 7.3% in rentals and 7.8% in prices. Occupancies fell 0.3 percentage points to 89.1%, with an estimated 3 million sq m of industrial space coming online by the end of 2017. This is expected to further reduce occupancy rates, prices, and rentals, and reduce business costs for industrialists.

images.alt_text: INDUSTRIAL property rentals continued their decline, falling 2 per cent in the third quarter from the second quarter, culminating in a 7.3 per cent year-on-year decline.

site_title: Nomura said to maintain profit abroad after cutting 900 jobs
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc reported a second consecutive quarter of profit from overseas operations, with a pretax profit of 45.8 billion yen (S$610 million) in the three months ended Sept 30, up from a loss the previous year. The brokerage cut about 900 jobs in Europe and the Americas as part of a restructuring effort to save US$700 million and stem six years of losses outside Japan. This move is expected to help Nomura convince investors of the merits of its global footprint.

site_title: Verizon warily staying with deal to buy Yahoo
summary: Verizon is moving forward with its $4.8 billion purchase of Yahoo pending the outcome of an investigation into a massive breach. The breach, affecting Yahoo customers, could have a "material" effect on the acquisition, allowing Verizon to lower its offer or scrap the deal. Verizon executive Marni Walden stated the company is not willing to "jump off a cliff blindly" but is strategically considering the deal's impact. The company also announced it will purchase the technology behind video startup Vessel and keep most of its staff.

site_title: China holds first anti-terror drills with Saudi Arabia
summary: China and Saudi Arabia held their first joint anti-terrorism drills, involving 25 special forces from each side, in a two-week training session near Chongqing. The drills aimed to enhance combat skills and tactics against terrorism and non-traditional security threats. China's concern over terrorism in its western Xinjiang region, where hundreds have died in recent unrest, prompted the move. The joint exercises follow China's efforts to expand security ties with Middle Eastern and Muslim neighbors, as President Xi Jinping vowed to oppose terrorism during a visit to Saudi Arabia earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Special forces from China and Saudi Arabia have held their first joint anti-terrorism drills, state media reported on Thursday, China's latest effort to expand security ties with countries in the Middle East and its Muslim neighbours.

site_title: Seoul: Won weaker on political issues, stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won decreased 0.4% to 1,138.0 against the US dollar, amid ongoing political uncertainty following President Park Geun Hye's public apology for sharing speech drafts. This move was seen as an attempt to refocus attention on a proposal to amend the constitution to allow for multiple presidential terms.

site_title: Obama seeks more close cooperation from Turkey on IS group
summary: President Barack Obama urged Turkey to increase cooperation in the fight against the Islamic State group, saying the US and Turkey need to apply sustained pressure on ISIL in Syria. Obama called for more dialogue on Turkey's role in the Counter-ISIL Coalition's efforts in Iraq, where Turkey has been positioning troops. The US and Turkey agreed on strong support for Iraq's territorial integrity, amid tensions between the Iraqi government and Turkey over Mosul. The US Defense Secretary Ashton Carter said Turkey would likely play a role in retaking Raqa in Syria.

site_title: China's Sept industrial profits rise 7.7% y-o-y
summary: China's industrial profits rose 7.7% year-over-year to 577.1 billion yuan in September, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This growth rate is similar to the first eight months of the year. Industrial liabilities increased 4.7% from the same period last year, while the data covers large enterprises with annual revenues over 20 million yuan.

site_title: Update: Total employment in Singapore contracted in Q3, second time since 2008/09 recession
summary: Singapore's total employment contracted by 3,300 in the third quarter of 2016, marking the second time since the 2008/09 recession. This contraction was primarily due to slower growth in construction and manufacturing sectors, mainly affecting work permit holders. Employment growth in services slowed to 5,700, while manufacturing continued to decline by 3,700 for the eighth consecutive quarter. Redundancies increased to 4,100 in the third quarter, with services accounting for 59% of the total redundancies. Experts expect further consolidation in the domestic labor market in 2017 due to external headwinds and sluggish business conditions.

site_title: Trump digs deep to defy Clinton momentum
summary: Donald Trump pledged to spend $100 million of his own money on his presidential campaign, defying Hillary Clinton's momentum with less than two weeks to go before the election. Despite a national lead of 5.9 percentage points, Trump claims a two-point lead in early-voting Florida and vows to win the electoral college victory. Clinton's campaign is set to hold a victory party at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York, while Trump is focusing on his business ventures, including the grand re-opening of his Washington hotel.

site_title: Australia shares hit 1-month low on oil woes; NZ higher
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to a 1-month low due to an overnight drop in oil prices, which hit energy stocks. Despite National Australia Bank's positive results, which beat expectations, the market was weighed down by weakness in the energy sector. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.51% after closing at its lowest in three months.

site_title: IMDA fines Netlink Trust S$500,000 for not meeting service standards
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has fined NetLink Trust (NLT) S$500,000 for failing to meet residential and non-residential Quality of Service (QoS) standards for service activation between January 2015 and June 2016. A S$200,000 fine was imposed for failing to meet residential QoS and a S$300,000 fine for failing to meet non-residential QoS. IMDA expects NLT to improve its processes and ensure it fully meets QoS standards. The fine is based on NLT's previous QoS failures and operational improvements.

site_title: UK's May accused by opposition of seeking 'bankers' Brexit'
summary: The UK's Labour Party is accusing Prime Minister Theresa May's government of pursuing a "Bankers' Brexit" that prioritizes financial industries over manufacturers and small businesses. Labour's chief economic policy voice, John McDonnell, will argue that this approach would exacerbate inequality. In contrast, Labour would work with the EU to protect industries like steel and ensure companies like Google pay their fair share in tax. McDonnell's comments come after May's speech at the Conservative Party Conference, where she sought to reassure banks that the financial industry would not be sacrificed during Brexit negotiations.

images.alt_text: The opposition Labour Party will push for the UK to have full access to the European single market and fight a "Bankers' Brexit", said the party's chief voice for economic policy, John McDonnell.

site_title: Residential reserve site at Serangoon North Ave 1 released for application
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released a 99-year leasehold site at Serangoon North Avenue 1 for application, offering up to 505 residential units. The 1.7-hectare site has a maximum gross floor area of 42,973 sq m and is located near Chomp Chomp Food Centre and Serangoon Garden Market. The site is available under the second half 2016 government land sales (GLS) programme and will be tendered only when a minimum acceptable bid is met.

site_title: Japan's Prince Mikasa, oldest imperial family member, dies at 100
summary: Prince Mikasa, Japan's 100-year-old uncle of Emperor Akihito, has died, leaving only four heirs to the Chrysanthemum throne. This marks a significant shift in the traditional male-only succession, sparking debate on whether women should inherit the throne. The remaining four heirs include 10-year-old Prince Hisahito, the emperor's only grandson, and Crown Prince Naruhito. Emperor Akihito hinted at abdication in August, a step unprecedented in modern Japan, and the future of the imperial family's succession is now under scrutiny.

site_title: In Cuba, online media pry open state grip on news
summary: In Cuba, online media outlets have emerged, bypassing the state's 50-year grip on news. Since 2013, internet access has been expanded to 200 Wi-Fi hotspots, allowing around 3,000 blogs and portals to be published on the island or by Cubans abroad. These independent media sites, such as The Sneeze, Neighborhood Journalism, and OnCuba, focus on everyday life and avoid confrontation with the authorities, unlike other dissident portals. While tolerated by the state, online media operate in a legal limbo, with limited access and high connection fees, and are forced to seek alternative funding sources to survive.

images.alt_text: Abraham, Elaine and Jose are under 30, and they've pulled off the unthinkable in Cuba - they are producing online news, prying open the state's half-century grip on the media.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined in early trade on October 27, 2016, following a broad sell-off in New York. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.13%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index shed 0.12% and 0.11% respectively. Investors were concerned about a planned oil output cut by key producers to support prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.29% to 17,342.15, and the Topix index down 0.19% to 1,380.04. The decline follows a previous day's market high, as investors locked in profits.

site_title: US now using Tunisia to conduct drone operations in Libya
summary: The US has begun conducting drone operations against the Islamic State in Libya from a Tunisian air base, according to US government sources. The US Air Force Reaper drones started flying out of the base in late June. This marks a new front in the US's counter-terrorism efforts in the region, following operations in Syria and Iraq.

site_title: Aussie loses another bout with 77 US cents barrier, kiwi steady
summary: The Australian dollar fell 0.24% to US$0.7630 on Thursday, failing to hold a beachhead at 77 US cents. The two-day rally fizzled out due to chart resistance above 77 US cents. This is the fifth time since September the Aussie has failed to hold a beachhead at this level, despite steady inflation figures reinforcing expectations that the Reserve Bank of Australia would skip a rate cut next Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore shares open almost flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened almost flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 1.7 points at 2,830.27. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 54, with 48.5 million shares worth S$44.6 million traded. The mixed showing on Wall Street overnight and uncertainty surrounding tariffs did not seem to affect investor sentiment, with the STI ending the day up 1.7 points.

site_title: Japan, US, South Korea agree to put more pressure on North Korea: Japan official
summary: Japan, the US, and South Korea agreed to increase pressure on North Korea to abandon its nuclear and missile programs, with the goal of achieving denuclearization of the peninsula. The decision was made during a meeting in Tokyo, where Japanese Vice Foreign Minister Shinsuke Sugiyama, US Deputy Secretary of State Antony Blinken, and South Korean Deputy Foreign Minister Lim Sung Nam discussed the issue. The three countries aim to work together to achieve this goal, with increased pressure on North Korea.

images.alt_text: Japan, the United States and South Korea agreed on Thursday to work together to put more pressure on North Korea to get it to abandon its nuclear and missile programmes, Japanese Vice Foreign Minister Shinsuke Sugiyama said.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.560 points to 1673.950. Volume reached 52.93 million lots worth RM12.83 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 84 to 45.

site_title: Korean won leads Asian currencies lower as ringgit drops on oil
summary: South Korea's won led declines in emerging Asian currencies due to falling crude oil prices, which curbed demand for higher-yielding assets. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index reached its strongest level in seven months, and US data supported the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike. The ringgit dropped 0.4% to 4.1805 against the US dollar, while the won fell 0.4% to 1,138.75. Analysts predict the won will trade in a range of 1,135 to 1,145 per US dollar.

site_title: Microsoft introduces Windows 10 update with creative focus
summary: Microsoft has introduced an update to Windows 10 with a focus on creative features for designers of virtual and augmented reality programs. The update, set to roll out in the spring, will include tools to invent and share 3-D objects and will be free to current Windows 10 users. The update aims to boost Windows sales by catering to the creative market, particularly in augmented reality. Microsoft has also released a new Surface Studio PC with a 28-inch display and a Surface Book laptop with improved battery life and performance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Parkway Life Reit, Mapletree Commercial Trust
summary: OCBC reported a 5% rise in net profit to S$943 million for the third quarter, driven by better non-interest income. Parkway Life Reit's DPU dropped 8.8% to 3.06 cents, while Mapletree Commercial Trust's DPU rose 1.5% to 2.05 cents, with a 24.8% jump in net property income. Strong September industrial output and mixed corporate earnings results may influence investor sentiment.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit posts 1.8% drop in fiscal Q2 DPU
summary: AIMS AMP Reit reported a 1.8% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.75 Singapore cents for the second fiscal quarter, with gross revenue down 4.3% year-over-year to S$29.91 million. Net property income also declined 6.9% to S$19.27 million, mainly due to lower rental contributions and redevelopment losses.

site_title: Samsung third-quarter profit drops amid Note 7 phone crisis
summary: Samsung Electronics Co reported a 17% slump in third-quarter profit due to the Note 7 phone crisis. The company's most profitable model was recalled and killed after reports of battery fires and explosions. Net income fell to 4.41 trillion won (S$5.42 billion) in the September quarter, potentially costing over US$6 billion. This is Samsung's worst corporate crisis to date, affecting its operations and reputation.

site_title: Belgium keeps EU, Canada waiting over trade deal
summary: Belgium has agreed to resume talks on the EU-Canada free trade agreement (Ceta), seven years in the making, after a deadlock was broken. The agreement is backed by all 27 other EU governments but rejected by the French-speaking south of Belgium. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called off his trip to Brussels, but remains ready to sign the deal when Europe is ready. European leaders hope to reach a consensus, with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker expressing optimism about the deal.

site_title: Gold holds decline as investors brace for higher interest rates
summary: Gold prices declined 0.1% to US$1,265.85 an ounce after a 0.5% drop on Wednesday, marking a 3.8% loss this month. The Federal Reserve's increasing bets on a December interest rate hike, with 72.5% odds, contributed to the decline. Data on US durable goods orders and the government's GDP estimate are expected to impact the market. The metal had surged 25% in the first half of 2016 following similar Fed rate hike expectations.

site_title: Samsung Electronics considering buying back more shares
summary: Samsung Electronics is considering another round of share buybacks, with the plan to be announced by the end of November. The company's head of investor relations, Robert Yi, declined to comment on specifics, including the amount of money to be returned to shareholders. This move follows Samsung's previous share buybacks in 2016, aimed at returning value to shareholders.

site_title: Snapchat said to seek to raise as much as US$4b in IPO
summary: Snapchat plans to raise up to $4 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at $25 billion to $35 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. The IPO could be the largest of a social media company since Twitter's 2013 sale. Snapchat, which recently changed its corporate name to Snap Inc, aims to sell shares in the first quarter of next year. The company's revenue is less than $1 billion, and it plans to file IPO documents confidentially with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

images.alt_text: Snapchat will seek to raise as much as US$4 billion in its planned initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q3 DPU down on absence of one-off divestment gain
summary: Parkway Life Reit (PLife Reit) reported an 8.8% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q3, reaching 3.06 Singapore cents, due to the absence of a one-off divestment gain. However, underlying earnings improved with 8.2% growth in gross revenue to S$28.1 million, driven by increased rent and appreciation of the yen. Net property income grew 8% to S$26.2 million, despite the decline in DPU.

site_title: Tennis: Kuznetsova reaps reward for refusing to give up
summary: Svetlana Kuznetsova overcame pain and fatigue to defeat Karolina Pliskova in a thrilling 3-6, 6-2, 7-6(6) match at the WTA Finals, securing her spot in the last four of the elite event. The 31-year-old Russian player, who trailed by a set and a break, dug deep to win, praising her coach's advice to focus on the points and shut down her negative thoughts. This victory marked Kuznetsova's first in the tournament and a significant reward for her never-say-die attitude.

site_title: Facebook says users can't stop it from using biometric data
summary: Facebook faces a lawsuit in San Francisco over its use of facial recognition technology, claiming the company's software can identify users without their permission. The Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, which allows users to sue for $1,000 to $5,000 per image used without consent, is being challenged. Facebook argues that users have not suffered a "concrete injury" and that the Illinois law cannot be applied outside the state. The case could lead to new restrictions on using biometrics in the US, similar to those in Europe and Canada.

site_title: China's Oppo uses sales rep army and ad blitz to leapfrog over smartphone rivals
summary: China's Oppo has successfully leapfrogged its smartphone rivals by employing an aggressive sales strategy, including a massive network of retail outlets, sales representatives earning commissions, and extensive advertising. The company's approach has allowed it to jump into first place in China's smartphone market with 17% market share, and it is rapidly growing in India and Indonesia. Oppo's success can be attributed to its control over design, distribution, and manufacturing, as well as its focus on creating a buzz around its products, particularly the R9 "Selfie Expert" smartphone. However, analysts question whether the strategy is sustainable as growth rates slow and the company faces increasing marketing costs.

site_title: European Union reaches out to Iran over Afghan refugees
summary: The European Union has increased humanitarian aid to Iran, doubling its assistance to 12.5 million euros this year, to help stem the influx of Afghan refugees. EU aid chief Christos Stylianides visited Iran, highlighting the need for Afghan refugees to integrate into the local society rather than migrate to Europe. The EU aims to persuade Iran to host more Afghan refugees by providing aid, including education and health services. However, Iranian officials say foreign aid covers only 6% of the cost of hosting the refugee community, and the EU should do more.

site_title: Signs that American workers are winning
summary: US workers are experiencing higher wages due to a tight labor market. The annual growth in average hourly earnings of production and non-supervisory workers reached its highest level in over six years in September. Wage growth has been more robust in states without significant oil production and in sectors like construction and manufacturing. A recent survey showed a record-high share of respondents reporting plentiful jobs, and the unemployment rate is at a low ratio of 1.44 unemployed Americans per job opening. This trend is expected to support inflation, consumer spending, and interest rates.

site_title: Wall Street watchdogs turning to artificial intelligence
summary: Wall Street regulators are turning to artificial intelligence (AI) to improve market surveillance. FINRA plans to test AI software next year, while Nasdaq and the London Stock Exchange Group (LSE) expect to use it by year-end. The technology aims to detect manipulative schemes and complex issues such as "layering" in stock trades. AI-powered software can analyze large amounts of data, identify patterns, and flag potential rule violations, potentially saving time and money for regulators.

site_title: An addiction to pork has China searching to hedge prices
summary: China is seeking to hedge the cost of its pork addiction by launching a hog futures contract on its Dalian Commodity Exchange, the country's largest marketplace. The contract aims to minimize price risk for farmers, meat buyers, and investors, and could generate trading valued at $4.1 billion annually. The move follows China's reliance on imports, which tripled to 2.4 million metric tons in 2016, and the country's struggles to keep up with domestic demand. The contract could also encourage consolidation in the industry, similar to the US benchmark set by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

site_title: OCBC posts 5% rise in Q3 profit
summary: OCBC reported a 5% rise in net profit after tax for Q3 2016, reaching S$943 million, driven by a 25% growth in non-interest income, particularly from wealth management and life assurance. Net interest income decreased 6% due to lower loan volumes and net interest margin. The group's non-performing loans ratio increased to 1.2% and customer loans declined 2% to S$209 billion. CEO Samuel Tsien attributed the earnings rise to diversified franchise and growth in wealth management and insurance income.

images.alt_text: Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Limited (OCBC) reported a 5 per cent rise in net profit after tax for the third quarter ended September 30, 2016 to S$943 million, underpinned by better non-interest income, particularly fees from wealth management and profit from life assurance.

site_title: GM's record results fail to end investors' unease over sector
summary: General Motors (GM) reported record-breaking third-quarter earnings, exceeding analyst estimates, but investors remain concerned about the industry's future due to a possible plateau in US sales. Despite this, GM predicts full-year earnings near the top of its previously stated range, driven by demand for light trucks in the US and luxury vehicles in China. The company's shares fell 4.2% following the announcement, largely due to concerns over Brexit-related issues in Europe and potential declines in industry-wide US sales.

site_title: Oil rebound to US$50 seen too little to ease exporter default risk
summary: Oil prices have rebounded to nearly $50 per barrel, but this increase may not be enough to ease the risk of government loan defaults for countries heavily reliant on oil exports, such as Ghana, Mozambique, Venezuela, and Nigeria. Despite the price surge, many countries face significant debt challenges, and credit and political risk insurers are seeing their worst claims environment in years. The International Monetary Fund has warned that some governments in sub-Saharan Africa have been slow to internalize the fact that oil prices are likely to remain low, exacerbating debt problems.

site_title: Trump's Hollywood star vandalised
summary: A man identified as James Lambert Otis vandalized Donald Trump's Hollywood Walk of Fame star, hacking out the gold lettering with a sledgehammer and pickaxe. Otis claimed he was targeting Trump's star to support women who allege they were groped or mistreated by the presidential candidate. This is the third incident targeting Trump's star, following previous vandalism including a swastika and mute symbol drawn on the tile earlier this year. The Los Angeles police department is investigating the incident.

images.alt_text: A man defaced Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame Wednesday, hacking out the gold lettering displaying his name and the television logo.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall slightly led by Novozymes
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Wednesday, led by a 11.2% drop in Novozymes, which trimmed its full-year outlook. The STOXX 600 index is down 6.6% from a year ago. Pharmaceutical and oil stocks were the heaviest contributors to the decline.

site_title: British PM a master of dodging questions: study
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has been found to have a unique skill in dodging questions, with only 14% and 41% of her answers in recent interviews providing direct responses to specific questions. Researchers have identified 35 techniques for evading questions, including non-specific responses and rephrasing. As parliamentarians press for more details on Britain's Brexit strategy, May's tactic of giving evasive responses may become increasingly transparent and a liability. Experts warn that her skill may have served her well in bringing her to the premiership, but could now hinder her ability to provide clarity on key issues.

site_title: Bitcoin probe tied to JPMorgan hack to get first guilty plea
summary: A Florida man, tied to an illicit Bitcoin exchange, is set to plead guilty to undisclosed charges related to a hacking ring that targeted companies including JPMorgan Chase & Co. The ring, led by Gery Shalon, engaged in pump-and-dump stock scams and online gambling, generating hundreds of millions of dollars. Michael Murgio, Anthony's father, is charged with money laundering. The plea marks the first guilty plea in the case, which also involves the alleged use of the Bitcoin exchange by hackers.

images.alt_text: A Florida man with ties to an illegal Bitcoin exchange that was allegedly used by hackers who targeted companies including JPMorgan Chase & Co is scheduled to plead guilty to undisclosed charges Thursday.

site_title: US warns Berlin on China takeover of chipmaker: report
summary: US intelligence services warned Berlin that a Chinese takeover of German semiconductor equipment maker Aixtron could give Beijing access to technology that could be used for military purposes. The German economy ministry withdrew its approval for a 670 million euro takeover, citing previously unknown security-related information. The review process is expected to take 2-3 months. Aixtron shares dropped 6.1% after the news, citing German intelligence sources. This is the latest concern in Berlin about losing key technology to China, following Chinese acquisitions of German companies such as Kuka.

site_title: Burundi notifies UN of International Criminal Court withdrawal
summary: Burundi has notified the UN of its withdrawal from the International Criminal Court (ICC), following President Pierre Nkurunziza's signing of a decree on October 19. The move was announced in an official document sent to UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon. This decision comes after Burundi's tensions with the ICC, which has investigated human rights abuses during Nkurunziza's presidency. The withdrawal is effective immediately, marking a significant shift in Burundi's relationship with the international community.

site_title: Carousell acquires online car classifieds platform Caarly
summary: Carousell, a Singapore-based mobile marketplace app, has acquired Caarly, a local online car classifieds platform, for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition will expand Carousell's presence in the online classifieds space, particularly in the vehicle classifieds market dominated by sgCarMart and STCars. This move aims to strengthen Carousell's position in the market and provide users with a wider range of buying and selling options. The terms of the acquisition have not been disclosed.

site_title: Long auditor-client relationships a threat to independence
summary: Regulatory changes in the European Union have led to a shift in auditor appointments for listed entities. Many companies, including Barclays, Aberdeen Asset Management, and Schroders, have replaced their long-time auditors with new firms due to EU rules limiting audit firms to a maximum of 10 years. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has proposed suspending mandatory audit firm rotation for local banks, citing strengthened measures to ensure auditor independence. This change aims to prevent long auditor-client relationships from compromising independence.

site_title: US dollar eases from highs on uncertainty over Fed, US election
summary: The US dollar eased from its nearly nine-month high against a basket of major currencies due to uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and the US election. The dollar index fell 0.09% to 98.634, marking a reversal from its 3.2% gain this month. Analysts attributed the decline to concerns about a potential rate hike in December and the US election's impact on monetary policy. The euro rebounded, while the yen rose on increased US Treasury yields.

site_title: Results raise concerns Apple has lost its tech superiority
summary: Apple Inc. posted its third consecutive quarter of declining iPhone sales, with revenue falling almost 30% from China in the fiscal fourth quarter. Despite this, the company expects better-than-expected holiday sales and improved sales from China and India. This marks the first time Apple's annual revenue has fallen since 2001, raising concerns about the company's tech superiority.

site_title: Wanted: Permanent home for WTA Finals
summary: The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) is searching for a permanent home for its season-ending championships beyond 2018. CEO Steve Simon praised Singapore, where the tournament has been held since 2014, as a "great" host, but no firm decisions have been made. Initial talks with the Singapore government and supporting parties have taken place, with Simon expressing a desire for a more permanent home to build the event and traditions.

site_title: The eloquence in Bob Dylan's silence about that Nobel prize
summary: Bob Dylan has declined to acknowledge his Nobel Prize in Literature, following in the footsteps of philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre, who famously declined the award in 1964. Dylan's silence has been met with frustration from the Swedish Academy, who feel he is disrespecting the institution and the literary tradition. Dylan's actions can be seen as a form of "bad faith," a concept coined by Sartre, where an individual abdicates their freedom and becomes an object, rather than remaining true to themselves. Dylan's refusal to accept the prize has been praised as a demonstration of artistic and philosophical freedom.

site_title: Sept factory output up; economists unsure if strong data will hold
summary: Singapore's industrial production surged 6.7% year-over-year in September, driven by strong growth in the biomedical and electronics clusters. The strong data, which was initially expected to be only 1% growth, has lifted economists' Q3 growth estimates. However, economists caution that the sustainability of this growth is uncertain, particularly if the regional technology impulse from smartphone launches fades. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects full-year GDP growth to be at the lower end of the 1-2% forecast range.

site_title: Cafe Football plans entry into Singapore in 2017
summary: Real estate firm Rowsley plans to open its first international Cafe Football in Singapore in early 2017, as part of its expansion into the UK, Europe, and Asia. The cafe will be part of a larger push by Rowsley, led by Singapore billionaire Peter Lim, to develop its hotel and cafe business. Former Manchester United stars Ryan Giggs and Gary Neville are partnering with Rowsley to expand their hospitality ventures, aiming to build several hotels with over 5,000 rooms over the next decade.

site_title: MCT's Q2 distributable income up 25% on acquisition; DPU inches up
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) posted a 1.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.05 Singapore cents for Q2 2016, driven by a 25.4% jump in income available for distribution. The trust's enlarged unit base and acquisition of Mapletree Business City I (MBC I) contributed to the increase. Gross revenue from VivoCity rose 5% to S$49.8 million, with occupancy rate at 99.9%. Despite soft demand conditions, MCT expects its existing properties to remain resilient due to VivoCity's healthy performance.

site_title: Shedding of S Korea shipyard jobs set to continue
summary: South Korea's shipbuilding industry, home to the world's top three manufacturers, has eliminated over 20,000 jobs this year, with an estimated 40,000 more positions at risk by the end of the year. The industry, which employed 163,000 people at the end of June, has lost a combined 6.6 trillion won in the last six quarters due to delivery delays and decreased demand. Shipbuilders are implementing restructuring plans, including job cuts and asset sales, in an effort to recover from the slump.

site_title: Singapore property investor, partner pump US$115m into Seychelles project
summary: Singapore property investor Kishore Buxani and his Seychelles-based partner have invested US$115 million in the first-phase development of an island in the Seychelles. The development includes a 30-villa resort operated by Six Senses and 17 luxurious private residences for sale. Construction on the residences is nearly complete, with the resort already soft-opened earlier this month. This investment marks a significant move into the Seychelles property market, with the two components making up about one-third of the island.

site_title: S'pore leads in race to be Asian LNG hub, says ex-Tokyo official
summary: Singapore has taken the lead in the Asian LNG hub, according to a former Tokyo official, citing its geographical location and experience in setting up commodity hubs. The city-state has surpassed Shanghai and Tokyo to emerge as the top contender. This development comes after Republic's efforts to establish itself as a major player in the global energy market.

images.alt_text: Mr Toyoda says that for the gas market to grow further, an Asian LNG price has to be established - but it has to be one that is delinked from the price of oil, which is too volatile and makes Asian buyers wary about raising their level of consumption of LNG.

site_title: ARA fund to invest in Shanghai property worth 20b yuan
summary: ARA Asset Management announced the establishment of ARA Harmony VI, a fund to invest in a 20 billion yuan (S$4.1 billion) China commercial property, Century Link, in Shanghai's Lujiazui Finance and Trade Zone. The investment, the largest single-asset property transaction in the Asia-Pacific this year, will benefit from the area's strong office and residential population and long-term growth potential. The fund is anchored by an undisclosed insurer, with Peninsula Investment Partners LP and Peninsula Co-Investment Holdings I (Century) LP holding minority stakes.

images.alt_text: ARA Asset Management on Wednesday said it would set up a fund, ARA Harmony VI, to invest in a China commercial property worth 20 billion yuan (S$4.1 billion).

site_title: Big Oil sees more profit pain as refining safety net slips
summary: Big Oil companies are facing reduced profits due to a decline in refining margins. The refining business, which previously supported oil companies during crude's collapse, is now experiencing a slump as fuel stockpiles overwhelm demand. Profits from refining contracted 42% last quarter, with the average US$11.60 a barrel being the weakest since 2010. The "best days are over" for refining, according to industry expert Alan Gelder, and earnings for the period are expected to be lower than expected.

site_title: Indonesia approves 2017 state budget with 2.41% deficit
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved the 2017 state budget with a 2.41% deficit, a balance between the initial 2.15% deficit and the expected 2.7% deficit. Revenue and spending targets were set below plan, with a focus on cutting spending and adjusting revenue outlook. The World Bank described the budget as "more realistic," with an economic growth outlook of 5.3% and a projected larger fiscal deficit next year.

images.alt_text: Ms Sri Mulyani describes the budget as "balanced and credible" and one which can hopefully boost national growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux Ltd's unit Hyflux Asset Management Pte Ltd plans to sell its 50% stake in treatment plant Galaxy NewSpring for US$136.5 million. This sale is part of the company's efforts to restructure and focus on its core businesses.

site_title: Heineken's beer shipments beat analysts' estimates of growth in Asia
summary: Heineken's third-quarter shipments exceeded analysts' estimates, driven by a 15% growth in the Asia-Pacific region, led by the Tiger brand in Vietnam. Shipments rose 10% in Vietnam and Cambodia, while Chinese consumers bought more of the Dutch brewer's flagship brand. The company reported a 2% organic volume growth and a 3.5% rise in premium beer shipments. Despite this, the stock fell 0.2% due to a one-time gain in the previous year's profit.

site_title: Malaysia to scrap nearly all subsidies for cooking oil
summary: Malaysia will scrap nearly all subsidies for cooking oil, with only the 1kg polybag subsidized at RM2.50, starting November 1. The move aims to deter smuggling and save on expenses, as the government allocates RM1 billion annually for the nine-year-old cooking oil price stabilisation scheme. The decision follows a rise in crude palm oil prices, with more than half of subsidized cooking oil smuggled out of the country. The government expects to save RM400 million by cutting most of the subsidies.

site_title: PE firm Northstar offers S$331m for Innovalues
summary: Private equity firm Northstar Advisors has launched a S$331.4 million takeover offer for Innovalues Limited via a scheme of arrangement, which will delist the precision manufacturer. Innovalues shareholders can choose between a full cash payment of S$1.01 per share or a combination of cash and shares of an unlisted company. The offeror plans to acquire Innovalues shares at a premium of 19% over the previous VWAP. The deal, which requires court approval and 75% shareholder support, aims to enhance shareholder value and provide an opportunity for the offeror to control a precision manufacturing company in the region.

site_title: Split your ticket, American voters
summary: The article suggests that "ticket splitting" - where voters support one party's presidential candidate and the other's congressional candidates - could be beneficial for the country. This practice, which was once common, has declined in recent years. The author argues that divided government, driven by ticket splitting, could lead to better government, as it would force politicians to search for common ground on contentious issues. This approach could also help to rebuild the political centers of both parties, which have become increasingly polarized. By supporting the opposing party's congressional candidates, voters can make a statement about the outcome of the election and avoid rewarding unpopular candidates with complete victory.

site_title: Landlord sees 'pain' for NYC apartments over surge in supply
summary: AvalonBay Communities, a US-based real estate investment trust, expects continued weakness in New York City's rental market due to a surge in new construction. The company, citing San Francisco and New York as its biggest markets, lowered its full-year revenue forecast for properties open at least a year. AvalonBay offered concessions valued at $440,000 and reported 50% of concessions were given in San Francisco, with one to two months of free rent being the norm. The market's rent decline is attributed to a lack of jobs to keep up with the supply of new units.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) was downgraded to "hold" from "buy" by OCBC Investment Research due to a stronger SGD against RMB and additional tax provision for Beijing assets. CRCT's Q3 DPU dropped 10.6% y-o-y to 2.36 Singapore cents. In contrast, Mapletree Industrial Trust (MINT) was maintained as "buy" by DBS Group Research due to steady DPU growth and flexibility from low gearing. Sembcorp Marine was reduced to "reduce" by CIMB Research after posting a S$21 million net loss in Q316.

site_title: Technology can be harnessed to serve the unbanked in Asean
summary: Digital financial services can help overcome the geography challenge in South-east Asia, where traditional financial institutions struggle to reach remote areas. Despite progress, only 36% of rural adults have a bank account, and 15% use a debit card. A study by AlphaBeta and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation found five key lessons to achieve universal financial inclusion: building trust, digitizing cash payments, engaging merchants, and nudging consumer behavior. McKinsey estimates that digital finance could raise emerging economies' GDP by 6% by 2025, with significant funding gaps for micro, small, and medium enterprises.

site_title: Another weak day for local stocks
summary: The Singapore Stocks Index (STI) fell 25.5 points to 2,828.57 on Wednesday, with a market turnover of only S$734 million. The low trading volume and average value per unit traded of S$0.56 indicate interest in penny stocks, leading some to view the market as the worst in 20 years. Major institutions such as HSBC Global Research have stopped covering local stocks, including Keppel Corp, while others like Macquarie Equities Research maintain a "neutral" rating. Investor confidence rose 3.6 points to 99.1, but experts expect market volatility to increase due to geopolitical risks.

site_title: GEH Q3 profit jumps on higher insurance, investment returns
