summary: Great Eastern Holdings' (GEH) third-quarter net profit surged 185% to S$195 million, driven by higher insurance business and shareholders' funds investments. Despite an 8% dip in gross premiums, the company's insurance arm saw a more than doubling of profit to S$171.1 million, mainly due to an investment-linked fund in Malaysia. Total weighted new sales remained flat, but new business embedded value rose 29% to S$135.3 million. The company's group chief executive expressed confidence in its growth prospects despite a volatile macroeconomic environment.

site_title: Swiss Club sells 3 plots of land at JLL auction
summary: The Swiss Club in Singapore sold three vacant plots of land for a total of S$15.222 million at JLL's auction. The plots, zoned for residential use, have freehold tenure and varying land areas, with the largest plot being 25,861 sq ft. A duplex penthouse at Seascape in Sentosa Cove sold for S$6.35 million, and a single storey house at Daffodil Drive fetched S$4.35 million. These sales follow recent transactions in the Good Class Bungalow segment, including a S$26.8 million sale along Bishopsgate and a S$17.8 million sale along Margoliouth Road.

site_title: Fiscal policy poles apart in Sweden and Norway
summary: Sweden's Riksbank and Norway's Norges Bank will make policy decisions on Thursday, with 26 analysts expecting the Riksbank to keep its benchmark rate at minus 0.5% and 28 analysts predicting Norway will keep its main rate at 0.5%. The divergence in policy is due to Norway's tapping of its oil wealth and targeting the krone to generate inflation, while Sweden has limited fiscal firepower and is tightening stimulus. Norway's core price growth is higher at 2.9%, putting pressure on Sweden's central bank to ease, despite a strengthening Swedish currency.

site_title: 2016 dividends hit by oil & gas troubles, lower special payouts
summary: Singapore's 2016 dividends fell 5.2% to S$16.3 billion, largely due to oil and gas companies' lower payouts and banks' reduced dividends. The decline was more pronounced than expected, with only three companies paying special dividends instead of four in 2015. Despite this, ordinary dividends from the telco sector are forecast to increase by up to 1.5%. The economy's growth forecast for 2016 is at the lower end of 1-2%, with only slightly higher growth in 2017.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q3 profit up 13.1% at S$19.3m
summary: Singaporean property developer First Sponsor reported a 13.1% increase in net profit to S$19.3 million for the third quarter, driven by higher development income and lower tax expenses. Revenue grew 11.5% to S$80.4 million, mainly due to increased sales of properties in the Millennium Waterfront project in China. Despite a significant decrease in property financing revenue, the company remains optimistic about loan recovery and has plans to launch the last residential plot in the project.

site_title: Philippine officials tell Japanese businessmen it's 'business as usual' despite regional tensions
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte assured Japanese businessmen that the Philippines-Japan relationship will remain "business as usual" despite regional tensions and Manila's reassessment of its relations with Washington. During a four-day visit to Tokyo, Duterte sought to downplay security concerns, while Japan agreed to extend loans and provide training aircraft to the Philippines. The visit aims to boost economic ties between the two countries, with the Philippines seeking to attract Japanese investment amid strained US relations. Duterte also expressed his desire to abrogate defense pacts with the US, but did not specify any concrete plans.

site_title: Tata sources: Clash of styles led to chairman's ouster
summary: Tata Sons Ltd ousted Cyrus Mistry, its chairman, in a surprise move at a board meeting on Monday. Mistry, 48, was replaced by Ratan Tata, 78, amid a clash of styles and concerns over his handling of the company's legal tangle with Docomo and other issues. Mistry's ouster follows months of brewing tension and a US$1.17 billion legal battle with Docomo. The decision has sent shockwaves through India's business community and raises questions about the company's succession planning.

images.alt_text: Mr Mistry (left), 48, was picked by Tata in 2011 after a long hunt. The board's move to wrest back leadership for Ratan Tata (right), 78, puts him in a club of "boomerang CEOs" who are back in their old job.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to face renewed scrutiny as legal woes continue
summary: Deutsche Bank will face renewed scrutiny as investors analyze its third-quarter results amid a multi-billion-dollar fine from the US Department of Justice over its role in the sub-prime mortgage crisis. The bank faces significant legal risks, with provisions for 8,000 cases totaling 5.5 billion euros, a far higher figure than US banks in similar cases. Despite shares recovering slightly, Deutsche's performance is expected to show a fresh loss of around 950 million euros, putting pressure on CEO John Cryan's restructuring efforts.

site_title: Viva trust to buy Jurong West logistics property for S$87m
summary: Viva Industrial Trust has entered into an option agreement to buy a logistics property in Jurong West for S$87.3 million, with a 30-year JTC lease term. The property features high-specification warehouse facilities and will be leased to Sharikat Logistics. The acquisition will reduce the trust's gearing by 0.5 percentage point and improve annualized distribution per stapled security. The lease will generate S$7.4 million per annum in net property income, and the trust plans to finance the acquisition through a combination of debt financing, private placement, and issuance of consideration stapled securities.

site_title: General insurance industry to embrace tech, incubate solutions for new risks: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's general insurance industry must adapt to emerging risks and technological advancements. Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need to incubate insurance solutions for new risks such as cyberattacks, supply chain interruptions, and reputational damage. The industry must also embrace technology and innovation to stay competitive. Wong noted the growing cybersecurity market in the Asia-Pacific region and the need to carefully consider complex issues like driverless vehicles and autonomous vehicles. He welcomed the General Insurance Association's efforts to engage stakeholders on these topics.

site_title: With economy stable, China steps up quest to rein in credit
summary: China's policymakers have established a new high-level committee to reduce corporate debt and leverage, amid concerns over high levels of debt and surging home prices. The committee, led by NDRC chairman Xu Shaoshi, aims to ensure companies reduce their debt-to-equity ratio. The central bank is also conducting a trial monitoring of banks' off-balance-sheet wealth management products to curb risks in the shadow banking system. China's total debt has grown 465% over the past decade, and policymakers are switching from stimulus mode to risk control, with the IMF warning that the window to address corporate debt is "closing quickly."

site_title: Attacks on network came from infected devices, says StarHub
summary: A series of attacks on StarHub's home broadband network occurred on Saturday and Monday, originating from infected internet-connected devices such as video cameras and routers. The attacks, described as distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, targeted StarHub's Domain Name Servers, overwhelming the network and disrupting services. Investigators believe the equipment was hijacked due to default passwords or malware-infected devices. StarHub has taken steps to disinfect affected devices and has appealed to customers to upgrade their cyber-security software. The incident highlights the vulnerability of telecommunications companies' core infrastructure to cyberattacks.

site_title: A$ shines on inflation data; US$ retreats from highs
summary: The Australian dollar rose to a three-month high against the yen, boosted by higher-than-expected inflation data in Australia, which made a rate cut unlikely. The Aussie jumped to US$0.7709, while the US dollar index fell 0.2% to 98.492. Investors are pricing out a US rate hike in December, and the dollar is expected to trade in a range ahead of a key jobs report and the US presidential vote in November.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar was an outperformer on Wednesday, bucking a broad risk-averse environment in global markets, helped by a higher-than-expected inflation reading that dented chances of an interest rate cut in the near term.

site_title: Singtel signs cybersecurity deal in Japan
summary: Singtel has signed a cybersecurity deal with TIS Inc in Japan, offering managed security services to help businesses build cyber resilience and protect critical infrastructure. The partnership will provide round-the-clock monitoring and rapid response to cyberattacks through a new Security Operation Centre in Tokyo. This will enhance Singtel's ability to offer global threat awareness and protection to Japanese businesses, strengthening its presence in the region and addressing the growing demand for managed security services in Japan.

site_title: IBM, Slack team up to build smarter data- crunching chatbots
summary: IBM and Slack are teaming up to build smarter chatbots for workplace messaging systems. The partnership will release a developer toolkit that integrates IBM's Watson artificial intelligence technology into Slack's platform, enabling companies to create custom chatbots. The chatbots will use Watson's Conversation system, which includes speech-to-text conversion and natural language processing, to better understand user queries and provide more accurate results. This collaboration aims to make it easier for companies to automate business processes using AI-powered chatbots.

site_title: New home sales stay close to almost nine-year high
summary: US new home sales stayed close to an almost nine-year high in September, with a 3.1% increase to a 593,000 annualized rate. Historically low mortgage rates and durable employment gains are driving housing demand, supporting economic growth. The median sales price of a new house rose 1.9% to $313,500. Sales were strongest in the Midwest and South, with a 4.8-month supply of homes on the market.

site_title: VW buybacks to begin under US$14.7b diesel test cheating accord
summary: Volkswagen has won final approval of a $14.7 billion settlement with US consumers and regulators over its diesel-cheating scandal. Under the deal, VW will buy back 2-litre diesel cars with defeat devices or offer compensation of $5,100-$10,000 per vehicle. The company has earmarked $19.5 billion to cover costs, and the settlement aims to remove polluting cars from the road. With 311,000 class-members already registered, the buybacks are expected to begin immediately, and VW has committed to almost $16.6 billion in settlements.

site_title: EU banks poised to win reprieve on capital rule for derivatives
summary: EU banks are set to receive a reprieve from capital regulations for derivatives trades, with a new EU rule planned to cut the capital needed when receiving collateral from clients. The change aims to prevent banks from passing on the costs of additional capital to clients, a move seen as a major victory for the industry. The revision is part of a broader EU effort to soften the impact of regulations on banks and kick-start the anaemic economy.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust posts 18% drop in Q3 DPU
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) reported a 18% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.987 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, due to higher operating expenses and lower net property income. The company has made progress in its strategy of divesting non-core properties and recycling capital, with a proposed divestment of 2 Ubi View for S$10.5 million. CIT's gearing ratio remains within the target range, and the company expects Q4 results to be negatively impacted by expiring master leases.

site_title: Singapore developers' forecast: less gloomy but still moody
summary: Singapore property developers' sentiment index shows improvement in Q3, with a composite sentiment index of 4.5, up from 4.2 in Q2. However, the indices still indicate deteriorating market conditions. 93.7% of developers expect the global economy to slow down, citing job losses and weakening growth as risk factors. 60% see Brexit as a good investment opportunity. Despite this, 43.8% expect a moderate decrease in residential property prices in the next six months.

images.alt_text: In Q3, 28.1 per cent of the developers expect new launches to increase moderately; 53.1 per cent expect new launches to hold at the same level in the next six months.

site_title: Timely call to keep an eye on social equity amid entrepreneurial push
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam expressed concern over the potential negative effects of the gig economy on social equity, citing risks of instability in wages and lack of social security contributions. Researchers from the National University of Singapore warned that the "pure pursuit of entrepreneurship" could exacerbate income inequality. The government, employers, and contract workers must work together to ensure the on-demand economy develops equitably, with a focus on the welfare and interests of growing numbers of contract workers.

site_title: Beatty becomes first US writer to win Man Booker Prize
summary: Paul Beatty became the first US writer to win the prestigious Man Booker Prize for his novel "The Sellout". The novel, a satirical portrayal of racial equality in Los Angeles, was deemed "shocking and unexpectedly funny" by the jury. Beatty, 54, said the novel should not be read as solely about race, but rather as a work of fiction. He received the £52,500 award, previously dominated by Commonwealth authors, marking a significant shift in the prize's global reach.

site_title: Boustead Projects settles customer dispute without payout
summary: Boustead Projects has settled a customer dispute over a 2008 warehouse construction project in Singapore without admitting liability or seeking payment. The earlier projected net payment of S$3.2 million was cancelled as a result of the settlement. The company and the customer entered into a settlement agreement, avoiding arbitration proceedings.

site_title: China paper warns against pension funds investment scheme
summary: A Chinese state-run newspaper, Global Times, has warned that Beijing's plan to invest pension funds in capital markets may lead to graft and mismanagement, citing concerns over local government management. The Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security has announced that provincial governments will be able to invest pension funds in stocks and other assets. Analysts have long warned about China's pension fund having a severe funding shortage, estimated to rise to nearly $11 trillion in the next 20 years. The pension fund currently has a surplus of over $3 trillion yuan.

images.alt_text: A Chinese state-run paper has warned against potential pitfalls from Beijing's moves to invest a portion of pension funds in capital markets, including the prospect that it could lead to graft and mismanagement.

site_title: Saudi Arabia faces deeper Opec cuts after Iraq opts out of deal
summary: Saudi Arabia faces deeper oil production cuts after Iraq and Iran opt out of the Algiers deal, which aims to manage global supply. The country, which initially agreed to a 1.3 million barrel per day cut, may need to cut production by over 2 million barrels per day in a worst-case scenario. The move could lead to significant financial losses for Saudi Arabia and potentially cede market share to other producers. OPEC representatives will meet in Vienna to discuss how the burden of output cuts is shared, with disagreements over production measurement and exemptions for countries like Iraq and Venezuela.

site_title: More corals die in Great Barrier Reef bleaching
summary: The Great Barrier Reef has experienced its worst-ever bleaching, with more corals dying and succumbing to disease and predators. A swathe of corals in the northern third of the 2,300-kilometre long reef died after unprecedented bleaching in March due to rising sea temperatures. Researchers found that live coral cover fell from 40% in March to under 5% in areas surveyed near Lizard Island, with many survivors in poor shape. This is the third mass bleaching event in 18 years, with the reef already under pressure from climate change, farming run-off, and other human impacts.

site_title: New LNG import supplies will boost energy security: Iswaran
summary: Singapore will receive new liquefied natural gas (LNG) import supplies from the US, Australia, Norway, Russia, Qatar, and Brunei, starting next year. The new tranche of LNG imports is a result of Pavilion Energy and Shell being appointed as importers for the new supplies. This move aims to boost energy security in Singapore.

site_title: Sustainability reporting and custom M&Ms
summary: A Singaporean study found that only 37.1% of listed companies published sustainability reports, with those that did tend to have more comprehensive disclosures. The Singapore Exchange is requiring companies to prepare annual sustainability reports starting in 2018. The practice of sustainability reporting is likened to ensuring Van Halen receives only non-brown M&Ms, serving as a signal to the market about a company's commitment to social responsibility. Companies that prioritize sustainability may not necessarily perform better financially, and proper reporting is key to demonstrating a company's values.

site_title: More coal plants will deepen instead of cut poverty, caution researchers
summary: Researchers warn that building just a third of planned new coal-fired power plants around the world could push hundreds of millions of people into poverty, accelerating climate change past the 2°C warming limit. A report by poverty and development organizations suggests that renewable energy is now the fastest and least expensive way to bring electricity to the world's poor, particularly off-grid and distributed renewable power. Building even a third of the 2,400 under-construction or planned coal plants would worsen climate impacts and push the world past the international temperature limit.

site_title: Vodafone UK fined record £4.6m for failing customers
summary: Vodafone UK has been fined a record £4.6m for "serious and sustained" customer failures, including not updating accounts when users topped up their credit. The issues stemmed from a new billing system, resulting in 10,452 customers losing £150,000 over 17 months. The company has refunded the majority of affected customers and apologized for the problems. The fine, the highest ever imposed by Ofcom, aims to send a clear warning to telecoms companies about treating customers fairly and in good faith.

site_title: Women and men won't reach economic equality for another 170 years: WEF
summary: The World Economic Forum's annual gender gap index reports that efforts to close the economic gap between men and women have stalled, and women may not reach economic equality for another 170 years. The index, which measures progress in education, health, economic opportunity, and political empowerment, found that the gap in political empowerment is particularly pronounced in the US, ranking 73rd globally. The economic gap has also reverted to pre-2008 levels, with women's economic participation and opportunity at 59% of men's.

site_title: US unlikely to ratify TPP in Obama's term: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warns that the US may not ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) in President Barack Obama's term, potentially damaging America's credibility as a global partner. The deal, involving 12 nations, including the US, Singapore, and Japan, is crucial for the US to maintain its influence in the Asia-Pacific region. Failure to ratify the TPP could lead to a loss of trust from allies and adversaries alike, with Lee citing North Korea's unpredictable behavior as a concern.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,673.92, down 3.51 points on Wednesday. 1.54 billion lots valued at RM1.81 billion were traded, with 285 gains and 496 losses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output increased 6.7% in September 2016, driven by growth in the pharmaceuticals and semiconductor sectors. This growth was reported by the Economic Development Board (EDB).

site_title: GrubHub quarterly revenue beats as orders increase
summary: GrubHub Inc reported a quarterly revenue beat, with US$123.5 million in revenue, a 44.1% increase from the same period last year. The company's active diners rose 19.5% to 7.7 million, and it forecast US$136-138 million in revenue for the current quarter. Net income attributable to shareholders rose to US$13.2 million, or 15 cents per share, beating analysts' expectations. This growth comes as the company faces competition from other food delivery services.

site_title: US crude stockpiles fell in latest week: EIA
summary: US crude stockpiles fell by 553,000 barrels last week, contrary to expectations of a 1.7 million-barrel increase. Crude inventories at the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub dropped by 1.3 million barrels. Gasoline and distillate inventories also decreased, with gasoline stocks falling by 2 million barrels and distillate stockpiles dropping by 3.4 million barrels. US crude imports rose by 133,000 barrels per day, while refinery crude runs increased by 182,000 barrels per day and refinery utilization rates rose by 0.6 percentage points.

site_title: Google halts Fiber rollout in some US cities
summary: Google has halted the rollout of its high-speed internet service, Google Fiber, in several US cities, including Chicago, Dallas, and Los Angeles. The company will lay off employees in some cities, citing a shift towards wireless technology. Google Fiber, which promised speeds of up to 1,000 megabits per second, will continue to operate in cities where it is already available. The decision is seen as a strategic realignment, with Google Access CEO Craig Barratt stepping down but remaining as an adviser.

site_title: US new home sales unexpectedly rise in September
summary: US single-family home sales unexpectedly rose 3.1% in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 593,000 units, nearing a nine-year high. This surpasses economists' forecasts of a decline to 600,000 units. Sales increased 29.8% from last year, driven by rising wages and low mortgage rates, with strong demand in the Northeast and Midwest. Despite this, residential construction likely remained a drag on GDP in the third quarter due to land and labor shortages, and home prices rose 1.9% to $313,500.

site_title: Coca-Cola posts 7% global revenues loss
summary: Coca-Cola reported a 7% global revenue loss for the sixth consecutive quarter, with net income plummeting 28% to $1.05 billion. Worldwide revenues fell to $10.6 billion, with declines in Latin America and Europe-Africa-Middle East regions. Growth in North America was strong, but Asia saw slight gains. Operating margins gained 50 basis points due to restructuring initiatives, but earnings per share dropped 27% to 24 cents.

site_title: War without end?
summary: The conflict against ISIS in Iraq and Syria is hindered by pre-existing rivalries among all parties involved, including the Iraqi and Syrian governments, rebel forces, and Kurdish factions. The Iraqi government focuses on asserting its authority, while the Syrian government prioritizes defeating its own opponents over ISIS. Foreign interventions by Turkey, Iran, Saudi Arabia, and Russia further complicate the situation, with each side seeking to advance their own interests. The lack of reforms in both countries and the resistance to representative governments contribute to the ongoing brutality of ISIS, which may continue to exist due to the complex web of interests and priorities.

site_title: US: Wall St lower, Apple set for worst day in 6 months
summary: Wall Street fell on Wednesday morning due to Apple's weak results, with the company's shares declining 3.7% and set for their worst day in six months. Oil prices also fell amid concerns of oversupply. The S&P 500 technology index dropped 0.72%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.54%. Despite overall earnings expectations rising 1.8%, companies that missed expectations faced severe reactions.

site_title: Serrano creditors approve schemes to collect more than S$32m in debt
summary: Serrano Ltd creditors have approved schemes to collect more than S$32 million in debt, in addition to S$68.6 million in unsecured loans. The agreements involve two properties, one owned by Maybank and the other by UOB, which must be sold within three months. If Serrano fails to sell the properties, it may need to hand over ownership to the banks. The arrangement requires shareholder approval and must be implemented within the specified timeframe.

site_title: PM Lee sounds warning on drop in US standing and credibility in region if TPP is not ratified
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that the US will suffer a "very big setback" if the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal is rejected by its lawmakers. The TPP, a 12-nation Pacific Rim trade pact, has received support from countries like Japan, but its rejection could damage US credibility in the Asia-Pacific region. Lee expressed concerns that the US is at risk of losing its standing if the deal is not ratified.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q3 profit up 8.2%, warns of competition
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported an 8.2% increase in net profit for its third quarter, reaching S$15.7 million, driven by strengthened margins. Revenue rose 1.2% to S$202 million, with a gross profit margin of 25.9%, higher than the previous year. The company warned of keen competition, despite the profit growth.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust posts stronger income in Q2
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 25.4% increase in income available for distribution for its Q2 2016, reaching S$53.7 million, driven by the fresh revenue contribution from Mapletree Business City I (MBC I). The trust posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.05 Singapore cents, surpassing the year-ago Q2 DPU of 2.02 cents. This growth is attributed to the acquisition of MBC I in August, which provided additional revenue.

site_title: Hyflux unit selling China water treatment plant stake for US$136.5m
summary: Hyflux Ltd's unit is selling its 50% stake in Chinese water treatment plant Galaxy NewSpring to Yunnan Water (Hong Kong) Company Limited for US$136.5 million. The transaction is part of Hyflux's asset light strategy, following its classification of the stake as assets held for sale since the end of 2015. The sale marks a significant move by the company to shed non-core assets and focus on its core business.

site_title: Stand-off traps EU's "too big to fail" bank reform in limbo
summary: European Union lawmakers have failed to revive a draft law giving regulators powers to split up risky banks, effectively leaving the region's "too big to fail" bank reform in limbo. The stalemate between centre left and centre right lawmakers has played into the hands of banks, who want the 2014 proposal scrapped. Despite EU states agreeing on a position, the impasse persists, with lawmakers and the European Commission vice president, Valdis Dombrovskis, unable to make progress. The deadlock highlights the delicate balance between regulation and economic growth.

site_title: StarHub's broadband service attack originated from devices in Singapore
summary: StarHub's broadband services were attacked twice in October 2016, resulting in a DDoS attack on its Domain Name Servers. The attacks, which occurred on Saturday and Monday, were similar and originated from devices in Singapore. The devices, such as video cameras and routers, were remotely controlled by hackers and participated in the attacks without the owners' knowledge. StarHub is investigating the incident and has appealed to customers to upgrade their cybersecurity software and use firewalls to prevent similar attacks. The company plans to visit subscribers' homes to clean infected devices.

site_title: Iraq lures investors to boost its oil output as Opec debates cuts
summary: Iraq is planning to boost its oil output to 5.5-6 million barrels per day by 2020, despite OPEC's efforts to cut production, as the country faces pressure to combat Islamic State. Iraq's oil minister, Jabar Ali al-Luaibi, has set a deadline for international firms to submit bids to develop 12 "small and medium-sized" oil fields, which will be developed quickly to mitigate damage from lower prices. This move signals Iraq's intention to increase production, contradicting OPEC's efforts to reduce output and revive prices.

site_title: United Overseas Insurance Q3 profit drops 22.4 %
summary: United Overseas Insurance reported a 22.4% drop in Q3 net profit to S$3.9 million, from S$5 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 1.8% to S$24.4 million. Q3 annualized earnings per share decreased to 25.68 Singapore cents from 33.1 Singapore cents. The company's shares were not traded on Wednesday, closing at S$4.75 on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: UNITED Overseas Insurance third-quarter net profit fell 22.4 per cent to S$3.9 million from the previous year, the group said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Wednesday evening.

site_title: Panama to join international tax convention on Thursday: OECD
summary: Panama will join the international tax convention on Thursday, sharing foreign taxpayer details with over 100 countries. The move comes after the country faced criticism for its role as an offshore tax haven, with leaked documents revealing how it helped the rich and powerful evade taxes. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) praises Panama's new laws, which will allow for automatic information sharing, but notes the country will still be deemed non-compliant due to its past track record. Panama will be subject to review before a potential inclusion on an international blacklist of uncooperative countries.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte tells Japan his China visit was just economics, blasts US
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte assured Japan that his recent China visit was about economics, not security, and vowed to stand by Tokyo in the South China Sea dispute. Duterte also criticized the US, stating he might end defense treaties, sparking concern among allies. Despite this, he reaffirmed Japan as a "special friend" and pledged to uphold democracy and peaceful settlement of disputes. Japan and the Philippines signed two yen loan projects worth up to $287 million, including patrol boats for the Philippine Coast Guard.

site_title: Vietnam's finance ministry proposes doubling Vietnam coal export quota
summary: Vietnam's finance ministry has proposed doubling the country's annual coal export quota to 3-4 million tonnes for 2017-2020 to reduce a mounting stockpile. The proposal comes after the government rejected a plan to lower taxes on coal to boost domestic sales, citing state budget concerns. The decision aims to trim the stockpiles of coal with low domestic demand without affecting state budget revenue. Vietnam's coal exports plummeted 75.9% last year, while imports surged 123.8% to 6.9 million tonnes in 2015.

site_title: Tata Sons former boss says group could see $18 bln in writedowns: letter
summary: Tata Sons, the conglomerate led by ousted Chairman Cyrus Mistry, may face potential writedowns of around $18 billion due to investments in unprofitable businesses. Mistry listed Indian Hotels Co, passenger-vehicle operations of Tata Motors, European steel operations of Tata Steel, telecom venture, and a power plant as "legacy hotspots." He estimated a write-down of around $24 billion over time, citing a realistic assessment of their fair value. The move comes after Mistry was removed from the company by the board, reportedly due to losing favor with family patriarch Ratan Tata and powerful trusts.

site_title: Singapore shares finish lower in low volume - again
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 25.48 points to 2,828.57 on Wednesday, with a low trading volume of 1.3 billion units worth S$734 million. The market's trading energies were directed towards penny stocks, with the average value per unit traded at S$0.56. HSBC Global Research stopped covering Keppel Corp due to a reallocation of resources, while Macquarie Equities Research maintained a "neutral" rating on the company. The poor interest in local stocks has raised concerns about the market's quality.

site_title: Boeing profit jumps despite slow sales; boosts delivery forecast
summary: Boeing reported a 12% increase in operating cash flow to $3.2 billion in the third quarter, beating expectations despite declining revenue. The company boosted its jetliner delivery forecast, raising its target to between 745 and 750 planes, and raised its year-end revenue target to $93.5 billion to $95.5 billion. Boeing's cost-cutting efforts and lean manufacturing drive are credited for the strong cash flow and profit margins. The company's stock fell 1.7% but later eased, and analysts said the cash would reassure investors but the stock has limited upside.

site_title: European shares fall as commodities, Lloyds weigh
summary: European shares fell 0.3% on Wednesday, weighed down by commodity-related stocks and British bank Lloyds, which dropped 3% after its results. Antofagasta's 6.5% decline in shares also contributed to the decline. However, Spanish stocks rose 0.1% after Banco Santander beat forecasts, and Logitech jumped 11% on a rise in Q2 retail revenue.

site_title: Concorde Hotel to undergo S$5m room refurbishment
summary: The Concorde Hotel Singapore will undergo a S$5 million room refurbishment from November to April next year. The upgrade will be conducted in phases over two floors, daily from 9am to 5pm, and will feature modern and contemporary designs, including new carpets, curtains, and bathroom renovations. The 407-room hotel, located along Orchard Road, will continue to operate as usual during the renovation period.

site_title: Juncker hopes for breakthrough for EU-Canada trade deal
summary: European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker expressed hope for a breakthrough in the EU-Canada trade deal, which has been stalled due to internal disputes in Belgium's Wallonia region. Talks between Belgian leaders and EU officials continued, with Juncker stating that an agreement could be reached today. The Comprehensive Economic Trade Agreement (CETA) aims to link the EU's single market with Canada's economy, but critics in Wallonia oppose terms that protect international investors and could harm local interests. A summit with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is still hoped for on Thursday.

site_title: China: Stocks fall as bond yields rise amid liquidity concerns
summary: China's stocks fell 0.4% and 0.5% in the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, amid concerns over tighter liquidity. Treasury yields rose for the third day, contributing to the decline. Despite a temporary easing of yuan depreciation anxiety, investors remain cautious about the impact of tighter liquidity on the economy.

site_title: Toyota to recall 5.8m cars in Japan, China, Europe over Takata airbags
summary: Toyota is recalling approximately 5.8 million cars in Japan, China, Europe, and other regions due to potentially faulty Takata airbag inflators. The inflators, which can explode with excessive force, have been linked to at least 16 deaths globally. The recall affects models such as the Corolla and Vitz, covering driver-side and passenger-side airbags installed between 2000 and 2014. This is part of the industry's largest-ever recall, with about 100 million Takata air bag inflators now classified as defective worldwide.

site_title: Airports seen adopting discreet screening measures to allay security fears
summary: Airports worldwide are adopting discreet screening measures to boost security amid increasing extremist threats. Following a June suicide attack at Istanbul's airport, Brussels set up temporary screening tents, but experts say this only relocates the target. Experts recommend more "invisible" screening measures, such as advanced technology and intelligence gathering, to effectively counter security threats. The aviation industry is taking proactive steps to enhance security in airports, prioritizing the safety of passengers and staff.

images.alt_text: Authorities will adopt more "invisible" screening measures to step up security in and around airports as they increasingly become targets for extremist activities, aviation industry experts said this week.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals pick up from 19-month low: BBA
summary: UK mortgage approvals rose to 38,252 in September, up from 37,241 in August, the lowest level since January 2015, according to the British Bankers' Association. Consumer lending grew at its fastest rate in nearly a decade, driven by strong demand for credit cards, while business lending declined by a net 312 million pounds. The housing market continues to show signs of underlying weakness, with mortgage approvals down 15% from the previous year. This trend is attributed to uncertainty about the European Union's implications and the Bank of England's interest rate cuts.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore Sept factory output stronger than expected
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output increased 6.7% in September 2016 compared to the same period last year, driven by growth in the biomedical and electronics sectors. This marks a significant improvement from the 0.5% year-on-year growth in August and a 3.4% year-on-year contraction in July. Economists attribute the surge to the recent smartphone launches, but warn that it may be an anomaly due to a subdued external outlook.

site_title: Google's Alphabet experiment misses key goal: keeping executives
summary: Alphabet's experiment, Google Fiber, has missed its key goal of keeping executives after CEO Craig Barratt's departure along with significant staff cuts and a retrenched strategy. This marks the third Alphabet CEO to leave since June, as the company struggles to control costs and put nascent businesses in sectors like biotech and robotics on a surer footing. The turmoil may highlight deeper problems in creating sustainable business models, with analysts attributing mounting costs and a retreat to a more focused strategy as the main reasons for the changes.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide to 6-week lows on foreign sales, won steady
summary: South Korean shares fell to six-week lows on Wednesday, closing down 1.1% at 2,013.89 points. Foreign investors sold 82.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares amid increasing caution over the Federal Reserve's next policy decision. The South Korean won remained stable at 1,134.0 to the US dollar. This decline follows a recent rally in the market, and investors are watching the Fed's decision closely for potential impact on the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks follow Wall Street lower amid investor caution
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.0% to 23,325.43, the largest drop in nearly two weeks, due to investor caution amid US election concerns, the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, and China's economy. The China Enterprises Index lost 1.4% to 9,698.85 points. Morgan Stanley warned that China's property boom and recent tightening would negatively impact the economy, citing structural issues. Nearly all sectors fell, with financial shares leading the decline, including Great Wall Motor's 12% drop after a Nomura downgrade.

site_title: k1 Ventures posts 88% drop in Q1 profit
summary: k1 Ventures posted an 88% drop in Q1 profit to S$10.5 million from S$87.3 million, mainly due to lower investment income from portfolio company Knowledge Universe Holdings. Revenue fell 86.2% to S$12.3 million, and earnings per share decreased to 2.42 Singapore cents from 20.16 cents. The company will not make new investments and focus on managing existing assets, recommending an interim tax-exempt dividend of 2 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Ntegrator secures US$15m supply contract from Vietnam's Viettel
summary: Ntegrator International has secured a US$15 million supply contract from Vietnam's Viettel to supply high-performance batteries. This marks the company's sixth and largest order to date, with deliveries expected by end 2016. The contract is part of a frame agreement entered in 2015 and is expected to contribute positively to Ntegrator's financial performance for the financial year ending December 31.

site_title: Philippine president assures Japan his visit to China was all about economics
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte assured Japan that his visit to China was solely focused on economic talks, dismissing any discussions about defense or alliances. The visit comes amid concerns about his foreign policy objectives, following verbal attacks on the US and overtures towards China. Duterte emphasized his commitment to standing up for his country's dignity, but did not rule out revising defense ties with Washington.

site_title: Heineken beer shipments beat estimates on growth in Asia
summary: Heineken NV reported a 2% increase in third-quarter shipments on an organic basis, beating analyst estimates, driven by a 15% gain in the Asia Pacific region. Shipments rose 10% in Vietnam and Cambodia, and Chinese consumers bought more of the Dutch brewer's flagship brand. Premium beer shipments rose 3.5%.

site_title: Hyundai Motor profit declines 29% as strikes cut production
summary: Hyundai Motor Co reported a 29% decline in quarterly profit to 1.07 trillion won (S$1.31 billion) due to labour strikes that cut production in South Korea. The decline was lower than the average of 23 analysts' estimates compiled by Bloomberg. The company's operating profit fell from 1.5 trillion won a year earlier, with executives taking pay cuts amid the earnings slump.

site_title: Lum Chang unit wins S$325m Tanah Merah MRT contract
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' subsidiary secured a S$325 million contract from the Land Transport Authority for the addition and alteration works to Tanah Merah MRT Station. The project includes building an additional platform and concourse, tracks, and viaducts, and connections to a new train depot. Construction began by end-2016 and is targeted to complete by 2024.

images.alt_text: CONSTRUCTION firm Lum Chang Holdings said its subsidiary has secured a S$325 million contract from the Land Transport Authority for addition and alteration works to Tanah Merah MRT Station.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust buys logistics property for S$87 million
summary: Viva Industrial Trust has entered into an option agreement to buy a logistics property at 6 Chin Bee Avenue for S$87.3 million, to be exercised after obtaining necessary approvals from JTC. The property, a newly completed ramp-up logistics development, comprises five levels of high-specification warehouse facilities. The acquisition is expected to enhance Viva Industrial Trust's portfolio and contribute to its growth.

images.alt_text: Viva Industrial Trust on Wednesday said that it has entered into an option agreement with Sharikat National to buy a logistics property at 6 Chin Bee Avenue for S$87.3 million.

site_title: After 20,000 job cuts, world's top shipyards brace for more
summary: South Korea's top three shipyards, Hyundai Heavy Industries, Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, and Samsung Heavy Industries, are bracing for more job cuts amid a prolonged slump in the industry. With over 20,000 jobs already eliminated this year, the sector is estimated to lose up to 40,000 more positions by the end of 2016. The industry's combined losses total 6.6 trillion won (S$7.9 billion) in the last six quarters due to delivery delays and declining demand for new vessels and oil drilling platforms.

site_title: Airbus Group Q3 core profit down 21%
summary: Airbus Group reported a 21% decline in third-quarter core profit to 731 million euros, largely due to a faltering commercial jetliner division and weak helicopter market. Revenues fell 1% to 13.95 billion euros. The company attributed difficulties in the supply chain for its A350 and A320neo jets. Despite this, Airbus maintained its outlook, citing continued growth in other divisions such as defense and helicopters.

site_title: Chinese paper says China, US to step up anti-graft cooperation
summary: China and the US are in "advanced negotiations" to return five Chinese corruption suspects who fled to the US, part of President Xi Jinping's war on deep-seated corruption. The suspects include former officials and business executives, with the US offering to share confiscated assets and conduct a joint investigation. China has been pushing for extradition treaties, but Western countries have been reluctant due to concerns over mistreatment of suspects. The negotiations aim to resolve the issue, which has been ongoing for months.

site_title: Lloyds says quarterly profit drops on £1b PPI charge
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc reported a 15% decline in third-quarter profit to £811 million due to a £1 billion charge to compensate customers who were wrongly sold loan insurance. The charge, the largest yet, brings total PPI costs to £17 billion over the past five years. The bank's core Tier 1 capital ratio rose to 13.4%, but its shares have fallen 24% this year, the second-worst performance among Britain's five-largest banks. The charge and Brexit-related rate cuts are limiting capital available for dividends and squeezing profitability.

site_title: Japan ruling party to change rules to allow Abe to extend term
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party is set to change rules, allowing Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to potentially serve for almost nine years, exceeding anyone since World War II. The change, accepted by lawmakers, would permit party leaders to serve three consecutive three-year terms. Abe, who has led the LDP to four straight national election victories, is expected to call an early general election to cement his position until 2021, assuming the party continues to win elections. The move is seen as a bid to maintain his position and secure his legacy.

site_title: Airbus targets over 670 jet deliveries this year
summary: Airbus aims to deliver over 670 commercial jets this year, surpassing its revised target of 650. The A320neo model will make up around 15% of narrow-body deliveries, down from earlier hopes of nearly 20%. Airbus Group Finance Director Harald Wilhelm also warned aerospace suppliers not to focus on dealmaking and to prioritize contract execution. The warning comes amid consolidation in the industry, including the recent $6.4 billion deal for B/E Aerospace. Deliveries of A350 passenger jets have been delayed by cabin equipment shortages.

site_title: Macau tourists help Galaxy casino beat profit estimates
summary: Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd's adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization rose 28% to HK$2.7 billion in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company's tourist-friendly casino resorts drew more recreational bettors and tourists to Macau, with shares rising to the highest level in over a year. Recreational gamblers' receipts jumped 17% and mainland Chinese tourists reached a record 1 million during the National Day holiday. However, the increase in competition and potential price war could put pressure on margins in the coming months.

site_title: Weak world economy saps German consumers' mood
summary: Germany's consumer confidence index is expected to fall to 9.7 points in November, down from 10.0 in October, according to a GfK survey. The decline is attributed to weak global growth and not solely due to German economic factors. However, consumers' expectations for the future rose slightly, while their expectations for income and purchases fell. This contrasts with businesses' increased optimism, as a separate Ifo institute survey showed companies were more confident than at any time since April 2014. Private consumption is predicted to contribute to Germany's economic growth this year.

images.alt_text: Germany can expect slightly less cheerful consumers in November, a monthly study from market research firm GfK said on Wednesday, as reports of weak global growth made themselves felt.

site_title: NZ's top spot as easiest place to do business has unpalatable side
summary: New Zealand has taken the top spot for ease of doing business in the World Bank's latest rankings, citing tax improvements. However, experts warn that this may mask the country's vulnerability to money laundering, as it ranks high in company formation and has been linked to shell companies and illicit funds. The government has taken steps to address these concerns, but some experts say more needs to be done to manage risks.

site_title: Nintendo cuts profit outlook as yen strength offsets Pokemon
summary: Nintendo lowered its annual profit outlook to 30 billion yen due to yen strength offsetting earnings from its popular Pokémon GO game. The company had previously estimated 45 billion yen, and its operating profit for the year through March is expected to be 30 billion yen. Despite Pokémon GO's unexpected popularity, Nintendo posted a 812 million yen loss in the three months to Sept 30, primarily due to a yen value gain. The company forecasts a weaker yen this year, averaging 100 yen to the US dollar and 115 yen to the euro.

images.alt_text: Japanese videogame maker Nintendo Co cut its annual profit outlook on Wednesday as income-eroding yen strength overwhelmed an earnings bounce from its popular Pokemon GO smartphone game.

site_title: Chinese state media urge new status for Xi
summary: Chinese state media urged a new status for Xi Jinping, citing a survey of 15,000 people who want him to be a "core" leader, similar to Mao Zedong. The People's Tribune magazine stated that strong leadership is necessary for a nation's rise, aligning with Xi's efforts to consolidate control. This move suggests Xi's intentions to maintain a single leader's authority, potentially solidifying his grip on power.

site_title: Google puts expansion of fibre optic network on hold
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, has put the expansion of its Google Fiber fibre optic network on hold in some markets. Work will continue in cities where service has started or is being developed, but other potential expansion plans are on hold. The company is also halting the recruitment of new employees, with estimates suggesting up to 9% of employees may lose their jobs. Despite this pause, Alphabet CEO Larry Page expressed excitement about the potential of providing ultra-fast internet to more people, and the company plans to continue its fibre optic project.

site_title: Singtel signs deal with Japanese firm to provide cybersecurity services
summary: Singtel has partnered with TIS Inc, a Japanese systems integration company, to provide cybersecurity services in Japan. Trustwave, a Singtel subsidiary, will establish a new Security Operation Centre (SOC) in Tokyo, which will offer 24/7 network monitoring and rapid response to cyber attacks. The partnership strengthens Singtel's presence in the region and provides a comprehensive suite of managed network, ICT, and cyber security services for Japanese clients and multinational corporations.

site_title: LTA awards Lum Chang S$325m contract to build new platform at Tanah Merah station
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$325 million contract to Lum Chang Building Contractors to build a new platform at Tanah Merah Station in Singapore. The new platform will be part of a four-in-one East Coast Integrated Depot at Changi, which will house trains from multiple lines, including buses. Construction is expected to start by the end of 2016 and complete in 2024.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a civil contract to Lum Chang Building Contractors to build a new platform at Tanah Merah Station for S$325 million.

site_title: A 300% rally that has investors questioning Anglo's plan to sell
summary: Anglo American Plc, the UK's best-performing blue-chip stock this year, has seen a 300% rally in its shares over nine months. The company's plan to sell more than half its assets, including coal and iron-ore mines, was met with skepticism from top investors, including Public Investment Corp, who urged executives to reconsider. The rapid price recovery has raised questions about the company's strategy, with some investors wondering if the plan was too drastic. The company's management is now under pressure to reevaluate its approach.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares open lower
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.86% on Wednesday, following a negative lead from New York, due to a decline in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index dropped 202.09 points to 23,363.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index was marginally lower at 3,129.84. Energy firms were particularly affected, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index down 2.10 points.

site_title: Singapore's factory output up 6.7% in Sept, boosted by pharmaceuticals, semiconductors
summary: Singapore's factory output increased 6.7% in September, driven by growth in the biomedical and electronics sectors. The biomedical manufacturing cluster's output rose 22.2% and the pharmaceuticals segment expanded 26.9%. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, factory output grew 3.5%. The electronics cluster's output increased 15.9%, with semiconductors growing 34.8%. This follows a 0.5% year-on-year growth in August and a 3.4% contraction in July.

images.alt_text: Singapore's manufacturing output increased 6.7 per cent in September 2016 compared with a year ago, boosted by growth in the biomedical and electronics sectors, the Economic Development Board (EDB) said on Wednesday.

site_title: Hillary, in Miami, gets Adele on her team
summary: Hillary Clinton took a break from her campaign in Florida to attend a pre-birthday concert by Adele in Miami. Adele expressed her support for Clinton, saying "what happens in America affects me too". Clinton, turning 69, was also featured on a Spanish-language entertainment show, where she shared her favorite recipe for chocolate chip cookies and was given a bottle of tequila to celebrate.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton took time off from storming the campaign trail in the key state of Florida Tuesday to take in a pre-birthday concert by pop icon Adele.

site_title: PE firm Northstar proposes to buy Innovalues for S$331.4m via scheme of arrangement
summary: Private equity firm Northstar Advisors has proposed a S$331.4 million takeover offer for Innovalues Limited via a scheme of arrangement. The offer is at S$1.01 per share, a 19% premium over the company's one-month VWAP before April 7. The acquisition would provide Northstar with control of Innovalues, a precision manufacturing company with a regional footprint.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.160 points to 1675.170. Volume reached 22.29 million lots worth RM10.85 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 69 to 54.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks dip as investors take profits on Fed fears; won inches up
summary: South Korean stocks dropped 1.4% to a one-week low, with investors taking profits amid market jitters over the US Federal Reserve's pending rate increase. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell to 2,008 points as of 0217 GMT. Analysts attributed the decline to the Fed's expected December rate hike, which is spurring investors to sell shares before a potential further drop.

site_title: Gold holds near three-week high as India buys ahead of festival
summary: Gold prices rose near a three-week high as India increased demand ahead of the Diwali festival, the world's largest bullion-consuming country. The metal traded at $1,274.19 per ounce in Singapore, its highest level since October 5. Despite a monthly drop, physical demand in India is expected to surge due to the festival and wedding season. This boost in demand has lifted gold prices, driven by increasing confidence in stronger physical demand.

site_title: Ex-Tata chief Mistry calls ouster illegal: Economic Times
summary: Former Tata Group Chairman Cyrus Mistry accused the conglomerate's directors of illegally ousting him, citing a lack of corporate governance and failure to discharge fiduciary duties. Mistry, who was removed without explanation, claimed the decision left him "shocked beyond words" and harmed the group's reputation. He alleged that alterations to the company's articles of association undermined his ability to turn around Tata's businesses, citing past foreign acquisition strategies and significant debt. Mistry's ouster was followed by the appointment of his predecessor Ratan Tata as the new chairman.

site_title: Singapore to introduce Cybersecurity Act and boost cybersecurity expenditure
summary: Singapore to introduce a Cybersecurity Act, requiring CII owners to secure their systems and networks, and boosting cybersecurity expenditure to at least 8% of IT budget. The Act will include compliance, audits, risk assessments, and incident reporting, and will facilitate sharing of cybersecurity information. The government aims to address the risks of cyber-attacks, following recent disruptions to services, and complement the existing Computer Misuse and Cybersecurity Act.

images.alt_text: Singapore government will introduce a Cybersecurity Act, requiring owners and operators of critical information infrastructure (CII) to be responsible for securing their systems and networks.

site_title: China police confirm illegally made, stored explosives killed 14
summary: A blast in a block of prefabricated houses in China's Xinmin, Shaanxi province, killed 14 people and injured 147. Authorities confirmed the cause was "illegal production and storage of explosives." Three suspects were arrested and confessed to the crime. The incident occurred in a coal-mining province where explosives are widely used. China has a poor record of industrial accidents, with previous blasts blamed on improperly stored chemicals or industrial explosives.

site_title: New LNG imports to bring to Singapore gas from US, Australia and Russia, among others
summary: Singapore to import liquefied natural gas (LNG) from the US, Australia, Norway, Russia, Qatar, and Brunei starting next year, bolstering energy security. The Energy Market Authority will consult the industry for rules on spot LNG imports. To support a secondary gas trading market, the Energy Market Company launched a Gas Trading Board, with the first trade taking place between Pavilion Gas and PacificLight Power. The move aims to further diversify Singapore's LNG supply and facilitate domestic bilateral gas trades.

site_title: Australia: Shares slide, Wesfarmers hit by disappointing Q1 sales
summary: Australian shares fell 1.5% to 5,360.4, hit by disappointing Q1 sales from Wesfarmers Ltd and losses on Wall Street. Oil majors Woodside and Oil Search declined 2.2% and 2.9% respectively. Entertainment company Ardent Leisure plummeted 22% after a fatal incident at its theme park. Meanwhile, iron miners Fortescue and Rio Tinto rose 2% and 1% on a rally in iron and copper prices.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday, down 12.35 points, or 0.43%, at 2,841.7, with losers outnumbering gainers 88 to 40. The trading volume was 44.9 million shares worth S$34.5 million. Investors are seeking positive news amid mixed earnings reports and an overnight retreat on Wall Street.

site_title: FLASH: PE firm Northstar offers to buy Innovalues, valuing company at S$331.4m
summary: PE firm Northstar has proposed a S$331.4 million offer to buy Innovalues via a scheme of arrangement. The acquisition, valued at S$331.4m, is subject to regulatory approvals. The deal is expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Coca-Cola West considering alliance with rival Kirin in Japan
summary: Coca-Cola West Co is in talks with Kirin Holdings Co in Japan for a potential alliance, which could involve cross-shareholdings. The companies have not made any decisions regarding the tie-up. This collaboration may aim to strengthen their presence in the Japanese market. The exact terms and details of the proposed alliance have not been disclosed.

site_title: Aussie jumps as inflation steadies, kiwi trails
summary: The Australian dollar rose half of a US cent to US$0.7684, its biggest jump in a week, as inflation ran slightly faster than expected, solidifying views that the central bank will hold rates steady into next year. The Reserve Bank of Australia is seen as "pushing back" concerns of further rate cuts, with futures markets slashing expectations of another interest rate cut. The Australian dollar also rose against the kiwi and euro, while the New Zealand dollar dipped due to expectations of a rate cut.

site_title: US dollar underpinned by Fed rate expectations, Aussie shines
summary: The US dollar remains steady in Asia trading, held near a nine-month peak, as investors expect the Fed to raise interest rates by year-end. The Australian dollar gains, driven by inflation data showing core inflation edged up, making a rate cut unlikely. The Aussie jumps to US$0.7709, while the US dollar index stands at 98.739. Expectations of a Fed rate hike in December support the dollar's strength.

site_title: Asia: Stocks weighed down by Apple, oil slide as Aussie climbs
summary: Asian stocks declined as Apple's disappointing earnings and crude oil's drop weighed on markets. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell, with energy companies leading losses. Apple's 2.9% drop in after-hours trading dragged US equity index futures lower. The Australian dollar strengthened, and inflation rose 1.3% in the last quarter, reducing expectations of an interest-rate cut. Global markets have seen declines in volatility, with a cross-asset gauge at its lowest since 2014.

site_title: Colombia eyes new front in peace talks
summary: Colombia's government plans to initiate talks with the National Liberation Army (ELN), its second-largest rebel force, as part of efforts to end a 52-year armed conflict. The move comes after a referendum rejected a peace accord with the Farc last month. President Juan Manuel Santos aims to free the last ELN hostage, former congressman Odin Sanchez, before negotiations begin in Quito, Ecuador. Analysts predict the talks will be complicated and that the ELN may maintain a high level of violent action, despite its willingness to show a "will for peace."

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on technical selling, Apple suppliers weak
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.2% to 9,365.82 points, driven by technical selling near the 9,400 level, amid weak reactions from benchmark technology suppliers to Apple's earnings. This follows a 0.7% gain on Tuesday, its highest close since June 2015. Soft overseas markets also contributed to the decline, which comes as investors navigate uncertainty over US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Najib ponders campaign finance overhaul in wake of donations row
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is considering reforms to campaign finance laws, including a ban on foreign donations, after a funding scandal has shadowed his administration for over a year. Proposed changes include unlimited donations from Malaysian citizens or companies, mandatory identity disclosure for donations above RM3,000, and stricter regulations on government-linked corporations and politicians. The reforms aim to prevent money politics from influencing elections and party politics.

site_title: Australia inflation edges up, market nixes rate cut
summary: Australia's inflation edged up to 1.6% in the third quarter, surpassing forecasts, as the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) showed an average rise of 0.4% in underlying inflation. Investors priced out a near-term rate cut, with interbank futures implying only a 4% chance of a rate cut at the RBA's next meeting. The RBA is likely to keep interest rates on hold, with some economists suggesting it may stay that way until 2017.

site_title: After 20,000 job cuts, world's top shipyards brace for more
summary: South Korea's top shipyards, including Hyundai Heavy Industries, Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, and Samsung Heavy Industries, are bracing for more job cuts amid a decline in demand for new vessels and shipping platforms. The industry has already eliminated over 20,000 jobs this year and is estimated to lose up to 40,000 more positions by the end of the year. The sector has lost 6.6 trillion won (S$8.081 billion) in the last six quarters due to delivery delays and weak demand.

site_title: Tasmania to get first direct flight to China (but only for milk)
summary: Tasmania will begin receiving direct flights to China, specifically to supply fresh milk to Ningbo, China, starting early next year. Moon Lake Investments Pty, owned by businessman Lu Xianfeng, will operate weekly round trips from Hobart International Airport. The milk, which will be flown in bulk, is sourced from Tasmania's far northwest coast, where it boasts "the cleanest air in the world." This move aims to capitalize on China's growing demand for imported milk, with the country's dairy market expected to reach $333 million by 2020.

site_title: VW judge approves US$14.7b diesel-cheating settlement
summary: A US District Judge approved a $14.7 billion settlement between Volkswagen AG and US consumers and regulators over the company's diesel-cheating scandal. Under the deal, VW will buy back or fix cars with 2.0-litre diesel engines, offering $5,100 to $10,000 in compensation to car owners. The settlement, which includes $1.2 billion for US franchise dealers and $603 million to US states, is the largest portion of VW's civil liability worldwide.

site_title: First Sponsor marks 13.1% growth in Q3 profit
summary: FIRST Sponsor reported a 13.1% growth in Q3 net profit to S$19.33 million, driven by higher development income. Revenue increased 11.5% to S$80.35 million, primarily due to higher property sales revenue. The Millennium Waterfront project achieved its best quarter, with 373 residential units sold, a 12% increase from the previous quarter. The group plans to launch the last residential plot for sale to capitalize on the exceptional market demand.

site_title: Dreamworld closed indefinitely as Aussie police probe 4 deaths
summary: Dreamworld theme park in Australia has been closed indefinitely as police investigate a fatal water-ride accident that killed four people, including two girls and two adults, after a raft flipped over at the Thunder River Rapids ride. The incident is the most lethal theme-park accident in Australia in nearly 40 years. Shares in the operator plummeted, and the company's market value dropped by billions of dollars. An investigation is ongoing, with engineers set to examine the machinery, and authorities appeal to the public not to defer holiday plans to the affected region.

images.alt_text: Ardent Leisure Group's Dreamworld, the biggest theme park on Australia's Gold Coast, will remain closed until further notice as police investigate a water-ride accident that killed four people. Shares in the operator tumbled as much as 22 percent in Sydney.

site_title: Vallianz clarifies rumours of salary payment delays to crew on Swiber vessel
summary: Vallianz Holdings Limited, a 25.15% owner of Swiber Holdings, has clarified rumors about delayed salary payments to crew on the Swiber Explorer vessel. The company has made arrangements to settle outstanding salaries, with transfers completed by August 2016 and expected to be received within two days. All outstanding salaries for September 2016 will be settled by the end of this week. Despite the detained vessel, Vallianz has been working closely with relevant parties to review the status of the three vessels.

site_title: City of London calls for post-Brexit banking rules that aid competitiveness
summary: The City of London is calling for post-Brexit banking rules that prioritize competitiveness, warning that EU regulations could harm the financial district's global influence. Lord Mayor Jeffrey Mountevans said "realistic, collaborative" regulation is needed to protect competitiveness and liberal market influence across the EU. This comes as other European cities, such as Paris and Frankfurt, vie for London's financial businesses following Brexit. The City's call contrasts with the views of Andrew Bailey, chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority, who has ruled out a "bonfire of regulations."

images.alt_text: London's financial district has called for a regulatory regime in the UK that does not harm competitiveness as bankers fear that being outside the European Union will reduce the capital's clout in global markets.

site_title: UN refusal to recognise role in Haiti cholera a 'debacle'
summary: The UN refuses to acknowledge full responsibility for the years-long cholera epidemic in Haiti, which has claimed over 9,000 lives, despite being morally and legally bound to help. UN special rapporteur Philip Alston calls the refusal "morally unconscionable" and "politically self-defeating". The UN is set to roll out a $200 million aid package, but critics say it's too little, too late. The UN must also establish a procedure to settle claims by cholera victims' families, according to Alston.

site_title: US Treasury tells banks to provide details on cyber attacks
summary: The US Treasury's Office of Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) has told banks to include details about cyber attacks in their suspicious activity reports (SARs) on fraud and money laundering. This is part of a broader effort to combat digital crimes, following a $81 million heist from the Bangladesh Bank's account. The advisory specifies that banks should include information on system breaches, IP addresses, and device identifiers to aid law enforcement in investigating cyber-related crimes. The move aims to strengthen the US financial system's defenses against cyber threats.

site_title: Hugo Boss CEO says wants to abandon luxury segment
summary: Hugo Boss CEO Mark Langer plans to abandon the luxury market and refocus on selling premium men's clothing, citing the lack of success in this segment. The decision comes after the luxury sector experienced its most severe slowdown in seven years. Langer aims to close unprofitable stores and cut annual costs by 50 million euros. This move follows the departure of former CEO Claus-Dietrich Lahrs, who had expanded Hugo Boss into the luxury market with over 400 stores worldwide.

site_title: China's Netflix wannabes spend billions to win viewers
summary: China's internet giants are investing billions of dollars in original content to compete with Netflix, with streaming platforms like Baidu's iQiyi and Alibaba's Youku.com spending up to 10 billion yuan and 3.1 billion yuan, respectively. The companies aim to produce more compelling characters and shows, such as "The Mystic Nine" and "Descendants of the Sun," to lure viewers and generate revenue. Despite the high spending, the industry is still unprofitable, with companies like iQiyi predicting losses until 2018. The competition is expected to continue, with Tencent and LeEco also investing heavily in content production.

images.alt_text: Tomb-raiding soldiers and imperial court villains are leading the latest battlefront for China's internet giants, which are pouring billions of dollars into new digital content to create the nation's answer to Netflix Inc.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust posts 18% drop in Q3 DPU
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) reported a 18% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.987 cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, due to higher operating expenses and lower net property income of 8.3%. Despite this, the CEO expressed steady progress in the company's strategy to divest non-core properties and optimize its portfolio.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, First Sponsor, SembMarine, Cosco
summary: Singapore-listed companies released mixed quarterly earnings reports, affecting trading. First Sponsor achieved a 13.1% growth in net profit to S$19.33 million, while Great Eastern Holding reported a surge in net profit to S$195 million. However, SembCorp Marine recorded a net loss of S$21.8 million and Cosco Corporation warned of a worse set of results due to cancellations and delivery extensions. Investors face a mixed bag of news ahead of GDP data, with some sectors showing resilience.

site_title: BoE's Carney says UK-EU trade links could be global template
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said that the UK's future trading relations with the EU could serve as a global template for a regulatory system. Following Brexit, UK banks are preparing to shift operations to continental Europe, with the EU's "equivalence" system potentially providing access to the single market. Carney expects the EU to consider equivalence with Britain, but notes that an independent dispute resolution mechanism and protections would be needed. He also emphasized the need for flexibility in regulations to accommodate the UK's large financial sector.

site_title: StarHub says hit by cyber attacks
summary: Singapore telecom operator StarHub Ltd reported intentional cyber attacks on its domain name servers, causing web connection disruptions for some customers on Oct 22 and Oct 24. The attacks were likely malicious distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, flooding servers with unwanted traffic. However, the company's services were not impacted, and the security of customers' information remained intact. StarHub mitigated the attacks within two hours and restored service. The incident occurred amid a global internet stability breach, but no evidence of data compromise was found.

site_title: US dollar near highest since March as Fed rate-increase wagers rise
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-month high against major counterparts as traders increased bets on a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase by year-end. The dollar appreciated against about half of its major counterparts, leaving it on track for an October gain, with the probability of a rate hike by December rising to 73%. This suggests the dollar may have room to extend gains, despite evidence of faster economic growth and accelerating inflation.

site_title: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman sees 'nothing good about Brexit'
summary: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman expressed concerns over the UK's Brexit vote, stating there's "nothing good" about it. The firm will likely relocate some employees and their families out of London due to the disruptions. Gorman believes the UK's exit will force global firms to reevaluate their business locations, particularly for trading activities. He also mentioned that Morgan Stanley may need to relocate its headquarters in Europe and potentially move capital and liquidity to other locations, including New York.

site_title: Women and men won't reach economic equality until 2186, index says
summary: The World Economic Forum's annual gender gap index predicts men and women won't reach economic equality until 2186 due to stalled progress in closing the gap. The index found that efforts to close the gap slowed dramatically in the past year, with women's economic participation and opportunity at 59% of men's levels. The gap in political empowerment is also pronounced, with the US ranking 73rd and taking 82 years to close at current rates. Iceland and Finland ranked highest in equality measures, while Yemen and Syria ranked lowest.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Wednesday, following two days of gains, due to lower oil prices and weak US consumer confidence data. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.28% to 17,316.66, while the Topix index fell 0.15% to 1,375.20.

site_title: Trump vows to scrap Obamacare as costs to jump 25 per cent
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump vows to scrap the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, following a report that Americans will see health insurance costs jump an average of 25% next year. The program, established by President Barack Obama, has seen a significant increase in premiums, with the largest jump expected in the 38 states with federally-managed health care exchanges. Trump claims the increase is much higher than reported, while his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton's campaign accuses him of wanting to "rip up the ACA and reverse the progress made."

site_title: Bill Gates foundation gives US$210m to Seattle-based university
summary: Bill Gates' foundation has donated $210 million to the University of Washington's Population Health Initiative, a 25-year project to improve global health. The donation will be used to construct a building at the university. This is one of the largest contributions to the university's history. The initiative aims to combat diseases, health disparities, and environmental healing, with a focus on air pollution's impact on illnesses. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is one of the world's largest private charities.

site_title: EU to extend Schengen border controls for three months
summary: The European Union has recommended extending border controls in the Schengen area for three months, starting in November, to cope with a significant number of irregular migrants. The move comes after a massive migrant influx last year, with over one million asylum seekers arriving in the EU. The controls will be in place in Austria, Germany, Denmark, Sweden, and Norway to prevent secondary movements and chaos. The EU aims to restore full functioning with no border controls by the end of the year, but the decision must be approved by member states.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q3 net profit surges to S$195m from S$68.4m a year ago
summary: Great Eastern Holding's net profit surged to S$195 million in Q3 2016, a 185% increase from S$68.4 million a year ago. Higher operating profits and favorable financial market conditions contributed to the growth, driven by increased profits from its insurance business and shareholders' fund investments. For the nine-month period, the group's net profit was S$394.1 million, 30% lower than the previous year. Despite this, GEH remains confident of its growth prospects in its operating markets.

site_title: Britain's May defies critics to back new US$22b Heathrow runway
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has backed a $22 billion expansion of London's Heathrow Airport, ending 25 years of indecision. The decision, set to be completed by 2025, aims to boost global trade links following Brexit. Despite opposition from politicians, including Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, and potential court challenges, May is likely to win parliamentary approval.
