Even in healthy credit states, pockets of serious problems exist, providing opportunities for local governments and community groups to target their efforts and improve access to credit. The report highlights the need for targeted interventions to address these disparities and support those left behind in the economic recovery.

site_title: Julius Baer, DBS said to mull buying ABN Amro Asia private bank
summary: Julius Baer Group, DBS Group Holdings, and LGT Bank are considering bids for ABN Amro Asia's private banking business in Asia, with a potential sale worth over $300 million. ABN Amro hopes to announce a deal by year-end to minimize uncertainty for its private bankers and clients. The sale follows similar retreats in the industry by other lenders, and ABN Amro has been exploring a sale with a financial adviser since this month.

site_title: Britain set to announce plans to expand London airport
summary: Britain is set to announce plans to expand London's airport capacity, with speculation growing that a new runway at Heathrow will be approved. Environmental activists are protesting in anticipation, while business leaders argue that London's five existing airports are not keeping up with rising air travel demand. The government-commissioned report recommends a £17.6 billion investment in a new runway, which could generate up to £147 billion over 60 years and create over 70,000 jobs. The decision will be subject to further consultation and a parliamentary vote in 2017/2018.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance as US manufacturing rises amid earnings
summary: Asian stocks rose as the US manufacturing gauge climbed to its highest since 2015, boosting bets for an interest rate hike by December to 71%. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index advanced 0.2% to 140.28, with Japan's Topix index adding 0.6% and South Korea's Kospi index losing 0.5%. The rally follows improved US economic indicators and a stronger US dollar, which weakened the yen.

site_title: Bobby Vee, clean-cut pop star from 1960s, dead at 73
summary: Bobby Vee, a 1960s pop star and mentor to Bob Dylan, died at 73 due to complications from Alzheimer's disease in a Minnesota care facility. Born Robert Velline, Vee began his music career as a teenager, buying his first guitar with newspaper delivery money. He went on to record with his band The Shadows, showcasing the self-effacing humility characteristic of the Upper Midwest. Vee's passing marks the end of an era for the clean-cut idol who rose to fame in the early days of rock 'n' roll.

site_title: Singapore makes progress in testing renewable energy technologies
summary: Singapore has completed the first stages of its renewable energy living laboratories, testing 10 solar photovoltaic systems floating on water at Tengah reservoir. The pilot aims to assess the environmental impact and economic viability of floating solar PV systems, with successful deployment planned for large-scale deployment. Additionally, the Renewable Energy Integration Demonstrator Singapore (REIDS) is developing microgrids to test their interaction, paving the way for solutions to be exported to South-east Asia and beyond.

site_title: Gold holds drop as equities rally, US dollar strength blunt demand
summary: Gold prices declined 0.1% to US$1,263.52 an ounce, as equities advanced and the US dollar reached a seven-month high, reducing demand for a safe-haven asset. The metal's 2016 gain was eroded due to prospects of higher borrowing costs from the Federal Reserve. This is the first back-to-back drop in gold prices in over two weeks, as investors await the central bank's next interest-rate decision.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.260 points to 1677.440. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 71, with a total of 61.58 million lots traded worth RM21.48 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open almost flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened almost flat on Tuesday, despite a lack of inspiration from corporate earnings reports and anticipation of debt restructuring by oil and gas players. The Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.2 points higher at 2,856.88, with gainers outnumbering losers 65 to 53. This is a departure from the previous 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, as investors seem to be cautious amid tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Stand pat decision in Oct was 'appropriate' as previous easing moves prop up growth: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained its monetary policy stance to meet its inflation target, despite a weakened economy outlook. The central bank kept the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band at a zero per cent appreciation rate, citing a need to keep core inflation around 2 per cent in the medium term. MAS expects global growth to remain broadly unchanged in 2017, with imported inflation expected to be subdued due to narrowing demand-supply imbalances in key commodity markets. The decision comes after recent easing moves, with three-fifths of their effects yet to be transmitted to the economy.

images.alt_text: Even though the outlook for Singapore's economy has weakened, its central bank said on Tuesday that it maintained monetary policy stance to meet its inflation target, while waiting for the full effect of recent easing moves to permeate through the economy.

site_title: US takes aim at cyber attacks from connected devices as recalls mount
summary: The US government is taking steps to counter cyber attacks from connected devices, also known as the "internet of things." The Department of Homeland Security has held a conference call with major communication service providers to develop strategic principles for securing these devices. Over a million devices have been commandeered by hackers, who can use them to disrupt websites. Companies are recalling affected devices, but experts say many will not be fixed and the broader security threat will worsen. The government and companies are focusing on recommending better software architecture and updating devices with native security.

site_title: JR Kyushu surges in debut, helped by fat dividends and tourism hopes
summary: JR Kyushu shares surged 15% on its market debut, reaching 3,010 yen, after pricing its IPO at the top of its range at $4 billion. The strong debut is attributed to fat dividends and hopes for the company's real estate business and increased tourism to Japan, particularly to the southern island of Kyushu, which attracted a record 2.8 million foreign tourists last year. The company aims to target a payout ratio of 30% through March 2019 and offers discount coupons for its railway services to shareholders.

site_title: Oil trades near US$50 as Opec chief seeks to resolve output plan
summary: Oil prices traded near $50 a barrel amid uncertainty over an Opec deal to reduce output. Opec Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo is set to visit Baghdad to discuss Iraq's exemption from planned cuts, citing conflict with Islamic militants. US crude stockpiles rose last week, and a committee will meet later this month to resolve differences on output levels. If the deal is not implemented, oil prices may retreat to $45 a barrel, according to resources analyst David Lennox.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Capitaland Retail China Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Mapletree Logistics Trust, GuocoLand, GL (Amended)
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday include Capitaland Retail China Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and GuocoLand, which reported mixed quarterly earnings. Capitaland Retail China Trust declined 10.6% in distribution per unit due to the weaker yuan, while Mapletree Industrial Trust rose 1.4% in DPU. GuocoLand's net profit plummeted 95% to S$25.6 million due to the lack of a one-time gain from the disposal of subsidiaries. Trading halted for Ezra Holdings, Nera Telecommunications, Starland, and GRP Limited.

site_title: Google acquires eye-tracking company for virtual reality efforts
summary: Google has acquired eye-tracking company Eyefluence, which aims to enable eye movements to control digital screens, for virtual reality efforts. Eyefluence, a three-year-old startup, had raised $21.6 million in funding and promised to allow users to manipulate objects and digital screens with their eyes. The deal is part of Google's investment in virtual reality, which has also included software and a mobile headset launch earlier this month, as well as investments in Magic Leap and other eye-tracking startups.

site_title: US calls on auto industry to make cyber security a priority
summary: US regulators issued guidelines for the auto industry to prioritize cyber security, recommending the development of layers of protection to secure vehicles throughout their life. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) issued "Cybersecurity Best Practices for Modern Vehicles" as recommendations, not enforceable rules. Automakers are expected to review the proposals and share information about cyber security threats. The guidelines follow recent efforts by major manufacturers to address hacking threats, including the establishment of a group to share information about cyber security threats.

site_title: Kerry speaks to Philippines counterpart after separation comment by Duterte
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry spoke with his Philippines counterpart after President Rodrigo Duterte's comments raised concerns about bilateral relations. Kerry expressed concern over the tone of Duterte's remarks, which criticized President Barack Obama and suggested a separation from the US. The phone call led Kerry to believe the US and Philippines can work through the issue, despite no practical action from Manila to move away from US ties.

site_title: Canadian pension fund invests US$375m in CapitaLand's third China fund
summary: The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) has invested US$375 million in CapitaLand's third China fund, Raffles City China Investment Partners III (RCCIP III), representing a quarter stake in the US$1.5 billion integrated development fund. The fund will invest in prime integrated developments in gateway cities in China for an eight-year period. This investment aligns with CPPIB's long-term strategy of investing in high-quality commercial real estate in China to deliver solid risk-adjusted returns.

site_title: Some 330 US Marines to be temporarily stationed in Norway in 2017
summary: Norway has agreed to temporarily station 330 US Marines at its Vaernes military base in central Norway starting January 2017, marking the first time foreign troops have been posted on its territory since World War II. The move is part of a trial period and will be reviewed throughout the year. Norway, a close US ally and founding member of the NATO alliance, aims to develop its defense capabilities and bolster its security with the help of US forces, particularly given concerns about Russian military activity in the Arctic.

site_title: Air pollution can affect blood pressure: study
summary: A study of over 41,000 European city-dwellers found that long-term exposure to urban air pollution increases the risk of high blood pressure. Researchers found that one extra adult in 100 developed high blood pressure in the most polluted areas compared to less polluted areas. The risk is similar to being clinically overweight, and exposure to particulate air pollution was associated with a higher incidence of self-reported hypertension. Noise pollution, especially traffic noise, also boosts the likelihood of hypertension.

site_title: CapitaLand sets up third integrated development fund in China worth US$1.5b
summary: CapitaLand has raised US$1.5 billion for its third integrated development fund in China, known as Raffles City China Investment Partners III (RCCIP III), with an eight-year life. The fund will invest in prime integrated developments in gateway cities. CapitaLand will subscribe for a 41.7% sponsor stake, while major investors from Asia, North America, and the Middle East will hold the remaining interests. This is the largest private capital-raising for CapitaLand, and it brings the group's assets under management (AUM) to over S$45 billion.

site_title: Evans pushes Fed to explain how data will guide rate-hike pace
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Charles Evans urged the Fed to be more explicit about its rate-hike pace, citing the need for flexibility in case forecasts don't pan out. He estimated a possible three rate hikes by the end of 2017, aligning with the median FOMC estimate. Evans also expressed optimism about the US jobs market, suggesting the unemployment rate could fall as low as 4.5% without triggering inflation.

site_title: UN blames all sides after Syria evacuation plan fails
summary: The UN blamed all sides in Syria after a failed evacuation plan to move critically injured and sick Syrians from Aleppo. Despite days of negotiations, fighting resumed, and no agreement was reached. The UN's humanitarian aid coordinator, Stephen O'Brien, cited delays in receiving approvals, armed group conditions for safety, and the Syrian government's refusal to allow aid supplies into rebel-held areas. The UN Secretary General warned that food rations will run out by the end of October, and nearly 500 people have been killed and 2,000 injured during the Aleppo bombing raids.

site_title: Twitter plans to cut hundreds of jobs: Bloomberg
summary: Twitter plans to cut hundreds of jobs, according to Bloomberg. The company had 3,860 employees globally as of June 2016. In September, Twitter announced it would lay off some employees and halt engineering work at a development center in Bengaluru, India.

site_title: May denies Britain heading for 'hard Brexit'
summary: Theresa May denied that the UK is heading for a "hard Brexit" during a House of Commons debate, insisting that the government aims for a good trade deal with the EU while controlling immigration. EU leaders have emphasized the need for the UK to maintain access to the single market, but May argued that a good trade deal can be achieved without meeting specific conditions. Businesses are pressing for continued access to the single market, warning of debilitating tariffs if the UK leaves.

site_title: Clinton looks to conquer early voting battlegrounds
summary: Hillary Clinton is focusing on early voting battlegrounds, including Florida and Ohio, with many Americans already casting ballots. The Clinton campaign expects a surge in early voting, particularly among Democrats, and is counting on an insurmountable lead in key states. As of Saturday, Democrats had narrowed the Republican lead in Florida from 5.3 to 1.6 percentage points. Clinton leads Trump nationally and in most battleground states, with a new poll showing her leading by 50-38.

site_title: Smartwatch sales tumble, dragged down by Apple
summary: Global smartwatch sales declined 51.6% in the third quarter, with Apple's sales plummeting 71.6% to 1.1 million units. The decline is attributed to consumers waiting for the new Apple Watch and upcoming Android devices. Analysts suggest that smartwatches are not for everyone, with a clear purpose and use case being crucial. Despite the drop, Apple maintained its top position, followed by Garmin and Samsung.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust Q2 DPU up 1.4%
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 1.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.83 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended Sept 30, 2016, driven by higher rental rates and occupancies in its high-tech buildings. Gross revenue rose 1.8% to S$84.2 million, while net property income increased 4.3% to S$63.6 million. Unitholders can expect their quarterly DPU on Nov 28.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Industrial Trust on Tuesday reported a 1.4 per cent increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.83 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended Sept 30, 2016.

site_title: South Korea Q3 GDP slows slightly, but better than forecast
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.7% in Q3, marginally ahead of market expectations but slowing from 0.8% in Q2. Private consumption rose 0.5%, capital investment slipped 0.1%, and construction investment rose 3.9%. The country's economy expanded 2.7% in Q2 last year, beating forecasts. Despite the slowdown, the growth rate is still considered strong, indicating the economy's resilience.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust posts 10.6% drop in Q3 DPU (Amended)
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 10.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.36 Singapore cents due to the weaker yuan. Net property income (NPI) grew 0.6% to 161.28 million yuan, but dropped 6.9% to S$32.77 million in Singapore dollars. Despite the decline, CRCT remains positive on China's retail growth prospects. The Reit manager expects the new mall addition, Galleria, to diversify income and strengthen the portfolio.

site_title: EU considers concession for telecoms operators in ending roaming charges
summary: The European Union is considering a proposal by Spain that would allow telecom operators to charge each other for hosting tourists on their networks when roaming charges are abolished. The proposal would allow operators to charge above the EU cap in exceptional circumstances if they cannot recover costs, potentially increasing wholesale prices and affecting domestic prices for consumers. EU diplomats are split on the proposal, with some countries favoring a lower wholesale cap and others seeking higher rates to recover costs.

site_title: Ninth century library goes digital to reach wider audience
summary: A 9th-century Moroccan library, al-Qarawiyyin, is going digital to make its ancient manuscripts available to a wider audience. The library, home to 4,000 rare manuscripts, has installed a laboratory to scan and digitize the texts, with around 20% already scanned. The project aims to preserve cultural heritage and make it accessible globally, with the library expected to reopen to the public in early 2017.

site_title: White pushes bigger SEC role in regulating US Treasuries
summary: SEC Chair Mary Jo White calls for a bigger role in regulating the US Treasury market, citing the need for consistency in controls and measures to prevent market instability. She suggests that firms trading in both equity and Treasury markets should be registered as dealers in both. White has directed the SEC staff to develop recommendations to enhance regulation of platforms trading government securities. Her push for a larger SEC role aims to strengthen the US Treasury market, which is currently overseen by the Federal Reserve and Treasury Department.

images.alt_text: The Securities and Exchange Commission should play a bigger role in regulating the market for US Treasuries, the head of the SEC said on Monday in what appeared to be a push for a bigger role for her agency in a market largely overseen by the Federal Reserve and Treasury Department.

site_title: May promises Parliament debates about Brexit - but not votes
summary: Theresa May has promised UK lawmakers debates on Brexit before formal negotiations, allowing for discussion on the UK's future relationship with the EU without committing to a specific position. The debates, to take place before and after the Christmas recess, will be general and do not require a vote. May aims to keep her negotiating stance ambiguous, but Andrew Tyrie warns this could damage business if clarity is not provided.

images.alt_text: Theresa May promised UK lawmakers they will be able to have a series of debates on how the government should approach leaving the European Union before she begins formal negotiations, a week after she had to back down in the face of a rebellion in her Conservative Party.

site_title: Colombia 'torpedoing' peace talks, say ELN rebels
summary: Colombia's ELN rebels accused the government of "torpedoing" peace talks due to an ultimatum to free a hostage before talks begin. The National Liberation Army (ELN) is holding former congressman Odin Sanchez, and the government's lead negotiator, Juan Camilo Restrepo, gave the rebels an ultimatum: Free the hostage or the talks are off. The talks, set to open on Thursday, are historic and mark a significant step towards ending the country's 50-year conflict.

site_title: AT&T, Time Warner defend merger as politicians challenge
summary: AT&T and Time Warner have defended their $108.7 billion merger, stating it will benefit consumers with smoother and innovative content delivery. The merger combines a dominant telecommunications company with a leading entertainment provider, allowing for more seamless content delivery. However, politicians and regulators have raised concerns over the deal's impact on competition and consumer choice, with some calling it a concentration of power in the hands of too few. The companies face an uncertain antitrust review process, with analysts predicting a "lengthy and arduous" review.

site_title: Frasers Property secures 115 hectare site in Melbourne for A$440m mixed-use project
summary: Frasers Property Australia has secured a 115-hectare site in Melbourne for a $440 million mixed-use project. The site, adjacent to a proposed rail station, will feature 1,200 residential lots, 8.3 hectares for education/community use, 8.3 hectares for retail, and 14.8 hectares for mixed-use commercial/employment. The acquisition underscores Frasers Property's commitment to new development in Melbourne, according to Anthony Boyd, executive general manager residential.

site_title: Alipay targets Chinese tourists with US payment deals
summary: Alipay, a Chinese mobile payment app with 450 million active users, is expanding into the US market through partnerships with payment processors First Data and Verifone. The company aims to target Chinese tourists, with 117 million travelers in 2014, and forecast to double by 2020. Alipay seeks to become a global payments provider, with 60% of transactions coming from outside China, and aims to reach 2 billion users in the next decade.

site_title: Oil dips on Buzzard restart, Iraq; US crude tests below US$50
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday, with US crude briefly falling below $50 per barrel, due to the impending restart of Britain's Buzzard oilfield and Iraq's request to be exempt from Opec production cuts. The US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 33 cents, or 0.7%, to settle at $50.52. Despite Opec's efforts to cut 700,000 barrels from global supply, losses were limited by higher equity prices and a weekly draw of 1 million barrels at the Cushing delivery hub.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dipped on Monday, with US crude briefly falling below US$50 per barrel, on news of the impending restart of Britain's Buzzard oilfield and Iraq's wish to be exempted from Opec production cuts.

site_title: US dollar gains against yen as traders see Dec Fed rate hike
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the yen, reaching a one-week high, as traders anticipate a potential December interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. A 74% chance of a rate increase in December was cited by CME Group's FedWatch programme, with Chicago Fed President Charles Evans suggesting three rate hikes between now and the end of 2017. This follows recent positive economic data and comments from central bank officials, including a one-year high in US manufacturing and a strong US home resales report.

site_title: Premier League club Watford in probe over fake HSBC letters
summary: Premier League club Watford is under investigation for allegedly submitting forged HSBC bank letters to support Gino Pozzo's takeover of the club in 2014. The letters claimed to have a £7 million bank guarantee, but an internal investigation by the club has found no evidence Pozzo was aware of the forged documents. The English Football League has launched a probe into the matter, and the club has been required to provide a full response to the allegations.

site_title: Dollar at nine-month high on bets for Fed hike, Clinton victory
summary: The US dollar reached a nine-month high against a basket of currencies on October 24, driven by expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike and a likely Hillary Clinton victory in the US presidential election. The dollar index rose to 98.846, its strongest level since February 3. Analysts attributed the surge to hawkish comments from central bank officials and polls favoring Clinton over Donald Trump, which could lead to a Fed rate hike in December.

site_title: British PM to lead trade delegation to India
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May announced she will lead a trade delegation to India in early November, aiming to boost relationships between small and medium-sized businesses. The visit comes as the UK seeks new trade relationships after leaving the European Union. May stated that while individual EU member states cannot hold bilateral talks on free trade deals with non-EU states, she is open to discussing trade arrangements with India. The visit is part of May's efforts to start formal negotiations on leaving the EU by the end of March, with a potential exit by early 2019.

site_title: Aussie homes are 'increasingly unaffordable': Treasurer
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison says states need to simplify residential land planning regulations to make homes "increasingly unaffordable" in cities like Sydney. Insufficient land releases and complex regulations are major factors, and Morrison will urge state counterparts to address these issues at a December meeting. This aims to boost housing supply and mitigate artificial price inflation. Dwelling values in Sydney have risen 14% this year, outpacing the national average.

site_title: Insurance agents warned against taking medical referral fee
summary: The Life Insurance Association Singapore (LIA Singapore) has warned against insurance agents taking medical referral fees, citing a practice that has gained popularity. Industry sources confirm an advisory was released to LIA members a few months ago. This warning aims to prevent the exploitation of consumers and maintain transparency in the industry.

site_title: Samsung offers upgrade plan in S Korea
summary: Samsung is offering an upgrade plan to Galaxy Note 7 customers in South Korea who trade in their recalled device for a Galaxy S7 phone, allowing them to trade up for a Galaxy S8 or Note 8 smartphone. The program, which includes financial incentives, aims to retain customers and limit long-term damage to the brand. The move comes after the company permanently ended Note 7 sales due to reports of fires from the device, which has cost Samsung US$5.4 billion in operating profit.

site_title: Visa profit, revenue beat analysts' estimates
summary: Visa Inc reported better-than-expected quarterly profit and revenue, driven by increased total payments volume of 47.1% to $1.86 trillion in the fourth quarter. The company's operating expenses rose 27% due to the inclusion of Visa Europe. Excluding special items, Visa earned 78 cents per share, beating analyst estimates. Despite this, the company expects adjusted earnings per share to grow in the mid-teens and net revenue to grow 16-18% in the current financial year.

site_title: In Marlboro country, a big-money race for the new smoke
summary: Philip Morris International is racing to develop cigarette substitutes that won't harm consumers. The company's Swiss research centre, the Cube, is working on a smoke-free future. Philip Morris aims to sell these substitutes, potentially becoming a major player in the market. The company's efforts come as governments worldwide impose stricter regulations on smoking. With a focus on innovation, Philip Morris is seeking to capitalize on the shift towards healthier alternatives, aiming to maintain its dominance in the tobacco industry.

site_title: BOE deputy governor sees barriers to global regulatory cooperation
summary: BOE deputy governor Minouche Shafik expressed concerns over barriers to global regulatory cooperation, citing the shared risks of rapid lending growth and financial crises. Despite the shared nature of these risks, regulators are reluctant to cooperate due to unequal distribution of benefits from globalization. Research by the BOE found that rapid lending growth abroad significantly increases the risk of financial instability, regardless of domestic lending growth. Shafik called for broader reciprocity and consideration of banks' health against the same risks to effectively curb excessive credit growth.

site_title: South Korea's Park proposes multiple-term presidency
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye proposed amending the Constitution to allow multiple-term presidencies or establish a parliamentary system. The single-term presidency has been in place for nearly 30 years, but Park believes it has served its purpose and is limiting policy effectiveness. A Realmeter poll found 70% of South Koreans support revising the Constitution, with 40% preferring a two-term limit. Park asked Parliament to form a special committee to discuss the amendment, which must be approved by a two-thirds majority and a national referendum.

site_title: 1 in 9 has no access to clean water
summary: Millions of people worldwide, particularly in Asia and sub-Saharan Africa, lack access to clean water and sanitation, with 1 in 9 people globally facing this issue. The Mekong River in Cambodia is a prime example, with millions of people relying on polluted water for drinking, bathing, and fishing. Climate change, rapid population growth, and inefficient water use exacerbate the problem. Despite efforts by governments and NGOs, water scarcity is a growing concern, with 21 of the world's largest aquifers having reached a sustainable tipping point. Effective solutions, such as water recycling and community-led initiatives, can mitigate the issue.

images.alt_text: Workers weighing fish on the banks of Cambodia's Tonle Sap, South-east Asia's largest freshwater lake. The water in the lake, however, is hardly fresh as it is fouled by sewage and agricultural and industrial pollution.

site_title: Russia working on options for oil accord with Opec, Novak says
summary: Russia is working on options for an oil accord with Opec, according to Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak. The two sides are discussing "concrete" output levels, with Russia considering an output freeze as an "efficient tool" to rebalance the market. Russia is the world's largest crude exporter outside Opec and has been vague about its participation in Opec's plans for the first output cuts in eight years. The Opec technical committee will meet at the end of October to discuss production cuts, with Russia set to decide its participation after the group's ministerial summit on November 30.

site_title: Eurozone business activity expands at the fastest rate
summary: Eurozone business activity expanded at its fastest rate this year in October, with a composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 53.7, beating forecasts. This growth, along with rising prices, is encouraging for policymakers, but may not necessarily lead to interest rate hikes as inflation remains below the ECB's 2% target. The service industry, particularly, performed better than expected, with a nine-month high in its PMI.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady, buoyed by bank rally; Spain outperforms
summary: European shares ended flat on Monday, buoyed by bank rally and driven by Spain's strong performance after a potential end to a 10-month political deadlock. The STOXX 600 Bank index rose 1.4%, while Spain's IBEX hit a six-month high. Other sectors saw mixed results, with healthcare and mining stocks gaining, while pharma stocks fell. The STOXX 600 healthcare index dropped 0.7%, and Syngenta fell 5.8% after ChemChina missed a deadline on its US$43 billion bid for Syngenta.

site_title: South-east Asia M&A deals set for first increase since 2013
summary: South-east Asia's merger and acquisition (M&A) deals are expected to increase for the first time since 2013, driven by a rise in intraregional deals. The value of M&A deals involving South-east Asian assets rose 49.8% to $44.5 billion in the first three quarters of 2016, with four of the top five deals taking place within the region. This uptick offset a slowdown in transactions with out-of-region entities, and private equity firms are acquiring more than they are selling.

site_title: New York's latest luxury apartment craze: driveways
summary: New York luxury apartment developers are incorporating private driveways into their projects to cater to the elite, driven by concerns of privacy and security. The feature, seen as unique, has gained popularity after the success of Isay Weinfeld's Jardim, which boasts a private driveway running the length of its lot. Similar driveways are being incorporated into other luxury buildings, such as 565 Broome, 1 Great Jones Alley, and Robert AM Stern projects, highlighting the trend's growing acceptance in Manhattan's high-end real estate market.

site_title: US: Stocks higher but Time Warner, AT&T fall
summary: US stocks rose, with the Nasdaq Composite Index climbing 1% to 5,309.83, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.4% and 0.5% respectively. However, shares of Time Warner and AT&T fell after their proposed mega-merger sparked criticism from politicians, despite gains from technology companies.

site_title: China's HNA to buy US$6.5b Hilton stake from Blackstone
summary: China's HNA Group agreed to buy a 25% stake in Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc for approximately $6.5 billion from Blackstone Group LP, easing the hotel company's stock overhang since its 2013 IPO. The deal, expected to be completed in the first quarter, will help both HNA and Hilton accelerate their businesses in China and capture a greater share of international tourism. HNA will appoint two directors to Hilton's board and own a pro-rata stake in Park Hotels & Resorts and Hilton Grand Vacations.

images.alt_text: China's HNA Group, on an acquisition spree in travel-related businesses, agreed to buy about 25 per cent of Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc from Blackstone Group LP for about US$6.5 billion, easing the overhang that has hampered the hotel company's stock since its 2013 initial public offering.

site_title: HPH Trust's Q3 profit falls 18.2%
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a 18.2% drop in Q3 net profit to HK$430.2 million due to weaker intra-Asia trade, Brexit-induced consumer sentiment, and structural changes in the shipping industry. Revenue fell 6.8% to HK$3.27 billion, mainly due to lower container throughput and average revenue per container. The trust expects a soft global trade outlook and remains cautious on cargo volume for 2016, but expects to benefit from mega-vessel deployments at its terminals.

site_title: Egypt sugar imports hit by foreign currency shortage
summary: Egypt is facing a severe sugar shortage due to a foreign currency shortage and rising global prices. The country, which consumes 3 million tonnes of sugar annually, imports 830,000 tonnes, but the dollar shortage is making it difficult for importers to source dollars needed to pay for shipments. As a result, sugar prices have risen 14% in some areas, with a cup of tea now costing 4 pounds, and the government has announced plans to buy sugar and create stockpiles to alleviate the crisis.

site_title: China to allow more local bad debt managers: sources
summary: China's banking regulator plans to allow local governments to set up more asset management companies (AMCs) to manage corporate debt and reduce the growing volume of troubled bank loans. The China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) is relaxing rules to allow multiple AMCs per province and lifting restrictions on how they deal with debt. This move comes as China seeks to manage its worsening debt situation, with non-performing loans reaching a 11-year high of 1.44 trillion yuan. The relaxation of rules aims to follow new policies such as debt-to-equity swaps and increased debt securitization.

site_title: Forging new frontiers (Amended)
summary: The Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) has achieved remarkable success as the oldest not-for-profit private education institute in Singapore, bucking the trend of private education institutions exiting the industry. MDIS has expanded to campuses in Singapore and Uzbekistan, and will move to a full campus in Malaysia in 2017. The institute provides quality education with facilities to help students practice job skills, and has secured internship placements and industry opportunities. MDIS's 'edupreneurial' spirit, which includes entrepreneurial mindsets and practices, has driven its expansion into new territories, including Uzbekistan.

site_title: Overcoming challenges: Building a strong and sustainable fintech sector
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to learn from fintech's challenges and adapt to change, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore setting up a regulatory sandbox to facilitate innovation. Despite growing pains and issues surrounding corporate governance and regulatory requirements, fintech holds great promise for society with benefits including cost-effectiveness, efficiency, and exceptional user experience. While scandals such as those involving Lending Club and bitcoin exchanges highlight vulnerabilities, Singapore's proactive approach and regulatory framework aim to strike a balance between innovation and control.

site_title: Samsung shareholders urged to block scion's board nomination
summary: A South Korean investment advisory firm, Sustinvest Inc, has recommended that Samsung shareholders vote against the nomination of vice-chairman Jay Y Lee to the company's board of directors due to his alleged involvement in "inter-affiliate" transactions. These transactions, common among South Korean conglomerates, are viewed as profiting insiders and undermine corporate value. Despite this, Samsung's biggest shareholder, the National Pension Service, plans to vote for Mr. Lee's directorship. The nomination is scheduled for a shareholders' meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Jack Ma urges China to use online data to fight crime
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma proposed that China's top security bureau use big data to prevent crime, aligning with the country's nascent online surveillance effort. Ma's stance resonates with China's ruling body, which is establishing a system to collect and parse citizen information. Ma's comments highlight the role of technology companies, including Alibaba, in building a system like Minority Report, where an all-knowing state can stop crimes before they occur. China's efforts to expand high-tech surveillance are expanding, with the Communist Party directing a defense contractor to develop software to predict terrorist acts based on citizen behavior.

site_title: Jakarta must signal tax amnesty won't recur: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has urged Indonesia's government to clearly communicate that the country's tax amnesty program is the last chance for taxpayers to rectify their affairs, as penalties will be applied if no action is taken. The program, which has revealed $300 billion in undeclared assets, is well-timed to coincide with the adoption of global rules allowing for the exchange of information to reduce tax evasion. The government has earned $414 billion in revenue from penalties, with 421,037 people and institutions participating in the program.

site_title: Hanjin shares dive on news of European exit
summary: Hanjin, South Korea's largest shipping company, saw its shares plummet 12% after announcing plans to close its European business, fuelling fears of liquidation. The company has applied for court approval to shut down units in over 10 countries, including Germany, and is seeking bankruptcy protection due to a $5.37 billion debt load. This would be the largest bankruptcy in container shipping history, affecting a downturn in global trade and China's slowdown. Hanjin's market value has nearly wiped out 80% in the past year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vibrant Group's subsidiary, Canistel Pte Ltd, has acquired a 30,249 square-metre mixed-use parcel of land in eastern China for 225 million yuan (S$46.2 million). Meanwhile, mainboard-listed Vibrant Group also reported a 95% drop in net profit to S$25.6 million for its first quarter ended Sept 30, down from S$516.5 million a year ago. Other listed companies, including GuocoLand Limited and NTT DC Reit, also reported declines in revenue and profits.

site_title: RMG's Q3 earnings ride on higher patient load
summary: Raffles Medical Group's Q3 earnings rose 4% to S$16.2 million due to higher patient load from its expanding clinic network and contributions from International SOS. Revenue grew 17.5% to S$119.3 million, despite higher staff costs and inventories. Earnings per share increased 2.2% and net asset value per share rose 5.6%. The group maintains a healthy cash position and expects to break even at its new medical centre in Holland Village next year.

site_title: Temasek's Pavilion Energy, Shell bag LNG supply deals
summary: Singapore has awarded exclusive LNG supply franchises to Pavilion Energy and Shell for three years or until they sell one million tonnes of LNG per year. The new deals are seen as a significant win for both companies, given the current supply glut, and offer improved terms with flexible pricing options, including the use of Henry Hub and Singapore Exchange's LNG Index Group. The move aims to benefit Singapore's gas consumers and increase competition in the domestic market.

site_title: The modern GOP is Mr Trump's party, even without him
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump is unlikely to win, with polls indicating a 7% chance of victory. Despite this, many Republicans who endorsed Trump continue to support him, indicating a lack of moral backbone. The article concludes that the modern GOP is Trump's party, with or without him, and that Trumpism is now part of the party's DNA. This will likely lead to an obstructionist and destructive opposition, potentially undermining the governability of the US.

site_title: Changi passenger volume in first 9 months up 6.2%
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore handled 43.5 million passengers in the first 9 months of 2016, a 6.2% increase from the same period in 2015. Cargo shipments rose 5.5% to 1.44 million tonnes, with Indonesia, Malaysia, and China being the top markets for growth. Passenger traffic in September increased 3.7% year on year, driven by growth in top source countries. The airport operator remains optimistic about the outlook for Singapore's air freight industry despite the challenging economic climate.

site_title: BOJ warns against risks in property sector
summary: The Bank of Japan is closely monitoring bank lending to the real estate sector, as excessive credit could lead to overheating and financial instability. Despite not seeing signs of a property bubble, the BOJ is concerned about the high ratio of real estate investment to GDP and banks' willingness to extend loans. Falling office building yields suggest investors have driven prices too high, and the central bank is urging banks to carefully manage risks when extending new loans. The BOJ's capital adequacy ratios are high enough to withstand financial shocks.

site_title: Equation Summit surges 43% on news of investors
summary: Equation Summit's shares surged 43% on Monday after four new investors, including a fund management firm and a veteran Chinese businessman, entered the fray through private placement, raising S$4.2 million. The new investors include Asdew Acquisitions, Teo Khiam Chong, Island Asset Management, and Chen Dawei. The subscription shares, representing 10.5% of the company's enlarged issued share capital, were allotted and issued to the subscribers under the general mandate. The company's innovative digital solutions, including a driver behavior reader and digital lock, were seen as a vote of endorsement for the technology company.

site_title: Singapore's O&M crisis separates the men from the boys
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine firms are struggling with debt due to the impact of cheap oil, forcing them to seek noteholders' forbearance. Companies like AusGroup and KrisEnergy have managed to secure extensions, while others, such as Rickmers Maritime Trust and Swissco Holdings, are facing "growing up" pains. Bondholders are being tested, with some demanding immediate payment, while others are offering concessions in exchange for a more substantial debt-to-equity swap. The crisis is highlighting the importance of transparency and fair treatment of investors in the Singaporean bond market.

site_title: Investors get short end of the stick with long-term US debt
summary: Investors in long-term US bonds are facing a potential downturn due to a crowded trade in longer maturities. The amount of global long-term debt has doubled since 2009 to about $6 trillion, with investors seeking relief from zero-interest-rate policies. However, rising inflation and mixed signals from central banks are raising concerns about higher interest rates, which could lead to significant losses for investors. Duration, a key bond-market metric, has reached historic levels, and a one-percentage point increase in interest rates could equate to $2.1 trillion in losses.

site_title: Working in the digital age: a look ahead for Singapore
summary: Singapore's job market remains resilient despite global economic sluggishness, with a low unemployment rate of 2-3% for citizens and residents. The country is embracing the gig economy and automation, with the Ministry of Manpower launching an online marketplace for tech-focused positions and offering SkillsFuture credits for training programs. Automation and independent work are expected to change the nature of work, with companies adopting flexible work arrangements, co-working spaces, and social tools to foster collaboration and innovation. Singapore's workers are well-positioned to thrive in the digital age, with the country's asset-light, idea-intensive economy and strong global connections.

site_title: Markets tend to misread populism's sway
summary: Global financial markets may underestimate the impact of populism due to a disconnect between the demographics that drive economic growth and those who participate in financial markets. The "left behind" group, characterized by lower-skilled, older, and rural individuals, has lower incomes and limited access to credit. This group's views are often not represented in financial markets, where educated and urban individuals dominate. As a result, markets may be complacent about the populist challenge, despite the growing trend of such movements in the US and Europe.

site_title: Investment managers bullish on India, say fund exodus likely to be temporary
summary: Global investment managers are optimistic about India's economy, citing its high yields, improving public finances, and potential interest rate cuts. Despite a long losing streak for the Indian rupee, foreign investors are expected to return to the country, drawn by its attractive debt offerings and Modi's reforms. Key investors, including Franklin Templeton and Mirae Asset, predict minimal negative impact from a potential US rate hike, with domestic investors increasingly driving the market.

images.alt_text: The Indian rupee's longest losing streak since May masks growing confidence among global investors in Prime Minister Narendra Modi's management of the world's fastest growing major economy.

site_title: A great way to fly direct to San Francisco
summary: Singapore Airlines launched direct flights to San Francisco, marking its return to non-stop services to the US. The inaugural flight SQ32 departed from Changi Airport on October 24, 2016, and took 14 hours and 35 minutes to arrive. The airline now serves San Francisco twice daily, with flights taking between 14-17 hours depending on direction and time of year. This move follows United Airlines' introduction of direct flights from Singapore in June. SIA has also ordered 67 A350s, including the A350 Ultra Long Range variant, to operate non-stop services to New York and Los Angeles.

site_title: Judo master poised to pull off 416b yen IPO for once 'hopeless' railway
summary: JR Kyushu, a Japanese railway company, is set to complete a 416 billion-yen IPO, making it the world's third-largest listing this year. The company, which has a history of losses, has turned profitable through diversification, including real estate and non-rail operations. Chairman Koji Karaike credits his efforts to transform the company, which was once considered "hopeless," and now faces challenges such as a declining population and natural disasters. The IPO is seen as an opportunity for the company to restructure and change its business model.

site_title: Belgian internal feud blocks EU-Canada trade deal
summary: The European Union's hopes for signing a landmark free trade deal with Canada have evaporated as the Belgian federal government failed to win consent from French-speaking regional authorities, specifically the Walloon region. The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) has been seven years in the making and is backed by all 27 other EU member states. The main concerns of the Walloons are related to the threat of surging imports and an independent court system, which critics say allows multinationals to dictate public policy.

images.alt_text: Mr Magnette's stance is seen to be both a matter of principle and opportunism, a chance to boost his reputation and to become leader of the centre-left in Belgium.

site_title: India's Tata Sons dumps Cyrus Mistry as chairman
summary: Tata Sons, India's $100 billion conglomerate, has removed Cyrus Mistry as chairman after nearly four years. The decision comes amid struggles with its steel arm and weak sales of its carmaking business. Ratan Tata, the 78-year-old founder, has taken over as interim chairman until a successor is appointed, likely within four months. Mistry's tenure was marked by rocky performances at several companies, including Tata Motors and Tata Steel, leading to concerns about the group's direction.

site_title: Young S'poreans must work at building future together: PM
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of young Singaporeans working together to build a better future. He noted that despite economic uncertainty, young Singaporeans have more opportunities than their parents, with a system that offers multiple pathways and relevant qualifications. However, finding jobs that utilize their skills is a challenge. Lee urged young Singaporeans to be resilient, adaptable, and team players, and to utilize government support schemes such as SkillsFuture. Ultimately, he believes that Singapore's strength lies in its united people working together to create a better future.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee said young Singaporeans have more opportunities than their parents did in education; there're more university places and also more pathways into the future.

site_title: NUS, Singtel launch S$43 million cybersecurity lab
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean launched the NUS-Singtel Cyber Security Lab, a S$43 million joint research and development lab, to focus on four areas: network security, predictive analytics, IoT, and quantum technology-based systems. The lab aims to increase cybersecurity professionals and train over 120 professionals in the next five years. It will also expand Singtel's cybersecurity offerings and strengthen the Singaporean cybersecurity ecosystem, with potential export opportunities to other markets.

site_title: Opec thinking of self-preservation, not market expansion
summary: OPEC has agreed to reduce oil production by 700,000 barrels per day to stabilize the market, but faces challenges in implementing the plan due to disputes among its 14 members. The group aims to hold production within a range of 32.5-33 million barrels per day to meet projected global demand of 95.42 million barrels per day next year. The agreement comes as the market struggles with weak Asian demand and tepid global economies, with some analysts predicting a possible market tightening in a couple of years. OPEC's focus on self-preservation rather than market expansion may be driven by the need to balance supply and environmental concerns.

site_title: Continuing decline in office and retail rents in Q3: Colliers
summary: Office and retail rents in Singapore declined in Q3, with office rentals falling 1.7% and 2.6% in premium and Grade B areas, respectively. Retail rentals dropped 12.5% quarter-over-quarter, with average monthly gross rents in Orchard Road and regional centers decreasing by 0.9% and 0.8%, respectively. The decline is attributed to oversupply, soft demand, and competition from e-commerce. Landlords are offering incentives and lower rents to fill vacant spaces, with a growing trend of shorter-term leases. A recovery is expected in two to three years, with premium and Grade A office rentals projected to fall 7-12% and ground-level retail rents by 2-3% for the full year.

site_title: STI ekes out gains on sluggish trading
summary: The local stock market rose 0.9% on Monday, driven by gains in banking stocks, with the Straits Times Index finishing at 2,856.68. Singapore's inflation rate stayed in negative territory for the 23rd straight month, but is expected to enter positive territory in the fourth quarter. Traders are closely watching the corporate earnings season this week, which could bring surprises and impact market valuations.

site_title: Major banks mark first cross-border trade using blockchain technology
summary: Australian cotton trader Brighann Cotton Marketing made a shipment of 88 bales of cotton to China from the US using blockchain technology, facilitated by Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Wells Fargo & Co. The $35,000 transaction marked the first cross-border trade between banks using multiple blockchain applications. The use of blockchain technology aims to increase efficiency and reduce costs in trade finance, with the goal of disrupting traditional processes. This milestone is part of a larger effort by the banking industry to harness the benefits of blockchain technology.

site_title: Construction, small and mid-cap stocks expected to benefit
summary: Malaysia's Budget 2017 unveiled on Friday had little impact on the stock market, with construction and small to mid-cap stocks seen as potential beneficiaries. The budget allocated RM3 billion to government-linked investment companies to invest in small and mid-cap companies, and also provided an initial funding of RM75 million for research in smaller firms. However, market trading was largely unaffected, with the benchmark FBMKLCI closing 0.47% up at 1,678 points. Analysts expect the move to be positive for the market, but warned of external headwinds in the coming months.

site_title: BOJ admits its policies have put pressure on banks
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has acknowledged that its aggressive monetary easing policies have put pressure on banks, potentially leading to a lending scramble to make up for declining income. The central bank's Financial System Report warned of risks of excessive risk-taking and a rise in property-market lending. However, the "yield curve control" policy introduced a month ago aims to improve banks' profitability by enabling them to borrow short and lend long. The BOJ report also noted that signs of overheating have not been observed, but there are concerns over the rapidly rising exposure of regional banks to overseas lending and potential systemic risks.

site_title: Plucky Kuznetsova stuns WTA Finals champ Radwanska
summary: Russian tennis player Svetlana Kuznetsova stunned WTA Finals champion Agnieszka Radwanska in a three-set match, prevailing 7-5, 1-6, 7-5. Kuznetsova, the eighth-ranked player, made her WTA Finals debut after winning the Kremlin Cup in Moscow, and pulled off the upset despite being the lowest-ranked player in the field. The match lasted 2 hours and 45 minutes, with Kuznetsova winning 12 of their 16 career meetings against Radwanska.

images.alt_text: Kuznetsova (above) came out with all guns blazing in what was a thrilling first set that lasted 50 minutes, fighting back from 1-4 down to win 7-5 as she took advantage of a number of uncharacteristic mistakes by Radwanska.

site_title: China coking coal futures extend gains on severe supply shortage
summary: China's coking coal futures rose 2.6% to 1,243.5 yuan (S$255.64) a tonne, extending gains, amid a severe supply shortage expected to continue in the coming months. The shortage, fueled by capacity cuts, has driven up prices for steel, with steel demand remaining firm. Analysts predict higher steel prices in the near future. Dalian coke futures surged 3.8% to 1,595.5 yuan a tonne, while iron ore futures gained 3.2% to 454 yuan a tonne.

site_title: Anheuser-Busch acquires DIY brewing company
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev has acquired Northern Brewer, a DIY brewing company, for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition aims to keep up with the evolving beer landscape as consumers shift towards craft beers. Northern Brewer, founded 23 years ago, supplies grains, hops, and equipment for homebrewers, and its acquisition will give InBev another layer of research and development, potentially identifying trends in the craft beer market. The move is seen as a strategic move by InBev to stay relevant in the industry.

site_title: Philips Q3 profit up 47%; misses estimates
summary: Dutch healthcare technology company Philips reported a 47% increase in third-quarter earnings, driven by rising sales and margins. The company's adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, and amortisation (Ebita) grew to €649 million. Sales rose 2% to €5.90 billion, with core "HeathTech" portfolio sales up 5%. However, the connected care division saw margins shrink due to a decline in Western Europe. Despite missing analysts' estimates, CEO Frans van Houten expects further earnings improvements in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Iraq baulks at joining Opec cuts
summary: Iraq is resisting Opec's efforts to cut oil production, citing its ongoing conflict with Islamic militants and the need to boost output to meet the country's energy demands. Iraq claims to produce over 4.7 million barrels a day, exceeding Opec's estimated figure of 4.2 million. The country's Oil Minister, Jabber Al-Luaibi, stated that Iraq should be exempted from output cuts, which has complicated Opec's efforts to reach a deal to stabilize oil markets. Russia is also hesitant to join the cuts, with Energy Minister Alexander Novak saying that the country is reviewing various scenarios to balance the market.

site_title: Understanding what makes millennial entrepreneurs tick
summary: Millennial entrepreneurs are driving innovation and growth globally, starting more businesses, managing more people, and targeting higher profits compared to previous generations. A study by Sage found that millennial entrepreneurs can be grouped into five distinct groups based on their behavioral traits, including ambitious business leaders, ethics and values-driven entrepreneurs, and those prioritizing work-life balance. The study also revealed that millennial entrepreneurs value doing social good, employee happiness, and work-life balance, and are more likely to start multiple businesses and prioritize their personal values over profits.

site_title: US regulators relooking safety rule costs
summary: US regulators are re-examining the safety rule requiring banks to set aside US$6 of capital for every US$100 of assets on their books, citing potential costs and unintended consequences such as higher trading costs and depressed repo market volumes. The rule, introduced last year, has been criticized by Wall Street firms and regulators, who argue that it may be too burdensome for short-term financing. A review of the rule's impact is underway, with potential adjustments on the table, and some regulators are questioning whether the rule's benefits outweigh its costs.

site_title: Finland's millionaire premier freezes pay in bid to save economy
summary: Finland's Prime Minister Juha Sipila has frozen pay for the country's millionaire premier as part of a bid to save the economy. The move aims to address a competitiveness gap of 15% with main trading partners and close a trade deficit. Exports are seen as key to economic success, and workers have agreed to a 0.4% pay rise this year, with no increase in 2017. The government plans to enforce productivity increases, with Sipila aiming for a 5% increase, in a bid to boost exports and drive economic growth.

site_title: Boeing takes on peers, partners for replacement parts, repair business
summary: Boeing aims to more than triple its aftermarket sales to $50 billion over the next 10 years, seeking higher profit margins. The company has added 35,000 parts to its stock, cut prices on 24,000 parts, and expanded training and services. Boeing's efforts are increasing competition with major suppliers, including Honeywell International and United Technologies. Analysts say the company's goal of doubling overall margins to the mid-teens by 2020 relies on its success in the lucrative aftermarket market, where margins can reach 20% or more.

site_title: Philippine president playing with fire
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's four-day visit to China aimed to mend relations with Beijing and seek economic aid, despite his country's long-standing ties with the US. The trip came after Duterte's "separation from the US" statement, which he later backtracked on. China agreed to resume talks on the South China Sea dispute, lift restrictions on Philippine exports, and provide aid for infrastructure development. However, US officials remain skeptical about the effectiveness of the trip, citing concerns about China's intentions and the Philippines' potential shift away from US influence.

site_title: At Tokyo Fashion Week, subcultures take centrestage
summary: Tokyo Fashion Week's spring/summer 2017 showcased a unique blend of entertainment, street culture, and animation, with established and breakthrough labels incorporating musical hook-ups, J-pop, and science fiction into their designs. This fusion of styles drove interest and transformed the event into a style fest. Japanese fashion brands drew inspiration from popular culture, such as singing cats, to create a visually striking and memorable collection. The event highlighted Japan's innovative approach to fashion, where entertainment and style intersect.

site_title: UK factories see stronger investment and exports, patchy orders: CBI
summary: UK manufacturers report stronger investment and exports, with a 15% decline in sterling since the Brexit vote boosting competitiveness. However, skills shortages and rising costs are growing concerns. The CBI's quarterly survey shows business investment intentions rebounding, but factory orders have dropped by 3.5% in the past quarter. The government's plans to restrict EU migration may exacerbate skills shortages, and higher costs may lead to higher consumer prices.

site_title: Creeping higher
summary: Singapore's economy is experiencing a rise in inflation, with the country setting up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. The government is also promoting employment and training for graduates, with Deputy Prime Minister Tan See Leng urging them to stay calm and focusing on better employment rates. Additionally, the government is facilitating trade talks in the US and offering a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses hit by tariffs. The country is also seen as a potential hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Investors snap up offices in key Europe cities ahead of Brexit
summary: Real estate investors are capitalizing on the potential exodus of 70,000 UK finance jobs due to Brexit by buying office space in key European cities. Schroders Plc, CBRE Global Investors, and Standard Life Plc are among those seeking to purchase offices in cities like Frankfurt, Dublin, and Amsterdam. With vacancy rates at historic lows, investors are snapping up partially vacant offices and plots with development potential to meet anticipated demand from banks and financial services companies.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported 3Q16 results with gross revenue rising 21.2% to S$28.0 million, but DPU slipped 13.7% due to a one-off capital distribution and a downward fair value adjustment of S$36.1 million to S$80.7 million for its 51 Alps Avenue property. OCBC Research downgraded CACHE to Hold, citing ongoing uncertainty over the property dispute and clouded earnings visibility.

site_title: Concerted efforts needed to keep IP plans sustainable
summary: The Health Ministry in Singapore has issued recommendations to insurers to keep Integrated Shield (IP) plans sustainable amid rising claims. Insurers face steadily increasing claims ratios and reduced underwriting profit margins, with 2015 underwriting margins dipping to minus 5%. The industry's buffet syndrome, where policyholders over-consume health services, contributes to the problem. The task force recommends a medical fee guideline, preferred healthcare provider panels, and pre-approval systems to mitigate costs. Insurers may reprice riders at higher rates, and policyholders will face higher premiums, particularly for private hospital coverage. A concerted effort is needed from all parties to ensure IP plans remain sustainable.

site_title: Swissco seeks revamp leeway from note and other stakeholders
summary: Swissco Holdings, a Singapore-based marine company, is seeking leeway from note and other stakeholders to address the prolonged crisis in the offshore and marine sector. Chairman Lim How Teck says the company's assets need to be marked to market to reflect current market valuations, which would require noteholders to help shoulder part of the pain. Swissco proposes converting US$65 million of notes to shares, pushing out the notes deadline to the end of 2020, and lowering the coupon rate. The company has defaulted on its last coupon payment and is seeking a standstill from senior lenders until December 2016.

site_title: UK set to back new Heathrow runway in long-awaited airport decision
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to back the expansion of Heathrow Airport, the country's busiest airport, after decades of indecision. A new runway at Heathrow, estimated to cost $17-22 billion, is favored over Gatwick due to its established trade links with emerging markets and the need for a new runway to build trade ties with other European cities. The decision will be subject to public consultation before a vote in parliament in 2017 or 2018, despite opposition from local councils and groups, who argue the project will have negative environmental impacts.

site_title: Yoma spins off its Myanmar tourism businesses in RTO
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings is spinning off its Myanmar tourism businesses, including Balloons over Bagan, Pun Hlaing Lodge, and a parcel of land, to Catalist-listed SHC Capital Asia. The move will create a Singapore-listed Myanmar-focused tourism company, with Yoma retaining a 53.48% stake. SHC will acquire the businesses for S$70.68 million and issue new shares to Yoma and other parties. A dedicated management team, led by Michel Novatin, will oversee the new entity, which aims to unlock value and participate in Myanmar's strong tourism market.

site_title: GK Goh to develop nursing home near Upper Thomson Road
summary: GK Goh Holdings subsidiary Canistel Pte Ltd has won a tender for a land parcel at Venus Drive near Upper Thomson Road, with a bid of S$24.3 million. The company plans to develop a nursing home on the land, aiming to provide differentiated aged care choices in Singapore. The project will be financed through a combination of internal resources and bank borrowings, with a maximum gross floor area of 5,600 square meters.

site_title: MLT maintains Q2 DPU; flags tough leasing environment
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) maintained its Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) at 1.86 Singapore cents despite a challenging leasing environment. The Reit owns industrial properties across Asia, with 10% of leases yet to be renewed and 37% up for renewal in the following two financial years. Rental rate increases were around 2% in Singapore, Hong Kong, and South Korea, while revenue growth came from acquisitions and organic growth, offset by lower revenue in Singapore and Korea.

site_title: Japan's exports fall for 12th straight month in September
summary: Japan's exports fell 6.9% in September from a year earlier, marking a 12th straight month of decline, but shipment volumes rose 4.7% in the year to September, the fastest gain in nearly two years. The yen's 16% gains against the dollar hurt export prices, but rising volumes pointed to a tentative pick-up in global demand. Analysts say net exports contributed to Japan's GDP expansion, and new data showed Japanese manufacturing activity grew at the fastest pace in nine months.

site_title: TD Ameritrade to buy Scottrade in two-step deal with TD Bank
summary: TD Ameritrade is acquiring Scottrade Financial Services for $4 billion in a two-step deal with TD Bank, combining two of the largest US discount brokerages. The deal will create a business with 10 million client accounts and $1 trillion in assets, executing around 600,000 trades per day. TD Ameritrade CEO Tim Hockey expects the deal to be competitive and anticipates annual cost savings of $450 million, with 20% of the combined workforce expected to be reduced. The deal is subject to US regulator approval and is expected to close by September 30.

site_title: GL Limited Q1 profit down 65% at US$11m on weaker UK hotel revenues
summary: GL Limited reported a 65% decline in net profit to US$11 million in Q1, mainly due to weaker UK hotel revenues and a weaker sterling. Revenue fell 15% to US$97.8 million. The company operates hotels, a private gaming club, and receives oil and gas royalties. Despite a cautious outlook, GL plans to refurbish three hotels and expects to launch them in the next year. The group anticipates a negative translation effect from the weak British pound on its financial statements.

site_title: China Auto Electronics to go private at S$0.16 a share
summary: China Auto Electronics, a Singapore-listed automotive electrical and electronics distributor, has announced its intention to go private at S$0.16 per share. The offeror, THB Auto Electronics, has cited low trading liquidity, greater management flexibility, and compliance costs as reasons for the delisting. The offer price represents a premium of 23% over the last traded price and 56.86% over the 12-month volume-weighted average price. The deal is led by executive director Wang Laisheng and other senior managers and retired directors of the company.

site_title: Belgian PM says cannot unblock EU-Canada trade deal for now
summary: Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel has informed European Council President Donald Tusk that the country cannot agree to sign the EU-Canada trade deal, CETA, due to lack of regional authority agreement. The EU had set a Monday deadline for Belgium to overcome opposition from its French-speaking south, or risk cancelling a Thursday summit with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to sign the pact. Michel stated that he had officially told Tusk of the decision, citing the need for regional authorities' agreement.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as M&A activity boosts confidence
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as merger activity boosted investor confidence, with the Dow Jones rising 107.73 points to 18,253.44, the S&P 500 gaining 9.69 points to 2,150.85, and the Nasdaq composite adding 33.87 points to 5,291.27.

site_title: GuocoLand Q1 profit plunges 95% at S$25.6m due to one-offs from a year ago
summary: GuocoLand Limited reported a 95% drop in net profit to S$25.6 million for its first quarter, down from S$516.5 million a year ago. Lower revenue of 54% to S$202.8 million was attributed to the absence of the Shanghai Guoson Centre sale and a lack of one-time gain from the disposal of subsidiaries related to the Dongzhimen project.

site_title: Singapore paves way for evolution of electricity industry
summary: Singapore is laying the groundwork for a more consumer-centric and efficient electricity industry, where households will manage their own demand for power and solar power and batteries will be integrated with the grid. The country plans to introduce smart meters, enabling consumers to track their utility consumption and make informed decisions. A pilot program, Project OptiWatt, aims to reduce peak demand through demand-side management. Additionally, Singapore is seeking feedback on regulatory frameworks for energy storage systems to facilitate the wider deployment of solar power and manage electricity demand better.

images.alt_text: "To facilitate wider deployment of energy storage, it is important to ensure that our policy, regulations and market framework remain current and facilitate new business models put forth by industry." - Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) S Iswaran

site_title: Britain banks to post stronger-than-forecast Q3 results
summary: Britain's major banks are expected to report stronger-than-forecast Q3 results, defying expectations of a squeeze in profits due to the Brexit vote. Consumer spending and labor market conditions have held up, while mortgage and business loan demand has only dropped modestly. Banks will report income little changed from last year, with Barclays expected to report a profit of £1.3 billion and Lloyds expected to contribute £750 million in PPI provisions. The results are seen as a "false period of calm" before the economic climate worsens next year as the UK formally starts the Brexit process.

site_title: Germany stalls Chinese takeover of tech firm Aixtron
summary: Germany's government has withdrawn approval for Chinese firm Grand Chip Investment to acquire Aixtron, a semiconductor supplier, amid growing concerns over Chinese investment in German companies. The decision comes after the government received previously unknown information related to security. The move is part of a broader effort by German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel to shield key EU industries from foreign investors, following a string of Chinese takeovers in Germany, including appliance giant Midea's purchase of robotics firm Kuka. The outcome of the review is uncertain, with shares in Aixtron plummeting nearly 11% after the announcement.

site_title: India's Ola ties up with BMW for luxury cabs segment
summary: Ola, an Indian ride-sharing service, has partnered with BMW to strengthen its luxury mobility segment. The tie-up allows Ola cab operators to buy BMW cars at cheaper credit, receive after-sales support, and guaranteed buyback. BMW-certified instructors will train drivers on auto safety systems and technology. This partnership follows Ola's recent tie-up with Mahindra & Mahindra, and is part of a broader trend of global automakers partnering with ride-sharing companies to stay competitive.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.78 points to 1,677.760 on Monday, closing higher. 1.64 billion lots, valued at RM1.69 billion, were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 407 to 378.

site_title: Offshore yuan weakens to record as PBOC seen tolerating decline
summary: The offshore yuan fell to a record low of 6.7869 per dollar, weakening to its weakest intraday level since 2010, amid a slump in Chinese exports and a dollar advance. The People's Bank of China is seen tolerating the decline, with the onshore yuan also falling in all but one session this month. The yuan's entry into the International Monetary Fund's reserves and the Federal Reserve's expected interest-rate increase have contributed to the decline, with the dollar rising to a seven-month high.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 25.62 points or 0.9% to 2,856.68, with 229 counters up and 153 down. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid global market positivity, despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: British broadcaster ITV to cut 120 jobs over Brexit uncertainty
summary: British broadcaster ITV plans to cut 120 jobs, accounting for 2% of its 6,000-strong workforce, as part of efforts to reduce costs by 25 million pounds due to Brexit uncertainty. The job cuts will be spread across the business, primarily affecting British-based staff. ITV expects a 1% drop in net advertising revenues in the first nine months of 2016, prompting the cost-cutting measures.

site_title: HPH Trust Q3 earnings sink
summary: HPH Trust, a Singapore-based Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, reported a 18.2% decline in net profit to HK$430.2 million in its third quarter, down from the previous year. Revenue also fell 6.8% to HK$3.27 billion. Earnings per unit dropped to 4.94 HK cents from 6.04 HK cents, and no distribution per unit was declared for the quarter. HPH Trust shares ended at S$0.62, 1.6% higher from the previous session.

site_title: Oil halts rally above US$50 as Iraq signals break from Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices halted their rally near $50 a barrel as Iraq threatened to derail Opec's plan to reduce crude output. Iraq's Oil Minister said the country should be exempt from production cuts due to ongoing conflict with Islamic militants. Opec's November meeting aims to implement output cuts, but uncertainty persists, and oil prices may fluctuate near $50.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks follow China market higher amid yuan depreciation concern
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.0% to 23,604.08, following a stronger performance from China's markets. The yuan slipped to 6-year lows but stabilized as state-owned banks sold dollars. Analysts expect a possible US rate hike in December to strengthen the dollar and put pressure on the yuan. Most Hong Kong sectors rose, with energy and financial shares leading the gain. Hong Kong-listed Nanjing Panda Electronics shares fell 16.9% after scrapping a restructuring plan.

site_title: Olam buys independent coffee company Schluter
summary: Olam International has acquired independent Swiss coffee company Schluter for US$7.5 million, expanding its presence in the European specialty coffee market and deepening its origination expertise in East Africa. Schluter's focus on sustainable supply chains aligns with Olam's core purpose of growing responsibly. The acquisition will make Schluter the specialty arm of Olam Coffee in Europe, with the company's managing director Philip Schluter expressing confidence in the combined business's ability to serve customers and partners better.

images.alt_text: Olam International has bought East African coffee specialist, Schluter, at an enterprise value of US$7.5 million.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up, but off highs seen last week
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.1% to 9,319.76 on Monday, but failed to maintain its previous week's highs. The electronics subindex rose 0.5%, led by Hon Hai Precision, while display makers AU Optronics and Innolux also saw gains. The Taiwan dollar softened against the US dollar.
