The lack of clear direction from regional markets contributed to the index's modest gain.

site_title: Samsung Note 7 buyers in South Korea file class-action suit
summary: In South Korea, 527 Samsung Galaxy Note 7 owners are filing a class-action lawsuit against Samsung Electronics Co, seeking compensation for time and effort lost due to the smartphone's recall and scrapping. The lawsuit, filed in Seoul's Central District Court, demands 500,000 won (approximately S$440) per plaintiff for the inconvenience caused. The suit comes after Samsung's global recall in September due to reports of the phone overheating and catching fire, with three owners claiming their devices caught fire.

images.alt_text: The number of Samsung Galaxy Note 7 owners demanding compensation for being inconvenienced by the smartphone's troubles is starting to rise.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Iraq resists joining output cut
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as Iraq resisted joining an OPEC deal to cut production, despite Iran's encouragement of other members to join an output freeze. Brent crude futures dropped 45 cents to $51.33 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 61 cents to $50.23 a barrel. Iraq wants to be exempt from production cuts due to wars since the 1980s, and the country may raise output slightly this month. Analysts believe oil markets are rebalancing, with a small deficit expected in Q3 and Q4, and a significant deficit in 2017.

site_title: Vibrant Group joint venture buys mixed-use land in China
summary: Vibrant Group's subsidiary, Master Development (Jiangyin) Co, Ltd, has acquired a 30,249 square-metre mixed-use land in eastern China's Jiangyin city for 225 million yuan (S$46.2 million). The site will be developed into 508 residential and 148 commercial units. Vibrant Group holds an effective 36% share in Master Development, with investment costs funded internally. The acquisition is part of the group's expansion plans in China.

images.alt_text: A JOINT-VENTURE of logistics solutions provider Vibrant Group's subsidiary has acquired a mixed-use parcel of land with a 70-year lease in eastern China for 225 million yuan (S$46.2 million).

site_title: Indonesia must signal tax amnesty won't be repeated, OECD says
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty program, which revealed almost $300 billion in undeclared assets, is nearing its deadline. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has urged the government to clearly communicate that the program is the last chance for taxpayers to rectify their affairs before facing full penalties. The OECD also emphasized that the Automatic Exchange of Information regime will be used to locate undeclared assets, resulting in significant revenue for the government. With 421,037 participants and $412.3 billion in declared assets, the program is expected to contribute to Indonesia's economic growth.

site_title: Motor racing: Malaysia mulls scrapping Formula One race amid falling ticket sales, viewership
summary: Malaysia is considering halting its annual Formula One Grand Prix race after its contract ends in 2018 due to declining ticket sales and TV viewership. The government and race organisers are set to meet to decide the country's future in hosting the event. Sports Minister Khairy Jamaluddin stated that the costs are too high and returns are limited, citing these factors as reasons for the potential cancellation.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust's Q2 DPU stays flat at 1.86 cents
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's Q2 distributable income to unitholders remained steady at 1.86 Singapore cents, with gross revenue and net property income increasing by 4.7% and 5.3%, respectively. The trust's overall portfolio occupancy rose to 96.4% and rental rates increased by 2% across Singapore, Hong Kong, and South Korea. Despite issuing S$250 million of perpetual securities, unitholders received the same amount after accounting for the increased distribution to perpetual securities holders.

site_title: Europe: Stocks log opening gains
summary: European stocks rose in early trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.4% to 7,049.15 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 also increasing 0.3%. Investors are watching the US interest rate outlook and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Passenger traffic at Changi Airport rose 3.7% to 4.58 million in September
summary: Changi Airport reported a 3.7% increase in passenger traffic to 4.58 million in September. Aircraft movements rose by 3% to 29,330, while cargo shipments increased 7.8% to 167,100 tonnes. The airport's growth is part of Singapore's strong economic performance.

site_title: Euro-area economy gathers momentum as price pressures increase
summary: The euro-area economy showed a significant boost in momentum, with the Purchasing Managers' Index for manufacturing and services rising to 53.7 in October, the fastest pace since 2016. This growth comes despite headwinds such as the UK's Brexit vote and global trade slowdown. The European Central Bank continues to support the economy with stimulus, which will be reviewed in December. This resilient growth suggests that the euro-area economy is becoming more resilient, but the impact of global uncertainty remains a concern.

site_title: Hanjin shares dive on European sale news
summary: Hanjin shares plummeted 13.9% to 1,000 won after the company announced it would close its European business, citing a US$5.37 billion debt load and seeking bankruptcy protection. This would be the largest container shipping bankruptcy in history, amid a six-decade downturn in the industry. The company expects to start the closure process this week after obtaining court approval, with a business revival plan due by November 25.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit manager announces board changes
summary: Starhill Global Reit, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, announced changes to its board, effective November 1. Lead independent non-executive director and chairman of the audit committee Keith Tay Ah Kee, 72, has resigned after reaching the nine-year mark as an independent director. He will be replaced by Hong Hai and Ching Yew Chye, who will join the board as independent non-executive directors and audit committee members. The changes aim to facilitate a progressive renewal of the board, following a code of corporate governance requirement. Starhill last traded at S$0.82.

images.alt_text: STARHILL Global real estate investment trust (Reit), which has a stake in Orchard Road's Wisma Atria and Ngee Ann City, said its Reit manager has made some changes to its board with effect from Nov 1.

site_title: Tax hike for China's high income group 'pure rumour', state media says
summary: China's state news agency Xinhua has denied reports that the government plans to increase income tax for the "high income" population, citing multiple official sources. The reports, which claimed a tax hike for those earning over 120,000 yuan, were deemed "misread" and "pure rumour". Experts from the finance ministry and tax bureau stated that 120,000 yuan is not the standard used to define the high income group and that the government will not increase tax. The denial comes amid criticism from netizens who claim the alleged threshold is set too low.

site_title: NUS, Singtel launch S$43m cybersecurity lab
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) and Singtel have launched a S$43 million cybersecurity lab, aiming to protect individuals, businesses, and public agencies in Singapore from cyber threats. The lab, hosted at NUS School of Computing, will conduct research and develop digital solutions, supporting 100 researchers and training 120 new cybersecurity professionals over five years. The collaboration aims to increase the pool of cybersecurity professionals and prepare them for employment opportunities in various sectors. The launch marks the 10th lab under the Corporate Laboratory@University Scheme.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares edge up ahead of earnings season
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.29% on Monday, recouping earlier losses ahead of Japan Inc's earnings season. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 17,234.42, while the Topix index of all first-section shares rose 0.17%. Investors remain cautious due to uncertainty in the earnings season, despite a rally in other Asian markets.

site_title: Chinese state-owned banks seen selling dollars to shore up yuan
summary: China's yuan exchange rate stabilized after falling to a six-year low, as state-owned banks sold dollars in the domestic foreign exchange market to slow the decline. The yuan has fallen 1.5% since September, driven by a resurgent dollar and concerns about slowing economic growth. The People's Bank of China may have intervened to stabilize the currency around its current level, which is seen as a key support level. The dollar hovered near a nine-month high, boosted by expectations of a US interest rate rise in December.

site_title: Indonesia financial regulator revises down 2016 loan growth outlook
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority (OJK) has revised down its 2016 loan growth outlook to 6-8 per cent, from 7-9 per cent. This is due to slow loan growth of 6.83 per cent in August, the lowest since November 2009. Rising bad loans have led to banks increasing provisions, squeezing profits. Despite this, banks' capital adequacy ratio remains strong at 23 per cent, indicating their ability to absorb risks of losses.

site_title: UK banks fear public, politicians set against them on Brexit
summary: UK banks are facing skepticism from the government and politicians over their warnings about the impact of a hard Brexit, which could lead to job losses and revenue losses. Despite the industry's significant contribution to the economy, bankers are being told that their concerns won't be prioritized in Brexit negotiations. The government has pledged to execute Brexit without special treatment for the financial sector, and some officials have expressed frustration with the industry's lobbying efforts, saying they have failed to appreciate the scale of the government's information-gathering exercise.

site_title: Plane crashes after take-off in Malta, at least five dead
summary: A light aircraft crashed shortly after take-off from Malta on Monday, killing at least five people. The twin-prop Metroliner was heading for Misrata in Libya when it crashed, sending flames and smoke into the sky. All flights to and from Malta International Airport were halted. The victims' identities and nationalities have not been released, but airport officials initially believed the plane was carrying EU border agency Frontex officials. The crash is Malta's worst peacetime air accident.

site_title: Australia: Shares end down as energy firms take hit on lower oil
summary: Australian shares ended down 0.4% at 5,408.5, as energy firms took a hit from falling oil prices. Iraq's refusal to join production cuts led to a 1.5% decline in the energy index, with Santos and Oil Search Ltd down 3% and 2% respectively. Healthcare stocks also fell, with Healthscope and Ramsay Health Care Ltd down 5.9% and 4.6% respectively.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's consumer prices are expected to dip in 2016, with the government projecting a 0.5-1.5% increase in 2017. Meanwhile, two Singapore companies, Ezra Holdings and Rickmers Maritime, are seeking to restructure their debts by asking bondholders to give up some rights. The Singapore government also launched a $43 million cybersecurity lab with NUS and Singtel. In corporate news, Singapore shares rose 0.9% in the local bourse, while the country's pension index improved to grade B.

site_title: Unofficial US-North Korea talks held in Malaysia
summary: A group of former US diplomats held unofficial talks with senior North Korean officials in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, as part of Track 2 diplomatic efforts. The two-day meeting occurred despite the US imposing sanctions on North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. This is the latest in a series of unofficial talks between the two nations, which have not been officially confirmed. The talks are seen as a response to North Korea's severed diplomatic communication channel with the US.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma urges China to use online data to fight crime
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma proposed the use of big data to prevent crime, echoing the Chinese government's effort to collect and analyze citizens' information. Ma stated that policing cannot happen without analyzing citizens' data, and humans can't handle the sheer amount of data amassed, where artificial intelligence comes in. Ma's stance aligns with China's ruling body's establishment of a system to collect and parse information on citizens, with minimal privacy safeguards.

images.alt_text: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma proposed that the nation's top security bureau use big data to prevent crime, endorsing the country's nascent effort to build unparalleled online surveillance of its billion-plus people.

site_title: NParks awards design consultancy services for Jurong Lake Gardens Central and East
summary: The National Parks Board (NParks) has awarded design consultancy services for Jurong Lake Gardens (JLG) Central and East to a team comprising Liu & Wo Architects Pte Ltd, Landscape Design Inc., and SALD Pte Ltd. The 90-hectare national gardens will be developed in three phases, with JLG Central and East set to be completed from 2020 onwards. Six firms were shortlisted from 31 submissions, following an Expression of Interest call from March 7 to May 4, 2016.

site_title: China to allow more local bad debt managers: sources
summary: China's banking regulator is allowing local governments to set up more asset management companies (AMCs) to manage corporate debt and reduce troubled bank loans. The China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) is relaxing rules that previously limited one AMC per province, enabling local asset managers to sell non-performing assets to other companies. This move is part of China's efforts to manage its worsening debt situation, which has seen a significant increase in non-performing loans. The move aims to help the economy by reducing the risk of debt defaults.

images.alt_text: China's banking regulator plans to allow local governments to set up more asset management companies (AMCs) as part of a broader effort to manage corporate debt and reduce the growing volume of troubled bank loans that pose a risk to the economy.

site_title: South Korea's Park opens door to future two-term presidencies
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye announced plans to reform the country's constitution, potentially allowing future presidents to serve two terms. The current limit of one five-year term was set in 1987 to prevent authoritarian rule, but critics argue it has rendered the presidency unstable. Park called the constitution outdated and said a government committee should be formed to push for a revision before her term ends in 2018. The proposal marks a shift from her previous stance against constitutional reform, and her office clarified that she would not run for a second term.

site_title: Consumer prices projected to dip in 2016: MAS, MTI
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rate stayed in negative territory for the 23rd straight month in September, coming in at -0.2% year-on-year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) expect headline inflation to dip to around -0.5% in 2016 and 0.5-1.5% in 2017. Core inflation is expected to average around 1% in 2016 and rise to 1-2% in 2017. The government attributes the muted cost pressures to a pullback in hiring and easing of non-labour business costs.

images.alt_text: The Singapore government expects headline inflation to come in "around -0.5 per cent" in 2016, and for this to pick up to 0.5 to 1.5 per cent in 2017.

site_title: BOJ frets about real estate lending boom, watchful of bubble risk
summary: The Bank of Japan is monitoring bank lending to the real estate sector, citing concerns about excessive credit and the risk of overheating. Although the BOJ doesn't currently see a property bubble, it's wary of high real estate investment ratios and falling office building yields. Commercial bank lending has been rising, with property development benefiting from increased lending. The BOJ assures that banks' capital adequacy ratios are high enough to withstand financial shocks, but urges them to carefully manage risks when extending new loans.

site_title: Australian, NZ dollars lose ground on Fed rate bets
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced losses on Monday due to growing expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate hike by year-end. The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7598, while the New Zealand dollar dropped 0.25% to US$0.7145. Investors are awaiting the consumer price report to gauge underlying inflation and its impact on interest rates. A strong inflation reading could support the Australian dollar, while a weak reading could lead to a November rate cut.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.29% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 2,839.28. Trading volume was 76 million shares worth S$55.3 million. Gainers outpaced losers 91 to 32, indicating a positive market sentiment. The rally comes ahead of upcoming quarterly earnings releases and GDP data.

site_title: Dollar up on US rate hike talk, but Asian markets edgy
summary: The US dollar rose in Asia on Monday, driven by increased bets on a Federal Reserve interest rate hike by the end of the year. The dollar reached 104 yen, while the pound fell below $1.22 and the euro suffered losses. Markets are also watching the corporate earnings season and the upcoming US presidential election, with dealers warning of an equity rout if Donald Trump wins. The dollar's gains were seen as a positive sign for the greenback, which has been driven by the US economy's recovery and the Fed's signals of a rate hike in December.

site_title: Hot stock: Equation Summit shares leap on news of placement to new investors
summary: Equation Summit's shares surged 43% in Monday morning trading after the company announced a private placement to raise S$4.2 million, with 600 million new shares to be issued to four new investors, including a fund management firm and a Chinese businessman. The shares reached the top volumes chart with an active trade of 81.93 million shares. The new investors include Asdew Acquisitions Private Limited, Teo Khiam Chong, Island Asset Management Pte Ltd, and Chen Dawei.

site_title: US banks add pieces to new instant payments network
summary: US banks are launching the Zelle instant payments network, which will allow customers to send and receive money using a uniform procedure across multiple banks. By the end of December, some US bank customers may notice Zelle features on their mobile apps, and about 20 banks will offer the Zelle app next year. The goal is to bring over 100 million customers into the network without disrupting existing payment methods. This move aims to create a widespread alternative to cash and checks, following the success of technology company Venmo.

site_title: South Korea president says time to discuss amending constitution
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye announced the need to amend the country's constitution to change the single-term presidency, citing difficulties in policy continuity and unified foreign policy. The president requested the establishment of a special committee to discuss the amendment, which would be the first since 1987. Her term is set to end in 2017, allowing for the proposed change before her departure.

site_title: Singapore inches up in Global Pension Index
summary: Singapore has improved its ranking in the Melbourne Mercer Global Pension Index, moving up to grade B from C+. The country's pension adequacy score increased due to government support for the poor and higher pension assets and labor force participation at older ages. Denmark remains in the top spot with an A- grade, indicating a robust and sustainable retirement income system. This improvement is expected to enhance Singapore's pension system and provide better benefits for its citizens.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE has inched up in the Melbourne Mercer Global Pension Index (MMGPI), with its score improving to grade B from C+ mainly driven by an improvement in pension adequacy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, falling 0.28% to 23,309.39, as traders returned from an extended weekend amid a tepid lead from Wall Street. In contrast, Shanghai's benchmark composite index edged up 1.11 points to 3,092.05, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.52 points to 2,053.08. This marked the beginning of the corporate earnings season, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.810 points to 1668.770. Volume was 36.49 million lots worth RM12.10 million, with 82 gainers outnumbering 56 losers. The market reaction was attributed to no major news, with investors seemingly unaffected by recent market fluctuations.

site_title: SMRT completes project works along NSL, EWL earlier, to resume regular Sunday services
summary: SMRT Corp has completed its renewal projects on the North-South and East-West Lines seven weeks ahead of schedule, allowing for the resumption of regular Sunday services. Since June 2016, services had started an hour later due to ongoing work. Over 20 weeks, SMRT's engineering staff replaced 2,300 sleepers and 3.2 kilometers of track, enabling the shortened 6-month project timeline to be completed in 22 Sundays. This will allow for an extra work hour on Sundays for track maintenance and renewal.

images.alt_text: SMRT Corp said that its engineering staff have made "good progress" on the various on-going renewal projects along the North-South (NSL) and East-West Lines (EWL), enabling the train operator to resume regular services seven weeks ahead of schedule.

site_title: Companies urged to use multiple vendors in wake of cyber attack
summary: A complex cyber attack on Friday's DNS provider Dyn, taking down major websites including Twitter and Paypal, has urged companies to use multiple vendors for DNS services. Experts say using multiple DNS providers can reduce the risk of such attacks, but may complicate traffic management. The attack, which involved flooded traffic from connected devices, highlights the need for internet security measures and calls for governments to mandate security standards. Companies are advised to implement diversity geographically and architecturally for defense against DNS attacks.

site_title: Najib chases 'ultimate' win as party faithful get budget goodies
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has allocated more funds to his coalition's loyal voters, including the poorest 40% of Malaysians, to limit potential damage from the country's political turmoil. The budget includes bonuses for civil servants, extra assistance for farmers, and improved infrastructure in rural regions. Najib seeks to balance a slowing economy with keeping voters happy ahead of a potential early election, which could come as soon as March.

site_title: Top US diplomat to meet Philippine foreign minister amid 'separation' issue
summary: US Assistant Secretary of State Daniel Russel arrived in the Philippines to meet with Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay amid confusion over the status of ties between the two countries. The visit comes as President Rodrigo Duterte said the US is the Philippines' "closest friend", despite earlier announcing a "separation" from the US and realignment with China. The US seeks clarification on the alliance's direction, while the Philippine official believes the US is getting mixed signals from Manila, requesting a meeting to discuss bilateral relations.

site_title: Samsung shareholders advised to block Jay Y Lee's nomination
summary: South Korean investment advisory firm Sustinvest Inc has recommended that Samsung shareholders vote against the nomination of vice chairman Jay Y Lee to the company's board of directors due to his involvement in "inter-affiliate" transactions. These transactions, common among South Korea's conglomerates, are viewed as profiting insiders and have come under increasing scrutiny. The recommendation is the first opposition to Lee's ascension as the heir-apparent of Samsung Electronics Co.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit near 1-month low as crude prices dip
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% on Monday, hitting a near one-month low, as energy stocks declined due to a drop in oil prices. Iraq's decision to exempt itself from a production cut by OPEC led to a decline in oil majors, with Santos Ltd and Oil Search Ltd dropping 2.6% and 1.6%, respectively. Financials also fell, with the 'Big Four' banks posting losses, and the central bank's next meeting on November 1 may lead to a possible interest rate cut.

site_title: Asia: Stocks subdued, US dollar hovers near 9-month high
summary: Asian stocks were subdued on Monday, following a sluggish performance on Wall Street, while the US dollar hovered near a nine-month high due to comments from a Federal Reserve official boosting rate hike bets. The US dollar index remained steady at 98.657, near its highest since February. Global markets await a slew of data, including consumer prices and corporate earnings, this week.

site_title: ASL Marine seeks to issue shares as Singapore bond strains mount
summary: ASL Marine Holdings Ltd. is seeking to raise S$25 million through a rights issue to repay Singapore dollar notes due in March 2017, amid mounting stresses in the local bond market. The company's S$100 million bonds have slumped to 70 cents, the lowest since 2013. ASL Marine has S$21.6 million in cash and S$592.2 million in total debt, and its managing director believes bankers will support the company's request for additional loans. The move comes as more firms in Singapore's shipping and oil and gas industries struggle to meet debt obligations amid weakening economic growth.

site_title: British banker pleads 'not guilty' to Hong Kong murders
summary: A British banker, Rurik Jutting, 31, pleaded "not guilty" to two murder charges in Hong Kong's High Court, marking the city's biggest murder case in years. Jutting, a former Bank of America Merrill Lynch employee, faces a three-week jury trial and could face life in prison if convicted. The killings of Indonesian women, Seneng Mujiasih and Sumarti Ningsih, shocked the city in 2014 and raised questions about the seedy underbelly of Hong Kong's financial hub. Jutting had pleaded guilty to a third charge of preventing the burial of a body.

site_title: Pavilion Energy and Shell appointed as new LNG importers for Singapore (Amended)
summary: Pavilion Energy and Shell have been appointed as new LNG importers for Singapore, supplying power plants and industries with liquefied natural gas. The two companies were chosen for their reliability, flexibility, and competitive pricing. They will receive an exclusive franchise of three years, or until they sell one million tonne of LNG, whichever comes first. This appointment is expected to boost Pavilion Energy's cashflow and diversify Sembcorp Industries' power generation business.

site_title: Raffles Medical posts 4% rise in Q3 net profit
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 4% increase in Q3 net profit to S$16.2 million, driven by higher patient load and revenue from its acquired International SOS business. Revenue rose 17.5% to S$119.3 million, but staff costs jumped 23% to S$61.4 million due to expanded operations. Despite a weaker economic outlook, the company expects to remain profitable for the rest of the year.

site_title: Mobius says gold to gain in 2017 as Fed goes slow on rate hikes
summary: Templeton Emerging Markets Group predicts gold will advance by 15% by the end of 2017 due to the Federal Reserve's slow pace on interest rate hikes and a subdued US dollar. This, combined with increased central bank buying of bullion, is expected to boost demand. Gold has already rallied 19% in 2016, driven by concerns over the global economy and monetary policies. The US dollar's strength is also expected to decline, making gold more expensive.

site_title: Singapore joins IEA as association country
summary: Singapore has joined the International Energy Agency (IEA) as an association country, allowing it to participate in global energy dialogue and keep abreast of new technical developments. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran announced the move, stating it's a natural extension of Singapore's close collaboration with the IEA. The country will partner IEA on two new initiatives, including a regional training hub and an annual forum at the Singapore International Energy Week. This brings Singapore's list of IEA association countries to include China, Thailand, and Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore issuers hit back at creditors
summary: Singapore issuers Ezra Holdings and Rickmers Maritime are asking bondholders to waive potential covenant breaches and events of default as they look to stave off immediate repayment demands. The companies launched consent solicitations, requesting investors to approve restructuring plans. In an unusual request, Rickmers specifically asked noteholders to revoke instructions for immediate repayment, allowing the companies to restructure and avoid immediate repayment. This move aims to give the companies time to restructure their debt and avoid potential financial distress.

images.alt_text: Ezra Holdings and Rickmers Maritime, two companies in Singapore's depressed oil services industry, are asking bondholders to give up some of their rights as they look to stave off demands for immediate repayment.

site_title: Japan Sept exports fall 6.9% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports fell 6.9% in September from a year earlier, marking the 12th consecutive month of decline, according to Ministry of Finance data. The result was lower than the median forecast of a 10.4% drop. Meanwhile, imports fell 16.3%, exceeding the estimated 16.6% drop. These declines indicate sluggish external demand and follow a 9.6% decline in August.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma, Raffles Medical, City Developments Limited, Frasers Centrepoint Trust
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, Raffles Medical Group, City Developments Limited, and Frasers Centrepoint Trust are stocks to watch. Yoma is spinning off its tourism business as part of a reverse takeover. Raffles Medical reported a 4% increase in net profit and 17.5% increase in revenue. City Developments Limited successfully raised S$977.6 million by unlocking the value of its Nouvel 18 condo. Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported a mixed quarterly report, with a 1.5% decline in distribution per unit but a record-high full-year DPU.

site_title: Unaffordable Aussie housing in government sights, says Treasuer Morrison
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison has urged state governments to simplify residential land planning regulations to address unaffordable housing in major cities. Insufficient land releases and complex development regulations are key issues. Morrison plans to discuss this with state counterparts in a December meeting. The issue will be a focus of Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government, aiming to increase housing supply and make homes more affordable.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.13% higher on Monday, driven by a slight increase in the US dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 17,207.01 and the Topix index gained 0.09% to 1,366.51. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Euro near seven-month low versus US dollar on policy divergence bet
summary: The euro remains near a seven-month low against the US dollar due to speculation that the European Central Bank will maintain its easy monetary policy, despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike this year. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that tapering and bond-buying plan discussions were not on the agenda at the last policy meeting. Speculators have increased bearish bets on the euro, with a fifth consecutive day of losses expected, marking the longest losing streak since May.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up on institutional buying; won down
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.3% to 2,039.90, driven by institutional buying, mainly from market heavyweights. Institutions purchased 68.3 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while offshore investors bought 18.8 billion won. The won fell 0.1% to 1,136.5 due to a stronger dollar. Analysts expect the market to be stable until major global events are resolved, with little chance of continued upward movement unless positive forecasts on fourth-quarter earnings emerge. Tech firms LG Electronics and Posco rose nearly 2%.

site_title: Microsoft to increase UK prices of enterprise products, citing falling pound
summary: Microsoft to increase UK prices of enterprise products by 13% for software and 22% for cloud services, starting January 1, 2017, due to the pound's 13% decline against the US dollar following the UK's Brexit vote. This move aims to offset the higher cost of imported goods. The price increase applies only to enterprise products and services, not consumer software or cloud services.

site_title: Clinton looks to consolidate lead over Trump
summary: Hillary Clinton is narrowing the gap in the presidential election, leading Donald Trump 50% to 38% among likely voters, according to a national ABC News poll. Clinton is seeking to consolidate her lead in key battleground states, including Florida, North Carolina, and Texas. The Democratic candidate is focusing on minority voters, particularly African-Americans, and has accused Trump of ignoring their struggles. Clinton's momentum is driving her to push ahead in the battle for control of Congress, with her husband Bill Clinton and Michelle Obama set to join her on the campaign trail.

images.alt_text: With just over two weeks to go before Americans vote for a new president, Hillary Clinton - who has widened her lead over Donald Trump - is stepping up her efforts in key battleground states to consolidate her lead.

site_title: 'Real-life Cinderella' film delves into plight of Hong Kong maids
summary: A new documentary, "Sunday Beauty Queen," shines a light on the lives of Hong Kong's domestic workers, challenging stereotypes about their experiences. The 94-minute film follows five Filipino maids as they prepare for the annual Miss Philippines Tourism Hong Kong pageant, revealing their exhausting daily routines, relationships with employers, and struggles with exploitation and mistreatment. Despite facing anti-migrant sentiment, the documentary highlights the contributions of foreign domestic workers and their efforts to find happiness and purpose in their work.

images.alt_text: Cyril Goliava cut an elegant figure in her yellow evening gown as she won a beauty pageant in Hong Kong, smiling to cheers from the crowd as she was presented with a tiara and trophy.

site_title: German momentum grows for curbs on Chinese overseas investment
summary: Germany is pushing for EU measures to give national governments more control over foreign investment in European companies, particularly from China, following the recent acquisition of German robot maker Kuka AG by China's Midea Group Co. Chancellor Angela Merkel's deputy, Sigmar Gabriel, is seeking expanded powers to block or impose conditions on non-EU shareholdings, amid growing resistance to unfettered Chinese investment. This proposal has gained support from EU Digital Economy Commissioner Guenther Oettinger, and is seen as a sign of a growing protectionist reaction to China's appetite for overseas acquisitions.

site_title: Clinton thinks regulators should scrutinise AT&T-Time Warner deal
summary: Hillary Clinton's spokesman stated that she thinks US regulators should scrutinize AT&T's acquisition of Time Warner closely, citing "a number of questions and concerns" about the deal. However, no conclusions should be reached until more information is available. Clinton's position reflects her concern over the potential impact of the deal on media diversity and competition.

site_title: Yoma to spin off tourism related business in reverse takeover with SHC
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings Ltd announced a spin-off of its tourism-related business as part of a reverse takeover of SHC Capital Asia Limited. The move will create the first Singapore-listed Myanmar-focused tourism company. Yoma's wholly owned unit Yoma Strategic Investments Ltd will issue 167 million SHC shares valued at S$43.94 million, giving it a 53.48% stake in SHC. The spin-off includes businesses such as Balloons over Bagan and Pun Hlaing Lodge, and is expected to unlock better value for Yoma shareholders in the long run, according to executive chairman Serge Pun.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping to wind down Europe business as demand slumps
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, South Korea's largest container line, will wind down its European business due to slumping demand on the Asia-Europe trade lane. The company will close its 10 European branches, including its German regional headquarters. Hanjin is also selling its Asia-US network and a terminal in Long Beach, California, as part of its bankruptcy process. The company expects to start winding down its European business as early as this week, following court approval. Hanjin's shares fell 14% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Hanjin Shipping Co, South Korea's largest container line that has already put its Asia-US business on sale after filing for bankruptcy protection late August, will wind down its European business as demand for its services on the Asia-Europe trade lane slumped.

site_title: Singapore to launch smart meter trial for electricity, water and gas
summary: Singapore is launching a smart meter trial for electricity, water, and gas to help consumers efficiently manage their consumption. The trial, involving the Energy Market Authority, Singapore Power, and the national water agency, aims to develop technical solutions for remotely reading meters and a mobile app to provide real-time consumption data. The trial's results will inform the government's plans to deploy advanced metering solutions nationwide, with the goal of introducing full retail competition in the electricity market by 2018.

images.alt_text: The Singapore government is studying a wider deployment of smart meters for electricity, gas and water supply.

site_title: Oil holds above US$50 as Iraq signals break from Opec output plan
summary: Oil prices held above $50 as Iraq threatened to derail Opec's output plan. Iraq's Oil Minister, Jabber Al-Luaibi, said the country should be exempt from planned cuts due to the ongoing conflict with Islamic militants. This move comes as Opec agreed to its first output reductions in eight years last month. US rigs targeting crude rose for an eighth week, indicating increased production. Oil prices dropped 0.4% despite the Opec plan, as investors remain cautious due to bearish market outlooks.

site_title: Equation Summit to place out 600m shares for S$4.2m
summary: Equation Summit Limited has entered into a subscription agreement to issue 600 million new shares for S$4.2 million, representing 10.5% of the enlarged issued share capital. The shares will be allotted and issued to four subscribers: Asdew Acquisitions Private Limited, Teo Khiam Chong, Island Asset Management Pte Ltd, and Chen Dawei. The subscription is for financial investment purposes and will be approved by a shareholders' resolution at an annual general meeting on October 28.

site_title: Outlook dims for Singapore Inc as economy moonwalks
summary: Singapore's economy is facing a prolonged period of low growth, darkening the outlook for the city-state's deeply indebted firms. Companies are cutting costs and slashing marketing budgets due to declining orders, fixed overheads, and a rise in bad debts. Earnings forecasts for Singapore-listed companies are falling at an average of 4% over the past three months, with projections for next year's net income down 4% from the previous quarter. The economy, which was previously seen as resilient, is showing signs of a recession, with a 4.1% contraction in the third quarter and a decline in consumer confidence.

site_title: Hanoi hopes to raise billions by selling stakes in brewers
summary: Hanoi's government plans to sell stakes in state-owned brewers, Hanoi Beer Alcohol and Beverage Joint Stock Corp (Habeco) and Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp (Sabeco), to raise up to $2.2 billion. The divestments are part of long-promised reforms to privatize bloated state firms, aiming to meet Vietnam's ambitious economic targets and boost growth. The sale comes as the country's public debt hits 62% of GDP, and foreign brewers are eager to tap Vietnam's growing beer market, where consumption exceeds 3 billion liters annually.

site_title: China Oceanwide agrees to buy Genworth for US$2.7b in cash
summary: China Oceanwide Holdings Group Co has agreed to buy Genworth Financial Inc. for US$2.7 billion in cash. Genworth will remain a standalone subsidiary with its own management team, led from Richmond, Virginia. China Oceanwide will also provide US$1.125 billion in debt assistance to help Genworth address maturing debt and strengthen its life insurance businesses. The deal will be completed through a China Oceanwide investment platform, with shareholders receiving US$5.43 per share.

site_title: Chinese money flowing to Hong Kong stocks has suddenly dried up
summary: Chinese investors have significantly slowed their buying of Hong Kong stocks, with net purchases dropping to just 7% of the previous month's $8 billion, according to Bloomberg data. The slowdown, which began after the National Day celebrations in October, has raised concerns about the impact on Hong Kong's stock market, which has been boosted by Chinese capital in the past. Analysts attribute the decline to valuation concerns and the impending Federal Reserve rate hike, with some speculating that mainland investors are seeking alternative assets due to the weakening yuan.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's stock market is suffering from a post-holiday hangover.

site_title: Moscow confirms ministry website attack after US hacker claim
summary: Russia's foreign ministry confirmed an old version of its website was attacked after a US hacker claimed to have posted a mocking message, targeting a site not used for a long time. The attack came after the US accused Russia of hacking into the 2016 White House race, a claim Russia has repeatedly dismissed. The ministry's main website was working normally on Sunday. The US hacker, known as the Jester, claimed the attack was meant to show the US elections' effect on people, while Russia's Maria Zakharova suggested it could be a sign of a "cyber machine of destruction."

images.alt_text: Russia's foreign ministry on Sunday said an old version of its website had been attacked after a US hacker claimed he broke in and posted a mocking message.

site_title: Elderly make up nearly a third of Japan's new entrepreneurs
summary: Japan's entrepreneurial spirit is fading, with the elderly making up nearly a third of new entrepreneurs, according to 2012 data from the Small and Medium Enterprise Agency. This marks a significant increase from 8% three decades earlier. Elderly entrepreneurs tend to provide management consulting and other services, leveraging their professional experience. However, the total number of small and medium-sized enterprises in Japan has fallen steadily in recent years, and younger people are less inclined to start their own businesses due to a fear of risk, with 36% of new entrepreneurs in 2012 being in their 30s or younger.

site_title: Brexit risks 'constitutional crisis' between UK's nations
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May risks a "constitutional crisis" if she doesn't involve Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland in Brexit talks, according to the Institute for Government. The report warns that a lack of cooperation could lead to a breakdown in the UK's governance structure. Experts say that the stakes are high, and a failure to reach consensus could result in a crisis. The UK's economy has already suffered, with a second consecutive month of shrinkage, adding to the pressure on May to find a solution.

site_title: AT&T-Time Warner deal sparks calls for scrutiny in Washington
summary: AT&T's proposed $85 billion takeover of Time Warner Inc has sparked skepticism in Washington, with both Democrats and Republicans expressing concerns about the deal's impact on anti-trust and regulatory enforcement. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Donald Trump have weighed in, with Trump saying he would block the takeover. The deal, announced just before the November 8 US election, has raised questions about the creation of a new telecommunications and media giant. Regulators are likely to closely scrutinize the effort.

images.alt_text: AT&T Inc's proposed US$85 billion takeover of Time Warner Inc generated skepticism among both Democrats and Republicans on Sunday, making it more likely that regulators will closely scrutinise the effort to create a new telecommunications and media giant.

site_title: Berkshire Partners nears deal to acquire Masergy
summary: Berkshire Partners is nearing a deal to acquire cloud networking firm Masergy for over $900 million, including debt. The acquisition would be a significant move for Masergy, which helps big corporations manage global network transmissions. The company, which competes with major telecom providers, has previously been owned by Abry Partners, which acquired it in 2011. A deal could be announced as soon as this week, with Masergy assisting customers like Amgen and Tesla with cloud communications and security services.

site_title: China steel mills defy capacity cutbacks
summary: China's steel mills are defying capacity cutbacks, producing more steel despite Beijing's efforts to curb emissions. For the past seven months, steel output has risen year-on-year, contradicting government efforts to reduce excess capacity. Environmental checks have increased, but the industry is not becoming leaner. This raises concerns about the effectiveness of China's environmental policies and the country's ability to meet its emissions targets.

site_title: Gold ends higher for the week on seasonal Asian demand
summary: Gold prices rose for the week, driven by seasonal demand from Asia, particularly China, India, and exchange-traded funds. Despite a strong dollar limiting gains, the precious metal saw its first weekly rise in four. Demand from Asia helped prop up prices, with Asian demand expected to continue through the end of the year.

site_title: Markets may be under-estimating impact of Fed tightening
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to raise short-term interest rates several times in the coming year, according to Charles Dallara, a leading financial industry figure. Markets may underestimate this impact, which could lead to market turbulence. Dallara warns of the risk of inflation reigniting, particularly in the US and Britain, and notes that unconventional monetary policy has created distortions in global financial markets. He also expresses concern over the growing debt in emerging markets and the potential for structural costs in the EU and UK due to Brexit.

site_title: Ireland may be isolated by renewed EU push for common tax base
summary: Ireland may face another tax battle with the EU as the European Commission proposes a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) on October 25. The move comes less than two months after the EU ordered Ireland to claw back 13 billion euros from Apple Inc. over tax irregularities. The CCCTB aims to create a unified tax base across the EU, potentially isolating Ireland from its European counterparts.

site_title: Clinton makes pitch in Ohio for wavering Trump fans
summary: Hillary Clinton is making a direct appeal to wavering Donald Trump supporters in Ohio, aiming to win over undecided voters. Clinton said she wants to answer questions and earn their vote, as polls show her expanding her lead nationally and in battleground states. Trump continues to face fallout from lewd comments and allegations of groping women. Clinton emphasized the importance of supporting American democracy, contrasting it with countries where opponents are jailed or executed. Her campaign has registered voters and pushed for early voting in Ohio, where Clinton is focusing her efforts.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton is making a direct appeal to voters who may be reconsidering their support of Republican Donald Trump after his tumultuous few weeks in the presidential race, saying she wants to assuage voters who are still wary about backing her instead.

site_title: Effects of US presidential elections, rate hike on gold
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's victory is seen as a bullish driver for gold, traditionally viewed as a safe-haven asset in times of uncertainty. Trump's campaign promises to reform the US establishment and challenge the status quo may lead to market volatility, while Hillary Clinton's likely win, seen as a continuation of the status quo, may result in uneventful gold prices. As a result, gold prices may experience a boost due to Trump's uncertainty-driven campaign.

site_title: Iraq balks at joining Opec cuts, making oil output deal harder
summary: Iraq has balked at joining Opec's output cuts, citing its ongoing war with Islamic militants and a need to boost production. The country currently produces over 4.7 million barrels a day, and its output could rise further. Iraq disputes Opec's figures that peg its output at less than 4.2 million barrels daily. The country's Oil Minister, Jabber Al-Luaibi, stated that Iraq should be exempt from cuts, and the group aims to decide on individual levels when it meets on November 30. Opec's efforts to trim output are being hindered by other producers, including Russia, which is also seeking to ramp up output.

site_title: French foreign minister calls for end to Aleppo 'massacre'
summary: French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault urged the international community to end the "massacre" in Aleppo, Syria, following a 72-hour truce. He called for a UN Security Council resolution condemning the use of chemical weapons and sanctions against perpetrators. Ayrault stated that 500 people have been killed in Aleppo since the regime's operation to recapture eastern Aleppo, and food rations will run out by the end of the month. The French minister also expressed concern about the humanitarian crisis and the need to provide aid to the population.

site_title: Iraq forces press Mosul assault, hunt Kirkuk attackers
summary: Iraqi forces have intensified their assault on Mosul, pushing deeper into the city with the help of Kurdish peshmerga forces. Despite Islamic State (IS) attacks on other cities, including Kirkuk and Rutba, the Mosul operation remains on track, with tens of thousands of fighters engaged in the battle. US officials estimate that 3,000-5,000 IS fighters are defending Mosul, and aid groups fear a large-scale displacement of civilians if the city falls. The assault aims to reclaim the last major Iraqi city under IS control, dealing a significant blow to the group's self-declared "caliphate."

site_title: Japan faces delicate diplomatic balancing act as Duterte visits
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to visit Japan on Tuesday, amid speculation over how Japan can balance its ties with Manila and Washington in the face of China's growing influence in the South China Sea. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will offer $48 million in loans to aid agricultural development in Mindanao, while the Philippines is expected to receive $24 billion in investments from China. Japan will likely stress its role as a stable partner in East Asia, while refraining from criticizing Duterte's controversial policies. The visit aims to ease strained relations between Manila and Washington and counterbalance China's influence.

site_title: This startup wants to make free wi-fi work for businesses
summary: Nimbus & Co, a Singaporean startup, aims to help businesses monetize their free Wi-Fi hotspots through its core offering, Nimbus Social. By applying analytics to existing Wi-Fi infrastructure, Nimbus Social helps businesses understand customer behavior and create targeted digital marketing campaigns. The startup provides a holistic solution, addressing issues of social engagement, digital footprint, and poorly optimized social media accounts. Nimbus has already worked with clients such as J.CO Donuts and Katrina Group restaurants, and plans to expand to Indonesia and Malaysia.

site_title: Sales fall as baby boomers start to age out of sports cars
summary: Baby boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, are aging out of sports cars, leading to declining sales. Ford's Mustang plant idled for a week as sales fell 9% for the year, with other sports cars, such as the Corvette and Porsche models, also experiencing similar declines. This shift is attributed to boomers' increasing comfort needs and a generational handoff to younger buyers, who are less likely to afford high-end sports cars.

site_title: Belgium given Monday deadline to back Canada trade deal
summary: The European Union has set a Monday deadline for Belgium to overcome opposition to a free trade deal with Canada. If Belgium fails to meet the deadline, a summit to sign the pact will be canceled. The deal aims to boost both economies, with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau urging Belgium to resolve its concerns. EU trade negotiators are racing against time to address the Walloon government's concerns before the deadline. The deal's fate hangs in the balance, with the EU warning that a summit cancellation would be a significant setback for both Canada and the EU.

site_title: Is starting up just for the rich?
summary: Starting a business is not exclusive to the rich, but having financial capital can be a significant advantage. Researcher Adam Grant found that having financial security allows individuals to be entrepreneurial and original in other areas. Many successful entrepreneurs, including those with family wealth, attribute their success to their passion for business and support from family. However, experts emphasize that financial means, business networks, and personal experience are also crucial for success. In contrast, broke entrepreneurs may be more risk-averse but also more resourceful and resilient, making the playing field more level.

site_title: China plenum to open with rumours Xi won't name successor
summary: China's annual plenum of the Central Committee is opening, amid rumors that President Xi Jinping may not step down after his second term, potentially breaking a tradition. The plenum, set to convene until October 27, will pave the way for the 19th Party Congress, where Xi is expected to name his successor. The 19th Congress will also see all but two members of the seven-member politburo renewed, with Xi's chosen successor to be groomed for the next five years.

site_title: An MBS boost for giving back to the community
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) hosted the Sands for Singapore Charity Festival 2016, where 222 participants completed a series of property-wide challenges for charity. The event raised S$120,000 in cash and prizes for charities chosen by the participants. This marks the highlight of the Sands for Singapore Charity Festival 2016.

site_title: Oil glut growing bigger despite Saudi Arabia saying worst is over
summary: The global oil market is experiencing a growing glut, despite Saudi Arabia's claims that the market is rebalancing. The price difference between Brent crude for two-month and three-month delivery widened to minus 69 US cents, the largest discount since February. The European market, which drives global prices, is awash with crude due to increased production from Nigeria, Libya, Russia, and Kazakhstan, while refineries undergo seasonal maintenance. This surplus is expected to persist until the Opec meeting on November 30, potentially leading to losses for speculators holding long positions in oil futures.

site_title: Good HR practices, training programmes crucial to support SMEs' growth
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can benefit from adopting good HR practices and training programs to support their growth. Companies like The Lo & Behold Group and Wong Fong Industries Ltd have implemented systematic approaches to fostering talent, including the use of HR diagnostic tools and robust feedback systems. This has led to lower attrition rates and a more engaged workforce. Experts emphasize the importance of investing in human capital development, continual innovation, and capability upgrading to support SMEs' sustainable growth and contribute to Singapore's economic progress.

site_title: The sky's the limit for AirAsia
summary: AirAsia's CEO Tony Fernandes aims to become Asia's largest low-cost carrier, connecting the dots in the budget carrier's global network. With operations in five countries, including India and China, Fernandes believes his airline has contributed to the growth and connectivity of the region. Despite facing competition, he welcomes it as a motivator for improvement. Fernandes' long-term vision includes expanding the airline's network beyond Asia, while navigating risks such as political uncertainty and oil prices. He has received the EY Asean Entrepreneurial Excellence award for his entrepreneurial journey, transforming AirAsia into an award-winning low-cost carrier.

images.alt_text: "Competition is the best form of motivation, the best form of becoming better, and I like competition. It keeps me hungry, keeps me going," says Mr Fernandes.

site_title: Singapore can be No 1 fintech hub, says Citi official
summary: Singapore is considered a "serious contender for the global number one spot in fintech" according to Deloitte's report and Citibank's Asia Pacific head, Anand Selvakesari. The country's government support for digital innovation and Citibank's efforts to transition to a smartphone-centric business model make it well-positioned to be a leading fintech hub. Citibank is investing heavily in digital solutions, including voice biometrics authentication, and aims to integrate fintech innovation to create a better customer experience. The bank's efforts reflect the need for traditional banks to adapt to the fintech explosion and provide frictionless transactions and curated customer journeys.

site_title: Airbnb's NY fight moves from legislature to courtroom
summary: Airbnb is suing New York after Governor Andrew Cuomo signed a bill fining residents for illegal short-term rentals. The bill aims to regulate the sharing economy and generate revenue for the city. Airbnb responded by filing a lawsuit in Manhattan federal court, claiming the bill infringes on its rights and violates the company's First Amendment freedoms. The company argues that the law unfairly targets its business and will harm the city's economy.

images.alt_text: Opponents and supporters of Airbnb outside the New York City Hall last year. Airbnb says New York lawmakers had ignored the wishes of their constituents.
Opponents and supporters of Airbnb outside the New York City Hall last year. Airbnb says New York lawmakers had ignored the wishes of their constituents.

site_title: Schlumberger Q3 earnings beat estimates
summary: Schlumberger reported Q3 earnings beating analyst estimates, with a profit of 25 US cents per share excluding one-time items. The company's North America onshore sales climbed 14% sequentially. Despite challenges from its newly acquired Cameron equipment unit, Schlumberger's US recovery was a positive factor. The company's global sales are still expected to lag behind the US market, but the earnings beat suggests a promising outlook for the company.

site_title: Confident Clinton steps up in battle for Congress
summary: Hillary Clinton plans to focus on working with her party to make gains in Congress, despite polls showing her leading in the presidential election. She stated she no longer wishes to respond to Donald Trump's attacks, instead emphasizing the importance of electing Democrats down the ballot. Trump, meanwhile, delivered a policy speech, vowing to create 25 million jobs and cut middle-class taxes, but also threatening to sue women who have accused him of sexual misconduct. The presidential election, which includes the election of a new Congress, will take place on November 8.

site_title: Does more sobriety await stocks again this week?
summary: The Singapore stock market may remain subdued this week due to unresolved investor anxieties and the corporate earnings season. The Straits Times Index ended flat last Friday amid mixed corporate earnings results, and US equities have been trading in a tight range due to concerns over the dollar, interest rates, and oil prices. Key events this week include the release of macro data from Asian economies and US home sales and GDP figures. Analysts expect a cyclical bottom in Asia, but caution against leaving no room for doubt in the US presidential election.

site_title: Tesla, rivals joust over what equipment to use in self-driving cars
summary: Tesla is equipping its vehicles with self-driving hardware that relies on cameras and radar sensors, but not lidar, a technology used by most other companies pursuing self-driving cars. This decision has intensified competition among rival car companies, with shares of Mobileye, a supplier of computer vision chips and software, rising 2.6% after Tesla's decision. Nvidia, a chipmaker, has secured a contract to provide processors for Tesla's new system, while other carmakers are working on different technology suites, including cameras, radar, and lidar, to enable fully self-driving cars.

site_title: Egyptians lose patience with govt as economy deteriorates
summary: Egyptians are losing patience with their government due to economic deterioration. Tax increases, soaring food prices, and cuts in state subsidies have sparked desperation and anger among the population. The situation has led to fears of mass street protests, similar to those that led to the ousting of President Sisi's two predecessors. The economic crisis has also raised concerns about the government's ability to maintain stability, with some warning of a repeat of the protests that brought about significant change in the country's recent history.

images.alt_text: Egyptians rushing to buy subsidised sugar from a government truck after a shortage across the country. They are being clobbered by tax increases, soaring food price inflation and cuts in state subsidies.

site_title: Growing in Asia? Go for depth, not breadth
summary: Asia's economic growth is slowing, but its relevance to investors remains. Despite challenges such as political instability and high corporate debt, Asia accounted for two-thirds of global GDP growth in 2015. The region's middle class is expected to exceed 3 billion by 2030, offering significant opportunities for companies. However, a one-size-fits-all market approach is unlikely to be successful, and companies need to shift their strategy to focus on market leadership instead of a widespread geographic presence. This approach can help companies achieve depth and dominate market share, leading to growth and profitability.

site_title: Corruption in China gets an airing on TV
summary: A new Chinese television series, "Always on the Road", has aired on state television, showcasing the lives of disgraced officials and their corrupt practices. The series highlights the lavish lifestyles of officials who were once serious about having fun, but are now repenting on camera after being punished for their crimes. The show features interviews with former officials, including those who received death sentences for taking bribes of nearly $38 million. The series aims to emphasize President Xi Jinping's efforts to wipe out graft, and it is part of the Communist Party's promotion of stricter rules for members and officials.

site_title: Putin helped save his oil giant. Now Rosneft returns the favour
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is turning to oil giant Rosneft for help, with the company providing a cash infusion to fill a budget gap and support the Kremlin abroad. Rosneft's turnaround is a triumph for Putin, who has protected the state-dominated system from US and EU pressure. The company's cash pile has grown to over $22 billion, thanks to financial engineering, a weakened rouble, and political support. Rosneft's CEO, Igor Sechin, has regained Putin's favor after a tumultuous period, and the company is now helping the Kremlin weather economic challenges.

site_title: Tudor said to be betting on data analytics, scientists
summary: Paul Tudor Jones' $10.6 billion hedge fund is investing in data analytics and partnering with startups to use machine learning in investment decisions. The firm has invested in startups led by Gil Syswerda and is hiring scientists to develop data-visualisation tools. Jones sees computer-driven analysis as vital to the firm's future, aiming to placate clients who have been dissatisfied with the firm's recent performance. This move is a signal that Jones believes data analytics can provide profitable investment ideas.

site_title: Connected gadgets blamed as Internet recovers from attack
summary: The Internet partially recovered from a global attack on Friday, with some of the world's most popular websites still down. Malware targeting the "Internet of Things" (IoT) devices, such as cameras and digital video recorders, is suspected to be the cause. According to journalist Brian Krebs, poorly secured IoT devices may have been compromised to create a "botnet" that powered the attack. This highlights the vulnerability of IoT devices and the need for better security measures to prevent similar attacks in the future.

site_title: Anbang abandons bid to buy US hotel near naval base
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group Co has abandoned its bid to purchase the Hotel del Coronado in San Diego, California, after opposition from US national-security officials. The deal, valued at around $1 billion, was called off due to concerns over potential national-security risks. The hotel is located near the Naval Base Coronado and is one of the most valuable properties in Strategic Hotels & Resorts, which was acquired by Blackstone Group LP for $6 billion last year. The decision delays Blackstone's ability to cash out at a profit and follows a recent trend of Anbang's aggressive dealmaking.

site_title: Tech earnings may wake bull market this week
summary: US stocks may experience a boost from technology earnings this week, with Silicon Valley powerhouses like Apple, Amazon, and Alphabet set to report results. A mega deal between AT&T and Time Warner could also lift the sector. Meanwhile, the technology sector is regaining its reputation as a market leader, with Netflix and Microsoft setting the pace last week. Oil prices have also surged, reaching their highest level in over a year, and miners and energy companies are experiencing a market bounce.

site_title: The 4Gs in successful business families: Generations, growth, giving and global
summary: Successful business families often adopt a "4Gs" mindset, which includes generations, growth, giving, and global thinking. This approach helps preserve family harmony and fosters family entrepreneurship. Examples of family businesses that embody this mindset include the Jebsen & Jessen Group, Luxasia Group, City Developments Limited, Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts, and OSIM. These companies prioritize tradition, culture, innovation, and community impact, and have achieved long-term success despite challenges. By adopting the 4Gs mindset, family businesses can create a strong foundation for growth, giving back to the community, and achieving global recognition.

site_title: Worst over for Dubai property: Nakheel chairman
summary: Dubai's property market appears to be recovering, with buyers returning and sales expected to increase, according to Nakheel chairman Ali Rashid Lootah. The emirate's real estate sales fell 30% in the first seven months of the year due to the economic slowdown caused by oil prices, but Lootah believes the worst is over and the market is maturing. Investors from the Gulf Cooperation Council, India, and the UK may consider Dubai as an alternative to UK property due to the country's Brexit vote, with Nakheel planning to expand its recurring income portfolio to $2 billion over the next five years.

site_title: Standing above the rest
summary: The EY Entrepreneur Of The Year awards 2016 featured a roundtable discussion with successful business owners. Key success factors for their businesses included adaptability, innovation, and a willingness to take calculated risks. They emphasized the importance of having a strong vision and being open to new ideas. The entrepreneurs also highlighted the need for effective leadership and a focus on customer needs. They attributed their success to a combination of hard work, strategic planning, and a commitment to their core values.

site_title: CEO pay ratios: populism or good governance?
summary: Regulators consider implementing "CEO pay ratios" to address excessive CEO pay, requiring disclosure of the relationship between CEO pay and other employees' pay. Some proposals would cap CEO pay at multiples of average or median pay of all other employees. The goal is to avoid more regulation, with companies instead being encouraged to enhance disclosures on remuneration-related matters. This approach aims to strike a balance between populism and good governance, allowing companies to maintain flexibility while providing more transparency on CEO pay.

site_title: British American Tobacco offers US$47 billion for Reynolds
summary: British American Tobacco (BAT) has offered $47 billion to acquire US cigarette maker Reynolds American Inc, creating the world's largest listed tobacco company with brands such as Newport, Lucky Strike, and Pall Mall. The deal would give BAT a leading presence in the US market and access to premium brands like Camel. BAT shares dropped 2.9% while Reynolds shares rose 7% in response to the offer. The deal is seen as a strategic move to simplify Reynolds' structure and capitalize on the growing e-cigarette market, with both companies to combine their e-cigarette efforts.

site_title: Director buying falls again, selling stays low
summary: Singaporean companies saw increased buying activity in the third week of October, with eight firms recording 14 purchases worth S$3.1 million. However, the number of selling firms and trades decreased. The buyback activity also rose for the second straight week, with 13 companies posting 42 repurchases worth S$7.14 million. Notable transactions included Star Pharmaceutical, GSH Corporation, GKE Corporation, Global Palm Resources, and New Silkroutes Group, with some companies buying back shares at higher prices than their previous acquisitions.

site_title: The ABCs of Singapore Reits (Amended)
summary: Singapore Reits, or S-Reits, are trusts that allow young investors to invest in income-generating real estate with favorable tax treatment. S-Reits benefit from tax exemption if they distribute at least 90% of their taxable income, resulting in high distribution yields of 6-8%. Reits can own properties in various countries, including Singapore, Australia, and China, and are subject to exchange rate risk. Investors should research risks and returns based on each country's characteristics. S-Reits are a viable option for retirement savings, offering potential for growth and minimizing the risk of capital losses.

site_title: Hanoi hopes to raise billions by selling stakes in brewers
summary: Vietnam's government plans to sell stakes in two state-owned brewers, Hanoi Beer Alcohol and Beverage Joint Stock Corp (Habeco) and Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corp (Sabeco), to raise up to $2.2 billion. The divestments are part of long-promised reforms to privatize bloated state firms, aiming to boost economic growth and meet ambitious targets. The sale is expected to be completed in the first three months of 2017, with foreign bidders competing for the stakes.

images.alt_text: The unprecedented divestments in Vietnam's two state crown jewels, the makers of the much-glugged Saigon and Hanoi beers, are expected to net as much as US$2.2 billion.

site_title: Keeping the family spirit alive
summary: Jebsen & Jessen (SEA), a diversified conglomerate, aims to maintain its family spirit beyond the third generation. Chairman Heinrich Jessen emphasizes the importance of only family members who can join the business, with shareholding members buying their shares and working in the company. The company has a history of overcoming near-death experiences, including World War I and II, and has adapted to challenges such as the Asian financial crisis. Jessen prioritizes the family's entrepreneurial spirit while maintaining sound financial discipline, and the company has received the EY-Barclays Family Business Award of Excellence.

site_title: Hosting WTA Finals a right fit for S'pore: STB
summary: Singapore successfully hosted the third edition of the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global, attracting a record 130,000 people to the Sports Hub and generating significant economic benefits. The tournament, which features the top eight singles players and doubles teams, saw Angelique Kerber defeat Dominika Cibulkova in an epic three-set battle. The event has been a resounding success for Singapore, with the STB estimating that each of the five instalments would net about S$15 million in tourism receipts. The current deal ends in 2018, but the STB is open to bidding again in the future if the event continues to fulfill its objectives.

site_title: Ensuring the right products and options for patients
summary: The Health Insurance Task Force's proposals aim to rein in rising healthcare costs in Singapore by promoting value-based healthcare, aligning guidelines for chronic conditions, and encouraging co-payment and deductibles. Experts agree that stakeholders must work together to manage costs, shift from volume to value-based care, and educate consumers on healthcare options. Implementing measures such as hybrid systems, co-payment, and deductibles can help patients take greater ownership of their health. Policymakers must balance cost control with quality of care, and consider subsidies to ensure affordable healthcare for the public.

site_title: Sunmoon CEO sees stars finally aligning
summary: Sunmoon Food Co, a distributor of fresh fruits and fruit products, is poised for a turnaround after a Chinese online shopping group, Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce Co, is set to invest S$15 million in the company. This investment, which could be worth up to S$24 million, is expected to give Sunmoon the working capital to handle larger volumes and help the company break into the China fresh fruit and fruit product space. CEO Gary Loh hopes this deal will be a game-changer for the company, allowing him to move on to other investments within three to five years.

site_title: Leading in the age of disruption
summary: Business leaders are embracing a "change agent" ethos to drive innovation and growth in a disrupted digital age. According to an EY-sponsored Harvard Business Review study, organisations with a clear purpose experience 10% revenue growth over three years. Leaders should leverage data and analytics intelligently, encourage intrapreneurship, and foster diversity and inclusivity to drive innovation. Embracing a curious and questioning mindset is also crucial, as leaders must be open to new ideas and willing to challenge existing mental models. By adopting these strategies, businesses can thrive in a rapidly changing world.

images.alt_text: Most leaders would agree that there should be a good mix of attributes such as genders, backgrounds, qualifications and nationalities on their teams.

"Size and ownership model alone rarely determine success in seizing the upsides of disruption and change. Rather, common qualities among leading businesses are their relentless pursuit of innovation in a digital era and business leaders leading differently to foster innovation that delivers to the bottom line." - Max Loh

site_title: All eyes on Swissco, Ezra debt meetings early this week
summary: Swissco Holdings and Ezra Holdings, two offshore services companies, will hold informal meetings with bondholders early this week. Swissco's meeting on Monday will discuss its proposed restructuring of S$100 million of 5.7% notes due 2018, following a default on a S$2.85 million coupon payment. Ezra's meeting on Tuesday will update noteholders on its "current position" regarding a consent solicitation for S$150 million worth of 4.875% notes due 2018. Both companies stress that no decisions will be made or voting will occur during the meetings.

images.alt_text: Attention will be on beleaguered offshore services companies Swissco Holdings and Ezra Holdings this week, as both prepare to hold what they called "informal" meetings with their bondholders.

site_title: Banks preparing to leave UK over Brexit: top official
summary: International banks are preparing to relocate some operations out of the UK in early 2017 due to Brexit uncertainty. According to Anthony Browne, chief executive of the British Bankers' Association, many banks have project teams working on relocation plans, with some smaller banks expected to start relocations before Christmas and bigger banks in the first quarter of next year. The relocation is due to concerns over the UK's "passport" to serve clients across the European Union, which may end after Brexit.

site_title: Swiss unblock US$140m after Italy tax fraud acquittals
summary: Switzerland has unblocked approximately $140 million in accounts frozen since 2005 to assist Italy in a tax fraud probe of Mediaset broadcaster. The unblocking follows a Milan appeals court's acquittal of Mediaset chairman Fedele Confalonieri and CEO Pier Silvio Berlusconi, who were previously sentenced to prison for tax fraud. The frozen funds were related to artificially inflated film distribution rights and slush funds in foreign bank accounts. The accounts can now be accessed once banks complete the unblocking procedure.

site_title: Qantas CEO turns around the airline and his public image
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce has transformed the airline from record losses to record profits in just two years. In 2011, Joyce hired bodyguards due to death threats after grounding the fleet during an industrial dispute. He has since won over hostile customers, politicians, and unions. This year, Qantas delivered record profits and dividends, and unveiled plans for growth. Joyce's turnaround has earned him a positive public image, a stark contrast to his past struggles.
