site_title: Dozens injured in Malaysia after gas-filled balloons explode at public event
summary: Dozens of people were injured, including children, after gas-filled balloons exploded at a public event in Malaysia's Kuala Terengganu, the 'Walk for the Blind' event. At least 30 people were hurt on Friday, October 21, 2016. The explosion occurred during the event organized by the Terengganu Health Department.

site_title: Britain's banks to reveal solid Q3 results, warn of Brexit storm ahead
summary: Britain's major banks are expected to report stronger-than-expected Q3 results, defying expectations that Brexit would immediately impact profits. Despite a quarter of Royal Bank of Scotland's and Lloyds' shares falling since the Brexit vote, consumer spending has held up and demand for mortgages and loans has only dropped modestly. However, senior executives warn that economic conditions will worsen next year due to the UK's formal exit from the EU, potentially leading to a "storm" in the financial sector.

site_title: Trump gains on Clinton despite furor over women, election comments: poll
summary: Donald Trump has narrowed Hillary Clinton's lead in the presidential election, cutting her advantage from 4 points to 4 points, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll. Despite controversy over Trump's comments on women and the election process, 63% of Americans believe he has committed sexual assault, but many still support him due to his stance on conservative issues. The poll showed a slight increase in support for Clinton, but Trump's deficit remains relatively narrow, just one week before the election.

site_title: China slams 'provocative' US sail-by in South China Sea
summary: China has condemned the US for sailing a warship near the Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, calling it a "serious illegal act" and "deliberately provocative". Two Chinese naval vessels warned off the US ship, which entered "Chinese territorial waters". China controls all the islands, disputed by Vietnam and Taiwan. The move has raised tensions in the region, with China asserting its sovereignty over the area.

site_title: Businesses must disrupt now, or fall by the wayside
summary: Businesses face significant disruption due to digital transformation, with companies from every industry sector challenged to keep pace with changing consumer behavior. The average lifespan of companies on the S&P 500 is predicted to be just 14 years by 2026, with half of today's companies expected to be replaced over the next decade. Only 61% of companies are actively trying to disrupt their competitors or industry through digitalization, with legacy technology a major barrier to innovation. Businesses must confront disruptive forces head-on with their own disruption plays or risk being disrupted themselves, making it a critical time for companies to invest in competitive differentiation and agile networks.

site_title: Raine Spencer, Princess Diana's stepmother, dies at 87
summary: Countess Raine Spencer, Princess Diana's stepmother, has died at 87 after a short illness. Known for her high society life and aristocratic titles, she married three times and had four children. Raine had a strained relationship with Diana, nicknamed her "Acid Raine," but reportedly reconciled with her in the early 1990s. The countess passed away peacefully at her London home, surrounded by her family.

site_title: Crash can be avoided despite China's property bubble
summary: China's housing market, while experiencing a nationwide 30% increase in house sales for the first eight months of 2016, is not a nationwide phenomenon, but concentrated in a handful of large cities, primarily Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou. These cities have seen house prices rise 7% on average, but valuations remain below 2009-10 peaks, and affordability has improved in lower-tier cities. A correction in these cities is inevitable but expected to be modest, supported by strong local economies and accommodative monetary conditions.

site_title: EU sets Belgium Monday deadline to back Canada trade deal
summary: The European Union has set a Monday deadline for Belgium to back the Canada trade deal, Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), amid opposition from the French-speaking region of Wallonia. The EU has offered tweaks to the treaty to secure Walloon backing, but the region's Socialist leader, Elio Di Rupo, cast doubt on a deal being reached next week. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau had set the Monday deadline, and if Belgium does not back the deal, a summit to sign the pact may be canceled. The EU had previously agreed on the deal with all 28 governments.

site_title: Banks readying to leave Brexit Britain: lobby group
summary: International banks based in Britain are preparing to relocate operations outside the country in 2017 due to post-Brexit uncertainty, according to Anthony Browne, director of the British Bankers' Association. Banks are uncertain about offering services across Europe after Britain leaves the EU in 2019, fearing potential trade barriers and job losses. Browne warned that if Brexit is bungled, trade in financial services between Britain and continental Europe could be at risk, affecting £20 billion in free trade.

site_title: Duterte, back from China, says he's not severing US ties
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte stated he's not severing ties with the US, contrary to comments made during a visit to China, where he said he was separating from the US. Duterte clarified that his foreign policy comments referred to a shift away from US influence, not a complete severance of ties. His cabinet members also emphasized the country's intention to maintain relations with the West, as Duterte rebalances foreign policy and broadens alliances.

site_title: Trump vows to weaken US. media 'power structure' if elected
summary: US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump vowed to weaken the US media 'power structure' if elected, citing the proposed AT&T-Time Warner deal as an example. He promised to sue women who have accused him of sexual assault and listed his policy plans for the first 100 days of his presidency. Trump's speech in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, came after he listed his grievances and described how he would address them from the White House.

site_title: Max Landis is a Hollywood disrupter with an attitude
summary: Max Landis, a prolific Hollywood screenwriter, has made a name for himself with his unique writing style and high-profile projects. His recent spec script "Deeper" sold to MGM for $2 million, while another script, "Bright," led to a $90 million Netflix deal. Landis credits his success to writing scripts in his head, feeling an existential imperative to bring his ideas to life. Despite criticism labeling him an egomaniac and pretentious, Landis maintains a strong social media presence and has collaborated with notable writers and directors, including his father, John Landis.

site_title: Cyber attacks disrupt PayPal, Twitter, other sites
summary: A cyber attack targeting Dyn, a little-known internet infrastructure company, disrupted access to dozens of websites, including PayPal, Twitter, and Spotify. The attack, which began in the Eastern United States, spread globally and was caused by tens of millions of infected devices launching a massive distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack. Dyn said it was fighting the third major wave of attacks, which were being launched from locations worldwide. The US Department of Homeland Security and FBI are investigating, amid growing fears about the cyber threat in the US.

images.alt_text: Cyber attacks targeting a little known internet infrastructure company, Dyn, disrupted access to dozens of websites on Friday, preventing some users from accessing PayPal, Twitter and Spotify.

site_title: Worst is over for Dubai property as buyers return
summary: Dubai's property market is showing signs of recovery as buyers return, according to Nakheel PJSC Chairman Ali Rashid Lootah. Real estate sales fell 30% in the first seven months of 2016 due to an economic slowdown, but Lootah believes the worst is over. He notes that the market is maturing with more serious, cautious investors and predicts a 10% drop in values in 2017. Meanwhile, Nakheel's Palm Tower project has sold about half of its 504 apartments, with the first 18 floors set to operate as a luxury hotel under the St Regis brand.

site_title: AT&T in advanced talks to buy Time Warner: banking source
summary: AT&T is in advanced talks to acquire Time Warner, a deal possibly worth over $70 billion, according to a banking source. The two parties have agreed on key points, but outstanding issues include the exact price and a breakup fee. The deal, which would unite the two media giants worth over $300 billion, is expected to face scrutiny from US antitrust regulators. Analysts predict the transaction could spark other big deals involving large media companies, amid challenges to media companies due to the decline of conventional cable television and the rise of streaming on mobile technology.

images.alt_text: Telecom giant AT&T is in advanced talks to acquire entertainment group Time Warner, a banking source familiar with the negotiations said Friday.

site_title: Whalers in crosshairs at international huddle
summary: The International Whaling Commission (IWC) is set to meet in Slovenia, where 88 nations will debate the fate of the world's remaining whales. The meeting comes as Japan's yearly whale hunt, criticized as a cover for commercial whaling, and a proposal for a South Atlantic sanctuary to protect whales are major points of contention. The IWC is deeply divided, with some nations opposing hunting altogether and others supporting Japan's "scientific" whaling claims. The outcome is uncertain, with heated debate expected over the future of the world's majestic marine mammals.

site_title: Facebook to allow more graphic news
summary: Facebook is allowing more graphic news to be shared on its platform, starting with posts deemed newsworthy or significant. The company is recalibrating its standards to allow more images and stories without posing safety risks, particularly for minors. This move comes after criticism for censoring content despite its historical or editorial value. Facebook has faced backlash for removing posts with nudity, including a historic Vietnam War photo, and has rejected lobbying efforts to brand certain posts as hate speech, including those by US presidential candidate Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Friday said that it will begin allowing more graphic or potentially disturbing newsworthy posts to be shared at the leading online social network.

site_title: US: Merger talk boosts Reynolds, Time Warner but Wall St ends flat
summary: US stocks ended flat on Friday, despite news of potential megamerger deals. Time Warner jumped 7.8% on reports of AT&T's talks to acquire the entertainment group, while Reynolds American surged 14% after British American Tobacco launched a $47 billion bid to buy the tobacco company. Microsoft also rose 4.6% to reach a 1999 record high on better-than-expected earnings. Despite the gains, the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 ended down 0.1% and less than 0.1% respectively.

images.alt_text: Megamerger buzz returned to Wall Street on Friday on a mixed day for US stocks, with shares of Time Warner and Reynolds American both surging on news of separate takeover deals.

site_title: Bollywood film set to screen after Pakistani actor ban
summary: A Bollywood film, "Ae Dil Hai Mushkil", starring Pakistani actor Fawad Khan, will be released in India as scheduled despite initial threats of violence from Hindu nationalists. The Film and Television Producers Guild of India agreed to ban Pakistani actors in future, and the film's director, Karan Johar, has agreed to contribute 50 million rupees to the Indian army as "penance". The deal was brokered between Johar, the guild, and a far-right leader, and protests have been called off. The film is set to release on October 28, two days before the Diwali Hindu festival.

site_title: New York state tightens rules on Airbnb
summary: New York state has tightened rules on home-sharing services like Airbnb, slapping a $7,500 fine on hosts who rent their apartments for less than 30 days. The new law prohibits advertising for short-term rentals and targets the lucrative market in New York City, where many hosts use Airbnb to afford their apartments. Airbnb has fired back, saying it will sue the law and accusing the state of favoring the hotel industry. The move is part of a growing trend of cities cracking down on short-term rentals.

site_title: London airport evacuated after 'CS gas' incident
summary: London City Airport was evacuated after a suspected CS tear gas spray was found, leaving 27 travellers feeling unwell. The incident prompted a 3-hour closure, with 500 people evacuated and several treated for breathing difficulties. A search revealed the suspected gas, with police investigating possible accidental discharge or intentional discard. Flights were diverted or cancelled, and airport staff were treated for breathing difficulties. The cause of the incident remains unclear, with no arrests made and ongoing enquiries.

images.alt_text: A suspected CS tear gas spray was found at London City Airport after passengers and staff were evacuated Friday following a "chemical incident" that left 27 travellers feeling unwell and halted flights.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Straits Trading Company is selling an office building in Melbourne, Australia, for approximately A$161.5 million (S$171.8 million) to AFIAA Australia 4 Pty Ltd.

site_title: The laboured market
summary: Singapore's labor market is experiencing a slowdown in economic growth, with redundancies rising to 7.4 per 1,000 workers in 2015. However, banks are still hiring, particularly in compliance and IT functions, indicating pockets of opportunities. The market's nuances highlight the need to close the gap between available skillsets and business needs. Despite growing redundancies, unemployment remains relatively low at 2.1% overall and 3.0% among residents.

site_title: China regulator tells banks to boost property loans risk management
summary: China's banking regulator has urged lenders to boost risk management of property loans amid record house price gains and concerns of price bubbles and debts. The China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) called for measures to control real estate business risks and prevent misappropriation of credit funds. Economists warn of a possible correction in the property market, which accounts for 15% of GDP, with over 20 cities introducing measures to restrict home purchases. The regulator's move aims to mitigate "systemic and regional financial risks."

images.alt_text: China's banking regulator has asked lenders to step up risk management of property loans amid record gains in house prices that have raised concerns of price bubbles and ballooning debts.

site_title: Europe: Stocks post weekly gain as bounce in banks buoys markets
summary: European stock markets ended the week with a 1.3% gain, driven by a rebound in bank shares and positive company results. The STOXX 600 index closed flat on Friday, but the STOXX Europe 600 banks index rose 0.5%. Analysts attributed the gain to robust results from Wall Street banks and improved FICC operations. However, concerns over Italian banks' bad debts and the future of the ECB's monetary stimulus programme remain. European stocks have lost favor among foreign investors this year due to sluggish earnings growth and an uncertain economic outlook.

site_title: KPMG marks changes at helm
summary: KPMG in Singapore has announced a leadership change for its 75th anniversary, with Ong Pang Thye taking over as the firm's new managing partner, succeeding Tham Sai Choy. Ong Pang Thye, who flew in for the occasion, is the first Singaporean to hold the position. This change marks a significant milestone for the firm as it celebrates its 75 years in Singapore.

site_title: S&P raises France's rating outlook
summary: Standard & Poor's raised France's long-term sovereign credit rating outlook to "stable" from "negative", citing gradual growth-enhancing reforms and fiscal consolidation. The US ratings agency left its view on French debt at AA, its third-highest rating. This move was welcomed by the French government, seen as a sign of confidence. The improvement is attributed to the country's efforts to introduce reforms and reduce its fiscal deficit.

site_title: Viva's Q3 DPS rises despite larger unit base
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) reported a 9.9% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.81 Singapore cents for its third quarter, driven by three acquisitions completed in the past year. Despite a near 20% enlargement in the unit base, the trust's occupancy improved to 88.6% and gross revenue rose 31.9% to S$24.3 million. The trust's gearing has decreased, and analysts expect gains from asset enhancement initiatives and potential rental reversions at its Viva Business Park.

site_title: US border town shrugs off Trump's Mexico wall plan
summary: Residents of the US border town of Nogales, Arizona, largely dismiss Donald Trump's plan to build a wall along the US-Mexico border, calling it "cuckoo" and implausible. The town already has a 5.5m metal barrier, and people continue to cross into the US undetected. Many residents rely on customers from Mexico, and the economy is deeply intertwined with that of the Mexican part of the city. A recent poll found that 86% of residents in Mexico and 72% in the US oppose the wall, and Trump's anti-immigrant rhetoric is seen as hurtful to the US-Mexico relationship, which is crucial for trade.

site_title: European Parliament head says will try to save Canada-EU deal
summary: European Parliament President Martin Schulz plans to hold emergency talks with Canadian Trade Minister Chrystia Freeland and Walloon premier Paul Magnette to revive stalled free trade talks between the EU and Canada. The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) has been hindered by disagreements over issues such as pork and beef imports and an independent court system. Despite EU support, Belgium's five sub-federal administrations must give assent, and French-speaking Wallonia has opposed the deal. Failure to reach an agreement may undermine the EU's credibility and impact its ability to forge other trade deals.

site_title: My favourite album
summary: A 1976 album by the Ramones, titled "Ramones by Ramones," is considered the best punk rock album ever by Rick 'Ramone' Ang. The album, recorded 40 years ago, has stood the test of time despite the band members' passing.

site_title: Psychedelia
summary: Mojoko's latest street art exhibition, featuring over 20 new works, is now open at The Refinery in Singapore until November 20. The exhibition showcases the artist's eclectic mix of icons and images, including Hawaiian hula girls, Spongebob Squarepants, and Sentosa Express light rail trains, in a vibrant and psychedelic style. The exhibition highlights Mojoko's unique blend of colors and characters, making it a visually striking display.

site_title: CMT's Q3 DPU drops, asset management fees rise
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 6.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q3 2016, despite a 4.7% increase in distributable income. The trust will spend S$54 million renovating the main entrance and interior of Raffles City Singapore mall. Asset management fees rose 9.6% to S$11.2 million. Gross revenue and net property income grew 4.9% and 5.5% year-on-year, respectively, driven by contributions from Bedok Mall and higher rental revenue from renovated properties.

site_title: Marble Universe
summary: The article delves into the world of wagyu, a type of high-quality beef from Japan. Three brands, Omi, Kobe, and Matsusaka, are considered the gold standard, with Matsusaka being the most expensive at $550 per kg. Japanese cows have a unique marbling system that sets them apart from Australian and US wagyu, which have cross-bred with other breeds. To ensure authenticity, look for the 'Wagyu Japanese Beef' logo and certification from the Japan Livestock Industry Association. The quality of wagyu depends on factors such as marbling, yield, and fat quality, making it essential to trust the butcher or restaurant.

site_title: Workers, companies must adapt and transform to stay relevant: Swee Say
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say urged retrenched workers to remain positive and adapt to the changing job market. He assured that the government, industry, and unions will provide support, and workers must be prepared to grow again. This comes amid reports of several companies laying off workers in large numbers.

site_title: Tobacco giant BAT targets US with US$47b Reynolds bid
summary: British American Tobacco (BAT) has launched a $47 billion bid to acquire Reynolds American, the US-based tobacco company, in an effort to expand its presence in the US market. The deal would give BAT a leading position in the US tobacco market and a significant presence in emerging markets. The proposal, valued at 43 billion euros, would bring together BAT brands with Reynolds American's Camel and Newport brands. BAT's CEO Nicandro Durante said the deal would strengthen the company's track record of consistent delivery for shareholders and further solidify its position as the world's largest tobacco company.

images.alt_text: British American Tobacco on Friday launched a vast US$47 billion bid for full control of Reynolds American, as it seeks expansion into the United States - the second largest market after China.

site_title: Asahi Glass opens regional innovation centre in S'pore
summary: Asahi Glass Co. has opened an Application Development Centre in Singapore, its first in South-east Asia and South Asia, to develop new solutions for the region. The centre will provide technical support for fluorochemical products, used in various sectors, and enhance the firm's capabilities to transfer advanced technologies and develop new products. Singapore's Economic Development Board sees this as a move to strengthen the country's position as a leader in smart cities, infrastructure, and green buildings for the tropical region.

site_title: Global iron ore pricing: Singapore has more clout than China
summary: Singapore has greater pricing power in the global iron ore futures market than China, despite having smaller volumes, according to a Goldman Sachs Group Inc. report. The Singapore Exchange's contract drives the market, not the Dalian Commodity Exchange, which is often assumed to set the price due to its high volumes. This suggests that Singapore's influence in the market is more significant than its smaller size would indicate.

site_title: Futuristic CEO David Low named EY Entrepreneur of the Year
summary: David Low, CEO of Futuristic Store Fixtures, has been named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2016 Singapore. He will compete in the EY World Entrepreneur of the Year competition in Monaco in June 2017. Low was recognized for his visionary leadership in growing Futuristic from a startup to a global business serving international retail brands across 56 countries. The other award winners include Lawrence Leow, Helene Raudaschl, and Lim Yong Guan, who were selected from 40 nominations based on entrepreneurial spirit, financial performance, and innovation.

site_title: The secret lives of BT folk
summary: A Business Times journalist explores the "secret lives" of his colleagues, challenging the perception that the publication's staff is "super-serious and stodgy." Through profiles of six colleagues, he reveals a diverse group of individuals with unique hobbies and passions, including a lifelong learner who teaches himself to code, a correspondent who is a concert pianist, and a lifestyle writer who is a playwright. The journalist argues that his colleagues are "spry, sassy, and singular," and invites readers to reconsider their assumptions about the people they work with.

site_title: Memory Lanes
summary: Tokyo's past is revealed through a walking tour, led by Walk Japan, that explores the city's origins as a swampy fishing village called Edo. Founded by shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu in 1603, the city was transformed through his vision, including the construction of a 26km canal and the Imperial Palace. The tour highlights remnants of this era, such as Nihonbashi Bridge, the original Mitsukoshi store, and the Koishikawa Korakuen Japanese garden. These hidden pockets of Edo's history offer a glimpse into the city's evolution over the past 400 years.

images.alt_text: PHOTOS WALKJAPAN, CLANHOUSE, JAIME EE. SKETCHES STUART AYRE
The quietly imposing Imperial Palace, where the Emperor resides.
Traditional street snacks are still a common sight.
Close-up of lion on Ginza's Nihonbashi Bridge.
Nihonbashi Bridge.
The Senso-ji Temple in Asakusa is Tokyo's oldest.
Koishikawa Korakuen is one of the city's oldest Japanese gardens, dating back to the Edo period.
Shellfish objectives - detail from prawn dish by Stuart Ayre, Tokyo-based illustrator.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Keppel Corporation's earnings are expected to be supported by promising property sales in China and Vietnam, offsetting declining offshore and marine revenues. DBS Group Research maintains a "hold" rating with a target price of S$5.25. Ascendas Reit's share price may be capped by the expiration of Exchangeable Collateralised Securities, prompting a downgrade to "hold" from "add". Cogent Holdings is upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$1.11 due to the expected positive impact of its Jurong Island Chemical Logistics Facility project.

site_title: China property curbs start to bite as prices ease in some cities
summary: China's property market shows tentative signs of cooling as new-home prices in some cities, such as Beijing and Shanghai, fell 3.7% and 2.5% in October from September. Authorities introduced curbs, including larger down-payments and purchase limits, in 21 cities. Despite initial signs of cooling, experts warn that the market still faces a bubble risk and that credit tightening remains a more effective control measure.

images.alt_text: Local governments in at least 21 cities have introduced property curbs in a bid to arrest runaway prices.

site_title: The glorious freedom of a roving lifestyle
summary: A 44-year-old woman, a self-described nomad, has lived in 18 temporary residences in six years after feeling unfulfilled in her life and career. She pursued higher education, starting fresh in New York, and found a sense of freedom and creativity in constantly moving and adapting to new spaces. Despite initial rejections, she eventually found a rhythm of taking odd situations and keeping her rent below market price. She's now enjoying a lease-free lifestyle, which has allowed her to build a new career and finally enjoy dating, and she plans to settle down one day, but for now, the freedom of her nomadic lifestyle remains a key part of her happiness.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Singapore's dining scene is revving up with new restaurants. Sichuan Duo Hua Restaurant reinvents fugu into Sichuan and Cantonese dishes, while BoChinche introduces Argentine cuisine at Comilona. Thevar 2.0 showcases mod-Indian cuisine and The Social Kitchen sets up shop at Bank of Singapore. Meanwhile, CMC Markets partners with Sophia Women to promote financial literacy. These establishments aim to engage the community and promote sustainability, reflecting the evolving needs of Singaporeans.

site_title: QAF rises in active trade
summary: QAF Ltd, a Singapore-based company known for its Gardenia bread brand, experienced a sudden spike in trading, rising over 1% in active trade on October 21, 2016. The stock, which saw 57 million shares traded, closed at S$1.24 per share. QAF reported a net profit of S$28.8 million for the second quarter, more than doubling from S$12.2 million, driven by a one-off gain from the sale of its stake in Gardenia Bakeries. The company expects to perform satisfactorily for the third quarter.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's Q3 DPU down 13.7% to 1.85 cents
summary: Cache Logistics Trust's third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) decreased 13.7% to 1.85 cents due to the absence of capital proceeds from the disposal of Kim Heng warehouse in Q3 FY15. Despite a 1.3% dip in distributable income, gross revenue rose 21.2% and net property income climbed 17.5% due to rental contributions from DHL Supply Chain Advanced Regional Centre and Australian properties. Net financing costs increased 18.6% due to borrowings and financing expenses. The portfolio's committed occupancy stood at 96.5% as of September 30.

site_title: Why did Lambo give Marvel a Huracán to destroy in Doctor Strange?
summary: Lamborghini CEO Stefano Domenicali revealed that the company partnered with Marvel to feature its Huracán in the movie Doctor Strange, citing the car's alignment with the film's themes of ambition, cutting-edge technology, and vision. The move aims to reach high-net-worth consumers who are drawn to the brand's unique design and performance. With the release of the Urus SUV in 2018, Lamborghini hopes to double its global sales and increase brand awareness, leveraging the popularity of superhero movies to connect with aspirational consumers.

site_title: Hello Japan
summary: There is no article to summarize. The provided content appears to be a collection of article titles and publication dates, but no actual article text is provided.

site_title: Friday's loss limits ST Index's gain for week to 0.6%
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton won the third and final debate with Republican candidate Donald Trump, but the local market didn't react positively, limiting the Straits Times Index's gain for the week to 0.6%. The lack of market response suggests investors have already priced in a Clinton victory, focusing on post-election factors such as earnings, the economy, and interest rates.

site_title: Investors hunting for value in Malaysian stocks
summary: Malaysian stocks are on the brink of their longest annual losses, but investors are taking bets on a rebound. Affin Hwang Asset Management's Gan Eng Peng is buying amid expectations of stabilizing earnings and an undervalued ringgit. Stocks have been cheap relative to global equities since 2009, but weak oil and the 1MDB scandal have hindered growth. Foreign funds are showing interest, with a recent surge in participation at investment conferences, but buying has been erratic. Analysts predict a potential rebound, with earnings growth expected to reach 7-8% in 2017.

images.alt_text: Stocks in Malaysia haven't been this cheap since 2009 relative to global equities. Yet they have been laggards in South-east Asia. The benchmark stock index is also headed for a third year of declines.

site_title: Amsterdam's US$10,000-a-night hotel anchors hip new district
summary: A 1970s-era office building in Amsterdam's Noord district has been transformed into a 24/7 entertainment destination featuring a hotel, restaurants, music venues, and offices. The A'dam Tower, formerly the headquarters of Royal Dutch Shell, was purchased for $10 million in 2012 and underwent a $50 million renovation. The complex now attracts thousands of visitors daily, offering a range of activities, including a hotel, revolving restaurant, nightclub, and underground club. The project aims to create a 24-hour economy in the area, drawing tourists and locals alike to the previously underdeveloped neighborhood.

site_title: The Big Swim
summary: The Anatara Kihavah Maldives Villa offers the world's largest natural manta feeding destination, where guests can witness over 100 manta rays during their annual migration across the Indian Ocean. This spectacle occurs during the full moon and typically lasts until the end of November. Guests can still experience the event before the end of the season or plan ahead for the next season starting in May 2017.

site_title: Tripartite partners push for jobs in thriving ICT sector
summary: Singapore's tripartite partners launch initiatives to provide better career support for ICT sector workers, aiming to reduce "missed match" between jobs and workers. The TechSkills Accelerator Integrated Career Services and SkillsFuture Career Services programme will offer job updates, training information, and career advice. The initiatives aim to overcome twin challenges of job mismatch and missed match, with 170,000 ICT professionals and 20,000 vacancies in the sector. The measures are driven by the Singapore Computer Society, labour movement, and three government agencies.

site_title: Our Japanese Obsession
summary: The Singaporean fascination with Japan continues to grow, with 190,900 travelers from Singapore visiting Japan between January and August this year, a 20% jump from the previous year. The Japanese obsession is evident in the number of Singaporeans who cook Japanese meals daily, have Japanese hairdressers, and watch NHK World. The article highlights several individuals who share their personal stories of being "nipponholics," with some quitting their jobs to spend months in Japan. The country's food, culture, and way of life are major draws, with many restaurants and eateries in Singapore offering authentic Japanese cuisine. The Japanese Embassy reports a 20% increase in Japanese restaurants in Singapore, and the country's tourism industry is booming.

site_title: A US venue with history becomes an outdoor megastore
summary: The Uline Arena in Washington, DC, a historic venue, has reopened as the East Coast's largest REI store. The 51,000-square-foot store joins a changing NoMa landscape with luxury condos, office buildings, and retail shops. The arena, originally built in 1941 as a hockey rink, has undergone a $10 million renovation to preserve its historic architecture and features, including concert posters and original basketball arena seats. REI's store marks the chain's fifth flagship location in the US and its first in the nation's capital.

site_title: EU leaders agree to modernise their trade defense instruments
summary: EU leaders agreed to modernize their trade defense instruments to defend against unfair trade practices, with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stating that a Europe-Canada trade deal could still be signed as planned next week despite a disagreement with the Belgian province of Wallonia.

site_title: Lots of goodies, but commitment to fiscal consolidation remains
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak presented a RM261 billion budget, 3.4% larger than last year's, with a projected 4-5% economic growth for 2017. The government aims to achieve a near-balanced budget by 2020, but analysts and Moody's express doubts due to the absence of major reforms to increase revenue. The budget includes handouts and cash transfers, such as the BR1M scheme, which has raised concerns about fiscal consolidation and the country's economic prospects.

site_title: New measures to boost S'pore's private education standards
summary: Singapore's Committee for Private Education (CPE) has introduced new measures to boost the country's private education standards. The regulations, which take effect immediately, require private schools to have at least S$100,000 in paid-up capital, set minimum academic requirements for fresh school-leavers, and mandate participation in the annual graduate employment survey. The changes aim to strengthen protection of students' interests and improve academic outcomes, with the CPE also introducing enhanced credit ratings and a new EduTrust certification scheme.

site_title: High networths join CDL's Nouvel 18 PPS deal
summary: City Developments (CDL) has secured a S$977.6 million deal with high net worth investors, including OSIM's Ron Sim and Straits Trading's Chew Gek Khim, to unlock the value of its completed Nouvel 18 condo. The deal, a profit participation securities (PPS) platform, values the condo at S$965.4 million and avoids hefty extension charges under the government's Qualifying Certificate (QC) conditions. CDL will retain a 5% annual internal rate of return and upside, while the investors will enjoy a preferred 5% annual return and potential upside.

site_title: Upbeat about Vietnam's residential property market
summary: Vietnam's residential property market remains upbeat, with the premium apartment price at US$2,180 per square meter, 24% below the 2007 peak. Foreign direct investments (FDI) in the country increased 12% year-on-year to US$11 billion in the first nine months of 2016, with Singapore being the second-largest investor after South Korea. Vietnam's GDP is expected to grow 6-6.5% from 2016 to 2020, driven by a young and educated population.

site_title: Pathfinder
summary: Boston Consulting Group (BCG) has achieved double-digit growth for five decades, with a 16% average growth rate in the last three years. Under CEO Rich Lesser's leadership, the firm has undergone a significant digital makeover, focusing on customised solutions, collaboration, and staying ahead of the curve in business ideas and practices. Lesser attributes the firm's sustained growth to its ability to adapt to changing environments and invest in new technologies, such as digital transformation, big data, and analytics. BCG has also opened eight new offices and grown its workforce to over 12,000, with a focus on building new capabilities and partnering with clients to drive change.

site_title: HK's home-loan war poised to heat up
summary: Hong Kong's home-loan market is poised to heat up as banks compete to attract borrowers, despite potential US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. Local banks have cut mortgage rates by 30 basis points, narrowing the gap to 1.3-1.35 percentage points above the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate. The competition risks reigniting property bubble fears, which the city's government has been trying to quell with cooling measures. The market share of top lenders, including Bank of China and HSBC, is closely contested, with mortgage rates putting pressure on banks' profitability.

site_title: Dollar jumps to more than eight-month high, euro weakens
summary: The dollar rose to its highest level since early February, reaching a 98.754 dollar index, driven by hawkish comments from Fed officials and increased expectations of a December interest rate hike. The euro weakened to a 1.0870 dollar price, its lowest since March 10, following the European Central Bank meeting and China's yuan depreciation. The dollar's rise and euro's fall were attributed to uncertainty surrounding the US presidential election and potential market volatility, with traders pricing in a 74% chance of a Fed rate hike in December.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target revenue for H2, with similar operating losses as in H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Asset management leaning more to ESG
summary: Asset management firms are increasingly adopting Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) principles, particularly in relation to climate change. Companies with poor ESG practices are being excluded from portfolios. BNP Paribas Investment Partners has aligned about half of its assets under management with ESG standards, while Amundi incorporates ESG ratings into its analyses. The adoption of ESG standards is driven by investor pressure, with Asian investors leading the trend in seeking social impact alongside financial gains. Firms are developing decarbonized indexes and working with pension funds to mitigate climate change risks.

site_title: FCT eyes retail malls held by third parties
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is exploring the acquisition of third-party retail malls despite waiting for its sponsor's assets to be stabilized. The Reit's Q4 DPU declined 1.5% to 2.815 cents, but full-year DPU reached a record high of 11.764 cents. FCT's gross revenue fell 6% to S$44.62 million due to renovations and tenant exits at Northpoint and Changi City Point. The Reit remains focused on maintaining occupancy and rental rates, with a 9.9% improvement in average rental rates for renewed leases. FCT's pipeline assets include a one-third stake in Waterway Point and the retail component of Northpoint City.

images.alt_text: A 3.2 per cent increase in revenue contribution from the Causeway Point (above), FCT's largest mall, partially offset lower contributions from Northpoint and Changi City Point.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.8 points to 1,669.980. The index saw 1.44 billion lots valued at RM2.05 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 392 to 327.

site_title: World Bank revises upwards energy-price forecasts for 2017
summary: The World Bank has revised its 2017 energy-price forecast upwards, predicting a barrel of crude oil will reach US$55, in line with analysts' projections. Energy prices are expected to jump by almost a quarter next year, driven by oil prices averaging US$43 a barrel this year. The forecast also suggests a solid rise in energy prices could translate into general inflationary pressures in the medium term.

site_title: Edwin Low
summary: Edwin Low, founder of Supermama, has transformed his passion into a successful business with his signature Japanese-made, Singapore-designed ceramics. After a chance meeting with Japanese porcelain maker Kihara, Low's store vaulted into the forefront of Singapore designers. Despite initial struggles with insolvency, Low's calculated risks and business instincts have led to Supermama's success, including high-grade ceramics and collaborations with Japanese companies. Low credits Japanese traits such as pride, quality control, and long-term relationships for his success, and aspires to replicate Japan's retail scene in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Edwin Low at his Supermama flagship store on Beach Road. art direction chris foo. - PHOTOGRAPHY KEVIN YANG

site_title: US:Wall St drops on bleak GE outlook
summary: Wall Street fell sharply Friday morning due to GE's disappointing forecast and lowered revenue growth target, weighing on industrials stocks. The S&P 500 industrial index tumbled 1.17 percent to a three-month low. However, Microsoft and McDonald's strong quarterly results helped limit losses, with Microsoft surging 5.6 percent and McDonald's rising 3.10 percent. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 95.7 points, or 0.53 percent, at 18,066.65.

site_title: Hedge funds hurt as investors withdraw US$28b in 3 months
summary: Hedge funds have experienced a significant outflow of US$28 billion in the last three months, according to research firm Hedge Fund Research. This brings the total outflow for the year to over US$50 billion, with many of the industry's largest and best-known funds affected. The outflow is the largest quarterly outflow since the 2009 financial crisis. Investors' discontent and big losses have led to a "bruising year" for hedge funds, with some managers forced to rewrite their strategies or exit the industry.

images.alt_text: DIRE OUTLOOK: Billionaire hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb has told his investors that "we are in the first innings of a washout".

site_title: Triyards Q4 net profit down 73% to US$2.2m
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a 73% drop in Q4 net profit to US$2.23 million due to lower gross profit margins. Revenue grew 7% year-over-year to US$94.2 million. For FY2016, revenue increased 20% to US$324.89 million, but net profit fell 34% to US$17.79 million. The company cited a one-time non-recurring negative goodwill of US$3.6 million from FY2015. Triyards expects challenging market conditions for the oil-and-gas industry and continues to see interest in its diversified offerings.

site_title: More US bank-stress rules may be coming -Fed's Tarullo
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Daniel Tarullo suggests introducing more measures to test big banks' capital and liquidity levels to safeguard the financial system. The Fed may consider additional "macroprudential features" in its stress testing, following research on the effectiveness of existing regulations. Tarullo acknowledges the challenge of determining the right balance between regulations and financial stability, citing the need to monitor firms that may try to circumvent requirements. He believes the greatest risks to financial stability lie in activities vulnerable to funding runs and asset fire sales.

site_title: The special one feels the heat
summary: Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho faces a crucial test against Chelsea at Stamford Bridge, his first return to the club since being sacked last December. The Red Devils are seventh in the EPL table, five points behind rivals Manchester City and Arsenal, while Chelsea, under new manager Antonio Conte, aim to bolster their credentials. Mourinho's tactics may be compromised by fatigue, having played three games in six days, and Chelsea's recent form, with Eden Hazard and Diego Costa creating and scoring goals. A goalless draw is expected, with neither team willing to take risks, making for a dull but crucial match.

site_title: China: Stocks gain for second week as typhoon shuts Hong Kong
summary: Chinese stocks gained for the second week, driven by signs of a stabilizing economy and speculation of government spending boosts. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.2% on Friday, taking its weekly gain to 0.9%. Hong Kong markets were closed due to a typhoon. Infrastructure-related firms, such as China Railway Group Ltd and China State Construction Engineering Corp, led the gains. The gains outweigh concerns about a weakening currency.

site_title: PM Lee pays respects to late Thai King at Bangkok's Grand Palace
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong paid respects to the late Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej at Bangkok's Grand Palace on his second and final day of a visit to Thailand. He laid a white wreath at the Royal Urn and signed the book of condolences. The planned meeting with his Thai counterpart was cancelled due to scheduling difficulties. Lee returned to Singapore later in the day without taking questions from reporters.

site_title: Singapore shares close Friday lower; STI gains 0.6% for week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed lower on Friday, despite a 0.6% weekly gain, due to declining liquidity. The lack of market reaction to Hillary Clinton's third debate victory suggests investors have already priced in election outcomes and are focusing on earnings, the economy, and interest rates. This week's trading volume was the lowest in nine sessions, with 1.5 billion shares traded at S$736 million.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's Q3 DPU slides, but net property income rises 17.5%
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 17.5% increase in net property income to S$22.1 million in Q3, driven by rental contributions from DHL Supply Chain Advanced Regional Centre and Australian properties. Gross revenue rose 21.2% to S$28 million, while DPU decreased 1.3% to S$16.6 million. The decline in DPU was offset by higher property-related expenses from multi-talented leases.

site_title: Baby boomers swap Corvettes for comfort as sports-car sales fall
summary: Baby boomers, born between 1946 and 1964, are outgrowing their midlife crisis years, leading to a decline in sports car sales. Automakers like Ford, Chevrolet, and Porsche are seeing a drop in sales of models like the Mustang, Camaro, Corvette, and Porsche coupes. This shift is attributed to baby boomers' increasing focus on comfort and practicality, with many opting for luxury SUVs instead. As a result, sports car sales are expected to shrink, with some manufacturers promoting alternative models with sporty features.

site_title: Maintaining an investment portfolio
summary: A 35-year-old marketing executive, Ivan, invests $40,000 in a retirement portfolio with a goal to grow to $120,000 in 20 years. He aims for an average portfolio return of 5.7% per year. Ivan's portfolio will be reviewed and rebalanced every six months to ensure it remains aligned with his risk profile and investment objectives. The portfolio will be diversified across equity and fixed income funds, with geographic diversification across Asia, Europe, and the US. Regular reviews and rebalancing will help Ivan achieve his long-term investment goals.

site_title: Semua Shipping ceasing operations, says Hoe Leong Corp
summary: Semua Shipping, a subsidiary of Malaysian oil tanker and transport logistics company Semua International, has ceased operations and will dispose of its vessels. The deal to sell 100% equity interest in Semua Shipping to R&A Telecommunication Group was cancelled after the parties agreed not to proceed. Hoe Leong Corp, which has a stake in Semua International, will review the financial impact of this decision in its Q3 FY16 quarterly results.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Committee for Private Education (CPE) in Singapore introduced measures to boost the private education sector standards, focusing on student protection and information transparency.

site_title: Reshuffle looms as Greek PM, sagging in polls, seeks debt relief
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is considering a cabinet reshuffle to boost popularity and secure debt relief from international lenders. The move aims to sideline ministers opposing key reforms, including Energy Minister Panos Skourletis, and appease austerity-jaded Greeks. A reshuffle would be a test of Tsipras's balancing act between implementing painful reforms and boosting his Syriza party's popularity, which has been sagging. A bailout review, including labor reforms and privatisations, has started in Athens, with Tsipras set to discuss it with European counterparts.

site_title: Princess Diaries
summary: In 1970, Crown Prince Akihito and Crown Princess Michiko's first official state visit to Singapore sparked a lasting fascination with Japan. During their visit, the royal couple planted a cycad tree in the Japanese Garden and paid a courtesy call on President Yusof Ishak. The Crown Princess, known for her kimono poise and pedigree, set in motion a trend that continues to this day, with Singapore's interest in Japanese culture showing no signs of stopping. This visit marked a significant moment in Singapore-Japan relations, forever changing the country's perception of Japan.

images.alt_text: BY AVANTI NIM. IMAGE YUSOF ISHAK COLLECTION, COURTESY OF NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF SINGAPORE

site_title: Straits Trading sells office building in Australia for A$161.5m
summary: Straits Trading Company has sold its Melbourne office building for A$161.5 million (S$171.8 million) to AFIAA Australia 4 Pty Ltd. The 26-storey building offers 21,010.8 square meters of office space and was valued at A$134 million as of June 30, 2016. The sale price represents a premium of A$27.5 million over its valuation.

site_title: Credit Suisse to pay 109.5m Euros in Italy tax probe
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to pay 109.5 million euros (S$166 million) to Italian authorities to end a tax probe into the bank's alleged use of insurance policies to help clients evade taxes. The bank will pay 8.5 million euros in administrative fines and 101 million euros in taxes, interest, and penalties. The probe, which began in 2005, involved around 4,000 clients hiding up to 8 billion euros in illicitly earned funds. This settlement removes another legal hurdle for the bank, which previously paid a US$2.6 billion fine for helping Americans evade taxes.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group AG agreed to pay 109.5 million euros (S$166 million) to Italian authorities investigating the bank's past use of insurance policies, allegedly to help clients evade taxes.

site_title: African banks failing coast to coast show spreading distress
summary: African banks are facing significant distress, with more failing as bad debt and slowing economies take a toll. The collapse of a Ugandan bank has added to the woes, with regulators suspending its board and taking over operations. Several other countries, including Nigeria, Kenya, Zambia, and Mozambique, have also taken action against their banks. Experts predict more failures, particularly in Nigeria, and warn of a broader African banking crisis, with consolidation and liberalization needed to address the issue.

site_title: McDonald's sales beat estimates as turnaround gathers pace
summary: McDonald's Corp reported strong sales growth in the latest quarter, beating analysts' estimates. Same-restaurant sales in the US rose 1.3%, driven by demand for all-day breakfast and promotions. Global sales at restaurants open at least 13 months increased 3.5%, beating expectations. The company also reported net income of $1.28 billion and earned $1.62 per share, excluding items. Total revenue fell 3% to $6.42 billion, but beat analyst estimates. McDonald's shares rose 4% in premarket trading following the positive earnings report.

images.alt_text: McDonald's Corp's turnaround gained momentum in the latest quarter as sales growth at established restaurants beat analysts' estimates, sending the company's shares up almost 4 per cent in premarket trading on Friday.

site_title: PM Lee pays respects to late Thai King in Bangkok
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong paid respects to Thailand's late King Bhumibol Adulyadej at Bangkok's Grand Palace on October 21, 2016, presenting a white wreath at the palace where the King's body lay pending completion of religious rites.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong paid his respects to Thailand's late Bhumibol Adulyadej at Bangkok's Grand Palace on Friday.

site_title: China to encourage banks to help fund rural pollution fight
summary: China has introduced guidelines to encourage banks to provide financing for rural environmental treatment projects, aiming to tackle mounting pollution issues in rural regions. The government aims to treat 60% of livestock waste and 90% of rural household waste by 2020, but currently bears the entire cost burden for water treatment and transmission infrastructure. The move aims to address the "weak link" in China's war on pollution, which has mainly focused on industrialized regions.

site_title: China's yuan crosses 6.76 level, weakest for 6 years
summary: China's yuan hit a fresh six-year low against the US dollar, crossing the 6.76 level, due to strong US dollar purchases and rising US dollar index to a seven-month high. The spot yuan reached 6.7606 per US dollar and lost 0.2% against the US dollar for the day, and 0.5% for the week. China's central bank considers the official market closing price in fixing the official guidance rate, allowing market forces to play a bigger role in determining the yuan's value.

site_title: Banks warn share tax hike threatens Paris' post-Brexit appeal
summary: France's lower house of parliament approved a proposed increase in the country's share tax to 0.3% from 0.2%, threatening the Paris financial center's post-Brexit appeal. The tax hike, which also extends to intra-day trading, has been criticized by financial sector lobbies, including the French banking federation, as a "bad signal" for the city's attractiveness. The government aims to attract businesses leaving London, but the high taxes remain an obstacle. The tax increase is expected to raise 500 million euros in additional tax revenue, but its impact on investors is unknown.

site_title: China Medical buys 51% stake in The Sloane Clinic for S$9.5m
summary: China Medical (International) Group has acquired a 51% stake in The Sloane Clinic, a Singapore and Malaysia-based aesthetic and plastic surgery chain, for S$9.5 million. This is China Medical's first acquisition, following a business strategy revamp in 2015. The acquisition gives China Medical a significant presence in the Singapore and Malaysia aesthetics market. The deal involves purchasing shares in two medical services companies, Eastlife and Maxglobe, which operate under The Sloane Clinic brand.

site_title: Update: Malaysia unveils prudent budget, aims to cut deficit
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak unveiled a prudent budget, aiming to cut the country's large fiscal deficit and debt burden. The total budget for 2017 is RM260.8 billion, a 3.4% increase from the previous year. Najib pledged not to raise the good and services tax (GST), and expects growth to pick up marginally to 4-5% and the budget deficit to be 3% of GDP. This move is seen as reassuring markets, despite the country's economic challenges posed by the slump in global crude prices.

site_title: UBS's currency trading volume hit record as pound crashed
summary: UBS processed a record number of currency trades during the pound's flash crash on October 7, with a peak volume 50% higher than its previous record. The pound plummeted 6% against the US dollar in just two minutes before recovering. The Swiss bank's system handled the surge smoothly, and market participants blamed human error and thin liquidity for the swings. The pound's performance is attributed to the UK's vote to leave the EU and is expected to continue due to market volatility and central bank policies.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch higher, led by Valeo, Yara
summary: European shares rose 0.2% in early trading on Friday, supported by a weaker euro and strong results from Valeo and Yara. This follows a two-week high set after dovish remarks from European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index is down 5.7% for the year.

site_title: CMT Q3 DPU takes a tumble
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 6.7% decline in third-quarter distribution per unit to 2.78 Singapore cents, down from 2.98 cents in the previous year. Distributable income fell 4.7% to S$98.4 million, while gross revenue grew 4.9% to S$169.7 million. Net property income increased 5.5% to S$119.5 million. CMT units closed at S$2.11, down a cent from the previous day.

site_title: Philippines' relationship with other countries will not cool down
summary: Philippines' budget minister, Benjamin Diokno, stated that the country's warming ties with China do not mean its relationships with other countries are cooling down. This comes after President Rodrigo Duterte announced his "separation" from Washington and plans to visit Tokyo next week. Diokno emphasized that the Philippines is open to any form of assistance, but will choose offers that benefit the country, indicating a shift in foreign policy priorities.

site_title: Thailand's Bank of Ayudhya books 11% Q3 profit rise
summary: Thailand's Bank of Ayudhya reported a 10.6% increase in quarterly net profit to 5.83 billion baht, driven by strong loan growth from retail clients. The bank raised its 2016 loan target range to 8-9% and posted a 7.7% lending growth in the first nine months. Non-performing loans fell to 2.10% of total loans, a new low since the Asian financial crisis. Bank of Ayudhya shares rose 2% after the earnings announcement, outperforming the Thai stock market.

site_title: Trump gets booed as he and Clinton trade barbs at fundraiser
summary: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton engaged in a heated exchange at a New York white-tie fundraiser, trading barbs just weeks before the November 8 election. Trump's jokes drew boos, with his attempts at self-deprecation falling flat. Clinton responded with lighthearted jabs, including a dig at Trump's views on women and his discomfort with teleprompters. The event, meant to bring levity to the campaign, instead highlighted the intense rivalry between the two candidates, with the fundraiser raising approximately $6 million for Catholic charities.

site_title: Bombardier to scrap 7,500 more jobs as CEO deepens cost cuts
summary: Bombardier Inc will cut an additional 7,500 jobs, over 10% of its workforce, as part of a restructuring plan to accelerate cost cuts and improve competitiveness. The Montreal-based company, which took on billions of dollars in debt developing its C Series jetliner, expects to yield $300 million in annual savings by 2018. CEO Alain Bellemare, hired in 2015 to restore profitability, is working to overcome cost overruns and a two-and-a-half-year delay on the $6 billion C Series program. The plan will result in $225-275 million in restructuring charges.

site_title: Philippine minister "clarifies" Duterte comments, says trade ties with US to stay
summary: Philippine Trade Minister Ramon Lopez clarified President Rodrigo Duterte's comments about the country's separation from the US, stating that trade and economic ties with the US will remain intact. Duterte earlier announced his "separation" from Washington in Beijing, but Lopez clarified that this was not a formal separation. The US Embassy expressed concerns about the uncertainty, but Lopez assured that trade and investment with the US will continue. The Philippines aims to diversify its economy and reduce dependence on a single country.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall, Nintendo dives on new console reveal
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.30% on Friday, snapping a five-day winning streak, amid investors locking in profits. Nintendo's new console reveal left markets underwhelmed, causing the company's stock to dive. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 17,184.59, while the Topix index fell 0.40% to 1,365.29. The decline marked a departure from the previous day's gains, as investors opted to lock in profits ahead of potential market volatility.

site_title: Hot stock: QAF rises in active trade
summary: QAF Ltd, the Australian pork producer, rose 0.81% to S$1.24 per share on the Singapore Exchange, with over 57 million shares traded. The company's net profit for the second quarter more than doubled to S$28.8 million, driven by an exceptional gain from the sale of its stake in Gardenia Bakeries. Revenue fell 17% to S$208.4 million. QAF expects to perform satisfactorily in the third quarter.

site_title: Halcyon Agri's offer to privatise GMG Global extended to Nov 8
summary: Halcyon Agri's offer to privatize GMG Global has been extended to November 8, from October 21. The offer, which includes 0.9333 Halcyon shares for every GMG share, has been extended by 2.5 weeks. Halcyon Agri, majority-owned by China's Sinochem International Corp, is seeking to consolidate its natural rubber businesses under Halcyon. As of October 20, Halcyon Agri held 88.64% of GMG shares.

site_title: Draghi's 'did not discuss' leaves investors filling blanks
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's cautious comments on Thursday's meeting left investors uncertain about the future of the ECB's quantitative easing program. The ECB's stimulus strategy remained unchanged, but Draghi hinted that the decision on extending or adjusting the program would be made at the December meeting. Investors are speculating about various parameters, including future rate cuts, bond-buying, and tapering, which may be decided by the end of 2017. The uncertainty is exacerbated by global economic and political risks, including the UK's Brexit and Italy's constitutional referendum, which may impact the ECB's decisions.

site_title: Mercedes car profits help lift Daimler Q3, offsetting trucks slump
summary: Daimler's Q3 operating profit rose to 4.01 billion euros, driven by higher earnings from Mercedes passenger cars, which saw a 11.4% return on sales. The increase offset a slump in truck sales, keeping the company on track to meet its guidance for a small increase in full-year profit. This follows the success of the new E-class sales, contributing to the company's adjusted full-year group Ebit forecast to slightly beat 2015 levels.

site_title: Singapore Sept headline CPI seen falling for 23rd month: poll
summary: Singapore's consumer price index (CPI) is expected to have fallen 0.2% in September from a year ago, marking the 23rd consecutive month of decline. The rate of decline is expected to moderate from recent months, with core CPI forecast to rise 1% year-over-year. The central bank's core inflation measure, excluding car and accommodation prices, is also expected to rise 1% year-over-year. The decline is attributed to lower global oil prices and falls in housing rents and private transport costs.

site_title: iPhone7 hits Korean stores in Note 7's absence
summary: The Apple iPhone 7 launched in South Korea, filling the void left by Samsung's Note 7, which was recalled due to reports of combustible models. The Note 7's discontinuation is expected to cost Samsung billions in lost profits. Pre-orders for the iPhone 7 sold out within 15 minutes, with long-time Apple users taking advantage of the opportunity. The move is seen as a victory for Apple, which is now reaping some of the benefits from Samsung's misfortune, particularly in the premium handset market.

site_title: Ericsson Q3 sees fall in North American sales, more cost cuts
summary: Ericsson reported a 8% decline in North American sales in the third quarter, mainly due to a customer's reduction in mobile broadband investments. This decline follows a profit warning last week and is part of the company's efforts to cut costs in response to a weaker mobile broadband market. Year-on-year sales in Europe, India, and mainland China also declined. The company plans to introduce further cost-cutting measures to address the challenges.

images.alt_text: Mobile telecom equipment maker Ericsson on Friday said sales in its biggest market, North America, declined in the third quarter, highlighting the depth of its crisis following its profit warning last week.

site_title: Oil prices stable as strong US dollar weighs, but market tightens
summary: Oil prices remained stable on Friday, influenced by a stronger US dollar and signs of a tightening market. US West Texas Intermediate crude traded at $50.59 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose to $51.45 per barrel. Despite a surge in US dollar, physical fuel markets showed confidence due to stabilizing demand, peaking Opec production, and declining global inventories. Opec plans to implement a 500,000 to 1 million barrels per day production cut, forecasting a potential return to $60 per barrel in 2017 and $70 per barrel in 2018.

site_title: Australia shares end down as Healthscope dives; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,430.3, dragged down by a profit warning from healthcare company Healthscope Ltd. A stronger US dollar also weighed on oil prices, pulling down energy shares. The US dollar rose to seven-month highs against a basket of currencies, while the euro fell to its lowest since March. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell for the second consecutive week, losing 0.1% this week.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks edge down on ECB decision
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.7% to 1,134.9 won per US dollar after the European Central Bank hinted at adding more stimulus in December. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed 0.4% lower at 2,033.00 points, marking a third straight week of losses. Foreign investors bought a net 46 billion won worth of Kospi shares, contributing to a 0.5% weekly gain for the shares, but a 0.7% decline for the won.

site_title: Amsterdam's US$10,000-a-night hotel anchors hip new district
summary: Amsterdam's Noord district has undergone a significant transformation with the redevelopment of a 22-story high-rise building, A'dam Tower, formerly the headquarters of Royal Dutch Shell. The building now features a hotel, restaurants, offices, and entertainment spaces, including a revolving restaurant with 120-euro tasting menus. The tower's renovation, which began in 2014, aims to create a 24-hour economy, attracting visitors and locals alike. The district's growth is attributed to the EYE Film Museum and cinema, which opened in 2012, and the recent openings of a music and performance space, a youth hostel, and new offices and condominiums.

site_title: First Prince music to be released posthumously
summary: Prince's label, Warner Brothers Records, will release the first posthumous music, including a 40-track greatest hits collection "Prince 4Ever" and an unreleased 1982 track "Moonbeam Levels", on November 25. The album will also feature a 12-page book of photographs. A second album of previously unreleased material, to accompany Prince's 1984 classic "Purple Rain", will be reissued next year. The releases come as Prince's estate moves forward with a business plan, with a tribute concert held in Minnesota last month to offer closure after his sudden death in April 2016.

site_title: China to surpass US as world's largest aviation market by 2024
summary: China is projected to surpass the US as the world's largest aviation market by 2024, with 927 million annual passengers by 2025, doubling from 487 million in 2016. The Asia-Pacific region, driven by China's growth, is expected to account for most of the surge in global passenger travel. Boeing forecasts a need for over 15,000 new planes and half a million new pilots and technicians in the region over the next 20 years.

site_title: Japan's Asahi Glass Co opens innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Japan's Asahi Glass Co has opened an innovation centre in Singapore to develop new solutions for the region, focusing on fluorochemical products used in various sectors. The Application Development Centre will provide technical support, transfer advanced technologies, and develop new products meeting regional demand. This move aims to deliver better service to Asia-Pacific customers and expand the company's capabilities in the region.

site_title: Malaysia hopes for faster growth, lower budget deficit in 2017
summary: Malaysia expects its economy to grow 4-5% in 2017, driven by domestic demand and a recovery in global commodities prices, particularly oil. The government projects a budget deficit of 3% of GDP, a slight improvement from 3.1% in 2016. The country's current account surplus is expected to shrink to RM14.8 billion, and total government debt is forecast to decrease to 53.2% of GDP. The government attributes the improved outlook to sustained demand for electrical and electronic goods, as well as a stable inflation rate.

site_title: Secura partners tertiary institutions to set up cybersecurity R&D laboratory
summary: Secura Group has partnered with Republic Polytechnic, the University of Glasgow, and the University of Glasgow Singapore to establish a joint cybersecurity R&D laboratory. The facility will focus on topics such as IoT, data analytics, and Industry 4.0, with an estimated S$10 million investment over the next three years. Secura chief Paul Lim hopes the collaboration will foster the cybersecurity ecosystem and create unique products and solutions.

images.alt_text: Catalist-listed security company Secura Group on Friday said that it will partner Republic Polytechnic (RP), the University of Glasgow (UOFG), the University of Glasgow Singapore (UGS) to establish a joint facility for research and development (R&D) in cybersecurity.

site_title: Euro falls to lowest since March as Draghi guarded on QE course
summary: The euro fell to its lowest since March, dropping 0.2% to $1.0904, as European Central Bank President Mario Draghi indicated quantitative easing won't end abruptly, leaving traders waiting until December for policy changes. This move has traders pricing in a weaker euro, with predictions of a potential drop to $1.0830. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index added 0.1%, while futures traders see a 68% probability of a US interest rate hike by December.

images.alt_text: The euro fell to its lowest since March after Mario Draghi signalled Thursday quantitative easing won't come to an "abrupt" end.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Hong Kong closed while Shanghai opens flat
summary: Chinese stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Shanghai Composite Index slipping 0.10% to 3,081.39 and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipping 0.06% to 2,059.08. Hong Kong markets were closed due to Typhoon Haima.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks retreat on profit-taking, TSMC slips
summary: Taiwan's stocks retreated on Friday due to profit-taking, with the main Taiex index down 0.2% at 9,301.87 points. TSMC, the world's top contract chip maker, slipped 0.5% despite its recent gains. The Taiwan dollar also weakened, losing NT$0.147 to NT$31.677 per US dollar. The decline followed a previous session's record high for the Taiex index, which touched its highest in over 15 months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday with a slight increase in the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index to 1668.03 points. Volume reached 26.2 million lots worth RM7.6 million, with 74 gainers outnumbering 53 losers.

site_title: Gold heads for first weekly gain in four as ETF holdings expand
summary: Gold prices rose for the first time in four weeks, gaining 1.1% to $1,264.61 an ounce, as investors boosted holdings in exchange-traded funds backed by the metal. The metal has rallied 19% this year, driven by the Federal Reserve's caution over interest rate hikes. Gold-backed ETFs expanded for a seventh day, reaching 2,059.6 metric tons, the highest level since June 2013, as the European Central Bank maintained its stimulus strategy unchanged.

site_title: Australia shares down as Healthscope sinks; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday, led by a 26% drop in Healthscope Ltd following a profit warning, and energy stocks declined 1% as oil prices slid due to a resurgent US dollar. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% as consumer discretionary stocks led the decline.

site_title: Magnitude 6.6 quake jolts western Japan, no tsunami warning or immediate damage
summary: A magnitude 6.6 earthquake struck western Japan on October 20, 2016, with its epicenter in Tottori prefecture at a depth of 10 km. Although a tsunami warning was not issued, roughly 40,000 households were left without power. There were no immediate reports of injuries or major damage. The earthquake was followed by a weaker aftershock about 30 minutes later, and nuclear plant irregularities were not reported.

site_title: 21,000 women for biggest miner to reach gender goal
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's top miner, aims to reach a gender balance of 50% in its workforce by 2025, with 21,000 additional women needed to achieve this goal. The company currently has an 18% female workforce, and CEO Andrew Mackenzie acknowledges the need for more initiatives to address the industry's long-standing male-dominated culture. To achieve this goal, BHP plans to feature counter-stereotypical images, develop flexible work options, and mitigate bias in its policies and processes.

site_title: New measures to boost private education sector standards introduced
summary: Singapore's Committee for Private Education (CPE) has introduced measures to strengthen the private education sector, including a minimum paid-up capital of S$100,000 and a minimum credit rating by June 1 next year. Existing private education institutions must participate in the annual graduate employment survey and obtain EduTrust certification for external degrees. New EduTrust standards, set to be released in January 2017, will require a four-year enhanced registration framework before applying for the quality mark. The measures aim to boost student protection and information transparency.

site_title: ANZ bank to cut about 30 jobs in institutional banking division
summary: ANZ Bank is cutting approximately 30 jobs in its institutional banking division, primarily in customer relationship roles based in New York, London, and Asia. The move is part of the bank's restructuring efforts to simplify its business and reduce low-returning assets, with improving productivity seen as crucial in a low-growth environment. This decision follows the bank's previous reduction of 300 jobs in Singapore and its commitment to maintaining an institutional banking presence across 14 Asian countries.

images.alt_text: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, Australia's third-biggest bank by market value, is cutting about 30 jobs in its institutional banking unit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending gains after reaching a six-month high the previous day. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.23%, while the Topix index gained 0.08%. Nintendo's stock plummeted 5% after revealing a new console.

site_title: Asia: Stocks set to end strong week as Japan exporters advance
summary: Asian stocks are poised to end a strong week as commodity producers drive gains, following Chinese economic growth data and investor expectations of a December interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Japan's exporters advanced, and the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose 1.4% for the week, with commodity producers leading the rally. Investors are bracing for the US presidential election and the Fed's potential rate hike, with Microsoft's earnings beating expectations.

site_title: Qantas warns intense competition on "kangaroo route" is lowering fares
summary: Qantas reports that airfares on international routes, particularly the "kangaroo route" between Australia and London, have fallen below pre-12-month levels due to increased competition. More than 30 airlines operate this route, resulting in extremely low fares. Qantas CEO Alan Joyce stated that London is a challenging market, but declined to comment on the route's profitability. The airline's warning highlights the intense competition in the global airline industry.

site_title: Google hawks hardware in real-world 'showroom'
summary: Google has opened its first real-world "showroom" in New York, offering hands-on experience with its new Pixel smartphones and other devices, including a virtual reality headset and a smart home assistant. The temporary store aims to challenge Apple's dominance in the market and test the feasibility of Google's brick-and-mortar retail operation. The pop-up shop, which will be open until the end of the year, showcases Google's artificial intelligence prowess and offers customers a unique experience, despite only a few visitors on its opening day.

site_title: Typhoon kills 12, destroys rice fields in Philippines, takes aim at Hong Kong
summary: Typhoon Haima, the strongest storm to hit the Philippines in three years, has killed at least 12 people and destroyed thousands of hectares of rice and corn fields in northern provinces. The storm, which is now heading towards Hong Kong, has left authorities assessing damage to infrastructure and crops. Eight of the victims were from the Cordillera region, according to reports from provincial officials.

images.alt_text: Typhoon Haima, the strongest storm to hit the Philippines in three years, killed at least 12 people and inundated vast tracts of rice and corn fields, officials in Manila said on Friday, before it took aim at Hong Kong.
