site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index up 0.16 points to 2,842.46. Trading volumes were high, with 51.2 million shares changing hands worth S$52.3 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 59 to 58, with LionGold and InnoPac being the most actively traded counters. The previous day, the Straits Times Index rose 0.4%, driven by investors' optimism despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Triyards, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, City Developments Limited, Keppel Corp
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a 73% fall in net profit to US$2.23 million for Q4 2016 due to lower gross profit margins. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Q4 distribution fell 1.5% to 2.815 Singapore cents, while City Developments Limited agreed to exit a luxury residential development for S$977.6 million. Keppel Corp posted a 38% drop in Q3 net profit to S$225 million due to cheap oil and overcapacity.

site_title: How mobile payment tech is transforming the way we buy
summary: Mobile payment technology is revolutionizing the way people buy goods and services. Consumers now expect seamless, cross-channel, and consistent shopping experiences, driving demand for digital and mobile payment solutions. According to Accenture's report, Asia is at the forefront of this shift, with consumers moving towards solutions that ease the purchasing process. Mobile commerce offers convenience, speed, and security, with over 80% of Singaporean consumers recognizing its benefits. Businesses that adopt mobile payment technology can gain a competitive edge, particularly by leveraging key moments in the purchasing cycle to turn browsers into buyers.

images.alt_text: Digital and mobile technology has transformed not only how products are discovered by consumers, but how they are paid for.

site_title: Saying 'no' to China just cost Australia US$3.3b
summary: Australia sold a 50.4% stake in power network Ausgrid to two local funds for A$20.8 billion, after the federal government barred a Chinese offer valuing the asset at A$25.1 billion due to national security concerns. The deal, worth A$16.2 billion in gross proceeds, was valued at 1.4 times Ausgrid's regulated asset base, compared to 1.7 times offered by State Grid Corp of China. The sale highlights the cost of limiting foreign investment and has raised doubts about Australia's openness to foreign investment.

site_title: Venezuela elections body suspends recall vote against Maduro
summary: Venezuela's government suspended a planned recall vote against President Nicolas Maduro after four local courts ruled to put the process on hold due to allegations of fraud. The National Electoral Council stated that a signature collection effort was "paralysed" pending clarification from the courts. The recall vote was scheduled for next week and was intended to remove Maduro from office. The suspension is the latest in a series of challenges to Maduro's rule.

images.alt_text: Venezuela's government suspended a referendum process against President Nicolas Maduro late Thursday after four local courts ruled to put the process on hold.

site_title: Obama calls for 'big' win to repudiate 'dangerous' Trump
summary: President Barack Obama criticized Donald Trump for suggesting he may not accept the election result if he loses, calling it a "dangerous" claim that undermines democracy. Trump stated he would accept the result if he wins but reserve the right to contest a "questionable" outcome. Obama and his wife Michelle urged voters not to fall for the Trump campaign's allegations of rigging, saying they are trying to take away hope. The election has become a test of democratic norms and voter engagement, with polls showing Hillary Clinton leading by a significant margin.

site_title: China home prices rise in fewer cities amid tougher curbs
summary: China's home prices rose in 63 of 70 cities in September, excluding government-subsidized housing, but at a slower pace than in August. Authorities have introduced curbs in 21 cities to cool prices, including larger down-payments and multiple dwelling limits. This may provide relief to policy makers seeking to avert a housing bubble. The property market's slowdown could help China achieve its 6.5-7% growth target for the year.

site_title: Thai junta fines former PM Yingluck, orders assets seized over failed rice scheme
summary: Thailand's ousted Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has been fined 35 billion baht (S$1.4 billion) and had her assets seized by the military junta over a failed rice subsidy scheme. The scheme, which paid farmers above market rates for their rice, was a flagship policy of Yingluck's administration and helped sweep her to office in 2011. Yingluck is now fighting the charges in court, with her supporters claiming the case is part of a military plan to wipe out the influence of the Shinawatra family.

images.alt_text: Thailand's ousted prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra said the military junta that overthrew her has ordered her assets seized and fined her 35 billion baht (S$1.4 billion) over a rice subsidy scheme critics say haemorrhaged billions of dollars.

site_title: Australian dollar nurses losses after jobs setback, NZ ticks lower
summary: The Australian dollar fell 1.3% to US$0.7630 on Thursday, its worst performance in five weeks, following a poor employment report that fueled concerns of further rate cuts. The decline was partly due to dovish comments by the Reserve Bank of Australia in its October policy meeting minutes. Despite this, the Aussie is expected to end the week mostly unchanged.

site_title: Triyards Q4 net profit down 73% to US$2.2m
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a 73% decline in Q4 2016 net profit to US$2.23 million, mainly due to lower gross profit margins. Revenue grew 7% year-over-year to US$94.2 million. For FY 2016, revenue increased 20% to US$324.89 million, while net profit fell 34% to US$17.79 million. The company expects market conditions for the oil and gas industry to remain challenging, with continued margin pressure, despite seeing continued interest in its diversified offerings.

site_title: JPMorgan facing criticism on valuation of complex bonds it sold
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is facing criticism for inflating the value of complex bonds it sold to individual investors by up to 15% in some cases. A study by Securities Litigation & Consulting Group found that the bank failed to account for fees associated with indexes that determined payouts on the securities. The consulting firm analyzed $253.7 million in structured notes sold by JPMorgan between 2011 and 2014, finding that some were sold with inflated valuations. The issue has raised concerns about individual investors' ability to understand fair prices for these securities.

site_title: Duterte goodbye to US swelling costs on US$42b bonds
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's decision to distance himself from the US has led to a surge in borrowing costs for the country. The peso fell 0.3% after Duterte announced "goodbye" to the US, and foreign-currency notes issued by the Philippines lost 2.3% in value, the worst among developing nations. Analysts predict a widening in sovereign yield premiums, with some estimating a 50 basis point increase. The decision is seen as a response to criticism from the US and European Union over Duterte's war on drugs, which has resulted in over 3,000 deaths.

site_title: Syrian military says will "bring down" any Turkish war planes in its air space
summary: The Syrian military stated that it will "bring down" any Turkish war planes entering its airspace, in response to air strikes carried out by Turkey in northern Syria overnight. The statement was released by the Syrian army general command.

site_title: Obama says Trump fraud claim 'undermines our democracy'
summary: President Barack Obama criticized Donald Trump's claims of a rigged election, calling them "dangerous" and "corrosive for democracy." Obama urged a "big" win for Hillary Clinton to leave no doubt about the result. Trump's suggestion to not concede despite losing at a debate made Obama say it's "not a joking matter."

site_title: Nintendo gives sneak geek peak at new portable console
summary: Nintendo unveiled the Nintendo Switch, a portable console that can be played at home and on the go, with a removable screen and detachable controllers. The hybrid machine is set to be released in March 2017 and will be powered by cartridges rather than discs. The company's shares soared 4.40% after the announcement, as the Switch is seen as a key product to boost Nintendo's bottom line and offset the disappointing demand for its Wii U console. Several major game developers have partnered with Nintendo for the Switch, including Activision and Ubisoft.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips after ECB meeting, stocks also down
summary: The South Korean won slipped 0.5% against the US dollar after the European Central Bank left room for further stimulus at its October meeting. The US dollar gained support from stronger-than-expected US home sales data. The won was quoted at 1,133.0 as of 0151 GMT, down from Thursday's close of 1,127.5. The move came despite the won's recent rally, which was attributed to investors' positive sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Alibaba expects to top Singles' Day record with new products
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd expects to surpass the record US$14.3 billion in sales from last year's Singles' Day with new activities such as virtual fashion shows and augmented reality games. The company aims to create a social experience that engages shoppers beyond just sales, with celebrity appearances and live streaming events. Alibaba is also investing in rural regions and international markets to find new revenue sources amid slowing consumer demand in China.

site_title: Hanjin in talks to sell terminal stake to Mediterranean Shipping
summary: Hanjin Shipping, South Korea's largest container line, is in talks to sell its 54% stake in the Long Beach Port terminal in California to Mediterranean Shipping Co. The sale, valued at approximately $122 million, is part of Hanjin's efforts to raise funds for debt reduction. Mediterranean Shipping, the world's second-largest container line, has the first right to purchase the stake. This sale is part of Hanjin's restructuring plan, which aims to raise $122 million by using the terminal stake as collateral.

site_title: May's ministers rush to smooth bankers' ruffled Brexit feathers
summary: Theresa May's government is making efforts to reassure bankers that it will fight for the finance industry's interests as the UK prepares to leave the European Union. Brexit Secretary David Davis and Trade Secretary Liam Fox have met with finance executives to address concerns over Britain's future relationship with the bloc. The government aims to balance curbing immigration with accessing the single market, which is crucial for London-based banks. A united front has been formed to defend the City of London as a "high priority" in Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Hong Kong delays stock trading as Typhoon Haima approaches
summary: Hong Kong's stock trading has been delayed due to Typhoon Haima's approach. The Hong Kong Observatory issued a No 8 gale or storm signal, with the third-highest warning expected to remain in force. Schools have been shut, and airlines warned of flight disruptions. The stock market delay will affect the morning session, with trading potentially cancelled if the warning remains in effect at 9am and closed for the day if the storm signal isn't lifted by noon.

site_title: Opec deal unlikely to lift oil prices for long, World Bank says
summary: The World Bank says Opec's deal to limit oil production is unlikely to lift oil prices for long due to the surge in production from shale-oil producers and other unconventional suppliers. Crude prices have surged over 7% since the deal was agreed on September 28. The rise of non-traditional supply sources, particularly US shale deposits, will constrain Opec's ability to control prices, limiting the impact of the production cut.

site_title: In global iron ore, Singapore is bossing China in setting prices
summary: Singapore's iron ore futures contracts, traded on the Singapore Exchange, have greater pricing power than those in China's Dalian Commodity Exchange, despite Singapore's lower volumes. According to Goldman Sachs, institutional investors account for a larger share of trade in Singapore, giving it more influence in setting global prices. This challenges China's efforts to develop its raw material futures markets as hubs for price-setting. The finding suggests that China's goal remains a distant one, with Singapore's contracts driving the market.

site_title: Tesla says it will roll out Uber-style ride services program
summary: Tesla plans to launch a ride-sharing service, dubbed the Tesla Network, allowing owners to share their vehicles with friends and family for revenue, but only through the program. The service was first outlined by CEO Elon Musk in July and is expected to be announced next year. The move aims to capture a share of the trillions of dollars in revenue from mobility services, but analysts have expressed financial concerns due to the high costs of building and maintaining an OEM-owned fleet.

site_title: Pentagon chief vows 'overwhelming' response to any North Korea nuke use
summary: Pentagon chief Ashton Carter vowed an "overwhelming" response if North Korea were to launch a nuclear weapon, following the country's failed medium-range missile test. The US strongly condemned the attempt, which violated UN Security Council resolutions. The US has deployed a missile-defense system to South Korea, and Carter reiterated the US's commitment to protecting its allies. Any nuclear use by North Korea would be met with a strong and effective response.

site_title: Didi president says China's ride-hailing giant is 'definitely going global'
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's ride-hailing giant, has announced plans to expand globally, with President Jean Liu stating "we're definitely going global." The company, valued at $35 billion, has already partnered with local players in India, the US, and Southeast Asia, and has acquired Uber's China operations. With a daily ride volume of over 20 million in China, Liu believes the industry is in its infancy stage and Didi will play a significant role in its global growth.

site_title: BHP chairman Nasser to step down as Brazil crisis eases
summary: BHP chairman Jacques Nasser announced he plans to step down after helping guide the world's largest mining company through the deadly Samarco tailings dam spill in Brazil. Nasser, 68, will not seek re-election to the board next year, citing the "basic structure" of BHP's response to the disaster as complete. The company has faced a downturn in commodities, but Nasser's leadership helped steer BHP to a 101% total return over the past decade, outperforming the UK's FTSE 100 Index. Nasser, who has been chairman since 2010, will remain on the board and has no desire to chase a new role.

site_title: CDL unit exits entire interest in Summervale Properties for S$977.6 million
summary: CDL exits entire interest in Summervale Properties for S$977.6 million, unlocking value in its luxury residential development, Nouvel 18. The transaction marks CDL's third Profit Participation Securities (PPS) platform and its first high-end residential project. CDL's wholly owned subsidiary, Trentwell Management, will manage and market the units, receiving an incentive fee upon meeting performance benchmarks. The deal allows Summervale to repay senior loans and notes, redeem PPS, and distribute the remainder to shareholders, including high net worth Singaporeans.

site_title: Oil holds above US$50 as Russia weighs boost, Nigeria cuts prices
summary: Oil prices held above US$50 a barrel as Russia's Rosneft PJSC said the country could boost production and Nigeria cut prices for its crude. Russia's largest oil company, Rosneft, stated its ability to increase production, following President Vladimir Putin's support for international output limits. Meanwhile, Nigeria lowered prices for all types of crude to boost its global market share. Oil futures rose 0.1% despite a 2.3% drop on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Oil held above US$50 a barrel even as Russia's largest oil company said the country could boost production and Nigeria lowered prices for its crude.

site_title: US confirms 11th death linked to faulty Takata air bag inflator
summary: US safety regulators confirmed an 11th death linked to a faulty Takata air bag inflator. The fatality, a 50-year-old woman, occurred in a 2001 Honda Civic that was first recalled in 2008 but never repaired. At least 16 deaths are now linked to the defect, which prompted a global recall of nearly 100 million air bag inflators by over a dozen automakers. The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) attributed the latest death to a ruptured inflator, highlighting the ongoing risks associated with the defective air bags.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust Q4 DPU slips 1.5% to 2.815 cents
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported a 1.5% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.815 cents in Q4 2016, down from 2.859 cents last year. The trust's distribution to unitholders fell 1.2% to S$25.9 million, while gross revenue decreased 6% to S$44.6 million. Despite a 3.2% increase in revenue from Causeway Point, Northpoint and Changi City Point contributed lower revenues due to asset enhancement initiatives and vacancy. Net property income declined 0.9% to S$31.4 million.

site_title: Police protests grow in France
summary: Protests against police violence are spreading across France, with demonstrators calling for reinforcements and stiffer penalties for officers attacked. The protests, which began after a series of attacks on police, have led to the French government seeking to contain growing anger. Prime Minister Manuel Valls has pledged support for police, while police unions are demanding a meeting with President Francois Hollande and fixed minimum sentences for attacks on officers. The protests are also linked to a string of Islamist-inspired attacks that have shocked France.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover and Ford test connected cars in Britain
summary: Jaguar Land Rover, Ford, and Tata Motors are testing connected cars in Britain, featuring technology that enables vehicles to communicate with each other and their surroundings. The trials aim to improve road safety and traffic flow. Jaguar Land Rover showcased a self-driving Range Rover Sport, while Ford and Volvo are working with Uber on trials of self-driving cars in the US. The UK government aims to have driverless cars on its roads by the end of the decade, with the automotive industry racing to develop autonomous vehicles to compete with tech firms like Google.

site_title: EU threatens Russia with sanctions over Syria
summary: EU leaders warned Russia at a summit that they will consider sanctions if Moscow stops "crimes" in Aleppo, Syria. EU President Donald Tusk stated that "all options are open, including sanctions" if the ceasefire is not respected. French President Francois Hollande also expressed concerns, saying that "all options are open" until Aleppo is protected. The EU is urging Russia to stop its role in the conflict, which has devastated the city.

images.alt_text: European Union leaders warned Russia at a summit on Thursday that they will consider sanctions over its role in the Syrian conflict if Moscow does not stop "crimes" in the devastated city of Aleppo.

site_title: Moscow slams US over arrest of alleged Russian hacker
summary: Moscow has criticized the US for arresting a Russian citizen, Yevgeny Nikulin, on suspicion of staging cyber attacks on the US. The arrest was made in collaboration with the FBI in Prague, with the Czech police. Russia's Foreign Ministry has vowed to fight Nikulin's extradition, citing US law enforcement's "political motivation" in targeting Russian citizens. The arrest comes amid tensions between the two countries, with the US accusing Russia of interfering in the 2016 White House election.

site_title: Investors seen hunting value in 1MDB-stricken Malaysian stocks
summary: Malaysian stocks, plagued by a scandal linked to 1MDB and weak profits, are attracting value investors amid bets on a rebound. Affin Hwang Asset Management Bhd's Gan Eng Peng has taken "big positions" in Sime Darby and CIMB Group Holdings, citing stabilizing earnings and an undervalued ringgit. Foreign funds are showing interest, with overseas brokers signaling unusual interest in Malaysia, driven by a desire to rebalance monies following strong outperformance in Indonesia and Thailand. Despite concerns, investors expect a 7-8% corporate earnings growth in 2017, leading to a 10% total return.

site_title: US dollar stands tall after dovish Draghi pressures euro
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro on Friday, tracking a weekly gain, following European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's dovish comments, which ruled out tapering of stimulus. The euro fell to a four-month low, while the US dollar index rose 0.1% to 98.369, up 0.4% for the week. The comments from Draghi also eased concerns about a US interest rate hike, which had been fueled by US data showing a surge in home resales. The dollar is poised to gain 0.5% for the week against the sterling.

images.alt_text: The US dollar stood tall in Asian trading on Friday, on track for a weekly gain against a basket of currencies, as the euro wallowed close to four-month lows after the European Central Bank quashed any speculation of tapering its stimulus.

site_title: US Treasury official urges move away from Libor
summary: US Treasury official Daleep Singh urges a transition to an alternative reference rate to Libor, citing its flaws and potential risks to financial markets. The Alternative Reference Rate Committee has identified two alternatives, the Overnight Bank Funding Rate and a Treasury GC repo-based rate. Singh warns that a disorderly transition could be costly and disruptive, and advocates for a transition before problems with Libor reach a critical point. This move aims to address concerns over Libor's reputation tarnished by manipulation and its potential impact on corporate treasurers, pension funds, and insurers.

site_title: Samsung in talks with LG Chem for new smartphone batteries
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is in talks with LG Chem Ltd to supply batteries for its new smartphones, following the fire-prone Note 7 debacle. The deal could start next year and comes as Samsung seeks to recover from a US$3 billion hit to its operating profit. Samsung SDI Co Ltd, the dominant battery supplier for the Note 7, will likely supply batteries to Samsung's new smartphones, marking a significant shift in the company's battery supply chain.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is in talks with LG Chem Ltd to supply batteries for its new smartphones, the Nikkei newspaper reported, citing sources.

site_title: BT Weekend gets into all things Japanese
summary: The Business Times' Weekend issue focuses on Singaporeans' obsession with Japanese culture, featuring an interview with Supermama's Edwin Low, who credits a chance meeting with Japanese potters for turning his business around. The issue also delves into millennials' spending habits, the benefits of overseas work experience, and the secret lives of BT staff. Additionally, lifestyle sections cover topics such as mod-Indian cuisine, zero-waste living, and financial literacy for women.

site_title: AT&T said to discuss takeover idea in Time Warner meetings
summary: AT&T and Time Warner executives have met to discuss potential business strategies, including a possible merger. Informal talks have focused on building relations, with neither side hiring a financial adviser. A merger would give AT&T access to Time Warner's popular programming, including HBO, NBA, and Cartoon Network. The talks are still in the early stages, and no specific terms or timeline have been established.

site_title: Tom Cruise brings action-packed "Jack Reacher" sequel to London
summary: Tom Cruise premiered his film "Jack Reacher: Never Go Back" in London, reprising his role as a former US military officer turned fugitive. The sequel, which also stars Cobie Smulders, follows Cruise's character on a mission to uncover a conspiracy. Fans gathered in Leicester Square to catch a glimpse of Cruise, and the film was described as a "classic action" film filled with suspense. The European premiere took place on October 20, 2016.

site_title: Philippine government has not asked to end ties to US
summary: The Philippine government has not requested the US to end security or economic ties between the two countries, according to a White House spokesman. The US and the Philippines have a long-standing bilateral cooperation, and the White House has not received any official requests from Filipino officials to alter this cooperation.

site_title: EU steps up calls for deals with Africa to curb migrants
summary: EU leaders at a summit are calling on Africa to boost its economic development in exchange for curbing migrant flows. Following a deal with Turkey, the EU is focusing on the central Mediterranean route from Libya to Italy. The draft statement asks EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini to report on progress with five African countries in reducing migrant arrivals and increasing returns by December.

site_title: Aussie employment surprisingly falls in September, stirs rate risk
summary: Australian employment unexpectedly fell 9,800 in September, with 53,000 full-time jobs cut, contrary to analyst forecasts. The unemployment rate remained at 5.6% due to a drop in participation, but the report may rekindle speculation of further rate cuts. The Reserve Bank of Australia may consider easing rates due to weak labor market indicators, with consumer price data set to be released next week.

site_title: Crown pushes on with hotel IPO as China detains staff
summary: Crown Resorts Ltd plans to proceed with an initial public offering of 49% of its Melbourne and Perth hotels, despite having 18 staff detained in China. The IPO will raise funds for development projects, allowing the company to maintain a strong balance sheet and credit profile. Crown Towers Melbourne will not be included in the offering. The move comes as the company seeks to diversify its revenue streams and support growth initiatives.

site_title: Dine in style
summary: The Business Times is celebrating its 40th Anniversary with exclusive dining deals at La Brasserie at The Fullerton Bay Hotel. Readers can enjoy a 35% discount on a la carte items from October 24-28. The Brasserie offers a classic dining experience with vintage furnishings and a stunning French panelling, serving dishes such as Provencal Lobster Bouillabaisse and La Brasserie Duck Confit. The offer is valid for both lunch and dinner, and can be found in the Business Times Weekend edition.

site_title: Yahoo, ACLU press US govt to disclose secret surveillance orders
summary: Yahoo and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) have asked the US government to disclose a secret surveillance order received by Yahoo in 2015, which allegedly required the company to scan all Yahoo Mail users' incoming messages to isolate specific data. The order was allegedly served under Title 1 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act and has not been publicly disclosed. The ACLU is seeking the release of the order and over 20 other significant rulings dating back to 2004, citing concerns over government hacking, encryption weakening, and bulk collection of financial records.

site_title: Microsoft shares hit high as cloud business flies above estimates
summary: Microsoft's shares rose 6.1% to an all-time high after reporting adjusted revenue and profit that exceeded analysts' estimates, driven by soaring sales from its cloud business. Revenue from Azure, its flagship cloud product, rose 116%, while the broader "Intelligent Cloud" business saw an 8.3% increase. Net income fell 4% to $4.69 billion, but the company still beat analyst estimates. This strong performance underscores Microsoft's shift towards cloud services and sets it apart from smaller rivals, with analysts predicting a significant market share in the cloud services industry.

site_title: Songwriting legend James Taylor makes Singapore date
summary: James Taylor, a renowned American singer-songwriter, will perform in Singapore on February 21, 2017, at The Star Theatre. Taylor, known for his soothing voice and hits like "Fire and Rain" and "Sweet Baby James," will bring an all-star band consisting of Steve Gadd, Michael Landau, and Luis Conte. This marks one of Taylor's many upcoming performances, following recent inclusions in the Kennedy Center Honors and Presidential Medal of Freedom.

site_title: Europe: Shares touch 2-week high as euro weakens, banks rally
summary: European shares rose to a two-week high, driven by a weak euro and a rally in bank stocks. The euro fell to a four-month low against the US dollar after the European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged. Banks such as Deutsche Bank, Royal Bank of Scotland, and Barclays rose 1.3-3.5% on positive results from US banks. However, shares in German engineering company GEA and British engineering companies Keller and Senior fell after profit warnings. The Stoxx 600 index ended up 0.2%, despite being down 5.8% for the year.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as Travelers, eBay tumble
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipping 0.2% to 18,162.35, as oil prices retreated and disappointing earnings from Travelers, Verizon, and eBay offset a strong report from American Express. Travelers fell 5.8% after reporting a 29.6% decline in third-quarter net profit, while eBay plummeted 10.8% due to disappointing sales outlook. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined 0.1% each, despite American Express's 9.0% gain.

site_title: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce turns around the airline, and his public image
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce has successfully turned around the airline after a three-year turnaround strategy, delivering record profits and dividends. Joyce hired bodyguards in 2011 after receiving death threats during an industrial dispute, but has since won over hostile customers and politicians. Qantas is targeting expansion in Asia, using "big data" for its frequent flyer business, and unveiling plans for new services and aircraft. Despite some lingering skepticism from unions, Joyce's turnaround has been exceptional, with Qantas shares tripling in value and customer satisfaction improving. Joyce has also used his positive profile to promote social causes, including marriage equality and women's progress.

site_title: 'Chinese Netflix' takes on tech titans in US
summary: LeEco, a Chinese tech giant, is entering the US smartphone market with lower-priced LePro 3 and Le S3 models, priced at $399 and $249 respectively, targeting rival tech titans like Apple and Amazon. The company aims to entice users with its online ecosystem offerings. LeEco's products will be available for purchase on its e-commerce website, LeMall.com, on November 2.

site_title: S$4.8b of SGD bonds redeemed early even as S$785m in default
summary: Singapore's SGD bond market is experiencing a downturn, with S$4.87 billion worth of bonds redeemed early this year, despite only S$785 million in defaults. Companies with strong balance sheets, such as CORDLIFE Group and Genting, are being affected, with prices falling to distressed levels. Experts attribute this to "collateral damage" from the market carnage, with investors seeking safer assets. Despite this, Singapore companies are still redeeming bonds ahead of maturity, with a focus on refinancing and call dates. The market is becoming increasingly challenging for investors, with limited options and a potential shift to other asset classes.

site_title: Films beyond mainstream fare aplenty this weekend
summary: Two independent film festivals, Perspectives Film Festival and Cartoons Underground, will take place in Singapore this weekend. Cartoons Underground, the first and largest independent animation festival, will showcase 20 hand-drawn cartoons from around the world, including Singapore, Israel, Turkey, China, and the US. The festival aims to promote alternative animation and provide a platform for studios to discover new talents. Meanwhile, Perspectives Film Festival will feature seven surrealist films, including classics like "Fantastic Planet" and "Eraserhead", and will explore the art of surrealist cinema.

site_title: Seletar Airport's new terminal can move up to 700,000 passengers
summary: Seletar Airport's new terminal, set to open by end-2018, will handle up to 700,000 passengers annually, freeing up capacity at Changi Airport. The two-storey terminal, spanning 9,500 sq m, will include a cafe, gate hold-room, and dedicated areas for business jets and private jets. The upgrade will also reduce bussing operations and increase parking stands, aiming to provide a new level of experience for passengers and optimize operational resources.

site_title: Ascott Reit's Q3 DPU at three-year high
summary: Ascott Residence Trust's (Ascott Reit) Q3 DPU reached a three-year high of 2.35 Singapore cents, up 14% from the previous year. Revenue rose 9% to S$123.9 million and gross profit grew 4% to S$57.5 million, driven by acquisitions in 2015 and this year. Unitholders' distribution grew 21% to S$38.7 million, the highest in a quarter since the Reit's launch 10 years ago. The Reit continues to target accretive acquisitions in gateway cities.

site_title: France warns UK's May of hard Brexit talks
summary: French President Francois Hollande warned British Prime Minister Theresa May that a "hard Brexit" would lead to tough negotiations, as she seeks a "smooth" withdrawal from the EU. Hollande criticized May's demands to limit EU migration and seek "maximum freedom" in the single market, which Brussels considers incompatible. The two-day EU summit in Brussels will focus on the Brexit process, with May set to meet EU leaders and Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande on Thursday warned British Prime Minister Theresa May during her first European Union summit that she would face tough negotiations if she insists on a "hard Brexit".

site_title: 30,000 healthcare jobs to be created by 2020: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong launched the 2020 Healthcare Manpower Plan, aiming to create 30,000 new healthcare jobs between 2015 and 2020. The plan includes initiatives such as enhanced clinical training, a new SkillsFuture Earn and Learn Programme, and a retention bonus incentive to attract mid-career talent. The government also plans to shift care beyond hospitals to community and home, requiring changes to the skills profile of the future workforce. The goal is to sustain a high-quality and affordable healthcare system for everyone.

site_title: World Bank boosts 2017 crude oil forecast to US$55 per barrel
summary: The World Bank has raised its forecast for crude oil prices in 2017 to $55 per barrel, up from $53 per barrel, due to an expected output agreement among Opec countries to trim excess supply. This increase is also attributed to a larger-than-expected 25% rise in energy prices next year. The Opec agreement aims to limit production to 32.5-33.0 million barrels per day, its first output cut since 2008.

images.alt_text: The World Bank raised its crude oil price forecast for 2017 to US$55 a barrel on Thursday from US$53 a barrel, as it expects an output agreement among the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) to help trim excess supply.

site_title: Keppel Corp Q3 gains down 38%, plans more layoffs at O&M unit
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore conglomerate, reported a 38% drop in Q3 net profit to S$225 million due to cheap oil and overcapacity in its offshore and marine (O&M) business, forcing another round of layoffs. The company plans to continue "painful measures" and is leaning on its property and infrastructure divisions for future earnings. Keppel O&M cut its direct workforce by 3,080, bringing total layoffs to nearly 8,000, or a quarter of its workforce.

site_title: Lethal Weapon is a blast, while Divorce works out
summary: TV shows are drawing inspiration from big-screen franchises, with "The Exorcist" and "Lethal Weapon" being rebooted. The buddy-cop action-comedy "Lethal Weapon" is currently airing on local cable, starring Clayne Crawford and Damon Wayans as partners taking on Mel Gibson and Danny Glover's iconic roles. This trend highlights the blurred lines between film and television, with both mediums borrowing ideas and concepts from each other.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages have maintained "buy" ratings on several companies, citing growth potential and strategic developments. SIIC Environment is expected to expand its water treatment portfolio and benefit from a dual listing application in Hong Kong, with a target price of S$0.78. CapitaLand Commercial Trust is poised to capture office market recovery with its redevelopment plans, maintaining a "buy" rating at S$1.81. AP Oil International is expected to increase shareholder value through a joint venture, with a target price of S$0.33. DeClout Limited is highlighted for its proven business and high upside, with a target price of S$0.34.

site_title: HK tribunal's ruling on short seller could stifle critical commentary, analysts fear
summary: A Hong Kong tribunal has ruled that US short-seller Andrew Left must repay $286,000 in trading profits and pay $4 million in legal expenses for publishing "false and/or misleading" claims in a 2012 report. The ruling has sparked concerns that it could stifle critical market commentary, potentially deterring short sellers from trading in Hong Kong. Analysts argue that the decision could have a chilling effect on negative market calls, hindering investors' ability to make informed decisions. Left plans to appeal the decision, citing stifled freedom of speech.

site_title: Strong yen begins to threaten Japan's tourism boom of recent years
summary: A strong yen is threatening Japan's tourism boom, with spending by foreign visitors decreasing in the third quarter of this year for the first time in over four and a half years. The yen's appreciation against other major currencies has led to a decline in yen-based tourist spending, dropping by 3% to 972 billion yen. Despite the decline in spending, the number of tourists remains steady, but officials are concerned about the impact of the strong yen on tourism-related earnings and inward foreign investment. The Japanese government had set a target of attracting 40 million visitors by 2020, but the decline in yen-based spending raises questions about meeting this target.

site_title: Plenty of thrills and spills in Jack Reacher sequel
summary: Tom Cruise reprises his role as Jack Reacher in the sequel "Jack Reacher: Never Go Back," performing his own stunts and bringing his signature rogue charm to the action-packed film. Four years after the events of the first movie, Reacher is drawn into a government conspiracy involving the deaths of US soldiers, alongside Major Susan Turner (Cobie Smulders). The film features intense action sequences, including warehouse fights and rooftop hand-to-hand combat, and explores a darker side to Reacher's character. Despite some over-the-top plot elements, the film is an enjoyable ride for fans of the action genre.

site_title: Queens Peak condo opens for preview this weekend
summary: Singapore's Queens Peak condo, developed by Hao Yuan Investment, will open for preview this weekend. The 736-unit project, featuring two 44-storey towers, will offer seamless connectivity to the Queenstown MRT Station. Prices range from S$680,000 for one-bedroom units to S$2.96 million for five-bedroom units. The launch date, set for end-October to November, depends on demand. Analysts expect "quite positive" demand, but note the price may be steep for a city-fringe location, with ideal prices ranging from S$1,350 to S$1,450 psf.

site_title: America's nightmare may be over soon
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump is facing a significant gender gap in the polls, with Hillary Clinton leading by nearly 20% among women voters. Despite Republican strategists advising him to focus on women, Trump doubled down on insults and personal attacks, further alienating female supporters. The debate performance, while slightly improved, did not change the electoral outlook, with Clinton maintaining a decisive lead in key battleground states. Trump needs to carry only two or three more states to win the election, but his uphill battle to win over undecided voters and secure battleground states appears insurmountable.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines in talks to rent out A380s for pilgrim flights
summary: Malaysia Airlines is in talks to rent out its A380 superjumbos to religious travel groups for Haj and Umrah pilgrimages, aiming to trim financial losses. The airline's CEO, Peter Bellew, said a deal could be reached before the end of December, with the planes used for eight months a year. This move could help Airbus, which has been struggling with weak demand for the A380, and provide an alternative market for used jets. The deal would involve reconfiguring the A380s to fit 700 people, a change Airbus is open to.

site_title: ECB keeps interest rates at record low as markets seek clues to stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its record-low interest rates, keeping the benchmark "refi" refinancing rate at zero percent, and the rates on the deposit and marginal lending facilities unchanged. The ECB's bond-buying scheme, worth 80 billion euros per month, was also left unchanged until the end of March 2017 or beyond. ECB President Mario Draghi provided few hints about future stimulus plans, reassuring markets that the bank would not taper its asset purchases. Analysts expect the ECB to extend its bond-buying scheme, as it remains under pressure to assure markets of its ability to do more.

site_title: Top global miner BHP Billiton sees signs of commodities recovery
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest mining company, sees early signs of a commodities recovery, with oil and natural gas expected to deliver gains into 2018. CEO Andrew Mackenzie expressed optimism, citing stronger-than-expected iron ore and metallurgical coal prices. The Bloomberg Commodity Index has surged 19% since January, with iron ore up 34% and oil up 14% since Opec agreed to production cuts. However, BHP's copper guidance is under review due to a power outage at its Olympic Dam mine, which may impact production.

site_title: Peak of Australia housing boom has passed: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts predict Australia's housing boom has peaked, with a looming apartment glut expected to lead to a slowdown in future developments. This slowdown will negatively impact economic growth, put 200,000 jobs at risk, and prompt the central bank to resume cutting interest rates next year.

site_title: Clinton accuses Trump of being Putin's 'puppet' in final debate
summary: Hillary Clinton accused Donald Trump of being a "puppet" for Russian President Vladimir Putin during the final presidential debate, saying he would likely get along better with Putin than her. Trump denied knowing Putin and claimed Clinton dislikes him, while Clinton responded that Putin has outsmarted her. US intelligence officials have accused Russia of meddling in the US election, and Trump has refused to concede that Russia was behind the hacking of Democratic Party emails.

images.alt_text: During Wednesday's final presidential debate, Mr Trump said he did not know Mr Putin but would likely get along better with the Russian leader than Mrs Clinton, a former US secretary of state.

site_title: S'pore companies disappoint in sustainability reporting
summary: Only 37.1% of Singapore's mainboard-listed companies reported on their sustainability practices in 2015, with 186 out of 502 companies disclosing information. The study, conducted by the National University of Singapore and the Asean CSR Network, found that companies with standalone sustainability reports tended to have more comprehensive disclosures. Despite a 15% increase from 2013, the rate of progress is still deemed insufficient, with less than half of companies expected to report by 2018. The Singapore Exchange requires listed companies to prepare an annual sustainability report by 2018, but experts argue that more action is needed.

images.alt_text: More than six in 10 of Singapore's mainboard-listed companies are still not communicating their sustainability practices to their stakeholders, says a new study.

site_title: Thai regime must prepare for return to democracy in crucial year ahead
summary: Thailand is preparing for a potential return to democracy after the passing of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who held significant moral and political authority during his 70-year reign. Although Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn may inherit the throne, it's unclear if the king's powers can be passed down. The prince has indicated a willingness to take his time, and it's too early to determine his ability to fill his father's shoes. This power vacuum presents an opportunity for Thailand to undergo political regeneration, but the country's future remains uncertain.

site_title: From a historical figure to a seminal literary one
summary: A play, "Starring Hitler as Jekyll and Hyde," explores the rise of fundamentalism and fanaticism through a fictionalized account of Adolf Hitler's life, combining historical facts with creative license. The play follows Hitler's transformation from an insecure art student to a menacing figure, while also delving into the lives of those around him, including his love interest Eva Braun and a police inspector tasked with stopping his killings. The ensemble cast delivers a strong performance, with the film noir staging and lighting design adding to the overall tension and dark atmosphere.

site_title: LG bucks trend with push on premium products here
summary: LG is bucking the trend of low-priced electronics by focusing on its premium products segment in the local market, with sales of OLED TVs increasing 240% this year. The company introduced a premium washing machine, the LG TwinWash, priced at S$4,398. This move highlights the demand for high-end electronics in Singapore despite the trend of mass market products.

images.alt_text: Even as tech and consumer brands and retailers continue to drive sales of mass market electronic goods with low prices, Korean tech giant LG is bucking the trend by focusing on its premium products segment for the local market.

site_title: Tesla, Apple and Uber demand pushing lithium prices even higher
summary: Lithium prices continue to rise, driven by explosive demand for electric vehicles, grid storage, and consumer electronics. The metal is dubbed the "new gasoline" and "world's hottest commodity" due to its critical role in energy storage. Demand is forecast to reach $46.2 billion by 2023, with China, Europe, and the US leading the charge. Supply is expected to become increasingly tight, with new projects delayed and existing production struggling to keep up. Investors are flocking to lithium stocks, with analysts predicting a dramatic run-up in prices next year.

site_title: Discovering Napa Valley's best pinot noirs
summary: The article highlights the exceptional quality of wines produced by Freeman Winery in Napa Valley, California. The winery's 2013 Ryo-Fu Chardonnay and 2014 Yu-Ki Estate Pinot Noir are particularly praised for their balance of ripeness, acidity, and freshness, rivaling their French counterparts. Freeman Winery's focus on organic and biodynamic farming, careful vineyard management, and attention to detail have resulted in outstanding wines, despite the winery's relatively short 15-year history. The winery's philosophy and Japanese ethos have contributed to its success in producing wines worthy of standing alongside Burgundian counterparts.

site_title: Duterte announces 'separation' from US in China speech
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte announced his "separation" from the US in a speech in China, declaring that the US had "lost" and he had realigned with China to resolve their South China Sea dispute through talks. The announcement comes after a tribunal ruling in the Hague in favor of the Philippines, and marks a reversal in foreign policy since Duterte took office. China has welcomed the move, with President Xi Jinping calling it a "milestone" in ties, and billions of dollars in deals are expected to be signed.

site_title: KrisEnergy rides wave of speculation
summary: KrisEnergy, an oil and gas exploration and production firm, has seen its share price rise in recent weeks amid speculation that Keppel Corporation may provide financial support. Keppel Corporation, which holds a 40% stake in KrisEnergy, has declined to comment on the rumors. KrisEnergy has been under financial pressure due to the oil price plunge, but a potential bailout could boost its balance sheet and provide its management with more flexibility. The company's third-quarter results are set to be announced on November 3, and investors are cautiously optimistic about the potential for a "lucky break."

site_title: Lufthansa lifts profit forecast on business bookings
summary: Lufthansa has raised its 2016 profit forecast due to improved business bookings and lower fuel costs. The airline expects adjusted earnings before interest and taxes to be similar to last year, despite geopolitical uncertainties weighing on sales. Revenue is expected to decline 7-8% this quarter, and the airline has successfully reviewed its capacity to address the decline in long-haul bookings. Lufthansa's stock rose 5.4% after the announcement, its largest intraday gain in two months.

site_title: Airbnb may crack down on multiple-home renters
summary: Airbnb has proposed measures to crack down on hosts in New York City who rent out multiple homes, bowing to pressure from politicians and tenants' rights groups. The company will bar hosts who violate local regulations three times and create a registry of hosts to make enforcement easier. This comes after a study showed many hosts list multiple homes and operate like "illegal hotels" in residential buildings. Airbnb also plans to ensure landlords receive a cut of revenue from short-term rentals, a sticking point for many property owners.

site_title: Dysfunctional politics in Europe and the US hurts us all
summary: Global economic growth remains stagnant despite 10 years of zero interest rates, attributed to "secular stagnation". Key factors contributing to this include demographic changes, such as an aging population and low productivity growth, and flawed economic policies, including EU and eurozone issues and anti-globalization rhetoric. The lack of transparency and sensible governance by politicians has hindered global growth, with the US and EU being particularly affected. Economists warn that socialism will widen the rich-poor divide, while globalization has been a net contributor to growth. The global economy needs a more nuanced approach to address its stagnation.

site_title: Indonesia cuts key rate again in bid to spur growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 4.75% for the sixth time this year, aiming to boost economic growth amid a weak global economy. The move was seen as a surprise, with 13 out of 17 economists expecting the rate to remain at 5%. The decision aims to strengthen domestic demand and support economic growth momentum.

site_title: A Seven special
summary: Mini has unveiled the Mini Seven, a special edition of its Cooper and Cooper S models, paying tribute to the classic Austin Seven and Morris Mini Minor sister models launched in 1959. The Mini Seven features unique paint finishes, contrasting color roof and mirror caps, and exclusive 17-inch alloy wheels. The interior boasts dark cottonwood trim and nappa leather upholstery. The special edition carries a $2,000 premium over the normal Mini, priced at $144,300.

images.alt_text: The Mini Seven's interior is enhanced by dark cottonwood trim, with malt brown accents flanking the centre console on the door panels.
One of the paint finishes available is Lapisluxury Blue, a non-metallic finish of the most intensive blue tone ever applied on a Mini.

site_title: Opec price war offers meagre rewards as shale learns to survive
summary: Opec's price war has not significantly benefited US shale, despite the two-year low prices and policy shift. Executives from ExxonMobil and ConocoPhillips expressed optimism about shale's future, citing its ability to adapt and thrive. The US shale industry has confirmed a large resource base in North America, with CEOs stating that they should not bet against its resilience. This suggests that shale has survived the price war and will continue to have a significant global influence.

site_title: 2016 Airshow reaps S$329m for S'pore economy: survey
summary: The Singapore Airshow 2016 generated S$329 million for the local economy, with over 130,000 trade and public visitors attending the biennial event. The event featured 1,000 companies from 48 countries, including 65 of the top 100 global aerospace companies, and welcomed 286 VIP delegations from 90 countries. Seventy-seven per cent of exhibitors and 57 per cent of trade visitors expect to finalize deals, but only 50 deals were signed during the event, totaling US$12.7 billion. Personal spending by foreign visitors rose 13.3% to S$94.5 million.

site_title: New or old, Morrissey still has a lot to say
summary: Morrissey, 57, recently revealed he underwent cancer treatment and postponed his show due to a flu bug affecting his band and crew. He rescheduled the gig at Marina Barrage, appearing healthier than expected, and performed a 20-song setlist leaning on his post-millennium albums. Only three Smiths songs were played, with newer material like "World Peace is None of Your Business" receiving positive reception from fans. Morrissey's enigmatic nature and lack of explanation for the no-show were characteristic of his behavior, leaving fans to continue unraveling his mysterious character.

site_title: A solar rickshaw to the rescue in fume-choked Kochi
summary: Georgekutty Kariyanappally, inventor of solar-powered vehicles, has launched a solar rickshaw taxi in Kochi, India, aiming to reduce air pollution and promote environmental protection. The three-wheeled, five-seater motorized rickshaw runs on solar power, offering a quiet and non-polluting alternative to traditional auto rickshaws. With a range of up to 120km on a sunny day, the solar rickshaw could have a significant impact on air quality and climate change in cities like Mumbai and Kolkata, where similar vehicles are being considered.

site_title: Temasek invests US$250m in China healthcare joint venture
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte, a Singaporean state-owned investment firm, has invested US$250 million in a 50-50 joint venture with Columbia Pacific Management in China's healthcare sector. The partnership aims to provide affordable healthcare services to China's growing middle-class population. This investment marks Temasek's expansion in the healthcare sector, following its recent investments in US pharmaceutical and healthcare firms.

site_title: Decision on London airport expansion only in end 2017
summary: The UK government is delaying a decision on expanding London's airport capacity, with Prime Minister Theresa May stating that a decision on Heathrow's third runway or Gatwick expansion will be subject to further consultation and a parliamentary vote by the end of 2017. This decision was expected to be announced next week.

site_title: Turbocharged Tucson
summary: Hyundai has introduced a turbocharged version of its Tucson compact crossover, featuring a 1.6-litre engine with 175 hp and 265 Nm of torque. The new 7-speed dual-clutch transmission provides quick shifting with minimal power loss. The Tucson 1.6 handles confidently and has a spacious interior with standard equipment including blind spot detection, cruise control, and an electric tailgate. The car's performance is enhanced with a Drive Mode Select button offering Eco, Normal, and Sport settings. The Tucson 1.6 is priced at S$129,999, making it the top-of-the-line variant.

site_title: Cooking decent but not memorable
summary: Wan Hao Chinese Restaurant, located in the Singapore Marriott Tang Plaza Hotel, has reopened after a month-long renovation. The restaurant's modern look features bold calligraphy and opulent decor, but the cooking remains decent but not memorable. The menu offers a mix of classic dim sum and newfangled creations, with some dishes standing out, such as the poached prawn and pork dumplings and the deep-fried taro dumpling with mini abalone and scallop. However, other dishes, like the sweet corn bun and pan-fried five-grain pumpkin cake, are less successful. Overall, the restaurant receives a 6.5-star rating for its inconsistent cooking and slow, impersonal service.

images.alt_text: Poached prawn and pork dumplings in a spicy chilli vinegar and oil sauce have kick.
Steamed shrimp dumpling with black truffle and cordyceps flower is a new creation.
Deep fried prawn mango roll is a fun match of gooey sweet mango and prawn in a crackling crust.
Roast meat trio platter.
Lemongrass jelly in a dragonfruit shell.
Chilled coconut pudding with purple glutinous rice puree.
Deep-fried taro dumpling with mini abalone and scallop.

site_title: Recipes rooted in tradition
summary: Four cookbook authors - Rita Zahara, Ong Jin Teong, Eric Low, and Theresa Noronha - have released books showcasing their respective cultures' traditional recipes. Rita Zahara's "The Many Flavours of Malay Cooking" features 70 authentic recipes from notable personalities in Singapore, while Ong Jin Teong's "Nonya Heritage Kitchen" explores Peranakan cuisine through its tools and origins. Eric Low's "Teochew Heritage Cuisine" highlights the unique characteristics of Teochew food, including its emphasis on natural and subtle flavors. Theresa Noronha's "The Eurasian Table" features her grandmother's recipes, which blend Portuguese, Indian, and Malay ingredients, providing insights into Singapore's Eurasian culture.

site_title: A-Reit's Q2 healthy despite industrial weakness
summary: Ascendas Reit (A-Reit) reported a 3.1% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.03 Singapore cents for its Q2 2016, due to a one-off item from last year. However, distributable income, revenue, and net property income grew 12.3%, 12.5%, and 23.1% respectively. The Reit mitigated industrial market weakness by enhancing and repositioning older properties and exploring subletting rules. Despite a 40 basis point decline in Singapore occupancy, overall portfolio occupancy improved to 89.1%.

site_title: Struggling Xiaomi bets on smart rice cookers
summary: Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone maker, is diversifying its business by investing in and selling various devices through its hardware startups. The company is partnering with over 60 startups to produce products such as smart rice cookers, hoverboards, and fitness trackers, which are typically priced lower than competing products. Xiaomi aims to hook customers with its MIUI operating system and encourage loyalty, with plans to generate 10 billion yuan in revenue from these partnerships this year. However, the company faces challenges from domestic competition and a need to innovate to regain its market share.

site_title: S'pore firms can show Chinese ones the way to internationalisation
summary: Lenovo's founder Liu Chuanzhi suggests that Singaporean companies can lead the way for Chinese firms in internationalization, a key driver for China's growth. Liu notes that China's private sector companies have a better sense of market principles and are now flush with capital, but uncertainty in policies must be avoided. Internationalization can help Chinese firms grow as the domestic economy slows, and Liu points to examples such as the growth of Beijing's Zhongguancun as a model for economic development.

site_title: Swiss government look to open doors for banks abroad
summary: The Swiss government has announced plans to boost the competitiveness of its financial sector, citing its role as the world's biggest centre for foreign wealth. The move comes as the country's banks face pressure due to global clampdowns on tax evasion. The government will review the "too-big-to-fail" rules and reassess its regulatory framework to support financial innovation and maintain access to foreign markets. This shift in tone is seen as a more supportive stance towards the industry, under new Finance Minister Ueli Maurer.

site_title: The US election: It's a no-win situation for the media
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump claims the media is conspiring against him, despite a lack of evidence. A Pew survey shows that 81% of Trump and Clinton supporters disagree on basic facts, indicating a deep-seated distrust of the press. Trump's critics argue that his behavior and policies are the subject of fair and balanced media coverage, while also pointing out that the media has unfairly scrutinized Clinton. The outcome of the election will likely exacerbate tensions between Trump and the media, with both sides potentially accusing each other of bias and manipulation.

site_title: PM Lee in Bangkok to pay respects to late Thai king (Amended)
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong arrived in Bangkok for a two-day visit to pay respects to the late King Bhumibol Adulyadej. He will meet with Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha to express condolences and pay his respects at the Grand Palace. Lee's visit comes as Thailand is in a year-long period of official mourning following the king's death. The country's throne remains vacant, with Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn awaiting his accession to the throne.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) signs the condolence book to the late Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej at the Thai embassy in Singapore on Oct 14, 2016.

site_title: Smart solutions for laundry, lighting needs
summary: A smart laundry system, pureWash Pro, has been introduced to reduce detergent use. The system injects oxygen, ozone, and ions into washing machine water, removing moisture and odors without harsh chemicals. Users can wash clothes without detergent for the first few cycles, then use a reduced amount to maintain fragrance. The system is not a miracle solution for stubborn stains and requires detergent for those. In contrast, Philips has introduced smart lighting systems, including lights and controllers, allowing for individual control and remote access through the Philips Hue app.

site_title: US:Wall St flat amid mixed earnings reports
summary: US stocks remained flat on Thursday, as weak earnings reports from Verizon and Travelers offset AmEx's strong performance. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.02%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Oil prices dropped 2% following a 15-month high, and Mattel rose 5.4% after beating earnings estimates. The Labor Department reported a rise in unemployment benefits, but below expected levels. Stock futures were higher after a poll suggested Hillary Clinton had won the third presidential debate.

site_title: Euro near 3-month lows amid focus on QE views
summary: The euro fell to a three-month low against the dollar, trading just above US$1.0976, amid speculation about the European Central Bank's potential to taper its bond purchase program. ECB president Mario Draghi's press conference may provide clarity, with investors seeking indications of tapering or a dovish tone. Meanwhile, the dollar rose 0.2% against the yen and a basket of currencies, boosted by renewed interest in the US election.

site_title: EBay tumbles after lackluster forecast for holiday shopping
summary: EBay shares plummeted 11% after the company's disappointing holiday shopping forecast, citing a need for more time to implement its turnaround efforts. CEO Devin Wenig said the company will shift its focus from promotional subsidies to deals on popular brands, but this effort will take at least a year to yield results. Analysts expressed concerns that EBay may miss out on the holiday shopping season, citing slowing growth rates and increasing competition from Amazon.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q3 DPU up despite lower revenue
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter of 2016, reaching 2.535 Singapore cents. Despite lower revenue from conventions and the sale of Park Mall, the earnings still surpassed the previous year. This was largely due to a higher year-on-year distribution. The company's revenue was impacted by lower convention bookings and the sale of Park Mall, but its DPU remains higher than the previous year.

site_title: Morning in the garden of good and evil
summary: Tanztheater Wuppertal's classic dance piece "Nelken" (Carnations), created by Pina Bausch in 1982, explores the conflicting forces of human emotions through its 24 scenes. The work, inspired by Bausch's childhood in postwar Germany, balances fear, joy, cruelty, and sadness with humor, illustrating universal themes of power, control, and subjugation. Despite being 34 years old, "Nelken" continues to provoke and inspire audiences, with its latest performance in Singapore marking the dance company's first show in the city-state in 40 years.

images.alt_text: Fear, joy, cruelty, sadness and humour are often rolled into one in the two dozen discrete scenes in Nelken, presented on a stage adorned with thousands of pink and red carnations.

site_title: SGX still in talks on potential tax waiver on Reit ETF
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is in talks with authorities on a potential tax waiver for Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs). The withholding tax on Reit ETFs, which tracks income from Singapore properties, is a major concern for potential issuers, with estimated impacts on returns for Singapore investors at 25 basis points. Despite this, a pipeline of Reit ETFs is underway, with the recently listed Asia-Pacific Reit ETF yielding around 5% in dividends and raising over $30 million in its first closing.

site_title: Tesla to ship all its cars with self-driving capability
summary: Tesla will begin shipping all its cars with self-driving capability, with every vehicle built having the necessary hardware for full autonomy. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, stated that buyers will have a choice regarding how much autonomy they want to give their vehicle, with the option for improved Autopilot or full self-driving. The new technology will feature 8 cameras, 12 sensors, and a computer with 40 times the processing power of previous models, providing a 360-degree view of the surroundings.

site_title: JPMorgan weighs exiting China venture
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is in talks to sell its minority stake in a Chinese investment-banking joint venture, JPMorgan First Capital Securities, to its local partner, First Capital Securities Co. This move comes as foreign banks become frustrated with partnerships they can't control. The New York-based bank is seeking a new partner to wield greater control, a sign of growing tensions between foreign banks and Chinese authorities. No agreement has been reached, and the sale is subject to further negotiations.

site_title: Disruption defines three challenges for Singapore
summary: Singapore faces three challenges due to disruption, a phenomenon driven by globalization and technology. Firstly, the displacement of legacy taxi companies, such as ComfortDelGro, by ride-hailing platforms like Uber, threatens employment of cab drivers. Secondly, the disruption's impact on drivers as independent contractors, who may become displaced by autonomous vehicles. Lastly, Singapore needs to inspire an appetite for continuous improvement among its people to cope with the disruption and remain competitive in the new economy.

site_title: Hedge fund managers expect 'massive' 34% pay cut, survey says
summary: Hedge fund managers are expected to face a 34% pay cut in 2016, with those with seven or more years of experience seeing a 14% decline in total compensation. The industry is experiencing criticism over high fees and poor performance, leading to a decline in investor withdrawals and payouts. Junior analysts, however, can expect a 10% increase in compensation. The industry is also expected to hire more professionals with technology or legal experience to improve data analysis and compliance.

site_title: Euro ends drop as ECB keeps interest rates, QE policy unchanged
summary: The European Central Bank kept interest rates and quantitative easing policy unchanged, causing the euro to rise against 13 of its 16 major counterparts and little changed against the dollar. European bonds tumbled this month, pushing yields on German 10-year bunds to their highest since June. The ECB's decision was seen as a surprise, contradicting expectations of a change to its quantitative easing program. Only 17% of economists polled predicted a change, with most expecting it to happen in December.

site_title: China's Geely shows global ambitions, launching new compact SUV in Germany
summary: Chinese automaker Geely, owner of Volvo cars, unveiled the Lynk & Co brand's first compact SUV, the '01', in Germany, targeting the European mid-market with a hybrid-powered, tech-savvy vehicle. The car features high internet connectivity, a shareable digital key, and will be priced competitively. Geely aims to challenge major European automakers with its global brand, which will also be sold in China and the US. The move is part of Chinese companies' efforts to acquire European technology to gain a global footprint, with Geely partnering with Ericsson, Microsoft, and Alibaba on the car's connected features.

site_title: Luxury market stagnates as wealthy Chinese shoppers stay at home
summary: The luxury goods market is expected to stagnate in 2016, with sales projected to reach 249 billion euros, the weakest performance since 2009. This is attributed to China's emerging middle class not fueling growth as previously expected, with the country's luxury market starting to recover from three years of stagnation. Industry leaders such as LVMH and Hermès have reported declining sales, while Burberry Group Plc has seen declines in its Asian business and worsening results at its wholesale unit, signaling a "war for market share" among luxury brands.

site_title: ECB, keeping rates unchanged, stays quiet about future policy
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) kept interest rates at historic lows, maintaining its guidance for rates to stay at their current or lower levels for an extended period. ECB President Mario Draghi said the bank remains committed to pursuing substantial asset purchases to spur growth and inflation, but gave few hints about future policy. The eurozone economy is experiencing a moderate but steady recovery, with inflation at a two-year high and wage growth remaining weak. Analysts expect unchanged rates with a possible extension to asset buys in December.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank kept interest rates on hold at historic lows on Thursday and its president said the Bank was committed to pursuing substantial asset purchases aimed at spurring growth and inflation.

site_title: FCOT's Q4 DPU dips; full-year showing is trust's best since listing
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 2.8% drop in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.45 Singapore cents, despite year-on-year increases in gross revenue, net property income, and distributable income. The decline was primarily due to the trust's manager paying its entire management fee in cash for the quarter, compared to 30% in units with the rest in cash in the previous year.

images.alt_text: Despite achieving year-on-year increases in gross revenue, net property income and distributable income, Frasers Commercial Trust's (FCOT) fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fell 2.8 per cent to 2.45 Singapore cents.

site_title: UK will ensure stability of financial sector - Brexit minister
summary: The UK government, led by Brexit minister David Davis, has assured the stability of the financial sector during the Brexit process. Davis stated that the financial sector, particularly the City of London, is crucial to the negotiations and that the government will do anything necessary to maintain stability. A transitional arrangement is being examined to cover the gap between Britain's exit from the EU and a new trade deal. Securing the future of the euro-denominated clearing industry is also a priority, with regulatory equivalence to be maintained.

site_title: Sales of existing homes in US increase more than forecast
summary: US existing home sales rose 3.2% to a 5.47 million annual rate in September, exceeding forecasts. The median sales price increased 5.6% to $234,200, while inventory dropped 6.8% to 2.04 million. Sales climbed 2.8% from September 2015, with first-time buyers accounting for 34% of all sales, the highest share in four years. The Realtors group attributes the increase to solid job growth, recovering home values, and low mortgage rates, but notes that inventory remains a limiting factor, and a pickup in construction is needed to boost turnover and moderate price gains.

site_title: China capital flow crackdown sees one trillion-yuan bust
summary: China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) cracked down on underground banking operations, seizing $8.43 billion in foreign exchange funds and 1 trillion yuan (S$206 billion) in illicit capital outflows. The crackdown comes as the yuan has depreciated 7.8% against the US dollar since last year's mini-devaluation. Authorities are tightening formal channels to curb outflows, but underground activities are increasing, with creative methods such as life-insurance policies and faked trade invoices. Experts warn that capital outflows could intensify, but China's currency reserves remain stable at $3.2 trillion.

site_title: Standing out from the pack (Amended)
summary: Local furniture and homeware retailers are innovating to enhance the shopping experience. Space Furniture, for instance, now offers a car-pickup service, eliminating the need for parking and traffic. This luxury touch is part of the retailer's efforts to differentiate itself from competitors. The company's focus on exclusivity and privacy is just one example of how retailers are rethinking the shopping experience to provide a more personalized and convenient experience for customers.

site_title: Ascott Reit's Q3 DPU of 2.35 cents at three-year high
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) reported a 14% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.35 Singapore cents in Q3, the highest DPU in three years. Revenue rose 9% to S$123.9 million and gross profit grew 4% to S$57.5 million. The Reit's asset size is expected to expand to S$5.3 billion upon completion of the Ascott Orchard Singapore acquisition next year. This is the highest distribution recorded in a quarter since the Reit's launch 10 years ago.

site_title: Six appeal
summary: Lexus has reintroduced the RX350 in Singapore, a mid-sized SUV that combines luxury and performance. The fourth-generation RX features a naturally aspirated 3.5-litre V6 engine producing 296 hp and 370 lb-ft, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The new model is well-suited for the large and luxurious SUV, providing a smooth and quiet driving experience. This marks the return of the six-cylinder engine in the Singapore market, alleviating concerns it was replaced by the four-cylinder turbo.

site_title: Duterte aligns Philippines with China, says US has lost
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte announced his "separation" from the US, aligning with China to resolve the South China Sea dispute through talks. He stated that the US has "lost" in this regard, as China and the Philippines agreed to strengthen economic ties. Duterte signed $13.5 billion in deals during his China trip, despite US concerns about the shift in foreign policy. The US-Philippines alliance has a 70-year history, but Duterte's remarks are likely to prompt fresh concern in the US, with the White House downplaying the comments.

site_title: Singapore retains 9th spot in rule of law index
summary: Singapore retained its 9th spot in the 2016 rule of law index, released by the World Justice Project. The country topped two categories: order and security; and regulatory enforcement. It ranked second in the absence of corruption category, after Denmark. Singapore scored high in low crime rates, effective regulatory enforcement, and respect for due process. The top three performers were Denmark, Norway, and Finland, while the bottom three were Afghanistan, Cambodia, and Venezuela.

site_title: VW said to target 3.7b euros in cost cuts at namesake brand
summary: Volkswagen AG plans to cut 3.7 billion euros in costs at its namesake brand by the end of 2020, aiming to shore up profitability and invest in future vehicle technology. The bulk of the savings will come from German factories, with a target of about 3 billion euros. The cost-cutting is part of a broader plan to restore weak profit at the VW brand and emerge from the emissions-cheating scandal. Talks with employee representatives are ongoing to protect jobs and allocate production to German factories, with no forced layoffs planned.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG plans to cut 3.7 billion euros (S$5.64 billion) in costs at its namesake VW car brand by the end of 2020 to shore up profitability and safeguard investment in future vehicle technology, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Alibaba CEO eyes offline market by being middleman
summary: Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang aims to expand the company's presence in the offline market by creating a network that allows physical stores to monitor transactions in real-time. This system, powered by Alibaba's cloud computing business, will enable retailers and brands to adjust inventories and orders more efficiently. With the potential to tap into China's 30 trillion yuan offline market, Alibaba sees this as a key driver of growth, despite short-term earnings drag. The company has pledged to continue investing in expansion, driven by trillions of dollars in Chinese household savings.

site_title: Another mixed, ho-hum day for stocks
summary: Stocks experienced a lackluster day in Singapore, with a 20-point rise in Dow futures and polls suggesting Hillary Clinton's win in the third US presidential debate failing to stimulate meaningful market action. Trading activity was focused on second-line counters, with Noble Group and Blumont being the most active. The Singapore public offer of NTT DC Reit was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues.
