site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore Business School found that most Singapore companies are not communicating sustainability. The 2016 Singapore Airshow generated nearly S$329m for the local economy. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to US tariffs, while Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup predicts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra expressed confidence in the Thai court clearing his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case.

site_title: Greater capacity, enhanced features planned for Seletar Airport's new passenger terminal
summary: Singapore's Seletar Airport is set to open a new passenger terminal at the end of 2018. The two-storey terminal will have a capacity of 700,000 passengers annually, with 500 sq m dedicated to business jet passengers. The S$50 million project will cover a gross floor area of 9,500 sq m. The new terminal aims to enhance the airport's services and cater to the growing demand for air travel.

site_title: Indonesia cuts interest rate for 6th time before Fed move
summary: Indonesia's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate for a sixth time this year, lowering the seven-day reverse repurchase rate to 4.75% to inject stimulus into the economy ahead of the US Federal Reserve's potential rate hike. The move aims to boost an economy that continues to undershoot President Joko Widodo's growth target of 7%. Despite inflation near the lower end of its target band, Bank Indonesia expects a lower-than-expected third-quarter growth and a possible one-time Fed rate hike in December.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed amid low volume
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced a mixed day with a slight decline, ending at 2,842.62 points, two points weaker than the previous day. Trading volume was low, with 1.56 billion units worth S$887.5 million. Despite a 20-point rise in Dow futures and initial polls suggesting Hillary Clinton's win in the third US presidential debate, market activity was minimal, with Noble Group being the most active counter. Brokers were not optimistic about current market conditions, and the Straits Times Index traded within a tight band, mostly in the red for the day.

site_title: A-Reit's Q2 DPU drops 3.1% to 4.03 Singapore cents
summary: A-Reit reported a 3.1% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.03 Singapore cents for Q2 2016. Total distribution for the first half of FY16/17 rose 13.9% to S$219.36 million. Net property income increased 21.7% to S$301.92 million, driven by the acquisition of One@Changi City and other Australian properties. The manager expects stable performance for FY17, barring unforeseen events, and attributes this to its capital recycling strategy and asset repositioning.

site_title: Indonesian militants jailed over deadly Jakarta attack
summary: Indonesian militants Dodi Suridi and Ali Hamka were jailed for their roles in a deadly Jakarta attack in January that killed 8 people. The attack, claimed by the Islamic State, was thwarted by security forces. Suridi was sentenced to 10 years for his involvement in making a bomb, while Hamka received a 4-year sentence for attempting to acquire guns and ammunition. The convictions highlight Indonesia's ongoing struggle with IS-linked attacks, with the country facing an increase in such assaults.

site_title: Keppel Corp's Q3 profit slumps 38%
summary: Keppel Corp's Q3 profit plummeted 38.1% to S$225 million, with revenue dropping 40.2% to S$1.5 billion. The decline was attributed to a sharp fall in the offshore and marine division due to fewer jobs, project deferments, and the suspension of the Sete Brasil contracts. To address the issue, the company's CEO announced that painful measures, including a 26% reduction in workforce and salary cuts for senior management, will continue. No dividend was recommended, and Keppel Corp shares rose 0.4% to S$5.44.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE conglomerate Keppel Corporation's third-quarter net profit fell 38.1 per cent to S$225 million from S$363 million a year ago.

site_title: Australia housing boom peak has passed
summary: Australia's housing boom has reached its peak, according to Morgan Stanley, with a looming apartment glut expected to lead to a slowdown in future developments. This slowdown will hurt economic growth, put 200,000 jobs at risk, and prompt the central bank to resume cutting interest rates next year. A national housing oversupply of about 100,000 dwellings is forecasted by 2018, with multi-dwelling approvals set to decline by 46% by the end of 2018.

images.alt_text: Australia's housing boom has passed its peak, with a looming apartment glut set to lead to a sharp slowdown in future developments, according to Morgan Stanley.

site_title: Foreign buyers of Hong Kong homes help drive price rebound
summary: Hong Kong's property prices have rebounded by 11% since March, driven in part by a surge in purchases by non-resident foreigners, particularly mainland Chinese buyers. In September, 250 homes were sold to non-resident foreigners, a 36% increase from the previous four months. Mainland Chinese buyers are attracted to Hong Kong's stable exchange rate and tax incentives offered by developers. This influx of foreign buyers has helped drive up prices, with mainland buyers accounting for 31% of property purchases worth at least HK$20 million in the second quarter.

site_title: China's Xi says hopes Duterte's visit can fully improve ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed hope that Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's visit to China can improve ties, particularly in handling disputes over the South China Sea. During their meeting, Duterte stated that the roots of the two countries' bonds are deep and not easily severed. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral relations and address territorial disputes.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q3 DPU rises despite lower revenue
summary: Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Suntec Reit) reported a third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.535 Singapore cents, up from 2.522 cents last year. Despite a 2.1% drop in net property income to S$57.23 million and a 4.3% decline in gross revenue to S$82.37 million, distributable income increased 1.1% to S$64.34 million. The increase in DPU was driven by a 1.1% rise in distributable income, despite revenue decline.

images.alt_text: MALL owner Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Suntec Reit) posted a third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.535 Singapore cents, up from 2.522 Singapore cents the previous year, it said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Thursday.

site_title: Nestle cuts sales outlook as 9-month organic growth disappoints
summary: Nestle cut its sales outlook for the year, citing a 3.3% increase in first nine-month organic sales, below its previous 4.2% estimate. The Swiss food giant attributed the disappointing growth to price deflation in Europe, weak commodity prices, and tough conditions in key markets like China and Brazil. Despite volume increases, Nestle prioritized pricing, and shares fell 1.7% in pre-market activity. The company now expects full-year organic sales to rise by 3.5%, down from its previous forecast of 4.2%.

images.alt_text: Nestle became the latest company to be hit by the global slowdown affecting food manufacturers after posting its weakest underlying sales growth in more than a decade.

site_title: 2016 Singapore Airshow contributed nearly S$329m to local economy
summary: The 2016 Singapore Airshow generated nearly S$329 million for the local economy, with over 130,000 visitors attending the event. The biennial show saw 1,000 companies from 48 countries participate, along with 286 VIP delegations from 90 countries. This year's trade attendees increased by 7% year-over-year, with 30% of attendees coming from overseas. The event is considered a key gateway to the Asia-Pacific aviation market, providing opportunities for global and regional companies to establish new business relationships.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher on energy rally
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.30% on Thursday, tracking gains in New York, as energy firms rallied on a surge in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index ended at 23,374.40, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. The Shenzhen Composite Index, however, added 0.32% to 2,060.39. The rally follows a similar trend in US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Starbucks opening up to 1,000 reserve cafes worldwide in bid to go upscale
summary: Starbucks plans to open 1,000 upscale Reserve cafes worldwide, targeting sophisticated customers, with the first location set to open next year. The Reserve chain will sell premium small-lot coffee and food from Princi. This move is part of Starbucks' effort to add different store concepts globally, including Roasteries that offer coffee tastings and spotlight premium coffee. The company also plans to open a Roastery in Tokyo, following locations in Seattle and Shanghai.

images.alt_text: Starbucks Corp plans to open as many as 1,000 locations of a new upscale chain that will tout its premium Reserve coffees, escalating an effort to reach more sophisticated customers.

site_title: Gold up on technical buying, focus shifts to ECB policy decision
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,272.20 an ounce due to technical buying ahead of the European Central Bank's policy decision. The ECB is expected to keep policy unchanged but may lay groundwork for easing in December, which could lead to a cheaper dollar and higher gold prices. Analysts predict gold could reach $1,300 by year-end, driven by suspense and uncertainty.

site_title: Swiss trade surplus highest since at least 1987
summary: Switzerland's September trade surplus reached its highest level since at least 1987, exceeding 4.37 billion francs. The strong sales of chemical and pharmaceutical products, particularly from companies like Roche and Novartis, contributed to the increase. Despite a decline in watch exports, the economy appears to have weathered a currency market shock, with the Swiss National Bank introducing negative interest rates to weaken the franc. The forecast for 1.5% growth in 2016 suggests the worst may be over for Swiss exporters.

site_title: 30,000 more healthcare workers needed by 2020 to care for elderly: MOH
summary: Singapore will need 30,000 more healthcare workers by 2020 to care for the elderly, who are aging rapidly and suffering from chronic ailments. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for specialized doctors and nurses to staff new facilities. The country will also need to rethink its approach to elderly care. This shortage highlights the growing demand for healthcare services in Singapore as its population ages.

images.alt_text: As Singapore's population ages rapidly and more suffer chronic ailments, it will require 30,000 more healthcare workers between last year and 2020. It will also need to completely rethink the way it cares for the elderly, said Health Minister Gan Kim Yong on Thursday.

site_title: Women in Asia-Pacific express dismay over US presidential campaign
summary: Women in the Asia-Pacific region expressed dismay over the US presidential campaign's focus on sexual harassment, saying it reveals America's lingering issues with democracy and women's rights. The campaign's handling of allegations against Donald Trump has drawn comparisons to how women are treated in other Asian countries, with many countries having made more progress in promoting gender equality and holding leaders accountable for their actions. The region's women politicians and leaders criticized Trump's behavior, with some saying he would be "unelectable" in their countries due to his alleged actions.

site_title: Glencore sells Australian coal haulage business for A$1b
summary: Glencore, a Swiss commodities giant, has sold its Australian coal haulage business for A$1.14 billion to an American firm, aiming to reduce its debt. The move follows first-half losses of US$369 million and a debt mountain of US$30 billion in 2015. Glencore has been reining in spending, scrapping dividends, and closing operations amid a commodity price slump. This sale is part of the company's efforts to stabilize its finances.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.46% in opening exchanges on October 20, 2016, tracking gains in New York due to a rally in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index increased to 23,412.68, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices remained flat.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.09 points to 1,667.18. The index saw 1.5 billion lots traded worth RM1.488 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 417 to 342.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stable at open before ECB decision
summary: Europe's main stock markets steadied ahead of the European Central Bank's interest rate decision, with London's FTSE 100 index and eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices virtually unchanged. ECB chief Mario Draghi is expected to prep markets for an extension of the monetary stimulus program, but no changes to interest rates or asset-buying are anticipated. Markets will focus on Draghi's news conference for forward guidance on the bank's next moves to support hesitant growth and inflation in the eurozone.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks at six-month high after US presidential debate
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.39% to a six-month high, closing at 17,235.50, after Hillary Clinton's strong showing in the US presidential debate. The Topix index also rose 1.00% to 1,370.80. Investors are optimistic despite US presidential uncertainty, as market favourite Clinton is seen as having beaten rival Donald Trump. The rally is expected to continue, with traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.260 points lower to 1667.090, with 26.8 million lots traded at RM7.97 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 62 to 43.

site_title: Vietnam aims to boost 2017 GDP growth to 6.7%: PM
summary: Vietnam aims to boost its 2017 GDP growth to 6.7%, with exports projected to grow 6-7% and inflation expected to average 4% next year. Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc made the announcement during Vietnam's National Assembly opening session. This target is lower than the 6.9% growth rate achieved in 2016, reflecting a slowdown in the country's economic growth.

site_title: ECB set to tee up next stimulus move: analysts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to extend its monetary stimulus program, which includes asset purchases, at its upcoming meeting. Despite a Bloomberg report suggesting the ECB may taper its asset-buying scheme, policymakers are expected to maintain the current 80 billion euro monthly purchases. ECB President Mario Draghi will address markets and investors on Thursday, providing insight into the bank's next moves to support eurozone growth and inflation. Analysts expect the ECB to hold off on announcing policy changes until December, when new growth and inflation projections are released.

site_title: PM Lee in Bangkok to pay respects to late Thai king
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is visiting Bangkok to pay respects to the late Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej at the Grand Palace. He will also meet with Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha to express condolences on the monarch's passing. Lee is accompanied by his wife Ho Ching and officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The visit is a two-day affair, marking a significant gesture of respect from the Singaporean leader to the Thai government.

site_title: Ringgit over 1-week high on oil; Malaysia budget eyed
summary: Malaysia's ringgit reached its strongest level in over a week due to higher oil prices, while investors await the unveiling of the country's 2017 budget on Friday. The Philippine peso also rose to a near one-month high on a budget surplus in August. Analysts expect the Malaysian budget to feature populist measures, which could support economic growth but also risk widening the fiscal deficit. The European Central Bank's monetary policy meeting is expected to provide insights into its plans for quantitative easing, which could impact emerging Asian currencies.

site_title: Australia's Crown says no charges laid against staff held in China
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts announced that no formal charges have been laid against 18 staff members held in China for alleged gambling crimes. The arrests, including three Australian nationals, were made amid a crackdown on corruption in Macau, a key gaming hub for the company. Crown's shares fell 2% after the announcement, while the company plans to spin off its underperforming Australian hotels to minimize exposure to the Chinese market. The move is seen as a response to the ongoing crisis, which has raised concerns about the company's ability to attract Chinese VIP gamblers to its Australian casinos.

site_title: Jail term for former China "democracy" village chief upheld on appeal
summary: A Chinese court upheld the jail term of Lin Zuluan, the former head of Wukan village, for three years and a month, plus a 200,000 yuan fine. The decision sparked renewed protests in the village, but they were shut down by heavily armed police. The ruling has raised concerns about China's suppression of dissent and grassroots democracy.

images.alt_text: A Chinese court on Thursday upheld a jail term for the former head of a southern Chinese village once seen as a cradle of grassroots democracy.

site_title: In Mexico, beers and cheers during Clinton-Trump debate
summary: In Mexico, a restaurant called Pinche Gringo BBQ hosted a debate-watching event where patrons raised beers and cheered when "Mexico" was mentioned, reflecting the country's interest in the US presidential election. The event drew a mix of American expats and Mexicans, with many expressing concern over Donald Trump's anti-immigrant rhetoric and calling him a "xenophobe." The crowd booed Trump's comments but cheered when Hillary Clinton was praised for her stance on immigration. The event highlights Mexico's deep connection to the US election, with the peso's value influenced by Trump's opinion polls.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as oil lifts energy firms
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as oil prices surged, lifting energy firms. The US energy department reported a surprise drop in crude inventories, fueling hopes about demand in the world's top economy. Oil contracts rallied over two percent, building on a recent rally since Opec's output cut agreement. The rally helped Asian markets, including Singapore, which notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data.

site_title: 'We are not killers': Clowns counter creepy fad
summary: Clowns from Latin America gathered at an annual convention in Mexico City to counter the "creepy clown" craze that has spread across the US, Europe, and Mexico. The clowns, who number over 200, denounced the trend, stating they are not killers. They emphasized that being a clown is a profession that brings joy, not terror. The group met to address the hysteria, which has led to detentions and police responses, and to reassure the public that clowns are not inherently menacing.

site_title: Opec price war offers meager rewards as US shale survives
summary: Opec's two-year price war has led to a surprising outcome for the US shale industry, which has emerged as a resilient force despite low prices. Executives from major oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips, have expressed optimism about the industry's future, citing lower costs and viable new oil wells. This has led to concerns among Opec officials, who warn of potential supply shortfalls by the end of the decade. The US shale industry is expected to continue growing, with crude production forecast to rise to 8.8 million barrels per day by the end of 2017, supporting a global oil price of around $50-$60 per barrel.

site_title: Qatar said to consider joining US$100b SoftBank tech fund
summary: Qatar is considering investing in the US$100 billion SoftBank Vision Fund, a global technology fund formed by SoftBank Group Corp and Saudi Arabia. The Qatar Investment Authority sovereign wealth fund is considering an investment of billions of dollars to diversify its economy. SoftBank chairman Masayoshi Son has visited the Gulf region to discuss investments with global investors. The fund aims to raise US$100 billion, with Saudi Arabia and other investors contributing the remaining amount, to back technology companies globally and provide new sources of income for Gulf Arab countries amid declining oil prices.

images.alt_text: Qatar is considering investing in the US$100 billion global technology fund formed by SoftBank Group Corp and Saudi Arabia, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Suspected IS-inspired militant stabs three Indonesian policemen
summary: A suspected supporter of Islamic State (IS) attacked police in Indonesia with a knife, wounding three traffic police officers in Tangerang, near Jakarta. The attacker, born in 1994 and unemployed, was shot in the thigh and leg and is being treated in hospital. Authorities suspect the perpetrator is an IS sympathiser, amid concerns about a resurgence in radicalism in Indonesia, driven by a new generation of militants inspired by the militant group. This attack follows a series of IS-linked incidents in Indonesia, including a gun and bomb attack in January and a militant blowing himself up at a police station in July.

images.alt_text: A suspected supporter of Islamic State attacked police in Indonesia with a knife on Thursday and wounded three of them in what appeared to be the latest violence inspired by the militant group in the world's biggest Muslim-majority nation.

site_title: In last debate, Trump suggests he may reject election result
summary: US Republican candidate Donald Trump suggested he may reject the outcome of the Nov 8 US presidential election if he loses, sparking concerns from his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton. Trump stated he would wait to decide whether the outcome was legitimate, while Clinton described his stance as "horrifying." The two candidates clashed on various issues, including women's rights, gun control, and US relations with Russia, with Clinton accusing Trump of being Putin's puppet and Trump denying the allegations. The debate marked Trump's last opportunity to sway undecided voters before the election.

images.alt_text: US Republican candidate Donald Trump on Wednesday suggested he might reject the outcome of the Nov 8 US presidential election if he loses, a possibility his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton called "horrifying."

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won take a breather; ECB awaited
summary: South Korean shares and the won remained stable on Thursday as investors awaited the European Central Bank's policy meeting, which may impact global markets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.1% to 2,043.20 points, while the won remained unchanged at 1,122.6 against the US dollar. Investors are uncertain whether the ECB will tighten or ease monetary policy, leading to a cautious tone in the market.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares and the won trod water early on Thursday as investors were uncertain whether the European Central Bank would opt to tighten or ease at a policy meeting due to conclude later in the global day.

site_title: Tesla to build self-driving technology into all cars
summary: Tesla plans to integrate self-driving technology into all its electric cars, starting with a new onboard computer with 40 times the processing power of the previous generation. The system, called "basically a super-computer in a car," will run in "shadow mode" to gather data on potential accidents. Elon Musk aims to collect statistically significant data to demonstrate the technology's safety and effectiveness before allowing it to take control on roads. Existing cars will not be upgraded with the autonomous driving hardware, as it would be impractical.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares cautious ahead of final Trump, Clinton showdown
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 5442.1, with energy stocks climbing over 1% as oil prices rose. Gains in industrials and materials were offset by declines in financials. Woodside Petroleum and Newcrest Mining rose after beating analyst forecasts. Meanwhile, Crown Resorts fell 3% after announcing a plan to spin off hotels and retail property. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.1%. Investors await the final US presidential debate, with concerns over potential economic vandalism if Donald Trump is elected.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit over 15-month high; TSMC leads
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index reached a 15-month high of 9,322.19, driven by foreign investor buying in TSMC, a leading electronics manufacturer. The electronics subindex climbed 0.03% and the financials subindex gained 0.2%. This marks the highest level since July 7, 2015. The rally comes despite global economic uncertainty, including US tariff threats.

site_title: Super Typhoon Haima barrels through northern Philippines
summary: Super Typhoon Haima made landfall in northern Philippines, causing widespread damage and displacement. The category five storm brought destructive winds of 225 km/h, toppling power and communication lines, and damaging houses. Despite initial fears of massive damage, there were no immediate reports of casualties. The storm weakened over land, prompting the weather bureau to lift storm warning signals, and was expected to exit the country by Thursday evening. The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council reported infrastructure damage, but no confirmed casualties.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat
summary: Tokyo shares opened flat on October 20, 2016, after four days of gains. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.07% to 17,011.30, while the Topix index was down 0.01%. The yen remained firm, following four days of gains.

site_title: Wal-Mart's China revival strategy calls in JD.com and its drones
summary: Wal-Mart is revamping its China strategy with a partnership between the retailer and JD.com, the country's second-largest e-commerce website. The partnership aims to deliver goods from around the world to Chinese consumers within hours, including using drones to reach remote villages. Wal-Mart will stock a JD.com warehouse with its products, offering tens of thousands of items to Chinese consumers. The strategy follows Wal-Mart's decision to sell its Chinese e-commerce platform Yihaodian and aims to tap into China's vast online market, where shoppers increasingly turn to online websites for convenience.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Dudley expects US hike later this year
summary: US Federal Reserve President William Dudley expects the US to hike interest rates later this year if the economy continues on its current path. Dudley downplayed any market risks of a December rate hike, stating it's "not that big a deal." A quarter-point hike is seen as a minor adjustment, with Dudley suggesting it will be manageable. This move is in line with the Fed's goal of maintaining economic growth and stability.

site_title: Most Singapore firms silent on sustainability
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore Business School found that over 60% of Singapore-listed companies fail to communicate their sustainability practices to stakeholders. Only 186 out of 502 companies reported their sustainability practices, with an average level of disclosure of 43.6 points. The study also noted that disclosures pertaining to climate change were insufficient, with only 12.9% of companies disclosing information on climate change efforts. Experts say the new SGX sustainability reporting requirement is not enough to encourage companies to consistently report sustainability, and that more action is needed to address the issue.

site_title: Australia dollar snaps 6-day rally on jobs blow, NZ dollar climbs
summary: The Australian dollar dropped 0.4% after a weak employment report showed a 53,000 full-time job loss in September, despite a low unemployment rate of 5.6%. This report raised concerns of a potential interest rate cut. The Australian dollar snapped a six-day winning streak, trading at US$0.7689.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar came off a six-week high on Thursday after a surprisingly weak employment report showed a big slide in full-time jobs and added to the risk of a further cut in interest rates.

site_title: US, South Korea detect another failed North Korea missile test
summary: North Korea conducted a failed test of a powerful medium-range Musudan missile, its second failed attempt in a week. The US and South Korea detected the launch, which is believed to be an intermediate-range missile that could be operationally deployed as early as next year. The failed test comes just hours before the third US presidential debate, highlighting the challenge posed by North Korea's fast-moving nuclear weapons programme to the next US president.

images.alt_text: North Korea on Thursday conducted what appeared to be its second failed test in a week of a powerful medium-range missile that experts warn could be operationally deployed as early as next year.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 9.2 points to 2,853.82, opening flat on Thursday. This follows gains from US stocks, driven by climbing oil prices and Morgan Stanley's earnings. In Singapore, 100.6 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 105 to 29. The most actively traded counter was Suntec Reit, which opened flat.

site_title: Russia's Putin says need to quicken work on new Syrian constitution
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin announced plans to speed up the adoption of a new Syrian constitution to facilitate future elections. During talks with French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Moscow proposed accelerating the process. Putin also stated that Russia is ready to extend a pause in air strikes in Syria, which had been halted in the city of Aleppo.

site_title: Philippines posts August budget surplus of 32.6b pesos
summary: The Philippine government posted a budget surplus of 32.6 billion pesos in August, with revenue growing 19% and expenditures rising 9%. This narrowed the budget gap for the year to 138.4 billion pesos, below the full-year deficit ceiling of 388.9 billion pesos. The surplus is seen as a positive sign for the country's economic growth, particularly under President Rodrigo Duterte's infrastructure spending plans.

site_title: UN General Assembly to take up Aleppo on Thursday
summary: The UN General Assembly will address the violence in Aleppo on Thursday, following the Security Council's failure to adopt a resolution demanding an end to the bombing of the besieged Syrian city. The meeting, initiated by Canada and 69 other countries, aims to inform member countries about the crisis and pressure Russia to stop its relentless bombing of Aleppo. The meeting is seen as a first step, with diplomats acknowledging its main objective is to pressure Russia to cease hostilities and provide humanitarian assistance.

site_title: Aleppo bombardment is 'war crime': France's Hollande
summary: French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel condemned Russian President Vladimir Putin's bombardment of Syria's Aleppo as a war crime. Hollande stated that the demand is for the bombardments by the regime and its Russian backers to end. Merkel described the air raids as "inhumane and cruel". This comes as the leaders met in Berlin to discuss the ongoing conflict in Syria.

site_title: Brazil central bank cuts rate for first time in 3 years
summary: Brazil's central bank cut its key interest rate for the first time in over three years, lowering it to 14% amid hopes of a recovery in the country's largest economy. The rate cut comes as a new centre-right government's reforms fuel inflation decrease and forecasts a possible gradual recovery. The bank cited a dip in inflation and a possible end to a long recession, but the rate remains high compared to other emerging giants.

site_title: Wells Fargo probed for alleged identity theft: report
summary: Wells Fargo is under a criminal investigation in California over alleged identity theft, following the discovery of two million unauthorized accounts opened for its customers. California Attorney General Kamala Harris has ordered the bank to provide information on the identities of affected customers and employees. Wells Fargo has been reeling since a scandal in 2016 revealed the fake accounts, leading to a $185 million fine, the firing of 5,300 employees, and the resignation of its chairman and CEO. The bank is cooperating with the investigation and faces potential felony charges.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo, under fire for creating two million unauthorised accounts for its customers, is under a criminal investigation in California over alleged identity theft, the Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Temasek invests US$250m in China health care venture
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte is investing US$250 million in a 50-50 joint venture with Columbia Pacific Management in China's healthcare sector. The partnership aims to provide affordable healthcare services to China's growing middle-class population. This investment marks a significant expansion of Temasek's healthcare holdings, following its recent investments in US pharmaceutical and healthcare firms.

site_title: Star Scarlett Johansson to run Paris popcorn shop
summary: Hollywood actress Scarlett Johansson is opening a gourmet popcorn shop in Paris, called Yummy Pop, in the city's Marais district. The 31-year-old actress will serve customers her own favorite flavors, including truffle, parmesan, and sage. The shop, which opened on October 22, was a labor of love with her French husband Romain Dauriac and features seasonal ingredients and unique flavors like sea salt and olive oil. The shop's success could lead to future locations, as the French capital is experiencing a wave of American-influenced food trends.

site_title: Brazil arrests top lawmaker behind Rousseff impeachment: police
summary: Brazilian police arrested Eduardo Cunha, a top lawmaker behind Dilma Rousseff's impeachment, on corruption charges. Cunha, accused of taking $40 million in bribes, laundering money, and hiding funds in secret Swiss bank accounts, denies the charges. Authorities seized $70 million in assets, including eight cars, and ordered his detention due to risks to public order and potential flight. Cunha's arrest signals the ongoing Petrobras corruption probe, which has already charged dozens of politicians and business executives. His downfall may lead to further corruption cases and impact Michel Temer's government.

images.alt_text: Brazilian police on Wednesday arrested Eduardo Cunha, the driving force behind former president Dilma Rousseff's impeachment, in a new escalation of a corruption probe shaking Latin America's biggest country.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime Trust says it has received lawyer's letter from noteholders
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust's trustee-manager received a letter from noteholders demanding immediate payment of S$100 million in medium-term notes. The letter, from Rajah & Tann Singapore, alleges the notes' trustee, DB International Trust, failed to enforce repayment despite a written request. The trustee-manager is validating the letter's contents, stating it has not received notice from the trustee that the notes are due and payable. The noteholders' actions are contingent on the trustee's failure to act within a reasonable period, as per the notes' terms and conditions.

site_title: Facebook now lets you buy food, movie tickets on site
summary: Facebook has introduced new tools allowing US users to purchase food, movie tickets, and schedule appointments directly on the site. Users can link with businesses using Facebook Messenger, with options to order food through delivery.com or Slice, book movie tickets through Fandango, and request appointments at spas or hairdressers. The platform also features a recommendation tool, where users can ask for advice and receive suggestions from friends. Facebook plans to expand these features to its 1.13 billion daily active users worldwide in the coming months.

site_title: Trump hopes to hit jackpot in last debate with Clinton
summary: Donald Trump will participate in his final presidential debate with Hillary Clinton on Wednesday, aiming to bounce back from recent allegations of unwanted sexual advances. Trump's campaign is trailing behind Clinton in polls, with her leading by more than six points in national polls. Trump plans to focus on policy issues, but his team is expected to bring up personal attacks, including allegations of Bill Clinton's infidelity and Trump's claims of a rigged election. The debate is seen as a crucial moment for Trump to regain momentum before the November 8 election.

site_title: Australia employment surprisingly weak, stirs rate risk
summary: Australia's employment unexpectedly fell 9,800 in September, with 53,000 full-time jobs lost, despite a stable 5.6% unemployment rate. The participation rate dropped to 65.5%, and analysts suspect sampling issues may have overstated the weakness. This report may prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia to reconsider rate cuts, as underemployment and weak hours worked suggest a slack labor market. A low consumer price reading could lead to another rate cut as early as November.

images.alt_text: Australian employment unexpectedly fell 9,800 in September as firms shed a huge 53,000 full-time jobs, a disappointing report that slugged the local dollar and could rekindle speculation of further rate cuts.

site_title: mm2 Asia unit acquires right to produce The Voice for Singapore/Malaysia
summary: Singapore-listed mm2 Asia has acquired the exclusive rights to produce and broadcast the Singapore/Malaysia version of The Voice, a talent competition, via a format licence agreement with Talpa Global. The show will be produced in Mandarin and marks the first time a single version of the format is produced for two territories. This move follows the global success of The Voice, which attracts over 500 million viewers across every continent.

images.alt_text: Singapore-listed mm2 Asia, via its subsidiary mm2 Entertainment, has entered into a format licence agreement with Talpa Global to acquire the exclusive licensed rights to produce and broadcast the Singapore/Malaysia version of The Voice, a talent competition.

site_title: British artificial intelligence hub opens
summary: A new research centre, the British artificial intelligence hub, opened at Cambridge University, exploring AI's implications from smartphones to robot surgeons and military droids. Professor Stephen Hawking stated that the rise of powerful AI could be either beneficial or detrimental to humanity. The centre will examine both positive and negative applications of AI.

site_title: Russia's Putin says Minsk accord should be basis for Ukraine solution
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that the Minsk accord, reached in 2015, should be the basis for resolving the Ukraine crisis. He emphasized that the accord's provisions, including OSCE monitors expanding their mission, should be implemented. The five-hour talks in Berlin also agreed on the monitors' broader role in conflict zones. Putin's comments reflect Russia's continued support for the Minsk agreement, which aims to establish a ceasefire and stabilize the region.

site_title: UN chief hopes for credible vote in DR Congo
summary: UN Secretary General Ban Ki Moon hopes a deal to delay the election in the Democratic Republic of Congo until 2018 will lead to a credible vote and improve human rights. The main opposition has rejected the deal, which would keep President Laurent Kabila in power. Kabila was due to step down in 2016. The UN chief urges the government to release political prisoners and respect peaceful assembly rights. The country has been ruled by Kabila since 2001, and anti-Kabila demonstrations turned violent, killing 49 people.

site_title: Nasa spacecraft loses computer before close encounter with Jupiter
summary: NASA's Juno spacecraft experienced a main computer glitch and lost science instruments before a planned close encounter with Jupiter, scuttling highly anticipated observations. The issue occurred 13 hours before the flyby, prompting the US space agency to put observation plans on hold until December 11. The cause of the computer outage is under investigation, and the mission's goals remain unaffected, with critical measurements taken during each close pass. Juno's computer restarted, and the spacecraft was deemed "healthy."

images.alt_text: Nasa's Juno spacecraft lost it main computer and science instruments shortly before it was due to make an orbital pass near Jupiter on Wednesday, scuttling highly anticipated close-up observations of the largest planet in the solar system.

site_title: Millions on alert as super typhoon hits Philippines
summary: Millions of people in the Philippines are on high alert as Super Typhoon Haima hits the northern province of Cagayan, bringing strong winds and heavy rains. The storm's winds are almost as strong as those of Super Typhoon Haiyan, which killed over 7,350 people in 2013. President Rodrigo Duterte has urged prayers for the country's safety, warning of giant storm surges and destructive winds. Authorities are bracing for potential destruction, as the typhoon's impact is closely watched by millions.

site_title: Australia business conditions ease, confidence up: survey
summary: Australian business conditions eased slightly in the third quarter, with a 4-point decline in its index of business conditions to +7. However, business confidence rose 2 points to +5, and firms became more optimistic about the outlook for activity and employment. Employment ticked up a point to +3, and forward orders improved to +4, suggesting solid labour demand. Producer and retail prices barely grew, which may impact the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on interest rates in November.

images.alt_text: Australian business conditions eased a little in the third quarter as sales and profits waned, yet firms still turned more confident on the outlook for activity and employment, a survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: Oil up over 2%; US crude at 15-month high on big drawdown
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% on Wednesday, with US crude reaching a 15-month high, as the US Energy Information Administration reported a 5.2 million-barrel drop in crude stocks for the sixth week in a row. US crude imports fell to their lowest since November 2015, contributing to the inventory decrease. Despite the drop, some market participants expressed skepticism, citing a large gasoline build. The price rally follows a 15% increase in oil prices over the past three weeks after OPEC proposed its first output cut since 2008.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust Q4 DPU down 2.8 per cent
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 2.8% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.45 Singapore cents for Q4 2016, down from 2.52 cents last year. Distribution income grew 4% year-on-year to S$19.49 million, while net property income rose 7% to S$29.3 million. The trust's gross revenue increased 5.7% to S$39.3 million. For FY2016, distributable income and DPU rose 14.5% and 1.1%, respectively, marking the highest since listing in 2006.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Commercial Trust, mm2 Asia, SGX, Keppel T&T
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 2.8% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.45 Singapore cents for Q4 2016. mm2 Asia entered into a format license agreement to produce the Singapore/Malaysia version of The Voice. Singapore Exchange (SGX) posted a 16.3% drop in first-quarter net profit to S$83.1 million. Keppel T&T more than quadrupled its third-quarter net profit to S$69.88 million, driven by its data centre division.

site_title: Yahoo calls for 'transparency' from US spy agencies
summary: Yahoo calls on US spy agencies for transparency, specifically requesting public confirmation of any secret orders served on the company, amid reports of a 2016 court order to scan hundreds of millions of user accounts for a state-sponsored terrorist organization. The company claims some reports were misleading and cites US laws that constrain its ability to speak about national security orders. This request echoes a similar call made by Senator Ron Wyden earlier this month.

site_title: Euro weakens against US dollar before ECB meeting
summary: The euro weakened 0.11% against the US dollar to US$1.097 ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday, with investors focusing on potential changes to the central bank's bond purchase program. ECB President Mario Draghi's comments may influence bond markets globally and currencies. The US dollar index remained little changed, while the Canadian dollar and Australian dollar also moved due to separate central bank announcements.

site_title: Election uncertainty weighs on parts of US economy: Fed beige book
summary: The Federal Reserve's beige book survey indicates pre-election uncertainty is weighing on US business sectors, particularly in the Boston region, where election uncertainty is delaying business decisions and causing subdued demand for loans. The labour market remains "tight" with modest employment and wage gains, while the strong US dollar hinders exports of manufactured goods. Despite this, most forecast models suggest a strong advantage for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton over Republican Donald Trump, and policymakers are unlikely to raise interest rates before the presidential elections on November 8.

site_title: Love it or hate it? Two Americans dish on Obamacare
summary: Two Americans, Johann Ali and Todd Ulmen, share contrasting experiences with the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. Johann Ali, a self-employed environmental consultant, praises the ACA for providing affordable health insurance, preventive care, and protection against pre-existing conditions. In contrast, Todd Ulmen, a retail clothing business owner, finds the ACA's narrow networks and high costs unaffordable, leading him to purchase a private plan. Experts attribute the ACA's challenges to a lack of healthy young adults signing up, resulting in a rising price of health insurance and a gap in coverage for those who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid but not enough to afford private insurance.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets advance as shares in banks and retailers rise
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by gains in banks and retailers. The Stoxx 600 index, however, remains down 6% since the start of 2016. Banks benefited from Morgan Stanley's better-than-forecast profits, while retailers like Carrefour and Zalando advanced after reporting higher sales. However, investors remain cautious due to uncertainty over the UK's EU exit and the euro zone economy, with some companies issuing profit warnings.

site_title: BHP Billiton sees early signs of commodity markets recovery
summary: BHP Billiton Ltd, the world's largest mining company, reports early signs of commodity market recovery. CEO Andrew Mackenzie expects oil and natural gas to deliver gains into 2018 due to rebalancing fundamentals. Iron ore and metallurgical coal prices have been stronger than expected, but supply growth is expected to outpace demand in the near term.

site_title: First Reit's Q3 DPU up on contribution from Kupang Property
summary: First Reit's third quarter earnings rose 1.9% due to contributions from Kupang Property, with a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.12 Singapore cents. Distributable income grew 4.7% to S$16.3 million, and gross revenue increased 6.5% to S$26.9 million. The trust reduced gearing to 30% from 34.4% after issuing S$60 million subordinated securities. CEO Ronnie Tan expects continued growth and yield-accretive acquisitions to sustain returns to unit-holders, citing a growing healthcare sector in Indonesia.

site_title: China home sales surge despite cooling measures
summary: China's cooling measures to curb property prices have had an unintended effect, leading to a surge in home sales with a 61% increase in September compared to the previous year. Despite attempts to limit speculation, developers are buying into the boom, with new construction starts rising 14% and land purchases increasing 20% year-over-year. Policymakers face a dilemma in balancing growth with the risk of a housing bubble, with economists warning that further restrictions could lead to a down cycle in 2017.

site_title: The Great British Bake Off effect
summary: The Great British Bake Off has sparked a resurgence in home baking, with a noticeable increase in the quality of baked goods and a growing number of people pursuing careers as professional pastry chefs. The show's success has also led to a reinvigoration of British baking culture, emphasizing diversity and inclusiveness. With its multicultural contestants and wholesome appeal, the show has become a staple of British television, reaching a peak audience of 15 million viewers. As a result, supermarkets and baking supply stores have seen a significant increase in sales, with many enthusiasts seeking to deepen their baking skills through weekend classes.

site_title: Australia air freight crunch hits top-end food producers
summary: Australia is facing an unprecedented shortage of air cargo space, hindering top-end food producers from exporting luxury products such as lobster, cherries, and figs to Asia. The shortage, exacerbated by freight carriers prioritizing higher-margin shipments of beef and milk, is estimated to cost growers up to A$100 million per year. Despite a nearly doubling of air freight export volumes to 35,000 tonnes in June, the industry says the increase is not keeping pace with growing demand from Asia's middle class, particularly during peak holiday seasons.

site_title: Rosneft enters India with US$13b Essar deal
summary: Russian state-controlled oil company Rosneft has entered the Indian market with a $13 billion deal to acquire 98% of Essar Oil, a refinery in western India. Rosneft will own 49% of the refinery, with Trafigura oil traders also investing in the remaining 49%. The deal aims to boost Russia's strategic position and provide access to the Asia-Pacific region. Analysts see it as a strategic victory for Russia, allowing the country to diversify its energy exports and bypass Western sanctions.

images.alt_text: Essar Oil's Vadinar refinery in western India is one of the country's largest refineries and one of the world's most modern, with access to a port navigable by the largest vessels.

site_title: US: Oil, earnings lift Wall Street but Intel drags
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive day, driven by gains in the energy sector and solid earnings from Morgan Stanley and Halliburton. Oil prices surged, with Brent crude up 1.9% and US crude up 2.6%, after a report showed a sharp drop in domestic inventories. However, Intel's disappointing revenue forecast dragged on the market, with the chipmaker falling 5.9%. Despite this, the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose, with the Nasdaq Composite adding 2.58 points.

site_title: Myanmar's storied film industry gears up for a sequel
summary: Myanmar's film industry, once thriving under a military regime, is on the verge of a renaissance. With nearly 400 theaters in its heyday, the country now has only 50 remaining, mostly in urban Yangon. A businessman aims to build 100 new cinemas in two years, sparking hope for a revived industry. However, many directors and actors feel stifled by censorship and outdated storytelling, and there is a desire to raise the bar and tackle sensitive topics.

site_title: Yahoo's Q3 profit more than doubles to US$163m
summary: Yahoo's Q3 profit more than doubles to US$163m, driven by cost-cutting measures rather than core business growth. The company's quarterly earnings call was skipped due to a pending takeover by Verizon. Despite recent data breach revelations, Yahoo is busy preparing for the deal. The boost in profits comes as Yahoo prepares to be acquired by Verizon, marking a significant shift for the struggling internet pioneer.

site_title: Chinese Internet upstart takes on tech titans in US
summary: Chinese Internet company LeEco unveiled a range of products, including smartphones, televisions, bicycles, and self-driving electric cars, at a press event in San Francisco. The company plans to launch its products in the US market on November 2, with prices starting at $249 for a smartphone and $649 for a 4K television. LeEco's founder, Jia Yueting, stated that the company aims to create an interconnected ecosystem, rather than competing directly with US tech giants. The company will offer a virtual reality headset and a subscription service for online content, with a "flash sale" on its e-commerce website.

images.alt_text: A Chinese internet colossus referred to as a combination of Netflix, Apple, Amazon and Tesla announced Wednesday it is taking on US tech titans on their home turf.

site_title: Predictability needed as anchor with outlook dicey
summary: Singapore's economy is experiencing its slowest growth since the 2009 global financial crisis, with a 0.6% growth rate in the third quarter. The main engines of growth, manufacturing and services, have contracted. The economy is also shedding jobs, with redundancies and graduate unemployment reaching levels last seen during the crisis. To address these challenges, fiscal policy should provide counter-cyclical support, greater predictability in taxes and duties, and strengthen automatic stabilizers. The government can consider measures such as one-off rental and income tax rebates, predictable tax and duty rates, and unemployment insurance to help businesses and workers adapt to the uncertain economic environment.

site_title: Global money flees Japan stocks at fastest pace since 1987
summary: Foreign investors are exiting Japan's stocks at the fastest pace since 1987, with a $59 billion outflow, amid concerns over Shinzo Abe's economic policies and the surging yen. This exodus is fueled by the yen's 16% gain against the dollar and the BOJ's inability to prevent a 12% slide in Tokyo's Topix index this year. Experts say Abenomics' effectiveness is undermined by the yen's strength and the lack of lasting growth or inflation. Some investors believe the BOJ will eventually stimulate the market, but others are skeptical, citing the need for structural reforms and the BOJ's methods as "insane."

site_title: France won't bend to UK demands despite 'lose-lose' Brexit
summary: France will not compromise on its stance despite the UK's "hard Brexit," with French officials labeling the outcome a "lose-lose" situation. France sees the UK's decision to leave the EU as a British choice with consequences the British must accept. French leaders, including President François Hollande and Banque de France Governor François Villeroy de Galhau, have consistently stated that France will defend its interests and will not re-write the rules to benefit the departing UK. France's focus remains on its own sovereignty and the EU's future, with Prime Minister Manuel Valls emphasizing the nation state as Europe's future basis of citizen organization and representation.

site_title: In Nigeria's largest city, Monopoly mimics its chaotic property market
summary: In Lagos, Nigeria, a Monopoly tournament mimics the chaotic real estate market, with bribery, scams, and machete-wielding gangsters prevalent. The game, which began four years ago, features local properties such as Bourdillon Road and Agege, and has been recognized as an officially recognized sport by the Lagos State Sports Commission. Despite the tournament's popularity, the real estate market in Lagos is plagued by corruption, scams, and violence, with buyers often being extorted by gangs and government workers demanding bribes for official documents.

site_title: All HDB industrial space to be under JTC by Q1 2018
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will transfer all 10,700 industrial units and 540 land leases to the Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) by Q1 2018, consolidating under a single agency. The move aims to better support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in business growth, offering one-stop access to industrial facilities and facilitating more efficient clustering of complementary activities. JTC will continue to provide the same support to HDB tenants, with contracted terms and conditions remaining unchanged.

site_title: Asean must develop regional strategy to fight cyber crime
summary: Singapore's government networks are frequently targeted by cyber attacks, including distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks and fake websites impersonating government sites. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for cybersecurity to be a priority for the country to be considered a "Smart Nation." The government has established the Cyber Security Agency (CSA) in 2015 to oversee and coordinate cybersecurity efforts, but the threat of cyber crime remains a concern. Developing a regional strategy to combat cyber crime is essential for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

site_title: Evonik pumps over 500m euros into S'pore chemicals industry
summary: Evonik Industries is investing over 500 million euros (S$763 million) in Singapore to build its second methionine plant on Jurong Island, doubling its production capacity to 300,000 tonnes per year. The plant, expected to start operations in 2019, will create about 150 jobs and boost global production capacity to 730,000 tonnes. The investment is driven by growing demand for methionine in Asia Pacific due to increased meat consumption and environmental concerns. The move is seen as a statement of confidence in Singapore as a location for high-value manufacturing.

site_title: Samsung's handling of Galaxy Note 7 fires angers Chinese
summary: Samsung's handling of the Galaxy Note 7 fires has angered Chinese consumers. In 2016, a Chinese customer, Zhang Sitong, was offered a new phone and compensation after his Note 7 caught fire, despite the company's earlier assurances that the Chinese version was safe. Samsung had claimed the Chinese version had a different battery, but this contradicted the US recall of over two million Note 7s. The incident highlights the company's inconsistent communication with Chinese customers.

site_title: Do negative interest rates hurt Japan real estate?
summary: The Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy, adopted in February 2016, may not significantly harm Japan's real estate market, but could lead to excessive risk-taking and boom-and-bust cycles. Despite this, real estate prices have continued to rise, driven by low interest rates, a weak yen, and the introduction of "Abenomics". The expected cap rates for prime properties have fallen, and investors are encouraged to seek higher-yielding asset classes, pushing up prices. However, the persistence of negative interest rates and deflation may lead to further rounds of monetary stimulus, supporting real estate prices.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuroda of the BOJ said recently that there remains "ample space for additional easing" under the existing policy framework.

site_title: Hong Kong lawmakers blocked from retaking oath
summary: Hong Kong lawmakers Yau Wai-ching and Baggio Leung were blocked from retaking their oath, despite being given permission to do so, after pro-Beijing politicians walked out of the swearing-in session. The pair had refused to apologize for their behavior during last week's oath-taking ceremony, in which they draped themselves in "Hong Kong is not China" flags and refused to pronounce China properly. The session was abandoned, leaving the pair's future as lawmakers uncertain. The move has fueled concerns that Beijing is tightening its grip on Hong Kong, fueling an independence movement.

site_title: Bridging the chasm between strategy and execution
summary: A new management book, "Strategy That Works," by Paul Leinwand and Cesare Mainardi, aims to bridge the gap between strategy and execution. The authors argue that many business leaders struggle to translate their strategies into effective execution, resulting in a "strategy-to-execution gap." To overcome this, they emphasize the importance of capabilities, a unified value proposition, and a chosen portfolio of products and services. The book also highlights five acts of unconventional leadership, including "committing to an identity," "putting culture to work," and "cutting costs to grow stronger."

site_title: Few answer call by Trump to watch polls
summary: Donald Trump urged supporters to monitor polling places on Election Day, warning of widespread voter fraud and a "rigged" outcome. He cited incidents in cities like Philadelphia and Chicago, where he claims voter fraud has occurred. Trump's call comes as the US prepares for its presidential election, with many critics labeling his claims of widespread voter fraud as unfounded and potentially intimidating to voters.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore banks are expected to report earnings decline of 2-5% quarter-on-quarter due to weaker net interest income and higher provisions. CIMB Research predicts non-interest income may improve after a risk-off Q2. Banks are set to release their earnings on Oct 27 (OCBC), Oct 28 (UOB), and Oct 31 (DBS).

site_title: Shale drillers are going for long - not deep - wells in the oil patch
summary: Shale drillers in the Permian Basin are adopting a new strategy of drilling longer, not deeper, wells to tap into oil- and gas-trapping shale. Companies like SM Energy and Pioneer Natural Resources are spending billions to expand their acreage and drill 10,000-foot laterals, increasing the value of each well by four and a half times. This technique, known as lateral drilling, allows producers to pull more crude out of fewer wells, making contiguous acreage more valuable. As oil prices remain low, companies are embracing this strategy to stay competitive.

site_title: SGX's Q1 earnings fall 16.3% amid uncertain outlook
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 16.3% drop in Q1 net profit to $83.1 million, due to lower market activities and revenue. Despite this, the exchange remains committed to diversifying into new businesses, with plans to complete its acquisition of the Baltic Exchange by end-November and implement regulatory changes. SGX also cut expenses by 8% year-on-year and maintains an interim cash dividend of five Singapore cents per share. The exchange expects a subdued outlook but aims to increase market share.

images.alt_text: "Our first-quarter performance this year reflects lower levels of market activities, compared with a more volatile market a year earlier," says CEO Loh Boon Chye.

site_title: Standard Chartered moving past India woes with Essar payment
summary: Standard Chartered is set to receive a $2.1 billion repayment from Essar Global, a steel-to-power conglomerate, in the next few weeks. This repayment could allow the bank to write back around $100 million of provisions related to Essar Global loans, potentially reducing its nonperforming loan portfolio by 20%. The repayment is seen as progress in Standard Chartered's turnaround plan, led by CEO Bill Winters, who has been shrinking the bank's balance sheet and tightening lending standards.

site_title: More consumer protection for US air passengers
summary: The Obama administration unveiled new consumer protections for airline passengers, including refunds for late arriving bags, more detailed flight information, and clearer data on lost or damaged wheelchairs. The measures aim to improve fair treatment for 700 million passengers. Airlines have criticized the proposals, citing different business models and the need to offer optional services. Major carriers, including Delta, oppose certain plans, such as examining the withholding of fare information from online ticket sellers. The measures are part of a broader effort to promote competition in US business and are expected to take effect in the coming year.

site_title: US$ softer, investors ponder Dec rate hike view
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.2% to 97.696, as Treasury yields dropped after US consumer prices showed moderating inflation, reducing expectations of a December interest rate hike. The core consumer price index rose 0.1% in September, slowing the year-on-year increase to 2.2%. This has led to a 5% decrease in Fed fund futures' probability of a December rate hike, from 70% to 65%. Investors also await the European Central Bank's policy meeting, where they expect clarification on the future of its asset purchase scheme.

images.alt_text: The dollar index was subdued on Wednesday as Treasury yields ticked lower after US consumer prices suggested underlying inflation was moderating, prompting investors to trim bets on an interest rate hike later this year.

site_title: Prudential eyeing move to Marina One
summary: Prudential is in advanced negotiations for a 90,000 sq ft lease in Marina One's East Tower, potentially occupying ground-level space for a customer service centre. Meanwhile, Mitsui OSK Lines has signed a 68,000 sq ft lease at the new UIC Building, with JustGroup being the first office tenant to occupy 40,000 sq ft. The Marina One project, which will have over 280,000 sq ft of office space, is expected to receive a Temporary Occupation Permit in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: China property investment up 7.8% in Sept
summary: China's property investment rose 7.8% in September, its strongest growth since May, contributing to a 6.7% economic expansion in the third quarter. This growth was driven by booming construction, sales, and prices, but developers may be cautious of new developments due to concerns of a property bubble. New construction starts fell 19.4% in September, and policymakers are implementing measures to curb prices and demand, including higher mortgage down payments and bans on second-home purchases. Despite this, analysts expect property investment to support the economy until year-end.

site_title: Sovereign bond price setback shows dangers of inflated safe-haven assets
summary: The massive bond market has experienced a sharp price decline in recent weeks, highlighting the dangers of purchasing safe-haven assets at inflated prices. Global investors' decisions to reduce holdings can outstrip the control of major central banks like the US Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank. This price setback underscores the volatility of the bond market and the potential risks associated with seeking safe-haven assets. The decline is a significant concern for investors and policymakers worldwide.

site_title: Japan mulls registration for high-frequency traders
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency is considering a registration system for firms engaging in high-frequency trading, which accounts for 70% of orders at the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The regulator aims to balance benefits of increased liquidity with concerns over market stability. Proposed requirements include risk management systems, transaction recording, and bans on brokers taking orders from non-registered traders. The council plans to make recommendations by the end of the year and propose legislation in January, following similar proposals in the US and Europe.

site_title: Banks losing clients to their employees who venture out on their own
summary: A team of 13 Morgan Stanley advisers overseeing $2.2 billion in assets quit to start their own shop, 6 Meridian, marking the latest in a string of departures from big Wall Street banks. The advisers took advantage of an industry protocol that allows departing brokers to take clients with them, and a loophole in the agreement that allows new firms to join without fear of a lawsuit. This trend has shifted billions of dollars in assets away from big banks, with similar departures reported at Bank of America and Deutsche Bank. The protocol, devised in 2004, has had unintended consequences, straining the agreement and prompting some big firms to reinterpret or opt out.

site_title: When VR and AR become just reality
summary: Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) technologies are rapidly advancing and have already begun to impact daily life. Valued at $80 billion by 2025, VR and AR are expected to have a massive impact on various businesses, including retail, healthcare, and the workplace. Companies like eBay are already incorporating VR and AR into their operations, such as virtual reality shopping tools and markerless augmented reality for shoppers. As these technologies evolve, they are likely to change corporate interactions, training, and cybersecurity, requiring companies to adapt and prepare for the unknown.

site_title: Big car COE premium spikes in latest bidding
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums surged in the latest bidding exercise, with Cat B premiums jumping S$3,409 to S$56,410. The Cat E category also rose, while Cat C and Cat D saw slight increases. The COE quota for November to January 2017 will contract by 6.2% to 24,234, with the largest cuts in Cat A (8.2%) and Cat B (7.0%) COE allocations. The upcoming three-week break and concerns over the economic climate contributed to the premium spikes.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums were mixed in the final bidding exercise before the start of a smaller COE quota next month.

site_title: Buses will be next stop for Singapore's self-driving trials
summary: Singapore plans to launch self-driving bus trials, starting with staff and students of Nanyang Technological University in early 2017. The trial will expand to 40 passengers and later to commuters in nearby areas. The move comes after a suspension of the world's first self-driving taxi trial due to an accident. The trial aims to test the feasibility of driverless buses for fixed and scheduled services, alleviating manpower pressures and traffic congestion. A two-year trial is expected to assess the safety and efficiency of self-driving buses.

site_title: Jasper volume surge prompts SGX query
summary: Jasper Investments, a Singapore-listed transportation services provider, experienced a significant surge in trading volume on Wednesday, with shares rising 17.6% to S$0.02 before reverting to its opening price. The company responded to a Singapore Exchange query, stating it was unaware of any reason behind the unusual trading activity. The heavy trading, involving 243.15 million shares, was not attributed to any previously announced information or other explanation.

site_title: Alibaba's Koubei seen raising US$1 billion to fund expansion
summary: Alibaba's affiliate Koubei is seeking to raise $1 billion in funding, valuing it at $8 billion, to expand into more cities and add users in the neighborhood services market. The company, which generated $5 billion in payment volume through Alipay in the June quarter, is competing with other web giants for the market. Koubei focuses on customers when they visit restaurants, while Ele.me, another Alibaba venture, is focused on food delivery. The funding will help Koubei expand into more cities and add users, as the "online-to-offline" market is expected to reach $1.5 trillion by 2017.

site_title: Europe space lander aims for risky touchdown on Mars
summary: Europe's Schiaparelli lander is set to make history on Mars with a risky touchdown on Wednesday. The 577-kg disc-shaped lander, weighing nearly 1,000 kg, will enter Mars' atmosphere at 21,000 km/h, testing technologies for a rover due in 2020. This marks Europe's first attempt to land a craft on Mars since the Beagle 2's failed mission over a decade ago. The successful landing will pave the way for future Mars exploration and potentially search for life on the red planet.

site_title: Jokowi builds reform momentum after sluggish start
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, or Jokowi, has regained momentum after a sluggish start in his presidency. Two years into his job, he has asserted his authority, cut fuel subsidies, and boosted revenue through a tax amnesty program. Despite challenges, Jokowi must implement an ambitious infrastructure program, reduce corruption, and achieve a 7% growth target by 2019.

site_title: Extraordinary measures needed in Malaysia's 2017 Budget: analysts
summary: Malaysia's 2017 Budget faces criticism for lacking innovative measures to tackle challenges posed by globalization and competitiveness. Analysts, including Ramon Navaratnam and Khoo Kay Peng, urge the government to adopt policies that promote higher economic growth and fairer income distribution. The country's weak ringgit, which has depreciated by nearly 30% over two years, is also a major concern. The government is under pressure to address the socio-economic problems and restore public confidence, particularly ahead of snap polls expected next year.

site_title: Germany said to shut door on Brexit back channel deals
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel's government is refusing to engage in back-door talks with the UK ahead of Brexit negotiations, maintaining a united EU front. The German stance emphasizes that discussions can't start until Britain presents its opening gambit, and any early talks could hand the UK an advantage. Merkel's focus on defending European values and the EU's single market suggests that Germany will not grant the UK favorable terms, even at the risk of curbing economic ties.

site_title: Singapore Reits are best performers this year due to attractive yields
summary: Singapore Reits have outperformed other markets this year, driven by attractive yields that attract investors such as BNP Paribas Investment Partners and Samsung Asset Management. The FTSE Straits Times Real Estate Investment Trust index has risen 8.9% this year, beating peers in Australia, the US, Japan, and Europe. International investors have accelerated purchases of Singapore Reits, with 217.84 million units bought in the five biggest Reits. The high yields, which exceed 7% for some Reits, are supported by tenant demand and expected rent growth.

site_title: Sea row no barrier to warmer China ties: Manila
summary: Philippine Foreign Secretary says China-Philippines territorial disputes shouldn't hinder warming ties. President Rodrigo Duterte is on a visit to China with 200 business leaders to establish a new commercial alliance. The visit comes amid strained relations with the US. Duterte aims to mend relations and diversify trade, despite ongoing territorial disputes. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: S$55.8m disposal gain boosts Keppel T&T's Q3 bottom line
summary: Keppel T&T's Q3 net profit more than quadrupled to S$69.88m, driven by a S$55.81m gain from disposing of a subsidiary. Revenue fell 8.7% to S$46.5m, while earnings per share jumped to 12.5 cents. The company also announced a S$758,326 investment in Courex, a logistics services provider.

site_title: TPP likely to be ratified by US: former trade official
summary: A former US trade official suggests the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement will likely be ratified by the US if Hillary Clinton wins the presidential election, despite its failure in the current "lame duck" session of Congress. The agreement will probably be modified to make it acceptable to a Clinton administration.

site_title: Dearth of data making evaluation of driverless cars in America a tough job
summary: US regulators struggle to evaluate the safety of driverless cars due to a lack of comprehensive data on crashes. A study by Virginia Tech found that reported crashes are underreported by 60-84% and that human drivers are more likely to be involved in crashes. Despite this, Google's self-driving cars appeared to perform better than human drivers in crashes once underreporting was factored in. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is pushing for a comprehensive database to benchmark the performance of self-driving vehicles, but officials acknowledge that the development of safety metrics is still a work in progress.

site_title: UK migration controls must not harm the economy: Hammond
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond has urged measures to reduce net migration into Britain to be designed to protect the economy, as the country navigates its exit from the European Union. Hammond, who campaigned to keep Britain in the EU, has reportedly clashed with Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet over the issue, but remains in her confidence. Hammond's comments come amid concerns that a hard Brexit could damage the economy, with sterling having fallen 17% since the June 23 referendum vote. Hammond denied reports of a rift with the Bank of England over monetary policy.

site_title: Swatch CEO says Chinese sales back in growth since July: Handelszeitung
summary: Swatch CEO Nick Hayek reported that Chinese sales for the watchmaker have returned to growth since July, with monthly increases. Brands such as Omega, Blancpain, and Longines showed positive development. Additionally, the company expects its automobile battery to be certified for the Chinese market within one to two years.

site_title: D-Wave claims leap in quantum computing
summary: D-Wave Systems Inc has unveiled a new, more-powerful quantum computer capable of handling 2,000 quantum bits at any instant, a significant leap in performance compared to its predecessor. The new device can achieve performance up to 1,000 times greater than the previous version, but its capabilities are still limited to solving optimization problems, not general mathematical problems. Critics argue that D-Wave's approach may not achieve the breakthroughs predicted by researchers, but the company claims its system offers a major advantage over classical computers.

site_title: Hedge fund startups plummet in Asia amid low returns, high fees
summary: Asia's hedge fund startups have plummeted to their slowest pace since 2000, with 27 new funds opening in the first nine months of 2016, down from 83 last year. Low returns and high fees have discouraged investors, with many opting for established managers. Globally, 457 funds opened in the first nine months of 2016, down from 876 last year. The "2-and-20" fee model has come under pressure, with investors demanding lower fees and higher returns. Newcomers to the industry face a tough spot due to business viability and income generation through fees.

site_title: Harley-Davidson stock jumps on boost from new engine, cost cuts
summary: Harley-Davidson's stock surged 9% to $54.19 on Tuesday, the largest daily gain in three months, after the company reported a boost in sales due to its new Milwaukee-Eight engine. The engine helped generate sales gains in September in the US, where Harley has struggled amid competition and an industry slump.
