The use of BIM, in particular, has shown positive returns on investment, with 75% of users reporting cost savings and shortened project life cycles. The government is mandating the use of BIM on public infrastructure projects, and project owners and developers can encourage adoption by co-investing in technology pilots and sharing rewards proportionately.

site_title: ST Engg to book S$61m charge on China venture
summary: ST Engineering to record a one-off S$61 million charge in Q3 2016 due to its struggling China joint venture, Jiangsu Huatong Kinetics (JHK), which is expected to run out of cash. The charge includes an impairment of ST Kinetics' net carrying value in JHK and closure costs. This move comes as part of ST Engineering's ongoing review of its Chinese business, which has been hurt by severe oversupply in various industries.

site_title: IBM profit margins shrink again in shift to cloud computing
summary: IBM's operating gross profit margin for Q3 fell to 48%, missing the average analyst estimate of 50.1%, as the company continues to shift to cloud computing and subscription-based services. Revenue declined 0.3% to $19.23 billion, while sales from its strategic imperatives group rose 16% to $8 billion. IBM reaffirmed its full-year profit forecast, but shares fell 3% to $150.21 following the report, which highlighted the company's ongoing challenge in finding growth in newer businesses to offset declines in legacy units.

images.alt_text: The company now has 49 data centres, having added two new ones in the third quarter in South Korea and Norway, says Mr Schroeter.

site_title: Modi govt plans state aid for solar factories
summary: India's government plans a 210 billion-rupee ($4.4 billion) package of state aid for its solar panel manufacturing industry, known as the Prayas initiative. The goal is to lift installed photovoltaic capacity to 175 gigawatts by 2022 and create an export industry, emulating China's success. The program aims to create 5 gigawatts of manufacturing capacity by 2019 and 20 gigawatts by 2026, with the potential to create thousands of jobs.

images.alt_text: India's policy proposal, expected to create thousands of jobs, is also in response to the industry's demand for help to the country's solar manufacturers, according to one official.

site_title: World body urges Asean to build up its tourism infrastructure
summary: The World Travel & Tourism Council (WTTC) has urged Asean to invest in tourism infrastructure to match the expected tourism boom over the next decade. The council notes that some regional markets, such as Myanmar, Cambodia, and the Philippines, are facing infrastructure constraints despite being unprepared for the impending tourism boom. The WTTC calls for increased investments in airports, hotels, and tourist attractions to support the growth of travel and tourism in Asean.

site_title: ICC Academy to host trade finance conference on Oct 26
summary: The International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) Academy will host a trade finance conference on October 26, focusing on regulatory trends and compliance in the industry. Key speakers include ICC secretary general John Danilovich and DBS managing director Lim Him Chuan. The conference aims to provide high-quality training for trade professionals on managing risks and ensuring operational efficiency. The event will also feature the release of the 2016 ICC Global Trade and Finance Survey results, which provides a detailed view of market trends. All Singaporeans and permanent residents can benefit from a 50% refund on registrations.

site_title: Australia's Tatts, Tabcorp in talks to create A$9.34b gaming giant
summary: Australia's Tatts Group Ltd and Tabcorp Holdings Ltd are in talks to merge, creating a A$9.34 billion gaming giant. The proposed deal aims to counter popular online rivals and bolster the companies' market presence. An investment banker involved in the talks expects a transaction announcement within the next two days. The combined entity would be one of the largest non-casino gambling firms in the country, significantly expanding its online betting capabilities and competitiveness.

site_title: Oil drifts as dollar offsets bullish Opec outlook
summary: Oil prices drifted lower on Tuesday, erasing early gains, as a stronger US dollar offset optimism over Opec's potential output cut in November. Despite a 13% rise in oil prices from three weeks ago, doubts remain about the cartel's ability to reach a deal, with some members preferring higher prices. Brent crude fell 0.4% to $51.32 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude slid 5 cents to $49.89 a barrel. Analysts say the market is too focused on the near-term outcome, despite recent positive trends.

site_title: China tech executives face health burdens in cut-throat industry
summary: A prominent Chinese mobile health app startup founder, Zhang Rui, died from a heart attack at 44, prompting a soul-searching in the Chinese tech community. Despite initial speculation that overwork was a cause, the company's spokesman stated there's no evidence to support this claim. The incident highlights the health burdens faced by China's tech executives, who often prioritize long hours and profit over well-being in pursuit of success. This raises concerns about the industry's culture and the need for better work-life balance.

site_title: Green expectations
summary: Gold prices rose after US President Donald Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada, with potential threats to other countries. Oil prices fell amid concerns over a bearish outlook due to Trump's tariff policies. China's solar stocks surged as the government calmed price wars, while Opec trimmed its oil demand forecast for the next four years. In other news, ExxonMobil is reportedly in talks to sell its Singapore stations to Aster, and Chinese tycoons are investing in Indonesia to become the country's aluminium giant. Global energy markets remain volatile amid Trump's trade policies.

site_title: Hiring in London has dropped sharply on Brexit, Hays CFO says
summary: London's financial industry has seen a sharp drop in hiring following the UK's Brexit vote, with Hays Plc reporting a 17% decline in London hiring compared to a 13% rise globally. Companies are being cautious with costs, citing uncertainty about the future. CFO Paul Venables stated that "business loves certainty" and that the drop in the pound is a sign of this uncertainty. While hiring has resumed for ongoing projects, new capital investments are being put on hold, and there is lingering uncertainty about trade deals with the EU and other blocs.

site_title: Investors build up cash piles, bond market crash fears grow: BAML poll
summary: Global investors have raised cash holdings to 5.8% from 5.5% in the previous month, as fears of a bond market crash grow. The bond allocation has been cut to a 10-month low, with 76% of respondents thinking bond prices are "frothy." Investors are instead shifting towards emerging market equities and commodities as inflation hedges, with emerging market equity allocations rising to a 3.5-year high. The survey also found that 31% of respondents expect yield curves to steepen, the highest since June 2014, amid concerns about stagflation.

site_title: China sets up new body to oversee aviation supplies
summary: China has established a new body, China Aviation Supplies, to oversee the aviation supply sector. The company is jointly owned by five state-owned firms, including China Southern Airlines and China Eastern Airlines. The goal is to promote efficient supply chain management and innovation in the sector. This move is part of China's ongoing reform of the state-owned enterprise sector and comes as civil aviation continues to boom in the country due to economic growth and increased air travel demand.

site_title: Vietnam gives thumbs-up to US regional role as pivot stumbles
summary: Vietnam's defense ministry has endorsed a continued US presence in the Asia-Pacific, supporting US "intervention" in the region to maintain peace and stability. Vice Defense Minister Nguyen Chi Vinh met with US Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Cara Abercrombie, affirming Vietnam's backing for a positive US role. The move comes amid uncertainty over Washington's faltering "pivot" strategy and the US presidential election. Vietnam has warmed ties with the US in recent years, including the lifting of a lethal arms embargo in May, and has disputes with China in the South China Sea.

site_title: Opec sec-gen optimistic on reaching oil output deal in Nov
summary: Opec Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo expressed optimism that the group will reach an oil production deal by November, with all 14 members agreeing to limit output to a range of 32.50-33.0 million barrels per day. Russia, not an Opec member, is committed to contributing to output limits, and a High Level Committee will meet in Vienna to finalize implementation details. Barkindo downplayed concerns over individual country output levels and suggested flexibility in implementation to account for special circumstances.

site_title: Decision on London airport expansion due next week
summary: The British government is set to make a decision on London's airport expansion next week, with speculation that it will back a new runway at Heathrow. The decision, delayed for years, has been made by a cabinet sub-committee, with ministers allowed to voice their views. A new runway at Heathrow would cost £17.6 billion and generate up to £147 billion over 60 years, but faces opposition from environmental groups and lawmakers. Business groups argue it would boost trade and help Britain keep up with rapidly expanding airports in the Middle East and Asia.

site_title: US: Wall St rallies on strong corporate earnings reports
summary: US stocks rallied on Tuesday, driven by strong corporate earnings reports. The S&P 500 rose 0.69% to 2,141.22, with all 11 major sectors gaining, led by the healthcare index. Netflix surged 17.5% after beating subscriber growth expectations, while UnitedHealth and Goldman Sachs also reported strong results. Analysts narrowed their estimate for a third-quarter profit drop, citing the positive earnings reports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.58% to 18,191.49.

site_title: Parallel imports hit 24% of 65,412 cars registered
summary: Parallel imports of cars in Singapore hit 24% of 65,412 registered vehicles in the first nine months of 2016, with Honda Vezel being the top model, accounting for 8,238 registrations. This marks the brand as the top model overall, surpassing authorized distributors' sales. The PI industry is expected to achieve record market share by year-end, driven by lower COE premiums and significantly larger COE quotas. However, demand for new cars has softened, with a 30% decline in the last three months, raising concerns about the industry's long-term prospects.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 13.56 points, or 0.5%, to 2,830.63 on Tuesday, with 1.6 billion shares worth S$902 million traded. The two-day gain marked the fifth consecutive rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Growth in low-fee products helps boost BlackRock profits
summary: BlackRock Inc, the world's largest asset manager, reported a 3.8% increase in quarterly net income to $875 million, driven by growth in low-fee products. The company's assets under management grew to over $5 trillion, with its iShares ETF business attracting $51.3 billion in new money. Despite a challenging market, BlackRock's long-term products absorbed $55.1 billion in cash, outperforming its peers. The company's shares rose 4.1% since the beginning of the year.

site_title: Road map to raise construction productivity
summary: Singapore aims to increase construction productivity by up to 3% annually until 2020, with the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) launching a new research and development road map to achieve this goal. The BCA plans to step up 35 technologies in seven R&D clusters and will specify productivity outcomes such as manpower savings for future Government Land Sales sites. The move is expected to improve collaboration, reduce construction noise, and enhance worksite safety, while maintaining building quality. Productive methods can save time and improve quality, according to BCA chief executive officer John Keung.

images.alt_text: Construction site productivity has increased by an average of 1.3 per cent each year since 2009, but there is still room for improvement as manpower will remain a "key constraint", National Development Minister Lawrence Wong said on Tuesday.

site_title: China Sept new yuan loans rise well above forecasts to 1.22t yuan
summary: China's banks extended 1.22 trillion yuan in new loans in September, a three-month high and exceeding forecasts, while money supply growth edged up. This indicates the People's Bank of China is keeping policy accommodative to support economic growth. However, recent data suggests many Chinese companies are hoarding cash, limiting the effectiveness of further central bank easing. Outstanding yuan loans grew 13% annually, driven by local government debt swaps and strong mortgage demand, highlighting risks to the banking system if a property boom pops.

site_title: Paris starts poaching business from London post-Brexit vote
summary: Paris begins advertising campaign to poach London's business after the UK's Brexit vote, citing lower rentals and good public transport as attractions. The campaign targets London's Heathrow Airport and Eurostar train station, highlighting Paris La Defense as a financial hub. London, which accounts for 41% of global foreign exchange turnover, may lose its position as the top financial capital due to Brexit, prompting officials to promote Paris as an alternative.

images.alt_text: According to Mr Hollande, Britain's decision to leave the EU should not jeopardise the bloc's principle of free movement.

site_title: M1's Q3 profit falls 23.4% to S$34.4m
summary: M1's third-quarter net profit fell 23.4% to S$34.4 million, primarily due to a 10.3% drop in revenue to S$249.1 million. Ebitda and earnings per share also declined. The company attributed the decline to traditional telecommunications services being impacted by OTT services and excess data usage revenue. However, key growth segments, such as IoT and cybersecurity, continue to trend well, and M1 made progress on new initiatives.

site_title: Asia: Markets climb on US rate hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday as investors awaited key US economic data and the last presidential debate, despite a negative lead from New York and Europe. The US Federal Reserve's comments on interest rates raised expectations for a gradual pace of rises, boosting regional markets. The dollar fell against several currencies, and stocks rallied, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai gaining 0.4-1.6% each. Attention turns to Chinese third-quarter economic growth figures and the European Central Bank policy meeting later this week.

site_title: China: Stocks end up as fears over B-share slump fade
summary: China stocks rallied on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index rising 1.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 1.4%, as investors shifted focus to Chinese economic data. The market rebounded from Monday's sell-off in B-share index amid yuan depreciation fears, with infrastructure and industrial stocks leading the gains. Analysts attributed the rebound to excessive fear-driven selling, and investors are now awaiting key economic data releases this week to gauge China's economic health.

site_title: Driverless car in Singapore collides with lorry, no injuries
summary: A self-driving car being tested in Singapore collided with a lorry on Tuesday, with no injuries reported. The test vehicle, operated by nuTonomy with two engineers on board, was changing lanes when the incident occurred. The Land Transport Authority stated that the test was being conducted at a slow speed. This incident is part of Singapore's efforts to develop autonomous technologies, with the goal of encouraging residents to use shared vehicles and public transport.

site_title: Investing in EMs: It's 'how' not 'when'
summary: Investors should focus on identifying stocks that can consistently generate returns, rather than timing the entry into emerging markets (EMs). EM stocks have experienced a revival, with the MSCI Emerging Market Index returning 13.86% year-to-date. However, getting the timing right is nearly impossible, and investors should prioritize strategies that generate consistent returns. Analysis shows that pulling in and out of EMs can significantly diminish return potential. Investors should examine their exposure to EMs, reassess their approaches, and focus on active stock selection, sector fundamentals, and long-term growth trends.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.86 points to close at 1,667.57 on Tuesday, driven by gains in the stock market. 1.57 billion lots valued at RM1.88 billion were traded, with 467 gainers and 319 losers. The market closed higher despite no major news or announcements.

site_title: Euro zone banks to tighten access to corporate lending: ECB survey
summary: Euro zone banks are tightening access to corporate lending for the first time in 2.5 years due to increased risk aversion and negative interest rates eating into their profits. The European Central Bank's lending survey found that banks stopped easing credit standards for enterprises in the third quarter and a majority expect to tighten them in the current quarter. Lenders cited lower risk tolerance and negative deposit rates as factors contributing to the tightening, which may lead to higher lending rates and charges for customers.

site_title: Goldman Sachs profit beats expectations on bond-trading surge
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 58% increase in net income to $2.1 billion, beating expectations, driven by a 34% surge in bond trading revenue. The bank's revenue from trading fixed-income securities, commodities, and currencies jumped to $1.96 billion. Analysts had expected $3.82 per share. Goldman's shares rose 1.9% to $172.21, and the bank attributed the strong performance to a rebound in bond trading and lower costs. The bank's return-on-equity was 11.2%, exceeding expectations.

site_title: China to limit rare earth output to no more than 140,000 tonnes a year by 2020
summary: China plans to limit rare earth metals output to 140,000 tonnes per year by 2020, down from 300,000 tonnes in 2015. The country also aims to cut separation capacities to 200,000 tonnes. Additionally, China will crack down on illegal activities in the rare earth mining sector. This move is part of a five-year development plan for the industry. The goal is to promote sustainable development and reduce reliance on China's dominant rare earth market.

site_title: Opec reversal is gift to oil majors after 2 years of 'hell'
summary: Opec has unexpectedly cut production, limiting volatile crude prices, a move that could benefit oil majors after two years of low prices. The decision aims to encourage spending and prevent a supply crisis, with Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid Al Falih seeking to convince explorers to start drilling again. Oil prices have risen to around $50 a barrel, a level where many majors can start investing, with Total SA welcoming the move and BP planning to balance cash flow with shareholder payouts. However, the deal's sustainability is uncertain due to potential non-Opec production increases and fractures within the group.

images.alt_text: When the bosses of the world's biggest oil companies gather in London on Tuesday, they might have the urge to track down the Saudi energy minister and shake him by the hand.

site_title: SIIC to up stake in Longjiang Environmental Protection Group
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings plans to acquire a 32.6562% stake in Longjiang Environmental Protection Group for 836 million yuan (S$172 million). The deal, funded by internal resources and borrowings, will see Longjiang become a subsidiary of SIIC, with SIIC owning 57.9687% of the equity interest. The acquisition is aimed at expanding SIIC's wastewater treatment business.

site_title: China challenges weigh on Danone third-quarter sales
summary: Danone, the world's largest yoghurt maker, reported a slowdown in third-quarter sales growth due to difficulties in China, particularly in its baby food and water divisions. Despite this, the company maintained its full-year guidance and expressed confidence in stabilizing dairy sales in Europe. Like-for-like sales growth was 2.1% in the third quarter, below analyst estimates of 2.2%. The company attributed the slowdown to a transition in China's regulatory environment and indirect demand for baby formula.

site_title: Australia's Tabcorp, Tatts in talks to create A$9.34b gaming giant
summary: Australia's Tatts Group Limited and Tabcorp Holdings Ltd are in talks to merge, forming a $9.34 billion gaming giant. The deal would combine the two companies, which command over two-thirds of the country's sports wagering market. A potential transaction could be announced within the next two days, pending a trading halt. The companies' shares have been declining due to competition from online betting agencies. The merger would require approval from 75% of Tatts' shareholders and would be scrutinized by Australia's competition regulator.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport seeks a new partner for its investment in Rio's Galeão international airport. ST Engg records a S$61m charge due to concerns over a Chinese joint-venture project running out of cash. A self-driving car in Singapore collided with a lorry, causing no injuries. Ezra Holdings seeks bondholders' consent to amend terms of its 4.875% notes. CDL plans to buy a 20% stake in a Tokyo residence. DHL launches a new S$140m facility at Changi to boost operational efficiency. Singapore shares close 0.5% higher on Tuesday.

site_title: China Sept new yuan loans rise to 1.22 trillion yuan, well above forecasts
summary: China's central bank extended 1.22 trillion yuan in new loans in September, exceeding forecasts and indicating a accommodative monetary policy. The growth in money supply edged up, but analysts remain skeptical about the effectiveness of further central bank easing due to companies' cash hoarding. Household loans accounted for 46% of total loans, driven by strong mortgage demand, while local governments are implementing restrictions on property purchases to cool soaring home prices. The PBOC has pledged to keep policy slightly loose, but analysts expect limited room for further interest rate cuts or rate reductions.

site_title: AP Oil, MoneyMax expand into financial leasing in Chongqing
summary: AP Oil International and MoneyMax Financial Services have partnered with Zongshen, a Chongqing-based motorcycle manufacturer, to form a joint-venture (JV) company focused on financial leasing in Chongqing, China. AP Oil will invest $5.14 million for a 12.5% stake, while Zongshen will hold 70%, MoneyMax 12.5%, and the Chongqing Free Trade Port Co will own 5%. The JV will engage in financial leasing, consulting, and leasing technology development in Chongqing, expanding AP Oil's existing relationship with Zongshen's subsidiaries.

images.alt_text: LUBRICATING-OIL manufacturer AP Oil International is venturing into financial leasing in Chongqing, China through a partnership with Singapore-listed MoneyMax Financial Services and two Chinese companies.

site_title: Remy Cointreau Q2 sales accelerate with China, US
summary: Remy Cointreau reported Q2 sales growth of 7.4% to 294.8 million euros, driven by 9.3% year-on-year sales growth in cognac, its largest market. Sales accelerated due to improved cognac sales in China and robust demand for premium cognac in the US. The company maintained its goal to increase current operating profit on a comparable basis for the full financial year. Sales growth was a reversal from a 0.5% decline in the previous quarter.

site_title: DHL to boost operational efficiency with new S$140m facility at Changi
summary: DHL has launched a new S$140 million facility at Changi Airfreight Centre, increasing its cargo handling capacity and processing shipments six times faster. The 23,600 square meter automated facility features an express parcel sorting and processing system, and a South Asia Hub, allowing for direct shipments to the hub and reducing travel and handling time. The facility is 33% larger than DHL's previous one and will enable the company to streamline service center operations, providing faster deliveries and better business efficiency.

site_title: Pimco cuts Asia risk while being Bullish on India, Indonesia
summary: Pimco, the world's largest actively-managed bond fund, is shifting its investment focus from high-yielding Asian assets to investment-grade bonds due to global uncertainty. The company expects a possible Federal Reserve rate hike and US presidential election risks. Despite this, Pimco remains bullish on India and Indonesia, citing their strong economic fundamentals and high-yielding sovereign bonds. The company has reduced its holdings in Thailand and the Philippines, but increased its overweight position in Indian corporates and quasi-sovereigns.

images.alt_text: Pacific Investment Management Co, which runs the world's biggest actively-managed bond fund, is shifting to investment grade from high-yielding dollar assets in Asia, expecting a period of global uncertainty.

site_title: ST Engg to book S$61m charge amid fears China unit will run out of cash
summary: ST Engg to record a S$61 million one-off charge for the third quarter due to concerns that its Chinese joint-venture project, JHK, will run out of cash. The project, which produces road construction equipment, will cease production to reduce operating losses. ST Kinetics owns 75.3% of JHK, with the remaining 24.7% held by China's state-owned enterprise Jiangsu Huatong Machinery. The charge is a result of the proposed halt in production, which is expected to impact the company's financials.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC are expanding cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rose for the 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: In Florida, Puerto Ricans could help sway White House race
summary: A growing number of Puerto Ricans, who are US citizens, are registering to vote in Florida, a key battleground state in the 2016 US presidential election. Since 2012, over 1 million Hispanics, mostly from Puerto Rico, have migrated to the state, many settling in the Orlando area. This influx has increased the Hispanic vote in Florida by 61% and has historically favored Democrats. Many of these new residents, such as Ana Iris Vazquez, strongly support Hillary Clinton, potentially swaying the state's outcome.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 climbing 0.6%, the DAX 30 rising 0.5%, and the CAC 40 increasing 0.7%. The positive open follows gains in Asian trading, driven by a decline in the US dollar ahead of US inflation data. Data expected to show UK inflation accelerated in September, contributing to the pound's 7.5-year lows against the euro and 31-year troughs versus the dollar since the UK's Brexit vote.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says oil at US$50-US$60 ensures adequate global supply
summary: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait suggest that oil prices between $50-$60 a barrel would ensure a sufficient global supply, setting a potential price band before the Opec meeting in Vienna next month. This would allow the development of low-cost resources to increase production over the next three to four years. Kuwait's Oil Minister and Saudi Arabia's Oil Co director agree that this scenario is logical and acceptable, while some industry experts, such as the International Energy Agency's Fatih Birol, see it as enough to meet short-term supply needs until 2020, potentially spurring US shale oil production.

site_title: Samsung says to invest 19.7b rupees to expand India plant
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd plans to invest 19.7 billion rupees (S$411.56 million) to expand its plant in northern India, near New Delhi. The plant, which produces mobile phones, refrigerators, and televisions, will receive the investment to enhance its operations. The expansion is aimed at bolstering Samsung's presence in the Indian market.

site_title: Rising gasoline, rents push US inflation higher in September
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.3% in September, the largest gain in five months, driven by surging gasoline and rent costs. The 12-month CPI accelerated 1.5%, the biggest year-on-year increase since October 2014. This inflation data suggests the economy is strong enough to generate inflation pressures, potentially keeping the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates in December.

images.alt_text: US consumer prices recorded their biggest gain in five months in September as the cost of gasoline and rents surged, pointing to a steady build-up of inflation that could keep the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates in December.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rebound, helped by China gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.5% to 23,388.37 points, driven by a rebound in Chinese stocks. China's A-share market was lower due to yuan depreciation fears, but Shanghai's US dollar-denominated B shares stabilized. The Hang Seng index and China Enterprises Index both gained, indicating a positive trend in Asian markets.

site_title: Hays says hiring in London slumps after Brexit vote
summary: Hiring in London slumped 17% after the UK's Brexit vote, according to Hays, an international recruitment firm. This decline follows a 10% year-on-year fall in net fees at constant currencies from the UK and Ireland in the three months to September 30. Despite stabilizing hiring for permanent jobs, temporary placements fell 11% in the quarter. The Brexit vote has led to cautious investment by firms, with some fearing rising unemployment. However, Hays reported strong growth in continental European markets.

site_title: Kurds announce progress in operation to degrade IS east of Mosul
summary: Iraqi Kurdish Peshmerga forces captured nine villages east of Mosul, degrading Islamic State's defenses in a 24-hour operation backed by the US-led coalition. The operation secured a significant stretch of the road between Erbil and Mosul, with coalition warplanes attacking 17 Islamic State positions. At least four car bombs were destroyed, and the Peshmerga claimed to have secured a crucial area for the upcoming offensive on Mosul, the largest city still under IS control.

site_title: Sharks are beautiful, diver says despite narrow escape
summary: A diver, Chan Ming, narrowly escaped a great white shark's attack while shark-watching off the Mexican coast. The shark broke into the metal cage, but Ming remained calm, and after a 20-second ordeal, he emerged safely. Despite the close call, Ming views great white sharks as "beautiful" and plans to continue diving. The incident led to reinforcement of the cage and changes in bait-throwing procedures to minimize future breaches. The shark suffered no serious injuries and was able to escape.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank seen standing pat on rates for now: poll
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5% for now, according to a Reuters poll of 17 economists. Only four economists predicted a 25 basis point cut, with seven expecting the rate to remain at 5% by year-end. This decision aims to stabilize the economy amidst global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Ryanair trims profit forecast on sterling weakness
summary: Ryanair has trimmed its full-year profit forecast by 5% due to the fall in sterling's value. The airline expects net profit between €1.3 billion and €1.35 billion, down from a previous forecast of €1.375 billion to €1.425 billion. Average fares could drop by up to 15% this winter, affecting the airline's revenue. Ryanair earns a third of its revenue in sterling, which contributes to the forecast reduction.

site_title: Filipinos trust United States much more than China: survey
summary: A survey by the Social Weather Stations found that 76% of Filipinos have "much trust" in the US, while 22% trust China. Despite President Rodrigo Duterte's recent criticism of the US and increased ties with China, the poll showed a slight decline in trust in both countries. Duterte's visit to China on Tuesday aims to boost the Philippine economy and diversify foreign policy. His anti-American rhetoric has left some Americans in the Philippines jittery, while experts warn that his shift towards China may risk destabilizing the region.

site_title: Samsung to compensate Galaxy Note 7 parts suppliers
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd will compensate component suppliers for the discontinued Galaxy Note 7 smartphones, covering unused parts, unfinished components, and materials bought to make Note 7 parts. The move comes after the company permanently ended sales of the fire-prone Galaxy Note 7 less than two months after its launch.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q3 DPU dips on sale of Sydney building
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 5.4% year-over-year decline in net property income to S$31.58 million for Q3 2016, with gross rent falling 6.5% to S$37.82 million. The decline was mainly due to the absence of income from the divestment of 77 King Street in Sydney. Partially offset by higher income from Ocean Financial Centre in Singapore, the company's DPU fell to 1.60 Singapore cents from 1.70 cents in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Reit on Tuesday posted distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.60 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2016, down from 1.70 Singapore cents in the same year-ago period.

site_title: CDL to buy 20% stake in 163-unit Tokyo residence
summary: CDL plans to buy a 20% stake in Park Court Aoyama The Tower, a 163-unit Tokyo residence, for an undisclosed amount. The project has a total gross development value of over 50 billion yen (S$666 million). The 26-storey tower features facilities like a swimming pool, gym, and private garden, with apartment sizes ranging from 389 to 3,789 square feet. Show flat previews have begun, with prices starting from 178.8 million yen for a one-bedroom unit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.69% in early trade on Tuesday, following a previous day's losses, while US data tempered interest rate hike bets. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,197.14, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.12% each. US tepid data and ongoing US-China trade talks contributed to the market's cautious mood.

site_title: Thai minister urges 'social sanctions' for royal critics
summary: Thai Justice Minister Paiboon Koomchaya urged "social sanctions" for those accused of defaming the monarchy following King Bhumibol Adulyadej's death, vowing to hunt down critics both at home and overseas. Royalist mobs and online crusaders have punished those perceived to have insulted the monarchy, including a woman charged with lese majeste for posting a comment on Facebook. The junta plans to renew extradition requests for Thais abroad, despite foreign governments being unlikely to cooperate.

site_title: Hyundai Motor's new China plants to build green cars, China-specific models
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. has announced plans to build two new plants in China, producing environmentally friendly vehicles and models targeting the local market. The facilities, set to be completed by 2017, will produce nine green vehicles by 2020, accounting for 10% of Hyundai's sales in China. The company aims to compete with low-cost Chinese rivals and will also sell a China-specific sport utility vehicle starting next year.

site_title: Asia: Markets climb, dollar dips after US figures
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, despite a weak US dollar, following mixed US economic data. The US dollar fell against the yen, euro, and pound, but regional markets rallied. Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Seoul all gained, with Singapore and Manila also posting healthy gains. Analysts expect a December rate hike by the Fed, but mixed data tempered expectations. Attention turns to Chinese third-quarter economic growth figures on Wednesday, which are expected to show a slowdown.

site_title: Americans work 25% more than Europeans, study finds
summary: A new study found that Americans work 25% more hours than Europeans, with the average US worker putting in 258 fewer hours per year. This translates to about an hour less per weekday. Europeans work 19% less than the average US worker, with US workers retiring later and taking fewer vacation days.

images.alt_text: Americans are addicted to their jobs. US workers not only put in more hours than workers do almost anywhere else. They're also increasingly retiring later and taking fewer vacation days.

site_title: Duterte's Beijing visit is a chance to reset China relations
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is visiting Beijing, China, for a four-day trip starting Tuesday, seeking to reset relations and boost infrastructure investment. The visit comes after a tumultuous first three months in office, marked by a war on drugs that has claimed thousands of lives, and international criticism of alleged extrajudicial killings. Duterte is looking for Chinese investment to alleviate economic concerns, including a decline in peso value and a loss of foreign investment. This trip marks a shift towards a closer relationship with China, potentially altering the Philippines' military alliance with the US.

site_title: 8 in 10 Singaporeans worry about growing old: survey
summary: A survey of Singaporeans found that 8 in 10 people are worried about growing old, with concerns over self-care and financial security being top issues. The survey also highlighted financial worries of running out of savings.

images.alt_text: Eight in 10 Singaporeans are worried about growing old, a survey has found.

site_title: Thailand must observe at least 15 days' mourning before royal succession: PM
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha announced that the country must observe at least 15 days of mourning for King Bhumibol Adulyadej before his successor, Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn, can ascend the throne. This follows the king's death last Thursday at the age of 88. The coronation of the crown prince will take place after the cremation of the king, which will follow a year of mourning, and the prince can become king before his official coronation.

site_title: AU Group, PhillipCapital set up joint venture to tap growth opportunities in Asia
summary: AU Group and PhillipCapital have established a joint venture, AU Group Asia, to tap growth opportunities in Asia. The partnership, led by Gerald Lim and Don Low, will focus on credit and political risks insurance. The joint venture aims to help companies in the region optimise receivables, control risks, and facilitate funding requirements. This move is seen as a strategic expansion for both companies, with the Asia-Pacific region being a key area for growth in traditional credit insurance and structured trade and political risk insurance.

images.alt_text: SPECIALIST credit-insurance broker AU Group and PhillipCapital have announced a new joint venture in Asia and the opening of its first subsidiary in Singapore.

site_title: Trump to propose five-year lobbying ban on ex-executive branch officials
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump plans to propose a five-year ban on ex-executive branch officials lobbying after leaving government, as well as a lifetime ban on senior officials lobbying for foreign governments. Trump also intends to ask Congress to impose a similar ban on former lawmakers and their staff.

site_title: YouTube signs up The Rock for new pay channel
summary: YouTube has signed actor Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson and director Doug Liman to produce shows for its subscription service. Johnson will star in the series "Lifeline" about an insurance company that prevents customer deaths, while Liman will produce "Impulse" about a girl who can teleport. The partnership marks YouTube's efforts to expand its content offerings and attract top talent.

images.alt_text: YouTube has signed up the world's highest paid actor Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson and Doug Liman, the director of The Bourne Identity, to make shows for its subscription service, it said late on Monday.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks step up on cautious Fed official's comments
summary: The South Korean won and shares rose on Tuesday after US Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Stanley Fischer offered cautious remarks about raising interest rates, citing a potential for longer and deeper recessions. The won was up 0.4% and the Kospi index rose 0.2%. Fischer's statement was seen as less confident about the US economy, boosting the won and South Korean shares. Offshore investors purchased a net 62.3 billion Korean won worth of Kospi stocks, while chipmaker SK Hynix Inc and LG Display Co Ltd declined.

site_title: Malaysia on alert as Mosul offensive stokes fears of militant influx
summary: Malaysia has increased security measures at its borders amid fears of a potential influx of militants returning home after the Iraqi forces' launch of a major offensive against the Islamic State stronghold of Mosul. The country has estimated around 4,000-8,000 militants, including Malaysians, in the city. Authorities have been exchanging intelligence with international agencies and have a suspect list, with 137 people already arrested for ties to Islamic State. Returning fighters will be detained and sent for deradicalisation, and Malaysia has revoked passports of 68 Malaysians who left the country to join the group.

site_title: On the trail of South Korea's high-tech peeping Toms
summary: In South Korea, a growing number of high-tech peeping Toms are using smartphones and spy gadgets to film women without their consent, particularly in public restrooms and changing rooms. The "molka" trend has become a daily news issue, with perpetrators ranging from college-educated men to pastors and coaches. To combat the problem, the Seoul city police have established an all-female squad to hunt down hidden cameras, and the government has offered cash rewards for reporting crimes. Experts say the issue is deeply rooted in South Korea's patriarchal culture and lack of open discussion about sex, and that a societal solution is needed to address the problem.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as mixed US data damp rate hike outlook
summary: Asian stocks rose as mixed US economic data supported the case for monetary policy to remain accommodative. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.1% to 138.28, while Japan's Topix index lost 0.1%. Investors are cautious ahead of the US presidential debate, but momentum builds for a December rate hike by the Federal Reserve. China's shares plummeted 6.2% in late trading, and New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 Index tumbled 1.3%.

site_title: Australia shares climb on financials, miners; NZ slides
summary: Australian shares rose 0.57% on Tuesday, driven by gains in financials and mining shares, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,413.9. Challenger Ltd reached a 16-year high after announcing asset growth, while iron ore futures fueled gains for miners like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index slid 1.3% due to losses in utilities and healthcare stocks, with Genesis Energy Ltd declining 2.9%.

site_title: New Silkroutes signs MOU with Chinese company to trade Middle East oil products
summary: New Silkroutes Group signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China Shipbuilding Industry Equipment and Materials Co to explore cooperation in trading Middle East oil products. The partnership aims to procure crude oil and petroleum products and incorporate a Singapore company to develop business activities in line with the "One Belt, One Road" initiative.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.850 points to 1655.560. Volume reached 16.99 million lots worth RM5.83 million, with 74 gainers outnumbering 41 losers.

site_title: Hyundai Merchant Marine considering bid for Hanjin's Asia-US route operations
summary: Hyundai Merchant Marine is considering a preliminary bid for Hanjin Shipping's Asia-to-US route operations, which include five container ships and 10 overseas businesses. The move comes after Hanjin filed for court receivership due to creditor cut-offs. A final decision has not been made. This acquisition would help Hyundai strengthen its presence in the global shipping market.

site_title: Tears and tortoises: Chinese TV unveils graft secrets
summary: China's state TV airs an 8-part documentary series revealing the behind-the-scenes of corruption cases, including a probe into former party chief Zhou Benshun, who was accused of superstition. The series, "Always on the Road," shows Zhou's involvement in superstitious practices, including having a tortoise buried with scriptures after it died at his home. Three officials, including Zhou, Bai Enpei, and Li Chuncheng, appeared on the show, admitting their guilt and cooperating with investigators, in a bid to avoid death sentences.

site_title: Oil trades near US$50 a barrel before US crude inventory data
summary: Oil prices remain near US$50 a barrel ahead of US crude inventory data, with futures adding 0.6% in New York. Crude inventories are forecast to have increased by 2.1 million barrels last week, according to a Bloomberg survey. Oil prices are expected to trade near US$50 a barrel through winter unless Opec reaches an agreement to trim supply. A meeting of an Opec committee later this month aims to resolve differences over supply reductions, with analysts predicting a consolidation in oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil traded near US$50 a barrel before data forecast to show US crude stockpiles expanded for a second week.

site_title: Dengue cases last week dropped to below 100 for the first time this year
summary: Dengue cases in Singapore dropped to 95 last week, the lowest mark for 2016, with a 29-case decrease from the previous week. This marks the first time the number of cases has fallen below 100 this year. The decline is attributed to the National Environment Agency's efforts to control mosquito populations.

site_title: VW seeks final approval of emissions deal without fix in hand
summary: Volkswagen AG is seeking final approval of its $14.7 billion settlement with US regulators, covering 482,000 vehicles with 2.0-litre diesel engines that use "defeat devices" to cheat emissions tests. Without an approved fix, VW may be forced to buy back the cars or compensate owners. A San Francisco federal judge is set to consider final approval on Tuesday, following a court conference on November 3 to discuss a solution for 85,000 vehicles with 3.0-litre engines. VW has agreed to spend up to $10 billion to buy back 2.0-litre models and invest in clean technology.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG is asking for a final sign-off on its US$14.7 billion settlement with drivers as it continues to seek regulators' approval of a fix for 482,000 pollution-spewing vehicles still on US roads.

site_title: S'pore stocks gain slightly as STI edges up 0.07% to 2,818.98
summary: Singapore shares rose slightly in early trading, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.07% to 2,818.98. Gainers outnumbered losers 75 to 68, driven by shares like OCBC Bank, which rose 0.48%. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Honda to build new factory in China for compact cars
summary: Honda Motor Co plans to build a new factory in Wuhan, China, starting in spring 2019, with an initial production capacity of 120,000 cars per year. The factory, operated in a joint venture with Dongfeng Motor Group Co, will increase Honda's Chinese output by about a fifth. The project will cost "hundreds of millions of dollars" and is influenced by China's tax break on passenger cars with engines up to 1.6 litres, which effectively reduces the price by $1,000.

site_title: Southwest, JetBlue experiencing tech issues preventing new bookings
summary: Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways are experiencing technical issues due to an outage of a pricing engine provided by Sabre Corp, preventing new bookings. The issues affect JetBlue's website, mobile app, and phone bookings, while Southwest's international bookings remain unaffected. Both airlines apologized for the inconvenience and stated they are working to resolve the issue.

images.alt_text: Southwest Airlines Co and JetBlue Airways Corp said they were experiencing technical issues preventing new bookings due to an outage of a pricing engine provided by Sabre Corp.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following two days of gains, due to an uptick in the yen dampening investor sentiment. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.11% to 16,880.77, while the Topix index fell 0.09% to 1,351.39.

site_title: Chinese state firms launch 12.2b yuan fund to invest in impoverished regions
summary: Chinese state firms have launched a 12.2 billion yuan (S$2.5 billion) fund to invest in impoverished regions as part of China's poverty reduction strategy. The 51 enterprises aim to increase the fund to 100 billion yuan, targeting 70 million people living below China's official poverty line of 2,300 yuan per year. China aims to reduce the poverty line by 10 million annually starting from 2016, with the new fund part of a broader effort to use market forces to combat poverty.

site_title: Melania Trump calls taped comments by Donald Trump 'boy talk'
summary: Melania Trump defended her husband, Donald Trump, by calling lewd comments made on a 2005 video "boy talk." The comments, in which Trump bragged about groping women, were made during a conversation with Billy Bush on Access Hollywood. Melania described the conversation as "egged on" by the host, leading her husband to say "dirty and bad stuff." The comments have shaken Trump's campaign, with him trailing Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton in opinion polls ahead of the November 8 election. Melania's comments marked her first television interviews since the tape's release.

site_title: Australian tycoon 'deeply concerned' for Crown staff detained in China
summary: Australian gaming tycoon James Packer expressed concern over 18 Crown Resorts staff detained in China, who were seized for suspected gambling offenses. The staff, including an executive in charge of luring high-rollers, are being held in Shanghai. Packer's board held an emergency meeting to determine the company's next steps. The Australian government has been notified of the detention and consular officials are making arrangements to visit the staff. Crown's shares plummeted 13% on Monday but rebounded 2% on Tuesday.

site_title: Modi said to plan 210b rupee boost for India's solar factories
summary: India's government plans a 210 billion-rupee (S$4.313 billion) package to boost the country's solar panel manufacturing industry, aiming to lift its installed photovoltaic capacity to 175 gigawatts by 2022. The Prayas initiative, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, aims to create an export industry and emulate China's success in solar manufacturing. The plan is part of India's broader goal to reduce its reliance on imported solar panels and meet its own renewable energy targets, estimated to cost US$200 billion.

site_title: Wind could supply fifth of world electricity by 2030: GWEC
summary: Wind power could supply up to 20% of the world's electricity by 2030, according to the Global Wind Energy Council (GWEC). The industry group predicts a 2,110 GW capacity by 2030, with China's share expected to quadruple to 666.5 GW. Annual investment of 200 billion euros is needed, reducing carbon dioxide emissions by over 3.3 billion tonnes per year. China's growth is driven by cost reductions and a commitment to curb climate change, but transmission capacity remains a challenge, particularly in the northwestern provinces.

images.alt_text: Wind power could supply as much as 20 per cent of the world's total electricity by 2030 due to dramatic cost reductions and pledges to curb climate change, the Global Wind Energy Council (GWEC) said in a report released in Beijing on Tuesday.

site_title: Target, McDonald's react to US creepy clown sightings in lead up to Halloween
summary: Two major US brands, Target and McDonald's, have taken steps to address the recent creepy clown sightings ahead of Halloween. Target removed clown masks and costumes from its US stores and online, while McDonald's reduced Ronald McDonald's public appearances due to the "current climate around clown sightings." The phenomenon began in late August, with reports of menacing individuals dressed as clowns or wearing clown masks in several states, prompting police and parents to take notice. The moves aim to tamp down hysteria and provide a more traditional image of happy clowns.

site_title: Netflix subscriptions boom around world, shares jump 20%
summary: Netflix Inc. exceeded expectations with a 50% surge in subscribers in the third quarter, driven by its original shows like "Stranger Things". The company reported a 20% jump in shares, reaching US$119.82, as it plans to start generating "material global profits" next year despite increased spending on original programming.

site_title: Disney said to have dropped Twitter pursuit partly over image
summary: Disney dropped its pursuit of Twitter partly due to concerns over the platform's image, specifically bullying and harassment, which may damage the company's wholesome family image. Despite hiring investment banks and listening to a presentation from Twitter executives, Disney ultimately decided not to pursue a bid. Other companies, including Salesforce and Alphabet's Google, also declined to make a move. Twitter's struggles with abuse and harassment on the site may be a larger issue for its business prospects than its executives initially thought.

site_title: Trump foundation stops fundraising in New York state
summary: The Donald J Trump Foundation has stopped fundraising in New York state, following a warning from the state attorney general's office that failure to do so would constitute a "continuing fraud." The move comes after the office warned the group last month that it was in violation of a state law requiring charitable organisations to register. The Trump campaign says the foundation is cooperating with the investigation, while the New York Attorney General's office has extended the deadline for the foundation to file financial paperwork.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's charitable foundation has stopped fundraising in New York state, the state attorney general's office said on Monday, weeks after the office warned that a failure to do so would constitute a "continuing fraud".

site_title: Singapore's Changi seeking new partner for Rio airport
summary: Singapore Changi Airport is seeking a new partner for its investment in Rio de Janeiro's Galeão international airport after its existing partner, Odebrecht SA, may leave the project. Changi has a stake in other airports and has relationships with top investors, aiming to bring one in as a new partner. Finance Minister Henrique Meirelles expressed confidence that state development bank BNDES would disburse a long-term loan to help finance the company, despite BNDES' previous credit decline due to Odebrecht's corruption charges.

site_title: Rio police fire tear-gas during Brazil budget plan protest
summary: Police in Rio de Janeiro fired tear gas at protesters demonstrating against a proposed government spending cap in Brazil, marking the first violent incident in a wave of street protests against President Michel Temer's economic policy. The cap, aimed at closing a 10% budget deficit, would restrict budget increases to the inflation rate for 20 years and cut social spending. About 5,000 protesters were involved, and small standoffs between police and protesters continued in adjacent streets. The protests come as Temer's government faces opposition from union movements over Petrobras' plans to sell assets and cut debt.

site_title: Rich countries 'confident' of meeting climate finance pledge
summary: Rich countries, including 38 developed nations and the European Commission, are confident they can meet their pledge of $100 billion in climate finance for poor countries per year by 2020, according to a report released in Marrakesh. The pledge, made in 2015, aims to support efforts to curb global warming to under two degrees Celsius. The report, which estimates the finance will come from governments and multinational development banks, not private contributions, has been welcomed by observers, but they note that more detail is needed on how the remaining difference will be made up.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Qian Hu Corporation's third quarter net profit plummeted 94.6% to S$5,000 due to a decline in its fish and accessories business segments. Meanwhile, ST Electronics secured S$480 million worth of contracts, and Sabana Reit posted a 32.2% dip in distribution per unit to 1.2 Singapore cents. The Singapore stock market rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat ahead of key earnings, ECB
summary: US stocks retreated 0.3% ahead of key earnings reports and the European Central Bank's policy decision. Analysts described investor sentiment as cautious, citing economic and political headwinds. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell to 18,086.40, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined. Despite some gains from Bank of America and Hasbro, Caterpillar and Mattel lost ground due to CEO changes and earnings reports. The ECB's Mario Draghi is under pressure to clarify stimulus plans, with investors awaiting his news conference on Thursday.

site_title: Caltex Australia confirms offer for Woolworths' fuel business
summary: Caltex Australia Ltd has made a proposal to buy Woolworths Ltd's petrol station chain, valued at over A$1.5 billion. The move comes as Woolworths seeks to sell non-core assets to shore up its core grocery business. Caltex is already Woolworths' fuel supplier, and a separate report suggests BP may also be interested in acquiring the 500 petrol stations. The proposal is expected to be a significant deal for Caltex, which would expand its presence in the Australian fuel market.

site_title: Ezra seeks consent to amend terms of S$150m of 4.875% notes due 2018
summary: Ezra Holdings is seeking bondholders' consent to amend the terms of S$150 million in 4.875% notes due 2018 to avoid potential covenant breaches or default. The company is offering a consent fee of 0.1% for early acceptances by November 2, 2016, and 0.05% for late acceptances. An extraordinary general meeting for bondholders will take place on November 9 to discuss the proposal. Ezra aims to address its financial obligations and strengthen its financial position.

images.alt_text: EZRA Holdings is seeking bondholders' consent to amend the terms of S$150 million in principal amount of 4.875 per cent notes due 2018 to avoid any potential covenant breaches or default.

site_title: RBA sees 'reasonable' growth prospects as mining headwinds wane
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has reassessed its economic growth prospects, stating they are "reasonable" despite headwinds from the mining industry. The central bank's policy meeting on October 4 left the benchmark cash rate unchanged at 1.5%, citing moderate growth as the main factor. While employee earnings growth has stabilized, uncertainty remains about jobs and housing. The RBA believes growth will continue at a moderate pace, but warns of ongoing uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Australia's prospects for maintaining economic growth that will stimulate job creation and eventually higher wages and inflation are "reasonable," the central bank said.

site_title: Canada 'very concerned' about Russian hacking: Foreign Minister Dion
summary: Canadian Foreign Minister Stephane Dion expressed concern about possible Russian hacking, following US accusations against the Kremlin. Dion called for a "safe and free cyberspace" without providing evidence of a specific threat. Canadian Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale stated the government is reviewing its cyber capabilities to protect critical systems, citing past breaches in Canada. Canada's strained ties with Russia have led to criticism over Syria and Crimea, but the government is seeking to re-engage, including cooperation in the Arctic. A Canada-Russia meeting on the Arctic is scheduled for November.

images.alt_text: Canadian Foreign Minister Stephane Dion said Monday he is very concerned about possible Russian hacking, following US accusations against the Kremlin.

site_title: Fed's Fischer says government needs to boost US economy
summary: Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Stanley Fischer stated that the US economy needs a boost to support interest rate hikes. He argued that the government's efforts to stimulate economic growth are hindered by slow growth, low productivity, and demographic changes. Fischer noted that monetary policy alone cannot drive economic growth and that a combination of factors, including private investment, public infrastructure, education, and regulation, are needed to promote faster growth and higher productivity. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates in December, but Fischer warned that low rates could signal dim US long-run growth prospects.

site_title: Oil falls to one-week low as Opec supply climbs, rig count grows
summary: Oil prices fell to a one-week low as Opec members increased supply and US producers boosted drilling. Libyan output rose to 560,000 barrels per day, while Iran aims to reach 4 million barrels per day. US rig count also increased for the seventh week. These developments threaten to compound a global oil surplus.

site_title: Philippine leader Duterte's new problem is an Arabian nightmare
summary: Philippine leader Duterte's country is experiencing an influx of returning foreign workers, including Arman Abelarde, who left Saudi Arabia after his company fired staff due to the oil slump. This trend is part of an exodus of laborers from the Arab Gulf, a major source of labor for half a century. With the oil slump drying up government contracts, many workers are struggling to find new employment, leading to financial difficulties for their families.

site_title: Sing Holdings acquires hotel in Melbourne
summary: Sing Holdings acquires the 14-storey Travelodge Docklands hotel in Melbourne, Australia for A$107m. The acquisition marks the group's first foray into the Australian property market and is expected to provide a stable stream of recurring income. The existing hotel lease agreement will continue to be in effect, and the hotel will operate under the Travelodge brand. The deal is conditional upon obtaining a statement from the Australian Treasurer by January 31, 2017.

site_title: Goldman Sachs Asia chairman to step down
summary: Goldman Sachs Asia chairman Mark Schwartz, a 27-year veteran, will retire at the end of 2016, following a slowdown in initial public offerings and merger advisory in Asia. The move comes as the firm cuts 30% of its staff in the region, except for Japan, amid a probe over its dealings in Malaysia's 1MDB scandal. Schwartz played a key role in building Goldman's business in Asia and will serve as a senior director at Goldman following his departure.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs is losing an architect of its Asia-Pacific division at the same time it confronts slowing activity in the region and a probe over its dealings in Malaysia.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as weak earnings hit Pearson and Marine Harvest
summary: European shares fell 0.7% on Monday as weak business updates from Pearson and Marine Harvest weighed on the market. Pearson's 8.4% drop was the worst on the FTSE 100, while Marine Harvest's 4.1% decline cut its 2016 output guidance. Italian bank stocks outperformed, with the FTSE All Italia Banks index rising 1.3%, despite concerns over bad debts. US bond yields rose, and investors remain cautious about the UK's post-Brexit economy.

site_title: High Court approves Temasek's scheme to buy out SMRT
summary: Singapore's High Court has approved Temasek Holdings' scheme to buy out transport operator SMRT Corporation, paving the way for the delisting of SMRT's shares after 16 years. The last day of trading is Oct 18, and the scheme goes into effect on Oct 25, with a payout of S$1.68 per share expected by Nov 1. SMRT shareholders voted 84.83% in favor of the deal, which valued the offer at S$1.2 billion. The government will also buy SMRT's rail operating assets for S$991 million.

site_title: Swee Hong's price jump prompts SGX query
summary: Swee Hong's shares surged 57% to S$0.022 on Oct 17, 2016, making it the most actively traded stock that day. The sudden price jump prompted a query from Singapore Exchange, with Swee Hong stating it was unaware of any new information. The company has been undergoing debt restructuring and has recorded three consecutive years of pre-tax losses, exceeding its current assets by S$56.6 million.

site_title: Clinton widens lead in latest poll as Trump cries foul
summary: Hillary Clinton has widened her lead over Donald Trump nationally and in key swing states, with a 12-point advantage among likely voters and 11 points among registered voters, according to a poll by Monmouth University. Trump's campaign has focused on claims of "large scale voter fraud," despite denials from his own party. The Republican nominee's lead has been eroded by allegations of lewd comments about women and accusations of sexual assault, with six in 10 voters believing he made unwanted advances. Trump's team has deployed his wife Melania to tamp down the furore, while his running mate Mike Pence has sought to ease tensions by promising acceptance of defeat.

site_title: IBM in AI for the long haul, betting big on its Watson version
summary: IBM is investing heavily in its artificial intelligence technology, Watson, aiming to build a multibillion-dollar business. The company has spent billions of dollars on Watson, employing an estimated 10,000 workers, and has shown success in assisting with daunting tasks like cancer diagnosis. IBM is now expanding Watson's capabilities, including a new genomics service that can analyze gene sequences and provide diagnostic analysis to oncologists. The company expects Watson to generate $500 million in revenue this year and potentially reach $6 billion by 2020.

site_title: US dollar weakens on profit-taking, inflation view
summary: The US dollar retreated from its seven-month highs on Monday as investors took profits from the recent rally, amid concerns about the Federal Reserve's inflation and interest rate policies. Fed Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a "high-pressure economy" to reverse the 2008-2009 crisis, while Fed Vice-Chair Stanley Fischer acknowledged the challenge of controlling interest rates. The dollar index fell 0.16% to 97.862, while the euro gained 0.28% to US$1.10, as investors awaited the European Central Bank's policy decision on Thursday.

site_title: Panasonic, Tesla team up to make solar components for SolarCity
summary: Tesla and Panasonic have partnered to produce solar-energy components for SolarCity, with production set to begin in 2017 at SolarCity's factory in Buffalo, New York. The deal bolsters Elon Musk's plan to merge Tesla and SolarCity, providing consumers with one-stop shopping for electric cars and solar-powered electricity. The partnership is contingent on approval of Tesla's acquisition of SolarCity by shareholders in a vote on November 17. The agreement deepens the existing relationship between Tesla and Panasonic, which are jointly building a $5 billion lithium-ion gigafactory in Nevada.

site_title: S'pore gaming startup Razer buys George Lucas-founded THX
summary: Singaporean gaming startup Razer has acquired THX, a 33-year-old theatre sound company founded by George Lucas, for undisclosed financial terms. The deal aims to make Razer an all-round entertainment company, expanding its product development into music and movies. THX will operate as an independent entity under its own management, with Razer retaining its top talent and intellectual property. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to push Razer into new territory, including live streaming, virtual reality, and gaming, with plans to invest in THX and access capital and resources.

site_title: Opec's U-turn misses point that demand could start falling
summary: OPEC's decision to cut oil production to boost prices may be at odds with the industry's long-term trend of declining demand. A report from the World Energy Council predicts that petroleum consumption will peak in 2030 and decline thereafter due to rapid improvements in renewable energy, electric vehicles, and other disruptive technologies. This could lead to a permanent shift from growth to decline in oil demand, with estimates suggesting a peak of 103 million barrels per day by 2030. If OPEC fails to adapt, it risks "stranding" resources and destroying shareholder value.

site_title: Keppel divests stakes in Chengdu township project
summary: Keppel Land is selling its stakes in Chengdu Century Development Co (CCDC) to Sichuan Zhong Tie Wen Rui Property Co for 342.08 million yuan (S$69.81 million). The divestment, expected to be completed by end 2016, will not impact Keppel Corp's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year. The sale includes 9,664 apartments and supporting amenities developed by Keppel Land's joint venture partner, CCDC, which has sold all residential units.

site_title: Why delay in global debt repayment is worrisome
summary: Global debt has reached a record $152 trillion, surpassing pre-2008 financial crisis levels. Despite initial expectations of "deleveraging" where debt repayment would slow the economy, little to no debt repayment has occurred globally, with many countries becoming more indebted. The IMF warns of a "vicious feedback loop" where high debts discourage borrowing, leading to a slowing economy and stymied deleveraging. Economists differ on the severity of the issue, with some citing low interest rates as a cushion against a future crisis, while others warn of a potential financial crisis.

site_title: Galaxy Note 7 ban extends to Japanese, Aussie carriers
summary: Japan and Australian carriers have banned Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones from airplanes due to fire risk concerns. The ban follows US regulators' move to bar the devices from flights, with penalties for passengers found with the recalled handsets. Japanese carriers, including All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines, will confiscate or ban the devices, while Australian airlines have also barred the devices from all planes. The recall was issued after reports of exploding batteries and fires, leading to numerous injuries and the device's production halt.

site_title: PAG Asia Capital to invest undisclosed amount in Paradise Group
summary: PAG Asia Capital has invested an undisclosed amount in Paradise Group Holdings, bolstering the restaurant operator's expansion efforts across Asia. Founder Eldwin Chua and COO Edlan Chua will retain their positions and remain significant shareholders. The investment is expected to fuel Paradise's aggressive expansion in China, where its restaurant business is proving successful. PAG's financial muscle will also aid Paradise's overseas operations, complementing its growth plans.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit adds data centre to portfolio
summary: Keppel DC Reit has entered into a conditional share purchase agreement to acquire a 90% stake in Keppel DC Singapore 3 for about S$202.5 million. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to the Reit's distribution per unit and will increase its portfolio assets under management to S$1.35 billion. The Reit's distributable income for the third quarter rose 13.7% to S$16.78 million, with DPU increasing 13.8% to 1.9 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singtel's offering turns local dwellings into smart homes
summary: Singtel has launched its SmartHome service, allowing homeowners to remotely control lights and appliances for S$25 a month. The service uses the TightEye app and is compatible with Samsung smart locks, cameras, and other devices. A centralized Smart Hub links the devices together, and additional smart plugs, sensors, and a remote control extender are available for purchase. Singtel is testing other smart home gadgets and platforms but is currently limited by compatibility issues.

site_title: Gold seen rebounding next year amid low real interest rates
summary: Gold prices are expected to rebound to as high as $1,350 an ounce in 2017, according to Toronto-Dominion Bank's head of commodity research, Bart Melek. The rally is driven by low real interest rates and a potential stronger US dollar following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike in December. Experts predict a significant increase in gold demand, with portfolio managers and analysts urging investors to diversify their portfolios and increase their gold holdings.

site_title: Swiss firm to move with the times with microwave fondue
summary: Swiss dairy company Emmi AG plans to introduce microwaveable fondue in its home market, aiming to boost sales. The $15 All-in-One Fondü kit, available in the US since last year, will be introduced in Switzerland next year. The fondue is microwaved inside the package, keeping the brandy-infused cheese gooey. The move is seen as a response to stagnating sales in the traditional fondue market, with some critics labeling it a sacrilege. Emmi AG aims to adapt to changing consumer preferences and trends.

images.alt_text: Mr Riedener says that Emmi is moving away from the traditional Swiss mountain chalet image because it is a bit old-fashioned.

site_title: Duterte shifts foreign policy focus to China with 4-day visit
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to embark on a 4-day visit to China, where he aims to announce billion-dollar deals and cement his country's foreign policy shift away from the US. Duterte has expressed willingness to hold military exercises with China and Russia, but not with the US. He has also sought Chinese financial help, despite US criticism of his war on crime, which has claimed over 3,700 lives. Deals worth billions of dollars are expected to be announced during the trip, marking a significant pivot in the Philippines' foreign relations.

site_title: NODX back in the red in September after a flat August
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 4.8% year-on-year in September, beating market expectations of a 5.8% drop. The decline was the sixth in the past nine months, but the month-on-month growth of 2.4% was better than forecast. Pharmaceuticals exports showed a 16.2% surge, while ships and boats declined 99.9%. Despite this, economists expect the NODX to decline 2.5% for the full year, with some suggesting an upward revision to the Q3 GDP figure due to stronger manufacturing activity.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) slipped back into negative territory in September, posting a year-on-year 4.8 per cent decline after a flat growth in August, the latest trade figures from International Enterprise (IE) Singapore on Monday showed.

site_title: British consumers most upbeat in 5 years in September: survey
summary: British consumers reported their highest confidence in five years in September, according to a Deloitte survey, with a three percentage point increase from the previous quarter. However, London consumer sentiment fell by three percentage points, reflecting concerns about the region's reliance on financial services and migration. The survey also warned that spending power could be challenged in 2017 due to rising inflation and EU exit negotiations.

site_title: Israeli designer's fantasy footwear finds famous fans
summary: Israeli designer Kobi Levi's psychedelic shoes have gained popularity among celebrities like Lady Gaga, with their unique designs resembling everyday objects. Levi, 41, aims to bring glamour to the everyday through his extravagant and fun designs. His shoes are part of a world of "everyday glamour" that he showcases in his work, setting him apart from other designers.

images.alt_text: Levi at his workshop with some of his creations in Tel Aviv. They occupy, he says, the crossroads between "design, art and fashion."

site_title: Bank of America profit rises 7.3%
summary: Bank of America's third-quarter profit rose 7.3% to $4.96 billion, beating analyst estimates, driven by a 39% increase in fixed-income trading revenue and lower expenses. The bank's adjusted earnings per share exceeded expectations, and all four major business lines reported earnings increases. CEO Brian Moynihan attributed the results to the bank's strategy of responsible growth and focus on customer relationships.

site_title: Micro-blogger Weibo's shares almost triple while Twitter slumps
summary: Weibo Corp's shares have nearly tripled this year, reaching a market value of nearly $11 billion, while Twitter Inc's shares have slumped over 20% due to growing competition from emerging markets. Weibo's dominance in the Chinese market and its ability to adapt to government censorship have contributed to its success. The company's ad revenue has increased 45% and its monthly active user growth has outpaced Twitter's, with 282 million daily active users in June. Weibo's US-traded shares have reached their highest since its 2014 IPO, while Twitter's shares have fallen below its 2013 IPO price.

site_title: Trudeau family embraces 'celebrity politics'
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has leveraged his family to bolster his image as a down-to-earth leader, embracing "celebrity politics." His wife Sophie and their three children, Xavier, Ella-Grace, and Hadrien, often accompany him on trips and events, showcasing a traditional family dynamic. This approach has helped Trudeau connect with younger generations and maintain a high approval rating, with experts noting his "Hollywood factor" and ability to relate to anyone. The family's public appearances, including social media posts, have further cemented Trudeau's reputation as a modern leader.

site_title: Sept factory output rises marginally, utilities dip
