summary: US industrial production rose 0.1% in September, driven by a 0.2% increase in manufacturing output, which was boosted by the production of textiles and plastics. However, utilities production declined 1.0% due to lower energy output. The report suggests a moderate acceleration in economic growth in the third quarter, with industrial production rising at an annual rate of 1.8% for the quarter. The dollar rose against currencies, while oil prices stabilized. The industrial sector is expected to continue recovering from the lingering effects of the dollar surge and oil price plunge.

site_title: 'The End' for Trump, a media creation?
summary: Donald Trump's presidential campaign is experiencing a slow and painful decline, abandoned by key GOP politicians and facing widespread media criticism over his comments on women. Despite a strong showing in the second debate, Trump's approval ratings have plummeted, and his strategy of relying on white blue-collar voters has failed to materialize. The media, which initially fueled his rise to fame, is now portraying him as a divisive figure, and his attempts to control his media image are backfiring. With just weeks left in the campaign, Trump's chances of winning the presidency appear increasingly slim.

site_title: Buyers snap up UK commercial property
summary: UK commercial property auctions are attracting buyers, despite the country's Brexit uncertainty. Allsop, the country's largest auctioneer, reported its biggest sale volume in a decade, with £115 million raised from 231 properties. Overseas buyers, including those from China and South Africa, are also participating, drawn by the pound's slump. Local investors are undeterred, with average rental yields at the auction falling sharply compared to July. Auctioneers believe the market is shifting towards private investors buying commercial real estate, with many bidders coming from established portfolios worth millions.

site_title: SPH to trim staff by up to 10% over two years
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) plans to reduce its workforce by up to 10% over two years and merge its English-language newspapers, The New Paper and My Paper, into a free daily tabloid starting December. The company aims to adapt to tough business conditions and improve operational efficiency. The merger will increase circulation to up to 300,000 copies and remain free from Mondays to Saturdays. SPH will work with unions to support affected staff and make cost-control measures to stay ahead in the media industry.

site_title: Effort needed to give Syrians respite from carnage
summary: US and Russia, along with Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and Iran, have begun talks towards a truce in Syria. However, tensions remain high, with Russia suspending nuclear cooperation with the US in retaliation for US sanctions. The conflict has left 250,000 civilians under siege in Aleppo, with air strikes devastating the city. A negotiated settlement is seen as the only way to provide respite for the innocent civilians. The international community must work together to address the ongoing carnage in Syria, despite the challenges posed by regional players.

site_title: S'pore aims to set Asia gold benchmark price
summary: Singapore is considering setting a gold benchmark price for the Asian time zone to reduce traders' exposure to intraday price swings and overnight foreign exchange risks. The move aims to establish the city-state as a regional bullion hub, following a significant growth in gold trading since 2012. The proposed benchmark, set at 2pm Singapore Time, would provide a daily price in addition to the existing 1030 and 1500 London time prices, facilitating timely tracking of Asian demand and improving transparency for the industry.

site_title: Libyan fund loses legal battle with Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs wins a 2 1/2-year legal battle against Libya's sovereign wealth fund, with the London High Court ruling in favour of the Wall Street icon. Judge Vivien Rose dismissed the fund's arguments after a seven-week trial, despite embarrassing revelations about Goldman Sachs' bankers' business conduct. The verdict is a triumph for Goldman Sachs, vindicating its position despite past controversies.

images.alt_text: The dispute is centred on the US$1.2 billion the LIA paid to Goldman to invest in nine equity derivatives trades, all of which ultimately turned out to be worthless.

site_title: Apple's OLED switch will make or break suppliers
summary: Apple plans to adopt OLED displays in its next major iPhone upgrade, putting pressure on Japanese suppliers to build up manufacturing operations. Suppliers like Sharp Corp and Japan Display Inc (JDI) are under pressure to invest in OLED production capabilities, with initial costs estimated at $2 billion each. JDI, which already depends on Apple for 54% of its revenue, is planning to invest 150 billion yen to set up its OLED manufacturing line. The move could make or break suppliers, with Takeo Miyamoto, an analyst, stating that failure to invest in OLED could lead to suppliers being forced out of the smartphone business altogether.

site_title: Region's casinos cannot ignore Chinese punters - but it's a risky bet
summary: Crown Resorts, Australia's largest casino company, has had 18 employees detained by Chinese authorities, including a manager, amid a crackdown on promoting gambling. The detention is a risk for Crown, which has been distancing itself from direct involvement with China. China's broad-brush legislation allows for ill-defined offenses, and the detention may be related to promoting casinos in China. This incident highlights China's significant influence on the global gaming industry, with Macau's operators experiencing a downturn. The situation is unclear, but it may signal a broader shift in Beijing's attitudes to gambling.

images.alt_text: Casinos across the Asia-Pacific are partly a bet on China: This was the message from Crown Resorts, Australia's biggest gambling company, whose shares crashed on Monday after the Chinese authorities detained some employees.

site_title: Williams pulls out of WTA Finals again
summary: Serena Williams will miss the WTA Finals in Singapore for the second year due to injury and health concerns. The WTA announced the 35-year-old American won't participate in the BNP Paribas WTA Finals Singapore presented by SC Global, which starts on Sunday. Meanwhile, Madison Keys and Karolína Plíšková secured their spots in the tournament. The WTA Finals will be won by the top-ranked player at the end of the season, with Angelique Kerber expected to end the year as the World No. 1 player.

site_title: 14 dead, scores missing in Myanmar ferry disaster, says official
summary: Rescuers in Myanmar have discovered 14 bodies and expect to find more after a ferry capsized on Saturday, killing at least 14 people. A total of 154 people have been rescued, including teachers, students, and workers. The ferry sank 72 kilometers north of Monywa, central Myanmar.

site_title: Is your business ready to deal with ransomware?
summary: Ransomware, a type of malware that encrypts data and demands payment to release it, is emerging as a major threat to individuals and businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Despite its growing threat, many businesses are not prepared to tackle ransomware attacks, with only 25% of companies confident in their ability to defend against cyberattacks. To protect against ransomware, a three-pronged approach is necessary: education, security software, and backup. Implementing education, using up-to-date antivirus software, and maintaining a robust backup system are essential to minimize the risk of ransomware attacks.

site_title: Ascott wins 3 new Middle East serviced residence deals
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has secured contracts to manage three new properties in Saudi Arabia, including its first in Mecca, and plans to open 11 new properties across the Middle East by 2020. The deals will increase its portfolio to over 2,700 units in 19 properties across 10 cities. Ascott aims to double its Middle East portfolio to 5,000 units by 2020, driven by growing demand from religious tourism, which is valued at US$5.68 billion in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Euro steadies ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The euro steadied ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting, where officials are expected to consider reining in emergency aid to the euro zone economy next year. The dollar has risen 2.5% since October, but its bond yield shift may be slowing down. The ECB is likely to extend its quantitative easing program beyond March, but may begin to question the need for ultra-low interest rates and money-printing, potentially making the euro positive on non-dollar crosses.

site_title: Maypak, Alcom minorities urged to reject general offers
summary: Minority shareholders of Malaysia Packaging Industry (Maypak) and Aluminium Company of Malaysia (Alcom) have been urged to reject general offers due to overly steep discounts of 60-70% to their revalued net asset values (RNAVs). Mercury Securities deemed the offers as not fair and unreasonable, citing potential for Towerpack to improve operational efficiency and maintain Alcom's listing status. The offers were triggered by controlling shareholders acquiring stakes over 30% in the companies.

site_title: Investors on edge as US banks declare Card Wars
summary: US banks are engaging in a "Card Wars" competition, with major banks like JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, and Bank of America offering lucrative credit card rewards to attract customers. Analysts predict that this battle may erode profit margins, as customers like Morrie Low, who collect cards for travel awards, may not become profitable customers due to the high upfront rewards. This competition is driven by the desire to tap into the growing demand from millennials, who are increasingly using credit cards for travel and other benefits.

site_title: Lendlease upbeat about plans for Paya Lebar Quarter
summary: Lendlease, an Australia-listed property developer, is optimistic about its S$3.2 billion Paya Lebar Quarter urban regeneration project in Singapore. The mixed-use development, spanning 3.9ha, will feature seven buildings, including office towers, residential blocks, and retail space. Despite a softening retail sector and gloomy Singapore economy outlook, Lendlease remains upbeat about demand for the project, which will be developed on a 99-year leasehold site.

site_title: GM pushes ahead with expansion in Mexico
summary: General Motors (GM) is moving forward with a $800 million investment in its global small-car lineup, including a factory retooling in San Luis Potosi, Mexico. The company has been quiet about the investment, unlike its rival Ford, which has faced criticism from Donald Trump for moving jobs to Mexico. GM's cautious approach may be due to the potential backlash from Trump and the risk of disrupting labour talks in Canada. The investment will also build the all-new Chevy Equinox sport-utility vehicle next year.

site_title: US, Canada banks slash share of UK property loans before Brexit
summary: North American banks significantly reduced their share of UK commercial property loans before the 2016 EU referendum, cutting from 14% to 7% in the first six months. This was attributed to uncertainty about the vote and a cooling market, which led to a 13% decrease in new loan originations. The value of defaulted loans fell by more than half to £4.5 billion, mostly from loans advanced before 2009. UK banks and member-owned lenders increased their market share to 44% of all new loans, while capital-market volatility and concerns over Chinese growth also contributed to the market slowdown.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cityneon Holdings acquired Victory Hill Exhibitions, a production and distribution company, positioning itself to grow in the immersive attractions market, particularly with blockbuster movies like Avengers and Transformers. The acquisition, combined with its existing partnerships, is expected to attract a generation of superhero fans.

site_title: The case for investing in an S-Reit ETF
summary: Singapore is expected to launch an S-Reit ETF, which will track the performance of the SGX S-Reit 20 Index, providing a retirement solution for retail investors. The ETF's benefits include low management fees, accessibility, and potential to attract liquidity to the S-Reit market. Despite some competition from other Reit funds and ETFs, industry experts believe the proposed ETF will have a compelling proposition, particularly with its focus on dividend-weighted Reits across Asia. The launch of the ETF is seen as a positive development for the S-Reit market, which is expected to grow despite moderating distribution growth trends.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's DPU unchanged for Q3
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents for the third quarter, unchanged from a year ago. The trust generated net cash of S$69 million, with higher cash flows from the Keppel Merlimau Cogen (KMC) acquisition and a progressive boiler upgrade at the Senoko Waste-to-Energy plant. Net profit for the quarter was S$17 million, almost double from the previous year, driven by insurance compensation from a cable fault in Australia. Revenue was flat at S$160 million.

site_title: Big central bank assets jump fastest in 5 years to US$21t
summary: The world's 10 largest central banks have increased their assets to $21.4 trillion, a 10% jump from last year, the fastest pace since 2011's European debt crisis. This growth has coincided with rising stock and bond prices, with the MSCI All Country World Index gaining 19% and the Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Index advancing 50%. The largest central banks, particularly the Bank of Japan and the European Central Bank, have expanded their assets by $2.1 trillion, accounting for almost all of the top 10's combined increase.

site_title: Lack of new blood casts doubt over Wells Fargo's overhaul plan
summary: Wells Fargo's overhaul plan is being questioned due to a lack of new blood on its board and in senior management. The bank's CEO, Tim Sloan, has been criticized for not bringing in outsiders to fix its aggressive sales culture, despite his long tenure at the company. Analysts say Sloan's closeness to the bank's inner circle may hinder his ability to overhaul the culture that led to a scandal involving 2 million unauthorized accounts. The bank's board has not announced any new faces, raising concerns that the culture may not be changing.

site_title: DBS raises stake in banks' cashback war
summary: DBS Bank has launched a cashback programme that rewards customers for transacting with the bank, offering up to S$130 per month. The programme attaches cashback to the base value of transactions, rather than the savings account, and includes bonuses for paying mortgage instalments and buying insurance and investments through DBS or POSB. This move aims to draw deposits from competitors and reinforce DBS's position in the home loans market. The programme is seen as a simple and competitive way for customers to earn cashback.

site_title: Companies urged to move from adding value to creating value
summary: A seminar by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and PwC emphasized the need for companies to move from adding value to creating value to survive. Keynote speakers Ho Meng Kit and Ng Siew Quan urged businesses to adopt incremental changes and create new products and services that customers value more. They stressed that innovation involves improving products, processes, or business models to address societal needs. The seminar aimed to equip small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with strategies to innovate successfully and achieve long-term success.

site_title: Efforts to lift sunken Sewol ferry could drag on into 2017: South Korean govt
summary: South Korean efforts to lift the sunken Sewol ferry, which sank in 2014, may continue into 2017 due to poor visibility and the complexity of the salvage operation. The 6,825-tonne ferry, carrying 476 people, capsized and sank off the island of Jindo, resulting in 304 deaths. Salvage operations, led by a Chinese consortium, have been hampered by bad weather and technical issues, with the timeline repeatedly delayed. Maritime Minister Kim Young Suk has warned that the lift may not be completed this year, with further delays expected.

site_title: Germany wants Tesla to stop using the term 'Autopilot' in ads
summary: Germany's Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt has asked Tesla to stop using the term 'Autopilot' in ads, citing potential misleading suggestions that drivers' attention is not needed. The Federal Motor Transport Authority (KBA) has written to Tesla, requesting the change to avoid customer misunderstandings. Tesla maintains that Autopilot requires drivers to pay attention at all times, similar to an airplane. The request comes amid concerns over driver attention and safety.

site_title: BRICS meet at tipping point in global economic inequality
summary: The BRICS nations (Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa) met in Goa for their 8th annual summit, focusing on reforming the global financial architecture and addressing global economic inequality. Despite concerns over rising inequality within countries, the BRICS have driven a historic movement towards greater global income equality, lifting 600 million people out of poverty since 1981. However, the trend's sustainability is uncertain due to decelerating emerging market growth and rising income inequality within countries. The BRICS' efforts may lead to the first period of sustained movement towards greater global income equality in two centuries, but the outcome remains uncertain and vulnerable to reversal.

site_title: Cedar Strategic Holdings eyes Myanmar luxe project
summary: Cedar Strategic Holdings is acquiring a 49% effective stake in the luxury mixed-use Golden City development project in Yangon, Myanmar. The property investment group has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire DAS for approximately US$24.9 million. The project has a floor area of 335,284 square meters and a gross development value of US$694 million. The acquisition is expected to be financed through internal resources and a loan from the company's controlling shareholder, and is expected to be completed in two phases. The deal marks Cedar Strategic Holdings' first step into the Myanmar luxury real estate market.

site_title: Stronger rupiah allows for more reserves: Bank Indonesia
summary: Bank Indonesia's executive director Doddy Zulverdi stated that a stronger rupiah allows the central bank to increase foreign reserves, which have risen 9.2% this year to $116 billion. Indonesia's current-account deficit is expected to narrow to below 2% of GDP by the end of the year, thanks to fund inflows and improved trade. The rupiah is currently in line with the bank's fundamentals, and policy-makers have cut interest rates to support the economy and offset the effect of a stronger currency.

site_title: Tesco gets PR and share price boost from row with Unilever
summary: Tesco's shares rose 5% after a pricing row with Unilever, with analysts praising the supermarket group for casting itself as the consumer's champion. Unilever is believed to have backed down from raising prices to compensate for the decline in sterling following the UK's Brexit vote. This move is seen as a public relations victory for Tesco, with analysts saying it will help to maintain low prices for shoppers.

site_title: ECB to maintain status quo when it meets on Thursday: traders
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to maintain its current policy unchanged when it meets on Thursday, despite pressure to do more, according to a majority of euro money market traders polled by Reuters. The ECB may discuss technical adjustments to its asset purchase scheme but a decision could be deferred until December. Eurozone inflation remains below the ECB's 2% target, and traders are divided on whether the ECB will extend its monthly bond-buying beyond March 2017.

site_title: Broad market weakens despite STI bounce
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,817.07, up 1.83 points, despite a weak broad market with 145 rises and 235 falls. Trading was characterized by hectic churning of low-priced issues, with LionGold and Swee Hong Holdings drawing queries from the Singapore Exchange. Blue chip shares, including Singapore Press Holdings, ended lower after the company reported a 17.5% drop in net profit. Market analysts expect the US presidential election outcome to impact global markets, with potential implications for interest rates and economic growth.

site_title: Home is where the heart is
summary: Orange Valley Nursing Homes, a leading provider in Singapore, has achieved success by prioritizing its residents, environment, and employees. Founded in 1993 with 108 beds, the company has expanded to six homes with a combined capacity of 1,013 beds. Its "Residents First" approach offers personalized care, choices, and autonomy, while its commitment to the environment is reflected in sustainable practices such as organic gardens and composting. The company also prioritizes employee development, emotional health, and well-being, resulting in high patient satisfaction and a competitive edge in the industry.

site_title: As Trump bashed China, he sought business deals with its govt
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's hotel firm, Trump Hotel Collection, pursued a lucrative business deal with State Grid Corporation of China, an electricity company headed by a top Communist official, despite his aggressive condemnation of Beijing. The deal, potentially worth $100-150 million over 15 years, was negotiated in 2015. Trump has repeatedly accused China of stealing American jobs, but his company's dealings with state-owned enterprises have raised questions about conflicts of interest and double standards.

images.alt_text: During his White House bid, Mr Trump has frequently excoriated China, claiming it has stolen millions of American jobs.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q3 DPU unchanged at 0.93 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported unchanged third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) at 0.93 Singapore cents, matching the same period last year. The company's net profit rose to S$17 million from S$8.67 million. This is the first time DPU has remained unchanged in the past two years.

site_title: US industrial output rises marginally, utilities weigh
summary: US industrial production rose 0.1% in September, driven by a rebound in manufacturing output, but was offset by a decline in utilities production. This suggests moderate acceleration in economic growth in the third quarter, with industrial production rising at an annual rate of 1.8%. The sector is recovering from the lingering effects of the dollar's surge and oil price plunge, with factory activity showing signs of improvement and new orders increasing.

site_title: Beware white elephants in infrastructure push: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for governments to prioritize profitable and necessary infrastructure projects in Asia, particularly in a low-interest-rate environment. He suggested public-private partnerships to ensure profitable returns while meeting country needs, aiming to avoid wasting resources.

images.alt_text: DPM Tharman said that with cost-overruns the norm in large projects, "we have to put on our micro-economic hats" to ensure every project has a payoff that justifies the cost.

site_title: Developers' private home sales set to jump in October
summary: Singapore private home sales are expected to surge in October, potentially reaching the highest monthly level this year, driven by several new project launches. Despite a dim economic outlook and falling property prices, buyers are keen on new homes, with analysts attributing the demand to lower mortgage rates and a stabilizing market. OrangeTee forecasts sales volume may surpass 1,100 units, exceeding previous highs this year, with analysts predicting 7,500 to 8,200 private homes will be sold in the primary market in 2016.

site_title: Businesses can change the game with a Silicon Valley mindset
summary: Businesses can regain industry leadership by embracing a Silicon Valley mindset, characterized by innovation, agility, and disruption. This requires a cultural shift to a "digital-first" company culture, breaking down organizational silos, and empowering employees to adopt new processes. Companies must also rethink their IT approach, focusing on cloud-native applications, agile development, and data-driven intelligence. By combining technology with the right strategy and employee empowerment, businesses can rapidly change and make profound changes in today's world, ultimately delivering customer demands in the right context, at the right time.

site_title: Sing Holdings to acquire Melbourne hotel for A$107m
summary: Sing Holdings is set to acquire Melbourne hotel Travelodge Docklands for A$107 million, marking its first hospitality asset and entry into the Australian property market. The company has signed a conditional property sale agreement with GL InvestmentCo Melbourne, depositing A$5.35 million. This deal is expected to further expand Sing Holdings' presence in the global hospitality industry.

site_title: Singapore into new phase in economic diplomacy
summary: Singapore is shifting its economic diplomacy strategy to focus on new exportable services, such as fintech, commodities, and high-tech products, rather than traditional trade in physical goods. This move aims to leverage the country's strengths in regulatory infrastructure and business openness to foster economic cooperation with nations beyond its immediate neighbourhood. With global trade growth slowing, Singapore seeks to diversify its economy and establish itself as a hub for innovation and technological development. The government is exploring new initiatives, such as cooperation agreements with countries like Switzerland and Norway, to drive growth and retain its position in the global economy.

site_title: German car industry warns UK that 'hard Brexit' could trigger shift south
summary: Germany's VDA auto industry association president Matthias Wissmann warns that a "hard Brexit" for the UK could lead to parts of Britain's car industry moving to southeast Europe, potentially to Slovakia or Poland, due to potential tariffs of up to 10% on car exports. This uncertainty could result in investors holding back in the UK, creating uncertainty for 5-7 years. German carmakers exported 810,000 cars to Britain last year, more than to any other country, and the industry's priority is to maintain the EU single market.

site_title: Sabana Reit Q3 DPU falls 32.2%
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 32.2% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.20 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2016. Distributable income fell 31.7% to S$8.86 million, while net property income decreased 24% to S$13.91 million. Gross revenue fell 9.7% to S$23.03 million due to negative rental revisions and lower portfolio occupancy. Multi-tenancy occupancy levels increased to 82.6% in Q3 2016.

site_title: UK Sept commercial property values fall slightly: MSCI IPD index
summary: UK commercial property values fell 0.21% in September, a slower decline than in July and August, according to the MSCI IPD index. This suggests concerns about Brexit's impact on the UK property market are easing. Commercial property deal activity has picked up, driven by a drop in sterling, and most funds have reopened. Total returns from UK commercial property rose 0.2% in September, a reversal of the 0.1% drop in August. Valuers have also dropped Brexit uncertainty clauses from property valuation reports.

site_title: UK PM happy for "differing views" on Brexit, will get best deal: spokeswoman
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May will consider "differing views" among her ministers to prepare for Brexit negotiations, her spokeswoman said. Despite reports of sharp disagreements, particularly over finance minister Philip Hammond's support for a "soft Brexit," May has full confidence in Hammond. Hammond's department denies reports of him resigning or obstructing the Brexit process. The spokeswoman emphasized the need for the government to work together to achieve a successful Brexit, with the prime minister focused on getting the best deal for the UK.

site_title: Caterpillar to get new CEO as mining slump persists
summary: Caterpillar announced that CEO Doug Oberhelman will step down on January 1, citing a prolonged slowdown in the mining sector. The company has struggled with declining results due to slower growth in China and lower oil prices, leading to job cuts and facility closures. Oberhelman will be replaced by Jim Umpleby, the company's group president. The announcement comes as the mining sector continues to face challenges, with Caterpillar's shares dipping 0.1% in mid-morning trade. The company's headcount has declined by 10% to 100,000, and it expects additional job cuts in the second half of 2016.

site_title: Singapore court approves Temasek's buyout of SMRT
summary: Singapore's High Court has approved Temasek Holdings' buyout of SMRT Corporation, a 16-year-old float. The last day of trading for SMRT shares will be October 18, and the payout of $1.68 per share is expected by November 1. SMRT shareholders voted to let Temasek take SMRT private via a scheme of arrangement on September 29.

site_title: Oil prices firm, rise in US drilling weighs
summary: Oil prices rose 23 cents to $52.18 per barrel on Monday, driven by expectations of an Opec intervention to curb production at their November 30 meeting. However, a rising US drilling rig count capped gains. Analysts say Opec's action will support prices, but a physically oversupplied market and weak global GDP estimates may limit further gains. The US dollar's strength also weighed on prices.

site_title: Banks in UK will shift some activities to Frankfurt in 2017: official
summary: Banks in the UK will begin shifting some operations to Frankfurt in 2017 to ensure full access to the European Union market. According to Hubertus Vaeth, head of Frankfurt Main Finance, banks have informed him that they will move some operations to Germany next year. The exact size of the operations being moved is still unknown, and there is no pressure to hurry the re-engineering process. This move aims to maintain the banks' access to the EU market post-Brexit.

site_title: China to help Cambodia modernise its armed forces: government
summary: China has agreed to help modernize Cambodia's military, signing new agreements to boost military aid worth around $237 million. The assistance includes soft loans, debt cancellation, and military aid. Cambodia's Defence Minister Tea Banh announced the agreements, which follow a visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping last week. The move is seen as a boost to Cambodia's national defense, with a focus on strengthening its airspace and acquiring fighter jets from China in the long term.

site_title: Liverpool's landmark Liver Building up for sale
summary: Liverpool's historic Royal Liver Building, a 1911 Hellenistic temple modelled on the Baalbek structure, is up for sale for the first time. The £40 million (S$68.13 million) building, owned by Royal London Mutual Insurance Society, has protected status and houses companies including HSBC and ITV. The sale, facilitated by CBRE, is expected to attract strong interest from UK and global investors, with the building described as a "truly iconic symbol of Liverpool" and a rare opportunity to acquire a unique part of the city's heritage.

site_title: US: Wall St dips as energy, health stocks offset BofA boost
summary: US stocks declined on Monday morning, with the S&P 500 falling 0.13% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.15%. Energy and healthcare stocks dropped, offsetting a 0.16% gain from financials led by Bank of America's strong earnings report. Investors are cautious ahead of the US presidential elections and potential interest rate hikes. The energy sector fell 0.54%, while the healthcare sector declined 0.29%, led by declines in Merck and Anthem.

site_title: VW factories to raise efficiency by up to 8%: Handelsblatt
summary: Volkswagen aims to boost factory efficiency by 5-8% annually, eliminating every third shift and eliminating expensive weekend shifts. This plan is part of the company's efforts to cut costs following the diesel emissions scandal. The supervisory board is set to approve new spending targets on November 18.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker on Monday despite late index rebound
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rebounded 1.83 points to close at 2,817.07 after late short-covering, despite a weak broad market with 145 rises and 235 falls. Trading was characterized by hectic activity in low-priced issues, particularly in the oil and gas and healthcare sectors. LionGold and Noble Group were among the top-volume counters. The index has rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: ST Electronics secures S$480m of contracts in Q3
summary: ST Electronics, the electronics arm of Singapore Technologies (ST) Engineering, secured contracts worth about S$480 million in the third quarter of 2016. The contracts were won in rail electronics & intelligent transportation, satellite & broadband communications, and advanced electronics & ICT solutions sectors. The contracts include projects for rail, satellite, and government agencies, with completion dates ranging from 2019 to 2020. The contracts are not expected to impact the company's earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Lian Beng acquires Khong Guan Industrial Building for S$31m
summary: Construction firm Lian Beng Group acquired Khong Guan Industrial Building for S$31 million. The eight-storey, 57,019 sq ft building is located in the MacPherson/Tai Seng industrial estate, 300m from Tai Seng MRT Station. The purchase price is approximately S$544 per sq ft, and the building is zoned for "Business 1" use at a plot ratio of 2.5.

site_title: Qian Hu Q3 profit plummets 94.6% to S$5,000, even as revenue rises
summary: Qian Hu Corporation reported a 94.6% decline in Q3 net profit to S$5,000, despite a 10.1% increase in revenue to S$19.6 million. The decline was attributed to a difference in sales mix for its fish business segment. Earnings per share dropped to 0.01 Singapore cent from 0.08 Singapore cent in the previous year. The company's shares closed 4.44% lower.

site_title: KepLand China selling stakes in Chengdu township project
summary: KepLand's two associated companies and joint-venture partner are selling their stakes in Chengdu Century Development Co to Sichuan Zhong Tie Wen Rui Property Co for 342.08 million yuan (S$70 million). KepLand has an effective interest of 44.05% in CCDC, formed in 2003 to develop The Botanica township project. The divestment is expected to be completed by end-2016 and is not expected to impact Keppel Corp's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit expands portfolio; Q3 distributable income up 13.7%
summary: Keppel DC Reit has entered into a conditional share purchase agreement to acquire a 90% interest in Keppel DC Singapore 3 for approximately S$202.5 million. The proposed transaction will be funded by a preferential offering of 242 million new units, valued at S$1.155 per unit. The reit also announced a 13.7% increase in distributable income for the third quarter, reaching S$16.78 million, and a 13.8% increase in actual distribution per unit to 1.9 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: PERPETUAL (Asia), a trustee of Keppel DC Reit, has entered into a conditional share purchase agreement with Keppel Data Centres Holding, a joint venture between Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation and Keppel Land

site_title: SIA's passenger load factor falls in September
summary: SINGAPORE AIRLINES' passenger load factor for September fell 2.1 percentage points year-over-year to 78.7% due to weaker passenger demand. Passenger carriage decreased 4.2% and capacity was reduced 1.7%, while the number of passengers carried declined 3.4% to nearly 1.52 million. The airline attributed the decline to weaker demand across all regions except East Asia.

site_title: Peugeot buys used car retailer in diversification push
summary: PSA Group, the parent company of Peugeot, Citroen, and DS, is acquiring a 30% stake in French online second-hand car retailer Aramisauto. The deal aims to expand PSA's presence in the second-hand market, which is twice the size of the new car market. The acquisition is part of PSA's diversification push, led by CEO Carlos Tavares, who aims to slash production costs and turn the company into a leading player in multi-brand vehicle repairs and second-hand sales. The deal is expected to help PSA double its second-hand car sales to 800,000 vehicles by 2021.

site_title: SPH to merge My Paper and TNP, to cut up to 10% staff in right-sizing exercise
summary: SPH to merge My Paper and TNP into a revamped TNP, which will be distributed for free starting December. The move aims to refresh the product portfolio and cut up to 10% of its 4,182 staff force over two years. The new TNP will have a daily average sales of over 60,000 copies and will be available in English only, with no Sunday paper. The company aims to improve operational efficiency and diversify revenue streams to maximize stakeholder value.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall at open
summary: European stock markets fell at the open on Monday, with the FTSE 100 down 0.3%, the DAX 30 down 0.3%, and the CAC 40 down 0.4%. The decline comes ahead of an ECB meeting this week and speculation over US borrowing costs.

site_title: Vietnam floods kill 25 as new typhoon approaches
summary: Severe flooding in central Vietnam has killed at least 25 people and destroyed over 240,000 homes since Friday. Heavy rain started last week, with a state-run hydropower plant's sudden water release contributing to the destruction. A typhoon, Typhoon Sarika, is expected to hit Vietnam on Wednesday, with northern provinces on high alert. Authorities may issue evacuation orders and ban ships from sea. Vietnam is hit by tropical storms or typhoons every year, causing widespread destruction along coastal regions.

site_title: China touts reforms, vows to battle corruption in organ donation system
summary: China has vowed to battle corruption in its organ donation system, with 100% of transplants now voluntary, according to Director Huang Jiefu. The country has ended systematic use of organs from executed prisoners, cracked down on a black market, and increased public donor rates. Despite challenges, China has made undeniable reforms, with global experts praising its efforts to remake its system. The government has zero tolerance for corruption and is committed to fulfilling ethical principles, with 11,000 organ transplants conducted last year. China aims to leave behind an era of controversial organ harvesting.

site_title: Thailand considers steps to help service sector as country mourns
summary: Thailand is considering measures to support its tourism and service sectors, which have been affected by the 30-day mourning period following King Bhumibol Adulyadej's death. The government aims to maintain economic growth of 3.3% this year, despite the subdued atmosphere in Bangkok's bars and resorts. Any measures introduced would be sensitive to the feelings of Thai people and aimed at boosting the overall economy.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall as talk grows of Federal Reserve rate rise
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday as investors anticipated a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike before the end of the year. The news followed healthy gains at the end of last week, with shares boosted by data showing China's factory prices rose for the first time in four years, indicating the country's economy may be reaching the end of a slowdown. Analysts believe the Fed will raise borrowing costs but at a steady pace, citing comments from Janet Yellen.

site_title: Britain looks at paying into EU budget after Brexit to get market access: FT
summary: Britain may continue to pay billions into the EU budget after Brexit to maintain single-market access, according to a plan being discussed by the government. Prime Minister Theresa May has not ruled out making future payments to the EU to secure privileged access to the single market. This move aims to shield certain sectors, such as finance and the automotive industry, from the impact of leaving the EU. Continued payments would allow Britain to maintain some preferential access to EU markets while pulling more sovereignty back on areas like migration.

site_title: Iran oil minister: hopes soon to reach Qatar's gas production
summary: Iran's oil minister, Bijan Zanganeh, expressed hope to boost the country's natural gas production to Qatar's level by early next year. Iran plans to increase crude oil production to 4 million barrels per day by 2019 and 4.28 million barrels per day by 2020. The country also aims to boost condensate output to 1 million barrels per day as early as 2018. Iran plans to tender new oil and gas contracts to international and domestic companies, focusing on enhancing oil recovery rates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for governments to focus on microeconomic aspects in infrastructure projects, ensuring they justify costs. Non-oil domestic exports declined 4.8% in September. Singapore Press Holdings plans to merge My Paper and TNP, cutting up to 10% staff. Inflation expectations remain at record lows, and Singapore will explore setting the gold benchmark price for Asian users. Ascott secured new serviced residence contracts in the Middle East, while Cedar Strategic Holdings announced a proposed stake in a US$694m project.

site_title: Malaysia inflation seen picking up to 1.7% y-o-y in September: poll
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate is expected to rise to 1.7% in September, slightly faster than the previous month's pace, according to a Reuters poll. Low fuel prices kept inflation in check despite higher food prices. This marks the first increase in the inflation rate after five months of slowing, following a seven-year peak of 4.2% in February. The central bank previously cut its inflation projection to 2-3% for the year.

site_title: Singapore makes another bid for Asia to help set gold price
summary: Singapore is set to launch a feasibility study to bring the gold benchmark pricing in London to users in Asia, allowing Asian market participants to help set the price of bullion. The study, to be conducted by the Singapore Bullion Market Association, London Bullion Market Association, and Intercontinental Exchange Benchmark Administration, aims to establish a US dollar price discovery mechanism for gold during Asian business hours. The move seeks to address price volatility and overnight foreign exchange risks faced by Asian bullion traders, who are the world's largest buyers of gold.

site_title: Gold rises as US rate outlook assessed against investor demand
summary: Gold rose 0.4% to $1,256.07 an ounce as investors weigh the US interest rate outlook against robust demand. Despite a 4.5% monthly decline, gold holdings in gold-backed ETFs increased to 2,051.3 metric tons, the highest since June 2013. The Federal Reserve is considering a rate hike, but Fed Chair Janet Yellen said the economy could recover from the Great Recession, keeping policy easy. Investors remain optimistic about gold, with Fed fund futures indicating a 66% probability of a December rate hike.

site_title: Cost cuts help Pearson to reiterate targets amid tough trading
summary: Pearson, the world's largest education company, reiterated its full-year outlook despite a 7% decline in nine-month organic sales due to weak demand for courseware in its North American higher education business. The company attributed the decline to tighter cost management, which helped counter the decline. Pearson maintained its adjusted operating profit forecast of £580-£620 million. The company's CEO, John Fallon, expressed confidence in delivering the guidance and achieving its long-term growth goal, despite challenging market conditions.

site_title: China's Avic, Citic, others inject US$850m to fund Tencent's Supercell purchase
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd has raised US$850 million by selling new shares to investors, including Chinese state-owned firms Avic Capital and Citic Capital, to fund its US$8.6 billion acquisition of mobile game maker Supercell. The consortium, which also includes China Citic Bank Corp and China Cinda Asset Management, will own 50% of the company. The deal is expected to be completed on or around October 27.

images.alt_text: Tencent Holdings Ltd said a consortium formed to buy game developer Supercell has raised US$850 million by selling new shares to investors including Chinese state-owned investment firms Avic Capital and Citic Capital.

site_title: Japan's JR Kyushu sets top price for up to 416b yen IPO filing
summary: JR Kyushu, a Japanese railway operator, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at 2,600 yen a share, raising up to 416 billion yen (S$5.6 billion). The government-owned company aims to capitalize on Japan's tourist boom, with record 2.8 million foreign tourists visiting Kyushu last year. The IPO is expected to be Japan's largest this year, with global coordinators including Nomura Securities and JP Morgan Securities. The company's diversification into non-railway businesses may also boost profit, but the timing of privatization raises concerns amid weak investor activity and falling stock prices.

site_title: Chinese official who hoarded cash convicted of corruption
summary: A former Chinese energy official, Wei Pengyuan, was convicted of corruption and given a suspended death penalty after being found guilty of hoarding over 200 million yuan in cash. Wei abused his position to approve coal projects and took 212 million yuan in bribes. The court sentenced him to life in prison, citing his vast assets and inability to explain their source. This case reflects President Xi Jinping's ongoing fight against corruption, which he warns could affect the Communist Party's grip on power.

images.alt_text: A former senior Chinese energy official found to have more than 200 million yuan (S$41.68 million) in cash at his home has been given a suspended death penalty after being found guilty of corruption, state news agency Xinhua said on Monday.

site_title: Cedar Strategic announces proposed stake in US$694m Golden City project
summary: Cedar Strategic Holdings (CSH) has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire DAS for approximately US$24.9 million, gaining a 49% stake in the US$694 million Golden City project in Yangon, Myanmar. CSH aims to expand into Myanmar's luxury real estate market. A loan of up to US$5 million will be used to supplement cash resources for the acquisition. The deal aligns with CSH's growth strategy focused on development and investment properties in emerging countries.

site_title: Australia shares end lower as casino operator Crown slumps; NZ down
summary: Australian shares closed lower on Monday, with Crown Resorts Ltd slumping 13.9% after 18 employees, including its head of VIP gambling, were detained by Chinese authorities. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.8% to 5,388.7, its lowest in almost three weeks.

site_title: Japan bans Galaxy Note 7 on airplanes over fire risk
summary: Japan has banned all Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones from airplanes due to fire risk concerns, following US regulators and several carriers. The recall, which includes replacement devices, was prompted by reports of exploding batteries and fires leading to injuries. Airlines must confiscate or prevent passengers from carrying the devices on flights, with penalties possible. The ban applies to all major carriers in Japan and several others worldwide.

site_title: Even at US$100 for coal, Asia's LNG industry struggles to compete
summary: Asia's LNG industry struggles to compete with thermal coal despite the recent surge in coal prices to nearly US$100 per tonne. LNG prices remain relatively low at US$6.50 per million British thermal units, making it less competitive than coal in power generation. The industry's reliance on higher production costs and lower demand in Asia hinder its competitiveness, despite the cleaner profile of natural gas compared to coal in terms of pollution and carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: The liquefied natural gas (LNG) sector has watched with joy how thermal coal prices have soared this year, hoping that the unexpected spike would at last make LNG price competitive in Asia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end up as exporters boosted by cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for a second consecutive day, with major exporters benefiting from a strong US dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.26%, while the Topix index rose 0.40%. The rally was driven by the yen's decline, which boosted exporters' earnings. The strong dollar also supported US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Serena Williams withdraws from WTA Finals in Singapore
summary: US tennis superstar Serena Williams has withdrawn from the WTA Finals in Singapore, citing ongoing shoulder injuries that have hindered her in 2016. Williams, a 22-time Grand Slam champion, had been dealing with shoulder troubles since her Olympic loss in Rio and was hoping to compete in Singapore. Her doctor advised her to stay home and heal, ending her 186-week reign atop the world rankings. The WTA Finals are set to start on October 23.

site_title: 14 dead, scores missing in Myanmar ferry disaster: official
summary: A ferry capsized in central Myanmar, resulting in 14 confirmed deaths and scores missing. 154 people were rescued, with the sunken vessel located on the Chindwin River. The ferry was carrying 240-250 people, exceeding its capacity. Authorities have arrested four staff members and are searching for one crew member and the ferry's owner. Survivors reported the incident occurred quickly, with some managed to escape by clinging to debris, while others were killed or injured. The death toll could reach up to 100.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks extend losses on foreign selling; TSMC dips
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.01% to 9,163.21 on Monday, amid continued foreign selling and a decline in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest contract chipmaker. Foreign investors posted a net sell of Taiwan stocks on Friday, and the Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.795 per US dollar. The electronics subindex rose 0.3%, while the financials subindex fell 0.5%.

site_title: Oil extends decline as US producers boost drilling amid glut
summary: US oil producers increased drilling for a seventh consecutive week, boosting output and contributing to a decline in oil futures. Oil prices fell 0.7% in New York after reaching near US$50 a barrel amid speculation over Opec's ability to implement supply cuts. West Texas Intermediate for November delivery dropped to US$49.99 a barrel, and Brent for December settlement fell to US$51.88 a barrel. The US has added over 100 rigs since June, with crude inventories at a 474 million barrel high.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong shares slipped 0.30% in the opening minutes of trade on Monday, following a rally at the end of last week. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,164.54. In contrast, Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices remained flat. This decline was attributed to profit-takers moving on from the previous week's gains.

site_title: Developer sales rise to 509 private homes in Sept, up from Aug's 468 units
summary: Developer sales in Singapore rose to 509 private homes in September, up from 468 units in August and higher than 341 units in September 2015. Including ECs, developers sold 769 units, slightly lower than August but higher than September 2015. The figures, released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, show a continued strong demand for private homes in the city-state.

images.alt_text: Developers sold 509 private homes, excluding executive condominium (EC) units, in September 2016, up from 468 units in August 2016 and also higher than the 341 units for September 2015.

site_title: Lendlease lays out plans for Paya Lebar Quarter (Amended)
summary: Lendlease has unveiled plans for the S$3.2 billion Paya Lebar Quarter urban regeneration development in Singapore. The 99-year leasehold site, located at the junction of Paya Lebar Road and Sims Avenue, will feature seven buildings, including three grade A office towers, three residential towers, and over 200 retail shops. The development is expected to be completed in phases, with retail and commercial spaces ready by 2018 and residential towers in 2019. NTUC FairPrice Finest and Kopitiam have been named as the first two anchor tenants.

site_title: Crown shares plunge after China detains high-roller chief
summary: Crown Resorts' shares plummeted 10% in Sydney after 18 Chinese staff, including the high-roller chief, were detained for questioning. The detention of three Australians also sparked concerns. The company was unable to contact the detained staff, leading to a significant decline in its stock price.

site_title: Lack of new blood casts doubt over Wells Fargo's change plan
summary: Wells Fargo's decision not to introduce new faces to its board or senior management following a sales scandal has raised questions about its ability to overhaul its culture. The bank's long-tenured executives, including CEO Tim Sloan, have been criticized for lacking the necessary critical distance to address the issues. Analysts and experts argue that bringing in outsiders could help fix the culture, citing examples of successful turnarounds in other companies. Wells Fargo has maintained that it is comfortable with its current leadership, but the lack of change has sparked concerns about its ability to address the crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares drift near 1-1/2-month lows ahead of China economic data
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.8% to near 1-1/2-month lows on Monday, amid a cautious mood ahead of China's economic data release. The Hang Seng index lost 0.8% to 23,037.54, while the China Enterprises Index declined 0.6% to 9,541.08 points. Investors await China's GDP data, which is expected to show a 6.7% growth rate for the third quarter. Other data to be released includes money supply, loan growth, and retail sales, which will provide insight into the country's economic performance.

site_title: S Korea says economy will hit 2016 growth forecast despite Samsung Note 7 risk
summary: South Korea's economy is expected to meet its 2016 growth forecast of 2.8% despite risks from Samsung Electronics' Note 7 sales and Hyundai Motor Co's strikes. Deputy Finance Minister Lee Chan-woo attributed the potential negative impact of these factors to the third and fourth quarters, but noted that other sectors, such as consumption and investment, can offset the losses. The country's August industrial output fell 2.4% from July, the fastest decline in 19 months, but growth is still expected to comfortably meet the government's forecast.

site_title: Samsung Elec says it started mass production of 10-nanometre chips
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd announced it has started mass production of semiconductors using 10-nanometre technology, becoming the first company in the industry to do so. The technology will be used in half of Samsung's next Galaxy S smartphones expected to launch in early 2017, and also in Qualcomm's high-end Snapdragon 830 chips.

site_title: Australia: Shares drift as casino operator slumps, NZ drops
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Monday, with Crown Resorts plummeting 12.5% after 18 employees, including its head of VIP gambling, were detained by Chinese authorities. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,410.6 points. This marks Crown's worst percentage performance in nearly eight years, contributing to the overall market downturn.

site_title: Japan's top producer says zinc could surge to 5-year high
summary: Japan's top zinc producer, Mitsui Mining & Smelting, predicts zinc prices could surge to a 5-year high of US$2,500 a metric ton by March due to a "super tight" ore supply. The company joins Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, and Citigroup in highlighting a bullish outlook, citing a global deficit of 440,000 tons this year. Glencore's planned 500,000 tons of output cuts and China's winter production curbs also contribute to the shortage. Experts forecast zinc prices to average US$2,445 in 2017.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday with a slight increase of 0.660 points to 1661.130 on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. Volume was 25.9 million lots worth RM11.10 million, with 88 gainers outnumbering 45 losers.

site_title: Goldman Sachs vindicated but bruised in court battle with Libyan fund
summary: Goldman Sachs has won a court battle against Libya's US$67 billion sovereign fund, with the London High Court ruling in favour of the Wall Street giant. The dispute centred on nine equity derivatives trades worth US$1.2 billion, which the Libyan Investment Authority (LIA) claimed were made under "undue influence" and "unconscionable bargaining". However, Judge Vivien Rose dismissed the fund's arguments, stating that the LIA had exaggerated its staff's naivety and that the trades were no different from other investments made by the fund. The LIA is likely to appeal the decision.

images.alt_text: The outcome of a two-and-a-half-year legal battle between Goldman Sachs and Libya's US$67 billion (S$93.2 billion) sovereign fund is a triumph for the Wall Street giant, which was vindicated despite embarrassing revelations about how some of its bankers conducted business.

site_title: Tibet's thangkas find new fans across China
summary: In China, traditional Tibetan thangka paintings, depicting Buddhist deities and symbols, are gaining popularity among outsiders, including Han Chinese collectors. Dozens of students at a school in Lhasa are learning the medieval art, with over 100 apprentices, including some Han Chinese, participating in the revival. The art form, which was once lost during the Cultural Revolution, is now being commercialized, with prices soaring and thangkas selling for thousands of euros. While some experts warn of the risks of commercialization, others see it as a way to introduce Tibetan Buddhism to a wider audience and fill a spiritual void in China.

images.alt_text: Her eyes riveted to the canvas, Wulan meticulously applies colour to an image of the Buddha, using pigments made of crushed pearls, turquoise and agate.

site_title: Thai bonds suffer record outflows as king's death sparks concern
summary: Thai bonds experienced record outflows of $1 billion last week following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who had maintained stability in the nation's politics for seven decades. The baht currency dropped to its lowest level since January, and the country's debt saw a record outflow this year, totaling $10.7 billion. The passing of the king has raised concerns about the impact on Thailand's economy and politics, leading to increased market volatility.

site_title: Indonesia turtles find new freedom as they scurry into sea
summary: A group of turtles, including 1,000 baby turtles and 50 adults, were released into the sea by local tourists in Pariaman, Indonesia, after being cared for at a conservation centre. The centre, which focuses on protecting olive ridley, hawksbill, and green turtles, has handled over 30,000 turtles since its establishment in 2009. The turtles were released into the wild after being cared for in small pools with filtered sea water, and visitors can pay to release a turtle into the sea. The move aims to protect these endangered species threatened by poaching and habitat destruction.

site_title: Hollande faces across the board criticism after tell-all book
summary: French President Francois Hollande faces widespread criticism after releasing a tell-all book that criticizes judges, politicians, and even soccer players. The book, which was written based on 100 hours of interviews, has sparked controversy weeks before Hollande's decision on running for a second term. Polls show him as the least popular president since the 1960s, with only 14% of the French supporting his re-election bid. Critics, including former President Nicolas Sarkozy and Socialist party members, have questioned Hollande's judgment and called for discretion.

site_title: Hot stock: Swee Hong up by as much as 57% to S$0.022, says unaware of reason behind heavy trading
summary: Swee Hong shares surged by as much as 57% to S$0.022 on Monday, making it the second most actively-traded stock. The civil engineering firm attributed the sudden increase to unannounced information, but was unaware of the reason. Over 151.9 million shares changed hands, with the counter opening at S$0.015 and trading at S$0.019. The Singapore Exchange queried the trading activity, but Swee Hong maintained it was not aware of any information not previously announced.

site_title: Tesla, Panasonic to collaborate on solar cells production
summary: Tesla and Panasonic to collaborate on solar cells production in Buffalo, New York. The partnership will enable Tesla to use Panasonic's cells and modules in its solar energy systems, including Powerwall and Powerpack. Panasonic is expected to begin production in 2017, with Tesla committing to purchase the cells over the long term. This collaboration aims to improve the efficiency and affordability of solar energy systems.

site_title: Poll: Australia seen grabbing uninterrupted GDP growth record
summary: Australia is forecast to enjoy uninterrupted economic growth for at least two more years, extending a quarter-century without recession. Analysts expect a 2.9% GDP growth rate this year and 2.8% and 2.9% in 2018, making Australia the country with the longest run without a recession. Strong export volumes, record low interest rates, and a home building boom have driven growth, with commodity exports and mining investment also set to boost the economy. Policymakers believe the worst of the mining downturn has passed, and growth is expected to remain resilient despite global challenges.

site_title: Canada union votes to approve Fiat Chrysler contract
summary: Canadian manufacturing workers at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles voted 70.1% in favor of a tentative labor agreement, clearing the way for talks with Ford Motor Co. The approval would have triggered a strike at two Fiat Chrysler plants in Ontario, Canada, but the deal is expected to pave the way for a potential merger between the companies.

site_title: Duterte heads to Beijing looking for more Chinese business deals
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to visit Beijing for a four-day trip starting Tuesday, bringing up to 400 business leaders, including wealthy tycoons, to discuss potential business deals. This visit is seen as a sign of eased tensions between China and the Philippines, with Professor Li Jinming stating it as the strongest signal of reduced tensions. Duterte's predecessor had promised to use a jet ski to reclaim a disputed reef seized by China, but the current visit focuses on economic cooperation.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Monday, down 3.82 points or 0.14% to 2,811.42, following a fall in US stocks and investors' anticipation of a volatile week. The Straits Times Index has had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Gainers outnumbered losers 79 to 53, with Spackman rising 2.098% to S$0.146.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare says MOU with Hai Yen Group terminated
summary: CATALIST-LISTED ISEC Healthcare announced the termination of its memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Vietnam-based Hai Yen Group, effective immediately. The non-binding agreement, entered in January, had lapsed on October 15. ISEC stated that the parties will not proceed with a formal agreement or establish a joint venture company. Despite the termination, ISEC continues to see business potential in Vietnam and will explore other opportunities.

site_title: Sinochem unit says has no knowledge of merger with ChemChina
summary: Sinochem International Corp, a unit of state-owned Sinochem Group, denies receiving information about a proposed merger with ChemChina. The two state-owned chemical companies are in discussions about a possible merger to create a $100 billion chemicals, fertiliser and oil giant. Sinochem International said it has no knowledge of the merger and that neither it nor its parent company has expressed such an intention to any government department. The merger has been proposed by China's central government as part of efforts to slash state-owned companies and create larger, more competitive industry players.

site_title: North Korea missile exploded shortly after lift-off: Seoul
summary: North Korea's latest test-firing of a Musudan missile, capable of hitting US bases as far away as Guam, failed shortly after lift-off due to an explosion. The test occurred near an air base in the city of Kusong, and the news was delayed by 16 hours, with reports only emerging on Monday. The Musudan missile has a theoretical range of 2,500-4,000 km, and successful testing could help North Korea develop an operational ICBM capable of striking the US mainland by 2020. The failed launch marks the first since a failed test in June.

images.alt_text: An explosion almost immediately after launch was behind the failure of North Korea's latest test-firing of a powerful medium-range missile, the South Korean military confirmed Monday.

site_title: Ascott wins three new serviced residence contracts in Middle East
summary: Ascott, a CapitaLand subsidiary, has secured contracts to manage three new serviced residences in Saudi Arabia, including its first in Mecca. The properties, Ascott Makkah, Ascott Villas Riyadh, and Spectrums Residence in Jeddah, are set to open in 2017. This marks an increase in Ascott's Middle East portfolio to over 2,700 units across 19 properties in six countries. CEO Lee Chee Koon aims to double the portfolio to 5,000 units by 2020, driven by growing religious tourism in the region.

site_title: Airbus to overtake Boeing on aircraft output rates by 2020: CEO tells paper
summary: Airbus CEO Fabrice Bregier stated in a German newspaper interview that the company aims to overtake Boeing in terms of annual plane deliveries by 2020. Airbus has been trailing behind Boeing since 2012 but has been leading in new orders. Bregier emphasized that Airbus will focus on its A320 neo and A350 widebody planes to achieve the goal.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MMP Resources, ISEC Healthcare, SPH
summary: MMP Resources, ISEC Healthcare, and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) are stocks to watch. MMP Resources corrected a typographical error in an application to wind up the company, disputing claims of unpaid sums. ISEC Healthcare terminated a memorandum of understanding with Hai Yen Group, but maintains interest in Vietnam. SPH posted a 17.5% fall in net profit for fiscal 2016 due to declining revenue and impairments from the magazine segment.

site_title: China launches latest manned mission to space
summary: China successfully launched its latest manned space mission, Shenzhou 11, on October 16, 2016, carrying two astronauts into orbit aboard an experimental space laboratory. The crew will spend a month aboard the space station, part of a broader plan to have a permanent manned space station operational by 2022. The mission marks a significant step forward for China's space program, demonstrating its capabilities in space exploration and development.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda: To adjust policy as needed to hit 2% price goal
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda announced the central bank will adjust monetary policy as needed to achieve its 2% inflation target, focusing on economic, price, and financial developments. This follows the BOJ's switch to targeting interest rates instead of expanding the monetary base in an effort to boost the economy, which has been stagnant for decades. Kuroda stated that Japan's economy is expected to expand moderately, but no specific timeline was provided for achieving the inflation target.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as investors mull US interest-rate outlook
summary: Asian stocks rose for a second day as investors weighed the US interest-rate outlook, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 0.1% to 138.25. The yen's weakness and key economic data, including industrial production and inflation, influenced the market. Despite Fed Chair Janet Yellen signaling a deliberate approach to raising interest rates, the odds for monetary tightening in December hovered above 60%. Investors are monitoring global events, including the US-EU trade talks, and remain cautious amid tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US dollar touches 7-month high after upbeat US data
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-month high against a basket of currencies on Monday, driven by upbeat US data and a rise in US Treasury yields. The dollar index gained 0.1% to 98.122, while the euro hovered near a three-month low of $1.0965. The greenback's momentum was expected to be tested by upcoming events, including China's GDP data and the ECB policy meeting. Despite this, the dollar's upward trend was expected to continue, with investors focusing on the potential for a December interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Oil prices fall on latest rise in US drilling
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures trading at $50.03 per barrel, down 32 cents from their last settlement. The decline was attributed to a rising US rig count, record Opec output, and slowing global economic growth. International benchmark Brent crude oil futures also dropped 20 cents to $51.75 per barrel. Analysts expect Opec to cut output in November, with potential participation from Russia, which may alleviate concerns about a global production overhang. Oil prices are expected to remain volatile.

site_title: Frankfurt fair shakes up book world with art, tech gadgets
summary: The Frankfurt Book Fair has incorporated technology into its 5-day event, featuring virtual reality experiences, interactive classrooms, and 3D-printed art. Publishers are embracing new technology to engage readers and create innovative content. The fair also showcases educational publishers' use of apps and 3D printing in biology lessons. A "fair within a fair" called Arts+ will discuss the challenges and opportunities of working with digital technology, while a project called "The next Rembrandt" uses artificial intelligence and 3D printing to recreate a work by the master painter.

images.alt_text: There will still be more books than you could ever read, but visitors to this week's Frankfurt Book Fair will also be invited to don virtual reality goggles, visit an interactive classroom and discover 3D-printed art as publishers plug into new technology.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by a weak yen lifting automakers and exporters. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.15% to 16,880.83, while the Topix index rose 0.09% to 1,348.37. The gains were attributed to a weak yen, which benefits exporters, including automakers.

site_title: US companies brace for climate-friendly alternatives in cooling systems
summary: US companies, including Honeywell and Chemours, are ramping up production of alternative coolants for air conditioners and refrigerators in response to a global agreement to phase down hydrofluorocarbon (HFC) gases. The Kigali accord aims to reduce HFCs by 80% by 2047 and is an amendment to the 1987 Montreal Protocol. Companies have already begun developing and testing HFC alternatives, with investments totaling hundreds of millions of dollars. The phased transition is expected to eventually reduce costs for consumers, as the majority of the cost of air conditioners is attributed to electricity.

images.alt_text: US chemical companies including Honeywell and Chemours are ramping up efforts to produce alternative coolants used in air-conditioners and refrigerators, following a global pact to reduce planet-warming greenhouse house gas emissions.

site_title: 'Put on microeconomic hats' for infrastructure projects: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for governments to adopt a microeconomic approach when overseeing infrastructure projects, particularly in the low interest rate environment. He warned that cost overruns are common, with average overruns ranging from 20-45%, and called for rigorous cost-benefit analyses. Tharman also highlighted the importance of public-private partnerships, leveraging technology to drive down costs, and prioritizing projects that offer the greatest pay-off.

site_title: China sends astronauts into space with plans for longest mission
summary: China successfully launched the Shenzhou-11 spacecraft on Monday, sending two astronauts, Jing Haipeng and Chen Dong, into space to dock with the Tiangong-2 space lab. The 33-day mission marks a crucial step towards China's goal of building and operating its first space station by 2022. The crew will test equipment and technologies, including exercise bicycles and broadband links, while consuming over 100 types of space food. The mission is seen as a point of national pride, with China's space program aiming to send an astronaut to the moon by 2025 and land an unmanned vehicle on Mars.

site_title: MMP Resources says typo error corrected in application filed to wind up company
summary: MMP Resources stated that a typo error has been corrected in an application filed to wind up the company. The initial amount of S$5.22 million was corrected to S$30,000 in the affidavit filed by Edward Lee Ewe Ming. MMP Resources disputed Mr. Lee's claims and plans to vigorously oppose the application, stating it is in the process of a forensic audit that may be used to oppose the application. The court hearing is scheduled for October 28.

site_title: NODX slips back into negative territory in September
summary: Singapore's NON-OIL domestic exports (NODX) declined 4.8% year-on-year in September, falling back into negative territory. This follows a 1.9% dip in August and a 2.4% jump in the previous month. External demand remained weak, with NODX shipments to most major markets declining except for Hong Kong, the EU, and South Korea. Electronic NODX dropped 6.6% year-on-year, while non-electronic NODX fell 4.0% from August.

site_title: US banks slashed share of British property loans before Brexit
summary: US banks significantly reduced their share of British property loans to 7% from 14% in the first six months before the Brexit referendum, amid uncertainty and market cooling. UK banks and member-owned lenders increased their share to 44%, while the overall volume of new loans fell 13% to £21.4 billion. The decrease in new loan originations was partly due to market slowdown and investor concern over the referendum, rather than solely Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Won nears 3-month low on US rate hike fears, stocks dither
summary: The South Korean won dropped to its lowest level in three months, falling 0.8% to 1,140.7 against the US dollar, amid concerns that the Federal Reserve will hike interest rates in December. Positive US economic data, including a rebound in retail sales and a rise in inflation, strengthened these views. The won's decline was also influenced by a US treasury report that kept South Korea on its monitoring list.

site_title: 1MDB notes reward bulls focused on scandal-hit bond's backers
summary: Bonds of 1Malaysia Development Bhd have surged despite investigations into its activities, as investors bet on the strength of its backers. International Petroleum Investment, Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, paid the coupon on 1MDB's $1.75 billion of October 2022 notes as co-guarantor, narrowing the yield premium to IPIC. Actively traded 1MDB bonds have an extra yield of 220 basis points over US Treasuries, compared to 101 for IPIC, indicating investors' confidence in the fund's backers.

images.alt_text: Bonds of 1Malaysia Development Bhd have surged despite broadening investigations into the state investment fund's activities, as investors bet on the strength of its backers.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts says 18 staff detained in China
summary: Crown Resorts, Australia's largest casino company, confirmed that 18 of its employees, including its head of VIP gambling, have been detained by Chinese authorities. The staff were reportedly held following police raids last week, and Crown has been unable to make contact with them. The company is working with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to determine the welfare of its employees.

site_title: Japan PM Abe sends ritual offering to Yasukuni shrine for war dead
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sent a ritual offering to Yasukuni Shrine for war dead on Monday to mark the annual autumn festival. The shrine is seen in China and the two Koreas as a symbol of Japan's past militarism, honoring 14 Japanese leaders convicted as war criminals. Abe's visit has sparked outrage in Beijing and Seoul, but is a long-standing tradition in Japan.

site_title: Operation to retake Mosul from IS has begun: Iraq PM
summary: Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi announced the start of operations to retake the city of Mosul from the Islamic State group, declaring "the time of victory has come". This comes after months of fighting, with the goal of liberating the city from IS control. The operation marks a significant shift in the conflict, with the Iraqi military leading the charge. The city's liberation is seen as a key victory in the fight against terrorism.

site_title: Bank Indonesia says strong currency gives room to build reserves
summary: Bank Indonesia's executive director Doddy Zulverdi stated that the country's strong currency, which has gained 5.7% this year, gives room to continue increasing foreign reserves to a four-year high of $116 billion. The central bank plans to keep the currency from strengthening excessively and has cut interest rates five times this year to support the economy. Reserves are expected to narrow to below 2% of GDP by the end of the year due to fund inflows and trade improvements.

site_title: Apple's push for better screens to make or break Japan suppliers
summary: Apple plans to transition its iPhones to OLED screens next year, putting pressure on Japanese suppliers to increase OLED production. To meet this demand, Sharp Corp and Japan Display Inc are investing heavily in OLED manufacturing, with initial costs estimated at $2 billion each. The shift to OLEDs is expected to be worth $18.6 billion by 2018, surpassing LCDs.
