Japanese Display faces significant financial risks if it fails to secure a contract with Apple, with analysts warning that the company's current financial situation is precarious.

site_title: Britain PM May heads to India with eye on post-Brexit trade
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to lead a trade mission to India in November, as part of efforts to bolster post-Brexit trade with countries outside the EU. The trip aims to forge a new global role for Britain and will focus on small and medium-sized businesses. May will hold talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and sign commercial deals during the visit. This move comes as the European Commission has stated that it will not negotiate a new trade deal for Britain until it has left the EU.

site_title: Greek PM Tsipras bolsters grip on party in congress vote
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has been reconfirmed as leader of his leftist Syriza party with 93.54% of the vote at a party congress, bolstering his approval rates among grassroots members. This follows his 74% vote at a 2013 congress. Tsipras, 42, has maintained his position as party leader since 2013.

site_title: Mega-merger poses challenge to China state-run oil giants
summary: A potential merger between Sinochem Group and China National Chemical Corp (ChemChina) could create the largest oil refiner in China, rivaling state-run companies Sinopec and CNPC. The combined entity would have assets worth over $100 billion and annual capacity of 50 million tonnes, according to Wood Mackenzie Ltd. The move is seen as a strategy by policymakers to boost competition in the oil sector, contrary to previous plans to break up dominant state-run companies.

site_title: No bartering away territory, economic rights to China: Duterte
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte vowed not to "barter" away territory and economic rights ahead of a visit to Beijing, where he aims to mend ties with China over the South China Sea. He will raise a ruling outlawing China's claim to most of the sea, but will not impose hard limits, instead seeking to "talk and maybe paraphrase" the judgment. Duterte's visit comes after a row over the South China Sea, with China building artificial islands in disputed waters.

site_title: US Republican party office in North Carolina firebombed
summary: A firebomb attack was carried out on the Orange County Republican Party headquarters in Hillsborough, North Carolina, with the message "Nazi Republicans leave town or else" sprayed on an adjacent building. The attack, which occurred overnight, resulted in significant damage to the office and no injuries. The executive director of the state's Republican Party called the attack "political terrorism," while presidential hopeful Donald Trump blamed it on supporters of his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. Mrs. Clinton denounced the incident as "horrific and unacceptable."

site_title: Foreign investors, consumers starting to take advantage of cheap sterling
summary: Foreign investors and consumers are taking advantage of the cheap sterling, with some predicting that investment will accelerate as the pound becomes less volatile. Despite forecasts of further steep falls, foreign property investors and consumers have begun purchasing British assets and goods. The pound has tumbled 35% against the yen and 25% against the euro since 2015, with some analysts predicting further declines of 10-20%. The UK property, travel, and retail industries are seeing the first signs of bargain hunting, with some companies experiencing significant price drops, making British assets and goods attractive to overseas buyers.

site_title: UK needs to give banks clarity on Brexit future or face exodus
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May must provide banks with maximum certainty on Brexit's future to prevent an exodus, warns Open Europe. The think tank recommends a bespoke deal ensuring UK banks' access to the EU single market and reciprocal access for European banks. An interim agreement could preserve banks' ability to provide services on similar terms beyond the two-year negotiation period, preventing a significant loss of financial services in the UK and Europe.

site_title: US expands airline curbs on Samsung Note 7
summary: The US has expanded airline restrictions on Samsung Note 7 smartphones, banning the devices from flights due to safety concerns over overheating and fires. The ban affects 1.9 million Note 7s sold in the US, and passengers who try to bring the devices on board may face fines and confiscation. The government urges passengers to return their phones to Samsung or their wireless carriers, and airlines are updating announcements to inform passengers about the ban. The restrictions apply to both passenger and cargo aircraft, and are considered a "forbidden hazardous material" under US law.

site_title: India conglomerate Mahindra open to reducing stakes in units
summary: India's Mahindra Group, a $18 billion conglomerate, is open to reducing its stakes in publicly traded units to facilitate fundraising. The company may cut its shareholdings in six listed entities, including Mahindra & Mahindra Financial Services Ltd, to less than 51%. This strategy aims to encourage unlisted group companies to tap private equity for investment and list on stock exchanges.

site_title: A global pushback
summary: A global backlash against globalization could severely weaken international trade, lifting millions out of poverty in the last 70 years. Companies must engage with stakeholders, be open and transparent, and act with integrity to build trust with local communities. Policymakers should champion cooperation models that promote broadly shared gains and reject cynical and fearful agendas. Isolationism and trade protectionism can lead to a "closed economy" that will eventually die. Smart economies will keep their doors open to the rising nationalistic tide, while closed economies will become redundant. Policymakers must address domestic problems, such as income inequality and unemployment, rather than blaming globalization.

site_title: New Zealand service sector growth slows slightly in September
summary: New Zealand's services sector experienced a slowdown in growth in September, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index falling 3.8 points to 54.1. Poor weather and school holidays are believed to have contributed to the decline, with 39.3% of respondents citing these factors. This marks a contrast to the manufacturing sector, which saw a rise in activity in September to its highest levels since January.

images.alt_text: Growth in New Zealand's services sector softened in September, a survey showed Monday.

site_title: Trump attacks, Clinton lies low as last debate nears
summary: Donald Trump has launched a series of attacks on Hillary Clinton, claiming that the US media is rigging the presidential election against him. In a string of tweets, Trump accused Clinton of lying and suggested that voter fraud will be a problem on election day. His running mate Mike Pence attempted to lower tensions by saying that his camp would accept defeat if that's what voters decide. Despite Trump's claims, polls show Clinton ahead, with some putting her margin at 11 points, and her running mate Tim Kaine criticized Trump's assertions as dangerous.

site_title: Thais unite in monochrome to mourn their revered king
summary: Thailand mourns the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, with tens of thousands of people turning out in black to show their collective grief. The usually colorfully dressed nation has come together in monochrome attire, with many businesses and government staff following suit. The sudden demand for black clothing has sparked fears of a national shortage, but the government is working to ensure supply. The event marks a rare unifying moment for the politically divided nation, which has been plagued by rival camps and mass protests in recent years.

site_title: US$ rises as data backs December rate hike view
summary: The US dollar rose to its best weekly performance in over seven months due to strong September retail sales and producer prices data, reinforcing expectations of a December interest rate hike. Fed Chair Janet Yellen hinted that the central bank might need a "high-pressure" economy to reverse the damage from the last financial crisis. This move sparked a brief trimming of gains against the Japanese yen and euro.

site_title: Singaporeans' inflation expectations remain at record 5-year lows: SInDEx
summary: Singaporeans' inflation expectations remain at a record 5-year low, averaging 2.63% for the year ahead, according to the Singapore Index of Inflation Expectations (SInDEx). This is the lowest level since the survey's inception in 2011, despite global economic uncertainty and weak demand. Experts attribute the low expectations to persistently low oil prices, subdued demand from emerging economies, and consumer confidence in the US. The median headline inflation is significantly lower than the historical average, suggesting that Singaporean households believe the inflation environment will persist.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans' inflation expectations for the year ahead have remained at a five-year low, weighed down by subdued global and domestic demands.

site_title: Thursday's US debate focal point of week ahead
summary: US presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are set to face off in the third debate on Thursday, potentially influencing market sentiment ahead of the November 8 election. Despite Clinton's perceived pro-establishment stance and Trump's anti-trade views, investors are hesitant to make big bets due to uncertainty and the potential for dramatic changes in opinion polls. Markets may remain quiet until the debate concludes, with traders focusing on rotational churning of low-priced issues and responding to queries from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Japan mulls joint administration of disputed Russian-held isles
summary: Japan is considering proposing joint administration of four disputed islands held by Russia, aimed at resolving a 70-year-old issue between the two nations. The proposal is set to be discussed with Russian President Vladimir Putin in December. The islands, known as Japan's Northern Territories and Russia's Kurile chain, have prevented Tokyo and Moscow from signing a post-World War Two peace treaty. This move could potentially unblock a long-standing issue between Japan and Russia, but the outcome is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Japan is considering proposing joint administration of disputed islands held by Russia in the hope of unblocking an issue that has bedevilled their relations for 70 years, the Nikkei newspaper reported on Monday.

site_title: Higher sales, happier staff after Walmart pays staff more
summary: Walmart, the US' largest private employer, has reported improved sales and customer satisfaction after increasing staff wages and implementing changes to scheduling and training. The company's average hourly pay for full-time non-managerial employees rose 16% to $13.69, with a minimum of $10 for workers completing a training course. The move, aimed at boosting employee loyalty and productivity, has seen a 75% rebound in stores meeting customer-service goals and a rise in sales. However, the impact on earnings and stock price has been less significant, raising questions about the long-term effects of this approach.

site_title: Oil prices dip on stronger US$, rig count rise
summary: Oil prices fell slightly on Friday as a stronger US dollar weighed on prices, despite a rise in the US oil rig count to 16 weeks without cuts. The US dollar posted its best weekly performance in over seven months, impacting greenback-denominated commodities. Brent crude settled down 8 US cents to $51.95 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude ended down 9 US cents at $50.35 a barrel, closing flat for the week. Analysts expect prices to continue rising on expectations of Opec output cuts.

site_title: UK consumers most upbeat in 5 years, but not in pro-EU London
summary: British consumers are at their most confident in five years, according to a survey by Deloitte, with overall confidence rising by three percentage points. However, this upbeat mood is not shared in London, where consumer sentiment fell by three percentage points due to concerns over the country's uncertain future relationship with the EU. Despite this, retail sales are expected to continue growing, but spending power may be challenged by rising inflation and EU exit negotiations.

images.alt_text: A survey of Britain's housing market published last week found property prices fell in London, bucking a rise in the country as a whole.

site_title: The cars and chemicals in the DAX
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The DAX, Germany's blue-chip index, tracks the country's largest and most easily-traded companies, including industrial and engineering giants. The index is composed of 30 stocks, weighted by market capitalization, and includes companies like BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Volkswagen. The DAX has a history of resilience, with a significant increase in 2014 and a current trading ratio of 14 times forward earnings. Key companies in the DAX include BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Volkswagen, Bayer, and BASF, which are major players in the automotive, chemicals, and engineering sectors. The index offers opportunities for long-term investment.

site_title: Singapore's int'l health-insurance market likely to stay in the pink
summary: Singapore's international health-insurance market is expected to grow 15% or more in the next 1-2 years, driven by Cigna's plans to expand its distribution channel. Despite rising medical inflation and claims ratios, the sector remains optimistic, with Cigna's CEO, Lena Tsia, attributing the growth to steady premium growth and strategic alliances. The company aims to leverage technology to reduce healthcare costs and improve productivity, with its tele-health solution set to roll out in Singapore next year.

site_title: Big Oil experimenting with technology to lower costs
summary: Big Oil companies, including Shell, Statoil, and Chevron, are experimenting with various technologies to reduce costs in the face of low crude prices. Companies are using drones for inspections, simplifying drilling designs, and optimizing pipeline routes to cut costs. Statoil has reduced development costs for its Johan Sverdrup field by a fifth and saved $1.8 billion through innovations. These efforts aim to preserve dividends and infrastructure, allowing companies to compete and grow when the market recovers.

site_title: Independence will happen, says Scotland's separatist leader
summary: Scotland's separatist leader Nicola Sturgeon confirmed preparations for a second referendum on independence from Britain, stating her belief in Scotland's independence is stronger than ever. The Scottish National Party leader pledged to "explore all options" to prevent Scotland being taken out of the European Union against its will.

site_title: Curbs by regulators raise risks of China builder debt
summary: China's developers face a double blow from cooling measures and curbs on bond market access, increasing debt risks. At least 21 cities have introduced purchase restrictions and tightened mortgage lending limits. The average yield on Asian dollar-denominated high-yield notes has jumped to 6.4%, threatening developers' refinancing risk and increasing the likelihood of defaults. Total debt for Chinese developers has risen to a record high of three trillion yuan, with median total debt increasing eight times Ebitda, and profitability worsening due to low gross profit margins.

site_title: Watchdog says about 15 Swiss banks in money laundering 'red zone': report
summary: About 15 Swiss banks are in a "red zone" for money laundering risks, according to FINMA chief executive Mark Branson. The list includes banks involved in asset management and often serving clients from emerging markets. Falcon Private Bank, facing a criminal investigation over links to 1MDB, is given a second chance but risks losing its banking license if it repeats the offense. The watchdog aims to educate lenders on emerging markets rather than withdrawing from them.

site_title: Portugal to tax real estate fortunes to help fund pensions
summary: Portugal is introducing a 0.3% tax on real estate fortunes above 600,000 euros to fund pensions. The tax, included in the 2017 draft budget, aims to raise 160 million euros annually. The measure, opposed by the real estate sector, will spare beneficiaries of the "golden visa" scheme, which has attracted foreign investment. The government expects the tax to enhance the sustainability of social security and contribute to fiscal justice.

images.alt_text: Portugal will introduce a tax on real estate fortunes above 600,000 euros (S$915,200) in 2017 to help pay for pensions, the government has said.

site_title: The news of 2056
summary: By 2056, Singapore's financial market is expected to double its current level, with the Straits Times Index reaching around 6,000, driven by corporate deal sizes and growth in industries like finance, services, and information and communications. Climate change and demographics will also shape decisions, with population-related issues and rising temperatures expected to impact policy agendas. Additionally, technological advancements, such as robots with artificial intelligence, may lead to breakthroughs, including potential contact with an extraterrestrial civilization.

site_title: The board's duties in a takeover
summary: A target company's board has fiduciary duties to act in the best interests of shareholders, including providing timely and accurate information about a potential takeover offer. The board must notify shareholders of a serious offer without delay, keep confidential information secure, and ensure prompt announcements are made about potential offers. The board must also appoint an independent financial adviser to provide competent advice on the takeover offer and make this information available to shareholders. The board should avoid actions that could frustrate the offer or deny shareholders a chance to decide on the offer's merits.

site_title: Threat of new arms race looming - in space
summary: The US and other military powers are preparing for a potential war in outer space, with concerns about the vulnerabilities of satellites and the risk of a new arms race. Russia and China are developing capabilities to attack satellites, and the US is accelerating its efforts to defend its space assets. Experts warn that a space war could be devastating, causing widespread damage and creating a chain reaction of destruction. The US must develop effective but limitable forms of space attack to prevent its communications network from becoming vulnerable.

site_title: Global poultry producers eye South Korea market
summary: Global poultry producers are expected to increase imports to South Korea, where a ban on overseas suppliers has been lifted, due to low per capita consumption rates. South Korea's demand for chicken is fueled by the popularity of "chimaek" - a fried chicken and beer combination that has become a craze in the country. The market is dominated by three local producers, but imports are expected to rise 9% this year and 8% in 2017, potentially squeezing domestic producers with lower prices.

images.alt_text: The popularity of fried chicken and beer, known as chimaek, has boomed in recent years, fuelled by its appearance in a hit South Korean television drama and an explosion of restaurant chains.

site_title: Nerd-heavy JBA going strong in flood mapping business
summary: JBA Group, a UK-based flood mapping specialist, continues to thrive with a high density of technical experts. The company, which started with three staff 20 years ago, has grown to 400 employees and is now a leading provider of flood mapping data to insurers and governments. With 20% of staff holding a doctorate, JBA is uniquely positioned to model flood risks, which are the largest annual losses for many insurers. The company is expanding into new sectors, including mortgage companies and banks, and is working with competitors to provide data for global modelling companies.

site_title: Singapore banks still hiring despite slowing economy
summary: Singapore's banking sector continues to hire, despite the country's slowing economy, with DBS and Citi combined having over 1,200 vacancies. The majority of these positions are in compliance and IT roles. This contrasts with the recent trend of job cuts in the banking sector, mainly in investment banking. The resident unemployment rate in Singapore has risen to 3%, exceeding the 2.6-2.9% range for the first time in five years. Banks are also focusing on internal mobility and talent acquisition processes to maintain efficiency.

images.alt_text: While global banks are slashing Asia positions - especially in investment banking - banks operating in Singapore have thousands of vacancies, mainly in compliance and information technology.

site_title: After initial scare, all eyes now on ECB's stimulus plans
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is under pressure to clarify its stimulus plans after investors reacted to speculation about ending its massive bond-buying programme. Analysts expect the ECB to extend the quantitative easing programme, despite sluggish eurozone growth and low inflation, with most expecting the bank to hold off on announcing fresh monetary support until December. The ECB is set to review its asset-buying scheme at its meeting on Thursday, with policymakers considering "tapering" the programme, but most analysts believe the bank will continue to support the economy.

site_title: Self-driving cars: Best thing to happen to motorbikes
summary: Self-driving cars are expected to significantly improve safety for motorcyclists, reducing fatalities by up to 80%. According to BMW Motorrad's Karl Viktor Schaller, robots at the wheel will minimize the most hazardous situations, such as left turns, and alert drivers to prevent accidents. The technology may boost motorcycle sales, particularly in the US, China, and India, where affordability is a factor. However, in countries like Europe, where motorcycles are the primary mode of transportation, self-driving cars may deter sales.

site_title: Xi warns of globalisation backlash at BRICS summit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned of a global backlash against globalization at the BRICS summit in India, citing a rising tide of protectionism and anti-globalization. Despite his peers' support, the leaders of China, Russia, Brazil, and South Africa issued a joint declaration focusing on business and trade ties, including a new credit ratings agency and combating tax evasion. The declaration did not include a fierce condemnation of India's rival Pakistan, as Modi's peers held off on signing on to such a statement. The BRICS leaders vowed to strengthen economic cooperation.

site_title: Investors may be in for another volatile week in the stock market
summary: US stocks are expected to be volatile this week, influenced by various factors including uneven earnings, growth data, the presidential election, Brexit, and the Federal Reserve's rate decision. The fourth quarter is seasonally strong due to holiday shopping, but earnings reports have been mixed, with some companies, such as Alcoa and JPMorgan Chase, beating expectations. The Brexit saga, the ongoing US presidential election, and the Fed's rate hike promise continue to pose risks. Analysts warn that the bar is set high for companies in the earnings season, and the outcome of the Fed's decision may impact the stock market.

site_title: He sees big opportunities beyond the horizon
summary: SUTL Enterprise, a Singapore-based marina operator, plans to expand its overseas footprint in Asia and other developed markets. The company aims to capitalize on growing demand for luxury leisure pursuits from Asia's high-net-worth individuals, particularly in Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Myanmar, and Thailand. SUTL Enterprise has announced several marina projects in Malaysia, the US, Indonesia, and China, and is eyeing greenfield marina developments in Asia. The company's CEO, Arthur Tay, believes Asia has a lot to grow in terms of marina assets and is not deterred by the uncertain global economy.

site_title: Independence will happen, says Scotland separatist leader
summary: Scotland separatist leader Nicola Sturgeon confirmed preparations for a second referendum on independence from Britain, citing a stronger belief in Scotland's future as independent. She said another referendum is "highly likely" if all other options to keep Scotland in the EU fail. The SNP will present a bill for a new referendum to the Scottish Parliament this week. Sturgeon acknowledged the challenges of convincing EU member states to accept a unique Brexit solution for Scotland, but expressed determination to give Scotland a chance to choose a better future.

site_title: Health effects of Pokemon Go fading: report
summary: A study by Microsoft researchers found that the initial surge in physical activity among Pokémon Go players declined significantly after one month, with the average daily step count decreasing by 1,473 steps. Highly engaged players, who played the game repeatedly, saw an initial increase of up to 1,473 steps per day, but this effect also faded. The study suggests that Pokémon Go could have had a significant impact on public health, but its popularity and engagement rates have decreased over time, limiting its potential benefits.

site_title: Singapore investors back to selling of Wall Street stocks
summary: Singapore investors resumed selling US stocks in the first half of 2016, dumping shares worth a net US$2.83 billion in the first quarter and US$410 million in the second quarter, according to US Treasury figures. The sell-offs were likely driven by profit-taking after US equities rebounded in March. This pattern is in sync with global investors, who also sold a net US$23.06 billion of shares in the first quarter and US$17.34 billion in the following quarter.

site_title: Leveraging 'cutting-edge technology' to sell furniture
summary: Singapore-listed furniture maker Commune introduces virtual reality (VR) and 3D-planning services at its stores to drive sales, becoming the first player in the Singapore furniture sector to utilize these technologies. The move aims to enhance customer experience, address pain points, and showcase products digitally. Commune plans to roll out these services regionally in the next half to one year, with a focus on China, where the company aims to open 100 shops, 70% of which will be in China. The company's strategy seeks to balance brick-and-mortar stores with digital services, leveraging technology to stay ahead in the competitive furniture retail market.

site_title: No bartering away territory, economic rights to China: Duterte
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte vowed not to "barter" away territory and economic rights in a visit to Beijing, where he aims to mend ties with China over the South China Sea dispute. Duterte will raise the international tribunal's ruling outlawing China's claim to most of the sea, but will not impose hard limits on territories or economic zones. He agreed with a Supreme Court justice that giving away Scarborough Shoal would be an impeachable offense, and that China's claims are not allowed under the constitution. Duterte's visit comes after a state visit to Brunei and amid strained relations with the US.

site_title: Shareholders give their nod to merger of Italy's Banco Popolare, BPM
summary: Italian banks Banco Popolare and Banca Popolare di Milano (BPM) have voted to merge, creating the country's third-largest lender. The merger, approved by shareholders, aims to strengthen the banking sector and consolidate Italy's troubled lenders. The new entity, Banco BPM, will have 25,000 employees, 2,400 branches, and manage assets worth 171 billion euros. The deal brings much-needed breathing room to Italy's lenders, which hold 360 billion euros of bad loans, and has been supported by unions and the European Central Bank.

site_title: Volkswagen to pay US$175m to US lawyers suing over emissions
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to pay US$175 million to US lawyers in a class action lawsuit over emissions, as part of a larger settlement of US$16.7 billion to compensate US owners and address claims from states and federal regulators. The company admitted using secret software to cheat exhaust emissions tests, affecting millions of vehicles worldwide. A US$10.033 billion buy-back offer for polluting vehicles is set to be finalized, with regulators potentially approving a fix for some 2015 VW diesel vehicles as early as next month.

site_title: Australia looking into report Crown employees detained in china
summary: The Australian government is investigating reports that at least 18 Crown Resorts Ltd employees, including three Australian citizens, have been detained by Chinese authorities. Consular officials are seeking confirmation from Chinese authorities. The employees, including a senior executive, were reportedly being questioned by Chinese authorities. This development raises concerns about the safety and well-being of Australian citizens abroad.

images.alt_text: The Australian government is investigating a report that at least 18 employees from the Melbourne-based Crown Resorts Ltd have been detained by Chinese authorities.

site_title: After initial scare, all eyes are now on ECB's stimulus plans
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is under pressure to clarify its stimulus plans amid speculation of an end to its massive bond-buying program. Despite concerns, analysts expect the ECB to extend its quantitative easing scheme, which aims to boost the economy, and is currently set to expire in March. The ECB's chief Mario Draghi will address investors' concerns during a meeting on Thursday, with many expecting him to lift the veil on an extension of the program.

site_title: HDB calls for solar leasing tender
summary: The Housing Development Board (HDB) has launched a solar leasing tender to install solar panels across 636 HDB blocks and 31 government sites in Singapore. The tender, part of the SolarNova programme, aims to raise adoption of solar power. The installation is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2019, with a total capacity of 40 megawatt peak. The tender will close on December 30, 2016, and is estimated to be awarded in the first quarter of 2017.

site_title: Wells Fargo CFO says has not considered giving back recent bonuses
summary: Wells Fargo CFO John Shrewsberry stated he has not considered giving back bonuses earned following a scandal over unauthorized accounts. His compensation is paid out over several years to address such situations. This comes after the bank faced criticism for creating millions of unauthorized accounts. Shrewsberry's comments were made in an interview with CNBC.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co CFO John Shrewsberry said Friday he has not considered giving back bonuses he has earned following a scandal over unauthorized accounts.

site_title: Deutsche Bank mulling cutback in US operations: reports
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering scaling back its US operations as part of a cost-cutting overhaul, amid mounting legal expenses threatening its profitability. The move, reportedly discussed by the supervisory board, would be more likely than a sale of its asset management business. Despite no decision, the bank's shares have risen 2.04% on the day, while it has lost 46% of its market value this year. CEO John Cryan is under pressure to lower costs further, with the company reviewing its US activities and capital requirements.

site_title: Canada housing sales show signs of rebound amid stricter measures
summary: Canada's housing market showed signs of a rebound in September, with national home sales rising 0.8% and average prices increasing 2.7%. Toronto home values climbed 21% from a year earlier, while Vancouver recovered from a sharp drop in August. New measures introduced by Finance Minister Bill Morneau include stricter stress tests and eligibility criteria for insured loans, which may impact first-time home buyers. Markets outside British Columbia are not showing signs of weakness, and it remains to be seen if the new measures will lead to a soft landing or a sharper correction.

images.alt_text: Home values in Vancouver in September are up from a sharp drop in August and national average prices are up 2.7 per cent.

site_title: K-pop idols take acts into the army
summary: In South Korea, K-pop idols are required to serve in the military for 21 months, including famous stars like U-Know Yunho from TVXQ. The army hosts a propaganda festival where fans can see their favorite pop idols perform, and the event aims to soften the image of the military. Despite some stars' attempts to evade conscription or flout army rules, many fans appreciate the opportunity to see their idols in uniform, and some even romanticize the military draft culturally. The festival has become a successful export of K-pop, attracting fans from around the world.

site_title: Salesforce CEO says will not bid for Twitter
summary: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff has ruled out bidding for Twitter, stating it was not the "right fit" for the company. This decision comes after Twitter's shares fell 5.2% to $16.88. Salesforce shares rose 4.8% to $74 following the announcement.

site_title: Modi hosts BRICS leaders amid bloc's economic woes
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is hosting BRICS leaders in Goa, seeking to boost trade ties and address the bloc's economic woes. The leaders, from Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, face challenges including falling global demand, lower commodity prices, and corruption scandals. India aims to increase intra-BRICS trade and cooperation, while also discussing regional security, climate change, and Syria. However, analysts question India's chances of securing a joint BRICS condemnation of Pakistan due to China's diplomatic support.

site_title: Satellite communications lifting S-E Asia's remote regions into Internet age
summary: Satellite communications are revolutionizing remote regions in South-east Asia by providing internet connectivity and e-commerce services to underserved areas. Countries like Indonesia and Myanmar are adopting SatComms to leapfrog traditional ICT adoption. High Throughput Satellites (HTS) are enabling stable connectivity and facilitating the growth of e-commerce, streaming media, and digital transactions. Companies like Netflix and Amazon are expanding their services to these regions, while banks and retailers are using SatComms to provide basic services like ATM transactions and credit card services, bridging the digital divide in the region.

site_title: Obama meets with national security team on Syria, Islamic State
summary: President Barack Obama met with his national security team to discuss the fight against Islamic State and the war in Syria. The meeting considered military and other options, but it was unclear if Obama would order US air strikes on Syrian government targets. The US had broken off bilateral talks with Russia on reaching a ceasefire in Syria, and Obama directed his team to continue multilateral talks to seek a diplomatic resolution. Pressure mounts on the Syrian government to halt its offensive in Aleppo, where 275,000 civilians are trapped.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama met on Friday with his national security team to discuss the fight against Islamic State and the war in Syria, the White House said.

site_title: 150 nations agree major deal in Rwanda to cut greenhouse gases
summary: About 150 nations agreed on a global deal to reduce greenhouse gases used in refrigerators and air conditioners in Rwanda. The deal, agreed by US Secretary of State John Kerry, divides countries into three groups with different deadlines to reduce the use of factory-made hydrofluorocarbon (HFC) gases. Developed nations commit to reducing their use by 10% by 2019, while developing countries freeze their use by 2024 or 2028 and then gradually reduce it. The agreement marks a major milestone in combating climate change.

site_title: Iran foreign minister to join Syria talks in Switzerland
summary: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif will attend an international conference on the Syrian crisis in Lausanne, Switzerland, marking a change in Iran's stance. Russian and US Foreign Ministers Sergei Lavrov and John Kerry will also meet, along with representatives from Turkey, Saudi Arabia, and Qatar. The talks aim to resolve the five-year conflict that has claimed over 300,000 lives, but hopes for a breakthrough are low. Zarif's participation signals a shift in Iran's position on the crisis, which had previously stated it would not participate.

site_title: Modi, Putin set to sign energy deals ahead of Brics
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi are set to sign energy and defense deals ahead of the Brics summit in Goa, India. The agreements include Russia's delivery of its most advanced anti-aircraft defense system to India and a multi-billion-dollar deal in which Russia's Rosneft will acquire India's Essar Oil. The talks focus on strengthening energy ties and meeting India's growing demand for fuel and electricity, as well as discussing India's tensions with Pakistan. The Brics summit aims to deepen the partnership between the nations and challenge Western hegemony.

site_title: Inspired corporate giving, SME-style
summary: Milton Friedman's 1970 statement "the only social responsibility of business is to increase profits" is being reevaluated in Singapore. The concept of corporate social responsibility is gaining traction among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with some embracing the idea of using resources to benefit society. This shift is driven by changing consumer expectations and the need for businesses to demonstrate their commitment to social and environmental causes. As a result, some companies are adopting a more socially conscious approach, challenging Friedman's traditional view of business.

site_title: Gluten-free products going strong with US sales up 11%
summary: US gluten-free product sales reached $1.57 billion in 2016, up 11% from 2014. Despite only 1% of the US population having celiac disease, gluten-free products continue to be popular, outperforming the grocery sector's 3% growth. The category is driven by tie-ins with other health trends, such as paleo diets. This growth is a significant contrast to declining sales in other categories, such as cereal.

site_title: US sees no currency manipulation, adds Switzerland to watch list
summary: The US Treasury announced that none of the US' major trading partners is manipulating its currency to gain an unfair competitive advantage. This is in contrast to Donald Trump's threats to declare China a currency manipulator. Switzerland was added to the foreign exchange monitoring list, while China, Japan, Germany, South Korea, and Taiwan were kept on the list but did not meet the enhanced scrutiny standard under a new trade enforcement law. The report concluded that no major trading partner met the standard for manipulating exchange rates for unfair trade advantages.

site_title: German government tells lawmakers it would not take a stake in Deutsche Bank
summary: The German government has stated that it would not take a stake in Deutsche Bank if the bank were to issue new stock. This decision was made during a closed-door briefing with lawmakers, citing the need for a different bank resolution system than in 2009. The government officials emphasized that the state's involvement in Deutsche Bank's financial struggles is not feasible. The move comes as Deutsche Bank faces a US$14 billion settlement demand from the US Department of Justice related to mortgage securities mis-selling.

site_title: Trump accuses Mexico's Carlos Slim of trying to help Clinton
summary: US presidential nominee Donald Trump accused Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim of trying to help Hillary Clinton win the election through his connection to The New York Times, where Slim is a major shareholder. Trump claimed the Times is being used as a "corporate lobbyist" for Slim and foreign corporations to bankroll the publication of stories accusing him of unwanted advances. Trump also reiterated his claims that women who have accused him of misconduct are making up their stories.

site_title: Hollande to honour Nice attack victims three months on
summary: French President Francois Hollande will lead tributes to the 86 victims of the Nice Bastille Day truck massacre three months after the attack. The ceremony, originally planned for July 14, was postponed due to storms in the region. Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, a Tunisian extremist, drove the truck through a crowd of 30,000 people, killing 86 and injuring over 400. The Islamic State group claimed Bouhlel as one of its followers, with nearly a third of the victims being Muslims. The attack has raised tensions in French society, particularly among the Muslim community, and has sparked recriminations against the government's security response.

site_title: WikiLeaks releases Clinton speeches for Goldman Sachs
summary: WikiLeaks has released three of Hillary Clinton's paid Goldman Sachs speeches, highlighting her ties to Wall Street in the final stretch of the 2016 presidential election. The campaign did not contest the authenticity of the remarks, which were part of a hacked email trove from John Podesta. The US government and Clinton's campaign have blamed the hacks on the Russian government, while WikiLeaks claims to be helping Clinton's Republican rival, Donald Trump. The released speeches cast a spotlight on Clinton's Wall Street connections, sparking controversy in the final days of the election.

site_title: New York surgeons separate 13-month-old boys conjoined at head
summary: Surgeons at the Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Centre in New York successfully separated 13-month-old conjoined twins Jadon and Anias McDonald, who were joined at the head, in a rare 16-hour operation. The twins underwent skull reconstruction and are being closely monitored for brain swelling and stroke. Anias, who suffered a drop in heart rate and blood pressure, is expected to experience paralysis during recovery. The surgery was a high-risk procedure with a dismal success rate, and the twins' long-term health is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Surgeons at a New York City hospital on Friday separated a pair of 13-month-old boys who were congenitally joined at the head, completing a rare operation that carried a risk of death and severe brain damage, their mother said.

site_title: US senator asks Obama to replace top market regulator
summary: US Senator Elizabeth Warren is calling for President Barack Obama to replace SEC Chair Mary Jo White, citing her alleged obstruction of efforts to require companies to disclose political donations. Warren claims White has refused to develop a rule despite overwhelming public support, and has made it necessary for Obama to invoke his authority to name a new chair. The move comes as businesses have secretly funded candidates in the 2016 elections, sparking concerns about the influence of money in politics. Warren's letter demands a new SEC chair to address the issue.

site_title: Russia unveils first ever monument to Ivan the Terrible
summary: Russia has unveiled its first monument to Ivan the Terrible, a 16th-century tyrant known for his brutal rule, despite historians' protests. The bronze statue, erected in Oryol, was backed by the culture minister, who claims Ivan's rule was mythologized by Western travelers. Historians disagree, citing mass executions and a socioeconomic crisis under his rule. The monument's unveiling has sparked controversy, with locals and activists opposing the tribute to a ruler responsible for thousands of deaths and a civil war.

site_title: Need good questions for AGMs? SIAS has you covered
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has launched an initiative to provide free, carefully researched questions for shareholders to ask at upcoming annual general meetings (AGMs). The questions cover a range of issues and aim to improve the quality of engagement between management and shareholders. So far, SIAS has provided questions for 35 Singapore-listed companies, with more to follow, and hopes to raise the quality of shareholder meetings and give companies an opportunity to constructively engage with shareholders.

site_title: For European stocks, dividends found in telcos, insurers, oil
summary: European stocks with strong dividend yields are best found in telcos, insurers, and oil companies, according to Jorg de Vries-Hippen, an Allianz Global Investors fund manager. De Vries-Hippen cited these sectors due to their historical performance and stable cash flows. He recommended investing in European equity dividend funds focused on these sectors, offering a reliable source of income.

images.alt_text: The top five holdings in Mr de Vries-Hippen's fund at end-August were reinsurer Munich Re; Luxembourg-based satellite owner SES; Royal Dutch Shell; Swiss telco Sunrise Communications; and British telco Vodafone.

site_title: Julius Baer sells second Singdollar perpetual bond
summary: Julius Baer Group sold S$325 million in 5.75% perpetual Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bonds to cash-rich investors, marking the second Singdollar AT1 perpetual sold by the Swiss private bank. The bonds were oversubscribed, indicating strong demand from investors seeking to redeploy their funds. This sale follows Julius Baer's first Singdollar AT1 perpetual sold in 2015.

site_title: Big Mouth
summary: Morrissey, the iconic frontman of The Smiths, is set to return to Singapore after a 2012 sell-out gig, playing a solo concert at Marina Barrage on October 15. The 57-year-old singer-songwriter has released 49 singles and 12 solo top-10 albums, including three UK chart-toppers. Tickets are available through Sistic and at the door, if not sold out.

site_title: Pacific Andes flags Singapore debt restructuring hurdle
summary: Singapore faces challenges in becoming a global debt restructuring hub as a fish distributor, Pacific Andes Resources Development Ltd, has abandoned local court proceedings and filed for US bankruptcy protection. The company's decision highlights the limitations of Singapore's existing laws, which only offer a moratorium preventing creditors from enforcing claims within the city. The US bankruptcy process offers a worldwide moratorium, making it more appealing to companies. The Singapore government has acknowledged the need for an improved restructuring framework, with plans to propose legal amendments later this year.

site_title: Obama latest target in spate of heckling
summary: President Barack Obama has become the latest target in a wave of heckling by bounty-seeking agitators as the 2016 US election nears its end. Incivility has spilled into campaign events, including a protester in Cleveland declaring Bill Clinton a rapist, for which Infowars has offered a $5,000 reward. This marks a rise in aggressive behavior targeting Democrats, with Obama being the latest in a series of high-profile targets.

site_title: Mental health first, work second
summary: Mental health advocates are calling for a shift in priorities, with some companies and leaders already taking steps to address the issue. A Singapore-based social business founder, Laura Allen, revealed she struggled with suicidal thoughts due to burnout and a culture of secrecy surrounding mental health. Experts say genetics, environment, and job stress can contribute to mental health problems, which can be masked by high achievers. To combat this, businesses are being encouraged to provide mental health insurance, counseling services, and safe spaces for employees to discuss their struggles, with leaders setting an example by prioritizing their own mental well-being.

site_title: Bob Dylan: A complicated and complicating poet
summary: Bob Dylan has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature by the Swedish Academy, recognizing him as one of the most authentic voices America has produced. His work, akin to that of Walt Whitman and Emily Dickinson, is described as audacious and resonant. The award acknowledges Dylan's unique ability to create powerful images through his poetry and songwriting, solidifying his place among the country's most iconic literary figures.

site_title: Mazda picks Singapore firm as its Indonesia importer
summary: Mazda Motor Corp has appointed Eurokars Group as its importer for cars in Indonesia, following the firm's success in Singapore. Eurokars' boss impressed Mazda with his performance in Singapore, leading to the Indonesian partnership. This move aims to replicate the success achieved in Singapore.

images.alt_text: "Since I am originally from Indonesia, I have good market knowledge of the automotive business there," says Mr Kwee. "Together with Eurokars' extensive distribution network and infrastructure, Mazda hopes to achieve a milestone in Indonesia under my leadership."

site_title: Two ultra high net worth investors buy more property in S'pore
summary: Two ultra-high net worth investors, a Hongkonger and a Spanish tycoon, have expanded their presence in Singapore's luxury property market. A Hongkonger, Naina Buxani, purchased a S$21.2 million penthouse at Nassim Park Residences, while Spanish tycoon Ricardo Peralta bought a three-storey shophouse along Boon Tat Street for S$19 million and two adjoining shophouses along Amoy Street for S$9.9 million. Both investors are attracted to Singapore's shophouse market due to its 999-year leasehold tenure and potential for rental income.

site_title: Blackstone, GIC said to be shortlisted for DLF's assets in India
summary: Blackstone Group LP and Singapore sovereign fund GIC Pte have been shortlisted to purchase a 40% stake in DLF Cyber City Developers Ltd, India's largest listed developer. The stake could fetch over 100 billion rupees (S$2.07 billion) and will be used to retire debt, resulting in the owners' stake climbing to 80.2% from 74.9%. The sale is described by DLF as a "game changer" and is expected to bring in a cash inflow of between 71 billion rupees and 76 billion rupees after tax.

site_title: Swedish housing market fights off tighter rules amid rally
summary: The Swedish housing market experienced a significant rally in September, with apartment prices jumping 3% and house prices rising 1%. The regulator's amortisation requirement, introduced in June, appears to have had a limited impact in cooling the market. Consumer confidence rose to the highest in over a year, and households expect home values to increase. Experts attribute the market's resilience to a combination of factors, including limited supply and rising optimism among households, but warn that further measures, such as a loan-to-income cap, may be needed to prevent unsustainable debt growth.

site_title: Shoppers spending more, pushing Sept retail sales growth to three-month high
summary: US retail sales rose 0.6% in September, the largest gain in three months, driven by shoppers spending freely after a slow quarter. Core sales rose 0.1%, and wholesale prices increased 0.3%, driven by higher energy and food costs. The solid job growth and modest wage increase are expected to continue pushing consumer spending up over the next year, with inflation potentially picking up.

site_title: UN voices concern ahead of envoy's visit to Burundi
summary: The UN Security Council expressed deep concern over Burundi's refusal to allow the deployment of a UN police force, amid escalating tensions following a report blaming state police for violence. The UN envoy Jamal Benomar will visit Bujumbura for crisis talks, with the council hoping the dispute can be resolved. Burundi has broken off ties with the UN rights office and voted to pull out of the International Criminal Court, and the UN resolution on deploying 228 police officers remains deadlocked. The UN rights report warned of a "risk of genocide" in Burundi.

site_title: Spotify's Ek becomes chairman as co-founder steps down
summary: Spotify co-founder Daniel Ek is taking on the role of chairman, consolidating power ahead of a planned initial public offering. Martin Lorentzon, another co-founder, is stepping down as chairman after 10 years, becoming vice chairman. Ek aims to maintain tight control over the company, a strategy similar to other tech industry founders like Mark Zuckerberg. The move comes as Spotify prepares to face public-market investors and rivals like Apple and Amazon, and is currently in critical negotiations with record companies to determine profitability. Spotify surpassed 40 million paying customers and generated over $2 billion in revenue last year.

images.alt_text: Spotify co-founder and chief executive officer Daniel Ek is consolidating power over the world's largest music streaming service, taking on the role of chairman ahead of a planned initial public offering as soon as next year.

site_title: Samsung Note 7 phones said to be banned on US airline flights
summary: The US government has banned Samsung Note 7 smartphones from airline flights due to safety concerns over overheating and fires. The devices, sold in the US, are restricted from being carried on planes, even if they're shut off. This expansion of restrictions comes after Samsung halted production and sales of the device following recent incidents. The crisis is estimated to cost Samsung $5.3 billion in profits, with over 1.9 million Note 7s affected in the US.

images.alt_text: All Samsung Electronics Co Note 7 smartphones will be banned from airline flights by the US government, according to a person familiar with the decision that will be a significant expansion of restrictions on the devices linked to almost 100 incidents of overheating and fires.

site_title: SIA to take delivery of 18 Airbus planes in the next year and a half
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is set to receive 18 new Airbus A350 planes over the next year and a half, with the first delivery expected in October. The fuel-efficient aircraft will enable SIA to add capacity to its long-haul network and resume direct flights to the US, including San Francisco. SIA has ordered a total of 67 A350s, with 50 to be delivered this year. The airline's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, emphasized the importance of the A350 to its operations, citing positive customer feedback. SIA also plans to operate A350 Ultra Long Range variant flights to New York and Los Angeles from 2018.

site_title: Market-timing can work, but it mucks things up
summary: Market-timing, a strategy of shifting assets in response to market shifts, can work but carries significant risk. The greater the potential reward, the higher the risk. This approach involves buying high and selling low, but timing is crucial. Historically, attempts to time the market have been unsuccessful, with the author noting they were "seven years too late" after the 2007 financial crisis. Market timing can lead to significant losses, as seen in the crash of 2007 and the missed boom of 2011. A cautious approach is recommended to mitigate risk.

site_title: Pennies in play as STI drops 2.1% this week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 2.1% this week to 2,815.24, amid US earnings concerns and the release of the September US Federal Open Market Committee meeting minutes, which suggested a December interest rate hike. Trading volume picked up on Wednesday and Friday, with Noble Group and Spackman Group rebounding after being heavily shorted. The week's weakness was attributed to the inconclusive US presidential debate, with markets looking to external factors for inspiration.

site_title: (No headline) - A-O14
summary: A low-profile property trust is investing in a data centre, a move seen as a strategic gamble in the industry. US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fell, indicating a possible improvement in the labor market. China has urged Southeast Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs, while Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Meanwhile, Reliance Jio's India IPO has been delayed beyond this year, and China has unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: 2 local banks among Marco Polo noteholders giving the nod for revamp
summary: Marco Polo Marine has received approval from noteholders to restructure its S$50 million medium-term notes (MTN) maturing this month. The restructuring proposal, which includes extending the redemption date to 2019 and offering an additional 1.5% interest per annum, received 97.18% of votes from noteholders. Two local banks, DBS and UOB, are among the noteholders supporting the proposal. The company has also committed to paying an additional interest and extending a mortgage over its land in Batam as collateral to noteholders.

site_title: Frequent Buyers
summary: Savvy foodies in Singapore prioritize quality and affordability over exotic souvenirs, opting for fresher and cheaper ingredients when frequent travel allows. They source items like seasonal fruit, bonito flakes, and wagyu beef from local wholesalers, rather than duty-free shops. These individuals, such as Grace Yip, a COO of a local bank, carefully pack their purchases to ensure they arrive fresh, with items like A3 wagyu strip loin and peaches from Tokyo. This approach allows them to enjoy gourmet goodies without breaking the bank.

site_title: Job Bags
summary: This article is not about job bags, but rather a collection of unrelated articles about various topics, including fashion, lifestyle, and social causes. The articles appear to be from a news website and cover a range of subjects, including mod-Indian cuisine, volunteer engagement, zero-waste initiatives, financial literacy, and design solutions for unusual home layouts.

site_title: My favourite movie
summary: A 1981 film critic praises "An American Werewolf in London" as a "groundbreaking cinema" with a great mix of horror, humor, and special effects. Anthony Chiam, co-founder of SCUM, notes that such films are rare today.

site_title: Why bad news is bad, or not
summary: Singapore's economy performed worse than expected in Q3, expanding just 0.6% compared to the previous year, while the unemployment rate rose to 2.1% in June. Despite this, researchers suggest that negativity bias may be driving the focus on bad news, as people are primed to avoid danger and may overestimate the current state of the world. However, there have been numerous bright spots in the country, including Olympic and Paralympic wins, Oscar and award-winning productions, and notable achievements in various fields, highlighting the need to redefine what constitutes "good news" in Singapore.

site_title: Korean fever fires up Spackman stock
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group's stock surged 17% in Singapore, driven by a "buy" rating from RHB Research, which predicts a strong turnaround due to the upcoming release of blockbuster film "Master", potential sale of its stake in Korea's largest entertainment talent agency, and divestment of a loss-making asset. The stock could benefit from a buyback or special dividend, and the research house expects Spackman to return to profitability by the end of FY16 and improve further in FY17.

site_title: Weak sentiment persists, but SMEs still expecting to keep headcount: SCCCI report
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) continue to struggle with weak market conditions and global economic headwinds, but remain optimistic about keeping their workforce intact. 85.4% of SMEs expect to add staff or remain the same in 2016, up from 83.7% last year. The biggest challenges faced by SMEs are rising business costs and stiff competition in the Singapore market, but their impact has decreased compared to 2015. The government is urged to make rules and regulations less rigid to facilitate SMEs' business operations and adopt a business-focused mindset.

images.alt_text: Business sentiment among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore remains weak, as they continue to struggle against global economic headwinds and weak market conditions.

site_title: Dispiriting Q3 stupefies market, underscores need for reforms
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 0.6% year-on-year in Q3, the slowest pace since the 2008/2009 global financial crisis, with manufacturing and services sectors experiencing sequential contractions of 17.4% and 1.9% respectively. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) left monetary policy unchanged, warning of a "step-down" in growth in the second half of 2016. Private-sector economists urge the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) to propose structural reforms to address the economy's stagnation, with some predicting a technical recession if the CFE's recommendations are inadequate.

site_title: Mother Care
summary: In post-war Singapore, women played a crucial role in daily life, shopping at wet markets with baskets and cooking simple meals for their families. With limited refrigeration and domestic helpers, they were the backbone of the nation. As Singapore transitioned, women continued to care for their children and contribute to the country's growth, shaping its future.

site_title: S'pore retail sales down in August
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined in August, with a 6.5% year-on-year drop in the index excluding cars. The decline was driven by decreases in computer and telecommunications equipment, watches and jewelry, and clothes and shoes. Even including motor vehicle sales, which rose 30.4%, the overall retail sales index fell 1% from the previous year. Food and beverage sales also dropped 2.5% from August 2015, with restaurants experiencing an 8.8% decline.

site_title: China's prices at factory gates rise for first time in 4 1/2 years
summary: China's producer prices rose 0.1% in September, the first increase in 4.5 years, driven by rising commodity prices such as coal and steel. The move follows steady rises in the last few months, fueled by government stimulus and demand for commodities. Economists expect further price recovery, but warn of vulnerabilities in the Chinese economy, including high corporate and local government debt levels. The data suggests a gradual easing of deflation pressures, but the economy's growth is still uncertain, with exports falling 10% in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: Inflation in China picked up last month with prices at factory gates (also called the producers' price index or PPI) rising for the first time in 4 1/2 years.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Amateur Championship to be at Sentosa Golf Club in 2018
summary: The 2018 Asia-Pacific Amateur Championship will be held at Sentosa Golf Club in Singapore, with the Serapong course ranked 58th in the Golf Digest ranking of the World's 100 Greatest Golf Courses. This marks the first time the event returns to Singapore since 2011. The championship will take place from October 4-7, 2018, and will be hosted by Sentosa Golf Club's The New Tanjong Course. Organizers are excited to host the 10th edition of the event, which aims to promote amateur golf and provide life-changing opportunities for young players from the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: (From left) Andy Johnston, general manager & director of agronomy, Sentosa Golf Club; Mr Low, president, Sentosa Golf Club; David Cherry, Billy Payne and Martin Slumbers, all from Augusta National Golf Club; Mr Tan, president and Kong Choong Soon, vice-president, Singapore Golf Association.

site_title: Nothing short of magical
summary: Disney's MagicBand is a wearable device that allows users to unlock doors, enter theme parks, and make purchases using a simple tap of the wrist. It also links to the Disney World app, enabling users to plan ahead, track wait times, and access exclusive experiences. The MagicBand features fingerprint scanning, Apple Pay, and personalized touches, such as customized designs and special messages. The device has the potential to inspire innovations in mobile wallets and wearable technology, with the theme park serving as a testing ground for its real-world applications.

site_title: Thai stocks, baht jump on optimism over royal transition
summary: Thai stocks surged 4.6% to close at 1,477.61, while the baht rose 0.9% to 35.30 a dollar, following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej. The strong market performance is attributed to optimism over a smooth transition, with volatility expected. The SET Index has jumped the most since 2013, indicating a positive response to the royal succession.

site_title: When prawns get naked
summary: A question about the terminology for prawns without shells has sparked debate in Singapore. Restaurants often use the term "deshelled" to describe prawns, crabs, and lobsters without shells, but the Oxford English Dictionary does not have an entry for "deshell." The term's usage may be more of a marketing ploy than a widely accepted culinary term, leaving consumers to wonder if it's a legitimate description.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Chef-owner Andrew Walsh launches new lunch sets at his restaurants, including CURE, COO BISTRO, and LOOF, with prices starting from $38. The new menu features 'glocal' dishes such as fettuccine prawn noodles and B.C.M. (bak chor mee) Grilled Cheese, created by local chefs Bjorn Shen. The restaurants offer a range of unique and locally-inspired food options, catering to customers looking for a new dining experience.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: US and Singapore Reits outperformed their respective benchmark indices during the last rate-hike cycle, with Hong Kong and US Reits outperforming since 2010. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Gone Native
summary: Chef Ryohei Hieda's Shoun Ryugin in Taiwan offers a unique culinary experience, showcasing native ingredients and seasonal Japanese products. The menu features dishes such as corn mash, dried tomato jelly, Taiwanese eel, duck, rosy seabass, crab, grouper, and lobster. This sister restaurant of chef Seiji Yamamoto's three-starred RyuGin in Tokyo and two-starred Tenku RyuGin in Hong Kong, provides a distinctive taste of Taiwanese cuisine with a Japanese twist.

site_title: SPH's FY16 net profit down 17.5% to S$265.3m
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 17.5% decline in FY16 net profit to S$265.3 million due to revenue decline and impairment losses from its magazine segment. The company's operating revenue decreased 4.5% to S$1.12 billion, and net profit per share was slightly higher than expected. SPH is undergoing a comprehensive review of its media business, including a push into digital space, but some plans require regulatory approval. The company declared a dividend of 18 Singapore cents per share, down from FY2015.

site_title: Asian infrastructure bill continues to grow, says ADB president
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) president has announced that Asia will require more than the initial estimated US$8 trillion in infrastructure spending by 2020, citing the need for an upward revision to the figure. This revised estimate is expected to be released soon, reflecting the growing infrastructure needs in the region.

images.alt_text: Referring to the number of multilateral development banks in play, Mr Nakao dismisses the notion that Asia is "over-banked", saying that the sums needed to build infrastructure are astronomical.

site_title: A Life Abroad
summary: Singaporean expats abroad often experience a mix of challenges and benefits. Nikheel Advani, a hotelier, travels extensively for work and enjoys his life in the Caribbean and Singapore, where he appreciates the contrast and laid-back atmosphere. Ellen Chew, a restaurateur, overcame initial difficulties in London and now loves the city, finding a sense of belonging and acceptance. Peter Kok, a civil engineer, misses Singapore but has found a warm expat community in Dubai, where he enjoys the city's unique culture and lifestyle. Jason Lee, an art collector and curator, appreciates the finer things in life and has curated a unique collection in London. Despite the challenges of living abroad, these expats have found ways to thrive and make the most of their experiences.

images.alt_text: Jason Lee, Art Collector, London. - PHOTOGRAPHY JASON BY AL OVERDRIVE
Jason Lee at his London home with a prized artwork by Zhang Ding. - PHOTOGRAPHY JASON BY AL OVERDRIVE
