The world has become increasingly unstable, with major challenges including the collapse of order in the Middle East, rising tensions with Russia and China, and a potential military conflict between the two nuclear powers. The US is also struggling to articulate a comprehensive strategy in dealing with China's growing military and economic power, and the recent moves by the Philippines to reduce its dependency on the US have raised concerns.

site_title: Surprising S90
summary: The Volvo S90, a mid-size sedan, has been unveiled, replacing the S80. It boasts a luxurious interior, sporty stance, and a two-litre twin-charged engine producing 320 hp. The S90's handling is surprisingly fun, thanks to its adaptive suspension and all-wheel-drive capability. Standard safety features include semi-autonomous drive, adaptive cruise control, and collision avoidance systems. With a starting price of $239,000, the S90 is a premium offering, emphasizing comfort and performance.

site_title: Surbana Jurong buys security firm from Temasek
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based urban development consultancy, acquired 100% of Aetos Holdings, a licensed auxiliary police organization, from Temasek Holdings for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition aims to integrate security and safety management into Surbana Jurong's facilities management services. With the addition of Aetos' 2,900 employees, Surbana Jurong will have a total of 13,000 employees worldwide and a combined annual revenue of around S$1.3 billion. The acquisition will enable Surbana Jurong to offer enhanced surveillance and security services, including CCTV systems, biometrics, and unmanned aerial vehicles.

site_title: Singapore users putting businesses at risk of cyberattacks
summary: The Singapore government plans to cut public servants off from the internet in May 2017 to tighten security, affecting 100,000 computers. A recent survey found that employees in Singapore use personal devices to access work emails, often without implementing basic security measures, exposing company systems to cyber threats. The survey revealed that 76% of respondents use personal devices, with only 57% taking additional security measures. Many employees also download unverified apps and connect to unknown Wi-Fi networks, increasing the risk of cyberattacks.

site_title: Japan's swashbuckling baristas making coffee 'sexy'
summary: Japan's baristas are elevating coffee to a luxurious experience, with many establishments offering unique and visually appealing drinks. The country's top baristas, such as Miki Suzuki and Takayuki Ishitani, are winning international recognition, with Suzuki set to compete in the World Barista Championship next year. Japan's coffee culture has become increasingly popular, with hipster cafes popping up across the country and coffee sales outstripping those of green tea. The focus on craftsmanship and attention to detail has made coffee-making a highly respected art form in Japan.

site_title: Manhattan apartment rents decline amid 35% surge in listings
summary: Manhattan apartment rents decreased by 1.2% to $3,396 in October, the second year-over-year decline since 2014. A surge in new listings and tenants shopping for better deals have reduced landlords' pricing power. The number of available listings rose 35% to 7,392, with landlords offering discounts averaging 2.8% to secure deals. Newly signed leases jumped 51% as tenants seek better deals, and sweeteners such as free rent were included in 15% of new leases. The market appears to be slowing, with no signs of an upward trend.

site_title: Rising claims point to premium hikes
summary: A study by the Life Insurance Association Singapore found that rising claims have drastically squeezed underwriting profit margins for Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) in Singapore, putting their long-term sustainability at risk. Insurers are expected to raise premiums to offset the increase in claims, which have risen from 46% in 2009 to 69% in 2013. The study suggests that benefit design and ward entitlements influence policyholder behavior, and that policyholders with IPs and IP riders tend to have higher claims incidence rates and visit private medical providers. Insurers are warning that it's unsustainable to continue writing these products, and that the insured public will eventually be most negatively impacted.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare faces delays to IPO after complaints
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Corp, a medical service provider, is facing delays to its initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore after regulators received complaints. The company had targeted to price the offering at S$1.52 a share to raise S$213 million, but delays have been caused by questions from regulators about its business. Fullerton Healthcare still hopes to complete the IPO, but no new timeline has been set.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping's Asia-US ops may go on sale on Friday
summary: Hanjin Shipping's Asia-US operations may go on sale as early as Friday, following the company's court-approved receivership process. The shipping line had total debt of 6.03 trillion won and its container ship capacity had shrunk to 17th place globally. The sale of assets, including five container ships and logistics systems, is expected to be completed by Nov 7, with creditors lining up claims. The move comes as the global shipping industry faces overcapacity and low freight rates.

site_title: Gallant working on back-up plan to redeem 2017 bonds
summary: Gallant Venture, a Singapore-listed vehicle distributor and developer, is working on a back-up plan to redeem its 2017 bonds maturing next year amid market concerns following Swiber Holdings' collapse. The company's CFO, Alvin Choo, is negotiating for standby banking facilities and expects to sign off on them by the end of the year. A Chinese buyer of Gallant's Shanghai property has agreed to remit a lump sum of S$260 million by the end of the year, but the company's bonds are currently trading at a low price, with buyers only willing to pay 95 to 96 cents to the dollar.

site_title: A Gallant concern
summary: Gallant Venture, an Indonesian play listed on the mainboard, is experiencing financial difficulties. The company's high debt levels and weak cash flow are expected to persist into 2017, despite its bonds trading at yields of 13-16%. This indicates distress in the market. The vehicle distributor and Batam-Bintan developer is facing intense competition in its core business, and a rate hike environment further exacerbates its cash flow problems.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Analysts from CIMB Research, Maybank Kim Eng Research, and OCBC Investment Research have upgraded or maintained their "buy" ratings for Innovalues Ltd, Sarine Technologies, and Soilbuild Reit. CIMB Research predicts 10-12% sales growth for Innovalues, while Maybank Kim Eng Research expects $4-6 million in net profit for Sarine. OCBC Investment Research lowered its distribution per unit forecasts for Soilbuild Reit due to lower occupancy rates but maintains a "buy" rating. The analysts also suggest a potential catalyst for Innovalues' growth through ongoing merger and acquisition discussions.

site_title: Pertamina consortium leads in race for Jawa 1 gas-to-power project
summary: A Pertamina-led consortium is leading in the tender for PLN's $1-2 billion Jawa 1 gas-to-power project in Indonesia, with a floating, regasification, storage and offloading unit and a 1,600 MW gas turbine, combined cycle power plant. The consortium needs to justify the large price differential and secure project financing before the award can be finalized, expected to be made by late-October. The project is crucial for Indonesia's 35 GW nation-wide electrification programme, and the award is seen as a key indicator of the country's energy development plans.

site_title: And they danced their hearts out
summary: Jerome Bel's Theatreworks-commissioned GALA, a dance performance featuring ordinary people, showcased their unique movements to music of their choice. The 20 performers, untrained in a specific dance style, brought their individuality to the stage, creating a witty performance under Bel's choreography. This unconventional dance, which blended solos, group performances, and solo choreography, highlighted the beauty of self-expression through movement.

site_title: Thai unifying figure leaves lasting legacy
summary: King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand, who ruled for over 70 years, died at 88 on Thursday in Bangkok. He was a unifying figure in a polarized country and played a significant role in Thailand's transition from an agricultural economy to a modern one of industry and commerce. His death has cast uncertainty across Thailand, but his legacy as a revered personification of Thai nationhood will endure.

site_title: Late bounce limits STI's loss to 8 points
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a weak day on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 2,805.48, down 8.23 points. Despite a 100-point loss in Dow futures, the market was supported by a strong close on Wednesday. Noble Group fell for the third straight day, while South Korean movie producer Spackman rose after a "buy" recommendation from RHB. The US Federal Reserve released minutes of its September meeting, indicating some members anticipate an interest rate hike "relatively soon".

site_title: Perisai's insolvency adds to gloom for M'sian oil & gas stocks
summary: Malaysia's Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Bhd declared insolvency on Wednesday after failing to meet bond obligations, triggering a 7% decline in the company's stock price. The move has led to concerns about the health of Malaysian oil and gas stocks, with many finishing in the red. Perisai has 12 months to regularize its position or face delisting. The company's insolvency adds to market concerns about the sector's stability.

site_title: The Spanish alternative
summary: The Seat Alhambra, a Spanish seven-seat MPV, is a Volkswagen Sharan clone manufactured in Portugal. It features a 2.0-litre turbodiesel engine paired with a dual clutch transmission, offering good low-end torque and a smooth ride. The Alhambra boasts standard features such as rear air conditioning, a driver's massage seat, and an integrated child booster seat. Priced from $165,500, it's available through distributor Vertex Euro Motors, with an estimated average OMV of $35,000.

site_title: ING said to move jobs to UK in contrary post-Brexit decision
summary: ING Groep NV plans to move 60 trading jobs from Amsterdam and Brussels to London, as part of a cost-cutting effort to consolidate operations. The company will also shut its equity derivatives business for financial institutions in New York, Singapore, and Brussels. The moves contradict a post-Brexit decision to maintain a significant presence in the EU. The plans were made confidentially, but the company aims to reduce costs and enhance operational efficiency.

site_title: Poor China trade numbers halt US dollar rally
summary: China's poor trade numbers halted the US dollar's rally, with the yuan fixed at a six-year low of 6.7255 yuan per US dollar. The offshore yuan traded 0.2% weaker, while Chinese exports fell 5.6% in yuan terms and 10% in US dollars. This data is expected to weigh on US treasury yields, and the US dollar dropped to 103.94 yen. Market discussions focus on the next round of central bank policy meetings, with the European Central Bank potentially discussing changes to its asset-buying scheme.

site_title: The young guns of local chinese cuisine
summary: Singapore's local Chinese cuisine faces a succession crisis due to negative connotations and the curbing of foreign talents. Young chefs, often from Malaysia, are drawn to the profession due to the willingness to endure hard work. The Society of Chinese Cuisine Chefs (Singapore) organizes events like the recent Youth Culinary Competition to raise the visibility of Chinese cuisine and attract young talents. This year's competition saw four winners, including Chef Teoh Yong Hui, who won the gold award for his traditional Chinese dish. The competition aims to promote the creativity and skills of young chefs and encourage them to develop their own unique interpretations of Chinese cooking.

site_title: Keen demand for SIA direct service to San Francisco
summary: Singapore Airlines' direct service to San Francisco is set to relaunch on October 23, following strong demand ahead of its non-stop flight to the US. The airline's senior vice-president said the uptake has been "very strong" for the non-stop option, which will benefit business travelers and those looking to connect beyond San Francisco. The new service will be the sixth direct flight to San Francisco, operated by the 253-seater Airbus A350-900, and will complement an existing daily flight via Hong Kong.

site_title: Afghanistan at critical economic, political crossroads
summary: Afghanistan stands at a critical economic and political crossroads 15 years after the US-led invasion in 2001. Despite over £100 billion in foreign aid, reconstruction has been slow, and unemployment remains above 40%. The economy has not diversified enough, and corruption is widespread. The internal security situation is precarious, with 23,000 conflict-related deaths and 41,000 injuries recorded by the UN since 2009. The Afghan government is seeking to advance reconciliation and peace talks with the Taliban, which could be key in facilitating a deal. The country's fragile gains, including a fledgling democracy and economic links with the outside world, are at risk of being undermined if the reconciliation process fails.

site_title: JES International says not notified of updates to proposed restructuring of China units
summary: JES International Holdings stated it has not been informed of updates to the proposed restructuring of its China units since a September 20 public notice. The company is exploring new business opportunities and considers a "very substantial" acquisition or reverse takeover. JES International filed an originating summons in the Singapore high court to transfer 60.8 million shares to its controlling shareholder. The company has not received further updates on this matter.

site_title: How Singapore business leaders can succeed in a fast-changing world: study
summary: A study by the Human Capital Leadership Institute suggests that Singapore business leaders lack a global mindset, preferring a structured and fact-based approach that may not be effective in a fast-changing global market. To succeed, Singapore's emerging business leaders should live and work overseas, gaining diverse perspectives and experiences. The study highlights the need for global managers to lead the way for local enterprises venturing overseas, and for business leaders to develop charisma, executive presence, and mental flexibility to navigate a VUCA world.

images.alt_text: Singapore business leaders may have a global outlook but they lack the global mindset - one that's truly inclusive of multiple, diverse perspectives - to take on the world, says a study by the government-backed Human Capital Leadership Institute.

site_title: Down Chinatown's memory lane
summary: Young Singapore artists are reimagining Chinatown through their works in the Pop-up Noise: Soul Searching event. 31 artists, aged 35 and below, are creating experimental, site-specific pieces that explore history and memory. The event, sponsored by the National Arts Council, features 19 new works and showcases the community's experiences of old Chinatown, which has witnessed Singapore's rapid transformation. The artists interacted with residents, uncovering historical facts and observing sights, sounds, and smells of the area, aiming to revive past experiences in a space of rapid progress.

site_title: Samsung's woes highlight explosive limits of lithium batteries
summary: Samsung Electronics scrapped its flagship Note 7 smartphone after weeks of reports of phones igniting and burning, citing a rare manufacturing process error. Experts warn that the explosive limits of lithium-ion batteries are being pushed by consumer demand for smaller, longer-lasting devices. The US Consumer Product Safety Commission has issued recalls for lithium-ion battery-related products in the past year, and Boeing was forced to ground its 787 jetliners after some lithium-ion batteries caught fire. Manufacturers are struggling to balance energy density and safety, with prices falling and safety mechanisms adding to production costs.

site_title: Tee International bags deals worth S$48m
summary: Singapore engineering group Tee International has secured S$48 million in new contracts, including a S$33 million deal from Changi Airport Group to develop a three-runway system. The contract involves engineering works, airfield lighting systems, and collaboration with main contractor Hock Lian Seng Infrastructure and Sembcorp Design and Construction. Tee International's unfulfilled order book now stands at S$372, with four ongoing projects at Changi Airport.

site_title: King Bhumibol dies, aged 88
summary: Thailand's King Bhumibol Adulyadej, the world's longest-reigning monarch, has died at 88. He passed away on October 13, 2016, at Bangkok's Siriraj Hospital after being ill since 2014. The government has declared a year of mourning and toned down entertainment functions for 30 days.

site_title: To suit every man
summary: Tom Ford's bespoke clothing brand offers made-to-measure suits tailored in Europe, crafted over 19 hours in 150 steps. Each suit takes 6-8 weeks to make and costs a starting S$6,000. The brand uses high-quality materials, including wool, wool-silk, and wool-cashmere blends. To ensure a creaseless quality, the suits have a canvas structure and five interior pockets. A second fitting is required after the initial fitting, which takes less than a week, to make any minor adjustments. The overall cost varies depending on fabric and details.

images.alt_text: Tom Ford flies in a made-to-measure specialist to Singapore from Italy three times a year; and a two-piece suit starts at S$6,000, while a shirt will cost upwards of S$1,200.

site_title: May's Brexit plan 'unconstitutional power grab'
summary: Theresa May's plan to trigger Brexit without a parliamentary vote has been criticized as an unconstitutional power grab by lawyers. David Pannick, representing an investment manager, claims the move tramples on centuries of legal precedent. The decision to trigger Article 50 and negotiations to leave the EU without a vote is seen as a reckless political move, prompting calls for parliamentary oversight of Brexit.

site_title: Singapore and Australia to launch upgraded FTA
summary: Singapore and Australia have completed the third review of their bilateral free-trade agreement (FTA), upgrading the pact to boost economic ties. The upgraded FTA, expected to enter into force next year, aims to reduce regulatory barriers and enhance access to government procurement markets. The agreement also includes new commitments in defence, scientific research, and combating trans-national drug crime, with the two countries committing to match monetary contributions of S$50 million to fund various projects.

site_title: Russia: America's new bogeyman?
summary: The US has been searching for a new global threat to replace the Soviet Union since the 1990s, and now Russia appears to be filling that role. However, Russian President Vladimir Putin is a nationalist leader focused on advancing his country's interests, rather than seeking global dominance. Despite the US accusing Russia of interference in the 2016 presidential election and supporting authoritarian leaders, Russia is not seeking to export its values globally. Instead, the US's aggressive campaign to target Russia as a new global threat could prove to be a self-fulfilling prophecy, potentially escalating tensions and leading to military action.

site_title: S'pore queries indicators in 2016 Global Innovation Index
summary: Singapore questioned the 2016 Global Innovation Index's handling of certain indicators, which showed a lopsided picture of its level of innovation. Despite ranking No 1 in "innovation inputs," it ranked No 20 in "innovation outputs." Experts suggested that Singapore's low innovation efficiency ratio of 0.6, placing it 78th globally, may indicate inefficiency in innovation. The discussion around the findings comes at a turning point in Singapore's RIE journey, with a $19 billion RIE 2020 Plan announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

images.alt_text: Singapore has questioned the handling of certain indicators in the 2016 Global Innovation Index (GII), which appear to present a lopsided picture of its level of innovation.

site_title: EU lawmakers in committee adopt report on carbon market reform
summary: EU lawmakers in the industry committee voted 45-13 in favor of a proposed compromise on carbon market reform, aiming to tighten the amount of carbon permits to align with the EU's ambitious climate goals under the Paris Agreement. The reform seeks to protect European businesses while addressing the surplus of carbon credits following the economic crisis.

site_title: A mini-Japan in Napa
summary: The article describes a visit to the Kenzo Estate in Napa Valley, California, owned by Kenzo Tsujimoto, founder of Capcom. The estate, which spans 4,000 acres, is meticulously planned and maintained in a precise Japanese style. The winery produces Bordeaux-style wines, including Asatsuyu (Sauvignon Blanc), Rindo (Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Petit Verdot, and Malbec), Murasaki (Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, and Petit Verdot), and Muku (Sauvignon Blanc and Semillon). The wines are described as well-made and showing good ageing potential, with a notable absence of prominent oak flavors. The article concludes that the Kenzo Estate is a notable addition to Napa Valley's wine scene, offering a unique and impressive display of wine production.

site_title: Singapore ultra-rich families can learn from Swiss and Germans: UBS Wealth
summary: Singapore's ultra-rich families can learn from Swiss and German families in preserving wealth across generations. According to UBS Wealth Management, the key factor is being results-oriented and having a strict approach to ownership. The combined wealth of billionaires in Singapore accounts for 80% of global wealth, with 42% being multi-generational families. In the next 20 years, 460 billionaires will transfer $2.1 trillion to the next generation, equivalent to India's GDP. The transfer of wealth will impact investment choices and risks, highlighting the importance of family management and ownership structure.

site_title: US import prices increase on gains in petroleum, food costs
summary: US import prices rose 0.1% in September, reversing a 0.2% decline in August, as petroleum and food costs increased. The 12-month decline in import prices was the smallest since August 2014, indicating import deflation may be easing. A strong dollar had previously held inflation below the Federal Reserve's 2% target, but the fading dollar rally and stabilizing oil prices may allow inflation to rise toward its target.

site_title: Buying a condo? Make a trip to the virtual reality showsuite
summary: Keppel Land is launching 30-40 new units of Highline Residences in Singapore, with a virtual reality showsuite available for visitors starting this weekend. The VR showsuite, created in collaboration with VMW Group, allows buyers to experience the units' layouts and finishes in 360-degree immersion. This is the first time Keppel Land has used VR technology for its showsuite, which costs less to build and can be completed quickly, but will not replace physical show units entirely. The units start from S$1.55 million for three-bedroom units and S$2.23 million for four-bedroom units.

site_title: India central bank chief warns of risks from Brexit, US elections
summary: India's Reserve Bank Governor Urjit Patel warned of potential risks from global events, including Brexit and the US presidential elections, which could impact BRICS countries' economies. Patel urged the countries to strengthen their domestic economies and make themselves attractive investment destinations. India has already made progress in improving its defenses, including price stability and fiscal rectitude. Patel also highlighted the need for public investments in skills development, citing the "Make in India" initiative to boost manufacturing.

site_title: Of cars and capsules
summary: Maserati and Bentley have unveiled their latest capsule collections, featuring luxury leather items such as bags, jackets, and accessories. The Maserati collection, in collaboration with Ermenegildo Zegna, showcases the brands' craftsmanship with discreet trident badges. The collections will be available at select Ermenegildo Zegna stores and online from next month. The Bentley collection, inspired by the Continental GT model, can be ordered through the Wearnes showroom. Both collections also feature non-leather clothing and accessories.

site_title: Consumer comfort improves after hovering near this year's low
summary: Consumer sentiment improved last week, rising to a four-week high of 42.1 in the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index, after hovering near the lowest level of the year. The index improved in views of personal finances, the economy, and buying climate, with increases to 54.5, 32.8, and 38.9, respectively. This uptick suggests a positive shift in consumer confidence, potentially indicating a more favorable outlook for the economy.

site_title: Snapchat said to have picked bankers for IPO
summary: Snapchat, the messaging service popular among teenagers, is preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) as its parent company, Snap Inc, has hired investment banks Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs. This could mark a wave of huge tech IPOs, including Uber and Airbnb, and help end a drought of tech IPOs. Snap has generated $367 million in ad revenue this year and is expected to reach $1 billion next year, but must demonstrate its path to profitability to investors. The IPO could be one of the most anticipated tech market debuts since Twitter's 2013 IPO.

site_title: Task force urges steps to rein in costs amid escalation of claims
summary: The Health Insurance Task Force (HITF) in Singapore has issued recommendations to rein in rising claims rates of Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), which could lead to steep premium hikes. The task force proposes introducing medical fee guidelines, a panel of "preferred healthcare providers," and pre-authorization of medical treatment to improve transparency and control costs. The Ministry of Health welcomed the report, stating that stakeholders must work together to ensure the sustainability of the healthcare system. Insurers have already begun to hike IP rider premiums for older policyholders, and the task force's recommendations aim to prevent further escalation of claims and ensure affordable healthcare for all residents.

site_title: UN appoints Guterres as new secretary-general
summary: The UN General Assembly formally appointed Antonio Guterres as the new secretary-general, replacing Ban Ki-moon, who stepped down after two five-year terms. Guterres, a former prime minister of Portugal, will serve a five-year term starting January 1. He is expected to play a more prominent role as the world's diplomat-in-chief. The appointment was adopted by acclamation by the 193 member states, with no opposition.

site_title: US jobless claims flat at start of October
summary: US jobless claims remain flat at 246,000 for the week ending October 8, marking 84 consecutive weeks of initial claims below 300,000. This is the longest streak since 1970 and beats analyst expectations of 255,000. Despite low productivity, the US economy has seen solid monthly job creation, with 156,000 positions added in September.

site_title: Maldives quits Commonwealth over rights row
summary: The Maldives quit the Commonwealth on October 13, 2016, amid a long-standing human rights dispute, following years of criticism over its record since the toppling of its first democratically-elected leader in 2012. The country accused the London-based Commonwealth Secretariat of interfering in its domestic affairs, citing a crackdown on dissidents and a controversial judiciary. The move comes after the Commonwealth criticized the government's actions, particularly the conviction of former President Mohamed Nasheed on terrorism charges. The Maldives is the latest country to leave the Commonwealth, following Gambia's exit in 2013.

images.alt_text: The Maldives angrily quit the Commonwealth on Thursday after years of wrangling over its human rights record since the toppling of its first democratically-elected leader four years ago.

site_title: HDB deficit before grants shrinks 19% to S$1.6b as new supply tapers
summary: The Housing Development Board (HDB) reported a 19% decrease in its net deficit before government grants to S$1.6 billion in fiscal 2016, driven by reduced new flat supply. The agency completed 24,163 flats, a 19.9% decline, and bookings increased by 1.6% to 22,432 units. Resale flat applications rose 11% to 19,620 units. Experts attribute the stability in the public housing market to HDB's measures, including the Proximity Housing Grant, which has increased demand from first-time homeowners. Resale prices remain stable, with more centrally located units performing better.

site_title: Crude stocks rebound, product inventories fall: EIA
summary: US crude stocks rose by 4.9 million barrels in the week to Oct 7, exceeding analyst expectations. Gasoline stocks fell by 1.9 million barrels, while distillate inventories dropped by 3.7 million barrels. Refinery crude runs decreased by 480,000 barrels per day, and utilization rates fell by 2.8 percentage points. Crude imports rose by 110,000 barrels per day. These changes are attributed to refinery cuts and decreased demand.

site_title: US stocks near one-month lows as China data weighs
summary: US stocks near one-month lows as investors worry about China's weak economic data and the potential for a US interest rate hike by the end of the year. China's exports fell 10% in September, and imports unexpectedly shrank, raising concerns about the health of the world's second-largest economy. The Federal Reserve's rate-setting meeting minutes showed several policymakers feeling a rate hike is warranted "relatively soon" if the US economy continues to strengthen, causing traders to slash their bets on a December rate hike.

site_title: EIA cuts 2016 US natgas production outlook to below 2015 record
summary: The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) has cut its 2016 natural gas production outlook to below the 2015 record of 74.14 billion cubic feet per day, with a forecast of 72.49 bcfd. This would be the seventh consecutive annual record for gas demand, but still surpass the 2015 record. US gas consumption is also expected to fall to 75.97 bcfd in 2016, down from previous forecasts.

site_title: Update: JES International's auditors issue disclaimer in FY2015 financial statement
summary: JES International's auditors issued a disclaimer in the FY2015 financial statement, citing non-preparation of consolidated financial statements and material uncertainties that may cast doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern. The company made adjustments to its unaudited results due to "inadvertent" oversight of directors' salaries and fees. Separately, the ailing Chinese shipping firm is exploring possible new business and has filed a summons to transfer shares to its controlling shareholder, without receiving updates on the matter. The company may consider significant corporate actions, including a substantial acquisition or reverse takeover.

site_title: Keppel hands over sludge treatment facilities in Doha to client (Update)
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings handed over its second landmark project in Qatar, the sludge treatment facilities in Doha North Sewage Treatment Works, to the client on July 5, 2016. The 10-year operations and maintenance contract commenced under Keppel Infrastructure Services. This project, designed and built by Keppel Seghers, has a capacity to treat up to 245,000 cubic meters of wastewater per day, making it the largest in Qatar.

site_title: China's ranks of super-rich rise despite economic slowdown
summary: China's ranks of super-rich reached an all-time high with 2,056 individuals having a net worth of two billion yuan (S$410 million) or more, up from 1,877 last year. Despite a slowing economy, property mogul Wang Jianlin, Alibaba's Jack Ma, and Tencent's Pony Ma topped the list with net worths of US$32.1 billion, US$30.6 billion, and US$24.6 billion, respectively. The biggest riser was mysterious tycoon Yao Zhenhua, who rose 200 places to fourth with a nine-fold increase in his wealth to US$17.2 billion.

site_title: Vallianz postpones EGM on proposed rights issue
summary: Vallianz Holdings has postponed its extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for a proposed one-for-one rights issue due to a proposed set-off and settlement agreement with Swiber Holdings, which owns 25.15% of Vallianz. Swiber wants to settle the actual subscription amount payable to Vallianz for its pro rata entitlement of the rights cum warrants issue against any amount owing by Vallianz to Swiber. The new date and time for the EGM will be announced in a supplemental notice and circular. This decision aims to provide sufficient time for shareholders to consider the latest development.

site_title: Possibly the best Rent production in S'pore to date
summary: A recent production of the musical Rent in Singapore, presented by Pangdemonium, has been praised as one of the most competent outside of New York. This marks the third staging of the musical in Singapore, following productions by Singapore Repertory Theatre in 2001 and YDL in 2005. The reviewer notes that minor production hiccups are forgivable due to the powerful and sweeping songs that drive the story forward. The production is likely to delight fans of the musical and those who love it "with a passion."

site_title: Children's bed shaped like missile that downed MH17 plane stirs unease in Russia
summary: A Russian company has sold a children's bed shaped like a Buk missile launcher, which downed MH17 in 2014, sparking outrage among Russian consumers. The bed, made in St Petersburg, has been criticized for its poor taste. International prosecutors have linked the downing of the plane to a Buk missile fired from a village held by pro-Russian rebels, with Moscow denying involvement and blaming the Ukrainian army.

site_title: India Fin Min warns against growing protectionism
summary: India's finance minister Arun Jaitley warned against protectionism in developed economies, citing the UK's Brexit vote and US presidential election rhetoric as examples. He expressed concern that protectionist tendencies could hurt global growth, particularly in developing countries. The World Trade Organization recently slashed its global trade volume growth forecast to 1.7% due to protectionist rhetoric. Jaitley hopes that economic needs will prevent countries from enacting punitive tariffs, but warned that the "tenor of the debate" remains protectionist during elections.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks sink after China data while Shanghai rises
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.61% to close at 23,031.30 after China's exports slumped 10% in the previous month. However, mainland Chinese markets recovered, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.09% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gaining 0.11%.

site_title: French finance minister eyes US bank exodus from London
summary: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin says big US banks will transfer business from London to the continent following Brexit, citing the "inevitable consequence." Sapin met with senior US bankers, who are now planning the transfer of activities, and France is seeking to attract business by fast-tracking firm registrations and offering tax benefits. However, France's high taxes and the Socialist government's support for a financial transaction tax in EU countries may hinder this effort. The European Commission aims to propose a solution by the end of the year.

site_title: UOB to launch online marketplace for SMEs to buy business essentials at bulk prices
summary: UOB to launch an online marketplace for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to purchase business essentials at bulk prices, including travel, stationery, insurance, and logistics services. The platform aims to provide SMEs with convenient access to essential business supplies, potentially reducing costs and increasing efficiency.

site_title: Swaps or cash: Final choice for Samsung Note 7 owners
summary: South Korea's Samsung Electronics offered incentives to owners of the recalled Note 7 smartphone, allowing them to choose between a full refund or exchanging it for another Samsung device. Those opting for a refund received a 30,000 won gift card, while those swapping for a new phone received an additional 70,000 won credit. The move aims to retain customer loyalty after the company's damaging recall fiasco.

site_title: This startup is using artifical intelligence to speed up financial compliance
summary: A UK startup, ComplyAdvantage, has received $8.3 million in funding from Balderton Capital to expand its artificial intelligence-powered anti-money laundering compliance services in Europe and North America. The company, which serves 200 global clients, plans to add to its 50-employee team and open a sales office in New York. The funding aims to help financial institutions comply with increasingly complex anti-money laundering and know-your-customer regulations.

site_title: Singapore task force urges action to rein in health insurance claims and costs
summary: A Singapore task force has issued recommendations to rein in rising health insurance claims and costs of Integrated Shield Plans (IPs). The task force, comprising 11 members, recommends introducing medical fee benchmarks, clarifying inappropriate medical treatment, and adopting a framework for pre-authorising medical treatment. It also suggests using preferred healthcare providers and deductibles and co-insurance features to reduce costs. The recommendations aim to prevent steep premium hikes and make IPs more sustainable, especially for policyholders who age and cease to work.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker but off their lows
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed Thursday at 2,805.48, down 8.23 points, after a weak US market day. Despite a 30-point loss earlier, the index recovered to close 0.4% higher. Elevated turnover, with 1.3 billion units traded, showed investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Thailand's beloved king, unifying figure, dies at 88
summary: Thailand's King Bhumibol Adulyadej, the world's longest-reigning monarch, died at 88, ending a seven-decade reign and plunging the nation into uncertainty. The king, a unifying figure, was known for his devotion to his people and his role in Thailand's transformation from an impoverished nation to a successful economy. His son, Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn, will succeed him, but his popularity is less widespread. Thailand will hold a one-year mourning period, and the country's generals face a test in maintaining stability during the succession process.

site_title: Surbana Jurong buys auxiliary police Aetos from Temasek
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean urban development group, has acquired 100% of Aetos Holdings, one of three licensed auxiliary police organisations in Singapore, from Temasek Holdings. The acquisition aims to expand Surbana Jurong's service offerings to include safety and security capabilities, particularly with the use of state-of-the-art unmanned aerial vehicles for enhanced surveillance and land survey services.

site_title: German court rejects emergency appeal to block EU-Canada trade deal
summary: Germany's Constitutional Court rejected emergency appeals to block the EU-Canada trade deal, known as Ceta, allowing the government to approve it under certain conditions. The deal requires unanimous EU trade minister support, which is set to be voted on next week. If approved, the agreement will be signed on October 27, with the European Parliament also needing to vote for parts to go into force.

site_title: Doosan Bobcat seeks US$890m in new IPO, under half of original plan
summary: Doosan Bobcat Inc, a South Korean construction equipment maker, is revising its initial public offering (IPO) plan, aiming to raise up to 990.9 billion won (S$1.226 billion), less than half of its original plan. The company had initially planned for an IPO of up to 2.45 trillion won. Doosan Bobcat's indicative price range is 29,000-33,000 won per share, with 30% of the company to be sold in the listing scheduled for November 18.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei slips as yen rebounds, China trade data disappoints
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average slipped 0.4% to 16,774.24, as the yen rebounded against the US dollar. China's weak trade numbers, with exports dropping 10% in September, further dampened sentiment. The US dollar fell 0.4% to 103.73 yen, moving away from its Wednesday high. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined.

site_title: Publish medical fee benchmarks: health insurance taskforce
summary: A health insurance taskforce in Singapore has released recommendations to address rising health insurance premiums. The taskforce suggests introducing published medical fee benchmarks to bridge the information gap between healthcare providers and consumers, and clarify existing processes to detect inappropriate medical treatment. This move aims to mitigate over-charging by providers, empower insurers to detect inflated claims, and promote active claims adjudication. The recommendations are part of the taskforce's efforts to address escalating claims costs for Integrated Shield Plans.

site_title: Cambodia embraces China's President Xi on state visit
summary: China's President Xi Jinping completed a two-day state visit to Cambodia, where he received praise for Beijing's efforts in the South China Sea dispute. Cambodia, a key ally, has long supported Beijing, receiving billions in aid and loans. During the visit, Xi and Prime Minister Hun Sen signed 28 agreements, including deals to boost agricultural sales. Cambodia's strong ties with China have hindered regional efforts to jointly rebuke Beijing, with analysts describing the relationship as "beaming with new vitality."

site_title: Charity groups ask court to halt Calais migrant camp closure in France
summary: Several charity organizations have asked a French court to halt the closure of the Calais migrant camp, also known as the "Jungle," which is set to be demolished on October 17. The camp, home to thousands of refugees from countries like Syria, Iraq, and Sudan, is being closed by the French government ahead of its demolition. The charities argue that the closure will leave the refugees without adequate assistance and shelter. An emergency ruling is expected within 48 hours.

images.alt_text: Several charity organisations have asked a court in France to halt the imminent closure of the notorious "Jungle" migrant camp where thousands of refugees live in the port city of Calais, many of them desperate to get across the sea to Britain.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore companies can now bid for Australian procurement contracts under the upgraded Singapore-Australia Free Trade Agreement (Safta). The HDB incurred a deficit of S$1.639 billion in FY 2015/2016. A health insurance taskforce has released recommendations to address escalating claims costs for Integrated Shield Plans. Surbana Jurong has bought Aetos Holdings, a licensed auxiliary police organisation. UOB is launching an online marketplace for SMEs to buy business essentials at bulk prices.

images.alt_text: Singapore companies will be able to bid for procurement contracts from Australia's federal government as well as all of Australia's eight states and territories under an upgraded Singapore-Australia Free Trade Agreement (SAFTA), the Ministry of Trade and Industry said in a press release Thursday morning.

site_title: Letters to the Editor
summary: The Business Times (BT) overhauled its weekend edition, launching a luxury lifestyle magazine called Weekend, with a debut cover story "State of Cool" that compared Singapore to other great cities. Readers shared their feedback, expressing appreciation for the new addition. This marks a shift in BT's focus towards lifestyle content, complementing its existing business coverage.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.010 points to 1,665.020. Losers outnumbered gainers 485 to 304, and volume reached 1.759 billion lots worth RM1.939 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Won hits 2.5 month closing low on strong dollar, weak China
summary: The South Korean won hit a 2.5-month closing low of 1,135.9 to the US dollar due to a strong dollar and weak economic data from China, creating a risk-off mood. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) also fell 0.9% to its lowest since late September. Offshore investors bought 192.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while the local currency was down 1.1% from Wednesday's close.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia 2017 palm output to surpass 2015 record: Mistry
summary: Palm oil output in Indonesia and Malaysia is expected to surpass the 2015 record in 2017, driven by the recovery of trees from the 2016 El Nino weather pattern. Industry analyst Dorab Mistry forecasts a "massive rebuilding of stocks" by the end of September 2017, which could weigh on benchmark palm oil prices. Mistry predicts a strong output recovery of nearly 6.5 million tonnes for the oil-year 2016/17 and calendar year 2017, with crude palm oil prices expected to drop to 2,200 ringgit by end-December.

site_title: Deutsche Bank said to implement hiring freeze amid cost cuts
summary: Deutsche Bank is implementing a companywide hiring freeze as part of its efforts to lower costs and boost investor confidence. The move, announced by CEO John Cryan, aims to cut costs by up to 1.9 billion euros this year. The bank has already suspended dividends, scrapped bonus awards, and cut 9,000 jobs since Cryan took over in 2015. Analysts predict a 47% drop in the bank's shares this year, and the hiring freeze is seen as a necessary measure to shore up investor confidence amid mounting legal costs and a probe into faulty securities.

site_title: Coke and Pepsi fund health groups but fight them too: study
summary: US soda giants Coca-Cola and PepsiCo have donated millions to health organizations, but simultaneously lobbied against anti-obesity measures, including taxes on soft drinks. Between 2011 and 2015, the companies sponsored 96 national health organizations, while opposing 29 public health bills. The study's authors warn that accepting funding from these companies can create a conflict of interest, as the organizations may inadvertently participate in the companies' marketing plans.

site_title: Trade-weighted sterling near record low, Brexit focus shifts to High Court
summary: Sterling nears record low against major currencies as the UK's Brexit process becomes increasingly uncertain. The pound surged 1.5% against the dollar and euro after Prime Minister Theresa May said she would allow lawmakers to scrutinize the Brexit process, but later appeared less concessionary in parliament. A High Court hearing to challenge the government's stance on Article 50 is set for Monday, fueling uncertainty and prompting investors to stay clear of the currency. The pound has shed 18% against the dollar since the Brexit vote in June, with trade-weighted sterling down 0.15% at 73.7.

site_title: China cracking down on rumour-mongering in property market
summary: China's Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development ordered local regulators to intensify probes into rumour-mongering in the property market, aiming to prevent a housing bubble. The ministry cited disruptions to the market and called for "stable and healthy" home prices. Local authorities have taken measures to calm the market, including banning real estate agents for spreading false information and restricting advertising wording. This follows a list of 45 developers and agencies found to have inflated the market through illegal behavior, including hoarding properties and spreading rumors.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets slid at the start of trading on Thursday, mirroring falls across Asia, following worse-than-expected economic data from China. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.5% to 6,987.97 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.9% to 10,425.79 points and Paris' CAC 40 retreated 0.7% to 4,421.81 points. China's exports plummeted last month, dealing another blow to its economy, amid weak global demand and imports.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slip ahead of earnings, views by key tech shares
summary: Taiwan's stocks slipped 0.5% on Thursday, tracking weak overseas markets, ahead of key tech firms' earnings statements. Electronics subindex fell 0.6% and financials subindex 0.8%. TSMC and Largan, suppliers of iPhone 7 components, were trading 1% lower, with analysts watching for clues on demand strength. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.715 per US dollar.

site_title: This bank-beating trading powerhouse doesn't use human traders
summary: XTX Markets Ltd, a foreign-exchange trading powerhouse, relies on programmers and mathematicians rather than human traders to fuel its growth. The firm uses sophisticated mathematical models and massive data sets to make trades, with computing power comparable to top supercomputers. XTX's strategy has allowed it to compete with high-frequency traders and banks in the US market, with its balance sheet and risk management capabilities giving it an edge. The company is now looking to expand into stocks, commodities, and bonds markets, and is competing with tech giants like Google for top talent, offering equity and unique perks to attract mathematicians and technologists.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Aussie shares end down on China woes, NZ closes higher
summary: Australian shares fell 0.71% on Thursday, their lowest close since September 28, due to weaker-than-expected Chinese economic data and a slump in oil prices. Energy and basic material stocks led the losses, with major miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto down 2.9% and 2.7%, respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.18% driven by gains in consumer cyclicals and utilities, with Fletcher Building and Meridian Energy among the top gainers.

site_title: US retaliates with airstrikes on Yemen coast after ship attack
summary: The US launched three airstrikes on areas controlled by Yemen's Houthi rebels after a navy ship, USS Mason, was targeted by two failed missile attacks in the Red Sea and Bab al-Mandeb strait. The strikes destroyed radar sites involved in the missile launches, and the US will respond to any further threat to its ships and commercial traffic. The initial assessments show no damage was caused by the second missile, which hit the water. The US aims to protect its personnel, ships, and freedom of navigation in the region.

site_title: Marmite taken off Tesco's online store as Brexit bites
summary: Marmite was removed from Tesco's online store due to a dispute with Unilever over pricing following the UK's Brexit decision. Unilever requested price hikes to offset the cost of imported commodities, but Tesco refused. The product, a British staple, was unavailable on the online store, sparking national furore. Other Unilever products, including PG Tips tea and Ben & Jerry's ice cream, were also affected. The issue was resolved shortly after, with Unilever products becoming available again.

site_title: Egypt said to get US$2b Saudi deposit in IMF deal boost
summary: Egypt has received a $2 billion deposit from Saudi Arabia, bringing it closer to securing a $12 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund. The deposit, part of Egypt's $6 billion from bilateral creditors needed for the IMF loan, eases concerns about the loan's approval and restores investor confidence. The move is seen as a boost to Egypt's efforts to overhaul its economy and float the Egyptian pound. The deposit follows recent tensions between Egypt and Saudi Arabia, but a Saudi ambassador is set to arrange for a high-level Egyptian delegation's visit to Riyadh.

site_title: Stevie Wonder to lead Prince fans in final sendoff
summary: Stevie Wonder will lead a sold-out tribute concert in Minnesota to honor Prince, nearly six months after the pop icon's sudden death. The event, which begins at 7:30pm, features a star-studded lineup including Christina Aguilera, Chaka Khan, Morris Day, and Mayte Garcia. The concert comes a week after Prince's estate opened Paisley Park for tours, with organizers hoping to draw local fans and fill the coffers for Prince's estate. Tickets start at $20, with proceeds expected to help pay off Prince's estate's uncertain finances.

site_title: Gold climbs for second day as investors boost holdings in funds
summary: Gold prices rose for a second day, gaining 0.4% to $1,260.17 an ounce, as investors boosted holdings in gold-backed exchange-traded funds despite expectations of a US interest rate hike. The Fed's September meeting minutes reinforced the likelihood of a December rate hike, but gold prices held steady. Platinum rebounded after entering a bear market on Wednesday, adding 0.8% to $949.20 an ounce. Assets in gold-backed ETFs reached 2,048.3 metric tons, the highest since June 2013, indicating investors remain bullish on the metal.

site_title: Alibaba sees 'tremendous' challenge for pure e-commerce business
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd expects pure e-commerce operators to face 'tremendous challenges' as it seeks to transform China's $4.5 trillion traditional retail industry. The company plans to upgrade retail businesses, improve efficiency, and integrate online and offline shopping experiences. Alibaba is also investing in business and geographical expansion, despite potential short-term earnings drag. The company aims to tap growth from cloud computing, digital marketing, and cross-platform entertainment, with a focus on serving two billion consumers and 10 million profitable businesses worldwide in 20 years.

site_title: Nazi jargon revival causes alarm in Germany
summary: German far-right politicians have revived long-banished words and phrases linked to the Nazi past, sparking comparisons to the 1930s. The Islamophobic Pegida movement has used terms like "Luegenpresse" (lying press) to discredit the media, reminiscent of Hitler's rhetoric. Historians draw parallels with the Weimar Republic's final years, as the re-emergence of such language fuels concerns about a resurgence of Nazi ideology in Germany.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lower at open
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.46% to 23,300.38 in the first trading session on Thursday, following two consecutive losses, after Federal Reserve minutes indicated policymakers were poised to lift US interest rates soon. Shanghai's benchmark composite index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index was nearly unchanged.

site_title: Australian dollar slips on weak China data, New Zealand dollar at 2-1/2 month lows
summary: The Australian dollar dropped to a 3-1/2 week low of US$0.7518 after China's exports declined by 10% in September, fueling a risk-off move. This was despite a record A$13 billion in demand for the A$7.6 billion government bond auction. The decline in Chinese imports also raised concerns, further impacting the Australian dollar. The currency's slide follows previous weak data from China, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US destroyer again targeted by missile off Yemen
summary: A US destroyer, the USS Mason, was targeted by a missile fired from rebel-held territory in Yemen for the second time in four days. The ship detected the incoming missile and deployed "countermeasures," which likely prevented it from hitting the ship. There was no damage to the ship or its crew, and the USS Mason will continue its operations. The incident is the latest in a series of missile attacks on US ships in the region.

site_title: Foreign investors sue Toshiba over accounting scandal
summary: Toshiba Corp has been sued by 45 mainly foreign institutional investors for 16.7 billion yen (S$224.81 million) in damages over its false profit statements related to a 2008 accounting scandal. The lawsuit, filed in the Tokyo District Court, is the largest single claim of compensation so far. Toshiba admitted to reporting inflated profits going back to 2008, with 15 other suits seeking 15.3 billion yen in compensation.

site_title: Japan to expand Djibouti military base to counter Chinese influence
summary: Japan plans to lease additional land in Djibouti to expand its military base, counteracting growing Chinese influence in the region. The expansion will allow Japan to deploy more personnel and aircraft, including C-130 transport planes and Bushmaster armored vehicles. The move is seen as a response to China's US$60 billion investment in African development projects and its construction of a military facility in Djibouti. The base, which already hosts 180 Japanese troops, will be used for maritime patrol operations and disaster response.

images.alt_text: Japan will lease additional land next year to expand a military base in Djibouti, eastern Africa, as a counterweight to what it sees as growing Chinese influence in the region, three Japanese government sources said.

site_title: HDB deficit down to S$1.639b
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) incurred a deficit of S$1.639 billion in the financial year 2015/2016, primarily due to home ownership expenses. The deficit from home ownership alone was S$1.179 billion. This marks a significant decline from previous years, indicating a possible improvement in HDB's financial situation.

site_title: Brexit battle reaches UK's high court in challenge to PM
summary: The UK's High Court is set to hear a challenge to Prime Minister Theresa May's right to start Brexit negotiations, following a June 23 referendum in which 52% of Britons voted to leave the EU. A legal challenge, backed by an investment fund manager, a hairdresser, and an expatriate, argues that negotiations cannot begin without a parliamentary vote. The challenge seeks to establish that parliament should legislate on Brexit terms before Article 50 can be triggered, with Gina Miller stating that "this is not about whether we should stay or leave, but how we leave."

site_title: Glencore jumps to 15-month high as coal prices extend surge
summary: Glencore shares jumped 6.4% to a 15-month high, closing at 236.2 pence, due to rising coal prices. The company, the world's top exporter of power-station coal, has benefited from a surge in coal prices, which have more than doubled this year. Glencore also plans to reopen a coal mine in Australia and produce coking coal, with a Japanese steelmaker agreeing to pay $200 per metric ton, the highest contracted price since 2012. The company's debt load is being cut, with a US$26 billion reduction.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall as China exports unexpectedly drop, yen gains
summary: Asian stocks fell as China's exports unexpectedly declined 5.6% in yuan terms in September, missing forecasts for a 2.5% increase. The yen strengthened, leading to losses in Hong Kong and Japan. Investors also weighed minutes from the Federal Reserve's September meeting, which showed several policymakers believed a rate increase was needed "relatively soon." The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped 0.5% as a result, with the Shanghai Composite Index also falling 0.1%.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% lower on Thursday, retreating 9.2 points to 2,804.51, amid US Federal Reserve meeting minutes suggesting a possible interest rate hike in December. Trading volume was high, with 101.4 million shares changing hands. The market remained positive overall, with 66 gainers for every 59 losers, as investors continue to navigate tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's next move.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds interest rates steady as debt soars
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) maintained its key interest rate at a record-low 1.25% for a fourth consecutive month, citing risks from mounting household debt. The decision comes despite a 11% increase in household debt to 1,257.3 trillion won. The BOK aims to ensure an ongoing economic recovery and approach its 2% inflation target in the medium term, while closely monitoring household debt and corporate restructuring.

site_title: Cathay Pacific shares plunge as it axes profit outlook
summary: Cathay Pacific shares plummeted over 5% after the airline scrapped its second-half profit outlook, citing intense competition and overcapacity. The Hong Kong-based carrier reported a net profit of HK$353 million for the first six months of the year. The company's shares traded at a low of HK$10.16 per share, down 5.58% from the previous day's close. This move marks a significant change from the airline's previous forecast, highlighting the challenges facing the aviation industry.

site_title: Category Four hurricane Nicole heading towards Bermuda
summary: Category Four hurricane Nicole is heading towards Bermuda, with maximum sustained winds of 215 km/h. Located 290 km south-south-west of Bermuda, the core of Nicole will pass over or near the island on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Extremely dangerous Category Four hurricane Nicole was heading for Bermuda, the National Hurricane Centre said late Wednesday.

site_title: Nations meet in Rwanda to tackle greenhouse gases
summary: Nearly 200 nations meet in Rwanda to discuss phasing out hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), potent greenhouse gases introduced to replace ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons. Delegates aim to commit to phasing out HFCs, which contribute to climate change, with some estimates suggesting they could add up to 0.5 degrees Celsius to global temperatures by 2100. The meeting, the 28th of the Montreal Protocol, follows years of talks and comes as countries seek to meet the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting warming to 2 degrees Celsius.

site_title: Taiwan's TSMC Q3 net profit climbs 28% to quarterly record
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) reported a 28% increase in Q3 net profit to NT$96.8 billion, a new quarterly record, driven by sales of chips and processors for Apple's iPhone 7. Revenue rose 23% to NT$260.4 billion, also a record. This strong performance suggests TSMC may beat its 5-10% growth guidance for 2016, with three months left in the year.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co's (TSMC) third-quarter net profit jumped 28 per cent, hitting a new quarterly record, as analysts said earnings were boosted by sales of chips and processors for Apple Inc's new iPhone 7.

site_title: Australia shares dip after Fed minutes; NZ gains
summary: Australia's shares dropped 0.4% to 5451.6, following an uninspiring US session and minutes from the Federal Reserve's last meeting, which suggested a possible interest rate hike in December. Despite this, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% as materials and telecom stocks gained. Key Australian stocks fell, including Oil Search (-1.5%), Origin Energy (-1.4%), and BHP Billiton (-1.4%).

site_title: Apple CEO Tim Cook visits Nintendo headquarters in Kyoto
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook visited Nintendo's headquarters in Kyoto, Japan, meeting with Nintendo president Tatsumi Kimishima and Super Mario co-creator Shigeru Miyamoto. The meeting came after the unveiling of Super Mario Run for Apple devices, marking Nintendo's first time partnering with a mobile gadget manufacturer. The visit boosted Nintendo's stock, which rose 2.6% before giving up gains. The Super Mario Run app is scheduled for release in December, with no Android version announced.

images.alt_text: Tim Cook seems to be enjoying his visit to Kyoto.

site_title: China exports remain sluggish amid mounting pressure on yuan
summary: China's exports declined 5.6% in yuan terms in September, snapping a six-month gain streak, and adding to pressure on the yuan, which is near a six-year low. The trade surplus widened to 278.4 billion yuan. The data may increase pressure on the yuan as it faces challenges from new property curbs and a decline in growth expectations. The yuan has dropped 3.4% against the US dollar this year, its biggest decline in Asia.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping Asia-US operations to be put up for sale as early as Friday
summary: A South Korean court plans to put Hanjin Shipping's Asia-US operations up for sale as early as Friday, following the company's court receivership process. The sale comes after Hanjin Shipping applied for court receivership due to global industry overcapacity and low freight rates. The company had a total debt of 6.03 trillion won (S$7.4 billion) as of end-June. The sale of assets, including container ships and logistics systems, is expected to begin on November 7, with a deadline for binding bids set for that date.

site_title: Qantas adds daily Sydney-Beijing flights to tap China tourism surge
summary: Qantas Airways will resume daily non-stop flights from Sydney to Beijing, a route it discontinued in 2009, to tap into China's surging tourism. The new daily flights, scheduled to begin in January 2017, will be code-shared with China Eastern and subject to regulatory approval. The move aims to capitalize on the 23% growth in Chinese visitors to Australia, now the country's leading source of tourists by visitor spend. This re-entry into the market comes as other Chinese carriers have also introduced new direct routes from Sydney to China.

site_title: Samsung stock meltdown attracts investors on survival bets
summary: Samsung Electronics Co's stock has experienced its largest three-day decline since 2012, with a 10% drop, after the company halted production of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones due to battery issues. Despite this, some investors, such as TT International and Skagen, remain optimistic, citing the company's ability to restore its brand and its potential for long-term growth. However, others, including a fund manager at JO Hambro Capital Management, are more cautious, citing concerns over the company's brand reputation and the impact on its sales.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Thursday, rising 0.27 points to 1667.30. Gainers outnumbered losers 77 to 44, with a trading volume of 25.8 million lots worth RM7.48 million.

site_title: Singapore-Australia free trade agreement upgraded
summary: Singapore and Australia have upgraded their free trade agreement, allowing Singaporean companies to bid for procurement contracts in Australia's federal government and all eight states and territories. Investors also won't need approval for investments below A$1.094 billion in non-sensitive sectors. The upgraded agreement is expected to enter into force in 2017, benefiting Singaporean businesses and investors.

site_title: China urges Australia to be "cautious" on South China Sea
summary: China urged Australia to be "cautious" on the South China Sea, hoping for matching words and actions, amid criticism of surveillance flights and US-backed freedom of navigation exercises. China claims almost the entire sea, worth $5 trillion in trade, and has built artificial islands despite international concerns. Australia has not conducted a unilateral freedom of navigation voyage, differing from its US ally. China's Vice Chairman Fan Changlong made the call during a meeting with Australia's Air Chief Marshal Mark Binskin, seeking to maintain healthy and stable military ties.

site_title: Two women say Trump touched them inappropriately: report
summary: Two women, Jessica Leeds and Rachel Crooks, have accused Donald Trump of inappropriately touching them in the past. Leeds claims Trump groped her on a flight over 30 years ago, while Crooks says he kissed her on the mouth and would not let go of her hand. Trump denies the allegations, calling them a "character assassination" and threatening to sue. The Trump campaign has also dismissed the claims, labeling them "fiction" and "dangerous." Neither woman reported the incidents to law enforcement, but friends and family corroborate their accounts.

site_title: NZ government posts surplus for second year as tax take increases
summary: New Zealand's government reported a surplus of NZ$1.83 billion for the fiscal year to June 30, exceeding its forecast of NZ$668 million. This marks the second consecutive year of surpluses, driven by a NZ$3.8 billion rise in core tax revenue. Finance Minister emphasized the need to reduce debt despite the positive financial outlook, citing global risks such as economic slowdowns and trade tensions.

site_title: Tee International bags S$48m new contracts
summary: Singapore-based engineering group Tee International has won S$48 million in new contracts, including a contract with Changi Airport Group to serve as a nominated sub-contractor for a three-runway system development project. The contract, awarded to its unit Trans Equatorial Engineering, involves work on an airfield lighting system. This win marks a significant milestone for the company, expanding its presence in the aviation sector.

site_title: Singapore, Australia sign Comprehensive Strategic Partnership agreements
summary: Singapore and Australia signed four agreements on Thursday, marking the start of the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, a pact that elevates their relationship. The agreements were witnessed by Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull at Canberra's Parliament House. This move aims to deepen cooperation between the two countries in various areas, including trade, defense, and security. The partnership is expected to enhance bilateral ties and foster greater collaboration between the two nations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DeClout, Soilbuild Reit, Duty Free International
summary: Three stocks to watch: DeClout, Soilbuild Reit, and Duty Free International. DeClout plans to sell a 72.09% owned subsidiary to Citic Telecom International Holdings for up to S$75 million. Soilbuild Reit reported lower occupancies and revenue for the third quarter, while Duty Free International's net profit surged 46% to RM13.8 million in its fiscal second quarter.

site_title: Sydney, Melbourne housing boom has peaked amid investor curbs, QBE says
summary: Sydney's housing boom is nearing its end due to curbs on investor lending and new developments. QBE Insurance Group Ltd forecasts the median house price in Sydney to remain flat over the next three years, with apartment prices falling 6.8% by June 2019. Melbourne's median home price is expected to fall 0.6% by June 2019, while Perth's median house price is forecast to be 10% below its 2014 peak. In contrast, Brisbane home prices are expected to rise 6.5% due to a lack of new supply.

images.alt_text: Sydney's housing boom is coming to an end, as curbs on investor lending and a raft of new developments combine to depress prices, according to QBE Insurance Group Ltd.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.52% to 16,926.82, driven by investors picking up exporters on a weaker yen.

site_title: UK housing market strengthens in September as Brexit hit fades
summary: The UK housing market strengthened in September, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' house-price gauge rising to 17 from 13 in August. Despite Brexit-related uncertainty, the economy proved resilient, and mortgage rates fell to record lows. New buyer enquiries increased for the first time since February, and price expectations climbed as property stock remained exceptionally low. London bucked the national trend, with prices expected to remain unchanged in 12 months, while other regions saw an upward price trend. The market appears to be settling down after a rocky first half.

site_title: Espresso yourself! Japan perks up to 'sexy' coffee
summary: Japan's coffee culture is gaining popularity, with hipster cafes and baristas offering unique and stylish beverages. The country imports over 430,000 tonnes of coffee annually, and top baristas are using techniques like nitrogen charging to create rich froths. Japanese people are known for their sensitive palates, allowing them to appreciate subtle flavor differences. The World Barista Championship is a highlight of Japan's coffee scene, with past winners including Hidenori Izaki and Yoshikazu Iwase. Baristas are making coffee "sexy" through their creativity and performance, with many prioritizing customer satisfaction and atmosphere.

images.alt_text: Need a pick-me-up?

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare said to delay IPO after regulatory queries
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Corp, a Singapore-based medical service provider, is delaying its initial public offering (IPO) after Singapore regulators received complaints about its business. Regulators are seeking more information, but the company remains hopeful of completing the IPO. The IPO was planned to raise S$213 million, with a share price of S$1.52, but no new timeline has been set. The company is engaging with regulators and plans to use half the proceeds for acquisitions and the rest for expansion into China.

site_title: Wanda's Wang defends top spot in China rich list
summary: Chinese property magnate Wang Jianlin has defended his top spot as the country's richest man, with a personal fortune of $32.1 billion, according to the Hurun rich list. Alibaba Group Holding Ltd founder Jack Ma saw his wealth surge 41% to $24.4 billion, while Baoneng's Yao Zhenhua rose 820% to $17.2 billion. This year's list highlights the growing financial muscle of China's super-rich, who are fueling a boom in global deals. The report also notes that China now has 594 dollar billionaires, surpassing the US.

images.alt_text: Chinese property magnate Wang Jianlin has defended his crown as the country's richest man, according to the annual Hurun rich list, fending off Alibaba Group Holding Ltd founder Jack Ma and new players on the block like Baoneng's Yao Zhenhua.

site_title: Tesla dominates US luxury sedan sales
summary: Tesla dominated US luxury sedan sales in the third quarter, with Model S sales increasing 59% and accounting for nearly a third of the market. The company's Model X luxury SUV sold 5,428 units, outselling Porsche and Land Rover but trailing behind seven Mercedes-Benz models. Tesla aims to replicate this success with its affordable Model 3, set to launch late next year. CEO Elon Musk has set a goal of selling 500,000 Teslas annually by 2018, but achieving this target will be a significant challenge.

site_title: Snapchat said to pick Morgan Stanley, Goldman to lead IPO
summary: Snapchat has chosen Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs to lead its initial public offering (IPO), with other banks including JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, and Barclays, as joint book runners. The IPO could happen as soon as March. The company, which has over 150 million daily active users, aims to generate more than $350 million in advertising revenue this year. This move follows the company's recent corporate name change to Snap Inc.

site_title: Disguises, aliases cloak Washington food critic in secrecy
summary: Washington Post food critic Tom Sietsema uses multiple disguises, including aliases and credit cards, to maintain his anonymity while reviewing restaurants in the US capital. To protect his objectivity, Sietsema eats at restaurants a dozen times a week, often visiting twice to give an initial critique. He has been covering the food scene since 2000 and has written a series on the top 10 food cities, winning a prestigious award from the James Beard Foundation in 2015. Sietsema's methods have become a cat-and-mouse game with restaurants, but he believes it's necessary to maintain the integrity of his reviews.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Post's current valuation remains attractive, with its core traditional mail business and property accounting for 93% of its value. Analysts UOB Kay Hian and Frasers Centrepoint Ltd maintain "buy" and "add" ratings, respectively, with target prices of S$1.77 and S$2.04. However, Singapore banks are expected to face worsening asset quality and slowing top-line growth, leading to a "negative" rating from Maybank Kim Eng Research.

site_title: Oil drops below US$50 as concerns emerge over Opec reduction plan
summary: Oil prices dropped below $50 a barrel for the first time in nearly three years as concerns emerged over Opec's production reduction plan. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to cut output to 32.5-33 million barrels a day, but internal differences have hindered the implementation. West Texas Intermediate fell as much as 42 US cents to $49.76 a barrel, while Brent dropped 60 US cents to $51.81 a barrel. The reduced output plan may not be enough to address the global supply glut, leading to bearish market sentiment.

site_title: Trump loss would be colossal 'waste of time' for him
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump warned that a loss in the upcoming election would be the "single greatest waste of time, energy and money" for him, citing his own $100 million investment in the campaign. Trump trails behind Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in national polls and faces criticism over a 2005 tape where he bragged about groping women. With just 27 days left until the election, Trump is attempting to salvage his campaign by criticizing Clinton's policies and character.

site_title: Cathay Pacific abandons forecast, conducts 'critical review'
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways scrapped its profit forecast and initiated a "critical review" of its business amid a deteriorating outlook, citing a 82% slump in net income in the first half and declining premium travel. The airline attributed the decline to increased competition with Middle Eastern carriers offering more direct services to the US and Europe from China. Cathay Pacific carried 2.7% more passengers in the first six months, but yields slumped 10% due to increased competition, and the company needs to "stop the bleeding" to improve its financial situation.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, Asia's biggest international carrier, scrapped its profit outlook and said the airline is doing a "critical review" of its business amid a deteriorating outlook.

site_title: September's Fed rate decision a 'close call': minutes
summary: The Federal Reserve's September interest rate decision was a "close call" for policymakers, who are now poised to increase rates in December to prevent inflation from rising.
