Minutes from the September meeting revealed that some members believed rates should be raised "relatively soon" to address strong job growth and low labor market slack. However, others argued that signs of inflationary pressure were missing, citing low core inflation and wage growth. The decision was closely divided, but Fed futures markets now suggest a 70% likelihood of a December rate hike.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall slightly as Ericsson slumps
summary: European stock markets fell slightly on Wednesday, with the STOXX 600 index down 0.5% for the second straight session. Ericsson slumped to an eight-year low after issuing a profit warning, with its quarterly operating profit plummeting 94% and sales declining. Nokia also dropped, while Deutsche Lufthansa and PageGroup rose. Italian lenders outperformed the sector, with UBI Banca, Banco Popolare, and UniCredit gaining between 2.4% and 6%.

images.alt_text: European stock markets fell slightly on Wednesday with Sweden's Ericsson slumping to eight-year lows after issuing a profit warning.

site_title: ING to shut equity derivatives business in Singapore, New York and Brussels
summary: ING Groep NV plans to move 60 trading jobs from Amsterdam and Brussels to London, while shutting its equity derivatives business in New York, Singapore, and Brussels. The move aims to consolidate operations and cut costs. The company also plans to eliminate 5,800 jobs in Belgium and the Netherlands to aid digital transformation, saving 900 million euros annually. This follows other European banks considering relocation amid Brexit uncertainty, with ING's move potentially drawing more talent to London despite the city's financial future in question.

site_title: Older and liberated, Depeche Mode readies new album
summary: Depeche Mode, the iconic electronic music group, is set to release its 14th studio album, Spirit, in the first half of 2017. The album will be accompanied by a 32-city, 21-country tour across Europe starting in May. The group, now older and liberated, feels more freedom to create and tour at their own pace. With a career spanning decades, Depeche Mode has had a significant impact on electronic music, helping to bring it into the mainstream and appealing to fans of various genres.

site_title: Wells Fargo CEO Stumpf steps down after fake accounts scandal
summary: Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf has stepped down immediately following a scandal in which bank employees opened millions of unauthorized accounts to meet sales targets. Stumpf had previously denied resigning, but will be succeeded by Tim Sloan, who will focus on restoring trust in the bank. The bank has already settled for $190 million in fines and restitution, and Stumpf will forfeit $41 million in compensation. Critics, including lawmakers, had called for Stumpf's resignation, citing his role in pressuring employees to meet unrealistic sales targets and stealing from customers.

site_title: Samsung's talks with Fiat said to stall amid Note 7 crisis
summary: Fiat Chrysler's talks with Samsung Electronics over a partnership with its car-parts unit, Magneti Marelli, have stalled due to Samsung's focus on resolving the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone crisis. The companies had agreed on a potential partnership, but disagreements over valuation and deal structure have hindered progress. Fiat's CEO, Sergio Marchionne, has been seeking to strengthen the company's technology capabilities, while Samsung aims to decrease its reliance on consumer electronics. The talks were initially set to be completed by the end of the year, but it's now unlikely that an accord will be signed.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV's talks with Samsung Electronics over a partnership with its car-parts unit have stalled because the Korean company is focused on resolving the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone crisis, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Top Glove Q4 profit falls 36.1% on stiffer competition
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a Kuala Lumpur-listed glove manufacturer, reported a 36.1% decline in Q4 net profit to RM65.6 million due to increased competition in the glove industry. Despite this, revenue rose 15.1% to RM2.89 billion and the company sold an "all-time high" number of gloves. Top Glove proposed a higher final dividend of 8.5 sen, citing expansion mode despite "intensifying competition and pricing pressure." The company expects to ramp up production capacity to 52.4 billion pieces of gloves per year by April 2017.

site_title: Boeing wins US$3.2b order from China Southern as 787 soars
summary: Boeing wins a $3.2 billion order from China Southern Airlines to sell 12 787 Dreamliners, valued at $271 million each. The deal comes after Qatar Airways announced a similar order, doubling Boeing's 787 order tally for the year. China Southern, the country's largest airline, has ordered over $15 billion of new aircraft from Boeing and Airbus in the past year, as the nation's aviation market is expected to become the largest in two decades. The planes will be delivered between 2018 and 2020.

site_title: TTIP, protests and the lessons of history
summary: A reported 80,000 people in Berlin protested against the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, while similar demonstrations occurred in other German cities. Bombings in New York and New Jersey also took place, highlighting the level of organisation behind the protests. The demonstrations reflect a broader trend of large-scale popular protests throughout history, driven by the development of mass communication. The protests in Germany are seen as a reaction to the perceived threat of free trade, despite the EU single market being widely popular.

site_title: Scottish leader slams UK 'xenophobia' over Brexit
summary: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is set to accuse the UK government of "xenophobia" and "scapegoating of foreigners" in its approach to Brexit. Sturgeon, a pro-EU leader, criticized the Conservative Party's handling of the June 23 referendum, which saw Britain vote to leave the EU. She will argue that the government's hard Brexit stance will have "ruinous consequences" for Scotland's economy and people, and will explore all options to protect Scotland's place in the EU.

images.alt_text: Scotland's pro-EU leader Nicola Sturgeon, will on Thursday accuse the British government of "xenophobia" and "scapegoating of foreigners" in its approach to Brexit, according to comments released by her office.

site_title: Tighter financing rules for developers on the cards
summary: China's securities regulator is set to tighten rules for listed real estate firms to issue bonds and private placements in an effort to curb excessive capital flowing into the property market. The Shanghai Stock exchange plans to raise the bar for real estate companies to issue corporate bonds, according to multiple sources. This move aims to regulate the property market and prevent speculative investments. The CSRC's decision is expected to impact the real estate sector and potentially influence the overall economy.

site_title: Wall Street selloff drags STI down 1.5%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.5% to 2,813.71 points on Wednesday, amid concerns over US interest rates and earnings worries. Banks, Singtel, Jardine Matheson, and Sembcorp Marine closed weaker, while penny stocks led the market. Noble Group fell for the second consecutive day after announcing the sale of its US unit, and Chasen Holdings was queried by the Singapore Exchange over unusual trading volume.

site_title: US SEC to finalise liquidity rules for funds, with some changes
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is set to finalize liquidity rules for US open-end funds, requiring them to show they have enough liquidity to cover redemptions from investors. The rules, which were first proposed a year ago, have sparked debate and concerns from industry experts. The SEC is considering changes to the proposal, including altering a minimum asset threshold and introducing "swing pricing" to protect existing shareholders. The final rules aim to ensure market stability and prevent a major fund from being caught short during a panic run.

site_title: BMW unveils self-balancing motorcycle of the future
summary: BMW unveiled the Motorrad Vision Next 100, a self-balancing motorcycle with zero-emissions, designed to stand upright at a complete stop. The bike's self-balancing system aims to protect riders, potentially allowing them to ride without helmets. However, the technology is still in development and not expected to be widely available until 2030. The motorcycle will not be fully autonomous, with human drivers required. BMW plans to commercialize fully autonomous vehicles by 2021.

site_title: Sterling firms; court to rule on Brexit trigger
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's offer to scrutinize the Brexit process has calmed market fears of a "hard Brexit", causing the pound to rise 1.2% to a 31-year high. A court will rule on Thursday on whether May can trigger Article 50 without parliament's consent. Investors fear a "hard Brexit" could hurt trade and foreign investment, but May's offer suggests a possible shift towards a "soft Brexit" or no Brexit at all.

site_title: Falcon Private Bank faces Swiss criminal probe in 1MDB case
summary: Swiss federal prosecutors have opened a criminal probe against Zurich-based Falcon Private Bank for allegedly failing to prevent suspected money laundering linked to 1MDB, the scandal-hit Malaysian state fund. The bank, owned by Abu Dhabi's IPIC, will cooperate with the investigation. Swiss law requires companies to prevent money laundering, and the Office of the Attorney General alleges that 1MDB misappropriated around $4 billion. This is the second Swiss bank to face a criminal investigation over 1MDB links, following BSI.

site_title: US: Stocks steady as Fed minutes support December hike
summary: US stocks ended steady on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1% at 18,144.20. The S&P 500 gained 0.1% to 2,139.18, while the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.2% to 5,239.02. The Federal Reserve's September meeting minutes supported a December rate hike, with some policymakers expressing hawkish views. Investors also focused on earnings season forecasts, with analysts expecting a fifth consecutive quarterly decline in S&P 500 company earnings.

site_title: Galaxy Note7 owners cheer news of full refund
summary: Samsung has announced that owners of the Galaxy Note7 in Singapore can receive a full refund for the device, which was discontinued due to battery issues that led to some units catching fire and exploding. The company will also provide refunds for the price difference between the replacement device and the original Note7. However, details on how to obtain refunds and replacements are not yet available, and the company is working with its telecommunication operator and retail partners to provide information soon.

site_title: Pound rallies as PM May relents on Brexit debate
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May relented on Brexit debate, accepting Parliament's right to vote on her plan for Britain's exit from the EU. This move eased investor concerns, causing the pound to surge 0.7% against the US dollar and 1.4% against the euro, its biggest gain in almost two months. The decision gives lawmakers a tool to pressure May and potentially limit her negotiating space, but experts warn the pound's rally may be short-lived due to concerns over the Brexit negotiations and UK's economic outlook.

site_title: Amazon joins music wars with new streaming service
summary: Amazon has launched a new music streaming service, Amazon Music Unlimited, offering tens of millions of songs for $9.99/month or discounted rates for Echo speaker users. The service is available to US customers and will launch later this year in Britain, Germany, and Austria. Amazon's entry into the streaming music wars comes as rival Spotify has over 40 million paying subscribers, while Apple Music has 17 million. The new service aims to capitalize on Amazon's Echo smart speakers and Prime membership, offering a competitive price point and potential for increased sales.

site_title: Fed urged to continue efforts to expand workforce
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of New York president William Dudley urged the Fed to continue its efforts to expand the US workforce, citing the benefits of its go-slow approach on interest rates. The Fed has already seen an improvement in the labor market, with people discouraged from work returning to the labor force. Policymakers are debating raising interest rates, but Dudley suggests they should aim to maintain a balance between employment and sustainable economic growth, avoiding a potential recession.

site_title: Toyota, Suzuki holding partnership talks
summary: Toyota and Suzuki are holding talks about a potential partnership to address changes in the global car industry. The partnership could focus on new safety and environmental technologies amid rapid industry changes. The two Japanese automakers did not announce details, but a joint statement noted that the "environment surrounding the automotive industry has been changing drastically and rapidly." This move comes as Japan's vehicle sector sees a wave of consolidation.

site_title: Japanese dump cheaper cars for luxury models
summary: Japan's luxury car market is booming, with imports of cars costing 10 million yen (S$133,240) or more surging 19% in the first nine months to 13,605 units. This growth is driven by a strong demand for premium cars among self-employed individuals, who account for a significant portion of the Japanese economy. In contrast, sales of minicars, which account for one in three vehicles sold in the country, are expected to shrink for a second consecutive year, with deliveries of kei cars forecast to drop by 8%.

site_title: Idling of 4 jackups compounds Swissco's cash woes: observers
summary: Swissco Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine player, has suspended interest payments for a S$100 million note issue due to significant cash flow problems. Industry observers attribute the issue to the idling of four jack-ups that were supposed to be on contract off Mexico, resulting in a huge cash drain. The company has also faced trouble in its jack-up business since the 2014 oil price collapse and has recently taken delivery of a new liftboat that has not secured any work. Swissco has acknowledged its cash woes and is working on a restructuring plan with stakeholders.

site_title: Canada-US oil pipelines resume operations after activists halt flow
summary: Environmental protesters halted oil flow through five Canadian pipelines by breaking into valve stations, causing a five- to seven-hour shutdown. The pipelines, which carry 15% of US oil consumption, were restarted after safety measures were taken. Companies involved shut down the lines as a precautionary measure. The incident has raised concerns about securing key energy infrastructure, prompting policymakers and energy executives to reassess security measures.

site_title: Takata bidders, carmakers to meet this month; US$3b bid on the table: sources
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese airbag maker, is seeking a financial investor to help pay for huge liabilities from the world's biggest car recall. Five bidding groups, including Daicel Corp and US buyout firm Bain Capital, will meet with carmakers such as Toyota, Honda, and Nissan to consider options, including a $3 billion bid. The company's $1.1 billion in capital is dwarfed by recall liabilities of $10 billion, and differences over whether to put Takata through bankruptcy complicate the discussions, potentially delaying restructuring plans.

site_title: Swiss housing market less worrying: central bank
summary: The Swiss National Bank expressed slightly reduced concerns about the housing market, citing a decrease in price dynamics and mortgage volumes. Despite this, the bank still views the market as having "disequilibrium" and will continue to monitor it closely. The SNB maintains a low interest rate policy and will intervene in currency markets to combat the overvalued Swiss franc. The bank believes its current policy is appropriate and inflation expectations remain stable, with a five-year outlook.

site_title: Odinaff hacker group targeting banks with fraudulent Swift messages, warns Symantec
summary: A hacking group called Odinaff has targeted banks using fraudulent Swift messages, similar to the 2016 Bangladesh heist that yielded $81 million. Symantec Corp reported that 10-20 organizations have been infected with malware to hide fraudulent transfer requests. Most attacks occurred in the US, Hong Kong, Australia, the UK, and Ukraine. Odinaff appears to be a financially motivated group, not a nation state, unlike Lazarus, linked to the Sony hack. Symantec will share technical information with banks and governments to help thwart potential attacks.

site_title: Sentosa hotel on the market for S$300 million
summary: The Le Meridien S'pore, Sentosa hotel, previously known as Movenpick Heritage Hotel Sentosa, is being put on the market for S$300 million. The hotel is owned by Treasure Resort, majority owned by Rodney Tan and his family. Recent valuations have ranged from S$270 million to S$284 million, with prices working out to S$1.41 million and S$1.49 million per room. The hotel is being rebranded into a Le Meridien, and its future sale price may be influenced by the current demand for Singapore prime projects above S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: IEA sees faster rebalancing of oil market if Opec executes curbs
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts that oil market rebalancing could occur faster if Opec implements its agreed output cuts. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) has agreed to limit production to 32.5-33 million barrels per day, aiming to reduce the market's oversupply. However, details on quotas and implementation remain unresolved, and Brent crude prices have rallied but may drop if Opec does not meet its targets. The IEA expects demand growth to slow, and a surge in US output may occur if prices rise above $60 a barrel.

site_title: Lower occupancy hits Soilbuild Reit's Q3
summary: Soilbuild Reit's Q3 revenue and earnings were impacted by lower occupancies at its industrial properties, falling 4.7% to S$19.73 million and 2.9% to S$17.26 million respectively. The decline in gross revenue and net property income was largely attributed to lower occupancies at its industrial properties.

site_title: Creepy clown hysteria spreads to Britain
summary: Creepy clown sightings have spread to Britain, with dozens of reported incidents in recent days, including students being scared at university and girls being approached by clowns on their way to school. The trend appears to have originated in the US, where a novel and film have been blamed for fuelling the hysteria. Police have increased patrols and warned of potential injuries, while experts attribute the trend to copycat pranksters and a fear of clowns fueled by popular culture.

site_title: Singapore banks missing the boat in booming S-E Asia
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, are struggling due to domestic sluggish growth and weak interest rates, despite having significant profits from their Singapore operations. The banks have neglected opportunities in neighboring countries such as the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam, instead focusing on expanding in Greater China, resulting in slow progress and high losses. The region is booming, with countries like Indonesia and Vietnam posting double-digit gains, but the banks are missing out on the potential of the $2.4 trillion Southeast Asian market.

images.alt_text: Domestic sluggish growth, the property market slump and the weak interest rate environment have contributed to poorer earnings for the local banks.

site_title: Janet Jackson confirms she's pregnant at 50
summary: Janet Jackson, 50, has confirmed she is pregnant with her first child. The pop superstar revealed her baby bump in a People magazine portrait. She and her husband, Qatari tycoon Wissam Al Mana, had previously announced plans to start a family. This marks a rare pregnancy for a woman over 40, but in vitro fertilization can extend age limits. Jackson has been private about her personal life, but her pregnancy is seen as a continuation of her late brother Michael Jackson's non-traditional approach to family.

images.alt_text: Pop superstar Janet Jackson has confirmed that she is pregnant with her first child at age 50 - and has the baby bump to prove it.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Authorities have seized Jason Holdings non-executive director Jason Sim's 23.62% stake in the company as part of a court judgment on a claim of S$1.3 million. Shares of Jason Holdings are suspended amid claims from suppliers and creditors. Meanwhile, Otto Marine will redeem its US$70 million outstanding notes in full by Oct 21, and Swiber Holdings is unable to make the coupon payment for its S$160 million notes due on Oct 18. Perisai Petroleum Teknologi is in talks to secure financing for its S$125 million unsecured notes that came due on Oct 3.

site_title: Yum Brands' China division eyes vast stores expansion after spinoff
summary: Yum Brands' China division, Yum China, plans to expand its vast store presence in Asia's largest economy, China, with a potential tripling of its locations to about 22,000 stores. Currently, Yum China has 7,300 restaurants in the country, and the long-term expansion will give it 15 stores per million persons in China. The separation from Yum Brands will allow Yum China to operate as a highly cash-generative business with ample cash on hand, enabling investments in new restaurants and digital engagement.

site_title: Lee and Turnbull hail deep friendship and closer partnership
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the deep friendship between their countries, despite significant differences in size, culture, and resources. They praised the strong strategic interests and perspectives that underpin their relationship, including shared values on trade, security, and human rights. Turnbull thanked Lee for his role in transforming the partnership, while Lee credited founding PM Lee Kuan Yew for developing strong ties between the nations. The two leaders reaffirmed their commitment to a rules-based trade system and cooperation with China, while also seeking to deepen Australia's engagement with Southeast Asia.

site_title: US dollar climbs with stocks after Fed minutes; pound snaps selloff
summary: The US dollar rose to a seven-month high after the Federal Reserve's minutes indicated policy makers may increase interest rates "relatively soon" while maintaining a gradual approach. This boosted equities, with the S&P 500 Index rising from a one-month low. The pound also gained for the first time in five days after UK Prime Minister Theresa May accepted Parliament's involvement in her Brexit plan. Investors have increased bets on a Fed hike, with odds of a rate lift this year rising to 66%. Oil fell a second day, while 10-year Treasuries declined.

site_title: Top German court hears challenge to EU-Canada trade deal
summary: Germany's Constitutional Court began hearing a challenge to the EU-Canada free trade agreement (CETA), which three activist groups claim breaches Germany's Constitution. The groups, Campact, foodwatch, and More Democracy, oppose CETA, fearing it will undermine workers' rights and worsen consumer standards. A ruling in favor of the complaint could block the agreement's implementation before official ratification by all EU states. EU trade ministers are set to vote on CETA in a week, requiring unanimous support and ratification from national and regional parliaments.

site_title: Food delivery apps spice up Indian train journeys
summary: Passengers on India's vast railway network can now access a variety of fast food options, including Kentucky Fried Chicken and local delicacies, through food delivery apps. The services, which can be ordered with a smartphone app, aim to improve the dining experience on long journeys. This development is seen as a significant improvement over the traditional, often poor-quality meals provided by the railway network. The move is expected to enhance passenger satisfaction and provide a more convenient dining option.

site_title: Australian Open serves up MasterCard as new payments partner
summary: MasterCard has entered a three-year partnership with Tennis Australia, becoming the new official payment partner for the Australian Open and the MasterCard Hopman Cup, as well as a naming rights partner. The deal aims to boost MasterCard's presence in tennis and provide a "priceless experience" for its customers. The partnership will also include lead-up events in Singapore, Shanghai, and Tokyo, with plans to reach out to cardholders in Asia.

site_title: Search for Earth-like planet to rely on private funding
summary: A privately financed telescope, Project Blue, aims to find an Earth-like planet in the Alpha Centauri system, one of our closest cosmic neighbors. The telescope, about 50 cm in diameter, would study the light reflected off a potential planet's atmosphere for signs of life. If successful, it could be more cost-effective than a NASA mission, with an estimated cost of $25-50 million. The project, led by the BoldlyGo Institute, will rely on crowdfunding, individual donations, and partnerships with institutions like the SETI Institute.

site_title: Haze-pollution control as infrastructure investment
summary: Indonesia's palm oil producers continue to clear land through slash-and-burn methods, despite economic losses and health risks, due to lack of financial incentives to switch to non-burning methods. The Asian Development Bank estimates the 1997 costs of haze to be US$9 billion, while the cost of switching to non-burning methods is estimated at US$1.2 billion. To address this issue, financing stakeholders' costs of switching land-clearance methods is proposed, with small landholders potentially receiving rewards or subsidies for using haze-free methods. This approach aims to create a win-win situation for everyone involved, and could be a model for other cross-border environmental problems.

images.alt_text: The ADB estimated the 1997 costs of haze to be US$9 billion, and that does not include the negative images of deforestation and pollution highlighted by activists and in turn leading to a fall in FDI. Those who resent the pollution must invest US$1.2 billion to avoid the US$9 billion in costs.

site_title: Securing smart cities: key role for companies
summary: The private sector plays a crucial role in securing smart cities by developing cybersecurity talent, spurring innovation, and changing the paradigm when managing and securing data. Companies can help build a robust pipeline of talent by partnering with institutions to train cybersecurity professionals. Additionally, firms can push innovation by incorporating innovative security and privacy design thinking into their offerings and working with governments to develop industry standards and best practices. To protect data, organizations must change their paradigm, using enterprise encryption solutions that can encrypt data in transit, at rest, and across cloud and hybrid environments. By working together, corporations and governments can create a secure smart city environment.

images.alt_text: Promising security solutions that have grown in popularity include a two-step authentication process that helps protect against data thefts.

site_title: Saka closes hedge fund as low interest rates fail to generate 'sensible returns'
summary: Saka Capital, a Singapore-based hedge fund, is closing its credit hedge fund due to low interest rates failing to generate "sensible returns." The fund, which peaked at $350 million in 2012, is liquidating and returning money to investors. The company will convert into a multi-asset family office, focusing on real estate, equities, debt, and currencies, and invest in the management team and close associates.

site_title: Online prices now form part of S'pore consumer price index
summary: The Singapore Department of Statistics (DOS) has begun including online prices in the consumer price index (CPI), a measure of average price changes in goods and services. This move aims to reflect the growing trend of online shopping, which is expected to reach US$5.4 billion by 2025. Online prices will be collected through web-scraping tools and databases, but some items, such as cooked food and utilities, are not available for online purchase. Economists welcome the inclusion of online prices, but note that it may have a dampening effect on inflation.

site_title: IPOs the dominant exit for startups; but S'pore lagging in this
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem lags behind in initial public offerings (IPOs), with mergers and acquisitions (M&A) being the dominant exit for startups. According to Jeffrey Chi, chairman of the Singapore Venture Capital & Private Equity Association, the lack of startup IPOs in the country has hindered the growth of the ecosystem. Despite this, notable M&A activities have taken place in Singapore, such as Alibaba's acquisition of Lazada. The Asean Venture Council, led by the SVCA, aims to boost the VC industry in South-east Asia by facilitating collaboration among VCs and promoting entrepreneurship.

site_title: Thailand stocks, currency slump amid concern over king's health
summary: Thailand's stock market and currency plummeted amid concerns over King Bhumibol Adulyadej's health, the world's longest-reigning monarch. The King, 88, has been battling various ailments in a Bangkok hospital for nearly a year and his health remains unstable. The stock exchange closed down 2.5% and the baht fell 1% against the dollar. Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn is expected to visit his father, and Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha plans to brief him on the government's work, sparking market jitters and public prayers for the King's well-being.

site_title: Samsung slashes Q3 profit estimate by a third
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. has slashed its Q3 profit estimate by a third due to the cost of recalling its Galaxy Note7 smartphone. The company expects July-September operating profit to be 5.2 trillion won (S$6.5 billion), down from a previous estimate of 7.8 trillion won. The move comes after a global recall and weeks of mounting problems with the device, which could be one of the costliest product-safety failures in tech history, resulting in a US$2.3 billion hit.

site_title: Eurozone hopes to keep IMF in Greek bailout
summary: EU finance ministers are working to keep the IMF in the Greek bailout program, addressing concerns about Greek debt sustainability. IMF participation would provide credibility and ensure equal treatment for Greece. This comes after over a year of talks, with European Central Bank board member Benoit Coeure addressing the European Parliament committee on economic affairs. The goal is to safeguard the Greek bailout and maintain credibility in the Eurozone.

images.alt_text: ECB board member Benoit Coeure said the IMF would give the plan credibility and safeguard equal treatment for Greece.

site_title: Greatest sceptics of coal surge may be miners themselves
summary: Coal prices surged this year, driven by Chinese policy changes that cut production and reduced reliance on imports. Despite this, miners remain cautious, with many expecting the rally to be short-lived. The biggest miners, such as BHP Billiton and Glencore, are hesitant to restart operations, citing concerns over sustainability and start-up costs. Analysts predict some restarts, but warn of a lag time before mines can reopen. China's production may also change, with the authorities considering increasing output to cool prices.

site_title: Duty Free International's Q2 profit up 46% at RM13.8m
summary: Duty Free International (DFI) reported a 46% surge in its Q2 profit to RM13.8 million, driven by a 4.7% increase in revenue and foreign exchange gains. Revenue from duty-free goods and non-dutiable merchandise contributed to the growth. Despite increases in rental and employee benefits expenses, DFI aims to be growth and value-driven, focusing on enhancing retail outlets and improving product categories. The company's shares closed 2.27% higher at 45 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: On the road to a sterling crisis with a 'hard' Brexit
summary: The UK is at risk of another sterling crisis with a "hard" Brexit, following a 10% drop in sterling immediately after the Brexit vote. The country's large external current account deficit, 6% of GDP, makes it vulnerable to reduced foreign financing. A hard Brexit would likely lead to a loss of foreign capital flows, causing domestic economic policy to tighten, raising import costs, and increasing inflation. This could result in reduced living standards, lower consumption levels, and decreased business investment, ultimately harming future UK growth prospects.

site_title: Don't let poor growth outlook dampen sentiment too much
summary: Singapore's third-quarter economic growth estimates are expected to show a poor outlook, with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Trade Minister Lim Hng Kiang signaling full-year growth within the 1-2 per cent range, down from the initial 1-3 per cent estimate. This dimmer outlook is a significant shift, with two key economic policymakers issuing a bearish view before official growth estimates are released. The comments have strong signaling effects, suggesting that the country's economic growth may be weaker than expected.

site_title: Boycotting SAARC isn't the answer
summary: India and four other countries, including Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Sri Lanka, have boycotted the 19th SAARC summit in Islamabad due to the Uri attack in Jammu and Kashmir. However, boycotting SAARC is not the solution, as it would further weaken the already fragile institution. Instead, members should strengthen SAARC mechanisms, adopt a "SAARC minus x" scheme, and explore bilateralism, sub-regionalism, and inter-regionalism to boost regional integration. South Asian countries should also enhance their links with ASEAN and implement policies to link themselves to production networks in Asean.

site_title: Wells Fargo faces costly overhaul of high-pressure sales culture
summary: Wells Fargo faces a costly overhaul of its high-pressure sales culture following a scandal over unauthorized customer accounts. The bank will need to dismantle and rebuild systems of sales incentives and performance management, requiring heavy spending on hiring, training, and installing safeguards. CEO John Stumpf and President Tim Sloan have laid out responses to the scandal, including the addition of 2,000 risk management employees, but experts predict a three to five year process to rebuild the sales and management structures. The bank's reputation has been soiled, and most stock analysts have cut profit forecasts, citing fallout from the scandal.

site_title: 2015: Farewell, Mr Lee
summary: Singapore held its first post-LKY election in 2015, with the People's Action Party (PAP) securing a landslide victory. The ruling party, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, demonstrated its ability to maintain the country's economic success. Meanwhile, Noble Group faced financial difficulties after a negative report from Iceberg Research, leading to impairments and a loss of its investment-grade credit rating. The PAP's election win marked a new era for Singapore, following the death of its founding leader, Lee Kuan Yew, in 2015.

site_title: Why China's efforts to cool its property market won't work
summary: China's efforts to cool its property market, which has seen rapid price growth despite a slowing economy, are unlikely to be effective. New measures, including higher downpayments and restrictions on non-residential purchases, may temporarily cap prices but could have limited impact and even push prices up in unaffected areas. Experts suggest a more efficient approach, such as a property tax, could better address the overheating issue. The real estate sector, accounting for a quarter of China's GDP, poses a significant policy challenge for Beijing, which could have disastrous consequences for the country's economy.

site_title: US stocks edge lower; Apple gains on Samsung woes
summary: US stocks edged lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% at 18,095.58, while the S&P 500 lost 0.1% to 2,134.32. However, Apple surged 1.0% after Samsung was forced to cancel production of its Galaxy Note 7 due to battery fire concerns. Investors remain cautious amid concerns of a sixth straight quarter of declining corporate profits.

site_title: Amazon challenges Apple and Spotify with streaming service
summary: Amazon launches Amazon Music Unlimited with a subscription price of $3.99/month for Echo owners, targeting Apple and Spotify. The service offers on-demand access to a music catalogue, with additional costs for Prime members ($7.99/month) and non-Prime members ($9.99/month). Amazon believes smart home devices, like the Echo, will drive music streaming growth, and the low price signals the music industry's shift towards flexible pricing. Analysts see the move as a strategic move to undercut competition and boost Prime revenue.

site_title: PSA invests in China's railway container terminal network
summary: PSA International has invested in China United International Rail Containers Co Ltd (CUIRC), a joint venture tasked by the Chinese government to develop and operate 18 railway container terminals. The investment, made through the acquisition of Hong Kong's Luck Glory International Ltd, will extend PSA's operations in China and make it the only global terminal operator with a shareholding in CUIRC. The deal aims to grow integrated sea-rail intermodal operations in China, a market currently accounting for only 2-3% of the country's seaport container volume.

site_title: Lloyds to cut 1,340 jobs under plan to boost profits
summary: Lloyds Banking Group, Britain's largest mortgage lender, plans to cut 1,340 jobs as part of a cost-cutting program aimed at boosting profits. The move is part of a larger plan to pare 12,000 roles by 2017, with 8,680 positions already cut. The lender will create 110 new roles and offer voluntary redundancy to employees. The job losses come amid record low interest rates and the UK's Brexit vote, which has led to evaporating income from lending. The government, which owns 9% of the bank, has restarted selling shares in the company.

site_title: Too hard for EU to replicate UK financial sector for now: BoE's Cunliffe
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe stated that large chunks of London's financial sector will not replicate the UK's financial sector in the European Union for now. Some activity may shift to New York after Brexit, while Frankfurt, Paris, Luxembourg, and Dublin hope to attract business from London. Cunliffe described the City of London as a complex "ecosystem" that took years to create, making it unlikely to be replicated elsewhere.

site_title: DeClout selling 72.09% stake in Acclivis to Citic Telecom
summary: DeClout, a Catalist-listed ICT service provider, is selling 72.09% of its subsidiary Acclivis to Citic Telecom International Holdings for up to S$75 million. The sale is expected to yield S$45.6 million in gross proceeds and a disposal gain of up to S$27.9 million. Citic Telecom will acquire the cloud and managed services business firm, with DeClout chairman Vesmond Wong seeing the deal as "opportunistic" for future collaboration. The proposed sale requires shareholder approval and will be used to pay off borrowings, fund joint ventures, and working capital.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Trump as president will pose global danger, says UN human rights chief
summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra'ad al Hussein, has stated that if Donald Trump becomes US president, the world will be in danger due to his views on vulnerable communities and plans to authorize torture. Trump's comments on minorities and interrogation methods have been described as "deeply unsettling and disturbing." Zeid's statement emphasizes the potential international danger posed by Trump's presidency, unless his views change.

site_title: Suburbs lead y-o-y slide in condo rents: SRX
summary: Rentals of private apartments and condos in Singapore's suburbs fell at a faster clip than in the city-fringe and Core Central Region, with Outside Central Region (OCR) seeing a 6% year-on-year decline. The trend is attributed to the completion of new units in the OCR, which will continue to impact rental prices. The overall rental index for non-landed private homes retreated 4.6% year-on-year, with HDB flat rents also declining 4.5% year-on-year. Market analysts point to weak leasing demand and economic factors as contributing to the decline.

site_title: Shell, BP hold lure of higher payouts after Brexit hurts pound
summary: The British pound's 30-year low has resulted in higher payouts for UK investors of Royal Dutch Shell and BP, two major oil companies. Despite oil's downturn, Shell and BP have maintained their payouts, with UK investors set to receive additional cash due to the weak pound. This has driven up the companies' London-listed shares. In contrast, US investors receive no benefit from the currency's decline. The companies have pledged to prioritize defending their dividends, ensuring continued payouts to UK investors.

site_title: BOJ chief again bangs the drum for monetary easing
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reaffirmed the central bank's commitment to further monetary easing if external shocks threaten its policy goals, despite IMF and World Bank consensus that the practice is losing effectiveness. Kuroda stated that the BOJ is prepared to ease policy, including lowering short-term rates, if the benefits outweigh the costs. This move comes amid concerns about the yen's rising value and the potential impact on the global financial system, with some economists warning that unconventional monetary policy could pose risks.

images.alt_text: The governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ) has once again asserted the central bank's determination to ease monetary policy further if external shocks threaten its policy goals, despite a consensus by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank that monetary easing is near the end of its effectiveness.

site_title: COE quota to shrink for 2nd straight quarter
summary: The Singaporean Certificate of Entitlement (COE) quota is set to shrink by 6.2% for the Nov to Jan 2017 period, to 24,234. Only two categories, non-passenger cars (Cat A and B) and motorcycles (Cat D), will see an increase in COE availability, with Cat C and passenger cars (Cat A and B) experiencing a decline. This marks the second consecutive quarter of COE quota contraction.

site_title: UK's May says lawmakers can debate Brexit process, no Article 50 vote
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May stated that lawmakers will have the opportunity to debate the UK's Brexit process, but ruled out a vote on triggering Article 50, which formally begins the UK's exit from the European Union. May's government has been under pressure to provide more details on its plans for the UK's departure from the bloc. The uncertainty surrounding the Brexit process has unsettled investors and markets.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday parliament would have every opportunity to debate her government's plans to leave the European Union, but ruled out letting it vote on triggering the formal Brexit procedure.

site_title: Manila formally invites UN rights official to probe killings
summary: The Philippine government has formally invited UN Special Rapporteur Agnes Callamard to investigate the thousands of killings during President Rodrigo Duterte's war on crime, amid allegations of extrajudicial killings. Since July, over 3,300 people have died in the crackdown, with the UN, EU, US, and human rights groups raising concerns. Duterte has rejected the allegations and called the campaign an internal affair. Callamard has agreed to discuss the investigation with the government, seeking guarantees for her safety and the scope of the investigation.

site_title: Opec says it raises oil output, despite deal to cut
summary: OPEC reported a 220,000-barrel-per-day increase in oil production in September to a 33.39 million-barrel-per-day high, defying its agreement to cut supply. The organization also raised its forecast for 2017 non-OPEC supply growth to 240,000 barrels per day, indicating a larger surplus in the market next year. This contradicts OPEC's September agreement to reduce supply to between 32.50 and 33.0 million barrels per day.

site_title: Foreigners cut down on emerging Asia bonds on belief US rate hike coming
summary: Foreign investors have cut their holdings in emerging Asian government bonds, particularly in South Korea, India, and Thailand, due to expectations of a US interest rate hike in December and concerns about inflation. The outflows total $2.09 billion so far this month, with South Korea experiencing the largest outflow, $2.09 billion. This follows September's outflows, and foreign investors have reduced holdings of short-term bonds, indicating a mixed sentiment towards emerging Asian debt.

site_title: Top bankers warn of risk of 2017 exodus from Britain
summary: Top bankers warn that if the UK does not retain access to the European single market after Brexit, they may start moving staff abroad as early as 2017. Senior executives from major financial institutions, including Citi and Morgan Stanley, expressed concerns about the government's tougher rhetoric on immigration and its impact on the economy. The UK's Economic Secretary to the Treasury said getting the best deal for the City of London will be a top priority in Brexit talks with the EU, with banks keen to retain "passporting" rights that allow them to sell financial services across the bloc.

site_title: US refinancing activity falls to lowest since June
summary: US mortgage refinancing activity fell 8% to its lowest level since June, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. The average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose 0.06 percentage points to 3.68%, the largest weekly increase in seven months. This rise followed encouraging domestic economic data and higher European government bond yields, sparking speculation about the European Central Bank's potential bond purchases.

site_title: Swiss raise 2017 quotas for non-EU workers
summary: Switzerland has increased its annual quota for non-EU workers from 6,500 to 7,500, allowing an additional 1,000 expert employees from outside Europe to enter the country next year. This move aims to help local companies recruit specialists and boost the economy. The decision comes after a 2014 referendum reduced immigration quotas, and parliament is currently debating a proposal to give local people hiring preference for open jobs. The move is seen as a way to curb immigration without jeopardizing trade agreements with the EU.

site_title: Pedalling for a good cause
summary: Singapore's OCBC Cycle, the largest cycling event in the city-state, drew 6,800 participants for its second edition. The event featured competitive and non-competitive rides, with companies participating in the Cycle of Hope Corporate Bike Ride to raise funds for various causes. A total of S$23,195 was raised, with Yinson Production being the largest donor. Minister Grace Fu joined the cyclists on the second day of the event, which took place over the weekend of Oct 1-2 at the Singapore Sports Hub.

site_title: Property market fever cools in China's Hainan
summary: China's property market in Hainan province showed a slowdown in the first nine months, with property investment growth falling to 2.5% from 12.2% in the first five months. Sales area growth rate also dropped to 46.4% from 51.4% in the first four months. However, property sales in Hainan are expected to rebound as the traditional peak sales season approaches, according to official data.

site_title: ASL Marine seeks more time to hold AGM, release Q1 2017 results
summary: ASL Marine Holdings is seeking a one-month extension to November 30 to hold its annual general meeting and release Q1 2017 results. The company cited needing a commitment letter from capital providers for new facility loans to finalize financial statements and annual report for FY2016. ASL Marine has also applied for a one-month extension to release 1Q results ended September 2016 to December 14, citing the need to compare financial information against FY2016 audited statements.

site_title: US small-business uncertainty gauge stays close to record
summary: US small business owners are experiencing high levels of uncertainty, with the National Federation of Independent Business's Uncertainty Index staying close to a record high of 86, according to a recent survey. The main concerns include uncertainty about the economy and government legislation, with 25% of owners citing this as a critical problem. The uncertainty gauge has been at a record high since September, amid the presidential election.

site_title: EU bank crisis rules having negative impact on sector: BOI
summary: The European Union's new bank crisis rules are having a negative impact on the sector, according to the Bank of Italy's director general. The rules, which shield taxpayers but hit retail investors first, undermine confidence in the system and are particularly concerning in Italy where many citizens have invested their savings in banks. Italy, along with other EU countries, is critical of the rules, which have been gradually introduced over the past few years. The combined effect of the rules and European Commission policies on state aid for struggling banks is deemed "overall negative" by the Bank of Italy.

site_title: Post-Brexit, EU's military powers argue for common defences
summary: France, Germany, Italy, and Spain have joined forces to push for a common European defence policy, seeking to maintain momentum after the UK's Brexit vote. The four countries have proposed sharing assets and deepening cooperation in EU missions, with a focus on increasing European spending, jointly developing assets, and expanding peacekeeping abroad. The proposal aims to strengthen the EU's military presence and give its foreign policy more clout, while assuaging concerns in Britain that the EU is planning a rival to NATO.

site_title: Potential oil output deal prompts another worry: a shortage
summary: Industry executives express concern over a potential supply shortage due to the sharp drop in oil investment following the oil price crash. Over $1 trillion in oil projects have been cancelled or delayed, with many fields taking years to develop. OPEC and non-member producers are working on a global production cap for at least six months, but experts warn of a potential shortage by 2020, with new projects adding only 1 million barrels of oil equivalent per year.

site_title: Court seizes Jason director's entire 23.62% stake
summary: Singapore-based timber flooring supplier Jason Holdings has had its non-executive director Jason Sim's 23.62% stake seized by authorities as part of a court judgment. The seizure was for S$1.3 million, stemming from a claim brought by CIMB Securities. Shares of Jason are currently suspended amid multiple claims from suppliers and creditors. Police have also interviewed Sim and employees related to Jason's main operating subsidiary, Jason Parquet Specialist (Singapore) Pte Ltd.

site_title: Lower occupancy hits Soilbuild Reit's Q3 DPU
summary: SOILBUILD Business Space Reit reported a 13.9% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.399 Singapore cents for its Q3 2016, down from 1.625 cents a year ago. Lower occupancy led to a 4.7% decline in gross revenue to S$19.7 million and a 2.9% drop in net property income to S$17.3 million. The reduction in revenue was largely attributed to lower occupancy at West Park BizCentral and Tuas Connection.

site_title: DeClout to sell subsidiary to China's Citic Telecom International for S$75m
summary: DeClout is selling its 72.09% stake in Acclivis Technology and Solutions to Citic Telecom International for up to S$75 million, with a disposal gain of up to S$27.9 million and 158% premium over the net asset value. The transaction is expected to yield positive financial impact, with gross proceeds of up to S$45.6 million. DeClout has requested a trading halt on its shares, which were last traded at 21.5 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Duty Free International Q2 earnings shoot up 46% to RM13.8m
summary: Duty Free International's Q2 earnings surged 46% to RM13.8 million, driven by revenue growth of 4.7% to RM157.0 million, mainly from duty-free goods and non-dutiable merchandise. Earnings per share expanded to 1.2 sen, while net asset value per share rose to 45.56 sen. No dividend was proposed, and shares closed 2.27% higher at 45 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Physical oil traders not convinced by upbeat futures market outlook
summary: Physical oil traders remain skeptical about the market outlook despite upbeat futures market optimism, citing a supply glut and discounts in spot markets. Financial investors, however, remain bullish, driven by Opec's production cut plan and a collapse in the gold to oil ratio. Experts warn that while the market may rebalance, the reality is that global oil production exceeds consumption, leading to concerns about a potential price fall.

images.alt_text: Tension is brewing in the oil market as the optimism of financial players who have poured cash into crude futures is not shared by physical players who keep cutting sale prices in a tough fight to secure customers amid an ongoing supply glut.

site_title: Otto Marine to redeem US$70m outstanding notes in full
summary: Otto Marine, an offshore vessel-builder, will redeem its US$70 million outstanding notes in full by October 21. The move comes after the company was delisted from the Singapore Exchange on October 7, following an offer by its controlling shareholder to buy shares at S$0.32. The firm cited challenging market conditions for the offshore and marine industry as the reason for its financial struggles. Despite being financially stretched, Otto Marine aims to honor its debt obligations to noteholders and maintain trust.

site_title: Wild swings are a regular occurrence in HK market
summary: A Hong Kong civil engineering stock, Luen Wong Group Holdings Ltd, has seen its market value jump 6,715% after its initial public offering (IPO) in April, making it the world's best-performing new listing this year. Analysts attribute the surge to a combination of factors, including quirks in Hong Kong's stock market, mainland Chinese firms buying companies for reverse takeovers, and the firm's tightly controlled shares. The stock's performance highlights the volatility of Hong Kong's small-company exchange, the Growth Enterprise Market (GEM), which regulators are reviewing to address extreme price fluctuations and other concerns.

site_title: IOC says confident on free internet for Beijing 2022 Olympics
summary: The International Olympics Committee (IOC) is confident that China will guarantee uncensored internet access for the 2022 Winter Games, despite China's strict internet controls. China has promised to provide an open internet during the Games, but journalists have previously experienced blocked access to sensitive sites during the 2008 Summer Olympics. The IOC's Vice President, Juan Antonio Samaranch Jr, stated that China has delivered on its promises in the past, and the organization is confident that the 2022 Games will be no exception.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The COE quota shrinks 6.2% to 24,234 for the November 2016 to January 2017 period, marking the second consecutive quarter of contraction. Non-landed private home rents eased 0.6% and HDB rents dropped 0.3% in September. Swissco Holdings' shares were suspended amid debt restructuring and lawsuits. The Singapore-Australia partnership was highlighted by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The Straits Times Index dropped 1.5% on Wednesday, while global markets were affected by US tariffs and economic concerns, including Vietnam's surprise reaction and China's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Toyota, Suzuki say exploring possible partnership
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and Suzuki Motor Corp are exploring a potential business partnership to increase industry cooperation on future technologies. The joint briefing is scheduled for Tokyo, but details remain unclear. This announcement comes after Toyota's recent buy-out of Daihatsu Motors, while Suzuki specializes in minivehicles. The partnership aims to leverage each company's strengths in the automotive industry.

site_title: Opec has 'firm commitment' from Putin that Russia will join deal
summary: President Vladimir Putin has given Opec a "very firm commitment" that Russia will join an oil production limit accord, according to Opec Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo. Talks with Russia have been "very constructive," and Opec is confident of Russia's commitment. This development could help stabilize global oil markets, which have been impacted by the Trump administration's bearish tariff outlook. The agreement would limit oil production for the next four years, aiming to balance supply and demand.

site_title: Swiss attorney general opens criminal probe of Falcon in 1MDB case
summary: Switzerland's Office of the Attorney General has opened a criminal probe against Zurich-based Falcon Private Bank for allegedly failing to prevent money laundering linked to 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB). The probe follows sanctions imposed by Swiss financial watchdog FINMA and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Tuesday. The OAG statement said the alleged failures could have been prevented if Falcon Private Bank was adequately organized. This move is part of ongoing investigations into 1MDB's alleged misuse of funds.

images.alt_text: Switzerland's Office of the Attorney General (OAG) has opened criminal proceedings against Zurich-based Falcon Private Bank over its alleged failure to prevent suspected money laundering linked to Malaysian state fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB).

site_title: Catholic Church urges government to monitor gambling situation
summary: The Catholic Church in Singapore has urged the government to closely monitor the recent introduction of online betting services by two lottery operators. Archbishop William Goh warned the community to take measures to help those who may fall victim to online gambling. The Church's statement comes as concerns grow about the potential negative impact of online betting on vulnerable individuals.

site_title: Lloyds to cut 1,340 jobs in UK under plan to boost profits
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc, Britain's largest mortgage lender, plans to cut 1,340 jobs as part of a cost-cutting program aimed at boosting profits. The move is part of a plan to pare 12,000 roles by 2017, with 110 new positions to be created. The job losses are within retail banking, operations, finance, and customer products and marketing. The lender will offer voluntary redundancy and consider compulsory redundancies as a last resort. The move comes as the company seeks to offset evaporating income from lending amid record low interest rates following the UK's Brexit vote.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares follow Asia lower on worries over US rates, Brexit
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.6% to 23,407.05 points on Wednesday, following Asian markets lower due to rising US presidential election uncertainty, a possible US rate hike, and Brexit negotiations. The recent decline in the British pound and fears of yuan depreciation also contributed to the market weakness. All main sectors declined, with raw material shares leading the drop.

site_title: Samsung offers refund to Singapore customers following Note7 recall, discontinuation
summary: Samsung is offering refunds to Singapore customers who purchased the recalled Galaxy Note7, with an option to exchange it for another device. The refund amount and whether consumers can switch to rival products are unclear. This decision comes after the company pulled the plug on its flagship device just two months after its launch.

site_title: Perisai in talks with potential financier, hopes for deal on S$125m of overdue notes
summary: Perisai Petroleum Teknologi, an oil and gas contractor, is in talks with a potential financier to secure financing for S$125 million of overdue notes. The notes came due on October 3, with bondholders rejecting a proposed restructuring plan. Perisai had received an indicative offer of financing, including a US$20 million amount for the noteholders. The talks may pave the way for a deal, which would help the company address its debt issues.

images.alt_text: EZRA Holdings associate company Perisai Petroleum Teknologi is in talks with a financial institution to secure financing that may pave the way for a deal on S$125 million of 6.875 per cent unsecured notes that came due on Oct 3, Perisai announced on Wednesday after the market closed.

site_title: PSA invests in China's inland railway container terminal network
summary: PSA International has invested in China United International Rail Containers Co Limited (CUIRC), a joint venture tasked by the Chinese government to develop and operate 18 railway container terminals. The investment, made through the acquisition of Hong Kong's Luck Glory International, will make PSA the only shareholder with global terminal operations. The deal aligns with PSA's overall strategy for China and aims to develop synergies with CUIRC for integrated sea-rail intermodal operations.

images.alt_text: PORT operator PSA International has invested into a Sino-foreign joint venture tasked by the Chinese government with developing and operating 18 railway container terminals within the country.

site_title: Sony enters virtual reality race with PlayStation VR headset
summary: Sony enters the virtual reality market with the PlayStation VR headset priced at $399, aiming to compete with rivals like Oculus Rift ($599) and Vive ($799). The headset is designed to plug into PlayStation 4 consoles, targeting 40 million existing users. Sony hopes to lure customers with its modest price tag and expand into music and film content. The market is expected to grow significantly, with cumulative shipments predicted to reach 40 million by 2020, worth $10 billion.

site_title: Germany's top court hears challenge to EU-Canada trade deal
summary: Germany's Constitutional Court is hearing a challenge to the EU-Canada free trade deal, CETA, amid concerns it will undermine workers' rights and worsen consumer standards. Three German activist groups collected 125,000 signatures, arguing CETA breaches Germany's constitution. A ruling in favor of the complaint could block the accord's implementation before official ratification by all EU states. The court's decision will influence whether CETA goes through, with EU trade ministers set to vote on it next week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 1.69 points to 1,667.03. The index saw 1.6 billion lots traded, with 355 gainers and 398 losers.

site_title: Samsung cuts profit, sales outlook after killing Note 7
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. has cut its third-quarter profit and sales outlook due to the discontinuation of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones, which were plagued by a fire hazard. The company now expects an operating profit of 5.2 trillion won (S$6.36 billion) compared to 7.8 trillion won. Revenue will also be lower at 47 trillion won, down from 49 trillion won. This is the deepest crisis in Samsung's history.

site_title: Kirin to buy stake in Brooklyn brewery in craft beer chase
summary: Kirin Holdings Co will acquire a 25% stake in Brooklyn Brewery, a craft beer company in Brooklyn, New York. The joint venture will launch the Brooklyn brand worldwide in January 2017. Kirin will issue new shares for the deal, and Brooklyn Brewery will remain independent with its management unchanged. The companies did not disclose the deal's value. This move is part of Kirin's expansion into the US craft beer market, which is growing in both the US and Japan.

images.alt_text: Kirin Holdings Co will acquire about a 25 per cent stake in a Brooklyn craft beer company, jumping on the specialty lager trend that's fast-growing in the US and Japan.

site_title: Australia sells A$7.6b of 30-year debt in record deal
summary: Australia's government sold A$7.6 billion in its largest-ever 30-year bond, with yields on benchmark 10-year debt jumping to a six-month high. The new March 2047 securities were priced at 3.27% to yield. The deal, managed by the bank, further extends Australia's yield curve following the sale of 2039 bonds last year, offering "relative value against swaps" and comparable overseas notes.

site_title: Top Glove raises dividend despite Q4 profit drop
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a 36.1% drop in Q4 net profit to RM65.6 million. Revenue increased 1.8% to RM722.1 million. Despite the decline, the company raised its final dividend per share to 8.5 sen from 6 sen in the previous year. The net asset value per share rose to RM1.46 from RM1.30.

site_title: Australian counter-terror police arrest two teens
summary: Australian counter-terror police arrested two 16-year-old boys in Sydney on Wednesday, seizing two knives. The arrest was made in Bankstown, southwest of Sydney, and the pair is in custody. No charges have been filed, but the incident comes after a 22-year-old man stabbed a 59-year-old grandfather in Sydney in June, with both incidents linked to an IS call to target high-profile Australian sites. Australian officials have prevented 10 terror attacks on home soil in the past two years.

site_title: Oil holds above US$50 as Russia sends mixed messages on output cut
summary: Oil prices remain above $50 a barrel amid uncertainty over Russia's commitment to reducing output. Russia's largest producer, Rosneft, questioned the need for output cuts, despite President Putin's earlier statement that Russia would join Opec efforts to stabilize the market. The Opec Secretary-General said most work on a supply deal is done, with countries including Russia, Azerbaijan, Algeria, and Venezuela set to meet to discuss details. The mixed messages from Russia have caused oil futures to remain little changed in New York.

images.alt_text: Oil held above US$50 a barrel amid uncertainty over Russia's willingness to join Opec efforts to stabilise the market.

site_title: China regulator to tighten financing rules for property developers
summary: China's securities regulator plans to tighten rules for listed real estate firms to curb excessive capital flowing into the property market. The Shanghai Stock Exchange will require companies to issue corporate bonds with a minimum AA rating and meet one of four conditions, which are yet to be specified. The move aims to reduce speculation and slow down the country's rapidly growing property market, which has raised concerns about China's ballooning debt. This follows a wave of restrictions imposed on housing markets in major cities, including higher mortgage downpayments.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker after Wall Street's Tuesday selloff
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1.5% on Wednesday to 2,813.71, with 2 billion units traded worth S$1.3 billion, amid US market selloff. Earnings worries and interest rate concerns were cited as main factors. The US Federal Open Markets Committee minutes released this week may indicate whether US rates are to be raised in December, further impacting global markets.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady, although Ericsson slumps
summary: European stock markets remained steady on Wednesday, with the STOXX 600 index rising 0.1%. Germany's DAX and Britain's FTSE 100 index also edged up. However, Sweden's Ericsson dropped 16% to its lowest point since 2008 due to a profit warning, while Nokia fell 6%. Other top risers included Deutsche Lufthansa, which gained 4.6% after an upgrade, and Ryanair and easyJet. The decline in Ericsson was attributed to a downturn in its mobile broadband business.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at more than 6-week low on US dollar strength
summary: The South Korean won dropped to a six-week low against the US dollar, closing at 1,123.6 won per dollar, down 0.3% from the previous day. Foreign investors sold 548.1 billion won worth of Korean shares, while institutions bought 619.3 billion won worth. Despite this, South Korean shares ended 0.1% higher at 2,033.73 points, with institutional buying offsetting foreign selling.

site_title: Duterte job-approval rating hits 86% despite drug war criticism
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's job-approval rating stands at 86% three months into his presidency, despite international criticism of his deadly drug war that has resulted in over 3,000 deaths. The rating, conducted by Pulse Asia Research Inc, also shows a 86% "trust rating" for the president, down five points from three months ago. Duterte's tough stance on the drug war has led to global condemnation, including from the US and UN, but has not deterred his popularity among Filipino voters.

site_title: China auto sales increase 29% as demand thins dealer inventory
summary: China's passenger vehicle sales surged 29% in September, driven by consumers seeking to beat an expiring tax cut, which led to clearing of inventory on dealer lots. The sales growth was led by small-car makers Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd and Mazda Motor Corp. If the tax cut is not extended, sales could plummet next year, potentially worsening a capacity glut and denting profit margins. Dealers are preparing stocks for the year-end surge in demand.

site_title: Thai stocks fall to 3-1/2 month lows on domestic concerns
summary: Thailand's main stock index plummeted 3.0% to 3-1/2 month lows, led by aviation and tourism industry shares, amid concerns over a Bangkok bomb plot and the health of 88-year-old King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who received haemodialysis treatment. The Thai baht fell to 35.51 baht to the US dollar, the lowest in four months, and Thai stocks have lost 6.6% since Sunday. The king's health and potential succession issues have fueled domestic concerns, making Thai stocks vulnerable to regional market sell-offs.

site_title: Toyota recalls 340,000 Priuses globally to fix parking brake issue
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is recalling 340,000 Prius hybrid models globally to fix a parking brake issue. The recall affects models produced between October 2015 and October 2016, with 210,000 in Japan and 92,000 in North America. No reported accidents in Japan, but some overseas. The balance of the recall will be conducted in Europe, Australia, and other regions.

site_title: Surge in renminbi usage by Singapore firms but pace may taper: HSBC
summary: HSBC found that Singapore firms are the largest adopters of renminbi outside of Greater China, with 26% of companies surveyed using the yuan. This rate is nearly twice the 15% usage rate from last year. However, HSBC expects the pace of adoption to "taper in future." The bank's survey polled 1,600 business decision makers from companies worldwide that conduct business with or from China.

site_title: Aussie shares end flat as commodities weigh; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Wednesday, weighed down by losses in commodities and a weak Australian dollar, which hit a three-week low. Materials and energy stocks, including BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals, declined. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell, closing at a 12-week low, with tech stocks leading the losses.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall as yen recovers
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 1.09% to 16,840.00, amid a pick-up in the yen and a dip in oil prices. Exporters sagged, while energy firms were hit by the decline in oil prices. The broader Topix index also fell 1.03%. The yen's recovery and tariff uncertainty contributed to the decline.

site_title: Top bankers warn of risk of 2017 exodus from Britain
summary: Top bankers warn that the UK's decision to leave the EU could lead to a mass exodus of staff to other countries as early as 2017 if the government doesn't clarify its stance on retaining access to the single market. Senior executives from major financial institutions, including Citi and Morgan Stanley, expressed concerns over the government's tougher rhetoric on immigration, which they believe could harm the economy. The bankers emphasized the importance of maintaining "passporting" rights, which allow them to sell financial services across the EU, to avoid relocating operations.

site_title: Real estate fund manager Standard Life sets up Singapore team
summary: Standard Life Investments has set up a four-person team in Singapore, led by Wong Choon Wah as CEO of the Singapore office, which will be based at Ocean Financial Centre. Wong, who also serves as head of Asia-Pacific real estate, reports to Mike Hannigan, head of international real estate. This move marks the European asset manager's expansion in Singapore, further solidifying its presence in the region's real estate market.

site_title: Fed minutes could show depth of hawkish rebel camp in FOMC
summary: The Federal Reserve's September policy meeting minutes are set to be released, potentially revealing the depth of hawkish dissent among FOMC members. Three officials dissented from the decision to keep rates in a range of 0.25-0.5%, with Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren citing concerns over inflation and financial stability. The minutes may provide insight into the Fed's deliberations and potentially shift expectations for a December rate hike, currently assigned a two-thirds chance by investors.

site_title: China targets parents in new religion rules for Xinjiang
summary: China has introduced new education rules in Xinjiang, targeting parents who encourage or force their children into religious activities. Those reported to the police will face penalties. The move comes amid unrest in the region, where hundreds have died in recent years in violence blamed on Islamist militants and separatists. The government denies committing abuses and claims the rights of the Uighur people are protected. The rules aim to control the spread of Islamic influence in schools.

images.alt_text: Parents and guardians in China's heavily Muslim region of Xinjiang who encourage or force their children into religious activities will be reported to the police, the government said on Wednesday while unveiling new education rules.

site_title: Indonesia's "Whisper Cinema" brings movies to the blind
summary: Indonesia's "Whisper Cinema" offers free monthly movie screenings for the visually-impaired, with personal commentators describing each scene to help them experience films. The initiative, launched in January 2015, aims to promote inclusivity and acceptance of people with visual impairments. Founder Cici Suciati puts local films on at a 50-seat cinema, where volunteers commentate on social media, providing a unique opportunity for the blind to enjoy movies. The project seeks to widen the horizons of visually-impaired individuals and promote social inclusion.

images.alt_text: Siswanto was born blind, but is now a regular at the movies since the "Whisper Cinema", a small, free monthly club aimed at bringing the silver screen to Indonesia's visually-impaired started last year.

site_title: Amazon challenges Apple and Spotify with new music streaming service
summary: Amazon has launched "Amazon Music Unlimited", a full-fledged music streaming service with subscription options as low as $3.99 per month for Echo owners. The service offers a vast catalog of songs on demand and is available on Echo devices, smartphones, and tablets. Amazon is counting on the Echo's voice control capabilities to set it apart, with plans to use AI to provide personalized recommendations and improve user experience. The low price is consistent with Amazon's strategy of undercutting the competition, and the company believes it will expand the music streaming market.

site_title: Rebel Hong Kong lawmakers challenge China in parliament
summary: Hong Kong lawmakers, including pro-democracy advocates, challenged China's authority during their oath-taking ceremony in parliament, citing concerns over the erosion of freedoms under the "one country, two systems" deal. The lawmakers, including Nathan Law, Baggio Leung, and Yau Wai Ching, modified their oaths to express their desire for self-determination and independence. The government warned that those who refused to take the oath properly risked losing their seats, but it's unclear whether any will be barred from taking up their seats.

site_title: Lawyers 'will not defend' main Paris attacks suspect
summary: Lawyers for Paris attacks suspect Salah Abdeslam announced they will no longer defend him, citing his refusal to answer questions and the intense surveillance of his jail cell. Abdeslam has been in jail since his arrest in March after four months on the run, and investigators still have not pinned down his exact role in the November attacks that killed 130 people. The lawyers' decision was made after feeling like they were making "social visits" to the prison, indicating a lack of progress in the case.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge higher led by techs, financials
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.3% to 9,244.99 points, driven by technology and financial shares. Electronics subindex gained 0.5% and financials subindex rose 0.7%. TSMC and Inotera's shares increased ahead of TSMC's earnings report and Inotera's deal with Micron Technology. The Taiwan dollar eased to NT$31.616 per US dollar.

site_title: China's yuan firms, supported by elevated borrowing costs in Hong Kong
summary: China's yuan firmed slightly against the US dollar, supported by elevated offshore borrowing rates in Hong Kong. The offshore yuan borrowing rate rose to 2.82838%, the highest level since Sept 21, forcing investors to prop up the Chinese currency. The yuan's spot rate rose to near the 6.72 level, 5 pips firmer than the previous late session close. Despite this, many believe the yuan will depreciate gradually to around 6.8 by the end of the year, and some traders are wary of possible central bank intervention.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell in the first minutes of trade on Wednesday, mirroring losses on Wall Street due to a weak US earnings season start. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.69% to 23,386.11, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.26% to 3,057.32. The decline was attributed to investor spookedness over the US earnings season, with global markets tracking losses.

site_title: Food delivery apps spice up Indian train journeys
