summary: India's vast railway network is introducing food delivery services through apps, offering passengers a wide range of hot dishes, including fast food and local delicacies. The new services, part of the modernization plan, aim to improve the quality of railway food after years of complaints about inedible meals. Companies such as Kentucky Fried Chicken and Domino's are partnering with Indian Railways, while private entrepreneurs are also trying to tap the market, targeting long-distance trains with limited food services. The goal is to provide faster and more convenient food delivery to passengers.

site_title: Fewer car COEs in next quota
summary: The Singapore government has announced a 6.2% contraction in the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) quota for the November 2016 to January 2017 period, with only two categories - Category C (goods vehicles and buses) and Category D (motorcycles) - expected to expand. Category A (cars below 1,600cc and 130hp) will suffer the biggest cut of 8.2% to 3,688 COEs each month. The decrease is attributed to slower vehicle deregistrations.

site_title: Obama tells students at town hall about how failures have shaped him
summary: President Barack Obama shared his experiences of failures and setbacks at a town hall event, discussing how they shaped him. He recounted the fallout from his first presidential debate and losing his first campaign for a US congressional seat in 2000, which humbled him and contributed to his later success. Obama also spoke about the importance of using platforms to speak to issues, citing childhood sports heroes Muhammad Ali and Arthur Ashe, who both brought about change through their activism.

site_title: Samsung phone recall portends Android turf war
summary: Samsung's recall of the Galaxy Note 7 due to fire hazards may lead to a turf war among Android smartphone manufacturers, with LG and Google gaining share. Despite the reputational damage, Samsung will remain competitive in the premium market. Google's newly released Pixel phones may attract consumers seeking an alternative to Samsung. Apple is expected to benefit from the shift, with some consumers switching to the iPhone 7. Analysts note that a hardware problem won't change a customer's preference for software systems, but Samsung's withdrawal creates a slightly bigger opening for other Android manufacturers.

site_title: Malaysia August factory output picks up 4.9% y-o-y, but misses forecast
summary: Malaysia's August industrial production rose 4.9% from a year earlier, exceeding July's 4.1% growth but missing economists' forecast of a 5.4% rise. The increase was driven by growth in the electricity, manufacturing, and mining sectors. Exports rose unexpectedly in August, fueled by higher shipments of manufactured goods and rising palm oil prices. However, a private manufacturing index showed factory activity contracted for the 18th straight month in September due to declining new orders and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Death of Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 set to hurt Vietnam exports
summary: Vietnam's economy is expected to be hurt by the recall of Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 smartphones, which represents about 20% of the country's exports. The recall led to a $1.1 billion decline in exports in September, contributing to the country's struggle to meet its 6.7% economic growth target. Vietnam's annual economic growth accelerated to 6.4% last quarter, but the loss of exports from Samsung, the country's largest exporter, poses a significant challenge. The recall has already impacted Vietnam's exports, and the country faces the loss of millions of dollars in exports at a time of economic struggle.

images.alt_text: The fallout from Samsung Electronics Co's dramatic move to end production of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone is set to spread to Vietnam, hurting an economy already hit by drought and lower oil prices.

site_title: Construction Bank plans 24b yuan debt relief for Wuhan Steel
summary: China Construction Bank plans to raise 24 billion yuan with Wuhan Iron & Steel Group to help lower the steelmaker's debt levels. The fund, the first in China to target state-owned enterprises, will invest in shares and take over maturing debt. The move aims to tackle excessive corporate leverage, with corporate debt at 165% of China's GDP in 2015. The fund may help lower Wuhan Steel's leverage ratio by 10 percentage points. This is part of China's efforts to reduce corporate debt, following government guidelines released earlier this week.

images.alt_text: China Construction Bank Corp, the nation's second-largest lender, said it plans to raise 24 billion yuan (S$5 billion) with Wuhan Iron & Steel Group for a fund that will help lower the unprofitable Chinese steelmaker's debt levels.

site_title: IPO candidate JR Kyushu seeks South-east Asia property deals
summary: JR Kyushu, a Japanese state-owned railway company, plans to invest in South-east Asia properties to reduce its reliance on Japan, where it generates almost all of its revenue. The company aims to spend 80 billion yen over three years on non-rail sectors, with sales forecast to increase to 400 billion yen by 2019. JR Kyushu plans to expand its non-rail sales to 62% of revenue by 2019, driven by a tourism boom in Japan and shifting interests of Asian tourists. The company is set to raise up to 416 billion yen in an initial public offering.

site_title: Australia coal rush to boost economic growth, prop up interest rates
summary: Australia is expected to see a boost in economic growth, trade deficit erasure, and interest rates being held steady, thanks to a surge in coal prices. Reports suggest Japanese steel makers have agreed to double the price of coking coal to $200 a tonne, while thermal coal prices have climbed 40% in three months. This could wipe out the country's trade deficit and jumpstart nominal economic growth, potentially lifting annual growth to 5% from 3%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is also expected to keep interest rates unchanged.

site_title: Yum's China unit eyes vast stores expansion after US spinoff
summary: Yum! Brands, the US fast-food giant, is set to spin off its China unit, Yum China, which will operate independently on the New York stock exchange starting November 1. The company plans to expand Yum China's presence to around 22,000 stores in China, tripling its current 7,300 locations. The separation aims to boost shareholder value and reduce costs, with Yum China expected to have over $900 million in cash reserves. The move will also allow Yum to focus on its US business, which faces challenges from sluggish consumer spending and increased competition.

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat on prospects of US rate hike
summary: Asian markets retreated on Wednesday due to concerns over a potential US interest rate hike, with investors spooked by below-forecast earnings from Alcoa. Samsung Electronics suffered further losses, extending its decline to 11% after scrapping the Galaxy Note 7 due to exploding battery issues. The Nikkei index fell 0.6%, while the Hang Seng Index dropped 0.9%. The US dollar rallied, and the pound showed some respite, edging up 1.5 cents against the greenback. Markets await the release of Federal Reserve minutes to gauge the bank's plans for lifting borrowing costs.

site_title: Apple to set up R&D centre in Shenzhen, bolster China ties
summary: Apple to set up a research and development centre in Shenzhen, China, as part of its efforts to spur growth in the world's second-largest economy. The move follows a similar plan for a centre in Beijing and aims to counter growing competition from local rivals like Huawei and Vivo. Apple's CEO Tim Cook announced the plan during a meeting with Shenzhen officials, seeking to bounce back in China where the company has lost market share. The centre is expected to bolster Apple's ties with China and support the company's growth in the region.

site_title: Non-landed private home rents eased 0.6% m-o-m in Sept, HDB rents down 0.3%: SRX
summary: Rentals for non-landed private homes and HDB flats in Singapore decreased month-over-month in September 2016, with private apartments and condos down 0.6% and HDB flats down 0.3%. Non-landed private homes saw a 14.2% decline in rentals, while HDB flats declined 11.3%. The rental index for private apartments and condos has contracted 4.6% year-over-year from September 2015, while the HDB flat index has shed 4.5%.

site_title: Gold holds decline as investors await Federal Reserve minutes
summary: Gold prices held steady despite a 0.5% decline on Tuesday, awaiting the release of Federal Reserve minutes for signals on the timing of the next interest rate hike. The metal has rallied 25% this year, but investors are cautious due to the looming probability of higher US borrowing costs, which would boost the US dollar and reduce gold's appeal. The Federal Open Market Committee's September meeting record may provide insight into Fed Chair Janet Yellen's pressure to tighten monetary policy, potentially leading to bearish gold prices in the near-term.

site_title: World's best IPO sees 6,000% gain as analysts say to stay away
summary: Luen Wong Group Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong civil-engineering stock, saw a 6,715% gain after its April IPO, becoming the world's best-performing new listing this year. The company's sales and profit were reported at $41 million and $1.1 million, respectively. Analysts, including Francis Lun, urge caution, citing quirks in Hong Kong's stock market and the firm's tightly controlled shares, which may have contributed to the price surge. This phenomenon highlights the volatility of Hong Kong's Growth Enterprise Market, with 56 companies experiencing a 1,000% market value increase between 2013 and 2015, despite 39 of them being losing money.

site_title: Singapore-Australia partnership greater than the sum of its parts: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country's partnership with Australia is greater than the sum of its parts, despite significant differences between the two nations. Australia's size and natural resources contrast with Singapore's lack of resources, while their societies have distinct ethnic compositions. Lee highlighted the shared outlook and ethos between the two countries, resulting in a "deep friendship." This partnership has been fostered through their cooperation on various issues, showcasing the strength of their bilateral relationship.

site_title: Australia shares slide on commodities; NZ hits 12-week low
summary: Australian shares fell 0.84% to a 3-month low, dragged down by a weak Australian dollar and commodities. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,433.6 points. Global miner BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto shed 2% each, while energy stocks fell 1.8% due to oil price retreats. In contrast, Tabcorp Holdings Ltd rose 2.8% after a ban on greyhound racing was reversed in New South Wales. New Zealand's benchmark index also declined 0.24% to a 12-week low, with the New Zealand dollar reaching 2-1/2 month lows.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.76 points to 1665.48. The market saw 66.8 million lots traded worth RM14.7 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 116 to 54.

site_title: Germany may tighten rules allowing failed asylum seekers leave to stay
summary: Germany is considering new legislation that would make it harder for failed asylum seekers to stay in the country. The draft law, proposed by Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere, would establish new rules for deporting migrants who have broken German law and pose a significant danger. The new rules would include stricter notification periods, increased detention times, and the removal of waivers for migrants who have misled authorities. The move comes after a series of violent attacks in Germany linked to Syrian refugees, fueling criticism of Chancellor Angela Merkel's open-door refugee policy.

site_title: Swissco stock suspended amid debt restructuring, lawsuits
summary: Swissco Holdings' shares have been suspended amid a debt restructuring plan. The offshore services provider met with noteholders on October 10 and plans to discuss further with them next week. Swissco is also involved in arbitration cases in Hong Kong to claim $26.1 million and $5.2 million. The company received a legal letter demanding $1.7 million. The stock suspension is related to the debt restructuring and ongoing disputes.

images.alt_text: OFFSHORE services provider Swissco Holdings' shares have been suspended since Wednesday morning as the group works on a debt restructuring plan, it said in a Singapore Exchange filing.

site_title: Facebook continues fight over US taxes after Ireland move
summary: Facebook is fighting with the US Internal Revenue Service over taxes related to its 2010 transfer of global operations to Ireland. The company has received seven broad summonses from the IRS, but claims it needs more time to comply. Facebook assigned a base value of $5.8 billion to the transferred assets, while the IRS estimates it at $13.9 billion. The company denied failing to respond to IRS summonses, producing thousands of documents in response to over 200 requests. Facebook is expected to provide more information in the coming days.

site_title: Seoul: Won at 3-week low on US dollar strength, Samsung shares extend plunge
summary: The South Korean won dropped to a three-week low at 1,123.4 against the US dollar, amid a global rally of the greenback. Samsung Electronics' decision to permanently end Galaxy Note 7 sales led to a 2% decline in its shares, contributing to a 0.3% drop in the Korea Composite Stock Price Index. The won's decline is attributed to the US Federal Reserve's strengthened forecast for a December rate hike, which is pressuring the currency.

site_title: Philippines set to roll out tough no-smoking law
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to sign a regulation banning smoking in public places, expanding the definition of public places to include all indoor and outdoor areas. The law, which is among the toughest anti-tobacco laws in the region, aims to reduce smoking prevalence and protect public health. The regulation is expected to come into effect next month, with Health Secretary Paulyn Jean Rosell-Ubial expressing hope that the president will sign the ban into law before the end of October. Public health campaigners have welcomed the push to end smoking in public places.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to sign a regulation this month banning smoking in public across South-east Asia's second-most populous country, rolling out among the toughest anti-tobacco laws in the region.

site_title: Asia: Stocks join global slump as pound beats back US dollar gains
summary: Asian stocks declined as the US dollar gave up gains, with Japan's Topix index falling the most this month. Samsung Electronics' woes, a weak earnings season, and concerns over US interest rates weighed on investors. Sterling rebounded against the US dollar, while emerging-market currencies fell. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped 0.4%, and futures on the S&P 500 Index rose 0.1%. Investors are focusing on corporate earnings and the Federal Reserve meeting minutes for guidance on interest-rate hikes.

site_title: Australia dollar firm on sturdy bond demand, kiwi near 2-1/2 month lows
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.5% to US$0.7579, rebounding from a three-week low, due to strong demand for a long-term government bond sale. The sale of the 2047 bond exceeded expectations, with bids exceeding A$13 billion. Analysts attributed the boost to solid appetite for Australia's high-yielding assets and a rebound in sterling after a Bloomberg report on the UK's Brexit plan. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar fell to a 2-1/2 month low, and the kiwi pushed higher on Wednesday to US$0.7093.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar inched up from a three-week low on Wednesday boosted by strong demand from investors for a long-term government bond sale, in a sign of solid appetite for the country's high-yielding assets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mermaid Maritime, Metro, Jason Marine
summary: Mermaid Maritime cut rates for two subsea and offshore services contracts in the Middle East to retain one deal and extend another. Metro Holdings reported its cash reserve came from recent property sales and expects to invest it in new ventures. Jason Marine Group announced it expects to record a net loss for its half year ended Sept 30.

site_title: Swiss banks haunted by growth in Asia as regulators probe funds
summary: Swiss private banks are facing increased scrutiny from regulators due to their involvement in the 1MDB scandal, which allegedly diverted over $3.5 billion. Enforcement actions are underway against UBS Group AG and Falcon Private Bank AG, with fines and license revocations imposed in Singapore. The scandal highlights the growing cooperation between regulators and the increasing difficulty for banks to confirm the origin of funds and the legitimacy of clients' assets. As a result, Swiss private bankers are losing clients who prefer secrecy, marking a shift away from their traditional model of relying on mystery to attract business.

site_title: 'Head Office is watching': How Falcon ignored 1MDB red flags
summary: Swiss authorities alleged serious breaches of anti-money laundering rules in Falcon Private Bank's dealings with 1Malaysia Development Bhd, a Malaysian state investment company, and a "young Malaysian businessman" with ties to the government. Falcon approved US$3.8 billion of asset transfers linked to 1MDB from 2012 to mid-2015, despite employee concerns and "conflicting evidence." The Swiss regulator found Falcon's managers failed to properly investigate business relationships with politically exposed persons and high-risk transactions. The allegations shed light on international banks aiding in the misuse of 1MDB funds meant for economic development, and Finma is considering opening a criminal case against Falcon.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.6% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.6% lower on Wednesday, shedding 17.57 points to 2,838.56, following a slide on Wall Street due to lacklustre US corporate earnings. Losers outnumbered gainers 101 to 44, with SATS and Noble Group among the most actively traded counters.

site_title: Samsung shares battered again over Note 7 woes
summary: Samsung shares plummeted 8.0% on Tuesday, wiping $17 billion off the company's market value, after it halted production and sales of the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone due to exploding battery issues. The move comes after a month-long recall, which led to reports of replacement phones catching fire. The company's reputation is severely damaged, making it vulnerable in the highly competitive premium smartphone market, particularly with Apple's new iPhone 7 and Google's Pixel smartphone launching during the holiday season.

site_title: Adviser rules out Trump meeting North Korea's Kim in near future
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's adviser, Peter Hoekstra, has ruled out a meeting with North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un in the near future. This stance takes a step back from Trump's previous willingness to talk to Kim to stop Pyongyang's nuclear program. Hoekstra cited that no circumstances would allow a summit meeting in the short or medium term, but said that all options, including preemptive strikes, would be considered to address the issue.

site_title: Japan's August core machinery orders fall 2.2% month-on-month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 2.2% in August from the previous month, contrary to a 5.5% decline forecast by economists. This marks a reversal from a 4.9% increase in July. Compared to the same period last year, core orders rose 11.6%, higher than the expected 6.5% gain. The data suggests fragility in capital expenditure, which could impact the economy in the coming months.

site_title: Yahoo says working to bring back auto forwarding feature
summary: Yahoo Inc. is working to bring back its automatic email forwarding feature, which was temporarily disabled. The feature was previously disabled following hacking and surveillance revelations. Users who set up forwarding in the past are unaffected, but those who want to switch to rival services are struggling. The move comes after Yahoo disclosed that at least 500 million user accounts were stolen from its network in 2014.

images.alt_text: Yahoo Inc said it is working to bring back its automatic email forwarding feature after a planned, temporary disablement.

site_title: Pound climbs 0.8% against US dollar, halts four-day decline
summary: The pound surged 0.8% against the US dollar, halting a four-day decline, and reached 1.2216 as of 7:52am in Tokyo. UK Prime Minister Theresa May accepted that Parliament should vote on her Brexit plan, but asked lawmakers to do so in a way that allows her to negotiate. The decision may calm investors after the pound fell 6% this month due to concerns about May's approach to negotiations.

site_title: Tokyo condo prices seen down 20% by Deutsche as BOJ shifts
summary: Deutsche Bank predicts Tokyo apartment prices may fall 20% or more by 2018 due to the Bank of Japan's shift to controlling bond yields, driving up mortgage rates. The BOJ's negative-rate policy and move to boost longer-term yields have already hurt buyer sentiment, with sales of new condominiums in Tokyo this year falling to the lowest since the 1990s. Experts expect higher interest rates and reduced borrowing costs, leading to a collapse of the "silent bubble" in the real estate market.

site_title: Electric cars could dominate roads in wealthy cities by 2030: report
summary: Electric vehicles could account for two-thirds of all cars on the road by 2030 in wealthy cities, driven by stricter emissions regulations, falling technology costs, and increased consumer interest. The cost of lithium-ion battery packs has decreased by 65% since 2010, with expectations of a further decline to below $100 per kilowatt hour over the next decade. This trend is expected to lead to widespread adoption of electric cars in cities like London and Singapore.

site_title: Investigators said to suspect new battery flaw in Samsung Note 7
summary: US investigators suspect a new battery flaw in Samsung's Note 7 smartphones, separate from the original recall issue. Preliminary evidence points to a problem with batteries made by China's Amperex Technology Ltd, which were used in replacement phones. The issue may have occurred after Samsung began replacing Note 7 phones with batteries made by Samsung SDI Co, which were slightly too large for the phone. This apparent new fault led to the sudden recall of the Note 7, which has resulted in significant financial losses for Samsung and potential damage to its brand image.

images.alt_text: Investigators believe the latest incidents of Samsung Electronics Co smartphones overheating, which prompted it to abandon its Galaxy Note 7 model, may be the result of a flaw different from the one that caused the device's original recall last month.

site_title: Apple, Samsung clash in top US court patent battle
summary: The US Supreme Court is set to decide a patent battle between Apple and Samsung, with the justices debating the value of design in a case that could have major implications for the technology sector. Samsung, ordered to pay $400 million for copying iPhone features, challenges the legal precedent requiring the forfeiture of all profits from a product if only a single design patent is infringed. The court's decision could lead to more litigations and impact the balance between technological innovation and protecting intellectual property. A ruling is expected in several months.

site_title: Hong Kong knows more about money, but France is better at managing it: study
summary: A study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) found that France ranked highest in the world on overall financial knowledge and behavior, scoring 14.9 out of 21. Hong Kong, Norway, Canada, and the UK followed closely. The US did not participate in the study, but a similar survey by the Finra Investor Education Foundation found that Americans' financial stability improved but knowledge slipped. Experts say that teaching abstract financial concepts is not enough, and that providing practical skills and knowledge is more effective in improving financial literacy.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence rises further in Oct: survey
summary: Australia's consumer confidence rose 1.1% in October, its third consecutive increase, with the sentiment index up 4.7% from October last year. Optimism about the economy and finances improved, with rate cuts from the Reserve Bank of Australia supporting the increase. The sentiment index for mortgage holders rose 2.2% and expectations for the economic outlook over the next 12 months also increased.

images.alt_text: A measure of consumer sentiment rose for a third month in October as Australians became more optimistic about the economy and their own finances for the year ahead, its compilers said on on Wednesday.

site_title: US dollar pressured by sterling's rebound from selloff
summary: The US dollar declined in early Asian trading on October 12, 2016, due to sterling's partial rebound from its dramatic losses. The pound rose 1.4% to US$1.2287, boosted by a Bloomberg report that British Prime Minister Theresa May will allow Parliament to vote on her Brexit plan. The US dollar index fell 0.2% to 97.533, while the euro remained steady. The dollar's decline was attributed to rising expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike and a potential shift in investor sentiment.

site_title: Fujitsu plans 1,800 UK job cuts
summary: Japanese IT giant Fujitsu plans to cut up to 1,800 jobs in Britain as part of a restructuring program aimed at making it more competitive in the global market. The layoffs, equivalent to 13% of its workforce, are not linked to the UK's vote to leave the EU. Fujitsu claims the cuts will enable the firm to provide better service and respond more quickly to customer needs, as part of its efforts to support customers in the era of digital transformation.

site_title: London: Stocks hit record as Samsung sinks
summary: London's FTSE 100 index reached a record high of 7,129.83 points due to a weaker pound, boosting British exporters and profits. However, Samsung Electronics plummeted over 8% after halting production of the Galaxy Note 7 and scrapping the model, impacting regional equities. US investors were cautious after Alcoa's disappointing earnings report, and major US indices fell more than 1% amid concerns about the third-quarter earnings season.

site_title: May backs down on Parliament vote over her Brexit terms
summary: Theresa May has accepted that Parliament should vote on her Brexit plan, allowing lawmakers to scrutinize her proposal before formal talks begin. The motion, supported by some Conservatives, gives lawmakers a tool to pressure May, who has a slim majority in Parliament. The decision comes as a London court is set to rule on whether May can trigger Article 50 without approval from lawmakers. The concession is seen as a concession to lawmakers favoring close ties to the EU, but its impact on Britain's departure is unlikely to be significant.

site_title: North Korea purges vice-foreign minister: report
summary: North Korea has purged its vice-foreign minister, Kung Sok-Ung, following the defection of its deputy ambassador to Britain, Thae Yong-Ho, and his family to the South in July. The purge was ordered by supreme leader Kim Jong-Un, who also expelled four other high-ranking diplomats in charge of European affairs. Kung Sok-Ung, a 72-year-old veteran diplomat, was held accountable for embassies in Europe and removed from his post and expelled to a rural farming area. This is the latest in a series of purges by Kim Jong-Un to solidify his grip on power.

images.alt_text: North Korea has purged its vice foreign minister as punishment for the recent defection of the nuclear-armed country's deputy ambassador to Britain, South Korean media reported Wednesday.

site_title: Trump lashes out at 'disloyal' Republicans
summary: US presidential hopeful Donald Trump lashed out at "disloyal" Republicans in a tweetstorm, deepening a split that threatens the future of the party. Trump declared himself unchained from party strictures, ridiculing leaders like John McCain and Paul Ryan, and vowed a 28-day campaign against Hillary Clinton. The move has fueled an intra-party war, with some Republicans saying they will vote for Clinton, while Trump fans vow to bring down Congressional leaders. The rift has raised concerns about the Republican Party's control of the House and Senate.

site_title: Google said to be reviving plan to build London HQ
summary: Google is reviving plans to build its new London headquarters in the King's Cross district, with the technology giant seeking a construction firm to build the project. The project was initially approved in 2013 but was later shelved for a more ambitious development. Google aims to start building the headquarters before the end of next year, according to sources.

site_title: Oil down on Opec doubts as it floats 6-month output cap plan
summary: Oil prices retreated from one-year highs after Opec announced a six-month output cap plan, citing doubts about its effectiveness in reducing a global crude glut. The plan aims to cut 700,000 barrels per day to 32.5-33.0 million barrels per day, but analysts question its impact due to supply uncertainty in 2017. Goldman Sachs said a deal targeting sustainably higher oil prices would be "self-defeating." Oil prices fell 1.4% to $52.41 a barrel, retreating from a one-year high of $53.73.

site_title: Personal computer sales continue to slide
summary: Personal computer sales continue to decline, with worldwide shipments totaling 68.9 million units in the third quarter of 2016, a 5.7% drop from the same period last year. This marks the eighth consecutive quarter of decline, the longest duration in industry history. PC makers face challenges, including weak back-to-school demand and low PC penetration in emerging markets, where consumers prefer smartphones and phablets for computing needs. Lenovo remains the top PC maker, but lost ground, while HP and Dell gained market share.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on weak Alcoa earnings, lower oil
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday after Alcoa's disappointing earnings, with the company's shares dropping 11.4% due to lower-than-expected earnings and a lackluster forecast. This is the third consecutive quarter of declining S&P 500 profits, leading to market caution. The disappointing earnings also raised concerns about the upcoming earnings season.

site_title: G7 boost banking cybersecurity as new Swift threat emerges
summary: The G7 group of leading economies has issued a new framework for battling financial institution hacking, following a rise in hacking incidents that have stolen client databases and millions of dollars. The two-page "Fundamental Elements of Cybersecurity" outlines principles for banks to implement cybersecurity programs, in response to threats like the "Odinaff" malware and the recent Swift network breach. The guidelines aim to defend against cyber threats and are aimed at public and private sector financial institutions. The move comes after a $81 million heist from Bangladesh's central bank using the Swift network.

site_title: Mermaid reduces rates for two Middle East contracts
summary: MERMAID Maritime Public Company has reduced rates for two Middle East contracts, aiming to retain one deal and extend another amid a challenging environment. The joint-venture company Zamil Mermaid Offshore Services Company retained a long-term offshore inspection, repair and maintenance services contract with a reputable client in the Middle East.

site_title: Singapore marina tycoon and CEO of SUTL wants Chinese travellers to set sail
summary: Singaporean tycoon Arthur Tay, CEO of SUTL Enterprise, aims to attract Chinese tourists to European marinas by offering luxury amenities such as hot towels and rice porridge breakfasts. He plans to expand its marina management to 20 locations in the next few years, targeting 120 million Chinese travelers. SUTL Enterprise, which owns a marina in New York, will compete with 5,000 European marinas with an annual turnover of 4 billion euros. Tay's expansion plans could reach $300 million per marina, and he hopes to lure affluent Asian visitors to Europe's leisure boating market.

site_title: German investor cheer could hit growth buffers: analysts
summary: German investor sentiment sharply improved in October, with the ZEW economic institute's headline index hitting 6.2 points, a 5.7-point increase from September and beating analyst predictions. Despite the positive reading, analysts warned against overconfidence due to ongoing economic risks, including concerns over Deutsche Bank's financial health and low interest rates. The index remains below its long-term average, and expectations of a "golden autumn" for German growth are being treated with caution.

site_title: Bunkering conference reaffirms its reputation
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) successfully conducted a full-deployment, multi-agency exercise, JOSE 2016, to test its preparedness for oil spill incidents. The exercise was timed with the 19th Singapore International Bunkering Conference and Exhibition (Sibcon), where MPA reaffirmed its commitment to cleaner fuel solutions. MPA has launched several LNG-related projects, including a Technical Reference (TR) for LNG bunkering standards, and is expected to see a growing fleet of LNG-fuelled vessels in Singapore's waters.

site_title: Firm linked to social media surveillance loses data access
summary: Twitter and Facebook have revoked data access for Geofeedia, an analytics firm that helped law enforcement track protesters using social media posts and location data. The American Civil Liberties Union reported that Geofeedia marketed its services to US police agencies, including a successful tracking of protests in Ferguson, Missouri. The move comes after internal documents revealed Geofeedia's capabilities, sparking concerns over social media surveillance.

images.alt_text: Twitter and Facebook on Tuesday revoked data access for an analytics firm which according to a civil liberties group helped law enforcement track protesters in social movements in US cities.

site_title: YouTube buys FameBit, matchmaker for videos and sponsors
summary: YouTube has acquired FameBit, a marketplace connecting video creators with brands interested in sponsoring their content. The deal, not disclosed in terms, aims to increase branded content opportunities. YouTube's relationship with brands and partnerships with creators, combined with FameBit's technology and expertise, will facilitate these matches. The acquisition will help YouTube expand its branded content offerings, according to YouTube product management vice president Ariel Bardin.

site_title: China Q3 GDP better than expected, says premier
summary: China's economy performed better than expected in the third quarter, with key indicators such as factory output, company profits, and investment rebounding. Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country's debt risks are under control, despite acknowledging downward pressure. China aims to achieve its annual economic growth target of 6.5-7% and maintain medium to high-speed growth. The government will take measures to ensure a stable property market and reduce high debt levels of non-financial firms.

site_title: Condo resale prices fall to lowest since 2012
summary: Singapore's condo resale prices fell 0.9% in September, the lowest level in four years, with a total of 683 units resold. Year-on-year, prices dropped 1.5% from September 2015, and 8.5% from the peak in January 2014. Resale volume also decreased 17.7% in September compared to August. Experts attribute the decline to substantial new residential completions and the total debt servicing ratio framework constraining large property loans, amid fears of an approaching recession.

site_title: Cost of a three-door bus depends on manufacturer's flexibility too
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore is considering introducing three-door buses with two staircases to improve commuter flow. Currently, only one manufacturer, Alexander Dennis Ltd (ADL), can build such a bus due to its flexibility and customisation capabilities. ADL's ability to build a bus "from scratch" without being constrained by existing frameworks allows it to develop innovative solutions tailored to individual operational requirements, potentially reducing costs by 20-25%.

site_title: Trump tax cuts would benefit the richest: study
summary: A study by the Tax Policy Center found that US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's tax cuts would primarily benefit the wealthiest Americans, with the largest benefits going to the top 10% of earners. In contrast, Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton's tax proposals could discourage investment among the wealthy. The study concluded that Trump's cuts would increase investment and boost economic growth, while Clinton's would reduce the government deficit and increase revenue. The tax cuts would result in a $6.2 trillion loss in federal revenues over 10 years, while Clinton's would bring a $1.4 trillion increase.

images.alt_text: The tax cuts promised by US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump would benefit the most well-off Americans, according to independent research published Tuesday.

site_title: Samsung sends its Galaxy Note7 to the graveyard
summary: Samsung has discontinued production and sales of its Galaxy Note7 smartphone due to ongoing reports of lithium-ion battery explosions and fires, despite a previous recall and replacement exercise. The company has asked owners to power down and stop using the device immediately. The decision is a significant blow to the company, with estimated sales of 12 million Note7 phones this year, and is expected to damage the brand's reputation for product reliability.

site_title: Russian cheesemakers celebrate sanctions, and hope they continue
summary: Russian cheesemakers celebrate the sanctions imposed on European food imports in 2014, hoping they will continue, allowing them to compete with European cheeses. Entrepreneurs like Oleg Sirota have invested in duplicating famous varieties, but duplicating Parmesan remains a challenge. Sirota sees sanctions as a catalyst for national revival and a symbol of resistance against Western pressure, and he believes the sanctions are what allow his business to thrive.

images.alt_text: For Mr Sirota, cheese is a symbol of national revival, and sanctions are his gospel.

site_title: Australia's same-sex marriage vote in doubt
summary: Australia's planned same-sex marriage vote is in doubt after the opposition Labor Party vowed to block the poll, citing concerns it would be divisive and expose same-sex couples to judgment. Labor leader Bill Shorten argued that a free vote in Parliament would be a more effective way to achieve marriage equality. Despite strong popular support, Australia lags behind other nations in allowing homosexual couples to wed. The proposed plebiscite, costing A$170 million, could be blocked by opponents in the Senate, where the government does not hold an outright majority.

site_title: Raffles Hotel to undergo 16-month restoration in stages from Jan 2017
summary: The Raffles Hotel Singapore will undergo a 16-month restoration project starting January 2017 to rejuvenate its facilities and interior design. The 3-phase project will result in the hotel being fully closed from November 2017 to May 2018, with the iconic Singapore Sling available at the Bar & Billiard Room during the first two phases. The restoration aims to maintain the hotel's unique ambience and charm, with no changes to its exterior. The project's investment value was not disclosed, but it is expected to have a minimal impact on the hotel's occupancy rate.

site_title: China plans tighter control of funds flow into property
summary: China's financial regulators plan to further tighten control of funds flowing into the property market, targeting speculative real-estate investments and money involved in land transactions. This comes after concerns over escalating home prices, with the central bank governor highlighting the issue. Authorities have already introduced curbs in at least 21 cities, including restrictions on down-payments and eligibility for buyers. Despite these measures, home prices continue to rise, with the latest official data showing a six-year high in August. The move aims to curb speculation and ensure robust property-market growth.

site_title: Time for Asean to forge regional position on cyber norms: Yaacob
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim emphasized the need for Asean to establish a regional position on cyber norms, citing the global discussions on cyber norms and the interconnected nature of Asean member states. To deepen cybersecurity cooperation, Singapore will launch a $10 million Asean Cyber Capacity Programme to fund various efforts, including national cybersecurity agencies and legislation. The country will also extend access to the CyberGreen initiative to Asean members for free, with Singapore as a founding sponsor. Experts stress the importance of regional information sharing, threat intelligence, and cyber legislation to prevent and disrupt cyber attacks.

site_title: The importance of nation branding and public diplomacy
summary: The US has maintained its position as the world's top brand despite strong anti-American sentiment due to its interventions in the Middle East. The Anholt-GfK Roper Nation Brands Index ranked the US as the No 1 brand in 2016, surpassing Germany. Public diplomacy efforts, particularly in the Middle East, have been criticized as a failure, but the US remains viewed favorably in many countries, with high approval ratings in Europe and Japan. The US approach to nation branding, which involves building a unique national identity, is seen as more effective than corporate branding techniques.

site_title: British MPs, lobby group pressure against 'hard Brexit'
summary: British lawmakers and the Confederation of British Industry are pressuring the government not to pursue a "hard Brexit," which would involve leaving the European Single Market. They argue that such a move would lead to higher tariffs, loss of trade, and lower economic growth. The UK Treasury estimates that a hard Brexit could result in a loss of £38-66 billion per year in tax revenues. The government, however, claims that a "soft Brexit" would be contrary to the will of the 52% of voters who chose Brexit. The issue has sparked debate over whether the terms of Brexit should be discussed in Parliament before negotiations with the EU begin.

site_title: Spotlight on KL's next move in 1MDB saga
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority has taken decisive action against two Swiss private banks, BSI Singapore and Falcon Bank, for breaching anti-money laundering rules in the 1MDB saga. This contrasts with Malaysia, where the probe into 1MDB appears to have ground to a halt despite similar allegations of embezzlement totaling $3.5 billion to $4 billion. Singapore prosecutors have also hauled up four people to court and frozen assets worth $240 million, while the US Justice Department has filed a civil suit to seize $1 billion of assets. Malaysia's inaction has drawn criticism, with Singapore's regulators urging the country to work together to address the issue.

site_title: SMG snags women's health clinic group for S$60m
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has proposed to buy Astra Women's Specialist group, a women's health clinic group, for S$60 million. The acquisition aims to expand SMG's obstetrics and gynaecology segment. The deal would boost SMG's O&G doctors to eight and promote cross-selling opportunities among its ambulatory care services. The transaction is expected to be completed in late January 2017, with a cash consideration of S$33 million and new shares worth S$27 million.

site_title: Trump bounces back but Republican Party still in tatters
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has bounced back after a scandalous video released in October 2016, featuring lewd and sexist comments. Many Republican party stalwarts have abandoned him, with House Speaker Paul Ryan conceding the race to Hillary Clinton. Despite this, Trump's combative debate performance seems to have righted the ship, and he remains on better footing. A double-digit lead in a recent NBC News poll shows Clinton's trajectory as the election approaches on November 8. The Republican party's internal struggles have led to a full-blown circus, with party leadership fleeing from Trump and focusing on down-ballot contests.

site_title: Japan passes US$32b extra budget, focus shifts to TPP bills
summary: Japan's Parliament approved a $32 billion extra budget for the fiscal year ending March 2017, funded mainly by construction bonds for infrastructure spending. This is part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic stimulus package. The budget is the second supplementary budget for the year.

site_title: Betting on a Life Cycle strategy
summary: Singapore is exploring the introduction of a Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme (LRIS) with a CPF Advisory Panel, which may include Life Cycle funds. Life Cycle funds aim to gradually reduce exposure to growth assets and increase stable assets as investors age. However, analysis of scenarios suggests that Life Cycle funds may not outperform CPF guaranteed return rates or balanced funds, especially during bear markets. In contrast, a balanced strategy with regular contributions can maximize the value of the pension at retirement and profit from volatility. The timing of equity performance is also crucial, and Life Cycle strategies may not maximize the probability of outperforming a guaranteed fixed CPF interest.

site_title: Iskandar Waterfront may revive IPO as early as next year
summary: Malaysian developer Iskandar Waterfront Holdings Sdn is considering reviving an initial public offering as early as 2017 to monetize its assets valued over RM30 billion. The company plans a dual listing in Malaysia and Hong Kong or Singapore, with potential strategic partnerships. The IPO comes amid the development of the 1,620-hectare Bandar Malaysia project, which will host a high-speed rail line and is valued at RM150 billion. The project's construction is funded by international banks, and the government is restructure 1MDB's debts.

site_title: LNG a key to cutting ship emissions: industry players
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) is nudging the maritime industry towards using greener marine fuels, including liquefied natural gas (LNG), ahead of the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) global cap on sulphur content in ship fuels. The MPA offers incentives, such as lower port dues, to encourage the use of clean fuels or approved exhaust-gas scrubbers. LNG bunkering is seen as a key part of the future in greener shipping, with the MPA awarding the first pair of LNG bunkering licences and providing funding for the development of LNG-fuelled vessels. However, industry players acknowledge that LNG bunkering infrastructure development will take time, with Shell estimating that LNG could comprise only 10% of bunker fuel in the maritime sector by 2030.

site_title: Seoul court mulls selling Hanjin's Asia-US business
summary: A Seoul court is considering selling Hanjin Shipping Co's Asia-US business as part of efforts to raise funds for the indebted company. The plan, which includes employees and customers of the company's Asia-US cargo handling operations, aims to maximize asset value. The court has not yet determined how many workers or vessels could be affected by the sale. Hanjin Shipping had 1,428 employees as of June 30, and the company is required to submit a revival proposal by December 23. The court's decision is expected soon.

site_title: Buffett discloses 2015 tax returns, challenges Trump to do the same
summary: Warren Buffett challenged Donald Trump to disclose his 2015 tax returns, following Trump's claim that Buffett used a nine-figure loss in 1995 to reduce tax obligations. Buffett fact-checked Trump's statement, suggesting Trump's strategy was not comparable to his own. Buffett's move was seen as a response to Trump's attempt to liken his tax strategy to those of wealthy Democratic supporters, including Buffett.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GLP leases 344,000 sq ft of space to Walmart in southern China. Jason Marine Group expects a net loss for its half year. Frasers Hospitality Trust's rights issue is oversubscribed at 141.3% with gross proceeds of S$266.3 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer is 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies also report concerns on revenue and operating losses, including Creative Technology and Indonesia's Trafigura employee detention.

site_title: Steel imports: risk of trade barriers in Japan
summary: Japan's steelmakers face challenges due to a surge in imports and a jump in the cost of key raw material coking coal. The industry's top mills have swung to losses in the first quarter, with Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp warning that prices must increase to absorb the extra cost. Japan has never adopted protectionist measures on steel imports, but the industry is considering trade action against Asian rivals if dumping conditions are met under the World Trade Organization.

site_title: Cause for optimism on RMB internationalisation
summary: The renminbi (RMB) has been included in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Special Drawing Right (SDR) currency basket, marking a significant milestone in its internationalisation. This is the first time a currency from a developing country has achieved this status. The RMB has a 10.93% weighting, ranking it as the third-largest currency in the basket. This move reflects China's growing economic power, financial markets, and trade volumes, with RMB settlement of Chinese trade increasing to around 30% of total world trade.

site_title: Driverless cars hit British streets
summary: Driverless cars have begun a trial in Britain, marking a significant step towards their introduction across the country. The Transport Systems Catapult (TSC) launched the trial, which features compact two-seater cars carrying passengers in a pedestrianised zone in Milton Keynes, north of London. The trial is part of a plan to roll out 40 vehicles in the city, paving the way for wider adoption of autonomous vehicles in the UK.

site_title: BP abandons Great Australian Bight plans
summary: BP has abandoned plans to drill in the Great Australian Bight after failing to meet environmental criteria. The company had planned to drill four deep exploration wells off the South Australian coast to search for oil and gas, but its application repeatedly hit hurdles. Conservation groups hailed the decision as a victory, citing risks to the environment and threatened species such as the southern right whale and white sharks. The decision follows a review of BP's upstream strategy, with the company stating that the project was not competitive or aligned to its strategic goals.

site_title: Falcon Bank loses S'pore licence; DBS, UBS fined over 1MDB-linked fund flows
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stripped Falcon Private Bank of its licence due to "serious failures in anti-money laundering (AML) controls and improper conduct by senior management." MAS also fined Falcon S$4.3 million and DBS Bank and UBS AG, Singapore Branch S$4.3 million and S$3.5 million respectively for breaching AML rules related to 1MDB-linked fund flows. The decision follows investigations into suspicious transactions between March 2013 and May 2015, with MAS citing weaknesses in Falcon's controls and head office senior management's actions as major factors.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Manulife US Reit's US$0.835 share price closed on October 11, 2016, with a target price of US$0.93. In contrast, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed on July 11, 2025. The US stock market opened lower on the same day due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue and an operating loss similar to the first half.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai wise not to dance to Beijing's tune
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen delivered her first National Day speech, refusing to acknowledge the "1992 consensus" on "one China" as a condition for talks with Beijing, despite pressure from China. Tsai emphasized maintaining the status quo and called for cross-strait exchanges to continue, but Beijing sees this as a prolongation of Taiwan's independence. China has suspended official talks and moved to squeeze Taiwan's international space, with President Xi Jinping indicating a willingness to use non-peaceful means to achieve unification. Tsai's stance is seen as wise by many, as it avoids acknowledging Taiwan's status as part of China.

site_title: Analysts say BOJ's policy framework makes helicopter money highly likely
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) new policy framework makes helicopter money "highly likely," according to analysts. The BOJ's decision to target sovereign bond yield levels could lead to a central bank-funded fiscal stimulus, with risks including a rapid yen depreciation. Despite Haruhiko Kuroda's repeated denials, some analysts believe the BOJ's creative monetary policy approach could enable more expansionary fiscal policies, potentially leading to helicopter money. The Japanese government has already approved a second supplementary budget, and an influential adviser is pushing for a third.

site_title: Crude oil prices slip from 1-year high on mixed Russian response to Opec
summary: Crude oil prices slipped from a one-year high after mixed responses from Russian oil industry officials to an Opec call for production cuts. Despite Opec's plan to cut 700,000 barrels per day, analysts warn of poor compliance and exemptions for non-core producers. Goldman Sachs stated that an agreement remains premature due to high supply uncertainty in 2017. As a result, Brent crude oil fell 0.6% to $52.79 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude slipped 0.7% to $51.

site_title: WEF sets up San Francisco office to catch tech wave
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has established its second US office in San Francisco, aiming to tap into the city's growing tech industry. The new 60-staff office will focus on policy recommendations for emerging technologies, with the goal of developing regulations that support innovation. Located near Silicon Valley, the office will be led by Murat Sonmez and will be the WEF's fourth satellite office globally, joining locations in New York, Beijing, and Tokyo.

site_title: Can't ease cooling measures with China property bubble, low rates
summary: Singapore's government may need to be cautious about lifting cooling measures in the property market due to a potential deflation in China's property bubble. A high proportion of satisfied homeowners contributes to social and political stability, and prices cannot be allowed to spiral out of reach for ordinary citizens. The government's introduction of a debt framework and increased public flats for first-timers have improved sentiment, contributing to a significant improvement in the ruling party's performance in the 2015 General Election. Lifting cooling measures now could lead to a surge in property prices.

site_title: Fifa appoints first ever Chief Women's Football Officer
summary: Fifa appoints Sarai Bareman as its first ever Chief Women's Football Officer, effective November 14. Bareman, a New Zealand native and former Samoan women's national soccer team player, will lead the newly created Women's Football Division as part of Fifa's management board. As the only female member of Fifa's 2016 Reform Committee, Bareman was a strong advocate for change within the organisation, particularly calling for concrete requirements on women in leadership positions. Her appointment marks a significant step towards promoting women's football globally.

site_title: Get up close with the world's top tennis stars in Singapore
summary: The WTA Finals Singapore, featuring top tennis stars like Serena Williams and Angelique Kerber, is set to take place from October 23-30. About 90% of 9,350 tickets have been sold through the Racquet Club, a corporate hospitality program offering perks like meet-and-greets, fine dining, and access to exclusive lounges. The tournament, which boasts a US$7 million prize purse, has seen increased bookings from companies in the business and consultancy sectors, with larger bulk bookings also on the rise.

site_title: Big, bad bankers are the true disruptive force
summary: The article argues that job cuts at global banks are not solely due to automation, but rather a result of mismanagement by senior executives and regulators' failure to punish top bankers for their actions during the financial crisis. The author points to Deutsche Bank and Standard Chartered as examples of banks that have been plagued by complex systems and poor management. The article concludes that the real disruption in the banking industry is not caused by technology, but by the actions of big, bad bankers who have not been held accountable for their roles in the crisis.

site_title: It's a dog's life: Yangon neuters city's many strays
summary: In Yangon, Myanmar, over 100,000 stray dogs roam the streets, with the city's animal welfare organization, Thevar, working to neuter the population. A recent operation involved darting 100 strays, with the goal of reducing the number of unwanted litters and improving the overall health of the city's canine population. The project aims to alleviate the issue of stray dogs, which can lead to public health concerns and animal suffering. Neutering is seen as a key step in addressing the problem and creating a more humane environment for both humans and animals.

site_title: Pennies continue to reign as STI sags
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 14.11 points to 2,856.13, marking a 1.3% loss, amid weak market conditions. The decline was attributed to a slide in Dow futures and a weak Hong Kong market. Bank stocks, including DBS and UBS, fell after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) took action against them for anti-money laundering lapses, with DBS and UBS receiving fines. Top volume stocks included Noble Group, SunMoon Food, Ezion, and Ezra.

site_title: Foreign investors cut back on emerging Asia govt bonds in anticipation of US rate hike
summary: Foreign investors have cut back on emerging Asian government bonds, particularly in South Korea, India, and Thailand, due to anticipation of a US interest rate hike in December and reduced expectations of further central bank easing. This follows a trend of outflows in September, with net sales of 1.7 trillion won (S$2.1 billion) in South Korea and 663.0 billion won in India. In contrast, foreign investors have maintained holdings in Indonesian bonds, which have seen inflows of 16.9 trillion rupiah (S$1.8 billion) in September.

site_title: Direct, co-investment in the spotlight
summary: Direct and co-investment in private equity are gaining popularity in South-east Asia due to the low-yield environment. This alternative method of financing allows investors to retain control over their investments by directly investing or co-investing alongside experienced General Partners. Large sovereign wealth funds and pension funds are opting for direct investment, while co-investment is becoming a popular alternative for those who wish to have a greater say in the investment strategy. The benefits of co-investment include higher returns, increased flexibility, and reduced fees, making it an appealing proposition in the region.

site_title: US$ hits 11-week high on rising bets of rate hike
summary: The US dollar reached an 11-week high against major peers due to rising bets on a Federal Reserve interest rate hike before the end of the year. Investors are also concerned about Donald Trump's potential presidency, which is seen as dollar-negative. The US dollar index jumped 0.6% to 97.475, with traders pricing in a 70% chance of a rate hike at the December meeting. Meanwhile, the Swedish crown hit a 6½-year low against the euro due to market expectations of a potential policy easing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) shut down the Singapore branch of Falcon Private Bank, a Switzerland-based merchant bank, due to "serious failures in anti-money laundering (AML) controls" and improper conduct by senior management. MAS also fined DBS and UBS for their roles in the matter.

site_title: BP's Dudley sees US$55-70 oil in coming years
summary: BP CEO Bob Dudley predicts oil prices will hover at $55-70 per barrel for the rest of the decade as the energy industry undergoes profound changes. The prediction comes after recent price fluctuations, with prices rising to their highest level in a year. Dudley also stated that stable prices are in everyone's interests and that fossil fuels will remain vital despite the growth of renewable energy, which he expects to reach 15% of the world's energy mix by 2035.

site_title: Globalisation in remission
summary: Globalisation appears to be in remission, driven by growing wealth and income inequality, fuelling nationalist fears and populist politics. Former trends of deregulation are slowing or reversing, echoing the Great Depression of the 1930s. Politicians are rowing back on global trade agreements, and multinational corporations may face headwinds as local brands and taxation gain favor. The world is at a political tipping point, with concerns over fiscal and infrastructure spending, unfunded welfare promises, and rising nationalism, potentially leading to protectionism and a return to older-world versions of countries and states.

site_title: US stocks dented by weak Alcoa earnings
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday as Alcoa reported disappointing third-quarter earnings, with the company's stock plummeting 7.9% after missing analyst expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. However, Apple's stock rose 2.1% after Samsung Electronics halted production of its Note 7 smartphones due to battery problems.

site_title: Metro fends off activist investor eyeing its cash holdings
summary: Metro Holdings, a Singapore property and retail group, has defended its cash holdings against activist investor Quarz Capital Management, which called for a special dividend. Metro expects net cash levels to decline due to capital-intensive property investments. The company has recently sold properties and plans to invest in new opportunities, with its cash position fluctuating with investments. Metro has a history of paying dividends, but has no fixed dividend policy to maintain flexibility in deploying capital.

site_title: Half full or half empty, the global economy cup is not running over
summary: The global economy is facing challenges, despite the IMF's "glass-half-full" assessment of its growth prospects. Rising trade protectionism, slowing productivity, and adverse demographic trends are concerns. Global debt has reached $162 trillion, posing a risk of unprecedented deleveraging. Income and social inequality are growing, fueled by protectionism and populism. The US presidential election and Brexit uncertainty have added to the uncertainty. Policymakers are weighing the need for fiscal spending to offset monetary easing, while Europe resists the call. The global economy's future remains uncertain, with the risk of stalling globalisation and a potential banking collapse in Europe.

site_title: US inflation expectations retreat in September: NY Fed survey
summary: US inflation expectations declined in September, with median year-ahead inflation expectations hitting a record low of 2.5% and three-year ahead expectations at 2.6%. Consumer expectations of earnings growth also decreased to 2.0% from 2.4%. The decline is attributed to a gradual decrease in price measures since 2013, as the US central bank looks to raise interest rates before the end of the year. The Federal Reserve seeks signs of inflation pressures before acting.

site_title: German ZEW investor sentiment jumps in sign economy still robust
summary: German investor sentiment surged in October to 6.2, the highest level since June, according to the ZEW Center for European Economic Research. The index rose from 0.5 in September, beating economists' expectations. This follows a string of strong economic results, including August exports and factory orders growth. Despite concerns over the EU's economic outlook, ZEW President Achim Wambach said the improved sentiment indicates "relatively robust economic activity."

images.alt_text: German investor confidence improved more than economists anticipated in October in a sign that the economy remains robust, according to the ZEW Center for European Economic Research in Mannheim.

site_title: Mermaid retains Middle East subsea contract at reduced rates
summary: Mermaid Maritime Public Company announced that its joint venture, Zamil Mermaid Offshore Services Company, has retained a Middle East subsea contract at reduced rates. The service day rates for the long-term contract have been lowered to ensure continuity until the end of the contract. This reduction was part of a cost-cutting initiative by the client due to the challenging business environment.

site_title: German investor cheer could hit growth buffers: analysts
summary: German investor confidence surged to 6.2 points in October, a 5.7-point increase from September, exceeding analysts' predictions of 4.0 points. This marks a significant improvement from low levels in August and September, which followed a post-Brexit dip in July. Despite the positive sentiment, analysts caution against overconfidence, warning that growth buffers may be hit. The improvement suggests a potential boost to Germany's economy, but further analysis is needed to determine the full impact of the increased investor confidence.

site_title: New courses, toolkit to 'future-proof' accountants
summary: CPA Australia has launched new training programs and toolkits to help accountants and finance professionals adapt to the digital age. The initiative aims to 'future-proof' accountants and stay relevant in the face of changing business models and technologies. The programs were unveiled at the CPA Congress 2016, attended by 380 professionals. The move is seen as a response to the increasing threat of automation and artificial intelligence in the accounting industry.

images.alt_text: The challenges of the digital age are already making some traditional accounting roles obsolete, says Philip Yuen.

site_title: UK minister says getting best Brexit deal for banks an "absolute priority"
summary: UK Financial Services Minister Simon Kirby stated that getting the best Brexit deal for the City of London, a top financial centre, is an "absolute priority." Kirby emphasized maintaining Britain's role as a top financial centre, allowing banks to hire global talent, and urged the financial sector to engage constructively with the government in Brexit trade talks with the EU.

site_title: Update: Samsung halts production, global sales of Note 7
summary: Samsung has halted production and global sales of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone following reports of the device's lithium-ion battery catching fire, including replacement phones. The company has directed customers to stop using the device and will offer full refunds or exchanges for other Samsung handsets. The move comes amid a growing recall crisis and a warning from the US Consumer Product Safety Commission, which is investigating reports of overheating and burning devices in multiple US states.

site_title: Wave of China property tightening hits home sales during holiday week
summary: China imposed restrictions on housing markets, including higher mortgage downpayments, to cool the hot property markets in cities like Beijing and Shenzhen. Over 20 cities were affected, with new home sales dropping by more than half. Prices of new homes in Shenzhen and Beijing fell 20% last week to entice buyers. The measures aim to curb China's ballooning debt and official concerns about the property market. The restrictions occurred during a traditionally high season for property sales, the National Day holiday week.

site_title: Metro expects net cash to decline as it seeks out property developments
summary: Metro Holdings expects its net cash to decline as it seeks property developments, following an activist shareholder's call for a special cash dividend. The company cited its capital-intensive property division and the need to reinvest capital into projects. Metro continues to evaluate a pipeline of projects, but insufficient cash could affect its ability to build future income streams. The company welcomes the shareholder's concerns and invites them to attend shareholder meetings to discuss the issues raised.

site_title: G7 sets cyber-security guidelines for financial sector
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) industrial powers have agreed on guidelines to protect the global financial sector from cyber attacks. The guidelines, agreed by finance ministers and central bankers, instruct governments to ensure financial regulators police cyber-security readiness of companies and cooperate to contain breaches. The goal is to maintain trust and confidence in the financial sector by enabling entities and public authorities to mutually assist each other in case of threats. The guidelines aim to address growing cyber risks and disruptions to interconnected global financial systems.

images.alt_text: The Group of Seven industrial powers said on Tuesday they had agreed on guidelines on how to protect the global financial sector from cyber attacks.

site_title: China's outflows may be worse than they look
summary: China's currency outflows may be larger than initially reported, with Goldman Sachs warning that capital is exiting the country in yuan rather than US dollars. Official data shows $27.7 billion in yuan payments left China in August, a significant increase from the $4.4 billion average over the previous five years. This raises concerns about the stability of China's foreign-exchange reserves and the potential for capital outflows to worsen.

site_title: Manhattan Resources unit to sell two-thirds of vessel fleet for 170.6b rupiah
summary: Manhattan Resources, a coal and oil and gas contractor, is selling two-thirds of its vessel fleet to PT Karunia Samudera Lines of Indonesia for 170.6 billion rupiah (S$18 million) in cash. The sale, valued at a 60% premium to book value, aims to improve the balance sheet and conserve resources. The company will use the net proceeds for general purposes and working capital as it shifts focus to power plant and property businesses in China. The sale is expected to result in a S$7.3 million gain on disposal.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.400 points to 1,668.720 on Tuesday, closing higher. The index saw 1.561 billion lots traded worth RM1.885 billion, with 440 gainers and 324 losers.

site_title: 1MDB's 'casualty' banks
summary: Singapore's OCBC Bank has named Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing outgoing CEO Helen Wong. Long, a former DBS veteran, will take over the role in 2017. The appointment comes as OCBC faces pressure from China's consumer lending push, which has impacted other Chinese banks. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising concerns for policymakers. OCBC's new CEO will oversee the bank's response to these challenges, including its expansion into green and transition finance.

site_title: Noble Group refinance needs in focus after sale of US unit
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, is focusing on refinancing needs after selling its US energy unit, Noble Americas Energy Solutions, for $800 million. The company's loans of approximately $2.3 billion are due in May, with estimates ranging from $25 million to $725 million. This sale largely completes Noble Group's efforts to raise $2 billion to bolster its finances. Investors and lenders are concerned about the company's ability to boost liquidity and return to profitability, following a share price collapse and credit rating cuts to junk.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker; pennies still very much in play
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 14.11 points to 2,856.13, a 1.3% loss, due to a decline in bank stocks following news of anti-money laundering lapses by UBS and DBS. Volume was high, with top names including Noble Group and Ezion. The loss comes after a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and despite a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Japan parliament passes 3.287t yen extra budget, focus shifts to TPP bills
summary: Japan's parliament approved a 3.287 trillion yen extra budget for the 2016 fiscal year, bringing annual spending to over 100 trillion yen. The budget will fund Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic stimulus package, including infrastructure spending and wage increases. With the budget passed, Abe's government will seek swift approval of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) pact, which is unpopular with US labour unions and environmental groups.

site_title: Japan's retail gloom casts doubt on government's upbeat spending projection
summary: Japan's retailers forecast a gloomy end to the year due to persistent economic malaise and lack of wage growth, prompting them to offer better products for less, cut costs, and pack shelves with white label offerings. This contradicts the Japanese government's recent upward revision of private consumption, which described it as holding firm. Most retailers report flat or weaker profits, casting doubt on the government's spending projection.

site_title: Brexit chief sees bright side to pound's decline for exporters
summary: Brexit Secretary David Davis broke with government convention to suggest that the British pound's decline to a three-decade low could help exporters, as a weaker currency boosts international competitiveness. Former Bank of England Governor Mervyn King echoed this view, calling the decline a "welcome change." The pound has fallen 17% since the Brexit vote, but Davis argued that the downsides of the decline are outweighed by its upsides.

site_title: China banks may need US$1.7t injection as credit quality worsens: S&P
summary: China's banks may need a US$1.7 trillion capital injection to cover potential bad loans, according to a report by S&P Global. Rising debt levels and credit quality issues, fueled by excessive credit growth, pose a significant threat to the country's banking system. The report estimates that Chinese banks' problem credit ratio could worsen to 11-17% by 2020, requiring a massive recapitalization. This comes as the IMF warns of unsustainable credit growth, with companies sitting on US$18 trillion in debt, equivalent to 169% of GDP.

site_title: Manhattan Resources to sell 44 vessels for 170b rupiah
summary: Manhattan Resources is selling 44 vessels to PT Karunia Samudera Lines of Indonesia for 170.6 billion rupiah (S$18 million) in cash. The vessels incurred a net loss of S$2 million in the half-year ended June 30, 2016. The sale price represents a 60% premium to the vessels' S$10.7 million book value. The proceeds will be used for general purposes and working capital as Manhattan shifts towards power plant and property businesses in China. The company expects to recognize a S$7.3 million gain on disposal.

site_title: Oil glut to last until mid-2017 unless Opec cuts output: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a massive oil glut will last until mid-2017 unless OPEC cuts its output. Despite tentative signs of declining inventories, the market is expected to remain in oversupply through the first half of next year. OPEC's agreement to cut output has led to a 15% rise in oil prices since its announcement, with some analysts suggesting the market's rebalancing could come faster if the cartel sticks to its target.

images.alt_text: A massive oil glut may weigh on world markets deep into next year unless the Opec producer cartel makes good on its promise to cut output, the International Energy Agency(IEA) said on Tuesday.

site_title: UBS said to poach Deutsche Bank's top private bankers in Asia
summary: Deutsche Bank's top private bankers in Asia, Ravi Raju and Anurag Mahesh, are leaving the firm to join UBS Group AG. Raju, who was Asia Pacific head of wealth management, will start at UBS in January in a senior management role. Mahesh, global head of key client partners, will depart and succession plans will be announced. Deutsche Bank has named Lok Yim as the new Asia Pacific head. The departures come after nearly a decade with the firm.

site_title: South Korea vows armed crackdown on Chinese fishing ships
summary: South Korea has vowed an armed crackdown on Chinese fishing ships operating in its waters, following a clash that sank one of its vessels. A coastguard vessel was rammed and capsized by a Chinese trawler, with no casualties. The South Korean foreign ministry summoned the Chinese ambassador to demand swift action. The coastguard warned of easing restrictions on the use of weapons, stating they will take a "more aggressive stance" when officers are in danger. This move comes amid disputes over illegal fishing and increasing numbers of Chinese vessels entering South Korea's waters.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks tumble after holiday while Shanghai rises
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.27% on the first day of trade after a long weekend, closing at 23,549.52, while Shanghai stocks rose 0.56% to 3,065.25. The decline was attributed to news of Chinese cities imposing measures to curb real estate price rises, affecting property firms. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose, and the Shenzhen Composite Index also increased.

site_title: SMG buys women's health clinic group for S$60m
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has acquired Astra Women's Specialists for S$60 million. The deal includes S$33 million in cash tranches and S$27 million in new shares. The acquisition brings the number of obstetrics and gynaecology doctors under SMG to eight.

site_title: Raffles Hotel to undergo 16-month restoration programme
summary: Singapore's iconic Raffles Hotel will undergo a 16-month restoration programme starting January 2017, focusing on interior design due to its status as a national monument. The hotel will close fully during the third phase, from November 2017 to May 2018. General Manager Simon Hirst aims to update facilities while preserving the hotel's history and heritage, ensuring it remains a cultural hub in Singapore.

site_title: FHT's S$266m rights issue oversubscribed at over 140%
