summary: FRASERS Hospitality Trust's (FHT) 32-for-100 underwritten and renounceable rights issue has been oversubscribed at 141.3% with valid acceptances and excess applications totaling 624.04 million rights stapled securities. The gross proceeds of S$266.3 million will be used to acquire a prime hotel in Melbourne's core central business district area. Key investors, Frasers Centrepoint Limited and TCC Group Investments Limited, have subscribed for their pro-rata entitlements, representing 21.6% and 38.8% of the total rights stapled securities, respectively.

images.alt_text: FRASERS Hospitality Trust's (FHT) 32-for-100 underwritten and renounceable rights issue has been oversubscribed at 141.3 per cent with valid acceptances and excess applications coming in for a total of 624.04 million rights stapled securities as at Oct 7.

site_title: Indonesia Aug retail sales growth at 14.4% year-on-year: central bank
summary: Indonesia's annual retail sales in August grew at 14.4% year-on-year, led by food and non-food items, according to a Bank Indonesia survey. July's sales growth was revised to 6.3%. Retail sales are expected to reach 15.7% in September, but are predicted to slow in November due to seasonal factors and higher price pressures.

site_title: Australia shares end steady after crude prices dip; NZ up
summary: Australian shares closed steady on Tuesday, paring early gains after crude prices dipped, but remained near one-year highs due to growing expectations of an oil production cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished flat at 0.08% or 4.37 points at 5479.80. Oil majors Oil Search and Santos surged over 3% after Russia's Putin said the country would join a proposed oil production deal. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.10% as the Reserve Bank signaled future policy easing to boost inflation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall to 3-week lows on Samsung Electronics worries
summary: South Korean stocks and the won fell to 3-week lows on Tuesday, with Samsung Electronics shares plummeting 8% after the company halted Galaxy Note 7 sales globally. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 1.2% to 2,031.92 points, while the won fell 1.1% to 1,120.4 to the US dollar. Foreign investors sold 335.7 billion won of Kospi shares, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Saudi Arabia sees its oil reserves lasting another 70 years
summary: Saudi Arabia's crude oil reserves, totaling 266.5 billion barrels, are estimated to last 70 more years, according to a bond prospectus. The majority of the country's wealth is derived from oil sales, accounting for 75% of total export earnings. Saudi Arabia plans to sell at least $10 billion in bonds and a stake in state-run oil company Saudi Arabian Oil Co, which holds 261.1 billion barrels of total Saudi reserves. The methodology for calculating reserves may differ from other producers or US securities regulators.

site_title: Samsung shares plunge 8% on Note 7 woes
summary: Samsung's share price dropped 8% on Tuesday after halting sales and exchanges of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone due to safety concerns. The company recalled 2.5 million Note 7s in September following lithium-ion battery explosions. The decision came after a global advisory for customers to stop using the devices. The share price ended the day at 1.54 million won.

site_title: Sterling slides back below US$1.23
summary: Sterling falls below US$1.23, trading down 0.6% as it continues to suffer from concerns about the economic fallout of Britain's planned exit from the European Union. The pound hit a nearly-eight-year low of 74.0 at the Bank of England's morning print, with some traders citing worries of financial sector cutbacks in London due to Brexit. The current account deficit and liquidity concerns also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Alibaba's US$60b finance arm seeks growth before IPO: sources
summary: Alibaba's finance arm, Ant Financial, is delaying its initial public offering (IPO) to focus on growth before listing, according to sources. The company, valued at $60 billion, is expanding its user base, adding merchants and customers, and exploring new markets like India. Ant Financial is expected to list in both mainland China and Hong Kong, with a possible simultaneous listing. The delay is due to the company's rapid growth, which may impact short-term financial results, and regulatory hurdles, including Beijing's restrictions on foreign companies owning Chinese financial institutions.

site_title: Swiss financial regulator raps Falcon Bank for breaches
summary: The Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority (FINMA) has banned Falcon Bank from entering business relationships with foreign politically exposed persons for three years and warned that its license will be withdrawn if it breaches regulations again. FINMA has also launched enforcement proceedings against two of the bank's former executives. The regulator found that Falcon Bank seriously breached money laundering regulations by failing to conduct adequate background checks into transactions and business relationships associated with the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund 1MDB.

site_title: Airbus lifts lid on helicopter talks after Poland scraps deal
summary: Airbus Helicopters has responded to Poland's decision to cancel a multi-billion-dollar military helicopter deal, accusing the Warsaw government of shifting goalposts and attempting to contravene EU regulations. The deal, worth 13.4 billion zlotys, would have created 3,800 local jobs and generated more value for Poland than for Airbus. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury claimed the company had offered new concessions, including offsets worth over 10.8 billion zlotys, before the deal was scrapped. Poland's decision has soured relations between France and its eastern European NATO ally, with France threatening to review defence cooperation and cancel a presidential visit to Warsaw.

site_title: YouTube video shows Note 7 'flamer' in Burger King
summary: A viral YouTube video shows a Burger King employee struggling to remove a burning Galaxy Note 7 from a table, highlighting the crisis Samsung faced with its smartphone model. The device was one of the recalled Note 7s, which were prone to exploding due to a lithium-ion battery issue. The video was shot on October 7, 2016, two days before Samsung announced a global halt to sales and exchanges of the Note 7.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says ongoing strikes could weaken recovery momentum
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Yoo Il Ho expressed concerns that ongoing strikes in various industries could weaken the economy's recovery momentum if prolonged. He urged employees at the cargo alliance, state-run companies, and carmakers to end their strike action immediately. The minister's warning comes as South Korea's economy is still recovering from the 2015-2016 financial crisis.

site_title: China's yuan weakens, speculation of further depreciation grows
summary: China's yuan reached a fresh six-year low against the US dollar, weakening to 6.7098 per dollar, after the central bank set a weaker guidance rate. The currency has fallen 3.2% against the US dollar this year. Market expectations of further depreciation and US dollar purchases fueled the decline. Traders expect the central bank to allow a slow depreciation to the 6.8 level by the end of the year, as investors chase the rising greenback. The People's Bank of China's decision has raised concerns about the currency's stability.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip as shares of oil majors retreat
summary: European stock markets fell on Tuesday, with a 0.3% decline in the pan-European Stoxx 600 index. The decline was largely due to a 0.4% drop in the Stoxx Europe 600 Oil & Gas index, as oil prices retreated from one-year highs. This marks a 7% decline in the Stoxx 600 index for 2016.

site_title: Airbus to cut A380 assembly rate to one aircraft per month from 2017
summary: Airbus plans to reduce the assembly rate of its A380 superjumbo to one aircraft per month from 2017, citing a need to smooth deliveries pending new orders. The current rate is 2.5 aircraft per month. The decision comes as sales of the A380 have been hit by improved range and efficiency of smaller two-engine models. Airbus still sees the A380 as attractive for solving airport congestion and plans to improve its efficiency. The company aims to maintain the A380 in its product portfolio.

site_title: New Zealand's central bank reiterates more easing to come
summary: New Zealand's central bank reiterated that further policy easing is necessary to achieve its inflation target of 1-3% amid a current rate of 0.4%. The bank kept the OCR at 2% and left room for potential rate cuts. Assistant Governor John McDermott stated that September quarter inflation is expected to be low, indicating a need for further policy easing to ensure inflation settles near the target range.

site_title: Tokyo: Stock index closes at month high
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed at its highest level in over a month, reaching 17,024.76, driven by an oil price rally and a weaker yen. The index jumped 0.98% and the Topix index gained 0.42%. This follows a global rally and traders returning after a public holiday.

site_title: Note 7 fiasco could burn a US$17b hole in Samsung accounts
summary: Samsung Electronics' recall of 2.5 million Galaxy Note 7 smartphones due to reports of phones catching fire has led to a potential US$17 billion financial loss. The company halted sales and asked users to shut off their phones while investigating new reports of fires in replacement devices. Analysts predict Samsung may scrap the Note 7 and move on to successor models to limit damage. The crisis marks the worst-ever recall for Samsung, which has already lost sales and reputation.

site_title: Apple, Samsung take battle to US Supreme Court
summary: The US Supreme Court is set to hear a case involving Apple and Samsung, with Apple seeking to uphold a $548 million verdict that found Samsung copied the iPhone's design. Samsung disputes the calculation of damages, arguing it should only be liable for the profit tied to patented design aspects. The case could have major repercussions in the tech industry, with observers watching to see how the court balances technological innovation and protecting intellectual property. A decision is expected in several months.

images.alt_text: The epic legal battle pitting Apple against its bitter rival Samsung over the design of the iPhone reaches a new level Tuesday when it heads to the US Supreme Court.

site_title: Thai police warn of Bangkok bomb plot, step up security
summary: Thai police have increased security at major landmarks and airports following reports of a bomb plot in a province near Bangkok. An armed group was planning car bomb attacks, with the motive unclear. This comes after a series of deadly bomb attacks in Thailand's south, including a wave of bombs in tourist towns that killed four people and injured dozens. The planned attacks are believed to be unrelated to the recent August bombings linked to Muslim separatists. Bangkok is currently hosting a regional meeting, and police are on high alert.

site_title: Nestle says executive from botox maker Allergan to run skin care
summary: Nestle has replaced the head of its skin-care unit with Paul Navarre, president of Allergan's international business, effective November 1. Navarre, a Frenchman, previously worked at Procter & Gamble Co. for 15 years. This move is part of Nestle's efforts to transform itself into a scientifically driven nutrition and health company, with an alliance to distribute Dysport, a competitor to Botox. Humberto Antunes, the previous head, decided to leave for a "new direction" in his career.

site_title: South Korea summons China ambassador over fishing boat clash
summary: South Korea summoned China's ambassador on Tuesday over a collision between a Chinese fishing vessel and a South Korean coast guard patrol boat that sank, killing no one. The incident occurred during an operation to crack down on Chinese vessels fishing illegally off South Korea's west coast. South Korea has repeatedly complained about China's illegal fishing activities and urged Beijing to help find a permanent solution. The incident is the latest in a series of disputes between the two countries over fishing and North Korea's nuclear programs.

site_title: Thais wear auspicious pink to help hospitalised king recover
summary: Thais wore pink on Tuesday to show support for 88-year-old King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who is in unstable condition after haemodialysis treatment in hospital. The palace stated the king's health is "not stable" after his blood pressure dropped, a rare admission. Many Thais believe pink attracts good luck, and the king has worn the color in the past. Well-wishers flocked to Siriraj Hospital, where the king has spent much of the past year, and prayers were held at temples, including Wat Pathum Wanaram.

site_title: Saudi Aramco CEO says 2018 will be right time for listing
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser expressed confidence that the company's initial public offering (IPO) would occur by 2018, citing recovered oil prices and favorable market conditions. Nasser stated that up to 5% of the company would be listed, with a planned investment of $300 billion over the next decade, focusing on gas. The IPO would be considered for multiple markets, but no specific location was mentioned.

site_title: BP abandons Great Australian Bight drill plans
summary: British oil giant BP has abandoned plans to drill in the Great Australian Bight after repeatedly facing hurdles at the National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Authority. The decision, made after reviewing its global upstream strategy, follows opposition from environmental groups who cited risks to the environment. BP cited a lack of competitiveness in the project, despite facing regulatory hurdles. Conservation groups hailed the decision as a victory, calling for other companies to follow BP's lead in leaving the area.

site_title: Seoul court considers selling Hanjin's Asia-US business
summary: A Seoul court is considering selling Hanjin Shipping Co.'s Asia-US business as part of efforts to raise funds for the indebted company. The plan includes selling the sales-and-marketing network, employees, and some vessels involved in handling Asia-US cargo. The sale would help the company recover from a global slump in trade and job cuts. The court aims to make a decision soon, while Hanjin is required to submit its own proposal for revival by December 23.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on profit-taking, TSMC eases ahead of Q3 results
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.8% on Tuesday, with the TAIEX index closing at 9,189.86 points, after reaching its highest level in over a year. Profit-taking and a report of declining exports in September contributed to the decline. The electronics subindex dropped 0.7%, and TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, traded down 0.5% ahead of its Q3 results. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.660 per US dollar, and the main TAIEX index is expected to be impacted by the company's outlook for global demand on tech products.

site_title: UBS 'disappointed' it did not do more to detect control lapses
summary: UBS expressed disappointment over not detecting anti-money laundering (AML) control lapses earlier, despite the Monetary Authority of Singapore's detection. The bank is strengthening its controls and taking action against individuals responsible. As a result, UBS will donate profits from the affected account to establish an industry-wide AML program to combat financial crime and uphold Singapore's status as a financial hub adhering to high standards.

site_title: US watchdog expands scrutiny to more Chinese deals
summary: US watchdog, the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS), has stepped up scrutiny of Chinese deals, targeting "non-notified transactions" that did not seek CFIUS approval. This includes a recent review of Fosun International's acquisition of US insurer Ironshore Inc, which delayed the insurer's initial public offering. CFIUS has added staff and resources to identify non-filers and has been approaching companies after deals are completed, rather than before. This increased scrutiny may delay deals and raise the risk of them being thwarted, and is part of a broader effort to address concerns about Chinese companies' ties to the US government and national security.

site_title: Helicopter money preparation seen by Mizuho in BOJ framework
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) decision to target sovereign bond yield levels has sparked speculation about the possibility of "helicopter money," a concept where the central bank provides fiscal stimulus directly to citizens. Analysts at Mizuho Securities and Nordea Markets see the shift as lowering the hurdle for helicopter money, while some experts, including former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers, argue that a successful yield-curve targeting strategy can enable more expansionary fiscal policies. Japan's central bank chief, Haruhiko Kuroda, has repeatedly ruled out helicopter money, but the government is considering a third supplementary budget to boost economic stimulus.

site_title: Takata shares dented by bankruptcy reports
summary: Takata shares plummeted 11% on Tuesday following reports that the Japanese airbag maker is considering filing for bankruptcy in the US, citing huge compensation costs due to a defect linked to 16 deaths and scores of injuries. The company faces a massive recall of 100 million airbags and may seek court protection only for its US division. Automakers, including Honda and General Motors, could face billions in costs linked to the recall and legal liabilities. The firm is also considering bids from private equity firms and auto parts makers to mitigate liabilities.

site_title: Colombia to launch peace talks with ELN rebels
summary: Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos announced the launch of peace talks with the ELN rebel group on October 27 in Ecuador's capital, with the goal of achieving "total peace." The talks come after the government freed a civilian hostage held by the ELN, and both sides have committed to creating a favorable environment for peace. The move marks a significant step towards ending half a century of conflict in Colombia, which has killed over 260,000 people and left 45,000 missing.

images.alt_text: The Colombian government and the country's second-largest rebel group, the ELN, announced Monday they would launch negotiations on Oct 27 in Ecuador's capital, with President Juan Manuel Santos predicting "total peace".

site_title: China premier says economy improving, debt risks under control
summary: China's economy performed better than expected in the third quarter, with factory output, profits, and investment rebounding. Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country's debt risks are under control, but acknowledged downward pressure. China aims to achieve its main economic targets this year and maintain medium- to high-speed growth, with annual growth of 6.5-7%. The government will take measures to ensure stable property market development and reduce high debt levels of non-financial firms. China's total debt load remains a challenge, but policymakers aim to develop the country's capital markets.

site_title: Falcon Bank says will focus elsewhere after losing Singapore licence
summary: Falcon Bank, a Swiss private bank, announced that it will no longer focus on the Singapore market after the Monetary Authority of Singapore withdrew its banking licence. The bank will instead concentrate on growing its businesses in Switzerland, the Middle East, and London. Despite the licence withdrawal, Falcon Bank's shareholder Aabar remains committed to supporting the bank's future development.

site_title: South Korea advises airplane passengers to turn off Galaxy Note 7 phones
summary: South Korea's transport ministry advises airplane passengers to turn off Galaxy Note 7 phones due to reports of fires in the devices. The advisory applies to all Galaxy Note 7 phones, including replacement ones, produced by Samsung Electronics. The move follows warnings from the Korean Agency for Technology and Standards. Passengers are advised not to use or charge the devices on airplanes to prevent potential fires.

site_title: DBS says it 'should have taken more rigorous action'
summary: DBS acknowledged that it should have taken more rigorous action against questionable activities despite the Monetary Authority of Singapore's decision that control weaknesses were not pervasive. The bank accepted financial penalties for lapses in 2013 and 2014 and will hold senior executives accountable. DBS will also donate profits to a worthy cause.

site_title: Theranos accused of duping investors about tests, performance
summary: Theranos Inc and founder Elizabeth Holmes are accused of duping investors about the company's performance and technology, allegedly lying about its blood-testing capabilities to raise $100 million in funding. Partner Investments LP sued Theranos in Delaware state court seeking to rescind a stock-purchase agreement. The hedge fund claims Theranos officials misrepresented the firm's performance to secure funding. This latest scandal adds to the company's growing reputation issues, which have already led to significant financial losses and regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Family feud reignites at South Korea's Lotte Group
summary: South Korea's Lotte Group is embroiled in a family feud after former vice president Shin Dong Joo filed a lawsuit against chairman Shin Dong Bin, accusing him of accounting fraud. Shin Dong Joo claims Lotte Shopping omitted 370 billion won in losses, totaling S$457.61 million, from 2013 to 2015. The lawsuit reignites a bitter dispute over the business empire's control, following a court's dismissal of an arrest warrant on Shin Dong Bin earlier this month. Lotte Group has announced it will take "necessary countermeasures" after reviewing the case.

site_title: ICC close to paying first war crimes reparations
summary: The International Criminal Court is close to making its first war crimes reparations, focusing on the pain suffered by child soldiers in the Democratic Republic of Congo. A million euros has been allocated to the Lubanga case, with the court ruling that the convicted warlord is personally liable for reparations. The Trust Fund for Victims aims to help rehabilitate the traumatised victims through special projects, including reconciling them with their families and reintegrating former child soldiers. The tribunal will hold hearings to determine the total amount of reparations, with estimates suggesting up to 3,000 children may have been recruited into Lubanga's militia.

site_title: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore slide in September
summary: Resale prices for non-landed private homes in Singapore dropped 0.9% in September, marking the lowest level in 50 months since July 2012. City fringe prices fell 1.3% and suburban prices 1.5%, while city centre prices rose 0.6%. This decline reverses the trend seen in previous months, where prices were rising.

site_title: FLASH: Falcon Bank says MAS decision 'will not impact strategic development'
summary: Falcon Bank announced that it will not be impacted by the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) decision, despite losing its licence. The bank stated it will focus on other strategic developments.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose in the opening minutes of trade on Tuesday, tracking advances across global stocks. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.68% to 24,013.84, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.23% to 3,055.05. Global stocks were boosted by investor confidence despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit by Samsung Electronics woes, won drops
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday as Samsung Electronics Co Ltd halted Galaxy Note 7 sales globally amid reports of fires. The company asked global carriers to stop sales and exchange original devices for replacements. Shares of Samsung Electronics dropped 5% and touched their lowest level since September 30, 2016. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) remained stable despite support from US market gains. The South Korean won fell against the US dollar ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes.

site_title: China said to plan tighter control of funds entering property
summary: China's financial regulators plan to further tighten control on funds entering the property market, targeting speculative funds and those involved in land transactions. The move aims to curb excessive investment in real estate. Authorities, including the central bank and regulatory commissions, will strengthen oversight to prevent rule-breaking. The exact details of the plan have not been disclosed. This move is part of efforts to curb China's growing property market, which has raised concerns about market instability and overheating.

site_title: FLASH: MAS directs Falcon Bank to cease operations in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has directed Falcon Bank to cease operations in Singapore, effective immediately. The MAS also fined Falcon Bank, DBS, and UBS for their roles in the bank's misconduct. This move is a significant step in maintaining financial stability in the country.

site_title: Fed's Evans sees benefits to overshooting inflation target
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans suggests engineering monetary policy to spur inflation above the 2% target, citing the low costs of doing so. Evans believes the US economy is not yet at full employment and that a rise in inflation above 2% would be minimal, making it necessary for policymakers to accept increased inflationary risk. This approach would help indicate policymakers' willingness to tolerate higher inflation expectations, potentially reducing the need for policy intervention.

site_title: Gold drops as traders raise bets on December Fed rate increase
summary: Gold prices dropped by 0.3% to $1,255.70 an ounce as investors expected a US interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December, boosting the US dollar and hurting gold's appeal. This decline pared gold's year-to-date gain to 19%. Futures prices signal a 68% probability of a rate hike in December, up from 61% a week earlier, as the Fed continues to tighten monetary policy after last December's hike.

site_title: Twitter CEO calls company 'people's news network'
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey defined the company as the "people's news network" in an internal memo, highlighting its mission to be the first place people check for news and updates. The move comes as Twitter explores selling itself, with potential buyers including Salesforce.com. Dorsey's message emphasizes the company's focus on news and sports on mobile devices, which could attract media companies as acquirers. The memo does not address the sales process, and Twitter shares closed at $17.56 per share on Monday, down 11% due to speculation about a potential buyer.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit holds gain as crude oil rebounds; baht slides
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 0.5% due to a jump in crude oil prices, defying a decline in Asian currencies. The US dollar index rose as futures indicated a high chance of a December interest rate hike. In contrast, Thailand's baht slid 0.3% to a three-month low, its seventh consecutive day of losses, amid concerns over the health of King Bhumibol Adulyadej. Global funds sold Thai bonds, while buying Malaysian and South Korean bonds, as the ringgit benefits from the oil price rally.

site_title: Singapore to launch S$10m Asean programme to fund cybersecurity efforts
summary: Singapore will launch a S$10 million Asean Cyber Capacity Programme (ACCP) to enhance cybersecurity cooperation among Asean member states. Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim announced the programme, which will fund various cybersecurity efforts, including training and consultancy work. Singapore will also offer Asean countries access to a global cyber health report card, CyberGreen, at no cost. The initiative aims to deepen cybersecurity capabilities and address the growing threat of cyberattacks in the region.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 5.64 points to 2,875.88. The increase followed a surge in crude oil prices, driven by optimism that major producers will cooperate to reduce output. The most actively traded counter, Noble Group, rose S$0.001 to S$0.199. Gainers outnumbered losers 108 to 29, with the rally continuing a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.53 points to 1664.89. Gainers outnumbered losers 103 to 42, with 28.6 million lots traded worth RM14 million.

site_title: China denies allegations its peacekeepers abandoned South Sudan posts
summary: China's defense ministry has denied allegations that Chinese peacekeepers abandoned their posts in South Sudan in July, calling the claims "malicious speculation". The Center For Civilians in Conflict reported that Chinese peacekeepers withdrew from a civilian protection zone after coming under attack, killing two soldiers. China's defense spokesman said the peacekeepers remained at their posts, rescued wounded soldiers, and continued to implement their mandate. The UN is investigating the performance of its peacekeeping force in South Sudan.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars fall as investors wager on Fed hike
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the US dollar on Tuesday as investors priced in a greater chance of a US Federal Reserve rate hike in December. The Aussie dropped 0.2% to US$0.7589, while the New Zealand dollar slipped to US$0.7134. The rate hike is seen as a result of Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton's widening lead in US Presidential election polls, which is perceived as a reaffirmation of the status quo, whereas Republican candidate Donald Trump's victory would bring policy uncertainty.

site_title: Bank of Shanghai plans to raise 10.7b yuan in IPO on mainland
summary: Bank of Shanghai Co plans to raise 10.7 billion yuan (S$2.2 billion) in its initial public offering in Shanghai to boost capital. The lender will sell shares at 17.77 yuan apiece, with a price-to-earnings ratio of 8.26. This move comes as regulators close loopholes in shadow lending, with China's smaller banks needing to boost capital to meet industry standards. The IPO aims to fund expansion and follow a wave of smaller banks raising money to meet regulatory requirements.

images.alt_text: Bank of Shanghai Co plans to raise 10.7 billion yuan (S$2.2 billion) in its initial public offering in the city to boost capital.

site_title: South Korea says economic recovery unstable, cites auto strikes
summary: South Korea's economy is facing an unstable recovery due to recent strikes, particularly at Hyundai Motor Co, which has slowed exports and production. Domestic consumption has been growing modestly, but further strikes could hinder expansion. The economy is also uncertain due to a pending US rate hike and a new anti-graft law that restricts public servants' gifts and meals. These factors may impact Asia's fourth-largest economy as it struggles to expand further.

site_title: Australia business conditions pick up in Sept: bank survey
summary: Australia's business conditions improved in September, with sales and profits rebounding and forward orders rising, according to a National Australia Bank survey. The index of business conditions rose one point to +8, while business confidence held steady at +6. Employment fell, but capital spending and sales jumped. The survey suggests a multi-speed economy with key sectors performing well, but warns of a risk from weakening retail conditions, which accounts for over 50% of Australian GDP.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise with oil near 15-month high; Samsung, yen fall
summary: Asian stocks rose, led by energy companies, as oil nears a 15-month high. The US dollar climbed versus major peers, and Japan's Topix index reached a four-month high. Samsung Electronics Co declined after halting Galaxy Note 7 sales, while the yen fell. US crude oil prices rose, and gold fell. The rally came despite uncertainty over tariffs and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: 'Hard Brexit' could cost £66b a year: Times
summary: A "hard Brexit" could result in a £66 billion annual loss to the UK economy, with GDP potentially falling by 9.5% if Britain leaves the European Union. This estimate comes from a leaked government paper.

site_title: Clinton weighed reinstating Glass-Steagall, Wikileaks emails show
summary: Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign considered reinstating the Glass-Steagall Act, a Depression-era law separating commercial and investment banking, to avoid antagonizing the Democratic Party's progressive wing. A 2015 email suggests Clinton's policy team discussed the idea, but ultimately decided against it in favor of a risk-based approach. The move was seen as a way to curry favor with liberal Senator Elizabeth Warren, who had been critical of Wall Street. The decision came ahead of Clinton's primary debates against Bernie Sanders.

site_title: Drake sets new record for American Music Award nods
summary: Rapper Drake has set a record for the most American Music Award nominations with 13 nods, surpassing Michael Jackson's record of 11. The Toronto rapper, whose album "Views" was the top-selling album in the US this year, is also a contender for Artist of the Year, alongside Adele, Beyonce, and others. Drake postponed his final tour performances due to a severe ankle injury. Winners are chosen through fan voting, unlike the Grammy Awards, which are decided by industry professionals. The awards ceremony will take place on November 20.

site_title: GLP leases space to Walmart in China
summary: GLP leases 32,000 square meters of space to Walmart in southern China, expanding the retailer's presence at the existing location. This is part of Walmart's total 210,000 square meters leased across nine cities in China, Japan, and the US.

site_title: Trump still alive, but Republican Party in tatters
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump remains in the race despite a damaging video release of his 2005 comments on women. The video, which included lewd and sexist remarks, has led to widespread Republican criticism and some party leaders abandoning Trump. Despite a combative debate performance, Trump's trajectory is considered poor, with a double-digit lead for Democratic rival Hillary Clinton in a recent poll. The Republican Party is in disarray, with some party leaders, including House Speaker Paul Ryan, effectively endorsing Clinton and others criticizing Trump. The election is four weeks away, with Trump and Clinton competing for the White House.

site_title: China's Sanan says it held talks with Osram on possible purchase
summary: China's Sanan Optoelectronics Co Ltd has held talks with German lighting maker Osram Licht AG on a possible acquisition, raising concerns about Chinese purchases of European industrial companies. The talks come as Chinese companies have announced over $190 billion in foreign acquisitions this year. A deal would give Sanan control of Osram, which makes high-end lighting products used in BMW cars. There are significant uncertainties about the deal's status, and Osram's shares have closed 1.6% lower following the news.

site_title: US dollar strengthens as bulls wager Fed rate increase is in sight
summary: The US dollar strengthened against most Group of 10 countries, rising 0.1% to 103.68 yen, as traders anticipate a possible interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December. Futures prices signal a 68% probability of a rate hike, driven by strong US economic growth and inflation. Hedge funds' net positions that profit from a stronger dollar reached its highest level since February. Analysts predict the US dollar will continue to strengthen through year-end, with some forecasting a March 2017 interest rate hike.

site_title: South Korea regulator says to examine Google's Android agreements
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator will examine Google's agreements with Android handset manufacturers for potential anti-competition issues. Chairman Jeong Jae Chan stated that the agency will re-examine anti-competition concerns, but no specifics were provided. The regulator had previously investigated Google's policies on the Android platform in August but did not elaborate on potential charges. This move follows South Korea's growing scrutiny of tech giants, including Google, for their market dominance and potential anti-competitive practices.

site_title: Australia shares touch highest in 6 weeks after oil surges; NZ firmer
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% to a six-week high on Tuesday, driven by energy stocks after oil prices surged 3% and hit a one-year high. Energy stocks gained 2.1%, with Santos Ltd and Oil Search Ltd jumping 4.8% and 2.6% respectively. Retail giant Woolworths Ltd also rose 0.9%. The gains were aided by iron ore and steel futures in China rebounding from multi-week lows. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.5%.

site_title: Goldman warns China capital outflows may be worse than they look
summary: Goldman Sachs warns that China's capital outflows may be larger than initially reported, with $27.7 billion in yuan payments leaving China in August, compared to a monthly average of $4.4 billion in 2014. This indicates that a significant portion of outflows are not market-driven and should be considered when measuring currency outflows.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, tracking Wall Street
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, tracking gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.45%, and the Topix index gained 0.24%, following strength in petroleum companies due to higher oil prices and a jump in Apple shares.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, tracking gains on Wall Street, where strength in petroleum companies due to higher oil prices and a jump in Apple shares boosted indexes.

site_title: Samsung to halt global sales, exchanges of Galaxy Note 7
summary: Samsung Electronics announced it will stop global sales and exchanges of the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone due to recent reported cases of fires in new devices, amid a recall crisis. The company is still investigating the issue and has temporarily halted production of Note 7s. The US Consumer Product Safety Commission and the Korean Agency for Technology and Standards also urge consumers to stop using the device. This is the second recall for the Note 7, following a previous recall of 2.5 million devices in September 2016.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Saizen Reit, Sim Lian, SingPost
summary: Saizen Reit completed a reverse takeover deal with Sime Darby Property Singapore, injecting Australian assets into the trust. Sim Lian's stock will be suspended due to a decrease in public ownership. Singapore Post appointed three new non-executive directors following a corporate governance review.

site_title: 1MDB partner Iskandar Waterfront weighs reviving Malaysian IPO
summary: Malaysian developer Iskandar Waterfront Holdings Sdn Bhd is considering reviving an initial public offering (IPO) as early as 2017 to monetize its assets valued over 30 billion ringgit. The company, which has a joint venture with 1Malaysia Development Bhd to develop the Bandar Malaysia project, aims to raise funds for its mega real estate projects. Despite concerns about links to 1MDB, the project is seen as a high-impact development that will sustain the economy for Kuala Lumpur and the country.

site_title: Billionaire Buffett fires back at Trump on tax claims
summary: Billionaire investor Warren Buffett fired back at Donald Trump, releasing his own tax information to challenge Trump's claim of avoiding income taxes by deducting business losses. Buffett, founder of Berkshire Hathaway, denied the claim, stating it was untrue. Buffett's move comes after Trump made the assertion during a televised debate. The billionaire investor invited Trump to release his tax information, a challenge Trump has yet to accept.

site_title: MAS shuts down Falcon Bank in Singapore, fines Falcon, DBS and UBS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has shut down Falcon Bank's Singapore branch for "serious failures in anti-money laundering controls" and imposed fines of S$4.3 million on Falcon, S$1 million on DBS Bank, and S$1.3 million on UBS's Singapore branch. The actions follow an investigation into 1MDB-related fund flows through these banks from 2013 to 2015. MAS also fined Standard Chartered Bank's Singapore Branch, with a final announcement pending. The crackdown is part of a broader effort to strengthen AML controls in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore is withdrawing the merchant bank status of Switzerland-based Falcon Private Bank's Singapore branch for "serious failures in anti-money laundering (AML) controls and improper conduct by senior management at the head office in Switzerland as well as the Singapore branch", it said on Tuesday.

site_title: Driverless vehicle to be tested on UK streets for the first time
summary: A driverless vehicle carrying passengers will be tested on UK streets for the first time, as part of trials aimed at paving the way for autonomous cars to hit the highways by 2025. The UK government has launched a consultation on changes to insurance rules and motoring regulations to allow driverless cars to be used by 2020. The government aims to build an industry worth around £900 billion by 2025, and the trials are part of its efforts to encourage technology companies and carmakers to develop and test autonomous driving technologies in Britain.

site_title: Revamped Macau sees golden week with a million Chinese tourists
summary: Macau saw a record 970,000 Chinese tourists during the National Day holiday, known as Golden Week, with a 6.9% increase from the previous year. Despite China's slowing economy, the city's efforts to diversify its economy, including non-casino attractions, appear to be paying off. The number of visitors from China has not been this high in at least 10 years, with the city's casino industry also posting a second month of higher gaming revenue in September.

site_title: Coca-Cola to buy AB InBev's stake in African bottler
summary: Coca-Cola will buy Anheuser-Busch InBev's 57% stake in Africa's largest Coca-Cola bottler, Coca-Cola Beverages Africa (CCBA), following AB InBev's takeover of SABMiller. Coke retains a 11.3% stake in CCBA and will negotiate terms with AB InBev in the coming months. The move aims to refinance CCBA, which operates in 12 markets across Southern and East Africa.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise helped by oil stocks; Deutsche Bank rebounds
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Monday, reversing earlier weakness, driven by oil stocks rallying on stronger crude prices. The STOXX Oil index rose 1.9% as Brent crude prices reached a one-year high. Deutsche Bank rebounded 3.4% after Austria's finance minister expressed confidence in resolving the German lender's problems without collateral damage. Despite some caution, investors favored equities over bonds, citing low interest rates and better returns on offer.

site_title: RBS denies latest SME claims, lawmaker demands review publication
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) denies allegations it deliberately caused small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to fail, stating investigations found no wrongdoing. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is reviewing the bank's Global Restructuring Group (GRG) treatment of SMEs during the 2007-09 financial crisis. A whistleblower's leaked documents support allegations of a "dash for cash" by bank staff, prompting Chairman of Parliament's Treasury Select Committee Andrew Tyrie to demand a publication date for the FCA review. The review, initially due by the end of 2015, is now expected to be completed.

images.alt_text: Royal Bank of Scotland said on Monday there was no evidence it had deliberately caused SMEs to fail, while a senior British lawmaker called for the country's regulator to fix a publication date for a long-delayed review into the allegations.

site_title: Breather for sterling; Mexican peso surges
summary: The British pound steadied on Monday after a 10% decline in Asia, with the Bank of England's trade-weighted index hitting its lowest since 2009 due to Brexit concerns. The Mexican peso surged 2% to its highest level in nearly a month after a video of Donald Trump making vulgar comments about women, increasing the chances of a Democratic victory in the US elections. The pound was trading 0.1% lower than Friday's close at US$1.2418, while the Mexican peso rose to 18.91 to the US dollar.

site_title: Motivating millennials
summary: The 2016 Deloitte Millennial Survey highlights the importance of putting personal values first for millennials in the workforce. To bridge the gap between millennials and organizations, Deloitte recommends prioritizing employee engagement and autonomy, offering flexible work arrangements, and fostering a culture of inclusivity and diversity. By doing so, organizations can attract and retain top talent, driving business success. The survey emphasizes the need for employers to adapt to the changing needs and expectations of the younger workforce.

site_title: Oil trades near 16-month high on Saudi, Russia output pledge
summary: Oil prices rose near a 16-month high as Saudi Arabia and Russia pledged cooperation to limit output. Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih expressed optimism for a deal that could lift prices to $60 by year-end. Russia's President Vladimir Putin said the country is willing to join OPEC efforts to stabilize the market, potentially leading to a 700,000 barrel per day cut in November. Oil futures declined slightly after the announcement, closing near the highest level since July 2015.

site_title: Active managers defend relevance in a bad year
summary: Active managers in the US equity market have defended their relevance despite a poor year, citing the need to allocate capital ethically and sustainably, flexibility in portfolio management, and advisory roles. According to Morningstar, $290 billion was withdrawn from actively managed funds, while passive funds gained $260 billion in net inflows. Despite this, CEOs from asset managers such as Allianz Global Investors, Henderson Global Investors, and JP Morgan Asset Management argue that active managers can provide valuable insights into markets, manage risk, and offer a trusted partnership to clients.

site_title: Facebook founder Saverin sued in dispute over bankrupt startup
summary: Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin is being sued by investor Bloso Investments Ltd over his role in the bankruptcy of mobile-payment company Jumio Inc. The lawsuit claims Saverin and other directors misled shareholders about the company's prospects, leading to a US$5 million investment. Jumio filed for bankruptcy in 2016 after being forced to restate earnings. Saverin, who became a billionaire through Facebook's IPO, predicted the company would be highly profitable but failed to deliver. The case is set to be heard in Delaware Chancery Court.

images.alt_text: An investor in Jumio Inc sued Facebook Inc co-founder Eduardo Saverin and other directors of the mobile-payment company accusing them of mismanaging the startup and duping shareholders about its prospects.

site_title: Facebook launches intra-office 'Workplace' network
summary: Facebook has launched Workplace, a global platform for businesses to replace internal communication tools, competing with Microsoft's Yammer, Salesforce's Chatter, and Slack. Developed two years ago, Workplace has been tested on 1,000 companies worldwide and is accessible without a Facebook account. The service, priced between 1-3 euros per connected employee, enables real-time chat, group hosting, and Facebook Live features. Early adopters include Danone, Booking.com, and NGOs like Oxfam and Save the Children. The platform aims to connect the world's 2.5 billion employees, with a worldwide market potential.

site_title: The cost of overhyping globalisation
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has clarified that the slowdown in global trade growth is largely due to weak economic activity, particularly investment, rather than new barriers to trade. However, the IMF's faith in trade liberalization has led to overhyping its benefits, creating unrealistic expectations. The actual benefits of trade liberalization have declined as trade barriers reached low levels, and commodity prices, not trade liberalization, fueled growth in the early 2000s. This led to a decline in living standards in commodity-importing advanced countries, with workers feeling squeezed economically, ultimately contributing to the backlash against globalization.

site_title: Asia's growth to outpace rest of the world: Iswaran
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran stated that Asia's growth is expected to outpace the rest of the world, driven by higher disposable incomes and increasing demand for sophisticated goods and services. Key trends include e-commerce and the health and wellness industry, with Asia projected to be the fastest-growing market for organic food and beverages globally. Iswaran emphasized the importance of companies developing a deeper understanding of Asian consumers and enhancing their capabilities to capitalize on growth opportunities.

site_title: Trump berates and threatens in incendiary debate with Clinton
summary: Donald Trump threatened to jail Hillary Clinton if he wins the presidency, amid a heated presidential debate. Trump also accused Bill Clinton of abusing women, sparking widespread condemnation from critics and fellow Republicans. Clinton maintained her lead in polls, with two separate surveys showing her 57-34 and 47-42 ahead of Trump. Trump's campaign ratings have suffered, with a damaging weekend and the debate failing to improve his ratings.

images.alt_text: Mrs Clinton and Mr Trump standing on stage during the second US presidential debate at Washington University in Missouri on Sunday. The vicious debate appeared unlikely to improve Mr Trump's ratings after a damaging weekend, polls showed on Monday.

site_title: Anti-Uber taxi protest blocks Lisbon airport access
summary: Hundreds of taxi drivers in Lisbon blocked access to Lisbon airport, protesting against app-based ride-sharing companies like Uber, which they claim unfairly undercut their business. The protest, the third against ride-hailing apps in a year, involved 6,000 taxis and caused long queues for tourists. The drivers oppose plans by the government to regulate ride-sharing companies, citing concerns over safety and taxes. The protest continued after a meeting with the environment minister failed to produce a breakthrough, with taxi drivers saying they would stay until their demands are met.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of taxi drivers blocked access to Lisbon airport and snarled traffic in the Portuguese capital on Monday as they protested against app-based ride-sharing companies such as Uber.

site_title: World squeezing more from energy despite oil supply glut, says IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that despite an oil supply glut, the world has seen a 1.8% reduction in energy intensity, the largest decline in a decade, driven by increased investment in efficiency measures. This trend is expected to help nations meet their greenhouse gas reduction ambitions while reducing energy costs. The IEA attributes the gains to government policies, particularly in China, which reduced its energy intensity by 5.6% last year, and investments in efficiency measures totaling $221 billion.

site_title: Gearing up for future challenges
summary: Local transportation and logistics company Kim Soon Lee has grown from a single truck in 1968 to an impressive fleet of over 420 vehicles in five decades. The company has navigated various challenges, including the oil crisis and the Asian Financial Crisis, by shifting its focus to the construction industry and expanding its service range to include machinery packing and warehousing. With a strong track record and solid reputation, Kim Soon Lee has differentiated itself from competitors and continues to grow, with plans to expand into new areas such as forklift rental and heavy vehicle parking.

site_title: Samsung suspends production of Galaxy Note 7, says source
summary: Samsung has suspended production of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones amid reports of fires in replacement devices, exacerbating the tech giant's worst-ever recall crisis. Top US and Australian carriers have halted sales or exchanges of Note 7s, while major airlines continue to ban the use of the phones on flights. The move comes after a replacement Note 7 on a Southwest Airline flight caught fire, prompting concerns about Samsung's ability to fix a problem that has already hurt its brand.

site_title: US: Oil shares, Apple boost stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, driven by gains in petroleum companies due to higher oil prices and a jump in Apple shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.5% to 18,329.04, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively. ExxonMobil and Halliburton rose 2.0% and 2.2%, respectively, after oil prices reached their highest level of 2016. Apple rose 1.8% following reports of Galaxy Note 7 smartphone issues.

site_title: Govt to upgrade jobs bank into new portal
summary: Singapore's government plans to upgrade its jobs bank into a new online portal, offering more functions and career planning tools. The revamp aims to address underemployment issues and provide jobseekers with clearer career paths and training programs. However, economists say the move is only a "band-aid" measure, urging a deeper rethink on how the country's labor force can be structured to address stagnating employment growth. The government attributes the decline in local employment to cyclical and demographic factors, including a shift in the youngest working demographic group and rising retiree numbers.

site_title: The future of work: enterprise social networks and coworking
summary: Singapore's office landscape is transforming, driven by a need for collaboration and business agility. Enterprise social networks, such as Facebook's Workplace, are increasing communication among employees, while co-working spaces are providing flexible workspaces for mobile professionals. Companies like HSBC and HSBC have adopted co-working to foster innovation and manage costs. The trend is expected to continue, with co-working operators launching new facilities in Singapore and the region, and large companies seeking to tap into the collaborative culture and services offered by co-working spaces.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint to pump up to half a billion into Thailand's Ticon
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has agreed to invest up to $520 million in Ticon Industrial Connection, a Thai industrial property developer, making it the single largest shareholder. The investment, if completed, will be conditional and could be valued at 13.23 billion baht. Ticon's market capitalization was 18.7 billion baht as of October 7.

site_title: US House speaker won't 'defend' Trump, as Clinton poll lead grows
summary: US House Speaker Paul Ryan has effectively ended his support for Donald Trump's presidential campaign, stating he can no longer "defend" Trump due to the Republican candidate's lewd comments about women. With 29 days until Election Day, Trump's campaign is facing increasing pressure. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton's poll lead has expanded, and she has returned to the campaign trail, revitalized by the latest polls.

site_title: Taking over a Hong Kong street for pleasure, not protest
summary: A group of people in Hong Kong's Central district took over a street for a car-free experiment, similar to the 2014 pro-democracy protests. The event, which drew hundreds, was not a protest but a "pleasure" activity. The area was previously blocked by protesters for weeks, but this time, participants were not concerned about police crackdowns. The event aimed to show that people can peacefully occupy public spaces without the need for protests.

site_title: No recession, but expect periods of negative growth: MTI
summary: Singapore's Trade Minister Lim Hng Kiang said the government does not expect an outright recession, but the economy may experience periods of negative growth. Lim cited weak economic indicators, including rising unemployment and a weak global outlook, as reasons for the concern. Despite this, the government stands ready to respond to a downturn and is prepared to consider introducing contingency measures. The forecast for the full year remains at between 1 and 2 percent, with growth expected to come in lower in the second half of the year.

site_title: Manulife US Reit shooting for one acquisition a year
summary: Manulife US Reit plans to acquire one office asset per year to grow its portfolio, focusing on secondary cities in the US. The Reit aims to diversify its portfolio by geography and tenant base, targeting assets with high yield accretion. US gateway cities like New York and San Francisco are reaching peak pricing, but Manulife US Reit can still find yield-accretive deals in secondary markets. The Reit's distribution yield is projected to grow to 7.1% in 2017, driven by the US office market's strong economic growth and competitive yields.

site_title: A shared responsibility for a digital future
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation vision relies on digital innovation, but its systems must be secure and resilient to prevent vulnerabilities. The city-state must balance the benefits and risks of emerging technologies like the Internet of Things (IoT), cloud computing, and data analytics. Cybersecurity is crucial, and individuals, businesses, and governments must work together to raise awareness and upskill the workforce. The government and private sector must co-develop learning opportunities to address the evolving competency demands of a Smart Nation, and a shared sense of cyber responsibility is essential for reaping the benefits of a digital future.

images.alt_text: Singapore is making steady progress towards enabling its ecosystem of people, businesses, infrastructure, education, policies and culture to be digitally ready. The relentless focus on digital will only be sharpened, in the light of the directions from the Committee on the Future Economy.

site_title: Investors should hope China's price-cooling measures work
summary: China has implemented price-cooling measures in 20 cities to curb rising property prices, but investors may be concerned about the effectiveness of these measures, which could lead to a sell-off in the market. Similar measures in 2010 were met with limited success, prompting the government to restrict developers' access to funding. If these new measures fail, investors may face increased borrowing costs and defaults, outweighing any short-term benefits. The measures may decrease property values and future profits, but could also avoid sky-high borrowing costs in the long term.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Financial names new CEO to oversee IPO in 2017
summary: Ant Financial, the online financial services giant controlled by billionaire Jack Ma, has appointed Eric Jing as its new CEO to oversee its initial public offering (IPO) in 2017. Jing, a veteran of corporate finance with extensive experience working with multinational companies, takes the helm from Lucy Peng, who will retain the position of executive chair. The switch comes as Ant Financial prepares for a potential Hong Kong market debut, which would be one of the city's largest IPOs since 2010.

site_title: Pragmatic policies needed to counter backlash against globalisation
summary: Globalisation faces backlash, but influential voices defend its benefits. IMF managing director Christine Lagarde and OECD secretary-general Jose Angel Gurria argue that globalisation is crucial for international cooperation and coordination. Singapore's Tharman Shanmugaratnam suggests that domestic policy failures, not globalisation, are the main cause of social issues. Despite this, protectionist policies are gaining traction in the US and UK, and trade agreements are under attack. Economists advocate for pragmatic policies to address the challenges of globalisation, such as supporting lower-skilled workers and targeted subsidies to protect threatened industries.

site_title: US oil prices close at US$51.35 a barrel, highest for 2016
summary: US oil prices closed at $51.35 a barrel, the highest for 2016, after Russian President Vladimir Putin stated Russia would support Opec's agreement to limit oil output. This move follows an agreement reached last month by Opec to reduce output. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate for November delivery jumped $1.54 from its previous close. Opec is set to meet in November to finalize details of the agreement. The price increase is attributed to the potential reduction in oil supply, which could lead to higher prices.

site_title: Leadership in the digital age
summary: Business leaders must adapt to the rapidly changing digital landscape and groom a new generation of leaders, particularly millennials, who will make up the core of a company's leadership pool in the near future. With their different values, these employees require a tailored approach to development. According to Philip Yuen, CEO of Deloitte Southeast Asia and Deloitte Singapore, senior management must dedicate more time and resources to develop leaders, even during difficult times. This will be crucial for companies to thrive in today's business world.

images.alt_text: "Leaders for tomorrow have to adopt a more open approach that allows for greater collaboration to embrace diverse capabilities." - PwC Singapore's Greg Unsworth

"We want to challenge conventional ways of collaboration and encourage them (leaders) to explore the use of emerging technologies and data science solutions to remain relevant to our clients' needs and expectations." - Standard Chartered's Stanley Sia

"Organisations need to keep in mind that they need to build leaders with a future focus, which means leaders that are relevant to the future, for example, those that are equipped with keen digital understanding and agility. These leaders also need to be front and centre of all efforts." - Deloitte Southeast Asia and Deloitte Singapore's Philip Yuen

"From my observation, some factors which are important to the millennials are having an office environment which encourages communication and team activities and having an environment which allows them to air their ideas and unhappiness." - WongPartnership's Rachel Eng

site_title: US office remains a landlord's market for at least next 2 years: Manulife US Reit
summary: The US office market remains a landlord's market for at least the next two years, driven by growing demand outpacing supply and increasing occupancies and rents. According to Manulife US Reit, the fundamentals of the US office sector are strong, with a vacancy rate of 10-15% or less indicating a landlord's market. The US has seen moderate construction of new office space following the sub-prime crisis, with demand rising steadily amid an unemployment rate of 4.9%. Key cities, such as Atlanta, Irvine, and Los Angeles, are expected to continue registering rental growth, with rents moderating to more sustainable levels in Orange County and Los Angeles.

site_title: Powerplus powers back to home base
summary: Singapore construction equipment manufacturer Powerplus, founded in 1973, returns home after a 13-year absence. The company, which was incorporated in the US in 2003, focuses on regional markets and beyond, but now seeks to tap into the Singaporean market. Under the leadership of CEO and chairman Marcus Ong, Powerplus plans to release some of its machinery into the Singaporean market, targeting the high-rise construction industry. The company aims to create a "one-stop" operation, offering affordable equipment at competitive prices, with a focus on quality products and technical support.

site_title: The Girl on the Train tops weekend box office
summary: The Girl on the Train, a psychological thriller directed by Tate Taylor and starring Emily Blunt, topped the weekend box office with an estimated $24.7 million in the US and Canada. The film, based on Paula Hawkins' novel, beat out The Birth of a Nation, which placed sixth, and Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life. The box office win marks a boost for Universal Pictures, which trails Disney and Warner Bros. in domestic market share.

images.alt_text: Emily Blunt plays an alcoholic who becomes obsessed with the lives of her ex-husband's new wife and nanny.

site_title: PM Lee unveils new cybersecurity strategy
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong unveiled a new cybersecurity strategy, focusing on four key components to boost the resilience of the country's Critical Information Infrastructure (CII) supporting essential services. The strategy supersedes the 2018 National Cyber Security Masterplan and will be implemented in collaboration with private-sector operators and the cybersecurity community. The goal is to strengthen Singapore's cybersecurity infrastructure and enhance its resilience against cyber threats.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare IPO prices at low end, raises S$213m: IFR
summary: Fullerton Healthcare's initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore priced at the low end, raising S$213 million at S$1.52 per share. This is below the indicative range of S$1.52-$1.93. The IPO consists of 140.3 million shares, with 18.9% of the company listed, following a greenshoe option. This is the company's first IPO, amidst a 17-year low in Singapore IPO activity last year.

site_title: Polly want a quaker? No thank you, says Spain
summary: Spain is dealing with an influx of South American quaker parrots, also known as monk parakeets, which have taken up residence in cities such as Madrid and are causing disturbance to residents and the ecosystem. The birds, which are native to Argentina, Brazil, and other countries, have been released into the wild after being kept as pets and have proliferated, competing with native birds for food and causing damage to trees. Authorities have banned the sale of the birds and are considering measures to control their population, but are hesitant to cull them due to animal rights concerns.

site_title: Regional development banks call for more coordination
summary: The heads of four regional development banks, including the Asian Development Bank (ADB), African Development Bank (AfDB), Inter-American Development Bank (IADB), and European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), have issued a statement calling for closer coordination and a "systemic" approach among multilateral development banks. The statement responds to a report from the Centre for Global Development, which recommends five changes to improve the effectiveness of these institutions. The banks also emphasized the need for regional development banks to play a more significant role in financing climate-smart and resilient infrastructure.

site_title: Filipino film gives new take on foreign domestic workers
summary: A documentary titled "Sunday Beauty Queen" has premiered at the 21st Busan International Film Festival, showcasing the daily lives of foreign domestic workers in Hong Kong. The film, directed by Baby Ruth Villarama, offers a fresh perspective on the lives of these workers, highlighting their hopes, dreams, and struggles. The documentary is in the running for the major documentary prize in Busan and follows a group of Filipino domestic workers as they prepare for an annual beauty pageant.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' research firm BS Group Research has maintained its top picks for Singapore stocks in October, including China Aviation Oil, Cityneon, Katrina Group, and Singapore O&G. They also added Ezion Holdings due to the recent Opec production cuts, which they believe will see a strong rebound in oil sentiment. Additionally, the firm has identified several undervalued stocks trading below their net cash per share, including Nobel Design Holdings, Sinostar PEC Holdings, and CDW Holding.

site_title: Aussie property market not overvalued: Morrison
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison stated that the country's housing market is not overvalued, despite rising property prices in Sydney. He also indicated that the central bank is unlikely to cut interest rates further, which are already at record low levels. Morrison cited "no evidence" to support claims of an overvalued market, saying risks can be "overstated."

site_title: Trump after the debate: The Departed or the Survivor?
summary: Donald Trump has refused to drop out of the presidential race despite releasing a video of him making vulgar comments about women. In a televised debate with Hillary Clinton, Trump successfully contained the fallout of the video, dismissing it as "locker room talk" and shifting the focus to Bill Clinton's alleged sexual misconduct. Trump forced Clinton to defend her policies and achievements, and his performance may have persuaded Republican sceptics that he's here to stay. Despite the controversy, Trump survived the debate and is unlikely to regain momentum, with his performance failing to change his reality of mostly white blue-collar support.

site_title: Short bets at record as Walmart fails to subdue JD.com bears
summary: Bearish bets on JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce company, reached record levels after Wal-Mart raised its stake to 10.8% in the company. Despite a 34% rally in JD.com's US-traded stock, analysts expect the company's 2016 adjusted net loss to widen 10% to 947 million yuan due to intensifying competition with Alibaba and economic growth slowdown. A strategic alliance with Wal-Mart is unlikely to bring a quick and easy result, with analysts citing Alibaba's stronger online platform and broader product offerings as a major challenge.

site_title: Temporary cut in GST possible if M'sian economy continues to weaken
summary: Malaysia is unlikely to increase the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate in the upcoming budget, maintaining it at 6%. However, if the economy continues to deteriorate, a temporary reduction in GST may be considered as a last resort. An online survey revealed living costs, housing, and urban issues as top concerns ahead of Budget 2017, set to be tabled on October 21.

site_title: Saizen Reit, Sime Darby Property make headway in RTO deal
summary: Saizen Reit and Sime Darby Property Singapore have made progress in a proposed Reverse Takeover (RTO) deal. Sime Darby Property will transfer its Australian industrial properties to Saizen Reit for A$356 million (S$371 million), which will be financed through new units and debt. The deal will expand Saizen Reit's unit base and increase its market value. The properties are currently fully occupied and have a weighted average lease expiry of 16.7 years, with annual rental escalations of 1.5% in the first three years and 2.75% thereafter.

site_title: China intensifies push to cut debt with steps to reduce leverage
summary: China has released guidelines to reduce corporate debt, stating that the government will not bear the final responsibility for borrowing by companies. The guidelines include measures for banks to swap bad debt to equity and acknowledge potential risks, such as cross-market contagion. China's total debt has grown 465% over the past decade, with corporate debt jumping to 165% of GDP. Policymakers aim to reduce systemic risks in the financial sector and stabilize the economy, which is forecast to exceed the 6.5% growth target for this year.

site_title: All-new BT Weekend a hit with readers
summary: The Business Times Weekend, a revamped publication, was well-received by readers with its new format featuring a luxury lifestyle magazine and a leisurely weekend read. The cover story examined Singapore's comparison to great cities and the salted egg yolk craze. Readers praised the publication's clean and modern look, intelligent writing, and well-curated content, with some even winning exclusive dining deals and digital access to The Peak Singapore. The revamped edition is available until November 30.

site_title: Noble sells US energy unit for US$800m
summary: Noble Group sold its US energy unit, Noble Americas Energy Solutions, to Calpine Corporation for $800 million, aiming to restore confidence in its balance sheet. The sale does not include net working capital, estimated at $248 million by Noble. Analysts say Noble's balance sheet is stronger, but some remain cautious on the stock.

site_title: Belgium and Singapore: 50 years of history and ties
summary: Belgium and Singapore celebrated the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations on October 10, 2016. The two countries have a long history of cooperation, with over 1,600 Belgians living in Singapore and more than 100 Belgian companies operating there. Singapore has chosen Belgium as its largest trading partner in ASEAN, and Belgian companies have invested heavily in Singapore's ports and infrastructure. The two countries have collaborated on various projects, including renewable energy and biomed, and have a strong economic partnership. The anniversary marked a significant milestone in the two countries' relationship and highlighted the potential for future cooperation.

site_title: SingPost appoints three new independent directors
summary: SingPost appoints three new independent directors, Fang Ai Lian, Elizabeth Kong, and Bob Tan, to its board in line with a corporate governance review. The appointments bring governance and professional experience, and greater diversity to the board. The company has also implemented various recommendations from the review, including reconstituting the ExCo as a finance and investment committee and forming a market disclosure committee. The board now has 11 directors, of whom seven are independent directors, and the company has substantially implemented all the recommendations from the review.

site_title: Janus Henderson to operate from CapitaGreen office
summary: Henderson Global Investors will operate its combined entity, Janus Henderson Global Investors, from a new office in Singapore's CapitaGreen building. The merger, announced last week, results in a combined assets under management of $322 billion. Job cuts are likely to occur globally, primarily in back-end support functions rather than front-end investment roles. Cost savings from the merger include $110 million annually, primarily from reduced building costs and regulatory compliance. The combined firm aims to grow at an estimated 2-3% annually, with products cross-distributed on each other's networks.

site_title: The new reactionaries!
summary: US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are peddling nostalgic agendas that promise to recreate a more appealing past. Trump aims to "make America great again" by undoing trade agreements and implementing massive tax cuts, while Clinton promises handouts and government programs. However, both proposals are unrealistic and ignore the complexities of the modern economy and demographic changes. The candidates' focus on the past rather than the future may lead to disappointment, as their plans fail to address pressing issues like aging population growth and stagnant productivity.

site_title: Dubai begins building 'world's tallest' tower
summary: Dubai has begun construction on The Tower at Dubai Creek Harbour, set to be the world's tallest tower when completed in 2020, surpassing the current Burj Khalifa. Designed by Santiago Calatrava Valls, the 360-degree observation deck tower will be slender, resembling a minaret, and cost around $1 billion. The project aims to be completed before the Expo 2020 trade fair in Dubai.

site_title: 2 more ex-BSI bankers charged in 1MDB-linked probe
summary: Singapore prosecutors have filed charges against two former BSI Singapore bankers, Yak Yew Chee and Yvonne Seah Yew Foong, for forgery and failure to flag suspicious transactions related to 1MDB-linked probe. The charges involve seven counts each, with three related to forgery and four for failing to report suspicious transactions between 2012 and 2014. The pair appeared in court to face the charges, as Singapore continues its probe into the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Brent oil price hits highest level in a year
summary: Brent North Sea crude oil rose to $53.45 a barrel on Monday, its highest price in a year, following President Vladimir Putin's indication that Russia is ready to join measures to limit global oil production. This marks a $1.53 increase from Monday's price. The price has not been this high since October 2015, when it reached $54.05 a barrel.

site_title: India SUV maker eyes China e-vehicle market
summary: India's Mahindra is exploring a joint venture in China to manufacture and sell electric vehicles, competing with over 200 local companies. The move aims to tap the country's growing e-vehicle market, where the government has set a target of 5 million EVs by 2020. Mahindra's CEO, Arvind Mathew, says the company is looking to build scale in the market, which is attractive due to its range of electric cars and generous government incentives.

site_title: FinTech defined: innovative change at its core
summary: FinTech, defined as "computer programmes and other technology used to support or enable banking and financial services," has become a key aspect of innovative change in the financial sector. It should meet needs, close gaps, and make lives better, as seen in digital payments, where companies like Alibaba and Lazada have made consumer transactions more convenient. FinTech also enhances business and investment decisions through technology, and its impact is characterized by simplicity, with a fundamental customer proposition that is easy to understand and benefit from.

site_title: SGX's querying system - still a work-in-progress
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has faced criticism for its inconsistent approach to querying companies about unusual share movements. A recent incident involving Keppel T&T's 12% share surge over 10 sessions, despite a prominent analyst report and company developments, raises questions about the effectiveness of SGX's querying system. Similarly, the lack of a query for Poh Tiong Choon Logistics' 54% share surge, which was attributed to a strategic review by five substantial shareholders, has sparked confusion. SGX's inconsistency has led observers to question its ability to discharge its duties and calls for the exchange to fine-tune its trading query system.

site_title: Malaysia's end-Sept palm oil stockpiles rise while exports drop
