summary: Malaysia's palm oil stockpiles rose to a near six-year high at the end of September, edging up from a low in the previous month, due to weaker exports and lower production. This could weigh on benchmark palm oil prices, which have fallen 6% since reaching a five-month high on September 26. As a result, palm oil prices rose 0.3% to 2,569 ringgit (S$851) per tonne at the midday break on Monday.

site_title: Greece has delivered reforms for bailout payout: EU's Moscovici
summary: Greece has delivered reforms necessary to unlock 2.8 billion euros in rescue loans from its third bailout, according to European Commission's Pierre Moscovici. The reforms, including the launch of a new privatisation fund and energy sector reforms, will be reviewed and may trigger talks on debt relief. However, Germany has expressed concerns that Greece still hasn't met all requirements, and the IMF demands a concrete plan to cut Greece's massive debt burden. The EU and IMF disagree on the extent of Athens' financial improvements.

site_title: UBS wealth management moves downmarket
summary: UBS Group AG, the world's largest wealth manager, is launching "SmartWealth" a digital platform to expand its business and scale up. The platform will offer low-cost online investment services to UK customers with as little as £15,000, and other countries will be included in the future. The move aims to take advantage of advances in digital technology and tap into the growing "mass affluent" market, with fees starting at 1.7% for actively managed portfolios. The project is part of UBS's global drive to expand its wealth management business and counter record-low interest rates.

site_title: Shifting perspectives
summary: Philip Yuen, CEO of Deloitte Southeast Asia and Singapore, emphasizes the need for three shifts in perspective for effective leadership in the digital age. These shifts include: (1) thinking differently, adapting to complexity and finding opportunities; (2) acting differently, embracing change and collaboration; and (3) reacting differently, thriving in ambiguity and confidence in the face of disruption. Yuen's advice aims to help leaders adapt to the rapidly changing digital landscape.

site_title: Uber gears up to take on Ola in India after exiting China
summary: Uber is expanding its operations in India, aiming to unseat homegrown rival Ola at the top of the market. The company has closed the gap, handling 5.5 million rides per week in August, and plans to recruit a million drivers by 2018. Uber has also stepped up investments in the country, unveiling its first-ever brand campaign in India. The company's operations in India are a strategic priority, accounting for 12% of all rides on its platform globally. Uber's CEO has cut short a paternity break to rejoin the fray, highlighting the company's commitment to the Indian market.

site_title: PTC chairman tempers expectations for 5.7% fare cuts
summary: PTC chairman Richard Magnus tempered expectations for a 5.7% fare cut, citing lower energy prices and the need to balance restructuring and investing in rail systems. Energy prices may rebound sharply, and the council must also address manpower issues and collective agreements expiring soon. Magnus emphasized the need for trade-offs between commuter interests and operator viability, and suggested standardizing fares and making gradual adjustments to avoid adverse impacts on the industry. A review of the fare adjustment mechanism is expected to occur in 2018.

site_title: PM Lee on 3-day official visit to Australia
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong begins a three-day official visit to Australia, marking the inaugural summit between the two leaders under their Comprehensive Strategic Partnership framework. Lee will meet with Australian counterpart Malcolm Turnbull, lay a wreath at the Australian War Memorial, and deliver an address to the Australian Parliament. The visit will also include the signing of several agreements covering military training, free-trade, innovation, and counter-narcotics. Lee is accompanied by his wife, ministers, and parliamentarians, while Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean will act as Acting Prime Minister during his absence.

site_title: China hits two more vehicle makers for green subsidy breaches
summary: China has punished two vehicle makers, Lifan Group and Chongqing Hengtong Bus Company, for producing and selling vehicles with lower power capacity batteries than advertised. The government accused over 25 car makers of breaking green car subsidy rules, casting a shadow on China's efforts to support the industry and combat pollution. The move has also impacted analysts' expectations for the industry's sales target of 700,000 electric and plug-in hybrid cars for the full year. China spent $4.5 billion last year on subsidies for green vehicles, which will be phased out by 2021.

site_title: Limited legal online betting 'creates safer space to manage gambling'
summary: Singapore has introduced a limited online betting system, allowing two operators to offer services after a three-year exemption from the Remote Gambling Act. Senior Minister Desmond Lee stated that the move aims to provide a "regulated and controlled" outlet for betting activities, diverting them from illegal operators. The government is concerned about the problem of remote gambling, which has a global market estimated to be worth around $40 billion. Social and Family Development Minister Tan Chuan-Jin emphasized the need to provide a "safer space" to manage these activities, while also addressing the issue of criminal involvement in online gambling.

site_title: Changes to elected presidency, NCMP schemes tabled
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a bill to amend the country's elected presidency system, including a new threshold for private-sector candidates, which must hold the most senior executive position in a company with at least S$500 million in shareholders' equity. A reserved election for minority candidates will also be introduced, where a community with no president in the past five terms will be given a reserved election. Additionally, the number of non-constituency MPs (NCMPs) will increase to 12 and they will gain equal voting rights. The bill will be debated in November.

site_title: SingPost adds three new directors to its board
summary: SingPost has appointed three new non-executive independent directors to its board, increasing the number of independent directors to seven. The new directors, Fang Ai Lian, Elizabeth Kong, and Bob Tan, bring governance and professional experience to the board. The company has also implemented recommendations from a corporate governance review, including reorganizing its board committees and establishing a finance and investment committee. This move aims to strengthen the board and improve governance.

site_title: UK, Finland-born economists win 2016 Nobel Prize for Economics
summary: UK-born Oliver Hart and Finland-born Bengt Holmstrom won the 2016 Nobel Economics Prize for their contributions to contract theory. The prize, worth 8 million Swedish crowns, recognizes their work as a foundation for designing policies and institutions in various areas, including bankruptcy legislation and political constitutions.

site_title: Founding family controls 99.2% of Sim Lian at close of delisting offer
summary: The founding Kuik family controls 99.2% of Sim Lian Group after exercising the right to acquire all remaining shares held by dissenting shareholders. Coronation 3G, the family's investment vehicle, made a cash offer of S$1.08 per share, and the company will delist from the stock exchange as a result. This marks a significant consolidation of ownership, with the family now holding nearly all of the company's shares.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.060 points to 1,665.320. The market saw 1.292 billion lots traded worth RM1.366 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 460 to 324.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's Falih says Opec should not crimp supply too tightly
summary: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih said Opec should not limit oil supply too tightly to avoid market shock, while maintaining a balanced approach. He expressed optimism that a global production deal could be reached by November, following the Algiers agreement. Falih emphasized the need for responsible behavior and avoiding a price drop that could impact investment, as prices have already dropped too low. He will meet with Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak to discuss Russia's reaction to the Algiers agreement.

site_title: Hollande weighs Putin talks amid 'unacceptable' Syria action
summary: French President Francois Hollande has expressed concerns over Russian President Vladimir Putin's actions in Syria, calling them "unacceptable" and "war crimes." Hollande is weighing whether to meet with Putin when he visits Paris on October 19, amid efforts to pressure Putin to stop supporting Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's regime. Hollande plans to discuss the issue with Putin and emphasize the need for an international investigation into alleged war crimes in Aleppo.

site_title: India bad loans mountain grows, risks delaying bank clean-up
summary: India's stressed loans in the banking sector have surpassed $138 billion, a 15% increase in six months, according to central bank data. This surge is expected to delay the government's clean-up effort and increase costs. The government has set a March 2019 deadline for banks to disclose problem loans, which will require significant writedowns and equity injections. India's state banks, which dominate the sector, need $27 billion in new equity capital by 2019 to meet global banking rules. The situation is expected to worsen, with NPLs estimated to rise by 35-40% and banks facing significant provisioning pressure.

site_title: Deutsche Bank forced into rethink as strategy overhaul stutters: sources
summary: Deutsche Bank's year-old strategic overhaul is facing a re-evaluation due to a potential $14 billion fine from US regulators for misselling toxic mortgage securities. The bank's management is considering tweaks to its plan, which aims to slash costs by cutting staff and selling non-core businesses. Despite initial plans to shed 9,000 jobs, the bank is reluctant to sack too many staff due to high redundancy payouts and fears over losing business. The overhaul is also behind schedule, with the sale of its stake in Chinese lender Hua Xia and the sale of Postbank retail lender expected to be delayed.

images.alt_text: Threatened with a multi-billion-dollar fine from US regulators, Deutsche Bank's management is rethinking elements of its year-old strategic overhaul that has made faltering progress, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Q&M's MOU to buy stake in Chinese dental lab business lapses
summary: Q&M Dental Group's Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to buy a 47.14% stake in a Chinese dental lab business has lapsed due to non-completion by Sept 30, 2016. The company remains in negotiations over the proposed acquisition. The original deal was signed in June, but it failed to meet its expected deadline. Q&M will continue to explore opportunities for growth in the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: Q&M Dental Group said on Monday a memorandum of understanding (MOU) over a business acquisition in China has lapsed.

site_title: British economy losing steam as business investment wilts, surveys show
summary: Britain's economy appears to be losing steam, with business surveys showing a slowdown in the services sector and doubts about the future following the country's Brexit vote. Investment intentions have hit four-year lows, with 40% of respondents expected to cut investment over the next three years. The weak pound has boosted exports for manufacturers, but concerns about a "hard Brexit" and access to the EU have pushed sterling to a 31-year low against the dollar. The economy is expected to grow by just 1% next year, according to the British Chambers of Commerce.

images.alt_text: Britain's economy appears to be losing steam, with major business surveys showing a marked slowdown in the services sector and boardrooms beset by doubt about the future following the country's vote to leave the European Union.

site_title: Public Transport Council chairman tempers expectations for fare cuts
summary: PTC chairman Richard Magnus tempered expectations for fare cuts, stating that a 5.7% reduction, the maximum allowed under the 2016 fare review exercise, may not be feasible due to lower energy prices. Magnus emphasized the need to balance restructuring and investing in rail systems to meet commuters' expectations, rather than granting the full quantum of reduction.

site_title: FLASH: Two BSI Singapore employees charged for criminal offences
summary: Two former employees of BSI Singapore have been charged with criminal offences. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has made the announcement. The charges are related to criminal offences, but no further details have been released.

site_title: Sime Darby Property to proceed with Saizen Reit reverse takeover
summary: Sime Darby Property Singapore will acquire Australian assets valued at A$356 million (S$371 million) through a reverse takeover of Saizen Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit). The acquisition includes 20 industrial properties across Queensland and the Northern Territory, totaling approximately 1 million square meters. The deal follows discussions announced in August. Saizen Reit will list on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) and gain access to Sime Darby's Australian assets.

site_title: Myanmar sends troops into Muslim-majority region after deadly attacks
summary: Myanmar has deployed troops into a Muslim-majority region near its border with Bangladesh in response to deadly attacks that killed at least nine police officers. The attacks, which occurred on Sunday, also resulted in the deaths of eight attackers and the capture of two. Authorities have imposed a curfew and restricted gatherings in the region, which has a large Rohingya population. Human rights advocates have raised concerns about potential human rights abuses, and the situation remains tense.

site_title: Thailand to revive Iranian economic ties through rice deals, trade
summary: Thailand aims to resume rice exports with Iran, increasing bilateral trade from $310 million to $3 billion by 2021. The agreement follows a meeting between Thai and Iranian trade leaders, with Thailand targeting 700,000 tonnes of rice exports annually. Iran's public health ministry is inspecting the quality of Thai grain, with shipping expected to begin soon after completion. This move is seen as a boost to Thailand's rice industry, which had faced economic sanctions imposed in 2012. The agreement also marks a significant step in strengthening economic ties between the two nations.

site_title: US: Strength in Apple, oil shares lifts US stocks
summary: US stocks opened higher Monday, driven by gains in Apple and petroleum-linked shares. Apple rose 1.1% after Samsung acknowledged production issues with the Galaxy Note 7 smartphone. ExxonMobil and Chevron also rose about 1% due to higher US oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all advanced 0.6-0.7% at the start of trade.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong launched the country's new cybersecurity strategy, aiming to strengthen the resilience of Critical Information Infrastructure. Meanwhile, two former BSI Singapore employees were charged with criminal offenses. Additionally, Deputy Prime Minister Gan announced a visit to the US for trade talks, while a new grant of up to S$100,000 was introduced for tariff-hit businesses.

site_title: KepLand to buy solar energy from Keppel Infrastructure to power its HQ
summary: KepLand, a Green Mark-certified office in Singapore, has partnered with Keppel Infrastructure to purchase renewable solar energy to power its corporate office. The energy is harvested from solar panels operated by Keppel Infrastructure and transferred to KepLand. This is the first time a Green Mark-certified office in Singapore uses offsite renewable energy to fully power its operations. KepLand aims to reduce its carbon emission intensity by 16% by 2020, resulting in potential savings of S$12.4 million. Regular audits will be conducted by the National University of Singapore's Solar Energy Research Institute of Singapore.

site_title: Global Q3 clean energy investment at weakest since 2013: research
summary: Global clean energy investment in Q3 2016 fell to its lowest quarterly level since 2013, totaling US$42.2 billion, a 31% decline from the previous quarter and 43% from the same period last year. This was mainly due to a slowdown in project financing in China and Japan, with asset finance of utility-scale renewable energy projects dropping 49% year-on-year. Experts warn that these numbers may be a 'new normal' and could lead to a record-low clean energy investment for the year.

site_title: China must take action to reduce high corporate debt: state planner
summary: China's state planner has urged the government to take action to reduce corporate debt levels, citing operating difficulties and financial risks for some firms. The National Development and Reform Commission will allow firms to develop equity financing and conduct debt-to-equity swaps, while stepping up checks on state-owned firms. The government will also permit firms to go bankrupt according to the law. China aims to combine deleveraging with overcapacity reductions to reduce corporate costs.

site_title: Taiwan calls for renewed talks with China
summary: Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-Wen has called for renewed talks with China, urging both sides to "set aside the baggage of history and engage in positive dialogue". Tsai has refused to accept the concept of "one China," prompting Beijing to cut off official communication. China views self-ruling Taiwan as part of its territory requiring reunification. Tsai's government has accused Beijing of pressuring countries to deport Taiwanese suspects and blocking Taiwan's participation in international events. Tsai has pledged to maintain the status quo and resolve differences through calm and flexible dialogue.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slip as Deutsche Bank falls
summary: European stock markets declined on Monday, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index falling 0.2% due to a 2.6% drop in Deutsche Bank shares. The bank's struggles with US authorities' demands for up to $14 billion over mis-selling allegations weighed on the sector. However, William Hill shares rose 5.5% after announcing merger talks with Canadian online peer Amaya.

site_title: Germany widens trade surplus in August
summary: Germany's trade surplus widened in August, reaching 22.2 billion euros, driven by a 5.4% increase in exports to 102.3 billion euros. Imports rose 3% to 80.1 billion euros. Analysts attribute the surge to strong demand for German goods, particularly outside the eurozone. The trade surplus has sparked calls for Germany to use its surplus to stimulate growth in the single currency bloc, with global financial chiefs, including Christine Lagarde and Mario Draghi, urging Berlin to increase spending.

site_title: Kuroda reiterates BOJ may push back inflation goal timetable
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated that the central bank may push back the forecast date for achieving its two per cent inflation target, citing strong uncertainty. The BOJ currently forecasts the target to be reached in the coming fiscal year, but Kuroda stated it may take "slightly more months" to reach the goal. This marks the latest in a series of warnings from the BOJ governor that the target may be pushed back due to uncertain economic growth and inflation forecasts.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated that the central bank may push back the forecast date for which it plans to achieve its two per cent inflation target, Bloomberg reported on Monday.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks rise after week-long break
summary: Chinese stocks rose over 1% on Monday, the first day of trading after a week-long break, driven by technology shares and a global rally. The Shanghai Composite Index increased 1.45% to 3,048.14, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.89% to 2,033.38. This follows a global market surge last week, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Givaudan says chairman, CFO to retire as sales growth slows in Q3
summary: Givaudan's chairman and CFO will retire in March 2017, with Calvin Grieder proposed as his replacement. The company reported slower like-for-like sales growth in Q3, totaling 3.1%, half the 6.2% growth in the first half, and short of a forecast. Third-quarter sales reached 1.184 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Hunt on for survivors after houses collapse in China, killing at least eight
summary: Four houses in Wenzhou, China's Zhejiang province, collapsed on Monday, killing at least eight people. Rescuers have pulled five survivors from the rubble. The cause of the pre-dawn collapse in an industrial district is unknown. The number of people in the buildings at the time of the accident is unknown.

site_title: China debt-to-equity swaps will not be free lunch for troubled firms: state planner
summary: China's planned debt-to-equity swap programme will target high-quality companies facing temporary difficulties, excluding "zombie firms". The government will not force banks to conduct swaps and will not be responsible for losses. Market-oriented swaps will not be a "free lunch" for firms, and the programme aims to reduce high corporate debt.

site_title: New British prime minister to decide on old runway problem in October
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will decide on new airport capacity near London by the end of October. She will consider plans for a new runway at either Heathrow or Gatwick, a decision that could impact Britain's economy and trading ties post-Brexit. The Heathrow option, worth $22 billion, faces environmental concerns but has strong trade links with emerging markets. A decision could come sooner if the UK's full capacity is reached, with the potential to boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Theresa May will decide where to allow new airport capacity near London this month, a long-awaited ruling that will help shape Britain's economy and trading ties following its vote to leave the European Union.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end firmer as Samsung Electronics recoups some losses, won rises
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.2% on Monday, rebounding from a decline in Samsung Electronics, which fell 1.5% amid a phone recall crisis. The company suspended Galaxy Note 7 production after reports of fires in replacement devices. The South Korean won strengthened 0.6% against the US dollar, as Samsung shares recouped some losses. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index closed at 2,056.82 points.

site_title: UK immigration plans would harm economy, business chiefs say
summary: UK business leaders criticize the government's plan to require companies to list foreign workers, calling it "anti-business and dangerously naive." More than 100 business chiefs signed a letter to the Daily Telegraph, saying the policy would harm the economy and workers' rights. Prime Minister Theresa May faces a growing backlash, with some, like Carolyn Fairbairn of the CBI, warning of a closed economy. The plan has been met with opposition from prominent business leaders, including Karan Bilimoria and Jeremy Leggett, who say it would hurt Britain's standing as a tolerant country open for business.

site_title: China says 173 steel firms violate environmental rules
summary: China's Ministry of Environmental Protection announced that 173 steel firms out of 1,019 inspected nationwide have violated environmental rules, including 62 involved in illegal construction and 35 exceeding state emission limits. The inspections were conducted in July to determine if the country's steel sector met state technology and emission standards.

site_title: Ex-Philippine president Ramos says Duterte government a "letdown"
summary: Former Philippine President Fidel Ramos criticized President Rodrigo Duterte's government, calling it a "huge disappointment and letdown" in his first 100 days in office. Ramos, a mentor to Duterte, said the government is prioritizing the war on drugs over issues like poverty and foreign investment. He listed the government's handling of extrajudicial killings, mixed statements on US relations, and verbal attacks on US President Barack Obama as concerns. Ramos expressed hope for a better future, urging Duterte to address the country's problems, starting with poverty.

site_title: Magnus Energy's auditor qualifies opinion over coal concession investment
summary: Magnus Energy's independent auditor issued a qualified opinion on the company's financial statement for the year ended June 30, 2016, due to an impairment loss of about S$15 million from its investment in coal concession rights. The loss was recognized after deducting a deferred tax credit of S$6.1 million. The final impairment loss depends on ongoing legal proceedings regarding the company's ownership interest in the coal concession.

site_title: Two ex-BSI Singapore employees charged with criminal offences
summary: Two former BSI Singapore senior private bankers, Yak Yew Chee and Yvonne Seah Yew Foong, have been charged with seven crimes each in connection with Malaysia's 1MDB case. The charges include forgery and failing to disclose information on suspicious transactions. The offences relate to Low Taek Jho's accounts with BSI Singapore, and the two Singapore nationals face prosecution.

site_title: World Bank's top economist tipped for Nobel
summary: The World Bank's top economist is among those tipped to win the Nobel Economics Prize, to be announced on Monday. The prize, created in 1968 by the Swedish central bank, honors economists working on growth and labor markets. The announcement comes as the awards season moves into its second week. No specific economist has been named, but their work on these topics is being recognized. The winner will be announced at 0945 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Thailand's economy to grow 3.2% to 3.5% this year: deputy PM
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3.2-3.5% this year, driven by increased foreign investment and record-high tourism. The forecast aligns with the Thai central bank's revised 2016 growth estimate. Tourism is expected to reach a record 33 million visitors, mostly from China. The economy expanded 2.8% last year, with Thailand forecasting a strong performance this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks close flat, pennies enjoy hectic churning
summary: Singapore's stock market closed flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index losing 5 points to 2,870.24, amid external uncertainties such as volatile oil prices and the upcoming US presidential election. Despite high unit turnover, the dollar value of business done was low, with only S$631.5 million traded at an average of S$0.28 per unit. This marked the highest unit turnover in three months.

images.alt_text: THE main feature of Monday's session was hectic churning of penny stocks such as Noble Group, Cedar Strategic, SunMoon and Ezra that propelled unit turnover to 2.2 billion units, estimated to be the highest in three months.

site_title: China's electric car market lures India's biggest SUV maker
summary: India's largest SUV maker, Mahindra and Mahindra Ltd, is exploring a joint venture with a Chinese partner to manufacture and sell electric vehicles in China's massive market. The company, which already sells electric cars in the UK and Indian subcontinent, aims to tap into China's growing demand for EVs. Mahindra Reva Electric Vehicles Pvt Ltd is open to partnering with a Chinese company to utilize its powertrain technology. This move could help Mahindra expand its presence in the global electric vehicle market.

site_title: Taiwan president calls on China to engage in talks with Taiwan
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen called on China to engage in talks with Taiwan, pledging to maintain peace between the two sides. In a National Day speech, Ms Tsai stated that discussions should focus on the peaceful development of the Taiwan Strait and the well-being of both sides. She emphasized that any talks should be conducive to peaceful relations, without specifying what could be discussed. This move comes amid growing tensions between Taiwan and China.

site_title: Samsung woes deepen over Galaxy Note 7
summary: Samsung Electronics has suspended production of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone due to ongoing safety concerns over its lithium-ion battery, which has been linked to explosions and fires. The company initially recalled 2.5 million units in 10 markets after complaints emerged, but reports of replacement phones catching fire led to distributors halting replacements. AT&T and T-Mobile have also halted exchanges of recalled phones. Analysts warn that the issue could damage Samsung's brand image and impact sales of other Galaxy smartphones, potentially costing up to $2 billion.

site_title: France says Britain has 'moral duty' on Calais migrant minors
summary: France has urged Britain to take in hundreds of migrant children from the Calais Jungle camp, citing a "moral duty" to care for those with family ties in the UK. Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve said there are up to 950 unaccompanied minors in the camp, many of whom have family in Britain. France plans to dismantle the camp, with residents to be scattered to reception centers, and Cazeneuve stressed that France has fulfilled its responsibilities. Britain is under pressure to accept the children, with campaigners arguing that they should be allowed to travel to the UK.

site_title: Fifa sued over treatment of Qatar World Cup workers
summary: A Bangladeshi man, Nadim Shariful Alam, is suing FIFA for allegedly failing to ensure fair treatment of migrant workers during the 2022 World Cup in Qatar. Alam claims he was exploited while working on World Cup facilities, paying $4,000 to a recruiter who took his passport and forced him to work under harsh conditions for 18 months. The Dutch Federation of Trade Unions is backing the lawsuit, calling for FIFA to take responsibility and grant or withhold hosting deals to enforce minimum labor standards.

images.alt_text: A Bangladeshi man who says he was harshly exploited while working on 2022 World Cup facilities in Qatar is suing Fifa for allegedly failing to use its influence to ensure workers are treated fairly.

site_title: China oil output rebound seen unlikely until prices top US$60
summary: China's oil output is unlikely to rebound until oil prices reach around $60 a barrel, according to Neil Beveridge, a Hong Kong-based analyst. China's oil production dropped 5.7% in the first eight months of the year as state-run companies shut expensive fields. With breakeven costs around $50 a barrel, production won't start to grow until prices surpass $60 a barrel, according to Beveridge. China is forecast to lead output declines across Asia, tightening the global market.

site_title: Saudi says US$60 oil 'not unthinkable' by year-end
summary: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih said it's "not unthinkable" that oil prices could surge to $60 a barrel by the end of the year, citing the convergence of supply and demand. However, he warned against drastic production cuts that could shock markets. The kingdom has already agreed to a surprise oil output cut as part of the Opec cartel, and Al-Falih emphasized that the focus is on supply and demand, not price. Saudi Arabia remains committed to its economic reform program, set to transform the country's crude-based economy by 2030.

site_title: Singapore's Fullerton Healthcare IPO prices at low end, raises S$213m: IFR
summary: Singapore's Fullerton Healthcare IPO priced at S$1.52 per share, at the low end of its marketing range, raising S$213 million. The offering comprised 140.3 million shares, with 18.9% of the company to be listed. This year's Singapore IPO activity has seen some relief after a 17-year low in 2023, with recent listings including Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust and Frasers Logistics and Industrial Trust.

site_title: China says Thailand made decision to block Hong Kong activist's visit
summary: China says Thailand blocked entry to Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong, 19, who was invited to speak about Hong Kong's "Umbrella Movement" protests. The decision was made by Thailand, not China, according to Chinese Vice-Foreign Minister Li Baodong. The move raised concerns about mainland interference in Hong Kong's autonomy and Chinese influence on Thailand's military government. Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha stated the issue was for China to handle, not Thailand.

site_title: China tries again to stop confessions through torture
summary: China has issued a joint statement emphasizing the importance of voluntary confessions and excluding evidence obtained through torture or coercion. The move aims to address widespread criticism and put a halt to the practice of using violence or threats to obtain confessions. The statement, issued by the Supreme Court and various ministries, marks the latest attempt by China to reform its judicial system and align with international human rights standards. This development may lead to increased cooperation with Western countries in extraditing corruption suspects.

site_title: Samsung suspends Galaxy Note 7 production: Yonhap
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd suspended production of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones due to reports of fires in replacement devices. The decision was made in cooperation with authorities in China and the US. This comes after a series of incidents involving the Note 7, which was recalled earlier this year. The cause of the fires is still under investigation.

site_title: Thai king's condition unstable after haemodialysis treatment: palace
summary: Thailand's 88-year-old King Bhumibol Adulyadej is in an unstable condition after receiving haemodialysis treatment, according to the palace. This is the first time the palace has stated the king's health is not stable, and his condition has yet to stabilize. The king, who has been treated for various ailments at Bangkok's Siriraj Hospital, was last seen in public in January and has been a subject of intense scrutiny due to strict laws protecting the royal family. The king's health has been a concern for over a decade, fueling political tensions in Thailand.

site_title: Yuan slumps most since June after trading resumes after holidays
summary: The yuan plummeted 0.46% to 6.7051 against the US dollar, its weakest point since September 2010, after China's markets reopened following a week-long break. The currency's decline was attributed to China's central bank allowing it to drift lower, potentially setting the stage for further depreciation. China's foreign-exchange reserves declined to $3.17 trillion, and the onshore yuan has weakened 3% against the US dollar this year, the most in Asia.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open higher
summary: Chinese stocks opened higher on Monday, tracking a global gain during the previous week's holiday. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.52% to 3,020.46, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.46% to 2,004.73. Hong Kong was closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Thai stock index falls 3.2% after palace statement on king's health
summary: Thailand's stock index fell 3.2% on Monday following a palace statement that King Bhumibol Adulyadej's health is in an unstable condition. The king, 88, received haemodialysis treatment, prompting financial markets to react. The Thai baht weakened to 35.065 to the US dollar, its lowest since July 26. This news closely monitored by financial markets in Thailand, where the king is widely revered as a symbol of stability.

site_title: Chinese developers tumble most in five weeks on property curbs
summary: Chinese property shares plummeted the most in five weeks, with Poly Real Estate Group Co and Beijing Capital Development Co losing at least 3.9% and 2.2% respectively, amid restrictions imposed by housing commissions in over a dozen cities to curb surging prices. Authorities increased land supply and forbade price increases in new home pre-sales without approval, aiming to stabilize the real estate market. This move follows a week-long holiday for the financial markets.

images.alt_text: Chinese property shares took their biggest beating in five weeks after authorities in more than a dozen cities imposed restrictions to curb surging prices during a week-long holiday for the financial markets.

site_title: US Navy ship targeted in failed missile attack from Yemen
summary: A US Navy guided missile destroyer, USS Mason, was targeted by two failed missile attacks from Yemen-controlled territory, with both missiles impacting the water before reaching the ship. The attack occurred in the Red Sea, and there were no injuries to the sailors or damage to the ship. The incident was confirmed by a Pentagon spokesman, Captain Jeff Davis. The cause of the failed attack is still unclear, but it is believed to be linked to Iran-aligned Houthi rebels.

site_title: Aussie shares rise as Clinton given better chance to win; NZ ends lower
summary: Australian shares rose marginally, closing up 0.15% at 5,475.40, amid increased odds against Donald Trump's US presidential win. Trump faces a crisis after a tape of him making derogatory comments about women. In contrast, New Zealand shares ended lower. The S&P/ASX 200 index's rise was seen as a reaction to Trump's worsening situation.

site_title: China's Juneyao Airlines to join Star Alliance group in 2017
summary: Juneyao Airlines, China's largest private carrier, will join the Star Alliance group in 2017 as a connecting partner. The airline, which operates routes to neighboring countries, aims to expand its international routes as more Chinese tourists travel abroad. Juneyao will not become a full member of the alliance, but rather a connecting partner, allowing it to benefit from the alliance's network without the full membership requirements. This move is expected to give Juneyao a springboard for its planned international expansion.

site_title: Putin in Turkey to push energy deals despite Syria crisis
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin visited Turkey on October 10, 2016, to discuss energy deals despite a crisis in relations between the two countries. Putin and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan are expected to reaffirm their commitment to the TurkStream gas pipeline and a nuclear power station in Turkey. The talks come after a period of acrimonious accusations over Syria, but both leaders are pushing forward with ambitious joint energy projects. The visit aims to strengthen economic ties between Russia and Turkey.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin visits Turkey on Monday for talks with counterpart Recep Tayyip Erdogan, pushing forward ambitious joint energy projects as the two sides try to overcome a crisis in ties.

site_title: Australia's Fortescue pays a dollar to buy out iron ore partner
summary: Fortescue Metals Group has bought out BC Iron's 75% stake in the Nullagine iron ore mine in Australia for $1, ending a seven-year partnership. The sale potentially boosts Fortescue's annual capacity by 6 million tonnes and may resume operations at the mine, which was closed due to high production and shipping costs. Fortescue will pay BC Iron a royalty from any future sales, and the deal clears the asset off BC Iron's books, allowing it to focus on another Australian iron ore mine, Iron Valley.

site_title: Gold rises after worst week since November as ETF holdings gain
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,264.35 an ounce after the worst week since November, as investors added to bullion-backed exchange-traded funds amid a weaker US dollar. The US jobs report showed fewer-than-expected jobs added, reducing the likelihood of higher US borrowing costs. Despite a 25% rally in the first half of the year, investors continued to buy gold, with ETF assets reaching the highest level in over three years.

site_title: Won, ringgit lead climb in Asia as peso holds gain after debate
summary: Asian currencies, including the won, ringgit, and Philippine peso, rose as US data showed the labor market is settling into a pace supporting the world's largest economy. Mexico's peso gained 1.3% after the US presidential debate, while the baht fell 0.5% due to concerns over the king's health. The MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index rose 0.2%, and South Africa's rand strengthened 0.5%. However, the increasing probability of a Federal Reserve rate hike tempered demand, with market-based odds of a December rate increase climbing to 64%.

site_title: China house collapse buries more than 20
summary: A house collapse in Wenzhou, eastern China's Zhejiang province, has buried more than 20 people under rubble. The incident occurred in the early hours, and six people have been rescued. The cause of the collapse is under investigation. This is not the first building collapse in China, with 16 deaths reported in May and two fatalities and 24 injuries in April. The incident highlights concerns over low-quality construction in the country.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble shares rise on sale of US energy unit
summary: Noble Group shares rose 3.1% on Monday after announcing the sale of its US energy unit, Noble Americas Energy Solutions, to Calpine Corp for US$1.05 billion. This marks a minor recovery for the beleaguered counter, which had previously indicated the unit's value to be more than US$1.25 billion. The sale is expected to have a positive impact on Noble's financials, despite the uncertainty surrounding the global energy market.

site_title: Film seeks new take on foreign domestic workers
summary: A documentary titled "Sunday Beauty School" has premiered at the 21st Busan International Film Festival, offering a fresh perspective on foreign domestic workers. The film, directed by Baby Ruth Villarama, follows a group of Filipino domestic workers in Hong Kong as they prepare for an annual beauty pageant, highlighting their daily lives, hopes, and dreams. The documentary aims to open a dialogue about the role of domestic workers globally, with an estimated 50 million overseas workers employed worldwide, sending $26 billion back to their home countries annually.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks shaky, Samsung Electronics tumbles on deepening phone recall crisis
summary: South Korean shares began the week on a shaky footing, with the Kospi index down 0.05% at 2,052.69 points. Samsung Electronics' stock tumbled 4.6% amid a deepening phone recall crisis, its largest loss in a month. The crisis follows reports of some Galaxy Note 7 smartphones catching fire. The South Korean won edged up 0.2% against the US dollar, while offshore investors sold Kospi shares worth 47.3 billion won. The market will closely watch the Fed's last policy meeting minutes for further guidance.

site_title: PM Lee launches Singapore's new cybersecurity strategy
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong launched the country's new cybersecurity strategy, focusing on strengthening the resilience of Critical Information Infrastructure (CII) that supports essential services. The strategy, developed after a year-long consultation process, outlines four pillars: building a resilient infrastructure, creating a safer cyberspace, developing a vibrant cybersecurity ecosystem, and strengthening international partnerships. The government aims to grow a culture of cyber-risk awareness, establish robust risk management processes, and increase the adoption of security-by-design practices across the supply chain.

site_title: Trump revives Bill Clinton scandals in bid to salvage campaign
summary: In the second presidential debate, Donald Trump revived past accusations against Hillary Clinton's husband, Bill Clinton, and called for her to be investigated and potentially jailed over her e-mail use. Trump also made vulgar comments on a 2005 video, which he later apologized for. Clinton responded by saying Trump's comments demonstrate his unfit nature and that he spreads falsehoods. The debate shifted towards policy, but the controversy may not have stopped Trump's campaign free fall. Trump's campaign is struggling, with polls showing Clinton widening her lead, and some strategists believe he's too damaged to rebound.

site_title: Trump calls video 'locker room talk,' attacks Bill Clinton
summary: US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump called a video of him making obscene comments about groping women "locker room talk" and dismissed it as embarrassing, but not representative of his character. He also attacked former president Bill Clinton, saying his actions were worse than Trump's words. Trump's comments were met with criticism from Hillary Clinton, who said his behavior showed he was unfit for the White House.

site_title: Celebrated Polish filmmaker Andrzej Wajda dies aged 90
summary: Polish film director Andrzej Wajda, a legend in the world of cinema, died on Sunday at 90, leaving behind an opus of acclaimed films inspired by his country's turbulent history. Wajda's first films were marked by the painful experience of World War II and the Polish resistance against the Nazis. He won the Oscar for lifetime achievement in 2000 and brought a political aspect to his films. Wajda's films, including "Pokolenie," "Kanal," and "Katyn," focused on stories suppressed by the communist regime, and he continued working until his death from lung failure.

site_title: Asia: Most stocks climb before debate as Federal Reserve rate hike looms
summary: Asian stocks rose ahead of the US presidential debate, with materials and consumer companies leading the gains. The MSCI Asia Pacific excluding Japan Index increased less than 0.1%. US presidential nominee Donald Trump's reputation took a hit after a 2005 video surfaced of him making derogatory comments about women. The American jobs report showed the Federal Reserve is on track to raise interest rates in December, supporting the rally.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Financial names new CEO to oversee IPO in 2017
summary: Ant Financial, a subsidiary of Alibaba Group Holding, has appointed Eric Jing as its new CEO to oversee its initial public offering (IPO) in 2017. Jing, a veteran of corporate finance, takes over from Lucy Peng, who will remain executive chair. The move comes as Ant Financial prepares for its Hong Kong market debut, which could be one of the city's largest IPOs since 2010. Jing brings extensive experience working with multinational companies, including his previous role as CFO of Guangzhou Pepsi Cola Beverage.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars off lows in light trade, US elections eyed
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Monday, with the Australian dollar hovering around 76 US cents after a two-week low of US$0.7553 on Friday. Markets increased the probability of a Hillary Clinton victory in the US presidential debate, boosting the currencies. Trading was subdued due to a public holiday in Japan and Chinese markets reopened after a week-long break.

site_title: Australia shares firm ahead of US presidential debate; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to a one-month high, driven by investor anticipation of the US presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,494.7 points, its highest level in over a month. Meanwhile, New Zealand shares fell. The Reuters/Ipsos poll showed Clinton leading Trump by 5 percentage points among likely voters.

site_title: FCL to pump S$520m into Thai industrial property developer
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) has agreed to invest approximately S$520 million in Thailand-listed industrial property developer Ticon Industrial Connection through a private placement. The investment represents a 13.6% premium over Ticon's 30-day volume weighted average price. Following the completion of the transaction, FCL's unit will hold around 40% of Ticon's enlarged share capital.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% down on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% to 2,867.98 points on Monday, ahead of the US presidential debate and expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike. Trading volumes were high, with 108.4 million shares changing hands. The decline follows a 5-day rally and comes amid uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: Uber aims to unseat Ola in US$10b India ride-hailing market
summary: Uber is intensifying its efforts to unseat Ola in India's $10 billion ride-hailing market. The US-based company aims to recruit 1 million drivers by 2018 and has expanded to 28 cities, handling 5.5 million rides per week. Uber is stepping up investments, including building up engineering and support teams in Bangalore and Delhi, and has introduced new services such as cash payments and a Help button for emergency alerts. The company is also adapting its service to India's unique market, including poor internet coverage.

site_title: As China's economy slows, migrant workers head home
summary: China's economy slowdown is leading to a rise in migrant workers returning to their hometowns, where job opportunities are scarce. The country's official unemployment rate has been around 4%, but the real level of unemployment is masked by the fact that migrant workers are not included in the data. Many migrant workers, like Zhang Sihu, have lost their jobs due to the slowdown, with some even returning to their family farms. This trend is also affecting employees of state-owned enterprises, with stagnant or lower wages and underemployment on the rise.

site_title: Billy Bush suspended from NBC Today show after Trump's lewd comments
summary: NBC has suspended television personality Billy Bush from the Today show after a 2005 taped lewd conversation with Donald Trump, who is a Republican presidential nominee. The suspension comes as a result of Trump's comments about groping women and trying to seduce a married woman. Bush's language and behavior on the tape are deemed unacceptable, according to NBC executive Noah Oppenheim. The suspension is indefinite and follows a flood of Republicans withdrawing their support for Trump, deepening fissures between him and establishment Republicans ahead of the November 8 presidential election.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down slightly 0.10 points to 1665.28. The market saw 20.7 million lots traded worth RM6.09 million, with 72 gainers outnumbering losers 38-0.

site_title: AT&T stops Samsung Note 7 replacements after reports of fire
summary: AT&T has stopped exchanging Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones due to reports of fires from replacement devices. The move comes after a Southwest Airlines flight was evacuated when a replacement Note 7 began smoking on board. The US Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the incident, adding pressure on Samsung. The company is struggling with a global scandal that has damaged its reputation.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Asian markets are closed on Monday for holidays, with Japanese, Hong Kong, and Taiwanese financial markets being shut. In contrast, Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. US stocks also reached fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher despite trade tensions.

site_title: China says willing to discuss "possibilities" with India on nuclear group
summary: China is willing to discuss "possibilities" with India on its bid to join the Nuclear Suppliers Group (NSG), a move that could potentially back India's nuclear power drive. The offer comes ahead of a summit in India, where Chinese President Xi Jinping will meet with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. China, a key NSG member, has historically blocked India's accession, citing the need for consensus among existing members. However, Vice Foreign Minister Li Baodong hinted at a possible compromise, stating that China will "jointly explore all kinds of possibilities" with India.

site_title: Trump scandal magnifies bias that Clinton win good for US markets
summary: US Republican Donald Trump's latest scandal, involving a 2016 video of him talking about groping females and trying to seduce a married woman, has bolstered Democrat Hillary Clinton's campaign and reinforced existing market expectations that a Clinton win would be positive for US markets. Strategists believe Clinton's positions are well-known, contributing to this bias. The Reuters equity poll found that a Clinton victory by November 8 would be more favorable for stocks until the end of the year.

site_title: Oil bulls leap into market as Opec supply-cut accord spurs rally
summary: OPEC's first output-cutting agreement in eight years has sparked a surge in oil prices, breaching $50 a barrel since its announcement on September 28. The deal, set to finalize quotas for members on November 30, has fueled a rally in oil futures, with US crude stockpiles dropping to their lowest level since January. However, analysts warn that the market's momentum may not last, citing the need for OPEC to finalize specific cuts and the fundamentals not supporting current prices.

site_title: Trump holds event with Bill Clinton accusers before debate
summary: Donald Trump held a press conference with Bill Clinton accusers, including Juanita Broaddrick and Paula Jones, just hours before the presidential debate. Trump denied the allegations and claimed the accusations were a "double standard" issue. Republican strategist Steve Schmidt stated that the crisis is irreparable and Trump's comments will likely prompt him to bring up Bill Clinton's indiscretions. The debate is expected to overshadow other topics, with Mrs. Clinton likely to address the controversy. Trump's campaign is facing a crisis, with many party leaders distancing themselves from him and polls showing Mrs. Clinton widening her lead.

site_title: South Korea Doosan Bobcat to withdraw its current IPO plans, will resubmit
summary: South Korea's Doosan Bobcat Inc has withdrawn its existing initial public offering plans and will resubmit a new plan as soon as possible. The company's largest shareholder, Doosan Infracore Co Ltd, cited regulatory uncertainty and market conditions. The machinery maker had set a preliminary price range of 41,000-50,000 won per share for the IPO, which would have raised up to 2.45 trillion Korean won. Doosan Bobcat has until February 2017 to list or start the process over under South Korean exchange rules.

site_title: UK firms show reluctance to invest after Brexit vote, BCC says
summary: UK businesses have become more cautious after the Brexit vote, with the British Chambers of Commerce citing "muted business investment intentions" in its first quarterly survey since the referendum. The BCC calls on Chancellor Philip Hammond to take steps to lift confidence, including approving new infrastructure projects. UK economic growth has slowed, with GDP rising 0.4% in the three months through September, down from 0.7% in the previous period. The government is expected to unveil new fiscal measures in the Autumn Statement, with the BCC urging final and irrevocable decisions on infrastructure projects to boost business confidence.

site_title: Noble Group sells US energy unit to Calpine for US$1.05b
summary: Noble Group has agreed to sell its US energy unit, Noble Americas Energy Solutions, to Calpine Corp for $1.05 billion. The sale aims to raise cash and boost liquidity for the commodity trader, which has been struggling due to a rout in commodity prices and mounting losses. The transaction is part of Noble Group's $2 billion capital-raising initiative, which includes cutting jobs and selling assets. The sale will fund growth opportunities in high-return businesses and reduce debt for the company.

site_title: Oil extends slide below US$50 as US rigs rise to 8-month high
summary: Oil prices slid below US$50 as US drillers added rigs for a sixth straight week, extending declines. The number of active US oil rigs reached a six-month high of 428, according to Baker Hughes data. Russia's Energy Minister Alexander Novak expressed doubts over a deal with Opec on output cuts, citing the group's agreement to cut production last month. The US oil market halted its drop to the lowest in over two years, threatening to derail the current rally, according to Michael McCarthy. Oil prices fell as much as 1.3% in New York.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, CDL, GuocoLand
summary: Noble Group agreed to sell its US energy unit, Noble Americas Energy Solutions, to Calpine Corp for US$1.05 billion. City Developments Limited (CDL) sold 337 units of Forest Woods condo at S$1,400 per square foot net average price. GuocoLand reported 37% of Guoco Tower's space committed to tech and media companies.

site_title: Deutsche Bank talks with Justice Department said to continue
summary: Deutsche Bank's negotiations with the US Justice Department to resolve a mortgage-backed securities investigation are continuing, despite a failed meeting between CEO John Cryan and Justice Department officials. Cryan expects the department to scale back its initial $14 billion settlement bid, which led to a record low in the bank's stock last month. The bank may face additional penalties for outstanding investigations, including a money-launder inquiry in Russia, potentially costing up to $2 billion. Deutsche Bank is exploring options to deal with legal costs, including a stock sale and a potential stake increase from Qatar's royal family.

site_title: Gold prices in for a roller-coaster ride
summary: Gold prices are expected to be volatile in the last quarter due to uncertainty surrounding Deutsche Bank's fallout and the US presidential election. The current deterioration of Deutsche Bank, a traditional safe-haven asset, supports gold prices, while the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike may pressure gold. The outcome of the US presidential election, particularly if Donald Trump is elected, may also support gold prices due to its unconventional approach and potential macroeconomic uncertainty.

site_title: May to court EU leaders as Brexit signals rattle global nerves
summary: Theresa May travels to Denmark and the Netherlands for talks with prime ministers Lars Lokke Rasmussen and Mark Rutte, aiming to build understanding for her Brexit position ahead of the EU summit in Brussels. The UK's focus on immigration controls has raised concerns about alienating international partners and losing access to the single market. May's foreign outreach follows trips to other EU capitals, as the UK prepares to trigger Article 50 and begin Brexit negotiations. The UK's economic concerns are also highlighted by a second consecutive month of economic shrinkage.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Theresa May will resume her foreign outreach this week after stirring global concern that her government's focus on immigration controls as it leaves the European Union risks alienating international partners as well as losing access to the single market.

site_title: Boeing wins US$18.6b deal as Qatar Airways buys first 737 Max
summary: Qatar Airways has signed a $18.6 billion deal with Boeing to buy up to 100 737 Max aircraft, marking the airline's first order with Boeing since 1979. The deal, worth $6.9 billion, includes 60 737 Max 8 jets, while Qatar Airways also ordered 40 777 and 787 Dreamliner aircraft. The order provides a boost to Boeing's sales and demonstrates confidence in the 737 Max, which is set to begin commercial service in the second quarter of next year.

site_title: Lens maker DynaOptics sharpens its focus on global markets
summary: DynaOptics, a Singapore startup, has developed a superior camera lens technology that it claims can improve mobile phone camera zooming capabilities. The lens was developed in a lab at the National University of Singapore over three years. The technology aims to resolve blurry images when zooming in on objects far away. DynaOptics plans to focus on global markets with its innovative lens, potentially disrupting the camera lens industry.

site_title: Multiplying corporate giving - from the top
summary: OCBC Bank, Singapore's longest-established bank, has seen a significant impact on its corporate culture through its corporate giving programs, with one in four employees volunteering. This has led to increased employee engagement, management and leadership skills, and a spirit of serving. The bank's efforts have also encouraged its leadership to participate in volunteerism, with senior executives inviting SME customers to an informal lunch event to promote staff volunteering. As a founding member of the Company of Good movement, OCBC is committed to working with SME clients to develop their own corporate social responsibility initiatives.

site_title: Gold sees worst week since '13 on renewed rate fears
summary: Gold experienced its worst week since 2013 due to renewed rate fears, with investors expecting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this year. The Cleveland Fed's Loretta Mester stated there's a "strong, compelling case" for rate hikes, and Fed funds futures data showed the odds of a rate hike by December increased to 66%. Gold futures fell 0.1% to $1,251.90 an ounce, taking last week's loss to 5%.

site_title: Goldman sees shock potential for US, Europe stocks this year
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts US and European stocks will decline by 2% each by December due to political risks, weak economies, and high valuations. The firm's managing director, Christian Mueller-Glissmann, advises a defensive stance towards Asia and emerging markets, and a bearish outlook on Europe and the US. This contradicts most strategist forecasts, which expect a 1.3% rebound in the Stoxx 600. The S&P 500 is trading at 18 times estimated earnings, making it vulnerable to significant drops in the event of shocks.

site_title: Kuroda signals BOJ may delay hitting inflation target
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted that the central bank may delay hitting its 2% inflation target to 2018, citing the need for "slightly more months" to achieve the goal. Kuroda also stated that the BOJ will continue or strengthen its monetary easing to achieve the target, potentially including further asset purchases. This would be the fifth delay to the price target since Kuroda launched his stimulus campaign in 2013, but he expressed confidence that the policy will succeed in managing long-term interest rates to around zero percent.

images.alt_text: Governor Haruhiko Kuroda gave the clearest signal yet that the Bank of Japan may postpone the forecast date for achieving its 2 per cent inflation target to 2018, even with economic growth set to accelerate next year.

site_title: Noteholders issue direct demand to Rickmers Maritime
summary: Noteholders of Rickmers Maritime Trust issued a direct demand to the trustee-manager, seeking immediate payment of their share of the S$100 million medium-term notes (MTN) due to concerns over the proposed restructuring proposal being inequitable and transparent. The noteholders, holding over 40% of the MTN, want a cash payment instead of new units, citing a lack of clarity on the deal made with bank lenders. The trustee-manager is expected to receive a "notice of acceleration" on Monday.

site_title: Former US treasury secretary warns of 'fire' danger in financial system
summary: Former US Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner warns of a potential "fire" in the financial system due to "dry tinder" and inadequate preparedness. He emphasizes the need for regulators to have the right tools to act in case of a new crisis. Global debt has soared to $152 trillion, or 225% of GDP, with non-financial sector debt increasing by 15 years. Rising debt service costs and interest rates pose significant risks, potentially leading to further financial distress and slowing global economic growth.

site_title: App that helps monitor mood levels is a winner
summary: An app called Emotional Analysis Buddy won the gold award for Best Innovative ICM Student Project in the tertiary category, helping monitor mood levels by analyzing social media posts. The app, developed by 20-year-old Koh Vinleon, identifies patterns and updates users on their emotional state, triggering a chat feature if levels dip too low. A silver award went to Happy Wheel, an app for wheelchair users, which provides accessible route information through crowd-sourced data.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Monday
summary: Japanese financial markets are closed on Monday for a national holiday. Meanwhile, in Singapore, stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Traders are brushing off US President Trump's new threats to extend the stock rally. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Trump faces Clinton in debate amid campaign chaos
summary: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton face off in the final presidential debate just a week before the US election, amid a chaotic campaign for Trump over his lewd boasts about groping women. Trump's White House campaign has been abandoned by Republican lawmakers and governors, despite a rare televised apology. Trump's campaign manager and the Republican National Committee chairman have backed out of scheduled television appearances. The debate will feature a town hall-style forum, where the candidates will face questions from the audience. Despite Trump's efforts to move on from the controversy, the scandal has damaged his chances, with national polls showing Clinton leading by 4.5 percentage points.

site_title: Aviation climate deal seen as a win for airlines, less so for the planet
summary: The UN has reached a global deal to regulate emissions from international aviation, requiring airlines to compensate for emissions growth through funding environmental initiatives. The deal, which covers only international flights, is voluntary for countries during the first six years and may cost airlines up to $23.9 billion annually by 2035. While seen as a victory by airlines, environmentalists consider it a "timid step" that does not significantly address the aviation industry's growing carbon emission problem.

site_title: N Sea drilling activity sinks to all-time low
summary: The North Sea drilling activity has reached an all-time low, with 27 rigs operating in September, the lowest number since records began in 1982. This decline is attributed to low oil prices, with the British oil industry expected to axe 120,000 jobs by the end of the year. The drop in drilling activity is a result of companies cutting spending to weather the low prices.

site_title: Fuhua pupils turn painting into real life
summary: Fuhua Primary School students in Singapore transformed a painted piano into a real-life piano using technology from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Makey Makey kit. Over five months, the 11-year-olds worked together to install actual piano keys above the painted keys, allowing them to play proper notes. The project earned them a gold award in the Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation's Best Innovative ICM Student Project category. The students used the technology to create a functional piano, showcasing their curiosity and experimentation skills.

site_title: From cars to confectionery: Australia's manufacturers revamp business
summary: Australia's car manufacturers, including Toyota, General Motors, and Ford, have closed their operations in the country, but many suppliers have adapted by diversifying into other sectors such as food, building, and exports. The Reserve Bank of Australia sees this shift as a key factor in the economy's transition away from mining. Despite a 5.4% decline in business investment, the non-mining sector has driven growth, with new investments in manufacturing rising 13%. The country's economy grew at 3.3% in the year to June, exceeding expectations.

site_title: Deutsche Bank secures backing from largest investor
summary: Deutsche Bank has secured backing from its largest investor, Qatari investors who own around 10% of the bank, and is seeking advice from other banks to restore market confidence. The bank is facing a potential fine of up to $14 billion from the US Department of Justice over mis-selling allegations, and is considering asset sales as an option. Despite this, Qatari investors are willing to keep their stake in the bank and may even consider buying more shares if it decides to raise capital. Deutsche Bank's CEO, John Cryan, is meeting with US regulators and senior managers of other investment banks to discuss the lender's options.

site_title: US beef prices set to keep falling
summary: US beef prices are expected to continue falling through 2019 due to an industry-wide buildup of cattle herds after a prolonged drought, resulting in a 30% drop in wholesale prices since May 2015. Beef production is projected to rise 5.2% this year and 3.4% in 2017 to a five-year high, driven by expanding cattle, hog, and chicken industries. As a result, consumers can expect lower grocery store costs, with retail ground-beef prices down 14% from a record in February 2015.

site_title: US$ overvalued as America nears presidential election
summary: The US dollar's strength is uncertain after the presidential election in November, with a PPP analysis showing it is overvalued against China's renminbi, British pound, and euro. The dollar's competitive advantage in Asia has been lost due to steep devaluations of Asian currencies. As a result, businesses and global markets are concerned about the potential impact on trade and investment. The outcome of the election will be closely watched for its effect on the dollar's value and the global economy.

site_title: The gold standard in innovation
summary: Singapore's top startups and schools have won honors at the 2016 Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation (SiTF) awards. Spiking took the gold for Best Innovative Start-Up - Early Stage with its real-time investment data app, while DynaOptics won for Best Innovative Start-Up - Growth Stage with its Wala Cam camera. The awards also recognized schools for their innovative projects, with nine organizations and ten schools receiving awards. The winners showcased international potential, with several having the potential to disrupt industries globally. The SiTF awards aim to encourage entrepreneurs and startups to grow and thrive.

site_title: Helping retail investors gain an edge
summary: A startup app, Spiking, has won the Gold award for Best Innovative Start-Up - Early Stage at the Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation awards. The app provides retail investors with key information on moves made by smart money, such as directors or substantial shareholders, on the Singapore Exchange. It aims to simplify the identification and selection of stocks for average investors. The app, developed by Aly, has scaled up its data coverage to over 10 stock exchanges in eight countries. The founder, Clemen Chiang, hopes the app will have a significant impact on retail investors' financial decisions.

images.alt_text: Singapore startup Aly is looking to give small investors the heads up with its app Spiking, which enables them to track their favourite stocks for moves made by big investors such as directors or substantial shareholders.

site_title: Crystal maker Swarovski aims to re-invent itself
summary: Swarovski, a luxury crystal maker, is re-inventing itself as a tech company. The company has been investing in a new office space in Austria, where it has hired millennial programmers and entrepreneurs, including founders of a smartphone application for hotels. This shift reflects the company's desire to expand its offerings beyond traditional crystal products.

site_title: British economy loses steam as business investment wilts: surveys
summary: The UK economy appears to be losing steam, with business surveys showing a marked slowdown in the services sector and boardrooms beset by doubt about the future following the country's vote to leave the European Union. Key measures of business investment and turnover confidence hit four-year lows, with the British Chambers of Commerce surveying 7,000 businesses reporting a notable slowdown in services. Investors are concerned about Britain losing preferential trading terms, pushing sterling to a 31-year low against the US dollar. The economy is expected to slow markedly next year, with growth forecast at 1% in 2017.

images.alt_text: Britain's economy appears to be losing steam, with major business surveys showing a marked slowdown in the services sector and boardrooms beset by doubt about the future following the country's vote to leave the European Union.

site_title: Tech, media tenants take up 37% of committed space at Guoco Tower
summary: Tech and media companies are taking up 37% of the committed space at Guoco Tower in Singapore, with 80% of the premium Grade A office space either taken or subject to advanced leasing discussions. The tower, part of the Tanjong Pagar Centre mixed-development project, is expected to attract major tenants such as Dentsu Aegis, ING, and Itochu Singapore. The diverse tenant mix is expected to maintain a stable demand for offices in the tower, driven by the counter cyclical nature of different industries.

site_title: How to retire at 40
summary: Three early retirees share their experiences living on 4% or less of their investment portfolio. Robert Karn advises dividing age by 20 for the safe spending percentage, resulting in 2% for a 40-year-old. Joe Udo, 38, retired in 2012 with $1.4 million, spends 4% of his portfolio and plans to retire by 55. Sydney Lagier, 44, retired in 2008 with $1.5 million, spends 3% of her portfolio and aims to reach age 102. Justin McCurry, 36, retired in 2018 with $1.5 million, spends 3% of his portfolio and blogs about financial independence.

site_title: Economists predict no change to MAS monetary policy for now
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to keep its monetary policy unchanged when its decision is announced this Friday, according to economists. A 60% probability of no change is cited by Nomura and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, while Citi economist Kit Wei Zheng estimates a 50-55% chance of maintaining the status quo. However, economists are more certain of a monetary easing next year if growth fundamentals do not improve, with a re-centring of the S$NEER band expected in April 2017.

images.alt_text: Economists are saying - meekly - that Singapore's central bank will not alter its monetary policy approach when its decision is announced this Friday, while an easing is ripe for 2017.

site_title: China Sept services sector growth dips but still solid: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector growth remained solid in September, with the Caixin/Markit services PMI dipping fractionally to 52.0 from 52.1 in August. The sector created jobs at the fastest pace in seven months, supporting the expectation that China's central bank will hold off on further monetary easing. The dip in PMI growth suggests stability in the economy, aligning with the growing consensus that China's central bank will refrain from interest rate cuts through at least the end of the year.

images.alt_text: China's services sector created jobs at the fastest pace in seven months in September as new business picked up, even though the overall rate of growth was little changed from August, a private survey showed.

site_title: Ontario may seek foreign investment in housing
summary: Ontario is considering foreign investment in the Toronto housing market, but Finance Minister Charles Sousa says more data is needed before making policy changes. Sousa welcomes foreign investment, citing its economic benefits, but notes that the government is sensitive to affordability. The federal government has introduced measures to cool the housing market, including tightened mortgage eligibility rules and a tax on non-resident sales. Ontario and the federal government will work together to determine if foreign buyers are driving growth in the Toronto market. The central bank warns that rapid price gains are unsustainable.

site_title: In the driver's seat
summary: A C-suite executive in Singapore must possess a combination of skills, including the ability to take risks, gain cross-functional experience, and be culturally aware. Key attributes include clarity, courage, curiosity, and integrity. Leaders must also be adaptable, resilient, and able to collaborate with diverse teams. Having an international perspective and staying ahead of change are crucial in today's fast-evolving business climate. Aspiring leaders should focus on developing their skills, being open-minded, and creating conditions for their team members to perform. Ultimately, a C-suite executive in Singapore must embody a strong leadership philosophy and be able to navigate the country's unique business culture.

site_title: Honeywell shares fall the most in five years as business jet slump continues
summary: Honeywell International Inc. shares plummeted 7.5% to a five-year low, closing at $106.94, after the company reported weaker-than-expected demand for business aircraft, missing its profit forecast and cutting its 2016 earnings target. The slump is attributed to a decline in emerging markets and the oil industry, which has crimped demand for business aircraft and helicopters. Honeywell's aerospace sales dropped 6% in the third quarter, and the company expects weakness to continue in 2017, with a possible recovery in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Auditor rotation: is it time?
summary: A question on auditor rotation for boards and audit committees has sparked debate, with some considering a change due to heightened industry awareness or company-specific circumstances. The decision to rotate auditors depends on weighing factors such as industry discussion, mandatory regulations, and director consensus. While the pros and cons of rotation are well-known, boards must collectively consider these elements to make an informed decision. The issue has become a pressing concern for companies and their audit committees.

site_title: Beijing moves to curb housing prices
summary: Beijing has implemented measures to curb a growing housing price bubble, including restrictive purchases, tighter mortgage access, and lower loan-to-value ratios, in nine cities. Property prices in first-tier cities have more than doubled year-over-year. Analysts consider these measures targeted and unlikely to impact recent economic activity.

site_title: US FCC chief unveils scaled-back business data reforms
summary: US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) chairman Tom Wheeler has unveiled a scaled-back proposal to reform the US$45 billion-a-year business data services market.
