Prices have retreated 0.4% year-over-year and are 11.4% below the peak in April 2013. The resale volume decreased 11.3% to 1,666 flats in September, but year-over-year, it increased 10.8%. Experts predict a stable market, with PropNex CEO Ismail Gafoor forecasting a 1-2% rise in prices next year.

site_title: Battle of the blockbusters (Amended)
summary: Singapore's top theatre companies are gearing up for the festive season with big crowd-pullers. Happy Ever Laughter, a biennial stand-up comedy show, will feature comedians like Patricia Mok and Kumar, while Rent, a 20th-anniversary revival, tells the story of young artists living with HIV/AIDS in the 1980s and 1990s. Monkey Goes West, a 2014 hit, will also be restaged with new choreography and shadow puppetry. The shows will be held at Esplanade Theatre, Drama Centre Theatre, and other venues, offering a diverse lineup of comedy and drama for the holiday season.

site_title: More than just bites
summary: In Singapore's competitive F&B scene, new establishments are emerging with unique concepts. Phat Cat Laundry, a laundromat-themed bar and restaurant, offers a fun take on the traditional concept, serving Asian-inspired dishes. Epiphyte, another new restaurant, combines food, art, and nature, with a focus on personal touches and a unique vertical garden. Red Tail Bar, a contemporary Asian restaurant and bar, features a nocturnal animal mascot and serves a menu with international influences. The.twenty.cavan, a month-old restaurant, highlights Asian dishes with a modern twist, while promoting the cuisine in a new way.

images.alt_text: Phat Cat Laundry (above) is a laundromat-themed bar and restaurant serving modern food with Asian influences.
One of its signature dishes is a Brontosaurus Char Siew Beef Rib.
Epiphyte is a new restaurant at Neil Road which centres around food, art, and nature.
The desserts at Epiphyte, like the Terrarium (above), have an artistic touch to them.
Red Tail Bar (above) is a new eatery from the people behind Zouk Singapore, which features globally-inspired drinks and food, following the "adventures" of its mascot - a red tail panda.
The restaurant serves a Scotch Century Egg wrapped in prawn and Kurobuta pork (above).

the.twenty.cavan at Cavan Road (above) takes the concept of traditional dishes and modernises them -- such as its version of "sweet and sour pork", done with lamb coated in flour and fried with blueberry sauce.

the.twenty.cavan at Cavan Road takes the concept of traditional dishes and modernises them -- such as its version of "sweet and sour pork", done with lamb coated in flour and fried with blueberry sauce (above).

site_title: GovTech aims to build deep tech capabilities in government, drive its digitalisation efforts
summary: Singapore's newly formed technology agency, GovTech, aims to build deep tech capabilities within the government to drive digitalization efforts. Chairman Ng Chee Khern emphasizes the need for a culture of excellence and innovation to create anticipatory services for citizens. GovTech will support the Smart Nation project by building platforms for co-creation, crowd-sourcing, and exchanging best practices with digital governments worldwide. The agency will also champion the deployment of smart technologies, including IoT and AI, to improve the citizen experience and enhance decision-making processes.

site_title: An uneven ride that barely stays on track
summary: The psychological thriller "The Girl on the Train" directed by Tate Taylor, is a less substantial film than it appears to be. Based on Paula Hawkins' novel, the story follows three women whose lives are intertwined, with Emily Blunt's performance as a self-destructive alcoholic receiving praise. The narrative is told from multiple perspectives, including the missing woman Megan, and the female detective investigating her disappearance. Despite the unlikable characters, the film works due to Blunt's portrayal, and the mystery unfolds with a surprising twist.

site_title: Boeing's third-quarter deliveries fall 5.5%
summary: Boeing delivered 188 commercial aircraft in the third quarter, down 5.5% from the same period last year, primarily due to a decrease in 777 and 787 deliveries. Deliveries of 777s fell to 22 from 27 in 2015, while 787 deliveries dropped to 36 from 37. This decline is attributed to production issues and a reduction in orders.

site_title: Space and style
summary: The Toyota Sienta, a seven-seat MPV, is now available in Singapore from authorized distributor Borneo Motors, after being a parallel import for over a year. The locally-assembled model in Indonesia features a Dual VVT-i engine, resulting in better fuel efficiency and lower emissions. The Sienta boasts quirky styling, electrically operated sliding rear doors, and a 4.2-inch TFT screen. Priced at S$112,888, it offers a balance of space, style, and performance, making it a more appealing option than the parallel-imported version.

site_title: ECB determined to press on with bond purchases: Sept minutes
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reaffirmed its commitment to purchasing eurozone bonds to support economic growth and inflation. In September, policymakers agreed that the economy needs continued monetary stimulus and that underlying price growth is not showing signs of a strong recovery. The ECB has set its inflation target at almost 2% and is willing to act quickly to achieve it. The central bank has also acknowledged the need to address potential risks, including the impact of Brexit and the ongoing economic recovery.

site_title: Globalization must be 'different,' IMF's Lagarde says
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde emphasized the need for "different" globalization, citing persistent inequality as a major concern. Globalization has largely benefited the world, but it must be adapted to prevent inequality, according to Lagarde. She urged world governments to work together to address the impact of globalization on displaced workers and others affected by technological and digital changes. This call comes amid growing protectionist sentiment in developed countries, with the US presidential nominees opposing a key trade pact.

site_title: US: Wall St falls as health stocks drag
summary: Wall Street fell on Thursday as healthcare stocks declined, despite strong economic data showing a near 43-year low in US unemployment benefits. The data precedes a crucial monthly jobs report that may influence the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. A growing number of Fed officials argue for higher rates, citing a robust labor market and inflation near the central bank's 2% target.

site_title: UOL-UIC joint venture buys Potong Pasir site for S$334m
summary: A joint venture between UOL Group and United Industrial Corporation (UIC) has acquired the Raintree Gardens site in Potong Pasir for S$334 million, bringing the total value of successful en bloc deals in Singapore to over S$1 billion this year. The sale price reflects a land cost of about S$797 per square foot, and each apartment owner will receive an average gross sale price of S$1.9 million. The acquisition is part of UOL's landbanking strategy and is expected to attract homebuyers and upgraders to the area.

site_title: Swiber to default on S$100m notes due 2016
summary: Swiber Holdings, an oil-and-gas firm, is unable to redeem and pay its upcoming coupon payment for its S$100 million notes due October 10, 2016. The 5.55% annual coupon payment is due on the same date. This marks a default on the company's debt obligations.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng, Park Hotel jointly invest in US$65m Maldives resort
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation and Park Hotel Group have jointly invested US$65 million in the Grand Park Kodhipparu resort in the Maldives. The 120 all-villa development is set to open in the second quarter of 2017, with Park Hotel managing the property. This is Park Hotel Group's second partnership with Chip Eng Seng, following the opening of Park Hotel Alexandra last year.

site_title: First cruise ship docks in Tunisia since 2015 attack
summary: A German-operated cruise ship, MS Europa, docked in Tunisia's La Goulette port for the first time since a 2015 jihadist attack, killing 21 tourists. The one-day stopover marked a positive step for the country's tourism industry, which has been in crisis since the revolution in 2011. Authorities hope to lure back big cruise operators, with a Switzerland-based company planning a stop in January. The event brought a sense of relief and renewed hope for local business owners, who had been impacted by the attack.

site_title: Twitter plunges 19% on report Google won't bid
summary: Twitter shares dropped 19% on Thursday after a report by Recode stated Google would not pursue a Twitter acquisition. Google had been seen as a potential buyer, but the news sent shares plummeting to $20.20 from Wednesday's close of $24.87. The decision not to bid may have alleviated concerns about a hostile takeover, but it also raised questions about Twitter's future and potential alternatives.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.810 points to 1,666.730. The index saw a volume of 1.799 billion lots worth RM1.731 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 402 to 355.

site_title: Some misses, but more hits at Lucky 8
summary: Lucky 8, a new Chinese restaurant at Shaw Centre, offers a welcome addition to the limited dining options in the area. The restaurant is open daily from 11.30am to 10pm, with advance orders not required. Despite some initial reservations about the "one day advance order required" policy, the reviewer found the food to be enjoyable and the service satisfactory. Overall, Lucky 8 is a positive addition to the local dining scene, providing more Chinese options for customers.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit buys UK data centre for £34m
summary: Keppel DC Reit, a data centre owner, has acquired a UK data centre for £34 million (S$59.7 million) through a 15-year lease with annual rent escalations. The data centre in Cardiff, Wales, is leased to a major global cloud service provider. The acquisition was funded entirely with pound-denominated debt. The move comes after the Reit's units slid a cent to S$1.21 following the announcement.

site_title: Opec could cut output more in Nov if needed: Algerian official
summary: Algerian Energy Minister Nouredine Bouterfa suggests Opec could cut production by 1% more than the initial 700,000 barrels per day, potentially reaching 33.5 million barrels per day, at its November meeting in Vienna. This would be the first increase since 2008. The move aims to stabilize prices, with Algeria being a key price hawk within Opec. An informal meeting in Istanbul on October 8-13 will discuss the implementation of the Algiers deal, attended by oil ministers from several countries.

site_title: BP Plc to get permission to set up fuel stations in India
summary: India has granted BP Plc permission to set up 3,500 fuel stations in the country. The decision was made by the oil ministry, which will soon issue a letter to BP's Indian unit confirming the licence. BP had sought the government's approval to sell petrol and diesel in India, following a long-standing absence from the market. This move is expected to enhance competition in the fuel retailing sector and benefit Indian consumers.

site_title: Singaporean arrested under ISA for supporting Isis, 3 others released
summary: A 33-year-old Singaporean, Asrul Alias, was arrested under the Internal Security Act in August for supporting the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (Isis). He has been placed under a two-year Restriction Order, limiting his movements and activities. Three others who were also investigated have been released. This is the first time a Singaporean has been arrested under the ISA for supporting a terrorist organization.

images.alt_text: A 33-year-old Singaporean supporter of terror group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (Isis) was arrested under the Internal Security Act in August, the Ministry of Home Affairs said on Thursday.

site_title: More than 80 persons detained under ISA for terrorism-related activities since 2002: MHA
summary: More than 80 individuals have been detained under the Internal Security Act (ISA) for terrorism-related activities in Singapore since 2002. As of the latest update, 17 are on detention orders, 2 on suspension directions, and 25 on restriction orders. The Ministry of Home Affairs emphasized the government's serious stance against terrorism support and pledged to take decisive action against those involved. Efforts to counter radical ideology, led by community and religious organizations, have been recognized and commended by the government.

images.alt_text: MORE than 80 persons have been detained for terrorism-related activities under the Internal Security Act (ISA) since 2002, the Ministry of Home Affairs said on Thursday.

site_title: Frasers Property Australia to buy industrial site in Sydney
summary: Frasers Property Australia announced the purchase of a 15.19-hectare industrial site in Sydney's Chullora area for an estimated A$55 million. The site will be developed into a 6-hectare parcel and leased to SUEZ Recycling & Recovery Pty Ltd for 20 years. The acquisition is expected to boost the company's capacity to serve major Australian and international clients in the Sydney market, particularly online retail groups. The site's proximity to the metropolitan area is expected to attract strong interest from potential tenants.

site_title: Tax set for showdown in Luxembourg
summary: Luxembourg hosts a meeting of 10 EU countries discussing a financial transaction tax, a levy first proposed five years ago to get a "fair contribution" to the cost of the financial crisis. Austrian Finance Minister Hans Joerg Schelling has set a deadline for a decision in October, or he will step down as the group's leader. Two working groups and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development are expected to provide reports on the tax's treatment of derivatives and cost-effectiveness. The European Commission first proposed the tax in 2011, but it has yet to gain consensus among EU nations.

site_title: Analysts temper hopes of market-friendly Malaysian budget
summary: Malaysia's upcoming Budget 2017 is expected to be market-friendly, but analysts say fiscal constraints will dampen prospects for economic growth. The government's tight finances and low oil-related revenues will limit spending, with Treasury expected to walk a tightrope to reduce the fiscal deficit to 3% of GDP. Economic growth is projected to decline to 4% this year, and the government will rely on major government-linked companies to invest in new projects. Analysts warn that investors should temper their expectations, citing a lack of direction and low investor confidence.

site_title: Australian banking inquiry set to pave way for more consumer-friendly rules
summary: An Australian parliamentary inquiry into the nation's Big Four banks is likely to lead to consumer-friendly changes, including a customer complaints tribunal and easier bank switching. Bank CEOs agreed to in-principle proposals, but Opposition Leader Bill Shorten remains opposed to a Royal Commission, which he believes would be a more effective solution. The inquiry follows scandals and criticism over the banks' failure to pass on rate cuts and their abuse of market power.

site_title: Asia flows boost shipping rates, displace US crude imports
summary: A surge in Asian demand for West African crude has led to a global increase in shipping rates for the largest oil tankers, affecting US crude imports. Chartering rates for Suezmaxes and very large crude carriers (VLCCs) have risen rapidly, with rates for Suezmaxes from the US Gulf to Japan or South Korea reaching around $3.5 million, more than double the rate two months ago. This surge in demand is tied to the resumption of exports from Nigeria and other West African countries, which could support benchmark oil prices in coming weeks.

site_title: 3-month Sibor finally cracks under ample liquidity, falls to 0.871%, the low for the year
summary: The three-month Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (Sibor) fell to 0.871% on Thursday, its lowest point for the year, due to ample liquidity. This decline marks a significant move after the Sibor had barely changed in the past few months. The weakening Singdollar against the US dollar also contributed to the rate's drop. Economist Eugene Leow from DBS Bank said the Sibor "finally caught up" with the more volatile three-month Swap Offered Rate (SOR).

site_title: US oil prices top US$50 a barrel for 1st time since June
summary: US oil prices surpassed $50 a barrel for the first time since June, driven by lower US petroleum inventories and the Opec plan to cut output. The US Department of Energy reported a 3 million barrel drop in US commercial crude-oil inventories and lower US oil production for the week ending September 30. Oil prices have strengthened despite skepticism from analysts about Opec's ability to follow through on the plan. West Texas Intermediate reached $50.25 a barrel, up 38 cents in intraday trade.

site_title: Samsung to 'review' split plan, shares hit record high
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to review a proposal by US hedge fund Elliott Management to split the company into two entities, following a 4.45% surge in its share price to a record high. The proposal, which includes a special dividend and dual-listing on a US exchange, aims to streamline the company and address a long-term undervaluation in the equity market. The move comes as Samsung navigates a complex leadership succession and global recall of Galaxy Note 7 smartphones.

site_title: No let-up seen in overseas acquisitions by Japanese insurers
summary: Japanese insurers continue to pay high premiums for overseas assets, with Sompo Holdings Inc agreeing to buy US property and casualty insurer Endurance Specialty Holdings Ltd for $6.3 billion, paying a 40.3% premium. This trend is driven by Japan's need for global diversification and the low interest rate environment at home. Analysts expect this push to improve the return on equity of Japanese insurers, which averages less than 10%. Similar deals by Japanese insurers, such as Sompo's and Tokio Marine's, demonstrate the willingness of Japanese companies to pay a premium for overseas targets.

site_title: SPH Reit reports higher DPU for Q4, FY2016
summary: SPH Reit reported a 1.4% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter of 2016, reaching 1.41 Singapore cents, up from 1.38 cents in the same period last year. The company's gross revenue also rose 2.7% for the quarter and 2.2% for the full year. Its aggregate DPU for the full year was 5.50 cents, a 0.5% increase year-over-year.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher; Noble, O&G and healthcare in heavy play
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened at 2,901, but drifted lower to 2,885.22, a 3.43-point gain. Heavy trading occurred in Noble Group, O&G, and healthcare sectors, with Noble Group rising 7.3% to S$0.191. Turnover was S$1.1 billion, the highest in recent standards. The STI has gained 3 points for the year so far, despite a slide in oil prices and Dow futures.

site_title: Citi says "time to buy" European banks
summary: Citi analysts upgraded their recommendation on European banks to "overweight" within regional portfolios, citing signs of improvement in the credit cycle and loan growth. Despite headwinds from ultra-low interest rates and regulatory costs, Citi sees negative risks as being more individual to select banks rather than system-wide. European banks are trading at their cheapest relative to US peers, with shares priced for disappointments rather than reduced risks, making buying them a contrarian trade.

site_title: Bukit Panjang LRT may be scrapped: SMRT internal blog
summary: SMRT Corp and the Land Transport Authority (LTA) are reviewing the future of the Bukit Panjang LRT, considering scrapping the system. A joint team is assessing the system's viability with a view to a major overhaul. SMRT Trains managing director Lee Ling Wee stated this in an internal blog. The decision will impact the 4.4 km LRT line in Bukit Panjang, which has faced technical issues and low ridership. The outcome is yet to be determined, but a major overhaul or scrapping is a possible option.

site_title: US unemployment claims point to solid jobs report
summary: US initial jobless claims fell to 249,000, down 5,000 from the previous week, marking 83 consecutive weeks below 300,000, the longest streak since 1970. This indicates a likely solid jobs report for the US this week, suggesting a strong labor market.

images.alt_text: Another week of low claims for unemployment insurance pointed Thursday to a likely solid report on the US jobs market this week.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares climb, aided by resources and appetite for China stocks
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 0.7% to 23,952.50 points, driven by buying of Chinese shares ahead of the market's reopening on Monday. Resource and financial shares, including PetroChina and China Shenhua, climbed 4.1% and 3.3% respectively. Galaxy Entertainment Group shares jumped 3.8% after Nomura raised its target price, while Lenovo Group rose 1.5% on reports of a potential acquisition of Fujitsu's personal computer business.

site_title: Study shows health improving globally, but progress is patchy
summary: A global study found that people's health is improving, with life expectancy rising to 69 years for men and 74.8 years for women, but progress is patchy, with chronic diseases causing seven out of 10 deaths. The study, which analyzed 195 countries, found that economic development drives health gains, but also highlighted disparities, particularly in the US, where poor health outcomes persist despite significant resources.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher, Fujitsu jumps on merger report
summary: Tokyo shares rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by a weaker yen boosting exporters. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.47% to close at 16,899.10. Fujitsu surged on reports it may merge its money-losing PC unit with Lenovo. The broader Topix index also rose 0.45%.

site_title: China eyes progress at Apec for China-backed free trade area
summary: China is seeking progress at the upcoming APEC summit in Peru on a Chinese-backed free trade area, with the framework's establishment being a key goal. China's foreign minister expressed hope for progress, following a 2014 APEC summit in Beijing where President Xi Jinping urged members to accelerate talks on the Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific (FTAAP). The framework's establishment was previously approved by APEC, with Xi calling it a "historic step".

site_title: UK productivity finally returns to pre-crisis high in Q2
summary: UK productivity has returned to pre-crisis levels, reaching a record high in Q2 2016. Economic output per hour worked rose 0.6% in the second quarter, surpassing the pre-downturn level seen in Q4 2007. This marks the first time since 2008 that productivity has exceeded its pre-crisis level. Hourly output growth slowed to 0.4% compared to the previous year, while unit labour costs increased 1.9%. The Office for National Statistics attributed the growth to a faster rate of productivity growth.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 1-week high, led by Samsung Electronics; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares ended at a one-week high, led by Samsung Electronics' 0.6% gain after US hedge fund Elliott Management proposed a restructuring plan. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) reached 2,065.30, its highest level since September 29. Offshore investors purchased 101 billion won worth of Kospi shares, contributing to the rally.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore High Court approved the judicial management of offshore firm Swiber Holdings and its unit Swiber Offshore Construction. HDB resale transactions decreased 11.3% in September, while Sibor fell to 0.871%, the year's low. NTUC Income introduced telematics-based motor insurance schemes, and SIA signed a codeshare deal with Air Mauritius. PUB sought proposals for R&D water projects, while UOL and UIC bought Raintree Gardens en-bloc for S$334.2m. Singapore shares rose 3.43 points to 2,885.22, driven by gains in Noble, O&G, and healthcare sectors.

images.alt_text: The Singapore High Court on Thursday granted the application to place ailing offshore firm Swiber Holdings and its unit Swiber Offshore Construction under judicial management (JM).

site_title: Berlin pursues discreet talks with US officials on Deutsche Bank
summary: Berlin is discreetly negotiating with US officials to help Deutsche Bank settle a $14 billion demand from the US Department of Justice over toxic mortgage bonds. German officials hope for a swift deal to buy time for Deutsche to regain its footing, as a settlement is crucial for Chancellor Angela Merkel ahead of a federal election next year. Merkel's government is wary of rescuing the bank, fearing it could be seen as a bailout, and is instead exploring a merger between Deutsche and Commerzbank or other European banks.

site_title: SMEs stand to gain from Asean Economic Community but challenges seen
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the Asean region can benefit from the Asean Economic Community (AEC) by accessing global value chains and trade tariffs, but they face challenges in leveraging these opportunities due to limited technology support and access to finance. The AEC, established in 2015, aims to liberalize trade barriers and promote economic integration among member states. Despite these benefits, SMEs may struggle to take advantage of the AEC's potential, highlighting the need for targeted support and infrastructure development to facilitate their growth and participation in the regional economy.

site_title: Asia FX outlook improves as hesitant Fed chains US dollar: poll
summary: Emerging Asian currencies are expected to fare better in the coming year due to receding expectations of rapid US rate hikes and China's stabilizing economy. A Reuters poll found that major Asian currencies, such as the Chinese yuan, Indian rupee, and Malaysian ringgit, are expected to weaken less than previously thought. The yuan is expected to depreciate about 3% from now until the end of September 2017, while the Malaysian ringgit is forecast to strengthen. Analysts attribute the improved outlook to the US dollar's vulnerability in the aftermath of the Fed's decision to leave monetary policy unchanged.

site_title: Australia shares gain on US data, oil; NZ stocks fall
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.6% to 5,483 points, tracking US gains after strong economic data and oil price increases. The US services sector activity rebounded to an 11-month high, boosting prospects of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December.

site_title: Indonesia holds military drill at South China Sea islands
summary: Indonesia's air force conducted a major military drill around the Natuna islands in the South China Sea, where clashes with Chinese vessels have occurred. Thousands of personnel and various aircraft participated in the exercise, which aimed to prepare for potential threats and face challenges. President Joko Widodo attended the drill, underscoring Indonesia's determination to defend its sovereignty in the region. The exercise comes amid tensions between Indonesia and China over maritime claims.

site_title: SIA signs codeshare deal with Air Mauritius
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has signed a codeshare agreement with Air Mauritius, allowing passengers to book SIA-operated flights between Singapore and Mauritius under the "SQ" designator code. The agreement, effective November 1, subject to regulatory approvals, increases travel options for passengers. Air Mauritius currently operates three weekly flights on the route. This partnership aims to provide more convenience and choice for travelers between the two destinations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, tracking gains in Asia and the US overnight, ahead of key US non-farm payroll data. London's FTSE 100 index added 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.5%, and the Paris CAC 40 gained 0.2%. The dollar strengthened further due to growing expectations of a US interest rate hike by the end of the year, despite positive data on the US services sector.

site_title: Thai September consumer mood improves for third straight month: survey
summary: Thai consumer confidence rose for the third consecutive month in September, according to a university survey. Consumers are optimistic about the government's focus on investment and economic stimulation in the fourth quarter. The Bank of Thailand has maintained its 2016 growth forecast at 3.2%, citing domestic and external risks. The Thai economy, which has struggled since the military seized power in 2014, remains sluggish, with exports and domestic demand still sluggish.

site_title: Pilipinas Shell sets IPO price range, targets up to 19.2b pesos
summary: Pilipinas Shell sets an initial public offering (IPO) price range of 64 to 70 pesos a share, targeting up to $400 million from the offering. The company aims to raise 17.6 billion to 19.2 billion pesos, its third IPO in the Philippines this year. The shares will be listed on the Philippines Stock Exchange on November 3. JP Morgan is the sole global coordinator, and BPI Capital is the domestic lead underwriter.

site_title: EasyJet suffers first profit drop since 2009 on terror, Brexit
summary: EasyJet reported its first profit drop since 2009 due to a decline in demand caused by terror attacks and the decline of the pound following Brexit. The airline's pretax profit for the 12 months ended Sept 30 is expected to be in the range of 490-495 million pounds, 28% lower than the 686 million pounds generated in 2015. EasyJet ceased providing full-year guidance after the Brexit decision, citing uncertainty.

site_title: Fuji Heavy recalls 100,000 Subaru cars to fix air pump switch
summary: Fuji Heavy Industries is recalling approximately 100,000 Subaru-branded vehicles in Japan to fix a problem with an air pump switch in the main fuse box. The affected models, produced between 2006-2013, include the Legacy, Impreza, XC, and Forester crossover SUVs. The company plans to also recall models overseas, but details are not provided. The recall aims to address a potential safety issue and is expected to be completed in the near future.

site_title: Malaysia's attorney-general says no new request from Swiss on 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's attorney-general's office stated it has not received a new request from Switzerland for assistance in investigating 1MDB. The office said it remains committed to international cooperation and will consider any future requests through diplomatic channels and in line with local laws. Switzerland's Office of the Attorney General had previously sought additional help from Malaysia in its 1MDB investigation.

site_title: Duterte's popularity soars with Philippine crime war: poll
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's popularity has soared to 76% among Filipinos in a recent survey, amid a brutal war on crime that has left over 3,000 dead. Despite global condemnation, Duterte has continued his threats and incitements to kill, with a promise to eradicate crime in six months. His approval rating is the highest among presidents in the country since democracy was restored in 1986, with only one other president, Fidel Ramos, enjoying higher popularity ratings three months into their presidency.

site_title: Barclays private bankers said to defect before OCBC takeover
summary: Barclays private bankers are defecting to Standard Chartered ahead of OCBC's takeover of Barclays' private-banking operations in Hong Kong, highlighting the intense competition for wealth managers in Asia. Over 10 relationship managers are joining Standard Chartered, while about 20 are expected to join OCBC's private banking unit. The defections underscore the demand for experienced wealth managers and the risk of trying to buy market share in an industry where successful relationship managers often take their best clients with them.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks head for second session of falls; TSMC dips
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell for a second consecutive session, with the main Taiex index down 0.3% at 9,247.97. Technology heavyweights, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), declined 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.376 per US dollar. This decline follows cautious trading, with foreign buying supporting TSMC's 30% year-to-date gains.

site_title: Norway boosts oil money spending to back recovery amid oil slump
summary: Norway's government plans to increase oil money spending to 225 billion kroner in 2017 to support the economy amid a slump in the nation's oil industry. The move comes after a record 206 billion kroner spending this year, with Finance Minister Siv Jensen stating that the budget will be "somewhat tighter" but adapted to the economic situation. The government aims to target new jobs and protect the economy, despite the oil market showing signs of exiting the crisis. The budget is expected to have a 1.1 percentage point stimulus to the economy.

images.alt_text: Norway's government will next year add to record spending of its oil income, withdrawing cash from its massive US$890 billion sovereign wealth fund to protect the economy against a slump in the nation's oil industry.

site_title: FLASH: High Court grants application for Swiber to be placed under judicial management
summary: The High Court has granted an application to place Swiber, a Singapore-based offshore services provider, under judicial management. This decision aims to address the company's financial difficulties and potential insolvency. The judicial management process will oversee Swiber's restructuring and ensure its continued operation. The outcome of this process remains uncertain, but it marks a significant step towards addressing Swiber's financial challenges.

site_title: Why women don't rise in the workplace: Robert Walters survey
summary: A survey by Robert Walters found that 37% of Singapore respondents cited family pressures, 32% management bias, and 30% a lack of workplace culture as reasons why women are underrepresented in leadership positions. The survey of 4,400 clients and job seekers in Asia-Pacific found that four in five women think women are underrepresented in leadership roles, with family pressures, work culture, and management bias as top reasons. Experts emphasize the need for women to advocate for themselves and equal opportunities.

site_title: PUB seeks proposals for R&D water projects
summary: PUB, Singapore's water agency, has launched a request for proposals for basic and applied research and development projects in the water industry, with up to S$25 million available for projects in two areas. The first focuses on increasing water resources, improving quality and security, and reducing production costs, while the second aims to accelerate the commercialization and export of water technologies. Interested parties have until December 8 to submit a white paper, with a roadshow scheduled for October 11.

site_title: Singapore court gives green light for Swiber to be placed under JM
summary: The Singapore High Court granted permission to place offshore firm Swiber Holdings and its unit under judicial management (JM) due to the company's insolvency. The judicial managers, from KPMG, will provide updates to creditors every six weeks unless a meeting is held within 60 days. The decision aims to facilitate a more orderly disposal of assets, with potential returns potentially higher than in a liquidation scenario, according to Swiber's counsel. No creditors expressed opposition, and the company's principal banker, DBS, was represented by its lawyers.

site_title: Thai students mark university massacre amid junta rule
summary: Thai students marked the 40th anniversary of a 1976 campus massacre by state forces in Bangkok, where around 2,000 students were attacked and dozens killed. The event occurred amid a military-ruled Thailand with a history of political upheaval and human rights abuses. A deep-rooted culture of impunity has allowed the military to intervene in politics and violate human rights, according to Human Rights Watch. Students remembered the massacre and called for accountability, while the military government declined to comment on the anniversary.

site_title: Thriller songwriter Rod Temperton dies aged 66
summary: Rod Temperton, the British songwriter behind Michael Jackson's hit Thriller, has died at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Temperton penned the iconic song in a taxi and also worked with Aretha Franklin and Mariah Carey. The Quincy Jones-produced album broke records in 1982, selling over 30 million copies in the US. Temperton's family requests privacy following a private funeral. Tributes from artists such as Mark Ronson, Boy George, and LL Cool J have been shared on social media, praising the songwriter's genius.

site_title: Evolution boss sees global uncertainty underpinning gold price
summary: Evolution Mining's executive chairman Jake Klein expects gold prices to remain strong due to global uncertainty, driven by geopolitical and fiscal uncertainty. Klein attributes investor demand for gold to terrorism, civil wars, and political upheaval, including the potential US presidential election of Donald Trump. Despite a recent drop, Klein believes gold equities are likely to continue a long bull cycle, with Evolution's shares jumping 75% over the past year.

site_title: Update: Switzerland asks Malaysia again for help with 1MDB case
summary: Switzerland has asked Malaysia for a second time to help gather evidence in the 1MDB case, which involves embezzlement of $800 million from a Malaysian sovereign fund. The Swiss Attorney-General's office has received evidence from Singaporean authorities and is investigating four people and one bank. US prosecutors have filed a request to seize $1 billion in real estate and luxury goods linked to the scandal. Malaysia has not received the request through the diplomatic channel, and the Malaysian Attorney-General's Chambers has expressed its commitment to international cooperation, but has yet to respond to the request.

site_title: Typhoon Chaba leaves six dead in South Korea
summary: Typhoon Chaba made landfall in South Korea's southern coast, causing widespread damage and flooding. The storm left six people dead, four missing, and over 230,000 homes without power. Industrial cities like Ulsan were severely affected, with two car plants closing due to flood damage. The typhoon also disrupted the Busan International Film Festival, with events cancelled or moved indoors. The storm was downgraded from a typhoon to a tropical cyclone over the Sea of Japan before hitting Honshu island.

site_title: Trump factory jobs sent to China may never come back
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's pledge to bring back American manufacturing jobs from China may be too late, with a Chinese company producing Ivanka Trump-branded shoes moving production to Africa. The company, Huajian Group, has been expanding to Africa and Southeast Asia in search of lower production costs, and its president, Zhang Huarong, has stated that low-wage, low-skilled manufacturing jobs are "being priced out of the Chinese market." Trump's focus on imposing tariffs on Chinese-made goods may not be enough to bring back jobs, as the labor-intensive work required to make fashionable shoes will always go to the lowest bidder.

site_title: US and Australia to share cost of US military's Australian deployment
summary: Australia and the US have agreed to share the cost of the US military's deployment in Darwin, Australia's tropical north, with a focus on regional security and stability. The two countries will invest over A$2 billion in infrastructure and other costs linked to the 25-year deployment. The deal, signed in 2014, aims to double the number of US Marines in Darwin from 1,250 by 2020, bolstering the US military presence in the disputed South China Sea. The agreement follows criticism from China and a call from a US soldier to increase Australia's involvement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.48% to 23,902.96, extending a fourth consecutive day of gains, following a Wall Street rally and upbeat US data. Mainland Chinese markets are closed for the National Day holiday. The rally follows positive US economic indicators and traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally as US economy picks up
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, led by Tokyo, as the dollar strengthened against the yen due to growing expectations of a US interest rate hike by the end of the year. Positive data on the US services sector reinforced the view that the top economy is on track, supporting a rally in shares. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4%, while the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: NTUC Income introduces telematics-based motor insurance schemes
summary: NTUC Income, Singapore's top motor insurer, has introduced two telematics-based motor insurance schemes: Drive Master and FlexiMileage. Drive Master tracks driving behavior and rewards good drivers with discounts of 5-20% on top of the no-claim discount. FlexiMileage measures only distance, offering 20-35% discounts for low-mileage cars. NTUC Income will be the first to apply this technology to passenger cars, although it is also being used to track commercial vehicles in Europe.

images.alt_text: Drivers participating in FlexiMileage must install the telematics device in their private cars, which will capture the mileage travelled by the vehicle.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up as Samsung Electronics hits record high
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.2% on Thursday, with Samsung Electronics hitting a record high after rejecting a restructuring proposal by US hedge fund Elliott Management. The proposal aimed to split Samsung into a holding company and an operating company, listing the latter on the Nasdaq. Samsung shares rose 5% in early trade, boosting the Korea Composite Stock Price Index. Market expectations for Samsung's third-quarter earnings guidance also contributed to the upward movement, with offshore investors expected to be net buyers.

site_title: Singapore's hedge fund assets rise at slowest in three years
summary: Singapore's hedge fund assets grew 11% to S$119 billion in 2015, the slowest pace in three years, as investors redeemed money amid a China stock market slump. This is down from 21% growth in the previous two years. The Eurekahedge Asian Hedge Fund Index gained 6.4% in 2015, the lowest since 2011. Investors withdrew US$13.7 billion from Asia-focused hedge funds in the first eight months of 2016, accounting for 12% of regional industry assets.

site_title: MetLife files for spinoff of US unit after weighing IPO, sale
summary: MetLife Inc has filed for a spinoff of its US retail unit, Brighthouse Financial Inc, after considering an initial public offering or sale. At least 80.1% of Brighthouse shares will be distributed to MetLife investors. The spinoff aims to simplify the company, reduce risks, and capitalize on the stability of annuities. CEO Steve Kandarian will retain international units and operations, while the Brighthouse spinoff will focus on predictable cash flow and reduce securities market risks. The move is seen as a quicker option to exit the business compared to an IPO during market volatility.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars outmatched as US dollar gets data boost
summary: The Australian dollar slipped 0.1% to US$0.7610, edging lower ahead of the US jobs data on Friday, which could boost expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike this year. The Aussie dollar was overshadowed by the looming jobs report, despite Australia reporting a smaller-than-expected trade deficit for August. The US dollar strengthened, gaining ground against the Australian and New Zealand dollars as investors focus on the jobs data and potential rate hike.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.6% up on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% on Thursday, reaching 2,900.45 points, driven by gains in US stocks and higher oil prices. About 56.5 million shares changed hands, with Noble and Ezion being the top traded counters. The market saw 96 gainers for every two losers, indicating a positive trend.

site_title: Brazil opens oil fields to foreign firms in major policy shift
summary: Brazil's Congress voted to open up its pre-salt oil fields to foreign investors, allowing companies other than Petrobras to operate blocks in the largest deep-water deposits. The legislation, approved 292-101, scraps Petrobras' obligation to be the area's sole operator, paving the way for investment in the heavily indebted state-controlled oil producer. The move marks a significant change to Brazil's offshore oil industry regulations, with Petrobras having the first pick of fields and foreign investors set to attract investment.

site_title: EU suspends Colombia fund after shock vote
summary: The European Union has suspended a 600 million euro development fund for Colombia after a referendum rejected a peace deal with the Farc rebel group. The fund was intended to help the Colombian government uphold the historic peace accord, which aimed to end a half-century of conflict. The EU's decision follows the referendum result, with Slovakia's EU minister stating that the current situation makes it impossible to continue with the fund's launch.

site_title: Ascendas sets up new S$3b funding programme
summary: Ascendas, a government-owned urban development group, has set up a S$3 billion Euro Medium Term Note programme, allowing it to tap international capital markets and diversify funding sources. The new programme is an addition to its existing S$1 billion multi-currency medium term note programme. CEO Miguel Ko stated that the programme will enable the firm to support business growth by having financial flexibility to embark on projects and developments driven by urbanisation trends in the region.

site_title: Yum blames South China Sea dispute for hammering results in Asia
summary: Yum! Brands Inc, parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell, reported disappointing results due to the South China Sea dispute. After an international arbitration court invalidated Chinese claims, consumers in China lashed out against Western companies, resulting in a 1% decline in same-store sales. This affected Yum's final full quarter in China, which will be spun off on October 31. The company's CEO attributed the decline to the dispute, citing a 4.1% projected sales gain in China instead of the actual 1% decline.

site_title: Gold holds near lowest in three months as US payrolls loom
summary: Gold prices traded near a three-month low as investors awaited the US payrolls report, which could influence interest-rate hikes and the economy's strength. Gold prices slumped 3.3% on Wednesday, the largest drop in over a year, due to concerns about central banks curbing stimulus. Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer emphasized the need for "transparent and sound monetary policies" to boost long-term growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.030 points to 1663.950 on Thursday, with gains outnumbering losses 76 to 41. Volume was 48.7 million lots worth RM14.02 million.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA share prices opened slightly higher on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 1.030 points to 1663.950.

site_title: Myanmar's KBZ Bank opens Singapore rep office
summary: Myanmar's KBZ Bank has opened a representative office in Singapore, marking the country's first bank to set up an office in the city-state. The office aims to facilitate regulatory requirements, market research, and business opportunities between the two nations. Following visa-free travel commencing on December 1, 2016, the move is expected to ease doing business between Myanmar and Singapore, which is the country's largest investor after China.

images.alt_text: MYANMAR'S largest private bank, Kanbawza Bank or KBZ Bank, has opened a representative office in Singapore.

site_title: Ricciardo backs Aussies facing Malaysia indecency row
summary: Formula One driver Daniel Ricciardo has expressed support for nine Australian men arrested in Malaysia for stripping off to tight-fitting swimwear and drinking beer from their shoes after his win at the Malaysian Grand Prix. The men could face up to two years in jail, but Ricciardo called their actions "harmless" and urged authorities to let them go. Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop has also warned that there are limits to what Canberra can do to help the men.

site_title: UOL, UIC buy Raintree Gardens en-bloc for S$334.2m
summary: UOL Group's associate company UVD (Projects) Pte Ltd has acquired Raintree Gardens residential development at Potong Pasir Avenue 1 for S$334.2 million after an en-bloc tender. The site, a former HUDC estate built in the late 1980s, will be funded by bank borrowings and internal resources. The acquisition is seen as part of UOL's business strategy to replenish its land bank for residential development in Singapore.

site_title: Wal-Mart boosts stake in JD.com moving further into China market
summary: Wal-Mart has increased its stake in JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce website, to 10.8% as part of its efforts to gain more market share in the country's online market. The move comes as Wal-Mart struggles to adapt to a slowing local economy and increasing competition from Alibaba-owned platforms. The partnership aims to leverage JD.com's online resources, including its logistics network, to win users and generate sales. The alliance is part of Wal-Mart's strategy to succeed in China, where it estimates 25% of global retail growth will come from in the next five years.

site_title: Opec to hold informal producer talks next week in Istanbul
summary: Opec oil ministers will meet next week in Istanbul to discuss implementing a 32.5-33 million barrels-per-day production cut, announced last month in Algiers. The meeting will include non-Opec producers and will finalize the deal at the end of next month. Most oil ministers are also scheduled to attend the 23rd World Energy Congress. The deal, which was made without Iran, excludes Nigeria and Libya due to their low oil production. The meeting aims to iron out the details of the pact, which was agreed upon last week.

site_title: Lenovo, Fujitsu said to discuss PC business merger
summary: Lenovo is in talks with Fujitsu to merge their personal-computer businesses, with Lenovo taking a majority stake. The deal aims to give Lenovo a bigger foundation to expand its share in the global PC market. Fujitsu would move its PC planning, development, and manufacturing divisions to Lenovo, with around 2,000 workers relocating. The companies are discussing pricing and terms, with a potential agreement expected this month. The merger would strengthen Lenovo's position in the market, while Fujitsu seeks to scale back its operations.

site_title: Twitter drops 9% after report that Google won't bid
summary: Twitter's stock fell 9% after a report stated that Google won't bid for the social network, contrary to initial speculation. Twitter has set a deadline for potential buyers to conclude negotiations by October 27. Salesforce.com and Walt Disney Co are among the companies considered to be in the running. The decline comes as Twitter continues to struggle with revenue growth and profit, despite its large user base.

site_title: Samsung turns Vietnam's farmers into bigger earners than bankers
summary: Samsung's investment in Vietnam has transformed the country's economy, making it the second-largest exporting center after Ho Chi Minh City. The company's factory town in Bac Ninh province has created 45,000 jobs and boosted local businesses, with per capita GDP rising three times the national average. Samsung's investment has also lifted farmers like Nguyen Thi Dung out of poverty, providing them with higher wages, social security benefits, and job stability. The company's expansion in Vietnam is seen as a key step in the country's plan to inherit China's manufacturing mantle.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher as yen drops further
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on October 6, 2016, as the yen fell, lifting exporters. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.56% to 16,913.60, while the Topix index gained 0.51% to 1,354.75. The yen's decline contributed to the market's increase.

site_title: Apple, Google, Coca-Cola top list of 100 most valuable brands: report
summary: Apple, Google, and Coca-Cola top the list of the world's 100 most valuable brands in 2016, according to Interbrand's report. Technology and automotive brands dominated the rankings, with Apple's brand value rising 5% to $178 billion and Google's up 11% to $133 billion. Social networks and e-commerce giants, such as Facebook and Amazon, were the top growing brands. The report ranks brands based on financial performance, customer influence, and premium pricing power.

site_title: Asia: Shares firm after US service sector rebounds
summary: Asian shares rose 0.2-0.9% on Thursday, driven by stronger US economic data and rising oil prices, while gold and the US dollar hit one-month highs. The US services sector rebounded sharply in September, boosting bets on a US rate hike in December. The US dollar rose to a one-month high against the yen, while euro zone bond yields picked up amid speculation of European Central Bank tapering. Oil prices also rose to their highest since June, supported by a fifth consecutive weekly drawdown in US crude inventories.

site_title: Paris climate accord ratified, to start next month: UN
summary: The Paris climate accord has been ratified, entering into force next month after gaining support from 56.75% of world greenhouse gas emissions, exceeding the 55% threshold. European nations led by Germany and France contributed to the threshold, with major emitters China, the US, and India already on board. The deal aims to shift the world economy away from fossil fuels.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to acquire artificial intelligence firm Viv, run by Siri co-creator
summary: Samsung Electronics is acquiring Viv Labs Inc, a US-based artificial intelligence firm, for undisclosed financial terms. The acquisition aims to integrate Viv's AI platform into Samsung's Galaxy smartphones, expanding voice-assistant services to home appliances and wearable technology devices. This move is part of Samsung's efforts to differentiate its devices with AI, competing with tech giants like Google, Amazon, and Apple in the rapidly growing AI market. Viv's co-founder and a Siri co-creator will continue managing the business independently following the acquisition.

site_title: HDB resale transactions down in Sept m-o-m but prices up 0.1%: SRX
summary: HDB resale transactions in Singapore declined 11.3% in September 2016 to 1,666 flats, but year-on-year sales increased 10.8% compared to the same period in 2015. The HDB resale flat price index rose 0.1% month-over-month in September, contrasting a 0.7% decline in August.

images.alt_text: The volume of HDB resale transactions in September 2016 contracted 11.3 per cent to 1,666 resale flats from 1,879 flats in the preceding month, according to data compiled by SRX Property.

site_title: Samsung targeted by US activist Elliott urging separation
summary: Samsung Electronics Co is urged by activist investor Elliott Management Corp to restructure its business into two companies: a holding company and an operating company. The proposal aims to simplify the conglomerate's structure, improve governance, and boost trading volumes. Elliott calls for a tender, dual-listing on Nasdaq, and a special dividend to shareholders. The move comes as Samsung navigates the aftermath of a Galaxy Note smartphone launch and the succession of Lee Kun-Hee, the company's chairman. Elliott's plan could deliver better capital returns, governance, and shareholder value, while simplifying the company's complex family holdings.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall led by utilities, real estate; Tesco soars
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday due to concerns about the European Central Bank's potential reduction of bond-buying, which hit utility and real estate stocks. The Stoxx 600 index is down 6% for 2016. Bond yields soared, weighing on utility and property stocks, while banks rose as higher yields boost lending. The ECB has not discussed reducing bond purchases, but the possibility of tapering has rattled markets.

site_title: Rock legends shatter limits with mega-concert
summary: Rock legends The Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney, Roger Waters, The Who, Bob Dylan, and Neil Young will perform at Desert Trip, a three-day concert in southern California, marking what may be the highest-grossing music festival of all time. The event, which sold tickets for up to $1,599, has drawn 150,000 people over two weekends, tapping into a senior audience dubbed "Oldchella." Despite some acts, including The Who, bowing out due to their ongoing tour, the festival has proven to be a huge success, with tickets quickly snapped up and special dining packages available.

site_title: IS recruits more educated than average: World Bank study
summary: A World Bank study found that recruits to the Islamic State group are better educated than their average countrymen, contrary to popular belief. The study, "Economic and Social Inclusion to Prevent Violent Extremism," found that those willing to become suicide bombers were more educated, and poverty and deprivation were not the primary reasons for joining the group.

site_title: Trump donated to state attorneys-general reviewing his business: WSJ
summary: US Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump donated to state attorneys-general while they reviewed decisions affecting his business, according to the Wall Street Journal. Records show Trump, his family, and associates gave campaign contributions to attorneys general in New York from the 1980s, including Eric Schneiderman, who is investigating the Donald J Trump Foundation. The donations were often made when Trump's companies had pending decisions in these offices, raising questions about potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: NSA contractor charged with stealing secret data
summary: A National Security Agency (NSA) contractor, Harold Thomas Martin, 51, has been charged with stealing highly classified information, including sensitive hacking tools used to break into foreign computer networks. Martin, who had top-secret national security clearance, was arrested in August and faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted. The charges come amid growing concern over cyberhacking and insider threats, and may further undermine the Obama administration's efforts to recover from Edward Snowden's 2013 disclosures about US government surveillance.

site_title: Alaska oil reserves may have grown 80% on giant discovery
summary: Alaska's oil reserves may have increased by 80% after Caelus Energy LLC announced the discovery of 6 billion barrels of light oil in Arctic waters. The reserve, estimated to be 40% recoverable, could produce up to 200,000 barrels per day. This discovery could provide a much-needed boost to Alaska's oil output, which has been declining, and is seen as a significant opportunity for the state. The development project is expected to cost $8-10 billion and could be operational by 2022.

site_title: Twitter to conclude sale deliberations this month: sources
summary: Twitter is set to conclude sale deliberations by the time it reports third-quarter earnings on October 27, according to sources. Potential acquirers, including Salesforce, Alphabet, and Walt Disney, are due to submit binding offers in the next two weeks. The timeline is ambitious, with CEO Jack Dorsey pushing for clarity on the company's future. Twitter has struggled to generate revenue growth and profit, and a sale could be seen as a way for the company to focus on customer service communications and business intelligence.

site_title: Brazil's Lula faces new corruption charges
summary: Brazil's ex-president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva faces new corruption charges connected to a construction project in Angola involving his nephew. Federal police charged 9 individuals, including Lula, with corruption and money laundering. This development threatens Lula's comeback hopes as a hero to the Latin American left and former supremely popular president.

site_title: Replacement Samsung Note 7 phone emits smoke on US plane: family
summary: A replacement Samsung Galaxy Note 7 phone on a US plane began emitting smoke, prompting investigations by the Consumer Product Safety Commission and the Federal Aviation Administration. The incident occurred on a Southwest Airlines flight after the phone's owner, Brian Green, received a replacement model two weeks prior. This is a new development in the global scandal surrounding the fire-prone Note 7, which has already led to a global recall of at least 2.5 million units. Samsung is working to recover the device and understand the cause, while the FAA confirmed the incident and initiated an investigation.

site_title: Oil trades near US$50 after US stockpiles decline for fifth week
summary: Oil prices traded near US$50 a barrel after US crude stockpiles fell for a fifth week, trimming an inventory overhang. Crude inventories dropped below 500 million barrels for the first time since January. Goldman Sachs predicts oil will stall at US$55 a barrel as US shale drillers resume production. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will decide on production quotas at its meeting on November 30. Oil prices rose 7.9% last month, with West Texas Intermediate and Brent futures also increasing.

images.alt_text: Oil traded near US$50 a barrel as US government data showed crude stockpiles dropped for a fifth week, trimming an inventory overhang.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Fischer says central banks need fiscal help to spur growth
summary: Federal Reserve Vice-Chairman Stanley Fischer stated that both monetary and fiscal policy steps are necessary to address sub-par economic growth. Fischer called for transparent monetary policies, infrastructure investments, education, and effective regulation to boost productivity and growth. He warned that chronically low interest rates could reflect deeper economic problems, and that monetary policy alone may not be sufficient to address the issue. Fischer emphasized the need for fiscal and regulatory measures to boost productivity growth and the economy's potential.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Vice-Chairman Stanley Fischer said both monetary and fiscal policy steps may be needed to fend off a protracted period of sub-par economic growth.

site_title: LVMH to take 80% stake in luggage brand Rimowa
summary: LVMH has agreed to buy a 80% stake in German luggage brand Rimowa for 640 million euros, with Dieter Morszeck retaining a 20% stake. Alexandre Arnault, son of LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault, will become co-CEO alongside Morszeck. The deal, subject to regulatory approval, is expected to be completed in January and marks LVMH's first acquisition of a German luxury goods brand. Rimowa is known for its high-quality, European-made luggage, particularly its aluminum suitcases.

site_title: Amid privacy outcry, Yahoo denies surveillance allegations
summary: Yahoo denies allegations of mass email surveillance, stating a report claiming the company built a special scanning program for US intelligence is "misleading". The report, citing former employees, said Yahoo scanned millions of emails to help the FBI and NSA, prompting an outcry from privacy activists. Yahoo claims it complies with US laws and received a small number of government requests in 2015, contradicting the report's claims. The company's transparency report and actions to challenge government requests suggest it may not have conducted mass surveillance.

site_title: Ex-AIG chairman starts to tell his side of story at fraud trial
summary: Maurice "Hank" Greenberg, former AIG chairman, defended himself against civil fraud allegations, claiming he relied on underlings to handle deal details due to his busy schedule. He testified that he trusted his team to structure transactions and relied on lawyers and accountants to ensure compliance with regulations. Greenberg maintained that he was too busy visiting 30 countries and reviewing documents to cover individual deals. He denied having confidence in the underlings handling two transactions in 2000 that were alleged to have hidden AIG's true financial condition.

site_title: US: Energy, banking shares lead stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, led by energy and banking shares, as oil prices advanced to near $50 a barrel and expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December boosted large banks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.6% to 18,281.03, while the S&P 500 rose 0.4% to 2,159.73. Twitter jumped 5.7% after reports of potential takeover bids, and Amazon rose 1.2% following a new "Prime" subscription program.

site_title: US, China said to be discussing choking off North Korean energy
summary: The US and China are discussing curbing North Korea's energy trade in response to its fifth nuclear test. The US wants to tighten sanctions, but China, which provides most of North Korea's food and energy, is hesitant to restrict its neighbor's energy supplies, fearing it could lead to the regime's collapse. Diplomats say other nations are considering separate sanctions once the UN Security Council acts, but a ban on energy trade is unlikely to succeed.

site_title: Portugal's Guterres wins unanimous backing to lead the UN
summary: Former Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Guterres has won the unanimous backing of the United Nations Security Council to become the world body's next secretary-general. He secured 13 "yes" votes, with two members undecided, after a nine-month campaign. Guterres will succeed Ban Ki-moon of South Korea, leading the UN with 105,000 peacekeepers and a $13 billion annual budget. His appointment marks the first time a Portuguese has held the position, and he faces significant challenges, including the Syrian civil war and humanitarian consequences of refugees fleeing the conflict.

site_title: Wounded gold bull market steadies after worst slump in 3 years
summary: Gold futures market steadied after a 3.3% slump on Tuesday, the biggest in almost three years, due to hawkish comments from Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland president Loretta Mester. Prices are down 7.9% since July's peak as investors expect tighter monetary policy. Forecasts predict a possible bottom at $1,257 an ounce, but some see a medium-term continuation of the move higher. Investors remain bullish on gold as a haven against election risks and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Google challenges Apple, Samsung with its Pixel
summary: Google has launched a new line of premium-priced Pixel smartphones, a virtual reality headset, and a Wi-Fi router, showcasing its artificial intelligence (AI) prowess. The Pixel smartphones, starting at $649, will be available with unlimited storage for photos and videos, and will come with Google Assistant. The company's new virtual reality headset, Daydream View, will be available in November, priced at $79. Additionally, Google has introduced its Google Home virtual assistant, a voice-activated assistant that enables users to tap into the company's online capabilities.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Pan-United Corp announced the divestment of its tug and barge business to its controlling shareholders for S$29.92 million, saving the company on future impairment costs. The move is expected to raise operating profitability and is seen as a positive step. Analysts estimate that Pan-United may generate S$26.2 million of profit after tax and minority interest in 2017, leading to an estimated dividend per share of 3.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Further global debt crisis could be building, IMF warns
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that the world's global debt is at an all-time high, reaching 225% of world GDP, and could hinder the fragile global economic recovery. To reduce debt, the IMF recommends adopting fiscal policies that support economic activity, restructuring private debt, and cleaning up non-performing bank loans. High private debt levels increase the likelihood of financial crises, which can slow economic recovery. The IMF urges regulatory measures to monitor and sustain private debt, and fiscal policies to create buffers for downturns.

site_title: China builds rival port as India-Iran project falters
summary: China has built a rival port to India's Chabahar port in Iran, which has stalled due to bureaucratic delays and disagreements over funding. The Chabahar port was intended to be a strategic hub for India, Iran, and Afghanistan, but it remains a sleepy outpost 13 years after its development began. China has invested significantly in the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, which competes with the Chabahar project. The project's slow pace has drawn criticism, with some analysts suggesting that the Indian government should have given the contract to China to complete the project quickly.

site_title: South-east Asia turns to the US as China exports drop
summary: South-east Asian countries are shifting their focus from China to the US as exports to the US increased in the first quarter, while shipments to China declined in four countries. The US has become a key source of demand for Asian goods, with consumer spending and a stronger dollar making US imports cheaper. Vietnam's exports to the US rose 21%, while Singapore's exports climbed 10%. The Trans-Pacific Partnership, which the US is considering joining, could raise GDP by 1.1% in member countries by 2030, marking a comeback for the US as a major trading partner in the region.

site_title: China scrambles to boost coal as winter looms, fuel demand peaks
summary: China is scrambling to boost coal production as winter approaches, amid a surge in fuel demand. The government's efforts to shrink the coal industry by cutting output controls have led to a 50% increase in prices this year. To avoid higher fuel costs, China is relaxing output controls, allowing miners to raise production by up to 1.4 million tonnes daily. This move aims to balance supply and demand, with prices expected to "normalise" this quarter and average 475 yuan a tonne in 2017.

site_title: Honda dragging its feet on Takata's future: sources
summary: Honda is delaying crucial decisions in talks with troubled airbag maker Takata, hindering efforts to resolve the car industry's largest recall. Despite being the largest customer, accounting for 14% of Takata's sales, Honda has been less active in discussions on potential bankruptcy of sub-suppliers. Other customers, awaiting Honda's buy-in, risk being left without a deal, with Takata's other customers waiting on Honda's proactive measures to cope with the issue. Honda believes it is in discussions, but its inaction may jeopardize a deal, leaving Takata's future uncertain.

site_title: How can hoteliers survive supply influx, weaker demand?
summary: Singapore hoteliers face challenges from a surge in supply and weaker demand, with visitor arrivals growing 12.5% in the first half of 2016 but hotel room revenue only increasing 3.1% to S$1.575 billion. The city-state's strong Singapore dollar, high labor costs, and increasing competition from new hotels contribute to the decline. To survive, hoteliers must innovate, streamline operations, and improve their offerings and service delivery, including focusing on extras such as free Wi-Fi and breakfast, providing proper training, and embracing technology advancements. The industry must also adapt to the rise of the sharing economy and court health-conscious tourists.

site_title: Hitachi mulling over stake sale in US$1.9b Kokusai unit: sources
summary: Hitachi Ltd is considering selling its controlling stake in Hitachi Kokusai Electric Inc, a US$1.9 billion unit that produces equipment for semiconductor makers and wireless-network gear manufacturers. Potential bidders have shown interest in the company, but Hitachi's decision on a sale remains uncertain. The deliberations are at an early stage, and the outcome could lead to a takeover of the entire unit.

site_title: Rolling Stones releasing new album
summary: The Rolling Stones are set to release their first album in over a decade, a collection of covers of Chicago blues classics, on October 6, 2016. The album was recorded in just three days with a simple microphone setup, aiming for a raw, authentic feel. Guitar legend Eric Clapton also participated in the sessions. The release coincides with the band's inaugural Desert Trip festival in California, which features other rock legends like Paul McCartney and Bob Dylan. This marks the Stones' first studio album since 2005's A Bigger Bang.

site_title: WTA Finals champ Radwanska to defend title in Singapore
summary: The WTA Finals in Singapore is taking shape, with defending champion Agnieszka Radwanska and Czech star Karolina Pliskova securing their spots at the US$7 million event. The tournament, set to run from October 23-30, features the top eight female singles players and doubles teams, including Radwanska, Pliskova, and Serena Williams. With three spots remaining, the competition is heating up, and fans can purchase tickets starting at S$32.90.

site_title: Samsung expected to report small rise in Q3 profit: analysts
summary: Samsung Electronics Co is expected to report a small rise in third-quarter profit, driven by healthy sales of memory chips and displays, despite the global recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones. Analysts estimate an operating profit of 7.4 trillion won, up 0.7% from a year earlier. The memory chip market, led by demand from Apple, will buttress earnings, while the mobile division's profit forecast has been lowered due to lost sales and costs from the recall. Samsung's chips division is expected to report quarterly operating profit of three trillion won or more.

site_title: Guangzhou, Shenzhen latest cities to impose property cooling rules
summary: China's southern megacities of Guangzhou and Shenzhen have introduced new measures to cool their real estate markets, including higher mortgage downpayments and home purchase restrictions. In Shenzhen, first-time home buyers must pay a 30% downpayment, while others must pay at least 50%. In Guangzhou, local residents are limited to purchasing two properties, with non-local residents allowed to buy one. These measures aim to balance economic growth with debt and risk concerns, and analysts expect a mild retreat in home prices.

site_title: Credit Suisse admits wrongdoing in asset measure, to pay US$90m
summary: Credit Suisse AG has agreed to pay a US$90 million penalty and admit wrongdoing for misrepresenting a performance metric in its wealth management business to investors. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) found that the bank misrepresented how it determined a new net assets metric, which helps investors gauge the bank's success in attracting new business. Former Credit Suisse executive Rolf Bogli, 52, also agreed to settle and pay US$80,000 for his role in the violations. The bank cooperated with the SEC and has since remedied the problems, with no allegations of intentional misconduct.

site_title: A human centric approach to designing the future workplace
summary: The concept of the future workplace is evolving to prioritize human-centric design, focusing on the well-being and productivity of employees, rather than just infrastructure and cost efficiency. This approach involves creating mixed-use projects with amenities, public spaces, and complementary businesses, promoting a holistic and inclusive ecosystem. The future workplace will be designed to support various needs, including private nooks for focus, and will prioritize sustainability, accessibility, and community engagement. By adopting a human-centric approach, employers can increase productivity, well-being, and job satisfaction, ultimately creating a better work environment for both employees and the surrounding community.

site_title: Price rebound for landed homes may exceed other residential types
summary: The landed property market in Singapore has shown a price rebound, exceeding other residential types. From Q3 2013 to August 2016, landed property prices fell by 17.4%, while non-landed prices declined by 4.6%. The market's reaction to market-changing forces is more pronounced, with a higher beta of over one compared to the URA Private Residential Property Price Index (PPI). This suggests that landed properties tend to outperform non-landed ones in both downturns and upturns. As a result, buyers of landed properties may see higher returns on investment, especially those who can afford to hold onto the properties during economic downturns.

site_title: ECs still popular among the sandwiched class
summary: Executive Condominiums (ECs) remain popular among the "sandwiched" class in Singapore, with steady demand despite competition from mass market condominiums and public housing. Since 2011, the government has released around 20,000 flats annually, while private condominiums have also seen abundant supply. ECs offer a full suite of condominium facilities, a lower price point (S$750-S$850 psf), and resale restrictions that allow buyers to sell to Singaporeans or SPR buyers after 5 years. Land developers are optimistic about the outlook for ECs, with 18 projects still available for sale in the market.

images.alt_text: Treasure Crest EC and Wandervale are two of the most successful EC launches since 2014.
Treasure Crest EC and Wandervale are two of the most successful EC launches since 2014.
The Terrace and Bellewaters which are among popular EC developments that have seen a steady stream of buyers.
The Terrace and Bellewaters which are among popular EC developments that have seen a steady stream of buyers.

site_title: FWD Singapore shows the way forward for insurers
summary: FWD Singapore, a new life and general insurer, aims to disrupt the sector with its predominantly digital business model. The company, part of Hong Kong businessman Richard Li's Pacific Century Group, plans to sell insurance products online instead of traditional methods. This shift aligns with rising online consumer behavior, where individuals increasingly buy goods and services online. If successful, FWD Singapore's digital approach could significantly impact the insurance industry.

site_title: MOH puts up fee schedules of private sector surgeons
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has published fee schedules for private sector surgeons, making treatment costs more transparent for patients.
