The list includes surgeon's fees, anaesthetist's fees, and facility costs for 141 procedures, compared to 65 in public hospitals. This move aims to enable patients to make informed decisions when choosing between public and private healthcare options. The list only includes institutions that performed at least 30 cases a year to ensure statistical significance.

site_title: Trikomsel bondholders to get shares in exchange for defaulted notes
summary: Trikomsel, Indonesia's mobile phone operator, has announced a debt restructuring plan to exchange defaulted bonds worth S$215 million for shares representing 25.5% of the parent company's total shareholding base. The exchange offer will be launched by the end of March 2017 and will be ratified by judges of the Jakarta Commercial Court. This move was approved by all known secured creditors and is expected to be completed by the end of June 2017.

site_title: MPA awards three firms S$8m in funds to defray costs of building LNG-powered vessels
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has announced a range of initiatives to propel the Port of Singapore into a cleaner-burning maritime future. The MPA has set aside S$8 million to co-fund the building of four ships that run on liquefied natural gas (LNG), and has also unveiled incentives such as waiving port dues for new LNG-fuelled harbour craft. Additionally, the MPA has signed a memorandum of understanding with SLNG to develop an interim truck-loading facility, and is working on a technical reference for bunkering standards in Singapore.

site_title: SGX helping to boost small-cap firms' outreach to investors
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has defended its track record in helping small-cap companies reach investors, with some firms performing well. SGX officials say a couple of tech listings are expected around year-end, and the exchange is actively helping small companies in Singapore and internationally. Despite challenges in the current market cycle, the level of interest in Catalist listings is increasing, with roughly a third of firms conducting secondary fund-raising every year.

site_title: Americans' anger against their elite could just make Trump's day
summary: Donald Trump's presidential campaign has defied expectations, despite his inflammatory comments and behavior. After being mocked by the media and GOP establishment, Trump's popularity surged in key battleground states, including Ohio, Florida, and Pennsylvania. His refusal to release tax returns and response to personal attacks by Clinton campaign led to a strong showing in the first presidential debate. New revelations of Trump's tax documents, showing significant financial losses, have sparked debate about his financial situation. Polls show a tight race between Trump and Clinton, with Trump maintaining a slim lead in some key states, leaving pundits questioning his chances of winning.

site_title: Pence succeeds in debate without really trying to defend Trump
summary: Mike Pence successfully defended himself in the vice-presidential debate against Tim Kaine, showcasing his preparation and calm demeanor. Pence largely avoided defending Donald Trump's controversial statements, instead focusing on Clinton's policies. The debate saw Pence take up a larger share of the conversation on Twitter and Facebook, with 48% of viewers saying he won the debate. However, the debate may not have significantly altered the presidential election dynamics, with both Pence and Kaine overshadowed by their unpopular running mates.

site_title: Germany needs to rethink trade surplus
summary: Germany is expected to generate the world's largest current account surplus this year, with a surplus of nearly $460 billion. This 10% higher than China's surplus and 9% of Germany's GDP. The surplus is a concern as it may lead to financial instability and is in contradiction to the principles of the Eurozone. To address the issue, Germany needs to boost domestic demand by increasing private and public investment, cutting taxes, and expanding public spending on infrastructure and education.

site_title: No skirting around diversity
summary: Singapore is pushing for greater diversity disclosure by the government and companies, with the government backing the move. The country aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025. Singapore is also exploring carbon offsetting legislation for airlines and introducing legislation for carbon offsetting in the aviation sector. Temasek's sustainability-aligned investments reached $46 billion in FY2025, with the company and other EV battery makers facing pressure to cut emissions.

site_title: Rising eurozone bond yields bolster euro
summary: The euro surged to a five-year peak against the pound and a three-week high against the yen, driven by rising eurozone government bond yields. Eurozone bond yields rose to two-week highs, prompting the euro to gain 0.4% against the yen and 0.2% against the dollar. The euro's rise was attributed to speculation that the European Central Bank may wind down its bond buying, despite an official denial. The euro's momentum is expected to continue in the near term, potentially narrowing the interest rate differential with the dollar.

site_title: Evergrande may well hold the key to China's IPO back door
summary: Evergrande, China's largest real estate developer by assets, is exploring a plan to inject equity into a property company listed in Shenzhen. This move could allow the company to raise equity in China without needing to go through the lengthy stock offering process. The plan comes as credit rating agencies warn Evergrande may not be able to pay its debts. The move could potentially lead to a flood of deals back home, as Asian investors view Evergrande as "too big to fail." This development may provide relief for the struggling company.

site_title: UPP to buy 58.34% stake in Canadian wood firm Taiga
summary: UPP Holdings, a Singapore-listed paper mill company, plans to buy a 58.34% stake in Canadian wood firm Taiga Building Products for C$18.9 million. UPP will also acquire some of Taiga's debt and buy 39.09% of the company from Berjaya Corporation. The deal is expected to be earnings accretive and expand UPP's geographical presence beyond Southeast Asia. The acquisition will be funded by a mix of cash and borrowings, with UPP also proposing to issue up to 837 million free warrants.

site_title: Reinventing Orchard Road amid the subdued retail climate
summary: Orchard Road, Singapore's iconic shopping belt, is facing a decline in popularity as consumer purchasing patterns shift towards e-commerce and suburban malls. Despite its iconic status, the area needs rebranding and repositioning to appeal to local shoppers and tourists. Initiatives such as Fashion Steps Out, Pedestrian Night, and Rev-Up@Orchard aim to revitalize the strip, but a collaborative approach by stakeholders is necessary. To attract tourists, Orchard Road can focus on tourist-friendly initiatives and product differentiation, leveraging local designers and experiential retail. With the rise of experiential retail, Orchard Road can spearhead the trend by integrating technology and offering a unique shopping experience.

site_title: Property agencies, agents keep exiting sector amid tough market
summary: Singapore's property agency sector continues to shrink amid a challenging domestic market. As of end-March 2016, the number of licensed property agencies decreased 3.5% to 1,372, while registered property agents fell 4.9% to 30,423. Many firms have stopped offering estate agency services, merged with others, or left the industry. Experts attribute this decline to increased professional requirements, technological disruptions, and low transaction volumes, which make it difficult for agents to sustain themselves. The situation is expected to worsen, with PropNex Realty CEO Ismail Gafoor predicting more agents will leave the industry next year.

site_title: Sime Darby's RM2.36b share placement oversubscribed
summary: Sime Darby's share placement to raise RM2.36 billion was oversubscribed, with demand worth RM6.2 billion. The 316.35 million shares were placed at RM7.45 each, a 3% discount to the five-day volume-weighted average share price. The proceeds will be used for debt repayment, capital expenditure, working capital, and placement expenses. This is the second-largest equity markets deal in South-east Asia this year, following Frasers Logistics' US$665 million initial public offering in Singapore.

site_title: High-end homes see price uptick
summary: Singapore's high-end homes in the Core Central Region (CCR) saw a 0.3% quarterly increase in prices in Q2 2016, marking the second consecutive quarter of growth after 11 quarters of decline. Total transaction volume of high-end homes increased by 31.3% year-over-year to 767 units, driven by realistic pricing and low prices. Foreigners, including ultra-high net worth individuals, continue to be drawn to Singapore, with a 33.5% share of CCR home purchases in Q2 2016. The market's growth is expected to spur interest in CCR properties, with potential buyers seeking "value-buy" properties.

site_title: Stability returning to suburban condominiums
summary: Singapore's suburban condominium market is showing signs of stability after years of decline, with the Outside Central Region (OCR) price index falling 8.4% since its peak in Q3 2013. Non-landed home prices in the OCR are decelerating, indicating stabilization in this market segment. Rental trends also indicate a slowdown, with rents in the OCR falling 1.2% quarter-over-quarter in Q2 2016. Strong sales of suburban condos, such as The Wisteria and Lake Grande, may continue to attract buyers, but the overall market is expected to remain under downward pressure due to cooling measures and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Criminals 'favour easy channels' to launder money
summary: Criminals favoring easy money laundering channels, particularly unlicensed money services businesses (MSBs) with lax "know your customer" (KYC) requirements, pose a significant threat to financial stability. Experts warn that these unlicensed MSBs enable illicit transactions, bringing a negative reputation to the sector. Authorities are working to combat this issue, but the ease of setting up such businesses highlights the need for stricter regulations to prevent money laundering.

site_title: 1MDB funds siphoned off under 'Ponzi' scheme
summary: A Swiss regulator has confirmed that 1MDB funds were siphoned off under a 'Ponzi' scheme, validating the claims made by Malaysian opposition lawmaker Tony Pua over a year and a half ago. The probe into Malaysia-govt-owned 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) is ongoing, with no further updates provided. This development marks a significant validation of Pua's accusations against the state-backed firm.

site_title: Maryland county tames suburban mess
summary: Montgomery County, Maryland, has transformed the suburban Rockville Pike thoroughfare through the Pike & Rose development, a $475 million project that combines apartments, retailers, offices, and public spaces. The project aims to create a walkable neighborhood with a mix of land uses, promoting smarter growth and reducing traffic. The White Flint Sector Plan, adopted six years ago, envisioned a 1.7-mile stretch of Rockville Pike with pedestrian-minded urban nodes, which is now being implemented through various development projects, including the addition of 5,000 residential units, 1.2 million sq ft of office space, and 1.6 million sq ft of retail space.

site_title: Price of curbing aviation pollution less than a glass of in-flight pinot noir
summary: The proposed United Nations accord to limit aviation pollution could cost airlines between $2.9 billion and $12.4 billion annually by 2030. Based on sample routes, this could add 31 cents to $12.10 per seat. Airlines estimate the measure would increase costs by 31 cents to $12.10 per seat, while the price for passengers may be less than an in-flight glass of pinot noir. The accord aims to reduce international flight emissions.

site_title: August trade deficit widens as services imports rise to record
summary: The US trade deficit widened in August, growing by 3% to $40.7 billion, driven by record purchases of services from abroad and a 1.2% rise in imports. Exports increased 0.8% to $187.9 billion, largely due to sales of consumer goods. The surge in services imports, largely related to the Olympic Games, provided a one-time boost that will disappear in September. Economists expect exports to pick up in the third quarter, supporting US growth.

site_title: Philippines to be second to China in growth in 2016: World Bank
summary: The World Bank has predicted that the Philippines will be the second-fastest-growing economy in the developing East Asian region in 2016, with a growth rate of 6.4%, alongside China. The country is expected to be followed by Vietnam and Indonesia. The report forecasts China's growth to slow to 6.5% in 2017 and 6.3% in 2018. The long-term challenge for the region is to sustain growth and make it more inclusive, with a focus on improving infrastructure, reducing child malnutrition, and harnessing technology to stimulate financial inclusion.

site_title: PM Lee lands in Udaipur after flight delayed by bad weather
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong arrived in Udaipur, India, after a delayed flight due to bad weather, forcing his plane to turn back to New Delhi. The 5-day trip includes attending the launch of the Centre of Excellence for Tourism Training. Lee had met with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi earlier, pledging cooperation in several key areas. The delay was attributed to "bad weather and poor visibility".

site_title: Asia's economic rise keeps pulling Americans west
summary: The US economic shift from the East Coast to the West Coast is attributed to the rise of Asia as a major economic power, making trade with the continent more cost-effective than with Europe. The invention of air conditioning, mass car ownership, and automation have contributed to the decline of US manufacturing in the Midwest. As trade costs decrease with proximity, cities and regions near Asia are experiencing economic growth, leading to population migration and investment shifts. California, Oregon, and Washington are expected to benefit from this trend, while the East Coast may focus on industries less sensitive to trade.

site_title: US prepaid debit card users to get federal protections
summary: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has announced new federal rules requiring prepaid debit card issuers to provide standardized disclosures of monthly fees and charges for cash withdrawals, customer service calls, and other activities. Starting in October 2017, prepaid cards must detail fees and charges, including liability protection up to $50 for lost or stolen cards. The rules aim to shed light on a product often criticized for high fees and poor disclosures, and are seen as stronger protections than those for traditional bank accounts.

site_title: Firms show interest in SriLankan Airlines
summary: Private equity firm TPG and investment company BlackRock Inc are among six firms showing interest in purchasing a 49% stake in SriLankan Airlines Ltd, a loss-making national carrier in Sri Lanka. The government aims to sell the stake along with management control as part of a broader restructuring effort to reduce support for state-owned firms and cut debt. This move is part of a broader strategy to restructure the airline and potentially turn it around.

site_title: Chi-X Japan poised to launch dark pool
summary: CHI-X Japan, a Tokyo-based share trading platform, is set to launch a dark pool called Kai-X on October 17, targeting institutional investors seeking to trade large blocks of shares anonymously. The move aims to capture market share from the Tokyo Stock Exchange amid increased volatility and thin liquidity. The dark pool will offer prices equal to or better than those on the TSE, with the goal of limiting information leakage and facilitating large block trades.

site_title: Property's place in investment portfolios
summary: Singapore's real estate sector is showing signs of stabilizing, despite market concerns. Research shows that Asians, particularly South Koreans, have a strong affinity for real estate investments, with housing and other properties making up 81% of household wealth. Luxury condominiums in prime districts and landed homes are expected to see price rebounds, with prices for luxury condos rising 0.3% in the second quarter. Investors may view this as an opportunity, rather than a crisis, with long-term fundamentals suggesting landed properties perform better.

site_title: Local assets under management rise 9% to S$2.6 trillion in 2015
summary: Singapore's asset management industry experienced a 9% growth in assets under management to S$2.6 trillion in 2015, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's 2015 survey. Despite turbulent markets, the industry benefited from its position in Asia and inflows into alternative strategies. The growth was driven by a combination of factors, including the industry's diversification and resilience to public market returns. The survey highlights the continued strength of the Singaporean asset management sector.

site_title: KepLand divests Myanmar hotel for US$41m
summary: Keppel Land is divesting its stake in Wiseland Investment, a Myanmar hospitality group, for US$41 million. Wiseland Investment owns and operates the 250-room Sedona Hotel Mandalay, which opened in 1997. The divestment is part of Keppel Land's strategy to focus on its core businesses. The transaction is expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Trio wins Nobel chemistry prize for 'world's smallest machines'
summary: Three scientists, Jean-Pierre Sauvage, J Fraser Stoddart, and Bernard Feringa, won the Nobel chemistry prize for developing molecular machines that can perform tasks with controllable movements. Their work may lead to new materials, sensors, and energy storage systems. The prize, worth 8 million Swedish crowns, was awarded for the discovery of the molecular motor, a concept similar to the electric motor in the 1830s. The scientists' work could revolutionize various fields, with Sauvage, Stoddart, and Feringa being recognized for their contributions to chemistry.

site_title: Narrowing gap between Grade A and B office buildings
summary: Singapore's office market saw a narrowing gap between Grade A and Grade B buildings due to weak demand and a looming supply wave. The rental premium between Grade A and Grade B buildings decreased to 24%, its lowest 10-year rate. Despite this, Grade A buildings remain highly sought after, with occupiers driven to "flight to quality" moves. Vacancy rates for Grade A buildings remain stable at 5.2%, while Grade B buildings face challenges to retain tenants due to limited demand. The market may return to growth beyond 2017, with the rental premium expected to widen to 30%.

site_title: Medium-term risks 'could hurt global financial stability'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of medium-term risks to global financial stability, citing a gradual slide into economic and financial stagnation. Commodity prices have risen, and emerging markets have supported a recovery in capital flows. However, financial institutions face cyclical and structural challenges, including weak profitability, low interest rates, and evolving market and regulatory environments. The IMF calls for deeper reforms and systemic management, particularly in European and Japanese banks, and urges policymakers to implement fiscal and structural policies to bolster confidence and raise global growth.

site_title: Indonesia's tax amnesty doesn't tackle the problem at its source
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty, launched in July, has collected over $7 billion in revenue, surpassing 90% of its 4,000 trillion rupiah target. However, critics argue the scheme doesn't address the root issue of tax evasion, with only 27 million of 255 million people registered as taxpayers. Detractors claim the program benefits wealthy individuals by allowing them to declare assets and pay penalties, but doesn't tackle the underlying concern of lack of confidence in Indonesia's legal system. The scheme's success should not lead to complacency, as deeper reforms are needed to create a conducive environment for local and foreign investment.

site_title: Will million-dollar HDB flats be the new norm?
summary: Singapore's public housing program, which has been a cornerstone of the country's asset ownership program, has seen a rise in million-dollar HDB flats. However, there is no reason for buyers to be alarmed, as these units are rare and primarily driven by market forces. The government has implemented cooling measures, such as the Mortgage Servicing Ratio and Total Debt Servicing Ratio, to regulate prices. The trend is largely driven by buyers' willingness to pay for high-end flats in desirable locations, rather than a sign of uncontrolled housing prices.

site_title: Dead end for central banks' policies, political help needed
summary: Central banks face a dead-end situation with their current policies, causing damage to banks, pension funds, and capitalism. Negative interest rates have led to bloated balance sheets and uncomfortable positions in financial markets. The Bank of Japan's initiative to keep Japanese government bond yields below zero threatens to make markets artificial. Central banks risk destroying markets if they continue to dominate them, stifling independent opinion and signals. To escape this predicament, central banks need to work together, adopt a more balanced approach, and receive international recognition that monetary policy cannot carry the burden of reviving economies alone.

site_title: Singapore notching up credentials for global innovation
summary: Singapore is emerging as a global innovation hub, particularly in trade finance and payments, thanks to its business-friendly environment and government support. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has been a key driver in fostering cooperation between companies and investors, and has introduced guidelines for cloud-based treasury tools. HSBC's Innovation Lab in Singapore is partnering with software companies to develop cloud-based treasury management solutions, and has also announced a blockchain-based prototype solution to streamline trade transactions. The country's expertise in global trade and innovation is recognized globally, solidifying its reputation as a trade and treasury entrepôt.

site_title: Keppel Singmarine bags deals for two LNG-fuelled tugs
summary: Keppel Singmarine, a subsidiary of Keppel Offshore & Marine, has secured contracts to build two LNG-fuelled harbour tugs as part of Singapore's LNG bunkering pilot programme. The tugs, expected to be completed by 2018, will use bunkering services from FueLNG, a Keppel Corporation joint venture with Royal Dutch Shell. The project aims to promote the use of LNG as a cleaner alternative to traditional fossil fuels in Singapore's port operations.

site_title: Small car COE premium rises
summary: The certificate of entitlement (COE) premium for small cars in Singapore rose in October's first round of bidding. Category A premiums increased to S$51,507, while Category E slipped to S$54,200. In contrast, Category B and Cat B premiums fell to S$53,001 and S$54,200, respectively. The unexpected increase in premiums has surprised car dealers, despite a slowing economy. The COE premium for small cars is now at its highest level since January 2020.

site_title: Govt backs push for diversity disclosure
summary: Singapore's government supports the Diversity Action Committee's call for companies to report on diversity policies and targets. Minister Tan Chuan-Jin stated that failing to disclose this information could harm the country's reputation and edge. The DAC's recommendations do not prescribe quotas, but instead encourages companies to publicly address diversity issues. Stronger regulatory action may be taken if progress is lacking, aiming to push Singapore-listed companies to improve diversity without imposing quotas.

site_title: JPMorgan may be biggest arranger of Middle East bond deals
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is poised to surpass HSBC Holdings plc as the biggest arranger of Middle East bond deals, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The New York-based bank topped the league table at the end of the third quarter, driven by governments and companies in the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) borrowing more and attracting American investors. This marks a shift after HSBC held the top spot for nine years, and JPMorgan's success is attributed to the increasing demand for bond issues in the region.

site_title: US factory orders increase slightly in August
summary: US factory orders increased slightly in August, rising 0.2% after a downwardly revised 1.4% increase in July. This marks the second straight monthly increase following two months of weakness. Economists had forecast a decline, but the data suggests the manufacturing sector is beginning to regain some steam. Core capital goods shipments, a measure of business confidence, edged down 0.1% in August, while inventories rose 0.2%. The rebound is seen as a positive sign for the economy, which has been hampered by weak global demand and a strong dollar.

site_title: The impact of fintech on real estate (Amended)
summary: Fintech firms are disrupting the traditional banking industry, generating demand for startup hub space and potentially affecting the office footprint of traditional banks. In Singapore, fintech is gaining traction due to supportive government policies and significant venture-capital backing. Major banks are setting up in-house fintech labs to collaborate with startups, while fintechs are congregating around hubs that provide a solid startup ecosystem. This trend is expected to lead to a significant downsizing in the banking sector's office occupancy, with a potential reduction of 904,000 sq ft of office space in Singapore's CBD.

site_title: United Engineers, OUE in play on stake talk
summary: Singaporean developer OUE has denied involvement in discussions to buy a stake in United Engineers (UE), despite UE's shares rising 3.2% on Wednesday. UE shares have been rallying on speculation that OCBC Bank and Great Eastern Holdings may sell their stakes. OUE has not ruled out a potential deal, stating it will make an announcement if a definitive agreement is reached. Both companies' shares have seen significant price movements in recent weeks.

site_title: Househunt October 2016
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article does not appear to be about a specific event or date, but rather a collection of news articles from October 2016. However, a few key points can be extracted: US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, and China urged South-east Asia to back openness amid US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Additionally, Reliance Jio, led by Ambani, delayed its India IPO beyond this year. The article does not contain any information from the specified date of October 5, 2016.

site_title: A record US$152 trillion in global debt unnerves IMF officials
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that the world is experiencing a debt hangover of unprecedented proportions, with global debt reaching a record $152 trillion, or 225% of world gross domestic product. This has led to slow global growth, making it difficult to pay off obligations, and poses a risk to financial stability. The IMF urges governments to use fiscal policy to boost growth, while also advising central banks to be cautious of the risks associated with private debt.

site_title: UPP plans to buy stake in Canadian firm linked to director
summary: UPP Holdings plans to buy a 58.3% stake in Canadian wood products manufacturer Taiga Building Products for C$18.9 million, with 19.3% held by director Tong Kooi Ong. UPP also intends to spend C$52.9 million on Taiga's unsecured subordinated notes. The acquisition is part of UPP's expansion plans.

site_title: Who'll benefit from new MRT stations?
summary: New MRT stations are expected to benefit private residential properties near them, particularly those within walking distance. A study found that properties near MRT stations see a 6.3% increase in value and an additional 4% premium for properties near interchange stations. The upcoming Downtown Line Stage 3 and Thomson-East Coast Line are expected to boost prices in areas like Changi Court, Changi Green, and Tropicana. Landed homes in Ang Mo Kio, Bishan, and Yio Chu Kang are also likely to benefit from the new lines, while River Valley and districts 15 and 16 are expected to see increased demand.

site_title: Taking a critical look at the images of colonialism
summary: The National Gallery Singapore (NGS) has launched a new exhibition, "Artist and Empire: (En)Countering Colonial Legacies," which challenges the traditional narrative of colonialism and its impact on art. The show, which runs until March 26, 2017, features over 200 works, including contemporary art responses to colonialism by artists from Asia-Pacific countries. The exhibition critically examines the colonial experience and its legacy, with works on loan from the Tate Britain show, and includes commissioned pieces by Singapore artists Erika Tan and Wong Hoy Cheong. The show aims to encourage viewers to re-examine Singapore's identity and place in relation to its colonial past.

site_title: Oil surges over 2% to June highs on another US crude draw
summary: US oil prices surged to June highs, rising 2% to $52.09 per barrel, after the US Energy Information Administration reported a surprise weekly drawdown of 3 million barrels in crude inventories. This marks the fifth straight weekly decline and surpasses forecasted build of 2.6 million barrels. Analysts predict prices may ease lower, despite the recent rally.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.85 points to 2,881.79, down 0.1%, amid concerns of central bank tightening. Despite this, the overall market saw a slight gain, with 236 gainers outnumbering 169 losers. Noble Group rose the most, followed by Ezra Holdings and Addvalue Technologies.

site_title: STI dips amid monetary tightening fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% on Wednesday, with the benchmark index closing at 2,881.79 points, despite the broader market showing a gain of 236 to 169 gainers to losers. The decline was attributed to fears of central bank tightening, particularly from the European Central Bank's potential tapering of quantitative easing and the US Federal Reserve's possible interest-rate hike. This sentiment led to a shift in investor focus towards penny stocks and commodity traders, with Noble Group rising 0.008 to S$0.178.

site_title: US trade deficit rises helped by huge Olympics payment
summary: The US trade deficit rose to $40.7 billion in August, driven by a surge in gold exports and a payment for Olympics broadcast rights, which increased foreign charges by 38%. Exports rose 1.2% to $185.7 billion, while imports were up 0.8% at $227.4 billion. Despite a slow global economy, the deficit remains close to recent lows, with the first eight months of the year showing a deficit of $330.7 billion, 1.3% below the same period in 2015.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises as oil drives energy shares
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by a 1.9% increase in oil prices to $51.84, supported by a decline in US inventories and Opec's supply cut deal. The ADP National Employment report showed 154,000 jobs added in September, below expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.47% to 18,253.26, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose 0.37% and 0.33%, respectively. Energy shares led the gains, with Exxon Mobil and Chevron rising 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively.

site_title: Audi labour boss wants job guarantee for German workers
summary: Audi's labor boss, Peter Mosch, urged the company's top management to build more electric models in Germany and extend a job guarantee for its 60,000 workers beyond 2018. Mosch emphasized the importance of job security during challenging times. Audi's plans to build its first mass-produced electric model, e-tron quattro, in Brussels, Belgium, contradicts this request. The employment guarantees are set to expire in 2018, prompting concerns about job security for German workers.

site_title: The case for private investment in S'pore's industrial properties (Amended)
summary: Singapore's industrial property market has faced stringent government policies since 2013, curbing speculative behavior and moderating prices. However, this has limited investment and development opportunities for private developers. The government's revised sub-letting policy and lease assignment rules have restricted regeneration prospects. Private developers can now team up with end-users to propose innovative industrial space solutions and seek lease flexibility options for government-owned leases. A strategy to acquire longer tenure or freehold private industrial properties may be viable for private owners with a long-term investment horizon, while experienced property advisers can help forge winning partnerships between the public and private sectors.

site_title: EU plans insolvency early warning alerts to cut banks' bad loans
summary: The European Commission proposes an early warning system to alert companies at risk of insolvency, aiming to cut the region's bankruptcy problem and help banks recoup bad loans. Non-performing loans (NPLs) on eurozone lenders' balance sheets reached nearly $1.5 trillion, or 9% of the bloc's GDP. The system, central to the proposal, is expected to improve banks' ability to make money on corporate lending. The draft proposal seeks to address the significant NPL issue affecting eurozone lenders, a problem that has been growing in recent years.

site_title: CapitaLand to have 6 malls in India by 2019
summary: CapitaLand plans to open two more malls in India by 2019, bringing the total to six operational malls. The upcoming malls are Forum, Mysore, and Forum, Cochin. The company's serviced apartment arm, The Ascott, has secured a contract to manage three new properties. CapitaLand's group CEO, Lim Ming Yan, attributed India's strong demand for quality real estate to rapid urbanization and foreign direct investment. The company is also in discussions for management contracts for shopping malls and serviced residences in key cities.

site_title: Trikomsel bondholders to get shares in exchange for defaulted notes
summary: Trikomsel, an Indonesian mobile phone operator, has agreed to exchange defaulted notes worth S$215 million for shares. The shares will be worth 327.4 rupiah each, representing 25.5% of the total shareholding base. The exchange is part of a capital injection plan, which includes a US$10.5 million injection by March 2017. The defaulted bonds were due 2016 and 2017, with coupon rates of 5.25% and 7.875% respectively.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure unit wins US$26.7m contract from China waste-to-energy plant
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings won a US$26.7 million contract to provide technology and services for the expansion of the Baoan waste-to-energy plant in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, China. The contract, awarded to Shenzhen Energy Environment Engineering, includes equipment design and technical services for furnace and boiler components, with completion expected by 2018.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Infrastructure Holdings said on Wednesday it has secured a US$26.7 million contract to provide technology and services to the Baoan waste-to-energy plant in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, China. The contract was secured through its wholly owned unit, Keppel Seghers Belgium.

site_title: Irish passport applications from Britons double since Brexit
summary: Irish passport applications from British citizens have almost doubled since the June 2016 Brexit vote, with 21,500 applications received since July, compared to 11,000 in the same period last year. Applications have increased each month and rose 120% year-on-year in September. This surge is driven by Britons seeking to hold onto EU citizenship via an Irish passport, with registrations in Northern Ireland also rising by 68% over the same three-month period.

site_title: China Jinjiang to buy two companies from controlling shareholder for 439m yuan
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding, a waste-to-energy company, announced it would buy two companies linked to its controlling shareholder, Zhejiang Zhuji Bafang Thermal Power and Wenling Green New Energy Co Ltd, for 439 million yuan. The acquisitions, funded by its initial public offering, will be completed by the end of the year. The deal is aimed at expanding the company's business and increasing its revenue.

site_title: FCA gets final report into RBS small business restructuring division
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has received the long-delayed final report on alleged malpractice at Royal Bank of Scotland's small business restructuring division. The report, commissioned by Promontory Financial Group and Mazars, investigates RBS's treatment of business customers in difficulty before and during the 2008 financial crisis. The FCA has not specified a publication date for the findings, which have been contested by RBS, which claims the GRG unit did not deliberately push small businesses to bankruptcy. The report's cost to the bank is estimated to be in billions of pounds.

site_title: McDonald's nears deal to sell Singapore, Malaysian franchise to Saudi group: sources
summary: McDonald's is set to sell its 20-year franchise rights for Singapore and Malaysia outlets to Saudi Arabia's Reza group for up to $400 million. This deal is part of McDonald's re-jigged Asian business strategy, shifting towards a less capital-intensive franchise model. The transaction has been facilitated by Malaysian bank CIMB, and Reza Food Services Co Ltd will operate the McDonald's restaurants in western and southern Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Kerry urges Taliban to reach peace with Kabul
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry urged the Taliban to reach a peace deal with the Kabul government, citing a recent example of warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar's peace agreement as a model. Kerry stated that a peace deal would allow the Taliban to achieve their goal of expelling foreign forces from Afghanistan, which they had been fighting against since a US-led invasion 15 years ago. He emphasized that a political settlement is the only way to end the fighting and achieve lasting stability.

site_title: Japan still needs to raise sales tax, economy minister says
summary: Japan's economy minister, Nobuteru Ishihara, stated that the country will eventually need to raise its sales tax to help cover rising social security costs in an aging society. The current 8% tax will not be sufficient, and Ishihara suggested increasing it to 12%, 13%, or 15% in gradual steps, requiring public approval through an election. This move aims to address persistent fiscal deficits and fund a social safety net, similar to developed European countries.

site_title: May takes swipe at business, saying 'this can't go on anymore'
summary: Theresa May criticized British business leaders, saying "change has got to come" to address abusive work practices and unpaid taxes. At the Conservative Party conference, she portrayed the June Brexit vote as a call for change in the country's work culture. May warned bosses who exploit staff, companies that don't pay taxes, and those who refuse to work with authorities, stating "this can't go on anymore." The pound has fallen to a 31-year low, and economists predict a "hard Brexit" could harm the finance industry.

site_title: Heeton divests iLiv@Grange en-bloc
summary: Heeton Holdings has divested its entire interest in the completed iLiv@Grange project for S$95 million, valuing the 16-storey project at S$1,623 per square foot. The sale includes 30 units and two penthouses, with 20 units leased at an average gross monthly rental of S$3.50 per square foot. The buyer group, led by Straits Trading's Chew Gek Khim and KSH Holdings' Choo Chee Onn, invested S$4 million in junior notes and S$4 million in ordinary shares. The transaction results in a loss for Heeton for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, rising 1.670 points to 1,662.920. Volume reached 1.626 billion lots worth RM2.156 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 477 to 288.

site_title: Millennials suffer worst fallout from economic crisis, OECD says
summary: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has reported that young people, particularly those under 30, have borne the worst fallout from the global economic crisis. Since 2007, nearly one in 10 jobs held by workers under 30 in developed countries were destroyed, with the recovery failing to significantly improve their job prospects. This trend has disproportionately affected young people, with the OECD stating that the job losses hit them "hard" and the recovery has been too weak to improve their prospects.

site_title: OKH Global appoints Lock Wai Han as CEO
summary: OKH Global has appointed 49-year-old Lock Wai Han as CEO, replacing Celine Tang, effective October 5. Lock was formerly director at the Singapore Police Force and CEO of CapitaMalls Asia (China). He will serve alongside Celine Tang on the board as non-executive chairman.

site_title: Insurer Sompo to buy Endurance Specialty for US$6.3b
summary: Japanese insurer Sompo Holdings Inc will buy US casualty insurer Endurance Specialty Holdings Ltd for $6.3 billion, its second-largest acquisition. The deal, valued at 40.3% premium, aims to expand Sompo's US foothold and offer specialized insurance products in the domestic market. Endurance's management will remain in place, and the deal is expected to benefit Sompo in the long term, with synergies emerging from bringing in insurance know-how.

site_title: UK car sales rise 1.6% in September to hit new record
summary: UK car sales rose 1.6% in September to a new record, with 469,696 units registered, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. This marks the sixth consecutive month of sales decline to individual customers, but strong demand from business buyers offset the drop. The Brexit vote's impact on the market is still unclear, with many purchases made months in advance. Industry chief Mike Hawes attributed the record demand to the government's ability to address consumer appetite despite ongoing uncertainty.

site_title: Euro makes broad gains, rises to 5-year high against sterling
summary: The euro surged to a 5-year high against the sterling, reaching 88.31 pence, and a 3-week high against the yen at 115.545 yen, driven by rising euro zone government bond yields. The euro also rose 0.2% against the US dollar. The euro's gain was attributed to speculation that the European Central Bank (ECB) may slow down its bond buying, contrary to earlier statements.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's assets under management grew 9% to S$2.6 trillion in 2015, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore report. The COE premium for small cars rose despite economic contraction, while Keppel Land divested its stake in Sedona Hotel Mandalay for US$41 million. MPA unveiled initiatives to reduce shipping emissions, and Keppel O&M secured contracts for two LNG harbour tugs. Singapore shares closed 0.1% down, and the country is exploring opportunities in sustainable aviation and advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Markets price in more easing by Indian central bank, see risk in policy shift
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has cut its policy rate by 25 basis points and lowered its real interest rate target to 1.25% under new governor Urjit Patel, indicating a shift towards greater tolerance of higher inflation. This move has prompted markets to price in another rate cut, as the RBI gave itself more room to cut rates further. The RBI also softened its stance on meeting its inflation target, setting it until 2021.

site_title: Powerful typhoon Chaba barrels toward Japan
summary: A powerful typhoon, Chaba, is heading towards Japan, packing gusts of up to 180 km/h, with warnings issued for gusts, heavy rains, and floods. The storm hit South Korea, causing flash floods, power outages, and at least two deaths. Japan's weather agency has issued warnings for western Japan, with domestic flights cancelled and thousands of homes affected. The storm is expected to hit Japan's main island on Wednesday evening and move out into the Pacific on Thursday.

site_title: Weaker growth in German private sector highlights slowdown risk: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector experienced weaker growth in September, with the PMI index falling to 52.8 from 53.3 in August. The services sector, which accounts for more than two-thirds of the economy, showed near-stagnation, with a PMI index of 50.9. Despite this, manufacturing remained robust, and service providers continued to hire staff. The data highlights a risk of a slowdown in the second half of the year, despite a predicted 1.9% growth rate for 2016, driven by private consumption and migrant spending.

site_title: UK services growth casts doubt on BoE rate cut prospects: PMI
summary: The UK services sector grew more strongly than expected in September, with a PMI reading of 52.6, higher than the median forecast of 52.0. This reading suggests the economy is growing at a quarterly rate of about 0.3%, casting doubt on the need for a Bank of England interest rate cut. The solid PMI readings for September and earlier this week's manufacturing and construction surveys further confound predictions that the Brexit vote would deliver a rapid blow to the economy. The chances of a British recession have "all but evaporated".

site_title: Nokia buys base station energy solutions start-up
summary: Nokia has acquired Eta Devices, a US-based start-up specializing in power amplifier efficiency solutions for network base stations. The deal aims to enhance Nokia's push to improve base station energy efficiency, a key area for operators transitioning to 4.9G and 5G networks. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: Switzerland asks Malaysia again for help with 1MDB case
summary: Swiss prosecutors have asked Malaysia for a second time to help gather evidence in the 1MDB case, which involves embezzlement of $800 million from a Malaysian sovereign fund. The case is linked to a Ponzi scheme and a total of $3.5 billion diverted from 1MDB. US prosecutors have also filed a request to seize $1 billion in assets in California, and Malaysia is set to seize $3 billion of assets belonging to Daim Zainuddin. The investigation is ongoing, with Swiss, Singaporean, and US authorities working together to uncover the truth behind the embezzlement.

site_title: Sharp sterling decline could affect rates: BoE's Broadbent
summary: Bank of England deputy governor Ben Broadbent stated that if sterling's decline is sharp enough, the central bank may raise interest rates. However, the decline since the June referendum has been "pretty orderly" and reflects markets' long-term judgments about Britain's economy. Sterling reached a 31-year low against the dollar following the UK's announcement of formal EU exit talks in 2017.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England could raise interest rates is sterling fell sharply enough, but so far its moves have orderly, Bank of England deputy governor Ben Broadbent said on Wednesday.

site_title: Eurozone business growth lost more momentum in Sept: PMI
summary: The Eurozone's business activity expanded at its weakest rate since 2015, with the PMI index falling to 52.6 in September. This marks a loss of momentum for the economy, which is attributed to growing caution about the economic outlook and political uncertainty. The service industry saw a decline in growth, and firms took on fewer new workers, with the employment sub-index reaching a five-month low. This weakening growth may concern policymakers, particularly as inflation remains below the ECB's target of 2%.

images.alt_text: Eurozone business activity expanded at its weakest rate since the beginning of 2015 last month, according to a survey providing the latest evidence the bloc's economy is losing momentum.

site_title: Hyundai Merchant Marine to turn Hanjin substitute route into regular service
summary: Hyundai Merchant Marine Co Ltd plans to turn its Asia-US route into a regular weekly service, starting Oct 14, utilizing five container ships with capacities between 4,000-6,000 TEU. The new route, initially offered as an alternative to Hanjin Shipping's services, aims to increase market share and strengthen competitive ability on Asia-US routes.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 2-week low, stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won closed at a two-week low of 1,113.7 to the US dollar, marking its fifth straight session of losses, due to growing Brexit worries. This is the lowest closing level since September 21. Meanwhile, South Korean shares were flat, closing down 0.1% at 2,053.00 points.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on ECB concerns, Tesco soars
summary: European shares fell 0.9% on Wednesday due to concerns over the ECB's bond buying program, while Tesco rose 7% after a well-received earnings update. The Stoxx 600 remains down 6% for the year. Other market movers included Delta Lloyd's 28% surge and telecoms group SFR's 6.4% drop after a market watchdog blocked an all-share buyout offer.

site_title: "Why are we doing what we are doing?"
summary: A group photography exhibition by seven contemporary artists explores the creative process, questioning technical and subject matter aspects. The exhibition features artists from Indonesia, Japan, and Singapore, discussing the shift in photography due to rapid technological advancements, such as smartphone cameras and instant screen views. The event aims to spark discussion on the future of photography and its creative process.

images.alt_text: A photograph from Agan Harahap's Vakantie in Indonesie (Holiday in Indonesia) series.

site_title: Top forecaster says gold may snap back on global political risks
summary: A top forecaster, Barnabas Gan, believes gold prices may rebound due to looming global risks. The US presidential election and Britain's potential exit from the EU could boost gold's role as a safe-haven asset. Additionally, increasing US shale oil output may curb crude prices and inflation, further supporting gold prices.

site_title: Keppel Land divests Sedona Hotel Mandalay
summary: Keppel Land has entered into a conditional sales and purchase agreement to divest its entire stake in Wiseland Investment (Myanmar) - which owns Sedona Hotel Mandalay - to Eden Hotels and Resort Co for US$41 million. The divestment is in line with Keppel Land's strategy to recycle capital for higher returns. The 250-room Sedona Hotel Mandalay, opened in 1997, will be sold after Keppel Land's first foray into Myanmar in 1993, with a focus on pursuing other opportunities in Yangon.

site_title: ECB lowers emergency funding cap for Greek banks to 51.8b euros
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered the emergency funding cap for Greek banks from €2 billion to €51.8 billion, as liquidity conditions improve and private sector deposit flows stabilize. This move reflects the ECB's efforts to reduce Greek banks' dependence on the emergency liquidity assistance (ELA) since February 2015. The ELA ceiling is valid until October 20.

site_title: Fed may face makeover whether Trump or Clinton wins White House
summary: The Federal Reserve may undergo a shakeup regardless of who wins the 2016 US presidential election, with Hillary Clinton seen as less likely to demand radical change than Donald Trump. Trump has expressed his desire to nominate a non-traditional candidate to lead the Fed, while Clinton would likely keep the status quo. The Fed's leadership, including Chair Janet Yellen, will expire in 2018, creating uncertainty over potential appointments. Legislative changes to the Fed are also possible, but would require bipartisan support or a single-party sweep of Congress.

site_title: Prada, Ralph Lauren lose ground in brand ranking as tech rules
summary: Fashion labels Prada and Ralph Lauren have lost ground in brand ranking due to a slowdown in demand from China, according to Interbrand's 17th annual survey. Prada dropped to 81st place, while Ralph Lauren fell to 98th. Luxury brands such as Hugo Boss also declined, with the company falling out of the top 100. The survey highlights the impact of global economic changes and shifting consumer preferences on the fashion industry.

site_title: Spain's services sector continues solid expansion in Sept: PMI
summary: Spain's services sector maintained a solid pace of growth in September, with a PMI of 54.7, down from 56 in August but above the 50 mark for the 35th consecutive month. The expansion was largely driven by an increase in new business, with new orders rising at a faster pace than in August. This growth is seen as a positive sign for the economy, which has shown few signs of being hurt by the lack of leadership since inconclusive elections in December and June.

site_title: China invests 500m yuan in public-private partnerships: Xinhua
summary: China has invested 500 million yuan in public-private partnerships (PPP) this year, supporting 703 projects totaling 1.2 trillion yuan in various sectors, including energy, transportation, and environmental protection. This move aims to alleviate local authorities' debt burden by luring private capital into infrastructure projects. The funding is part of the government's efforts to promote PPPs, which are seen as a key strategy for China's economic development.

site_title: Air Berlin in talks to merge tourist unit with TUIfly
summary: Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, is in talks to merge its tourist business with TUIfly, a move aimed at expanding long-haul flights and attracting higher-paying customers. The airline, which has made a net loss in seven of the last eight years, plans to discuss the combination of 35 aircraft with major shareholder Etihad and TUI. The move is part of a broader restructuring effort that could halve the airline's fleet and cut 1,000 jobs. The prospective transaction will be subject to corporate and regulatory approvals.

site_title: Small car COE premium rises as other categories slip
summary: The certificate of entitlement (COE) premium for small cars in Singapore increased by S$1,507 to S$51,507, despite a contracting economy. Category A, which includes cars below 1,600cc and 130hp, rose, while Category B, which includes cars above 1,600cc or 130hp, fell. The open category, Cat E, also decreased. These changes are in contrast to Category C and D, which saw lower premiums for goods vehicles and motorcycles.

site_title: Hong Kong activist deported from Thailand 'at China's request'
summary: Hong Kong democracy activist Joshua Wong was deported from Thailand after being held at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi airport, with supporters blaming China for his detention. Wong, 19, was due to speak at events commemorating a 1976 student massacre, but was instead put on a flight back to Hong Kong. Thailand's military government is suspected of acting under pressure from China, which has lavished investment and diplomatic support on the junta. Wong's detention is seen as a blow to Thailand's pro-democracy movement, with experts warning it will attract global attention and send a signal that Thailand's space is not open.

site_title: Taiwan detains ex-head of bank linked to Panama Papers
summary: Taiwan has detained former head of Mega International Commercial Bank, McKinney Tsai, and his top aide, Wang Chi Pang, on suspicion of violating banking and securities laws. The arrests follow a US fine of $180 million on the bank for "suspicious transactions" between its New York and Panama branches. Tsai was accused of insider trading and failing to fulfill his duties as head of the bank before the fine was announced. The detentions mark the first for Mega Bank officials linked to the Panama Papers scandal.

site_title: MPA unveils initiatives to move Singapore towards greener maritime future
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has launched initiatives to reduce shipping emissions. The authority will waive five years of port dues for new vessels fuelled by liquefied natural gas (LNG) and grant additional concessions for vessels that use LNG-fuelled harbour craft. MPA has also awarded funding for LNG-fuelled vessels and expanded its international focus group on LNG bunkering. The move aims to move Singapore towards a greener maritime future.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up as exporters lifted by weak yen
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.50% to 16,819.24, driven by a weak yen, which benefits Japan's exporters. The US dollar strengthened against the yen, lifting expectations for a US interest rate hike. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index advanced 83.59 points, while the Topix index gained 7.60 points. The positive move was attributed to a stronger US currency, which is expected to boost profits for Japanese exporters.

site_title: Oil major BP buys first Iranian oil since lifting of sanctions
summary: Iran's state-owned oil company, National Iranian Oil Co (Nioc), sold natural gas condensate to BP Plc for the first time since sanctions were lifted in January, marking the country's re-emergence as a major oil supplier. The deal, valued at an undisclosed amount, will be supplied to BP between September and October. This milestone comes as Iran aims to restore its crude oil output to pre-sanctions levels and wean itself off imported oil products. The sale is a significant step for Opec's third-largest producer, which has been ravaged by sanctions targeting its nuclear program.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall tracking overseas markets; financials, techs down
summary: Taiwan's stocks declined 0.3% on Wednesday, tracking overseas market falls, with financials and technology sectors leading the drop. The main Taiex index closed at 9,255.96, down from a 0.6% gain in the previous session. The electronics subindex fell 0.4% and the financials subindex lost 0.3%. The decline was attributed to cautious trading.

site_title: Hitachi said to eye stake sale in US$1.9b Kokusai unit
summary: Hitachi Ltd is considering selling its 50% stake in Hitachi Kokusai Electric Inc for approximately US$1.9 billion. The decision is part of Hitachi's strategy to review its portfolio amid a slowdown in demand from China and low oil prices. Hitachi Kokusai's shares rose 6.2% after the news, with analysts citing the company's superior technology and attractive value. The sale could lead to a takeover of the entire unit, with several international firms expressing interest. Hitachi has set a deadline for stake sales in early 2017, with no decision yet made.

site_title: Formula One: Ricciardo aiming to 'kick ass' in Japan
summary: Daniel Ricciardo aims to "kick ass" in Japan, a week after his win in Malaysia, where he celebrated by drinking champagne from his sweaty sneaker and offering it to Nico Rosberg. Despite Rosberg's apparent distaste, Ricciardo believes Red Bull can still pose a threat to Mercedes, particularly with rain forecast for the Suzuka race. Ricciardo acknowledges the emotional weight of the Japanese Grand Prix after Jules Bianchi's death in 2014, but says the team is prepared to block out emotions and focus on the race.

site_title: Hot stock: United Engineers up 3.2% to S$2.61
summary: United Engineers rose 3.2% to S$2.61 after trading over 2 million shares worth S$5.5 million. The firm has been pursued by OUE Ltd, backed by Riady, and OCBC Bank and Great Eastern Holdings are reviewing their stakes. The Singapore Exchange queried the firm on its trading activity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise, outperforming regional peers
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.4% to 23,788.31 points, outperforming regional peers, driven by energy shares after an overnight surge in oil prices and short covering. The China Enterprises Index gained 0.6%, while the MSCI's Asia-Pacific index fell 0.3%. Hong Kong property stocks declined, with China Resources Land easing 0.5% and China Overseas Land rising nearly 1%. The decline in Hong Kong property stocks was partly due to concern over a weakening Chinese currency and new home price restrictions in Shenzhen.

site_title: OUE: No ongoing talks on United Engineers, will announce if buying
summary: Developer OUE has stated there are no ongoing talks about buying United Engineers (UE), despite a Bloomberg report on its interest. OUE will make an announcement if a definitive agreement is reached to purchase shares in UE. The company's shares rallied 4% after the report, while UE's shares rose 7 cents to S$2.60. OUE's shares were down a cent before a trading halt for its latest announcement, which will be lifted at 12pm.

site_title: Voting for UN chief moves to key stage with Guterres top pick
summary: The UN Security Council is set to cast a sixth secret ballot on Wednesday to determine whether former Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Guterres will be the next UN Secretary-General. Guterres has come out on top in five closed-door polls, but a late entry by European Commissioner Kristalina Georgieva could pose a threat to his bid. The five veto powers will cast ballots with the choices of "encourage", "discourage", or "no opinion", while the other council members will remain anonymous. A consensus candidate is needed for a formal vote, which requires nine votes in favor and no vetoes.

site_title: North Korea embassy official defects in Beijing: report
summary: A North Korean embassy official in Beijing has defected, according to South Korea's Yonhap news agency, with the official responsible for sourcing medical supplies for North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un's family. This is the latest in a series of high-profile North Korean defections, which observers see as a sign of growing instability within the leadership in Pyongyang. South Korea's Unification Ministry has not confirmed the report, while Japan's government has denied reports of North Korean asylum seekers contacting the Japanese mission.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby says RM2.36b share placement is oversubscribed
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Bhd announced its share placement, raising RM2.36 billion (S$780.6 million), was oversubscribed due to strong demand from institutional investors. The 316.35 million shares were placed at 7.45 ringgit each, a 3% discount to the five-day volume weighted average share price. The proceeds will be used for debt repayment, capital expenditure, working capital, and placement expenses. The company's shares rose 2.2% to 7.78 ringgit following the announcement.

site_title: Trade war over trees looms as Canada, US remain at impasse
summary: Canada and the US are at an impasse in their softwood lumber dispute, with the US threatening to impose tariffs of up to 30% on Canadian producers. The dispute has been simmering for decades, with the US claiming Canada gives producers access to cheap timber on government land. The two countries have until October 12 to reach a new agreement, or the US can file new trade cases against Canadian imports. The dispute is expected to lead to mill closures, job losses, and volatility in the lumber market, with Canadian companies facing significant losses.

images.alt_text: Canada and the US are gearing up for another fight over trees.

site_title: Australia ends lower on ECB worries; NZ limps
summary: Australian shares fell 0.57% on Wednesday, with mining stocks declining due to commodity price drops. Investor confidence was also affected by a report of the European Central Bank's bond buying program withdrawal, although this was denied. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,452.9 points, down 31.1 points.

site_title: Nets IPO disappointment has investors raising doubts on pricing
summary: Nets A/S, a Nordic payments firm, has faced investor criticism over its initial public offering (IPO) valuation. The company was valued at $4.5 billion, but its shares initially rose 4.7% on the first day before closing 3.3% down. Investors had expected a post-IPO bump, which was not seen, leading to doubts on the pricing. The Danish Shareholders Association has expressed disappointment with the lack of a post-IPO increase.

site_title: Gold price plunge spurs CNMC Goldmine selloff
summary: CNMC Goldmine, a gold producer, fell 5.3% to S$0.54 after gold prices dropped 5 cents or 0.39% to US$1,266.30, their biggest daily decline since June 2013. The decline is attributed to a hawkish Fed voting member's speech and a potential increase in inflationary pressures. Analysts expect gold prices to rebound due to uncertainties in the next 12 months, including the US presidential elections and Brexit.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slip on Brexit worries, US dollar strength
summary: South Korea's won and stocks declined on Wednesday due to a risk-off mood fueled by the sudden fall of sterling and comments from a US Federal Reserve official hinting at a rate hike at the end of the year. The won dropped 0.6% and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.1%. The decline was attributed to growing fears of Brexit fallout and offshore investors selling Kospi shares worth 46.8 billion won.

site_title: Dutch clean-up 'heroes' turn beach rubbish into art
summary: In the Netherlands, a group of "treasure hunters" led by Ralph Groenheijde, a therapist and counsellor, has turned beach trash into art, sparking a cleaning crusade. The group, called TrashUre, has collected 40 tonnes of garbage since June, including 42 dirty nappies and sanitary pads. The trash is then transformed into art pieces, displayed in a museum, and used to educate the public about the importance of proper waste disposal. Groenheijde's initiative has gained attention, inspiring others to take action and highlighting the issue of plastic waste in the oceans.

site_title: Kaine, Pence clash in vice-presidential debate
summary: US Vice-Presidential hopefuls Tim Kaine and Mike Pence clashed in their only debate, with Kaine promoting himself as a trusted and capable vice-president for Hillary Clinton, while Pence defended Donald Trump's policies and style. Kaine attacked Trump's reputation and policies, while Pence defended him, highlighting Clinton's criticism of Trump. The debate focused on issues such as taxes, social security, and foreign policy, with Kaine seeking to discredit Trump and Pence pushing a theme of change. The debate highlighted the contrasting styles of the two men, with Kaine appearing more aggressive and Pence more polished.

site_title: Australian dollar rises on strong retail sales, NZ dollar at 7-week lows
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.26% to US$0.7636, its highest against the pound in over three years, due to strong retail sales data. Retail sales grew 0.4% in August, exceeding forecasts, and may provide relief to the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Aussie also rose against the yen and New Zealand dollar, while the New Zealand dollar fell to a 7-week low due to a decline in dairy prices.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble rally continues, now up 60% from Sept low
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, saw a 5.3% increase in its counter value, reaching S$0.179, amid a 60% rally from its September low of S$0.112. The stock traded 124 million shares worth S$21.7 million.

site_title: Singapore's assets under management up 9% in 2015: MAS report
summary: Singapore's assets under management (AUM) increased 9% to S$2.6 trillion in 2015, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) report. This growth was driven by new AUM, surpassing the one per cent global growth to US$71.4 trillion. Meanwhile, traditional asset managers saw a 4% increase, while private equity and venture capital grew by over 40% and real estate by over 80%. The MAS report attributes the growth to investors seeking excess returns from private markets due to disappointing public market returns.

site_title: After war and tumult, the Palestine stock market joins the world
summary: Palestine's stock market, the Palestine Exchange (PEX), has gained global recognition after being included in the FTSE Russell index of 27 frontier markets. Founded in 1995, the exchange has struggled to attract investors due to the ongoing conflict with Israel and its status as a partially controlled territory. Despite these challenges, PEX has a combined market value of $3.3 billion and has seen a 10% increase in its index over the past year. The inclusion in the FTSE Russell index is seen as a key step in promoting local companies and potentially bringing in foreign investment.

site_title: Billionaire Li looks at Siri-like software, 3-D printed cars
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing, known for early investments in Siri and Facebook, is examining startups in artificial intelligence and 3D printing for potential investments. His charity, the Li Ka Shing Foundation, is looking into carmaking via 3D printing and high-tech food, such as the "Impossible Burger". Li's interests provide insight into his business acumen and suggest a potential future role in shaping the technology world.

site_title: Australian government offers support but little sympathy for racetrack strippers
summary: Australian foreign minister says nine detained strippers must face consequences for their "foolish prank" at the Malaysian Formula One Grand Prix. The group wore underwear with the Malaysian flag and drank beer from their shoes, drawing widespread criticism. The incident has sparked debate in Australia about the country's tolerance of uncouth behavior abroad.

images.alt_text: Nine Australians detained by police for stripping down to their underwear at Sunday's Formula One Malaysian Grand Prix must face the consequences of their "foolish prank", Australia's foreign minister said Wednesday.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop with bonds, won on ECB, Fed concern; oil jumps
summary: Asia's stocks and bonds fell as central banks' less accommodative policies raised concerns. The New Zealand won slid the most in three weeks, while Japanese shares advanced after the yen dropped. Crude oil prices rose as US oil stockpiles declined. The US dollar strengthened against the won, and global dairy prices fell, contributing to New Zealand's 10-year debt decline. Despite the decline, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China: Financial markets closed
summary: China's financial markets are closed on Wednesday for a public holiday, with no updates on market trends or recent news. The article does not mention any significant events or developments in China's financial markets.

site_title: Hurricane Matthew pummels Haiti and Cuba, evacuations ordered in US
summary: Hurricane Matthew pummeled Haiti and Cuba, killing seven people and forcing hundreds of thousands to flee. The storm made landfall in Haiti as a Category Four storm, causing widespread destruction and flooding. Evacuations were ordered in the US, particularly in South Carolina and Georgia, as the storm is expected to hit the East Coast later this week. The storm's path is expected to bring significant rain and flooding to the Bahamas, with forecasters predicting massive destruction in Florida.

images.alt_text: Hurricane Matthew pummeled Haiti and moved on to Cuba after killing seven people, unleashing floods and forcing hundreds of thousands to flee the Caribbean's worst storm in nearly a decade.

site_title: Australia: Shares towed down by commodities, US rate hike risk
summary: Australian shares declined 0.7% to 5,445.6 on Wednesday, dragged down by weakened commodity prices, particularly in the mining sector, and heightened expectations of a US Fed rate hike in December. Materials stocks, including gold producer Newcrest Mining Ltd, fell 7.6% to a four-month low.

site_title: Abe's aides hint at early Japan election
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling Liberal Democratic Party is hinting at an early election in the next few months, with possible dates in January. The party has pushed its annual convention back two months, and Abe's public support is at a two-year high. The opposition remains weak, and a convincing win for Abe could put him on track to become the longest-serving leader of Japan since World War II. Abe has incentives to act quickly, including the possibility of staying on as party president for a third term and revising Japan's post-war constitution.

site_title: World Bank raises 2016 East Asia growth view, sees limited Brexit impact
summary: The World Bank has raised its 2016 economic growth forecast for developing East Asia and the Pacific to 6.4% and 6.2% for 2016 and 2017, respectively. The slight increase is attributed to the region's resilience to the Brexit impact, which is expected to be limited. The forecast is higher than the bank's previous estimate of 6.3% growth in 2016.

site_title: Oil resumes advance as US industry data shows inventory drop
summary: US crude oil inventory dropped by 7.6 million barrels last week, signaling a decline in the supply glut. Oil futures rose 1.3% in New York after the report, with West Texas Intermediate reaching $49.30 a barrel. A deal between Opec and non-members could trim output by 1.2 million barrels a day and boost prices. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will decide quotas at an official meeting on November 30. Despite the decline in inventories, high levels are expected to keep prices from rising too far.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.90 points to 1663.43. A total of 37.4 million lots were traded, worth RM13.1 million, with 63 gainers outnumbering 60 losers.

site_title: Australia retail sales hit 7-month high as shoppers return
summary: Australia's retail sales rose 0.4% in August, the largest gain in seven months, driven by rising household wealth and low unemployment. This surge provides relief to the Reserve Bank of Australia, which could boost economic activity in coming months. The retail sector, worth A$290 billion annually, is Australia's second-largest employer with 1.25 million workers. The increase in sales may also be seen as a positive sign for the economy, despite the UK's economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: Samsung Note 7 fires risk hurting demand for other products
summary: Samsung's Note 7 smartphone has led to a 30% drop in sales, including the high-end S7 Edge, due to concerns over battery fires. The company has recalled over 2.5 million devices and shipped replacements, but momentum has been lost against key rivals like Apple and Huawei. Analysts predict a decline in quarterly profit and estimate Samsung will set aside $1 billion to replace faulty phones. The impact on Samsung's other products, including washing machines and the Galaxy S7, is uncertain, with some analysts warning that consumers' mistrust could spread to other Samsung products.

site_title: Costs of airline climate deal may be peanuts for passengers
summary: The proposed UN aviation climate accord could cost airlines $2.9 billion to $12.4 billion annually by 2030, with estimated costs per seat ranging from 31US cents to $12.10. Airlines may pass these costs to consumers, but the expense is forecast to be a tiny fraction of their budgets. The accord, which would be the first global climate deal for a single industry, would require companies to offset emissions growth by funding environmental initiatives. Emissions from international flights account for about 2% of global greenhouse gases and are forecast to triple over the next few decades.

images.alt_text: The proposed United Nations accord to limit pollution from international flights could cost airlines billions. For passengers, the price may be less than an in-flight glass of pinot noir.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Evans says 'fine' with December hike if data stays firm
summary: Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans stated he would be "fine" with raising US interest rates by year-end if US economic data remains firm. He emphasized the timing of the hike is less important than the method of tightening, and would require inflation to rise and unemployment to fall further. Evans suggested a potential rate hike at the December policy meeting, but also left room for an earlier move in November if inflation increases.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AusGroup, Pan-United, Wilmar
summary: AusGroup has halted trading pending a meeting with noteholders. Pan-United Corporation's founding family has proposed buying its loss-making tug and barge business for S$29.92 million. Wilmar International has partnered with Brazil's Raizen Energia to export 4.5 million tonnes of Brazilian sugar annually.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares ease at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks eased at the open on Wednesday, tracking losses on Wall Street after a two-day rally. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.29% to 23,619.91, but dealers took a cautious approach following the US market's close. Mainland Chinese markets remain closed for the National Day holiday.

site_title: Amazon said to weigh EU settlement in bid to end e-books probe
summary: Amazon is in talks with European Union regulators to settle an antitrust probe into e-book contracts with publishers, potentially ending a year-long investigation. The probe focuses on whether Amazon's contracts prevent competitors from developing new products and limit competition between sellers of e-books. A settlement would require Amazon to overhaul pricing and disclose terms to other e-book retailers, similar to Apple's 2012 agreement with the EU. The move comes after EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager has targeted Amazon and other US companies in recent probes.

site_title: Boycott test for Asia's top film festival
summary: South Korea's 21st Busan International Film Festival (Biff) is set to begin, but it faces a boycott by prominent local filmmakers due to the ongoing dispute with the municipal government over artistic freedom. The festival will screen 300 films from 70 countries, including world premieres and award-winning films from the 2016 Cannes Film Festival. The boycott is in response to the government's treatment of former festival director Lee Yong Kwan and the lack of independence for the festival's organizing committee. Several films, including the hit zombie blockbuster "Train to Busan," have also been rejected due to the boycott.

site_title: US holiday sales expected to grow, boosted by wage gains
summary: US retail sales are expected to grow at a faster pace this holiday season, driven by rising wages and a strong job market. The National Retail Federation predicts a 3.6% increase in sales to $655.8 billion, excluding autos, gas, and restaurant sales.
