Non-store sales may rise 7-10% to $117 billion, with online sales accounting for 90% of this measure. Despite concerns over mall traffic and political uncertainty, retailers are optimistic, with many planning to hire seasonal workers and Macy's increasing its holiday workforce by 83,000.

images.alt_text: US retail sales this holiday season may grow at a faster pace than last year, fuelled by rising wages and a stronger job market, the National Retail Federation said.

site_title: Chinese buyers returning to Hong Kong housing, Wheelock says
summary: Chinese buyers are returning to Hong Kong's housing market, driving sales at Wheelock Properties' projects. Chinese buyers now account for 10% of Wheelock's mass-market properties, up from 5% a year ago. Mainland buyers made up nearly 20% of September sales at One Homantin, seeking homes as investments and for personal use, despite a 15% extra tax on non-residents. Rising housing prices and yuan fears are fueling this resurgent demand.

site_title: Trump has a new person to blame for tax problems: Hillary Clinton
summary: Donald Trump shifted blame for his tax problems to Hillary Clinton at a rally in Arizona, claiming she could have changed tax laws to prevent him from using them to avoid paying federal income taxes for two decades. Trump pointed to wealthy donors, including George Soros and Warren Buffett, as examples of those who also used tax laws to their benefit. Clinton's campaign portrayed Trump's avoidance of taxes as self-serving and unpatriotic, with 86% of voters surveyed viewing paying taxes as a civic duty.

site_title: Keppel O&M gets contracts for two LNG harbour tugs
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured contracts to build its first two dual-fuel diesel liquefied natural gas (LNG) harbour tugs, marking its first foray into the LNG sector. The tugs will use bunkering services provided by FueLNG, a Keppel joint venture with Royal Dutch Shell. Keppel has also entered into a memorandum of understanding with Shell to jointly explore potential opportunities in the LNG sector.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index losing 9.13 points to 2,875.51. The dip followed a decline in US markets overnight, amidst Brexit worries. The market saw an average unit price of S$0.63 per share, with 50.9 million shares changing hands. The evenly matched market had 60 gainers and losers, with top stocks including Singtel, DBS, and Noble.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on weak yen
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a weak yen, which raised business prospects for Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.32% to 16,789.92, while the Topix index rose 0.32% to 1,344.46.

site_title: Germany and France to share military facilities, aircraft
summary: Germany and France have signed an agreement to share an air base and transport planes, aiming to finalize the deal by 2021. The two countries will share C-130J Super Hercules military transport planes as part of a military shake-up following Britain's EU vote. The arrangement is part of efforts to strengthen cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Korean won drops with ringgit as ECB seen winding down stimulus
summary: South Korea's won dropped 0.6% to 1,114.60 against the US dollar, its largest three-week decline, amid concerns global central banks will raise interest rates and cut stimulus. The European Central Bank is expected to wind down bond purchases before ending quantitative easing. Meanwhile, the ringgit dropped 0.3% to 4.1390. The won's four-day loss reached 1.6%, while the US dollar index climbed 0.6% overnight, the largest gain in two weeks.

site_title: Ukip leader Diane James steps down after just 18 days on job
summary: UKIP leader Diane James resigned 18 days after taking the position, citing insufficient authority and support among European parliament colleagues and party officers. She cited "personal and professional reasons" for her decision. The party's direction is now in question following the loss of two leaders in three months. James' resignation comes after Nigel Farage's leadership, who helped lead the UK's Brexit campaign.

images.alt_text: Diane James resigned as the leader of the UK Independence Party a mere 18 days after succeeding Nigel Farage, who helped lead the campaign for the UK to leave the European Union.

site_title: Vancouver home sales fall 33% in September, most in six years
summary: Vancouver home sales plummeted 33% in September, the largest decline in six years, with 2,253 sales recorded. This follows the implementation of measures to curb price gains, including a 15% foreign buyer tax and new mortgage insurance rules. The benchmark price for detached properties rose 34% to C$1.58 million, while prices for all residential properties increased 29% to C$931,900. The sales drop suggests that cooling measures are working, but experts warn that Vancouver remains at risk of a housing bubble.

site_title: Kardashian freed herself, raised alarm after Paris heist: police sources
summary: Kim Kardashian was robbed at gunpoint in Paris, France, by five men posing as police officers who stole $10 million in jewels, including a ring worth 4 million euros and a case of jewelry worth 5 million euros. Kardashian was tied up and locked in the bathroom while the robbers took the valuables. She freed herself and raised the alarm by calling her bodyguard, who was not present at the time of the attack. The incident has raised concerns about security in France, particularly after a series of terror attacks.

site_title: Gold investors race to exit in biggest price slump since 2013
summary: Gold prices slumped by 3.3% to $1,269.70 per ounce, the largest loss since December 2013, as investors rushed to exit amid speculation of ending easy monetary policy. The European Central Bank is reportedly building a consensus to wind down bond purchases, while Federal Reserve officials hint at an interest-rate increase in the US. The prospect of higher rates and reduced stimulus curbs demand for gold as a store of value, with prices expected to bottom at $1,257 an ounce.

site_title: IMF warns of protectionist threat to global growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of a "dangerous" credit binge in China and a potential threat to global growth due to protectionist trends. The IMF's World Economic Outlook report downgrades its outlook for the US, citing slower growth, while upgrading forecasts for Japan and the eurozone. The fund urges countries to defend trade liberalization and economic growth, warning that protectionism could "turn back the clock" on free trade. Global GDP growth is expected to be 3.1% this year and 3.4% next year, with emerging economies expected to accelerate.

site_title: Vice-presidential candidates gear up for US election debate
summary: US Vice Presidential candidates Tim Kaine and Mike Pence are set to face off in their only debate of the campaign, just five weeks before the presidential election. The debate is seen as a crucial moment for Pence to reassure Republicans and defend Trump amidst controversies surrounding his taxes and treatment of women. Kaine, a liberal Democrat, will aim to convince undecided voters that Clinton is worthy of the Oval Office, while Pence must attack Clinton while pushing the Republican agenda. The debate is expected to be intense, with both sides vying for the attention of undecided voters.

site_title: Oil rebounds as industry data signals US stockpiles declined
summary: US oil futures rose 1.3% in New York after industry data showed crude inventories declined by 7.6 million barrels last week. This contrasts with a forecast of a 1.5 million-barrel gain. The data suggests a trimming of the supply glut, despite potential disruptions from Hurricane Matthew heading towards the US East Coast.

site_title: French finance minister warns Britain against "hard Brexit" battle
summary: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin warned Britain against a "hard Brexit" due to its late decision to trigger EU talks in March, signaling tough negotiations ahead. Sapin believes this late target indicates London is preparing for a battle, which is not in its interests. The French government has repeatedly warned Britain it cannot expect preferential access to the single EU market if it halts the free movement of workers. Sapin's comments come as French efforts to convince British banks to set up in Paris intensify due to the threat of losing their EU market access.

site_title: China's Shenzhen unveils steps to cool home prices: Xinhua
summary: China's Shenzhen city has introduced measures to cool home prices, including higher mortgage down payments for first-time home buyers (50% minimum) and second-home buyers (70% minimum). The city joins other Chinese cities in attempting to curb soaring home prices, which rose 9.2% annually in August. The government aims to balance economic growth with preventing property bubbles, following similar measures in other cities such as Suzhou and Chengdu. The move is part of a broader effort to tighten credit flowing into the property sector.

site_title: Thailand detains Hong Kong pro-democracy activist
summary: Thailand has detained 19-year-old Hong Kong pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong, who was barred from entering the country, at the request of China. Wong was scheduled to speak at an event commemorating the 40th anniversary of a Thai military crackdown on student protesters. He was given 80 hours of community service in Hong Kong for participating in the 2014 Umbrella Movement protests. His detention was condemned by Human Rights Watch, calling for his release and an end to Thailand's clampdown on dissent.

site_title: USDA to pay farmers more than US$7b due to low crop prices
summary: The US Department of Agriculture will pay more than $7 billion to farmers this fall due to low crop prices. The payments, part of the safety-net programs for corn, soybeans, and other crops, will benefit over 1.5 million growers who enrolled in the programs last year. Low crop prices, resulting from massive global harvests and increased competition, have led to the USDA's decision. The payments aim to support farmers affected by the market downturns.

site_title: Google makes new hardware push, takes on Apple with Pixel phone
summary: Google announced a new "Pixel" smartphone and virtual reality headset, making a move into home electronics and challenging Apple's iPhone in the global smartphone market. The announcements include a $649 Pixel, a new Wifi router, and a voice-activated digital assistant, "Home", aimed at creating an integrated world of devices and services. This move signifies Google's intent to compete directly with Apple, Amazon, and its own Android customers, taking tighter control of its products and services.

site_title: US dollar rises most in two weeks as wagers for Fed tightening rise
summary: The US dollar rose against its major peers, its largest gain in two weeks, following comments from Federal Reserve officials. Fed Bank of Richmond president Jeffrey Lacker urged tightening policy to combat inflation, while Fed Bank of Cleveland president Loretta Mester said the economy is ripe for a rate increase. A report showed US manufacturing expanded in September, further fueling speculation of a rate hike.

site_title: Yahoo secretly scanned customer emails for US intelligence: sources
summary: Yahoo secretly built a custom software program to scan all incoming emails of its customers for specific information requested by US intelligence officials, including the National Security Agency or FBI. The company complied with a classified US government demand, scanning hundreds of millions of Yahoo Mail accounts. This is the first known case of a US internet company agreeing to an intelligence agency's request by searching all arriving messages, rather than examining stored messages or scanning a small number of accounts in real time.

site_title: England aims to end reliance on foreign doctors after Brexit
summary: England plans to train more doctors to end its reliance on foreign recruits for the National Health Service after Brexit. Currently, a quarter of doctors are from overseas. Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt stated that EU nationals will be allowed to stay post-Brexit. The goal is to reduce the NHS's reliance on foreign doctors, with the government aiming to increase domestic training.

images.alt_text: England is to train more doctors so that it can end its reliance on foreign recruits for the state-funded National Health Service after it leaves the European Union, the government announced Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Deutsche Bank and Pearson help European shares rally
summary: European shares rallied on Tuesday, with Deutsche Bank reaching a two-week high and Pearson gaining 5.2% after Morgan Stanley expressed confidence in the company's Q3 results. Deutsche Bank's shares bounced back from a record low on Friday, driven by expectations of a swift deal with US authorities over a multi-billion dollar penalty. The Stoxx 600 index rose, with mining and healthcare stocks leading the gains.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as strong US dollar hits oil, metals shares
summary: US stocks fell Tuesday as a strong US dollar hit oil and metal shares, with commodities producers like ExxonMobil and Chevron losing about 1% and Barrick Gold and Newmont Mining plummeting 11.2% and 10.1%, respectively. The US dollar surged after hawkish comments from two Federal Reserve officials emphasized the need to lift interest rates soon. The comments boosted the dollar, denting commodities traded in the US currency.

site_title: Hedge fund urges Metro to pay extra dividend
summary: Activist hedge fund Quarz Capital Management is urging Metro Holdings, a Singaporean retailer and real estate developer, to pay a 21 cents per share one-off dividend to return excess cash to investors. The company's net cash holdings are high, accounting for over half its market capitalization, and its shares trade at 40% below book value. Quarz also calls for a clearer strategy for Metro's real estate division, improved investor relations, and management pay alignment with the firm's long-term profitability and share price.

site_title: Batten the hatches for cybersecurity for the IoT age
summary: Cybersecurity threats are becoming increasingly prevalent, with three-quarters of organizations in the Asia-Pacific region facing significant risks of cyber incidents. The need for robust cybersecurity defenses is clear, with the cost of global cyberattacks estimated at $315 billion in 2015. Governments in the region are taking steps to address the issue, with Singapore, China, and Taiwan announcing new cybersecurity laws and agencies. However, businesses and individuals are not yet adequately prepared, with many lacking robust cyber response plans and qualified cybersecurity experts. Experts emphasize that cybersecurity is a business practice that requires the involvement of all employees and departments, and that it should be viewed as a safety net that supports growth and productivity.

site_title: Aussie metal guru quits 007 tailor after six months
summary: Brioni has parted ways with its creative director Justin O'Shea just six months after hiring him to revamp James Bond's tailor. O'Shea, an Australian heavy metal fan, was seen as an unusual fit for the Milan-based fashion house. Brioni had dressed every James Bond from Pierce Brosnan to Daniel Craig. The decision comes after O'Shea's unconventional style and lack of experience in designing clothes raised eyebrows.

site_title: Oscar Wilde of fashion sends up its follies
summary: French fashion insider Loic Prigent has released a collection of one-liners and quotations, "I Love Fashion But it's Everything That I Hate," which has gained popularity among the Paris catwalk crowd. The book, filled with witty remarks and behind-the-scenes gossip, has been praised by critics, including actress Catherine Deneuve. Prigent, who has been documenting the fashion world for two decades, says the quotes came from models, designers, colleagues, and friends, and that he often quotes himself. The collection has sparked debate about the authenticity of its content, but Prigent insists that fashion's dogged perversity is a reflection of the world's current state.

site_title: GIC, GSA to invest in German student dorm
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and student accommodation operator GSA have partnered to invest in Germany's student accommodation market, targeting major university cities. They plan to invest in a portfolio of 1,000 beds and expand it to 1,500 beds, with a focus on Berlin, Cologne, Frankfurt, Hamburg, and Munich. The partnership aims to meet the growing demand for student accommodation in Germany, where the market is highly fragmented and in need of purpose-built facilities. GSA plans to open 10,000 beds in Europe, with Frankfurt leading the operational management of the student residences.

site_title: Asian investors turn to smart-beta ETFs as active managers' results disappoint
summary: Asian investors are shifting to smart-beta exchange-traded funds (ETFs) due to low investment returns and low interest rates. AUM in smart-beta ETFs in the Asia-Pacific region grew 47.5% to $10.5 billion in the year ended June. Investors are seeking higher returns and income streams, with smart-beta products offering lower fees than actively managed funds. The strategy has gained popularity in Japan, where negative interest rates and a strong yen have weighed on company performance, with Japanese investors seeking high dividends.

site_title: Deterioration of US-China relationship is open ended
summary: US-China relations are deteriorating, with no clear end in sight. A 2013 proposal by Chinese President Xi Jinping for a "new model" of major country relationship, emphasizing mutual interest and respect, was met with skepticism by the US. The US has since downplayed the idea, but held talks with Xi in Hangzhou, reaffirming a focus on managing the relationship rather than respecting China's core interests. With the US presidential election looming, it remains unclear whether the new administration will continue to pursue this approach, potentially leading to an open-ended deterioration of relations.

site_title: Opportunities in stocks of three high-end developers
summary: Three high-end developers, Wing Tai Holdings, Wheelock Properties, and OUE Limited, are undervalued due to overly pessimistic expectations of housing price declines. Their share prices reflect discounts of 40-58% from book value, with market-implied valuations ranging from S$1,300 to S$1,500 per square foot. Despite regulatory headwinds, demand for high-end homes has picked up, and the developers' healthy balance sheets and recurring income from rental properties provide a foundation for long-term growth. Investing in these developers now may offer attractive risk-reward and a margin of safety in terms of fundamental value.

site_title: Luxury lifestyle prices slip: Julius Baer index
summary: The Julius Baer Lifestyle Index for 2015/2016 found a 1.68% drop in US dollar terms, with 8 of 21 items experiencing price declines. Mumbai is the least expensive city, while Shanghai is the most expensive, with Singapore ranking second. Weaker Asian currencies and government intervention in the luxury goods market in China and Hong Kong contributed to the decline. Despite this, Chinese consumers remain the largest luxury market share, accounting for 31% globally.

site_title: Global growth outlook overshadowed by protectionism: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its global growth forecast to 3.1% this year and 3.4% next year, citing persistent stagnation and protectionism. The agency warns that populist calls for trade restrictions could fuel further economic decline. Central banks should maintain easy monetary policies to support growth, but the reliance on them is excessive. The IMF calls for a comprehensive and coordinated policy approach to reinvigorate growth, ensuring it is distributed more evenly and durable.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund (IMF), predicting that global economic growth will remain subdued this year and the next, has warned that the situation could worsen if the world turns its back on globalisation.

site_title: Jakarta tax amnesty has little impact on banks here: RHB
summary: A tax amnesty scheme in Indonesia has had a minimal impact on funds flowing out of Singapore's private banking industry, with only 1-2% of assets under management repatriated. The 79 trillion rupiah (S$8.3 billion) repatriated in the first nine months represents a small fraction of the total assets managed by Singapore's private banks, estimated at S$321 billion. The tax rate for repatriated assets is set to increase in subsequent phases, but the impact on Singapore's private banking industry is expected to be about 1-2% of all assets held here.

site_title: Jokowi taps Ma's guidance to make giant digital jump
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has tapped guidance from Alibaba's Jack Ma to accelerate the country's e-commerce growth, with McKinsey estimating the market could rise by up to $15 billion in the next three years. Indonesia's e-commerce market is expected to reach 7-8% of total retail sales by 2020, driven by a growing urban consumer class and rapidly expanding internet access. Ma has already established a foothold in Indonesia, with Alibaba's Lazada Group SA and ride-hailing app Go-Jek. The government aims to make Indonesia the biggest digital economy in South-east Asia, with Ma's advice seen as crucial to achieving this goal.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian Research and OCBC Investment Research have upgraded their targets for Singapore Post and ComfortDelGro Corp respectively. UOB Kay Hian targets SingPost at S$1.77, citing growth potential in e-commerce and logistics, while OCBC Investment Research expects ComfortDelGro's taxi earnings to remain resilient despite competition from Grab and Uber. The analysts also note potential corporate governance concerns and uncertainties, but remain bullish on the companies' prospects.

site_title: Iceland's fishing industry roots for rate cut amid krona gains
summary: Iceland's fishing industry is seeking a rate cut from the central bank amid a strengthening krona, which is impacting their bottom line. The currency has gained 11% against the dollar and euro over the past year, and is expected to continue to rise. The industry's managing director, Heidrun Lind Marteinsdottir, believes a rate cut would make Icelandic companies more competitive and beneficial to the industry. A snap election in October could also bring significant change, including a possible review of fishing quotas, which could disrupt the current business model.

site_title: Innovation in the public bus sector
summary: Tower Transit, a new bus operator in Singapore, has redesigned the job scope of its bus drivers to focus on safe driving and customer satisfaction. The company offers higher wages, career progression opportunities, and industry-leading initiatives, including upskilling courses and paid maternity leave. This approach has resulted in an over-subscription of interest from local job seekers, allowing Tower Transit to build a strong Singaporean core and attract new talent to the industry. The strategy has been a success, transforming the perception of the job and enhancing customer satisfaction with bus services.

site_title: Sterling dives to 30-year low
summary: The pound sterling has hit a 30-year low due to concerns about a potential "hard Brexit" that would restrict access to the European Union's single market. The currency has fallen 0.8% to US$1.2740 and touched its lowest level since 1985. Sterling's decline is attributed to Prime Minister Theresa May's announcement that financial services will not receive special treatment in EU exit talks. Despite the currency's losses, the lower exchange rate is expected to benefit exporters and help the Bank of England achieve its goal of faster inflation.

site_title: Analysts positive on Genting Malaysia's disposal of HK unit
summary: Genting Malaysia has sold its 16.9% stake in Genting Hong Kong to Golden Hope Ltd for RM1.71 billion, allowing the gaming company to monetize its loss-making investment after nearly 20 years. The funds are earmarked for working capital and expansion, making a special dividend unlikely. Analysts view the deal as positive, as it allows Genting Malaysia to finally realize value from its underperforming investment.

site_title: US buyers less than enthusiastic about Toyota Prius 'anime' design
summary: US buyers are less enthusiastic about the new Toyota Prius design, citing its busy and overwrought look, which some compare to the Pontiac Aztek. Despite this, the Prius remains a popular model in Japan, where it has resumed its position as top seller. Toyota attributes the US design's failure to mainstream appeal, but critics argue that the car's environmental credentials are being watered down with the introduction of the Prius Prime plug-in model, which lacks a battery-only option. Sales of the Prius have dropped 26% in the US through August, with owners citing cramped interiors and poor storage space as complaints.

site_title: France falls back in love with its humble grape pickers
summary: In France's Burgundy wine region, a revival of hand-picked grapes is underway, driven by organic winemakers who value the quality and control that manual harvesting provides. Despite the minimum wage of around 10 euros, many workers, including 69-year-old Rene Kleingardner, return year after year for the labor-intensive work. Local winemakers, such as Frantz Chagnoleau and Emmanuel Guillot, prioritize the well-being and camaraderie of their workers, who are often from diverse backgrounds, and see them as essential to the wine-making process.

site_title: Sterling skids to 31-year low, US$ strengthens
summary: The sterling currency slid to its 31-year low against the US dollar, weakening 0.7% to a 13-day high. The decline was driven by concerns over the impact of Britain's departure from the European Union. Meanwhile, the US dollar strengthened, with investors increasing bets on a rise in US interest rates by the end of the year, driven by a positive US manufacturing survey.

site_title: Many shale oil firms hedge 2017 prices on Opec rally
summary: Independent oil companies are hedging their price risk for 2017, taking advantage of the post-Opec rally. The WTI 2017 calendar strip rose above $50 a barrel, prompting producers to lock in cash flows. US shale firms, in particular, are expected to increase production, offsetting an output cut by Opec. Hedging activity is expected to rise, with open interest in WTI contracts jumping 10% over the last week. This trend is seen as a concern for Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, as it may reduce the effectiveness of their output cut.

site_title: India cuts rates in first decision by new panel
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, has cut interest rates to 6.25% for the first time under new governor Urjit Patel. The decision was seen as a surprise by markets, with 16 of 39 economists predicting a rate cut. The move aims to keep inflation in check, with the central bank aiming for a 5% inflation target by March 2017. The decision is expected to ease ties with the government, but room for further rate cuts will be limited. The benchmark S&P BSE Sensex rose 0.2% following the decision.

site_title: Singdollar slides, local interest rates remain weak
summary: The Singdollar (SGD) fell to S$1.3687 against the US dollar on Monday, influenced by broad-based USD strength and the battered sterling and euro. Local interest rates remain weak due to ample liquidity and inflows to the resurgent region. Despite the SGD's decline, its levels have returned to those seen in early June.

site_title: Concerns over global sulphur cap to dominate upcoming bunkering conference
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is set to make a decision on implementing a global sulfur cap of 0.5% by 2020. Despite the 2008 commitment, implementation has been patchy, with some countries and regions imposing the cap earlier. Industry analysts cite concerns over refining capacity expansion, tight refining margins, and the high cost of building vessels with liquefied natural gas (LNG) fuel systems as hurdles. LNG is seen as a more cost-competitive alternative, but its development is hindered by significant capital expenditure requirements. The IMO's decision is expected to impact the global bunkering supply chain and the future fuel mix.

site_title: The Changi Airport way
summary: Changi Airport has introduced several new initiatives to enhance customer satisfaction, resulting in a 6.28-point increase in its customer satisfaction score to 81.4 points. The new Early Check-in Lounge at Terminal 1 allows passengers to check in 24 hours before their flight, while self-service kiosks at Terminals 2 and 3 have been introduced. The airport's 50,000-strong community is encouraged by the high score, with 90% of passengers welcoming the new facilities, according to Tan Lye Teck, executive vice-president for airport management.

site_title: Student support services emerge as prime factor
summary: Singapore tertiary students prioritize student support services, including counselling, career advice, and financial assistance, as key drivers of perceived quality in education. This is partly due to the tight labour market and slow economic growth. Institutions are responding by offering career counselling at early stages, mapping curricula to professional accreditation requirements, and providing competency-based courses. Modularizing programs and enlisting industry partners to co-design teaching curriculum and assessments are also being explored to ensure relevance and responsiveness to industry changes.

site_title: Firms bought back S$72.6m of shares in September
summary: In September, 35 Singapore companies repurchased S$72.6 million of shares, with DBS leading with S$27.4 million. This brings the total share buybacks for the first three quarters to S$752 million, down 56% from last year. DBS, Singapore Airlines, and Olam International were active buyers in the last two months. The significant decline in share buybacks reflects the volatile market and lower trading activity.

site_title: Janus, Henderson to form giant
summary: Janus Capital Group and Henderson Group will merge in an all-stock deal worth US$320 billion, creating Janus Henderson Global Investors. The combined asset manager will have a global scale and assets under management. The deal highlights the pressure on actively managed investment companies from the growth of lower-cost passive strategies like exchange-traded funds (ETFs). The merger aims to increase global presence and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: JetBlue programme turning clerks into pilots
summary: JetBlue's Gateway Select programme is turning supermarket clerks, baggage handlers, and other non-pilots into pilots through a 7-month training program in Arizona. The initial six recruits, with varying flight experience, will become first officers at JetBlue in 2020 if they can handle the $125,000 price tag. The programme aims to address the US aviation industry's projected shortage of 15,000 aviators by 2026. Despite concerns from the pilots union, JetBlue is working with lenders to provide financial assistance and is seeking to recruit 24-48 new participants for the next round of training in 2018.

site_title: Slivers of light shine through shipping gloom
summary: Moore Stephens' shipping and transport partner Richard Greiner notes that the collapse of Hanjin Shipping and the ratification of the International Maritime Organization's Ballast Water Management Convention may have positive effects on the industry. The collapse could lead to overtonnaging, while the BWMC's requirement for $1.5 million equipment installations may alleviate overcapacity concerns. Despite uncertainty surrounding future regulations, confidence in the industry has reached its highest level in nine months, with a 5.4 confidence rating in the latest Moore Stephens Shipping Confidence Survey.

site_title: Philippine market selloff: It's the economy, not Duterte, say observers
summary: The Philippine market has experienced a significant selloff since July, attributed to economic concerns rather than President Rodrigo Duterte's war on drugs. A slowdown in remittances from overseas Filipinos, a key driver of growth, is a major cause for concern. Economists point to broader regional economic issues, such as China's slowing GDP growth and the impact of US tariffs on the Asian garment industry. Despite the market downturn, analysts expect the Philippine economy to remain stable, with some predicting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the global equity index.

site_title: Frontline staff on MD's advisory board
summary: FedEx Singapore has a unique staff engagement strategy, where the managing director's advisory board is comprised of frontline staff. This allows for candid dialogue between senior leadership and team members, enhancing customer satisfaction. The approach was recognized by the Aon Best Employers - Singapore 2016 program, which awarded FedEx Singapore a Special Recognition for Commitment to Engagement. This innovative approach enables the company to gain a sharper perspective on workforce-related matters, ultimately contributing to improved customer satisfaction.

site_title: Samsung Biologics aims to raise 2.25t won in IPO
summary: Samsung Biologics aims to raise 2.25 trillion won (S$2.77 billion) from its South Korean initial public offering, seeking to become the world's largest contract manufacturer of biological medicines. The company will offer 16.5 million shares at 113,000-136,000 won apiece, with a final price to be announced on October 28. The share sale will gauge demand from October 26-27. This move is crucial for Samsung Biologics, which has been working towards this goal for some time.

site_title: Euro-dollar rate adds to forex traders' woes
summary: Foreign-exchange traders are experiencing their worst losing streak on record due to the euro-dollar rate's narrowest range ever versus the dollar during the third quarter. Central banks, particularly the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, are to blame for the volatility decline, with investors increasingly skeptical of rate hikes. This has led to a stagnation in the euro-dollar rate, with forecasts suggesting it will remain within a narrow range until 2018, and momentum trading has fallen significantly, extending a seven-month losing streak.

site_title: Australia cracks down on rate riggers
summary: Australia has cracked down on rate riggers by making manipulation of financial benchmarks a criminal offense, with penalties including jail time. The new rules, set to take effect in January 2018, apply to banks manipulating equity indexes, Treasury Bond Futures settlement prices, and bank bill swap rates. The move aims to prevent future manipulation and ensure accountability among the country's largest lenders. The regulations follow ongoing probes into benchmark interest rate-rigging by multinational banks, including three of Australia's big four lenders.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge in JV to redevelop old CPF Building
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge Group has entered a joint venture with Mitsui and Tokyo Tatemono to redevelop the former CPF Building at 79 Robinson Road. The $1 billion project will feature 500,000 square feet of Grade-A office space and retail amenities, with Ascendas-Singbridge holding a 65% stake. The redevelopment aims to capitalize on Singapore's growing demand for prime office space, with a benchmark price of $3,000 per square foot.

site_title: Opportunities in an integrated Asean real estate market
summary: The Asean Economic Community (AEC) was launched in December 2015 to promote economic integration among member countries. The AEC facilitates the free flow of labor and goods, creating opportunities for real estate investments. As the AEC continues to expand, it is expected to increase demand for prime Singapore projects above S$3,000 per square foot (psf). The integration of the AEC will further boost the region's real estate market, providing opportunities for investors and developers. This will lead to increased economic growth and cooperation among Asean nations.

site_title: Friars' fresh tack revitalises Brooklyn church
summary: A Catholic church in Brooklyn, the San Damiano Mission, has seen a resurgence in attendance and community engagement under the guidance of Franciscan friars Nicholas Spano and Raphael Zwolenkiewicz. The church, which was on the brink of closing, has been revitalized through unconventional methods, including holding concerts and events outside the church and partnering with local organizations to serve the homeless. With the help of local artist serpentwithfeet, the church has become a hub for community activity, attracting a diverse crowd of around 200 people on a recent Thursday night.

site_title: When US presidential elections get nasty
summary: The 2016 US presidential campaign was marked by a level of nastiness comparable to that of the 1800 campaign between Thomas Jefferson and John Adams, and the 1828 campaign between John Quincy Adams and Andrew Jackson. Both campaigns involved personal attacks and derogatory language, with Jefferson and Adams being called "fool", "hypocrite", "criminal", and "tyrant", while Jackson was branded a "pimp" and his wife a "slut". The campaigns exposed deep social and cultural divisions, with a zero-sum mentality among Americans. The media environment also played a significant role, with trivial issues dominating the campaign narrative.

site_title: Unprepared British consumers face price squeeze
summary: British consumers face a price squeeze due to the pound's depreciation since the Brexit vote. Retailers are expected to pass on higher costs to shoppers, with some, like Apple, already increasing prices. The Bank of England forecasts a 1% growth in household spending next year, down from 5% in the past year. Inflation is expected to rise to 2% by the end of next year, above the Bank's target. The weaker pound will also impact other sectors, including food and clothing retailers, who are weighing their options on whether to raise prices or absorb costs.

site_title: Jetstar flies to the top
summary: Jetstar, a budget airline, has been ranked at the top among budget airlines, prioritizing customer experience and satisfaction. The airline has implemented various innovations, including real-time feedback, online virtual assistants, and seamless check-in kiosks. CEO Barathan Pasupathi aims to enhance customer experience by analyzing leading indicators and segments, focusing on key areas for improvement. These efforts have received international acclaim, highlighting the airline's commitment to customer care.

site_title: Too many fat pigs makes hog futures the biggest loser
summary: US hog futures experienced the worst investment performance in commodities last quarter and the past year due to an oversupply of pigs. The surplus is attributed to a 10% increase in pork output in August and a surge in the number of slaughtered animals in September. China's reduced pork purchases and a devalued peso threatening shipments to Mexico have contributed to the glut. Wholesale prices for pork cuts are at their lowest since 2009, and hedge funds are signaling that prices will remain low, with some predicting a decline to 40 cents per pound, the lowest since 2002.

site_title: Billionaire Riady family said to pursue United Engineers stake
summary: OUE Ltd, backed by the billionaire Riady family, is planning to pursue a stake in Singapore property and construction firm United Engineers Ltd. The move comes after Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp (OCBC) and its affiliates announced they were reviewing options for their combined stakes in the company. A formal sale process has not yet begun, and other parties may also express interest in bidding for the shares.

site_title: China Int'l to sell loss-making Tianjin unit for 460m yuan
summary: China International Holdings (CIH) has agreed to sell a loss-making property-development unit, Tianjin Xinzhong Property Development Co, for 460 million yuan (S$94.4 million) in cash. The unit holds the rights and benefits for the group's Tianjin Jixian project in northern China. The sale is part of CIH's efforts to streamline operations and reduce losses.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Metech International plans to issue S$2 million worth of non-convertible high-yield bonds through a crowdfunding platform with an 8% annual coupon rate. Meanwhile, Wilmar International partners with Raizen Energia to export 4.5 million tonnes of Brazilian sugar annually. Prudential Corporation Asia appoints Philip Seah as senior adviser and Wilf Blackburn as new CEO of Prudential Vietnam.

site_title: The new BT Weekend: A double bill to lift your weekend reading
summary: The Business Times (BT) is launching a new look and content reboot for its weekend edition, dubbed "Weekend", which will be a magazine supplement wrapped around the main newspaper. The magazine will focus on luxury lifestyles, featuring profiles of quiet achievers, fashion spreads, and travel and food reviews. The revamped main newspaper will include a new long-form feature called Brunch and a regular Inside View column. The new offerings will be available as an e-paper and will include exclusive content and promotions, including a complimentary Fitbit wristband for subscribers.

site_title: Thumbs up for 3 out of 5 sectors
summary: Singapore's public education, air transport, and land transport sectors have seen significant improvements in customer satisfaction, according to the Institute of Service Excellence's Q2 2016 CSISG scorecard. The public education sector, led by student support services, saw a statistically significant increase, while Changi Airport and budget airlines also improved. The air transport sector's increase was driven by higher ratings for expectations, quality, and value. Land transport improvements were attributed to increased reliability, helpfulness of staff, and train frequency. The logistics and private education sectors showed no statistically significant change.

site_title: Three UK-born scientists to share 2016 Nobel prize in physics
summary: Three UK-born scientists, David Thouless, Duncan Haldane, and Michael Kosterlitz, were awarded the 2016 Nobel Prize in Physics for their discoveries in condensed-matter physics, transforming the understanding of matter with unusual shapes. They studied superconductors, superfluids, and thin magnetic films using advanced mathematical models, revealing topological phase transitions and phases of matter. Their findings have relevance for materials science and electronics, with potential applications in new generations of electronics and superconductors. The prize was awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences on October 4, 2016.

site_title: US wants 'strongest possible' EU-UK ties: Kerry
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry emphasized the importance of maintaining strong ties between the EU and UK, stating that Washington will support its friends and allies as they navigate the Brexit process. Kerry expressed his goal of achieving a highly integrated and collaborative relationship between the EU and UK, countering the notion that Europe's vision is dead. He also urged the EU and UK to reject the idea of raising drawbridges to separate countries.

site_title: Sentosa Cove bungalow fetches near-record price of S$2,923 psf on land area
summary: A Sentosa Cove bungalow has been sold for a near-record price of S$2,923 per square foot (psf) on land area, totaling S$28 million. The 9,580 sqft property, with a 99-year-leasehold tenure, features a seafront location, high-quality interior design, and plush fittings. The sale price is only the second record-breaking deal for Sentosa Cove bungalows this year, indicating a one-off transaction driven by the property's prime location and luxury features.

site_title: Bad banking news in Germany for Angela Merkel
summary: Deutsche Bank, Germany's premier bank, faces its lowest point since establishment in 1870 due to overleverage, misapplied ambition, and regulatory issues. The bank's fragile capital base and impending fine from the US Justice Department over mortgage securities mis-selling pose significant implications for pan-European policies on banking and economics. Chancellor Angela Merkel may face a dilemma in providing state aid, potentially affecting the government's stance on banking and economics. The bank's struggles also underscore its inability to progress with European banking consolidation, despite its long history of influential executives.

site_title: Oil hits 4-month high on Opec speculation; cut gains on dollar
summary: Oil prices rose to a four-month high on Tuesday, driven by speculation over OPEC's plans to reduce output, but gains were limited by a stronger US dollar. Brent crude reached $51.37 a barrel, its highest since June 10. The rally was also influenced by weaker equity prices on Wall Street. However, the dollar's surge eventually pulled back oil prices, which settled at $51.02 a barrel. The OPEC's plan to cut demand for the next four years is expected to have a significant impact on the global oil market.

site_title: EU's richest countries getting lion's share of bloc's investment plan
summary: The European Union's 315 billion euro investment plan has largely benefited the bloc's richest 15 countries, with Italy, Spain, and Britain receiving the most funding for infrastructure and innovation projects. The report by the European Investment Bank found that spending is on track to meet its mid-2018 target date, despite concerns that poorer countries may be left out. The report's findings highlight uneven distribution of EU investment and raise questions about the bloc's commitment to economic equality.

site_title: Prudential appoints new Singapore chief
summary: Prudential has appointed two new leaders. Philip Seah, outgoing Singapore chief, will become senior adviser to Prudential Corporation Asia, while Wilf Blackburn, current Vietnam country head, will take over as Singapore chief pending regulatory approval. Seah brings over three decades of experience, and Blackburn has led Prudential Vietnam to success with diverse experience across Asia. The appointments aim to support Prudential's region-wide growth agenda.

site_title: Jurong Shipyard extends standstill agreement with NADL over rig
summary: Sembcorp Marine's Jurong Shipyard has extended a standstill agreement with North Atlantic Drilling Ltd for the delivery of the West Rigel semi-submersible drilling rig until January 6, 2017. During this period, NADL will continue to market the unit, while Jurong Shipyard has the right to sell it at an acceptable price. If the unit is not sold, the parties will form a joint asset holding company for joint ownership, with 23% owned by NADL and 77% by Jurong Shipyard.

site_title: Low rates are here to stay, ECB tells bankers
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced it will maintain low interest rates until inflation reaches its target, citing it's not the institution's responsibility to boost meager bank profits. Banks, particularly in Germany, have complained that low rates are eating into their lending margins. The ECB's chief economist stated that ultra-low rates are not a solution for banks' profitability issues.

site_title: Global M&A scene hit by uncertainties
summary: Global M&A activity has declined by over 20% this year due to economic and political uncertainties. According to Mergermarket, 12,283 deals worth US$2.2 trillion have been entered into so far this year, a decrease from 13,263 deals worth US$2.8 trillion in the same period last year. This marks a significant drop in deal value, reflecting the impact of uncertainty on deal-making.

site_title: Too many investors hedging the wrong way: Pimco
summary: Pimco warns that one-size-fits-all hedging tactics are undermining pension returns. The investment firm says Australian investors are missing out on opportunities by uniformly hedging against currency fluctuations, particularly for riskier assets. Research shows that hedging against US, Canadian, and pound fluctuations can curb risks, while hedging against euro, yen, and franc increases risks. Pimco advises investors to apply 100% protection for bonds and consider tailored hedging strategies for individual assets. This approach can significantly reduce portfolio risks, particularly in low-yield environments.

images.alt_text: Pacific Investment Management Co says one-size-fits-all hedging tactics are undermining pension returns.

site_title: IMF issues warning over China debt load
summary: The IMF has warned China that its growing debt load is at a "dangerous pace" and must take action to avoid a brewing crisis. China's total debt reached 168.48 trillion yuan (S$32 trillion) at the end of last year, equivalent to 249% of national GDP. The IMF urges Beijing to implement vital reforms to address structural issues, or risk a painful correction in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: UK to consider making it tougher for firms to hire foreign workers
summary: The UK government will consider making it more difficult for companies to hire foreign workers under a new immigration control consultation. Interior Minister Amber Rudd stated that the government aims to control immigration to maintain faith in the system and prevent local workers from missing out on jobs. The consultation will examine whether to tighten the test for companies recruiting from abroad, ensuring that foreign workers fill labor market gaps rather than taking jobs that British people could do. This move comes after immigration was a key factor behind Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

images.alt_text: The British government will consider whether to make it more difficult for companies to hire foreign workers under a new consultation on controlling immigration set out by interior minister Amber Rudd on Tuesday.

site_title: New York beats London for overseas property investors on Brexit
summary: New York surpassed London as the top destination for overseas commercial property investors, with $25 billion in sales in the 12 months through June, according to a Cushman & Wakefield report. London's sales plummeted due to Brexit concerns and high pricing, while the US economy and stronger dollar drew buyers. Manhattan has become a magnet for global investors, with nearly 1 in 10 dollars spent on income-producing real estate going to New York, as the US offers relative stability amidst global economic and geopolitical uncertainty.

site_title: Australia keeps rates on hold amid home building bonanza
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates at 1.5% amid a booming home building industry, which underpins economic activity and jobs growth. This decision was expected by economists, who had anticipated no change after previous rate cuts in August and May. The RBA's decision reflects its focus on supporting the economy during the current housing market boom.

site_title: IMF raises eurozone growth forecast despite Brexit
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) raised its eurozone growth forecast to 1.7% in 2016, citing low oil prices and economic stimulus policies. However, it warned of uncertainty due to Brexit and low inflation, which is expected to remain below the European Central Bank's target of near 2% through 2021. The IMF also edged up its forecast for 2017 to 1.5%, but noted that a recovery in domestic demand that would boost prices has decelerated in some eurozone economies. The fund urged the European Central Bank to maintain its accommodative stance to boost inflation.

site_title: Pan-United's founding family to buy shipping assets from firm for S$29.9m
summary: Pan-United Corporation is selling its shipping assets, including tugboats and barges, to its controlling shareholders for S$29.9 million. The decision follows losses in the tug and barge business since 2013, attributed to low freight rates and oversupply in vessel capacity. The sale will allow the shipping division to focus on logistics and ship agency services, while the funds will be used for future projects and working capital. The assets are being sold by investment holding company wholly owned by members of the founding Ng family.

site_title: STI ends higher but poor volume persists
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 13.8 points to 2,884.64, pushing it 2 points into the black for 2016. Despite the gain, trading volume remained poor, with Tuesday's turnover of 1.5 billion units worth S$766 million, the seventh time the dollar value fell below the S$1 billion mark in the past eight sessions. The low volume has been a persistent issue in daily trading.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's junk-bond market is experiencing its worst rout in at least four years as debt restructurings spread among shipping and oil-and-gas service companies. Sanofi's dengue vaccine received market approval in 11 countries. A group of bondholders, including a 77-year-old retired businessman, is demanding restructuring from companies. Meanwhile, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and student accommodation operator GSA are partnering to invest in the German market.

site_title: Call to woo hardware builders to augment S'pore's startup ecosystem
summary: Singapore is shifting its focus to hardware to drive industry growth, building on its successful software startup ecosystem. A recent event, Ventures Day, hosted by Applied Materials, aimed to attract hardware builders to the city-state. However, challenges include inexperience with physical work, lack of talent, and limited support from multinational corporations. To overcome these hurdles, Singapore will need to invest in education and training programs to develop the necessary skills and infrastructure to support hardware innovation. This move is expected to drive the country's next wave of industry growth and diversify its economy.

site_title: Jumbo opens fifth bak kut teh restaurant, expands seafood outlet
summary: Jumbo Group has opened its fifth bak kut teh restaurant, Ng Ah Sio Bak Kut Teh, at Resorts World Sentosa, expanding its seafood restaurant, Jumbo Seafood, in Clarke Quay by 50%. The new seafood outlet now seats 450, featuring self-ordering kiosks and VIP rooms. The group's CEO, Ang Kiam Meng, attributes the expansions to the group's growth, aiming to provide a differentiated dining experience for customers.

site_title: Sing dollar slides while interest rates remain weak on ample liquidity
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) slid to S$1.3687 against the US dollar (USD), matching its level in early June, amid broad-based USD strength and concerns over a hard Brexit. Despite this, local interest rates remain weak due to ample liquidity, with the three-month Sibor unchanged at 0.87% and the three-month SOR falling to 0.62%. The improving economies of Indonesia, Philippines, and Thailand continue to attract capital inflows, supporting the SGD.

site_title: US stocks edge up as IMF confirms global growth forecast
summary: US stocks rose early Tuesday, edging up 0.2% as the IMF maintained its 2017 global growth forecast at 3.1%. The warning on rising protectionism could crimp growth was noted, but incremental growth in Japan and the eurozone is expected to compensate. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose to 18,293.91, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.1% to 2,162.54. Technology stocks, including Alphabet, Apple, and Cisco Systems, also gained.

site_title: Wilmar and Raizen tie up to form Brazilian sugar venture
summary: WILMAR International has formed a 50:50 joint venture with Raizen Energia to create one of the world's largest exporters of Brazilian sugar, with a total volume of 4.5 million tonnes a year. The venture, Raizen and Wilmar Sugar (RAW), will be headquartered in Singapore and combine the strengths of Brazil's largest sugar producer and the world's leading commodity trader. Regulatory approvals have been received, and the joint venture aims to match export volume with Wilmar's extensive network of customers and enable Raizen to further consolidate its leading position in Brazil.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.700 points to 1,661.250 on Tuesday, driven by gains. The index saw 1.492 billion lots traded worth RM1.941 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 408 to 398.

site_title: India to develop its own palm oil sustainability framework-trade body
summary: India plans to develop its own palm oil sustainability framework, considering domestic ecology, due to differences in farming practices from Indonesia and Malaysia. The framework aims to address concerns over deforestation and environmentally sound behavior. India imports 70% of its edible oils, with the expansion of palm plantations expected to reduce imports. The framework will be developed in collaboration with Solidaridad, with potential expansion in southern and northeastern states. This move is part of India's efforts to reduce its reliance on imports and promote sustainable palm oil production.

site_title: IMF warns of protectionist threat to global growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has left its global economic forecasts unchanged for 2017 but warned of the threat of protectionism to global growth. The IMF expects global output to grow at 3.1% this year and 3.4% next year, but downgraded forecasts for growth in global trade volume and advanced economies. The US economy is expected to grow at 1.6% this year and 1.8% next year, while Japan and the eurozone are expected to grow at 0.5% and 1.7% this year, respectively. The IMF also warned of the risks of geopolitical tensions, economic shocks in China, and the potential for a low-growth era in wealthy countries.

site_title: Bill Gross of Janus warns financial markets have become 'a Vegas casino'
summary: Bill Gross of Janus Capital Group warns that global financial markets have become a "Vegas/Macau/Monte Carlo casino" due to central bank policies, which he believes hinder economies by keeping "zombie" corporations alive and inhibiting "creative destruction." Gross recommends Bitcoin and gold for investors seeking to preserve capital and advises that ultra-loose central bank policies will lead to capital destruction, not creation. He argues that negative interest rates erode historical business models, destroy savings and investment, and ultimately harm economic growth. Gross believes investors are now "scrapping like mongrel dogs" for returns at the zero bound.

site_title: German BGA trade body slashes 2016 export forecast
summary: Germany's trade and wholesale association BGA slashed its 2017 export forecast to 2.5% growth, citing growing global uncertainties. The revised forecast is a correction from its previous 4.5% growth prediction in April. The BGA attributed the downgrade to factors such as Britain's decision to leave the EU, increasing risks, and Brexit uncertainty. This marks a sharp correction from the 6.5% growth in exports in 2015, with Germany's economy relying on exports for growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks set for longest streak without losses in a year
summary: European stocks advanced for the sixth consecutive day, reaching a six-point trading range. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose 0.6% as exporters' gains boosted the FTSE 100 Index to a 16-month high. The pound fell to a 30-year low, contributing to the UK's gains. Investors await US economic releases for cues on borrowing costs, following weaker-than-forecast manufacturing data and hawkish comments from a Federal Reserve official.

site_title: Metech to issue S$2m in junk bonds through crowdfunding site
summary: Metech International plans to issue S$2 million in non-convertible high-yield bonds through a crowdfunding platform, FundedHere. The two-year bond pays an 8% annual coupon rate, with half of the principal due in 12 months. The company will use the funds to finance its supply chain management business, citing difficulties in securing loans from traditional lenders and the security market. The bond is secured by Simon Eng's equity stake as the largest shareholder.

site_title: Glencore offers to buy back US$1.25b of bonds to cut debt
summary: Glencore Plc, the world's biggest commodity trader, has offered to buy back up to $1.25 billion of its bonds as part of a plan to reduce debt. The company aims to cut its debt to $16.5 billion by the end of the year through asset sales. This move comes after S&P Global Ratings raised its outlook on Glencore to positive, citing progress on asset sales and higher commodity prices. The shares have rallied 138% this year as investors regained confidence in the company's ability to navigate the downturn in commodity prices.

site_title: Deutsche Bank shares recover after drawing support from clients, rivals
summary: Deutsche Bank shares rose 2.5% on Monday after receiving support from major clients and rivals, rebounding from a record low last week. German business leaders defended the bank in the press, while JP Morgan CEO Jamie Dimon expressed no concerns over Deutsche Bank's solvency. Analysts at HSBC noted the bank's strong liquidity and funding, and that fears of solvency were overdone. The German lender is working to reach a settlement with US authorities over a potential $14 billion penalty before the US presidential election.

site_title: Vietnam editor sacked over dissident interview
summary: Vietnam's editor Nguyen Nhu Phong was sacked and stripped of his press card for publishing excerpts of an interview with an exiled dissident. This move is part of the government's efforts to control expression in the authoritarian country, where dissident bloggers are frequently jailed. The decision marks a rare instance of top editors being dismissed, highlighting the government's tightening grip on the media.

images.alt_text: The editor of a Vietnamese news site has been sacked after publishing excerpts of an interview with an exiled dissident, the government said, the latest move to choke expression in the authoritarian country.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher to extend gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Tuesday, extending gains from the previous day, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.45% to 23,689.44. The rally was attributed to Asia-wide market trends, with banks being major beneficiaries. Mainland Chinese markets are closed for the National Day holiday.

site_title: French government flies to rescue of trainmaking plant
summary: The French government has ordered 21 high-speed TGV trains, worth up to 630 million euros, to preserve jobs at an historic locomotives factory in Belfort, France. The order, announced six months before an election, aims to maintain train production and jobs at the factory, which Alstom management had said could not survive a lack of orders. The government plans to upgrade some inter-city lines to TGV speeds and invest in the factory's transformation into a European train maintenance hub.

images.alt_text: The French government on Tuesday announced orders for 21 high speed TGV trains, mostly for tracks on which they cannot run fast, as part of a pre-election bid to preserve jobs at an historic locomotives factory.

site_title: Hanjin Group CEO apologises for shipping chaos
summary: Hanjin Group's CEO apologized for the shipping chaos caused by the collapse of its shipping unit, Hanjin Shipping, which is seeking bankruptcy protection due to a $5.37 billion debt. This would be the largest bankruptcy in container shipping history, affecting the industry's worst downturn in six decades. The collapse is attributed to slumping global trade and a slowdown in China. The company's chairman believes it can be salvaged, but creditors have rejected its latest plan.

site_title: Cortina acquires remaining equity interest in Taiwan subsidiaries
summary: Cortina Holdings has acquired the remaining equity interest in two Taiwan subsidiaries, Cortina Watch Co (CTW) and Pacific Time Co (PTT), making both wholly owned subsidiaries. Cortina acquired 25% of CTW for NTD58 million and the remaining 40% of PTT for NTD6.5 million, funded through internal resources. As of Aug 31, 2016, CTW's net asset value was approximately NTD147 million, while PTT's was NTD16 million. The acquisitions enhance Cortina's presence in the Taiwanese market.

images.alt_text: Singapore-listed watch retailer Cortina Holdings has acquired the remaining stakes in two Taiwan subsidiaries, making both of them wholly owned subsidiaries of the company.

site_title: It's the economy: Duterte not main cause of Philippines market selloff
summary: Philippine markets have been heavily sold down since July, primarily due to economic reasons rather than the country's president, Rodrigo Duterte, and the US's war on drugs. A slowdown in remittances from overseas workers and the heavy correlation between Philippine bonds and US Treasuries are major concerns. Market participants are preparing for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which could lead to a drop in Philippine bond prices, further affecting the market. This economic downturn is not attributed to the US-Philippines relationship.

site_title: Indonesia air force holds its largest military exercise in South China Sea
summary: Indonesia's air force is conducting its largest military exercise in the South China Sea, near Natuna islands claimed by China, as a show of sovereignty. The two-week exercise, involving over 2,000 personnel and Russian fighter jets, aims to deter China. Indonesia objects to China's inclusion of Natuna waters within its "nine-dash line" demarcation. The exercise follows a series of face-offs between Indonesian and Chinese fishing boats and is part of President Joko Widodo's campaign to bolster defense facilities in the area.

site_title: China International inks deal to sell loss-making Tianjin property unit
summary: China International Holdings sold its loss-making Tianjin property unit for 460 million yuan (S$94.4 million) in cash. The unit, Tianjin Xinzhong Property Development Co, held the rights and benefits for the Tianjin Jixian project, comprising land use rights for a project east of Ji county in Tianjin, China. The sale is expected to generate net proceeds of 421.51 million yuan. The company halted trading in September and plans to resume trading on October 5, with no shareholder approval required due to the sale being a "major transaction" under SGX listing rules.

images.alt_text: INVESTMENT holding company China International Holdings (CIH) has inked a deal to sell a loss-making property-development unit for 460 million yuan (S$94.4 million) in cash, it said in a Singapore Exchange (SGX) filing on Tuesday.

site_title: Seoul: Won extend falls on US dollar strength, stocks up
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.6% to 1,107.8 to the US dollar, driven by US dollar strength. However, South Korean shares rose 0.5% as offshore investors bought 181.9 billion won worth of Kospi shares, ending at 2,054.86 points. This moderation in fears over a Deutsche Bank fine also contributed to the market's increase.

site_title: New reality for banks, and the pound crashes again
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is not prepared to grant special favors to the financial industry during Brexit negotiations, according to sources. This decision is expected to lead to a drop in the pound, which has sunk to its lowest level since 1985. Financial services contribute significantly to the UK economy, but May's approach may lead to a "hard Brexit" and smaller bankers' bonuses, with just a few hundred jobs moving elsewhere in Europe.

site_title: MTQ to sell unit to ASX-listed firm for A$17m
summary: MTQ Corporation announced the sale of its Australian turbocharger unit, MTQ Engine Systems, to ASX-listed company Bapcor for an estimated A$17 million. The acquisition can be funded fully in cash or up to 50% through shares in Bapcor. The deal marks a significant move for MTQ Corporation as it focuses on its core business.

site_title: India's central bank cuts interest rates to six-year low
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, cut interest rates to a six-year low of 6.25% to boost economic growth, citing a good monsoon season. The decision, made by a new six-member monetary policy committee, aims to help farmers and reduce inflation, which has been at a five-year low since August. The move is seen as a positive step for the country's fastest-growing major economy, but growth slowed to 7.1% in the first quarter of the 2016-17 financial year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up on bank rally, weak yen
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.83% on Tuesday, driven by a bank rally and a weaker yen, lifting exporters such as Toyota and Honda. The Nikkei 225 index climbed to 16,735.65, while the Topix index gained 0.71%. The rally follows recent gains in Singapore and other Asian markets.

site_title: Asia refining margins tumble to near 6-week low on crude price spike
summary: Asian refining margins have fallen to a near six-week low due to a surge in crude prices following Opec's decision to curb output. Refining margins to Dubai crude have dropped 34% to US$4.98 per barrel, with naphtha and fuel oil refining margins also weakening amid easing gasoline demand. Upside for margins in the coming quarter is limited due to a supply glut in the naphtha market and lacklustre gasoline demand, with some traders expecting further declines.

site_title: Hanjin lost 'game of chicken' among global shippers: chairman
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd, the world's seventh-largest container shipper, has lost the "game of chicken" among global shippers due to support from governments, according to its chairman. The company sought court receivership after creditors halted further support, stranding $14 billion in cargo. Hanjin's collapse led to logistics crises, with ship crews stranded in international waters and cargo left unloaded. The company is set to submit a rehabilitation plan to a Seoul court in December, but many expect it to be liquidated, marking the largest-ever bankruptcy in the industry.

site_title: UK construction industry shrugs off post-Brexit vote slump: PMI
summary: Britain's construction industry unexpectedly returned to growth in September, according to a survey, with the Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 52.3. This marks the first time since May the index has surpassed the 50 mark, indicating growth. Housebuilding recovered and new orders increased, pushing the headline index to a six-month high, despite being below the average over the last three years. This positive data casts doubt on the Bank of England's decision to provide more stimulus to offset the impact of the June Brexit vote.

site_title: Ericsson slashes 3,000 jobs, 900 consultants in Sweden
summary: Ericsson, a Swedish telecom equipment maker, announced plans to slash 3,000 jobs in Sweden, along with 900 consultants, due to a tough market. The company, which had previously announced a 9 billion Swedish crown (S$1.43 billion) cost-cutting program in 2014, said it would also recruit 1,000 research and development positions in Sweden over the next three years. The cost and efficiency program is progressing according to plan.

site_title: Sterling slides to 31-year low as Brexit worries bite
summary: Sterling plummeted to a 31-year low against the US dollar on Tuesday, falling 0.5% to US$1.2764, amid Brexit worries. The currency's value slid after Prime Minister Theresa May announced the formal process of Britain's departure from the EU would start by the end of March. A two-year negotiating period will follow, and investors sold the currency on concerns about the economic impact of the Brexit.

site_title: Hong Kong home sales rise to 15-month high as demand improves
summary: Hong Kong home sales rose to a 15-month high in September, with 7,826 units sold worth HK$56 billion, according to government figures. Demand has recovered since February's 25-year low, driven by aggressive discounts and mortgage offers worth up to 120% of a property's value. This marks a significant improvement in the market, which had previously been impacted by a slowdown in buyer demand. The increase in sales is a positive sign for the Hong Kong real estate market.

site_title: LVMH buys 80% of German luggage group Rimowa
summary: LVMH has agreed to purchase 80% of German luggage maker Rimowa for 640 million euros, marking the French luxury group's first acquisition in Germany. The transaction is subject to competition authority approval and is expected to be completed by January 2017.

site_title: Oil declines from three-month high as US supplies seen rising
summary: Oil prices declined 0.9% in New York after reaching a three-month high due to expected US crude stockpiles to increase by 1.75 million barrels. Libya's production rose to 500,000 barrels per day, and Opec's supply cut is expected to have a "more concrete floor" under prices. Despite the cut, analysts believe a surplus remains and oil prices may falter in the low $40s. WTI for November delivery fell to $48.38 per barrel, while Brent for December settlement slid to $50.53 per barrel.

site_title: Apple still a star without Steve Jobs, but doubts linger
summary: Apple has maintained its position as the world's most valuable corporation despite the five-year absence of co-founder Steve Jobs, with a market value of over $600 billion. The company's profit and revenue have doubled since Jobs' death, but analysts question whether Apple is losing momentum due to a lack of innovation. Critics argue that Apple is relying on its existing products and services, with little new to offer, and that its leadership is not as visionary as Jobs'. However, others see Tim Cook as a successful operations manager who has kept Apple on track, with a focus on improving and perfecting existing products.

site_title: Thai MPs plan military-backed party to keep junta chief as PM
summary: Thai pro-establishment lawmakers plan to field a military-backed party to ensure junta chief Prayuth Chan Ocha stays as prime minister in the 2017 general election. Paiboon Nititawan, a former military-appointed senator, will set up a party to nominate Prayuth as the next prime minister. The military-backed constitution, adopted in August, requires future elected governments to rule on the military's terms. This move is seen as a way to maintain the military's influence in Thai politics.

site_title: Taiwan Sept exports seen growing for 3rd month, inflation picking up slightly
summary: Taiwan's exports are expected to rise 3.2% year-over-year in September, marking the third consecutive month of growth, with the biggest year-on-year growth since November 2014. September imports are also forecast to rise 8.3% year-over-year, the first expansion since late 2014. The consumer price index is expected to have risen 0.6% year-over-year, indicating a slight increase in inflation.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's exports in September likely rose for a third straight month, according to the median of forecasts from 14 analysts polled by Reuters.

site_title: Qatar Re gets licence to operate reinsurance branch in Singapore
summary: Qatar Re, a Bermuda-headquartered reinsurer, has received a licence to operate a branch office in Singapore from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The licence marks a significant expansion for the firm, which will now underwrite non-life treaty reinsurance from its Singapore branch. The move aims to increase Qatar Re's profile in the Asian reinsurance market, where Singapore is recognized as a leading hub. The branch will be led by Micky Lee, and will focus on property-per-risk, property catastrophe, and specialty lines.

site_title: Australia shares trade sideways following RBA meeting; NZ slumps
summary: Australian shares closed marginally higher at 5,484, despite a weaker-than-expected performance, following the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to hold its cash rate at 1.5%. The move was influenced by stronger-than-expected US manufacturing data, which boosted expectations of a December interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Philippines, US hold war games after Duterte tirades
summary: The Philippines and the US launched joint war games amid tensions between the two countries, sparked by President Rodrigo Duterte's verbal assault on the US since taking office. Duterte has threatened to scrap a defence pact and warned the war games will be the last of his term if the US doesn't back down. The exercise comes as the Philippines pivots towards China, with the US trying to maintain its influence in the region. The war games are seen as a test of the US's commitment to the Philippines and its role in the South China Sea.

site_title: Australian gamers shift from megabytes to 'live action'
summary: In Sydney, Australia, a new event called "Zedtown" has emerged, blending video game concepts with reality, where participants engage in a live-action zombie apocalypse experience. Gamers, aged 18 and above, pay $45 each to participate, racing to an evacuation point while avoiding being tagged by "undead" zombies. The event, which has sold out in minutes, taps into the trend of immersive gaming and virtual reality experiences, capitalizing on the growing demand for live-action gaming and entertainment.

site_title: Morton's Sunday Lunch
summary: Morton's of Chicago restaurant has introduced a Sunday lunch service, previously only available for dinner. The restaurant offers a set menu featuring signature dishes like lobster bisque, short rib bolognese, and centre-cut fillet mignon, available from 12-9pm. The decision to expand lunch hours was prompted by positive feedback from Easter and Father's Day openings.

images.alt_text: Rib bolognese.

site_title: UK sees 'global Britain' as tactic, not slogan: Mark Gilbert
summary: The UK government views its "Global Britain" strategy as a post-Brexit tactic to maintain trading relationships with EU peers, despite concerns over the potential for tariffs and restrictions. Prime Minister Theresa May's uncompromising stance on trade issues has set a "take no prisoners" tone, with ministers confident that other EU countries will take a pragmatic approach to negotiations. However, critics argue that the UK is overplaying its hand, and that the EU may respond with retaliatory measures, potentially undermining existing institutional structures. The UK's economic future remains uncertain, with business leaders awaiting details on the nation's Brexit negotiating strategy.

site_title: Braci
summary: Italian serial-restaurateur Beppe De Vito has opened a modern Italian restaurant and rooftop bar in Boat Quay called Braci, meaning "ember" in Italian. The menu features charcoal-cooked dishes, such as a Piedmontese Beef Rib Steak and homemade Tagliolini, as well as an omakase Surprise Menu.
