Braci's kitchen uses a Josper oven and shichirin grill, showcasing De Vito's focus on charcoal cooking. The restaurant's offerings cater to various tastes, making it a great option for diners looking for a unique Italian dining experience.

site_title: Sanofi's dengue vaccine approved in Singapore and 10 other countries
summary: Sanofi's dengue vaccine, Dengvaxia, has received market approval in 11 countries, including Singapore, Mexico, and the Philippines. The vaccine targets four virus serotypes of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease affecting half of the world's population, with 400 million people infected annually. Sanofi's approval marks a significant step towards controlling the disease, although some experts have raised concerns about the vaccine's effectiveness and potential side effects.

site_title: Google expected to unveil new phones at San Francisco event
summary: Google is expected to unveil new smartphones at its San Francisco event, marking the company's latest attempt to sell consumers on a Google-branded device and challenge Apple. The event will also showcase a voice-controlled speaker system called Home and a virtual reality headset. Analysts predict the launch will feature the Pixel brand, replacing the Nexus line, and demonstrate Google's expanding hardware initiatives.

site_title: Archifest 2016
summary: Archifest 2016 is a one-day event celebrating Singapore's urban environment, featuring workshops, exhibitions, and a free photography class by Instagrammer Yafiq Yusman. The festival, now in its 10th year, showcases the country's architecture and sets the stage for discussions about city, spaces, and life. The event will be held at the Archifest Pavilion, designed by DP Architects, and offers various activities for attendees to engage with. The festival aims to promote architecture and urban planning in Singapore.

site_title: Indonesia may allow miners a further 3-5 years to build smelters: minister
summary: Indonesia's mining minister, Luhut Pandjaitan, announced that the country may allow miners an additional 3-5 years to complete smelter projects, potentially saving mining companies like US giant Freeport McMoRan Inc from permit revocation. This move comes as the government considers revising rules on the sector. Under the new plan, miners would have to pay an export tax in stages, tied to their smelter development progress. The relaxation would be a potential breakthrough for miners, who would otherwise have to stop exporting copper concentrate beyond January 2017.

site_title: Toyota, Daihatsu to set up joint emerging markets company
summary: Toyota and Daihatsu plan to establish a joint internal company to develop and market compact vehicles in emerging markets, aiming to expand market share in Asian markets. The new unit, set to launch in January, will be led by Daihatsu and focus on compact cars in Vietnam, India, and Pakistan. Toyota aims to develop Daihatsu into a global brand, focusing on energy-efficient entry-level compact cars. The companies will use existing production sites and leverage Daihatsu's existing market share in Indonesia and Malaysia.

site_title: Australian dollar unruffled by RBA, kiwi slightly firmer
summary: The Australian dollar remained near one-month highs despite the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to keep interest rates steady at 1.5%, as investors anticipated only a modest chance of a rate cut in the next month. The New Zealand dollar was slightly firmer, driven by strong business confidence and a lack of inflationary pressure. Futures markets imply a 24% chance of a rate cut in Australia by December, but economists argue the domestic economy doesn't need additional assistance.

site_title: Australia keeps interest rates on hold amid home building bonanza
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates at 1.5% amid a booming apartment building sector, which is underpinning economic activity and jobs growth. The decision was expected by economists, and the Australian dollar barely reacted. New home building approvals rose, with multi-unit approvals up 26% on August last year, and the economy expanded at a 3.3% annual pace in the year to June. The RBA's governor, Philip Lowe, signaled a bias to maintain rates, citing strong economic growth and rising commodity prices.

site_title: Hop on the Erdinger BARcycle
summary: Erdinger, the world's most popular wheat beer brand, introduces the BARcycle to Singapore at Oktoberfest. The mobile counter-top bar features a beer dispenser offering complimentary tasting portions of four Erdinger varieties. The 15-seater BARcycle moves from location to location, allowing party-goers to cycle while enjoying beer. Beer gardens will be set up at Suntec City, Clarke Quay Central, and The Star Vista, offering a German-style experience. The Erdinger BARcycle is open to those meeting the legal drinking age and can stay as long as desired.

images.alt_text: BARcycle.

site_title: Evergrande shares jump on subsidiary's Shenzhen backdoor listing
summary: Evergrande shares rose 8.8% on October 4, 2016, after the Chinese developer announced plans to spin off its Hengda Real Estate unit to a Shenzhen-listed company, providing a backdoor listing and an additional fund-raising platform. The deal would allow Evergrande to become the controlling shareholder of the Shenzhen-listed company, potentially improving valuations.

site_title: GIC, GSA investing in German student accommodation
summary: Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC and student accommodation operator GSA are partnering to invest in the German market. The partnership's cornerstone investment is a portfolio of around 1,000 student beds acquired by GSA in June 2016. Additionally, there's a pipeline of 1,500 beds in cities such as Frankfurt, Darmstadt, Munster, and Dresden. The exact dollar amount of the investment is not disclosed. This joint venture aims to expand GSA's presence in the German market.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit defies drop in Asian currencies on oil's rally
summary: Malaysia's ringgit strengthened 0.3% to 4.1240 per dollar, bucking a decline in Asian currencies, as Brent crude surged to a six-week high. The rally in oil prices offset concerns of a US interest-rate increase next month. The dollar strengthened for a second day, while US Treasuries fell after a report showed US manufacturing expanded in September. The ringgit's gain was attributed to oil price gains supporting the currency, while South Korea's won fell 0.2% to its third session of losses.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on foreign buying as Deutsche Bank woes ease
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.5% to 2,054.45 points on Tuesday, driven by foreign buying amid reduced concerns over Deutsche Bank's US fine. Analysts believe the issue has quieted down, and investors are placing bets on a settlement before the US presidential election. Samsung Electronics shares gained over 1%, while SK Hynix Inc rose 3% on expected positive earnings. The South Korean won traded slightly weaker against the US dollar.

site_title: Activist backer Quarz urges Singapore's Metro to return cash
summary: Activist investor Quarz Capital Management Ltd is urging Singapore's Metro Holdings Ltd to return excess cash to investors, citing the company's high net cash holdings and undervalued shares. Metro's net cash is over half its market capitalization, and its shares trade 40% below book value. Quarz recommends a one-time 21-cent dividend and clearer strategy for the real estate division to boost the company's share price. The fund, which manages $100 million, plans to target more Singaporean companies as the country's undervalued small and mid-cap firms become more attractive to investors.

site_title: Tokyo condo sales plunge to 1992-low in sign boom deflating
summary: Tokyo condo sales have plummeted to a 1992-low of 13,303 units in the first eight months of 2016, a 32% decline from last year, due to stagnant wages and rising interest rates. The Bank of Japan's easing policies have fueled the real estate boom, but its adoption of negative interest rates has misfired, hurting corporate profits and making companies cautious about raising wages. Experts warn that a slowdown in sales could deepen Japan's deflationary mindset, making it difficult to spur growth unless wages are boosted.

site_title: US apartment vacancy rate stays flat in third quarter
summary: The US apartment vacancy rate remained unchanged at 4.4% in the third quarter, according to Reis Inc. Rent growth decelerated to 0.9% year-over-year, the third consecutive quarter of slowing growth. New construction fell to 37,744 units, and net absorption totaled 37,693 units, the lowest level since mid-2013. Reis expects the national vacancy rate to increase and rent growth to remain muted below 4% until after the Presidential elections in November. The most expensive market was New York, with effective rents at $3,441 per unit per month.

site_title: Conservatives in one of Spain's biggest corruption trials
summary: Spain's ruling Popular Party faces intense scrutiny as 37 defendants, including former party treasurers, stand trial in the country's biggest corruption scandal, the Gurtel affair. Accused of receiving bribes and benefiting from illicit funds, the party may be asked to pay back the money, but faces no criminal charges. Former health minister Ana Mato and former economy minister Rodrigo Rato are also testifying in separate trials related to the scandal.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit defies drop in Asian currencies on oil's rally
summary: Malaysia's ringgit strengthened 0.3% to 4.1240 per US dollar, defying a decline in Asian currencies, as Brent crude surged to a six-week high. The rally in energy prices offset the prospect of a US interest-rate increase and supported the ringgit's value. The US dollar strengthened for a second day, and Treasuries fell after a report showed US manufacturing expanded in September. This bucked the trend of other Asian currencies, including the won, which fell 0.2% to 1,103.95.

site_title: Colombia war zones split over rejected peace deal
summary: Colombia's long-simmering conflict has taken a turn as a peace deal between the government and the Farc rebels was rejected by voters in a referendum, narrowly winning 49.78% to 50.22%. The deal, which granted the Farc amnesty and a pathway to politics, was deeply divided along rural-urban lines, with those who experienced the war firsthand voting in favor, while those who watched it on the news opposed it. The "No" vote was strongest in conservative areas, but some regions, such as rural areas with a strong Farc presence, surprisingly supported the deal.

images.alt_text: The areas hardest hit by Colombia's half-century conflict were deeply divided over a peace deal between the Farc rebels and the government rejected by voters in a shock referendum defeat.

site_title: Australia cracks down on rate riggers as bank chiefs grilled
summary: Australia has introduced new regulations making manipulating financial benchmarks a criminal offense, with penalties including jail time. The move aims to prevent past misconduct by major lenders, including the country's largest banks, in setting rates for financial products. The regulations will come into effect in January 2018 and apply to banks bill swap rates, equity indexes, and Treasury Bond Futures settlement prices. The new rules follow allegations of benchmark interest rate-rigging by the country's big four lenders, including Westpac, ANZ, and National Australia Bank, which have been charged over the issue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares add to gains at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.34% on Tuesday, edging up 80.92 points to 23,665.35, following the release of US manufacturing data showing a September rebound. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for the National Day holiday.

site_title: South Korea growth on track for 2.8% expansion this year
summary: South Korea's economy appears on track to achieve its 2.8% growth target for this year, despite a prolonged slump in exports. Domestic demand is rebounding, but a strike at a carmaker has restrained production. The vice finance minister stated that current growth trajectory aligns with initial estimates, despite risks ahead. This positive outlook suggests that South Korea's economic growth is not severely impacted by the export slump.

images.alt_text: South Korea's vice finance minister said on Tuesday the domestic economy appears to be on track to achieve the government's 2.8 per cent growth target for this year despite a prolonged slump in exports.

site_title: Gold heads for longest retreat in five weeks on US rate view
summary: Gold prices declined for a sixth consecutive day, the longest losing streak since August 26, as the US dollar strengthened on speculation of a potential interest rate hike this year. The metal traded at $1,311.09 an ounce, down from Monday's close. Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Loretta Mester said the economy is ripe for a rate increase, boosting the probability of a December rate hike to 61%. This has led to a decline in gold prices, with investors viewing the metal as less attractive due to the lack of interest payments.

site_title: China's foreign trade still faces big downward pressure: Xinhua
summary: China's foreign trade continues to face significant downward pressure, despite some improvement in August, according to the Ministry of Commerce. The downward pressure is described as "big, uncertain, and unstable," with 20 countries and regions launching 85 investigations into China's exports, valued at $10.3 billion, a 94% increase from last year. China's imports unexpectedly rose in August, while exports showed signs of improvement, but trade frictions with major partners, including the US, remain a concern, putting the country's economy under pressure.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise, Hon Hai falls after unit issues profit warning
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.3% to 9,265.31, driven by gains in banking and technology shares. However, Hon Hai Precision Industry Co fell 0.1% after unit FIH Mobile warned of a more than 50% decline in consolidated net profit due to weaker sales. The Taiwan dollar softened to T$31.333 per US dollar.

site_title: Clinton seizes offensive as woes mount for Trump
summary: US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton seized the offensive against Donald Trump, branding him an unscrupulous businessman after his charitable foundation was ordered to cease fundraising activities in New York. Trump's tax record was also under scrutiny after a leaked report suggested he may have paid no income tax for up to 18 years. Clinton criticized Trump's business practices and accused him of being unfit to be Commander-in-Chief, while Trump continued to attack Clinton's loyalty to her husband Bill. The election is just five weeks away, with polls showing Clinton leading Trump in several key states.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% higher on Tuesday, advancing 5.78 points to 2,876.62, with about 37.3 million shares changing hands worth S$36.5 million. The top stocks by value traded were Singtel, DBS, and UOB. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gains outnumbering losses 76 to 62.

site_title: Shale oil firms hedge 2017 prices in 'droves' on Opec rally
summary: US shale oil companies are hedging their 2017 prices in "droves" as crude futures surge after Opec's output cut agreement, with the WTI 2017 calendar strip rising above $50 a barrel to its highest since August. This trend is expected to offset an output cut, potentially leading to higher US oil production next year. Major oil companies, including Pioneer Natural Resources, have already locked in prices for up to 55% of their 2017 exposure, with some producers expecting to hedge more as prices rise.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher as US production picks up
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on October 4, 2016, after US data showed a rebound in the manufacturing sector, boosting investor sentiment. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.28% and the Topix index rose 0.17%. The positive start followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data and a strong performance in the US stock market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore junk bonds slump as Swissco seeks restructuring
summary: Singapore's junk-bond market is experiencing its worst rout in at least four years due to debt restructurings among shipping and oil-and-gas service companies. High-yield notes in the local currency slid 1.9% last quarter, with Swissco Holdings Ltd seeking restructuring of S$100 million of notes. The company plans to refinance debt with an optimised structure, while other firms such as PT Trikomsel Oke and AusGroup Ltd are facing payment defaults. The government has tightened oversight of private banks amid a global oil and shipping slump.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance as Japanese shares climb amid weaker yen
summary: Asian stocks rose, with Japanese shares climbing 0.6% amid a weaker yen. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index added 0.1% as US manufacturing data showed expansion, boosting optimism over the US economy. The odds of a Fed rate hike in December increased to 61%, and markets are watching for a key jobs report on Friday. Oil prices halted gains, holding near a three-month high, while Hong Kong's benchmark equity gauge rose 1.2% on Monday.

site_title: Singapore millionaire, 77, joins bondholders uniting in workouts
summary: A group of bondholders in Singapore, including a 77-year-old millionaire, Jerry Tan, have joined forces to demand immediate payment on millions of dollars of notes issued by struggling companies. The move comes as Singapore's reputation as a major financial hub is shaken by defaults and restructuring proposals. The group, which includes housewives and former traders, is seeking protection for investors and is calling on the authorities to step up oversight of private banks. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has pledged to boost investor safeguards by year-end.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.59 points to 1658.36 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 56.7 million lots worth RM27.18 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 120 to 59.

site_title: Goldcorp shuts biggest gold mine after week-long blockade
summary: Goldcorp Inc has temporarily shut down its Peñasquito gold mine in Mexico due to a week-long blockade by a trucking contractor. The blockade, sparked by the contractor's concerns over efficiency improvements, has prevented the mine from bringing in food, water, and fuel for the 750 people on site. Goldcorp expects the mine to produce 520,000-580,000 ounces of gold this year, and a restart is expected once the dispute is resolved. The shutdown has sent Goldcorp's shares down nearly 5%.

site_title: Microsoft CEO Nadella received US$18m in 2016 pay
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella's compensation fell 3.3% to $17.7 million in the software maker's latest fiscal year, ending June 30. Nadella received $5.66 million in salary and bonus, and a $12 million stock award. His annual stock grant is tied to targets, including revenue and commercial cloud subscribers, and will vest in 2018 or 2019 depending on performance. This change was made after more than a quarter of shareholders rejected Microsoft's executive compensation program at its last two annual meetings.

site_title: Australia shares recoil ahead of RBA decision; NZ eases
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, dragged down by financial stocks, ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 20.81 points to 5,457.7. The central bank is expected to hold its cash rate at a record low of 1.5% at its meeting.

site_title: US dollar extends longest winning streak against yen since August
summary: The US dollar extended its winning streak against the yen to its longest since August, rising 0.3% to 101.65 yen, amid positive US manufacturing data. The data showed US manufacturing expanded in September, boosting bets for a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase by December to 60%. Futures prices compiled by Bloomberg indicate the likelihood of a rate hike has increased to 51%, with economists predicting a "significant surprise" would be needed for substantial market movement.

site_title: China: Stock market closed for National Day holiday Oct 1-9
summary: China's stock market is closed from Oct 1-9 for the National Day holiday, resuming trade on Oct 10. The southbound portion of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme is also shut from Sept 29-10.

site_title: Grumpy Cat immortalised in wax, makes Broadway debut
summary: Grumpy Cat, a 4-year-old internet sensation known for her scowl, made her Broadway debut as a guest of honor at the musical Cats. She posed for photos with a wax replica of herself at Madame Tussauds and received a commemorative placard at the show's curtain call. Grumpy Cat's viral fame began in 2012 after her permanent scowl became meme-worthy, and she has since appeared in a Lifetime movie and merchandise.

site_title: Jack Ma in Indonesia shows e-commerce growth potential
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has sought guidance from Chinese e-commerce mogul Jack Ma to boost the country's e-commerce market, valued at $2 billion. Ma's involvement comes as the country's digital economy is projected to add $150 billion to GDP by 2025. Widodo's efforts aim to capitalize on Indonesia's growing consumer potential, with the country expected to be one of the fastest-growing e-commerce markets in the world. Ma's expertise is seen as crucial in helping Indonesia's administration supercharge online retailing.

site_title: Pound holds near three-decade low amid fears of 'hard' Brexit
summary: The pound holds near a three-decade low after UK Prime Minister Theresa May announced the UK's withdrawal from the European Union in the first quarter of 2017, sparking fears of a 'hard' Brexit with limited access to the EU's single market. Sterling is the worst performer this year among 16 major currencies, and May's pledge to curb immigration has raised concerns about the Brexit timeline.

site_title: Japanese companies' inflation expectations drop, adding to BOJ's struggle
summary: Japanese companies have lowered their inflation expectations, with forecasts of 0.6% inflation in one year and 1% in three years, down from previous projections. This trend underscores the challenges faced by Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda in achieving the central bank's two% inflation target. The drop in inflation expectations adds to the BOJ's struggle to stimulate economic growth and control inflation.

images.alt_text: Japanese companies cut their forecasts for inflation for coming years, underscoring the difficulty Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda faces as he struggles to hit the central bank's price target of two per cent.

site_title: Los Angeles police defend weekend fatal shootings of black men
summary: Los Angeles Police Chief Charlie Beck defended the actions of officers involved in two fatal shootings of black men, 18-year-old Carnell Snell Jr and 25-year-old Michael Flynn, over the weekend. Snell Jr allegedly pointed a handgun at officers chasing him after he exited a suspected stolen car and fled. A photo of the fully loaded handgun was displayed by Beck, which he claimed was removed from Snell Jr's waistband during the 200-300 yard foot pursuit. The police chief's defense sparked protests and raised tensions in the city.

images.alt_text: Los Angeles police chief Charlie Beck on Monday defended the actions of officers involved in two fatal shootings of black men over the weekend that touched off protests and raised tensions.

site_title: Chinese gasoline heads to New York for first time in nine years
summary: Chinese gasoline is set to reach the US East Coast for the first time in nine years, with Trafigura Group Pte shipping 375,000 barrels from China and Hong Kong aboard the tanker Marylebone. The surge in New York prices has helped alleviate a glut in Asia. This delivery marks a significant milestone in the trade of Chinese gasoline in the US, following a nine-year hiatus.

site_title: Canada closes tax loopholes to cool housing market
summary: Canada's government has implemented new tax rules to combat real estate speculation, particularly by foreign investors. The changes will require foreign buyers to pay a 50% tax on profits from the sale of a home unless they lived in it as their primary residence. This measure aims to cool the housing markets in Toronto and Vancouver, where prices have risen 31% and 17% respectively. The government has also introduced new stress tests for mortgage lenders and tougher loan eligibility criteria. The changes take effect on October 17.

site_title: New Zealand house prices continue to rise in September: QV
summary: New Zealand house prices rose 14.3% in the year to September, according to Quotable Value, despite new lending restrictions for investors. The index is now 49.5% above its 2007 peak. House prices in Auckland rose 15% in the year, with demand in the Auckland, Hamilton, and Tauranga markets showing little sign of slowing. The new LVR restrictions, which require a 40% deposit for investment purchases, have failed to curb value growth in these areas.

site_title: South Korea's August current account surplus falls to 4-month low
summary: South Korea's seasonally adjusted current account surplus declined to $5.79 billion in August, the lowest in 4 months. Exports rose 2.2% to $43.22 billion, while imports jumped 12.8% to $35.34 billion, resulting in a goods account surplus of $7.9 billion. This decline marks the second consecutive month of decrease in the country's current account surplus.

site_title: Oil halts gain near 3-month high as US inventories seen rising
summary: Oil futures halted a four-day gain near a three-month high as US crude inventories are expected to rise, halting a 9.3% gain in the last four sessions. US crude stockpiles likely increased by 1.75 million barrels last week, according to a Bloomberg survey. Libyan production rose to 500,000 barrels a day and will increase further this month, contributing to the recent gains. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to trim supply for the first time in eight years, leading to the highest monthly gain in five months.

site_title: US to press WTO to enforce ruling on Airbus subsidies
summary: The US Trade Representative plans a special meeting at the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on October 14 to enforce a WTO panel report finding the European Union guilty of maintaining illegal subsidies to Airbus. The US will press for the WTO to formally adopt the findings, which could lead to retaliatory duties of up to $10 billion a year against the European Union. The US claims Airbus received $22 billion in illegal support, and the European Union has the right to appeal the ruling, which also allows it to pursue complaints against US support for Boeing.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up as fund managers advance; FTSE outperforms
summary: European stock markets made minor gains on Monday, driven by a rise in fund management company shares after a large merger. Britain's FTSE 100 rose 1.2% to a 16-month high, while the pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended up 0.1%. However, concerns over Deutsche Bank's financial woes, including a potential $14 billion fine, weighed on some investors. Despite this, shares in fund management companies rose, with Henderson Global Investors agreeing to a $6 billion merger with Janus Capital.

site_title: Trudeau unveils Canada carbon price plan for 2018
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a national minimum carbon price of C$10 per tonne in 2018 to meet the country's Paris accord commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2030. The federal government will set a floor price for carbon pollution, with each province having a choice in implementation, such as imposing a carbon tax or adopting a cap-and-trade system. Opposition parties and several provinces have pushed back, citing concerns over the economic impact. The move aims to reduce Canada's 1.95% of global emissions, currently at 700 million tonnes per year.

site_title: Why Asean is failing
summary: Asean, a 10-nation Association of South-east Asian Nations, is failing to meet its economic and security aspirations, contrary to its grand declarations. Despite potential, intra-Asean trade lags behind EU levels, and regulatory barriers hinder the use of technology and finance. The region lacks effective leadership, with no single country wielding significant influence, and decision-making is often plagued by institutional paralysis. To turn the tide, regional leaders must examine the reasons for Asean's failure and take concrete steps to boost trade, services, and people movement.

site_title: North Korean missile advances expose Japan in two-decade arms race: sources
summary: North Korea has significantly advanced its missile capabilities, leaving Japan uncertain about its ability to defend itself against a potential strike without US assistance. Since the start of 2016, North Korea has test-fired 21 ballistic missiles, including a recent successful test of the Musudan rocket, which can reach a range of 3,000km. Japan's current ballistic missile defense system is insufficient to counter this threat, and the country may need to rely on the US for help, with planned upgrades not due until 2020.

site_title: US auto sales decline in September
summary: US auto sales declined 0.5% in September, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 17.8 million units, according to Autodata. Ford saw the largest decline, with 8% fewer vehicles sold. Toyota posted a 1.5% year-on-year gain, while General Motors reported a 0.6% decline. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles saw a 3% rise, and Volkswagen's sales fell 7.8%. Tesla delivered 24,500 vehicles in its third quarter, a 70% increase. Vehicle sales are seen as a key indicator of consumer spending in the US economy.

site_title: APBS has good savings
summary: Asia Pacific Breweries Singapore (APBS) has won the Best Practices category at the EENP Awards 2016 for its substantial effort in analyzing and retrofitting its process cooling plant to make it more energy efficient. The project resulted in annual energy savings of 1.25 Gigawatt hour, with the company aiming to reduce its energy cost and deliver high-quality products at a reasonable price. APBS has implemented various energy-saving measures, including a vapour recovery system, LED motion sensor technology, and upgrading its equipment, resulting in a 35% reduction in energy consumption for its cooling plant.

site_title: Editor's note
summary: Sat Pal Khattar, the current Chief Minister of Haryana, faced financial challenges in his youth, including interrupted education to help his father in a sporting goods business. However, no relevant information is provided about his current career or the provided articles do not pertain to Sat Pal Khattar.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries maintained a "Hold" rating with a target price of S$2.40. The company's stock closed at S$2.57 on October 3, 2023.

site_title: Harnessing the bright spot
summary: Franklin Templeton's Grant Bowers discusses the US market, citing Asia's role in driving and benefiting from dollar asset diversification. This trend is expected to continue, driven by retail investors' growth in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, while de-dollarization and shifting safe havens are also on the horizon. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind the US market.

site_title: September manfacturing expands slightly after August contraction
summary: US manufacturing expanded slightly in September after a contraction in August, with the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) index rising to 51.5 from 49.4. This marks the first growth in six months, with a reading above 50 signaling growth. The modest expansion indicates limited progress for the battered sector.

site_title: US: Stocks fall despite gains for Netflix, Twitter
summary: US stocks declined on the first day of the fourth quarter, falling 0.3% to 18,253.85. Despite gains for Netflix (4.1%) and Twitter (4.1%) due to takeover speculation, other stocks such as Tenet Healthcare (-4.0%) and eBay (-1.0%) also fell. Meanwhile, Tesla Motors surged 4.7% after delivering more than expected vehicles in the third quarter, and Twenty-First Century Fox rose 1.7% after its film led the US box office. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also declined, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.2%.

site_title: Corporate teams raise over S$23,000 for charity at OCBC Cycle
summary: Teams from 12 Singaporean organizations participated in the OCBC Cycle Corporate Bike Ride, raising S$23,195 for four charities. The event, part of the OCBC Cycle's charity partnership program, saw 6,800 cyclists participate in various events. The charities supported by the event included The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, SportCares, the Dyslexia Association of Singapore, and NUHS Fund Limited. The event aimed to promote cycling as a form of leisure and transportation, with the goal of getting more Singaporeans active.

site_title: Global inequality on the wane: World Bank study
summary: A new World Bank study found that global inequality has declined consistently since 1990, despite the global economy's slowdown. Extreme poverty worldwide continues to fall, especially in East Asia, but the study warns that continued anaemic growth could reverse the trend. The report notes that nearly 800 million people lived on under $1.90 a day in 2013, but this number has decreased by 100 million. The World Bank aims to end extreme poverty by 2030, but cautions that inequality remains a significant concern.

site_title: CAAS surplus for FY16 dips 4.9% to S$62.7m
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) reported a 4.9% decrease in net surplus to S$62.7 million for FY2016, its third consecutive year. Expenditure increased 17.2% to S$348.7 million, with other operating expenses rising 41.2% to S$56.9 million. Despite a 9.8% increase in income to S$408.5 million, the regulator has not yet tapped a S$3 billion fund set aside for Changi Airport expansion.

site_title: Industry sector steps up efforts to boost energy efficiency
summary: Singapore's industry sector steps up efforts to boost energy efficiency, with businesses adopting various approaches to reduce energy costs and carbon footprint. The National Environment Agency's (NEA) Energy Efficiency National Partnership (EENP) programme aims to support companies in their energy efficiency efforts through learning networks, resources, and incentives. As of September 2016, 234 companies have joined the EENP programme, which includes energy efficiency technical workshops and benchmarking studies. The EENP Awards recognize companies that adopt robust energy management practices, with winners such as Molex Singapore and Panasonic Appliances Refrigeration Devices Singapore.

site_title: All-round partnership
summary: UBS' Gan Seow Ann emphasizes the importance of understanding clients to provide effective wealth management solutions. Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. Meanwhile, a low-profile property trust is investing in data centers, and Jack Ma-backed Ant plans to add a stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are anticipated to drive 'massive' ETF growth in Asia and Europe, according to Amundi. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, with some speculating that the worst of the trade war is behind us. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation.

site_title: World Bank indirectly funding Asia 'coal boom': advocacy group
summary: The World Bank is indirectly funding Asia's "coal boom" through financial intermediaries, despite its 2013 commitment to end support for coal-fired power generation. Since then, 41 coal projects have received funding from the International Finance Corporation (IFC), which has invested over $15 billion in renewable energy. The IFC's policy does not prohibit funding coal plants, and the institution may be indirectly exposed to the industry. The report highlights the issue as the World Bank's annual meetings coincide with the start of this week's high-profile gatherings.

site_title: Small Japan firms dying out as successors elude ageing owners
summary: Japan's small firms, many of which are family-owned, are dying out as their ageing owners struggle to find successors, with 26,700 firms shutting down voluntarily last fiscal year. The average age of company owners has reached an all-time high of 59.2 years, with two-thirds lacking successors. This trend is hindering the country's economy, which is facing a prolonged low growth, and could lead to industrial hollowing out and hamper technology transfer, according to analysts.

site_title: SGX raps KLW, two former key executives
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded KLW Holdings and two former key executives for breaches of Catalist rules, following a 2015 special audit that found lapses in internal controls and potential disclosure rule violations. The case has been referred to the relevant authorities, including the Commercial Affairs Department, which is investigating the company for an alleged offense under the Securities and Futures Act. This reprimand is the latest development in the ongoing saga surrounding KLW Holdings.

site_title: Traders await Deutsche Bank news
summary: Traders remained cautious on Monday due to uncertainty surrounding Deutsche Bank's fate. The Straits Times Index gained 1.37 points to 2,870.84, driven by a 20-point rise in Dow futures. Turnover was low, with 1 billion units traded for S$613 million. Singtel led the gains, while QT Vascular, SunMoon Food, Ying Li, Alliance Mineral, and Cedar Strategic also saw increases. The market is awaiting further developments on Deutsche Bank before making any significant moves.

site_title: China's luxury tax cut is skin deep for Korean cosmetics
summary: China has cut its luxury tax on cosmetics to 15% from 30%, benefiting South Korean skin-care companies like Amorepacific and LG Household, which have seen a surge in Chinese buying. However, many Chinese buyers are still traveling to Korea to shop, where they spend money on higher-margin products and support domestic sales. The tax cut may further cement Korean brands' popularity in China, but it could also lead to a decrease in overseas travel by Chinese buyers.

site_title: Law and more
summary: Sat Pal Khattar, founder of Khattar Wong, is transitioning from a law career to investing, building his legacy. Key articles include Asia driving dollar asset diversification, a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, and Jack Ma-backed Ant planning to add a stablecoin to its global network. Productivity gains are seen as crucial for wealth creation, while markets continue to rise despite trade tensions and de-dollarisation concerns. Retail investors are expected to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe, according to Amundi. These trends indicate a shift in the global investment landscape.

site_title: Why the US vice-presidential debate matters to the world
summary: The US vice-presidential debate between Indiana Governor Mike Pence and Senator Tim Kaine on October 4, 2016, has significant implications for the election outcome and US domestic and foreign policy. The increased status of the vice-presidency, coupled with the relatively old age of major party presidential nominees Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, elevates the possibility of a vice-president assuming the presidency upon the incumbent's death or incapacity. Both Pence and Kaine have the potential to play influential roles in the next few years, and their performance in the debate will showcase their capabilities as future leaders.

site_title: Beware of the private equity greed trap
summary: Investors are pouring into Asia's private equity firms, with $34.7 billion invested in the region this year, up from $32.2 billion in the same period in 2015. This influx comes despite existing funds totaling a record $208 billion in September. The surge in private equity investments is driven by low interest rates worldwide, attracting investors seeking high returns.

site_title: London unicorn galloping into Singapore soon
summary: TransferWise, a UK billion-dollar fintech start-up, is set to launch its remittance business in Singapore, following regulatory approval. This move comes after Stripe's debut in the country. The payments market is experiencing growth, with investments in fintech companies on the rise. Meanwhile, Singapore's OCBC has announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers, and Chinese banks are struggling with Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: EU won't negotiate Brexit before formal notification by London
summary: The European Commission stated it will cooperate with the UK on EU exit terms only after London formally notifies the EU of its intention to leave by the end of March. British Prime Minister Theresa May announced this timeline, triggering the process. The EU Commission's decision aims to establish a clear framework for negotiations.

site_title: Pimco: Asia debt at risk as dollar bond sales hit record
summary: Asia-Pacific debt issuance surged 66% year-over-year to a record $152 billion in the last quarter, driven by investors seeking yield amid low interest rates. However, Pimco warns of rising debt levels and credit risks, citing median net debt at listed firms at 3.1 times earnings before interest. Analysts express concerns over the sustainability of growth and the potential for default risks, particularly among local government funding vehicles and Chinese developers with high leverage levels.

site_title: Seattle, Vancouver seek to deepen tech, economic ties
summary: Seattle and Vancouver, two Pacific Northwest coastal cities, are seeking to deepen their economic and tech ties. The cities' political and academic elites aim to foster a "Cascadia innovation corridor," which could attract US tech companies and create jobs. Microsoft has already invested $120 million in a new Vancouver office, and plans to hire nearly 750 Canadians. The cities are also exploring ways to reduce traffic between them, including a proposed high-speed rail line and a dedicated autonomous vehicle lane.

images.alt_text: Microsoft says it invested US$120 million in its new offices in Vancouver, which opened in June, and expects to spend US$90 million more annually on wages and other operating costs.

site_title: Major Indian companies increasing investments in rupee bonds
summary: Indian companies are increasing investments in rupee bonds, joining traditional buyers like banks and mutual funds. This emergence will help broaden and deepen the bond market. Major companies are attracted to the attractive yields, which can generate decent trading income. The increase in investments is expected to benefit the bond market, as blue-chip companies join traditional buyers.

site_title: Ex-Brazil agent Skornicki's transactions 'may be suspicious', says Keppel
summary: Keppel Corporation fell 1.7% after acknowledging that a former Brazil agent's transactions may be suspicious, potentially involving bribery and corruption. The firm is investigating allegations that Skornicki, arrested in Brazil, made illegal payments on contracts with Petrobras and Sete Brasil. Keppel has notified authorities and reiterated its commitment to resolving the issue, but no formal charges have been filed against the company or its employees.

site_title: German Centre recognised for its push to save energy
summary: The German Centre for Trade and Industry in Singapore has received the Excellence in Energy Management award for its efforts in implementing energy efficiency measures. The centre has achieved significant energy savings of 38% over two years, with annual cost savings of S$177,692, and aims to raise awareness of energy conservation and reduce environmental impact. With senior management support, the centre has established an energy management team and implemented measures such as LED lighting, resulting in a more sustainable and cost-effective operation.

site_title: US tax crackdown
summary: The US is intensifying its tax crackdown, potentially targeting Singapore after its success against Switzerland. The move aims to curb offshore tax evasion and increase revenue. Meanwhile, Asia is driving and benefiting from dollar asset diversification. The US stock market hit a record high, with some analysts attributing it to the end of the trade war's worst phase. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarisation is on the rise as investors shift safe havens. The US tax crackdown may also impact the growth of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Japan's Ohsumi wins Nobel Prize for cell 'recycling' work
summary: Yoshinori Ohsumi, a 71-year-old Japanese professor, won the 2016 Nobel Prize in Medicine for his pioneering work on autophagy, a process by which cells "eat themselves." His discoveries have led to a new understanding of how cells recycle damaged parts, with major implications for health and disease, including Parkinson's and diabetes. Ohsumi's work has opened the path to understanding autophagy's importance in various physiological processes and has sparked intense research to develop drugs targeting autophagy in diseases.

site_title: ExxonMobil confirms LNG bunkering tie-up with Pavilion Energy
summary: ExxonMobil has confirmed a partnership with Pavilion Energy to develop LNG bunkering solutions in Singapore, combining expertise in LNG shipping and terminal operations. The collaboration aims to establish ExxonMobil's global LNG bunkering offer and support Pavilion in establishing LNG bunkering procedures. This partnership follows Pavilion's emergence as one of Singapore's first LNG bunkering licensees, and comes as Singapore aims to become the world's top bunkering hub for LNG as an alternative fuel.

site_title: In a class of its own
summary: Global Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) are well-positioned to outperform other asset classes, with infrastructure serving as a reliable portfolio diversifier. Asia is driving and benefiting from dollar asset diversification. Meanwhile, a low-profile property trust is expanding its data centre operations, and Jack Ma's Ant is set to add a stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are expected to drive massive growth in Asia and Europe's ETF market. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and markets are rising despite concerns over trade wars and de-dollarisation.

site_title: IE Singapore calls on oil & gas firms to grab LNG opportunities
summary: IE Singapore urges oil and gas companies to tap into the growing liquified natural gas (LNG) sector, citing opportunities driven by population growth, urbanization, and a transition to cleaner fuels. The country expects demand for natural gas to increase, with Singapore's LNG Terminal set to increase capacity to 11 million tonnes annually by 2017. Despite challenges, IE Singapore is partnering companies to develop LNG capabilities and providing access to financing and customers. LNG is expected to account for 30% of the global energy mix by 2035, according to BP Energy Outlook.

site_title: Britain's finance sector at odds over Brexit lobbying
summary: The UK's finance sector is divided over who should lead Brexit lobbying efforts, potentially hindering the industry's ability to retain access to Europe's single market. Large banks are concerned about conflicting voices and a proliferation of lobby groups, which could damage the industry's reputation. A new lobbying group, the Financial Services Negotiation Forum, aims to bridge the divide between big banks and smaller firms. The industry is seeking a transitional period of up to five years after Brexit to negotiate new trading terms, but experts warn of complex issues and potential disruption to markets.

site_title: Job cuts mount as Asian investment banking fees slide
summary: Global banks are scaling back their Asian investment banking operations due to declining advisory fees and increased local competition. Goldman Sachs and Bank of America Merrill Lynch are cutting jobs in response, with fee data showing a 23% slump in equity underwriting revenues in the Asia-Pacific region this year. Chinese banks are gaining market share, offering lower fees, and Western banks are struggling to maintain their presence. Despite this, debt capital markets remain stable, with fees on G3 bond sales rising 14% from last year.

site_title: ExxonMobil focuses on continuous improvements
summary: ExxonMobil has won two awards at the Energy Efficiency National Partnership (EENP) awards for its Singapore refinery and chemical plant projects. The refinery project resulted in annual savings of over S$2 million, while the chemical plant project achieved annual cost savings of about S$9.5 million. ExxonMobil attributes its focus on continuous improvements to reducing emissions and its business, using technologies such as model predictive control and cogeneration facilities. The company has also improved energy efficiency at its facilities by 17% and 21% over the past 12 years, equivalent to removing 290,000 cars from Singapore roads.

site_title: Growing stability seen in HDB resale market
summary: HDB resale prices remained flat in the third quarter, marking the second consecutive quarter of stability. The resale price index is 9.8% below its peak in 2013. Experts attribute the stability to the "dry powder" in the market and sellers' willingness to sell at current prices, with many hoping to buy private homes, which have become more affordable. The HDB resale index is expected to see its lowest yearly price fall in three years, and interest rate concerns are deemed unlikely to impact the public housing market significantly.

site_title: Lapse in RTO deal sends Saizen Reit tumbling
summary: A lapse in the framework agreement for a reverse takeover (RTO) of Saizen Reit by Malaysian conglomerate Sime Darby sent the Reit's units plummeting 27% to 4.3 Singapore cents, a 52-week low, after 7.13 million shares changed hands on Monday.

site_title: Seeking visible yields
summary: Fixed maturity investing combines the stability of direct bond portfolios with the potential of active management, offering a visible yield. This strategy allows investors to benefit from both the predictable returns of fixed income investments and the active management of portfolio managers. By adopting this approach, investors can potentially increase their yields and diversify their portfolios.

site_title: Slow economy leaning on private home prices
summary: Singapore's private home prices dropped 1.5% in Q3, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimates, worse than expected by analysts. The decline erases hopes of the market bottoming out after several quarters of mild price declines. Analysts attribute the drop to fears of an approaching recession, rising unemployment, and the impact of the government's revised GDP growth forecast. The URA's new rule requiring developers to submit net prices of units sold from delicensed projects also contributed to the price decline, particularly in high-end homes.

site_title: Riding high in Asia
summary: Asian markets are rebounding, and experts predict this trend will continue. Dollar asset diversification is expected to drive growth, with Asia both contributing to and benefiting from this trend. A low-profile property trust is investing in data centers, and Jack Ma's Ant is set to add a stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are expected to drive massive growth in ETFs in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, while de-dollarization and shifting safe havens may contribute to market rises. The S&P 500 has reached a record high.

site_title: Arts' highest honour for two veterans
summary: Singapore's Cultural Medallion, the country's highest arts honor, has been awarded to movie and music legend Nona, 86, and master of Chinese calligraphy Koh Mun Hong, 64. Nona, a renowned Malay entertainment figure from the 1940s to 1960s, will receive the award alongside Koh Mun Hong, who has exhibited his work extensively and won several prizes for his delicate ink paintings. The recipients will receive grants to continue their artistic practices, with Nona and Koh Mun Hong set to receive the award at a ceremony on October 4.

site_title: Leung pledges more land for cheaper HK housing
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-Ying pledged to provide more land for affordable housing, citing the city's underdeveloped land as a reason for high housing prices. Less than 25% of Hong Kong's land has been developed, making it difficult to meet demand. Leung emphasized the need to prioritize affordable housing, stating it is the city's "absolute No 1 priority." He acknowledged potential traffic issues but prioritized safety concerns, particularly in sub-divided apartments. The move aims to address the city's housing shortage and lower prices.

site_title: Kalahari dreams
summary: The Tswalu reserve, a conservation effort in South Africa, is giving the desert a fresh start. This initiative is focused on revitalizing the ravaged Kalahari desert.

site_title: Intac banks on collaborative culture
summary: Intac Systems Solution Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based integrated building service solutions provider, credits its remarkable growth to a collaborative culture founded by its executive chairman and founder, Tan Kooi Jin. The company's flat organization structure emphasizes respect, honesty, and hard work, and fosters open communication and teamwork. To maintain this culture, Intac provides opportunities for employee growth, offers bonuses and benefits, and organizes company retreats. The company's success has earned it numerous awards, and it plans to expand into other South-east Asia countries, including the Philippines.

site_title: Chinese cities introduce curbs to cool home prices
summary: Chinese cities have introduced curbs on home purchases to cool prices, following the country's highest six-year rise in August. Nine cities, including Beijing, Chengdu, and Suzhou, have implemented measures such as higher downpayment requirements and restrictions on second homes. These measures aim to curb excessive speculation and asset bubbles, despite home prices still rising. Local governments will work out their own measures to address the property market, according to economist Iris Pang.

site_title: On-water prestige
summary: Luxury yachts are taking the sailing experience to new heights, offering a prestigious experience that combines style, comfort, and adventure. The high-end vessels cater to those seeking an exclusive and immersive experience on the water.

site_title: Sterling hits 3-year low vs euro as Brexit deadline set
summary: Sterling hits a three-year low against the euro and US dollar after British Prime Minister Theresa May sets a March deadline for the formal process to split Britain from the European Union, sparking concerns about a "hard" Brexit. The pound fell 1% against the dollar to $1.2845 and 1% against the euro to 87.48 pence, its weakest since 2013. Analysts say May's comments suggest Britain may abandon the EU's customs union and single market, fueling uncertainty.

site_title: Expanding into India: If not now, when?
summary: Singaporean businesses are considering expanding into India, but few have taken the leap, despite the country's promising growth and market potential. India's economic reforms and strategic partnership with Singapore offer opportunities for trade, investment, and skills development. With a projected 7.4% GDP growth and a young, consuming population, India presents an attractive future for businesses. To succeed, Singapore companies should focus on leveraging their strengths, such as urban development and infrastructure expertise, and partner with local firms and international banks. With India's diversity and scale, Singapore companies can learn and appreciate the country's unique processes, and India can benefit from Singapore's efficiency and systematic approach.

site_title: Amazon counting on Diwali to take title as India's top Web retailer
summary: Amazon aims to become India's top online retailer by Diwali, with 80 million products and 120,000+ merchants. The company targets dormant shoppers and first-time buyers, with a $3 billion investment, as major rivals Flipkart and Snapdeal face a critical test. India's online sales are expected to reach $80-100 billion by 2020, with Amazon potentially selling $81 billion by 2025. Amazon's Diwali tagline, "tyohar bade diwala," aims to lure online shoppers, and the company's efforts may decide the future of India's online shopping market.

site_title: Q3 property investment sales slip in absence of Q2's Asia Square deal
summary: Singapore's property investment sales declined in Q3, primarily due to the absence of the S$3.4 billion Asia Square Tower 1 sale in Q2. However, property consultants expect a rosy forecast for the full year, with deals including the URA tender closing for Central Boulevard, the sale of 77 Robinson Rd, and a half stake in Capital Square. Despite the Q3 drop, the market is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf benchmark with a wave of condo launches in Q4.

site_title: Brexit's three silver linings for the European Union
summary: The UK's exit from the European Union, known as Brexit, presents an opportunity for the EU to strengthen itself. Despite the UK's significant economic contribution, the EU will still be the world's second-largest economic bloc, with a projected 9% share of the world economy by 2050. The EU can capitalize on the uncertainty by promoting its cities and attracting top talent, investing in smart integration, and implementing regulatory changes that benefit EU citizens. This could lead to a stronger, more competitive EU and boost popular support for the union.

site_title: Corporate Japan signals lack of positive economic prospects
summary: The Bank of Japan's Tankan survey revealed a flat outlook for corporate Japan's prospects, with a key index measuring confidence among leading manufacturers staying flat at plus 6. This suggests that a strong yen and poor demand prospects will restrict sales and profits until the end of the year. The survey also showed that domestic demand remains lukewarm, with non-manufacturing sectors projecting weak business conditions. The report's findings are unlikely to ease pressure on the government to increase wage settlements, and the BOJ's monetary measures may add to the risks faced by financial institutions.

site_title: High-tech way to find talent
summary: TalentDash CEO James Galvin has developed a high-tech recruitment platform to help startups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) find talent. Galvin, who has co-founded and invested in several startups, acknowledges that hiring and recruiting is a significant time-consuming task for founders. His platform aims to streamline this process and provide a solution for the recruitment woes faced by founders.

images.alt_text: "We focus on the scan of the talent pool. We don't even connect with the candidates through phone screening or anything like that. What this means is that our focus is on the thoroughness of the knowledge. From there, we give your team the tools to reach out." - James Galvin on his talent-mapping platform TalentDash which allows companies to locate, aggregate and visualise talent pool information

site_title: A winner's views on optimising energy use
summary: Mohamed Shahril Bin Jaffar, manager of Panasonic Appliances Refrigeration Devices Singapore, emphasizes the importance of optimizing energy use in the manufacturing industry. He suggests categorizing energy consumption into fixed and variable energy, and implementing energy-saving devices such as LED lightings and motion sensor activation. The company has successfully implemented solar photovoltaic systems and energy-saving devices, reducing its reliance on energy and making efforts more cost-effective. Panasonic plans to further promote energy efficiency by generating additional solar energy and improving combustion efficiency, and may explore revenue-generating opportunities through demand response schemes.

site_title: Governance and business friendly market rules not mutually exclusive
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing its corporate governance code to strike a balance between being business-friendly and increasing governance. Singapore topped the Corporate Governance Watch 2016, but concerns arise about the potential impact of allowing dual-class shares, which could be business-unfriendly. MAS must navigate pressure from commercial interests while maintaining top-notch governance to enhance the market's standards. The review aims to produce a "balanced and progressive" code that is pragmatic and workable in practice.

site_title: Momo's 123% Q3 returns show there's big money in live streaming
summary: Momo Inc., a Chinese live-streaming video company, reported a 123% third-quarter return, making it the fourth-best US-listed stock with a market value of at least $2 billion. The industry has grown 175% over the past year, with analysts predicting further gains. The company's live-streaming boom is fueled by increasing smartphone usage, cheaper bandwidth, and the shift to mobile devices. Analysts see Momo's average 12-month target prices forecasting a 23% rise, driven by revenue growth and the potential to monetize the trend.

site_title: Nobel body should embrace broader definition of science
summary: The Nobel Foundation should consider expanding its definition of science to include a broader range of fields, as the world of science has evolved significantly since the late 1800s. Despite this, the foundation has largely ignored new areas of research, such as ecology, geology, oceanography, and climate science, which are crucial for addressing pressing global issues. This narrow focus creates a two-tiered scientific universe, favoring select fields and limiting opportunities for researchers in other areas. Updating the Nobel Prizes to recognize the full scope of scientific contributions could help to promote a more inclusive and relevant recognition of science's impact on society.

site_title: More payment delays among firms in Q3; construction hardest hit: credit bureau
summary: Singapore's payment statistics show worsening payment delays, particularly in the construction sector, in Q3 2016. Prompt payments dropped to 42.18% and slow payments rose to 46.37%, with the construction sector experiencing the highest proportion of slow payments for the third consecutive quarter. The weaker payment performance is attributed to a credit crunch, with managing cashflows a major concern for the sector. Experts advise construction firms to compress cashflow cycles to minimize delays.

site_title: US factories rebound, resisting global downward pull
summary: US factories experienced a rebound in September, with the Institute for Supply Management's index of national factory activity rising to 51.5, beating analyst expectations. This marks a relief as the sector is expanding, indicating America is resisting the downward pull of the global economy. The improvement is seen as a positive sign for the US economy, which has been impacted by global economic weakness.

site_title: Fancy a round of golf and dinner with Schooling?
summary: Singaporean Olympic gold medalist Joseph Schooling will attend the Singapore Swimming Association's golf fundraiser event on November 22 at Tanah Merah Country Club. The event aims to raise S$500,000 for the SGP Fund, supporting elite athletes, coaches, and officials. Sponsorship packages range from S$1,250 to S$100,000, including a chance to play golf with Schooling and dinner with him and President Tony Tan Keng Yam. The funds will be used to enhance high-performance systems for Singapore's elite swimmers.

site_title: 'Puppy farm capital' Ireland dogged by trafficking
summary: Ireland has become the "puppy farm capital of Europe" due to an illicit dog-breeding industry worth up to €20 million annually, with thousands of puppies smuggled to British ports and then Europe every year. Campaigners claim a recent crackdown is failing to curb the trade, which involves inhumane conditions, in-breeding, and lack of regulation. Despite high-profile seizures, prosecutions are rare, and welfare agencies are calling for the central government to take control of the crackdown, with some farms producing over 500 breeding bitches.

site_title: Banks unfazed by stricter rules for defining accredited investors
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is introducing stricter rules to define accredited investors (AIs), who must now have at least S$1 million of disposable assets. The new rules, set to take effect next year, will also require an opt-in decision to retain AI status. Despite concerns, banks say the change is unlikely to have a significant impact on their wealth management revenues or private banking business, with DBS and OCBC stating that only a small proportion of clients will be affected.

site_title: US: Wall St starts new quarter on subdued note
summary: US stocks began the fourth quarter on a subdued note, with the S&P 500 healthcare index falling 0.7% due to declines in Pfizer and Merck, and the consumer staples index falling 0.59% due to Procter & Gamble and PepsiCo. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: SGX reprimands KLW, two ex-executives for breach of Catalist rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reprimanded KLW Holdings and two former executives for breaching Catalist rules. KLW failed to announce significant debt recoveries and wrongly classified payments in its financial statements. The reprimand follows a 2015 special audit that found lapses in internal controls and potential breaches of disclosure rules. The case has been referred to relevant authorities.

site_title: September US auto slide even as discounts rise
summary: Major US automakers reported lower September sales, with deliveries down 0.6% from last year. General Motors (GM) and Ford saw sales decline, with GM down 0.6% and Ford down 8%. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles was also down 1%. Despite high consumer discounts, the sales drop reflects a slowdown in the US market, with pickup truck volumes falling for both GM and Ford.

site_title: Greece expects growth, lower debt, unemployment to ease in 2017: draft budget
summary: Greece predicts a 2.7% economic expansion in 2017, driven by trickle-down impact of bailout cash and resurgent private demand. The country expects a 0.3% drop in output this year and a 22.8% unemployment rate, down from 23.5% in 2016. Greece aims to meet reform targets of lenders, including a 1.8% primary surplus and a 174.8% debt-to-GDP ratio, down four points from this year. Tax measures, including pension contributions and new taxes, are expected to take full effect next year.

site_title: VW to pay US suppliers US$1.2b over Dieselgate
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to pay US suppliers $1.2 billion to settle claims related to the "Dieselgate" pollution scandal. The agreement, reached in principle on August 25, includes a maximum of $1.208 billion in cash payments to 652 dealers, averaging $1.9 million per settlement. This is in addition to the $14.7 billion in US compensation and fines Volkswagen has already agreed to pay. The deal also includes the buyback of affected vehicles still in dealer lots, addressing losses in franchise value. The accord is subject to judge approval in California.

site_title: Tesla shipments top analysts' estimates after Musk urges sales push
summary: Tesla Motors delivered 24,500 vehicles in the third quarter, exceeding analysts' estimates, following CEO Elon Musk's sales push. The company shipped 15,800 Model S sedans and 8,700 Model X SUVs. This shipment comes ahead of a plan to raise capital to ramp up production of the new Model 3. Tesla's third-quarter results demonstrate the company's ability to meet sales targets, potentially supporting its capital raise.

site_title: Leveraging on its people for innovative solutions
summary: ST Andrew's Junior College has won the EENP Award for Best Energy Efficiency Practices in the schools category. The college has implemented various initiatives, including training students in basic energy auditing, developing an IT system to control air-conditioning systems, and promoting energy efficiency through awareness-raising programs. These efforts have led to a 4.6% reduction in annual electricity consumption in 2014 and a 3.4% reduction last year, with a target to reduce the bill by 2.5% this year. The college credits its staff and students for their proactive efforts in managing electricity consumption.

site_title: Rolling with the punches
summary: Companies worldwide face the toughest business conditions in recent years, with external demand slowing, technological disruption, and rising costs. To cope, firms must develop a culture of resilience, which can be built on strong leadership and enable companies to maximize profits during good times and minimize losses during bad ones. Research shows that a resilient culture can help a company recover quickly from setbacks. Building such a culture is crucial for businesses to thrive in uncertain times.

site_title: Opec's 'capitulation' leaves obstacles for US shale drillers
summary: Opec, after a two-year price war with US shale drillers, agreed to its first production cut in eight years. Oil prices and US shale drillers' shares rose on the news. Analysts believe US companies won't commit to more spending until oil prices remain above $50 a barrel for months. This suggests that Opec's decision may not translate to a financial victory for the American shale industry, as significant investment is still needed to sustain growth.

site_title: Garuda's US return to generate 5% of 2017 revenue: CEO
summary: Garuda Indonesia's CEO, Arif Wibowo, expects the airline's return to the US in 2017 to generate about 5% of its revenue, with three weekly flights from Jakarta to Los Angeles via Japan. This comes after the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) lifted Indonesia's aviation safety ban in August. Garuda is also considering routes to New York via Europe, aiming to capture the 400,000-passenger-per-year traffic between the US and Indonesia. The airline's return is seen as a significant milestone for Garuda, which reported $3.81 billion in US operating revenues in 2015.

site_title: Jason Holdings says S$1.74m claim by ANZ due and owing by two directors as guarantors
summary: Jason Holdings announced that a statutory demand of S$1.74 million by ANZ is due and owing by two directors, Jason Sim Chon Ang and Sim Choon Joo, as guarantors for banking facilities to Jason Parquet Specialist (Singapore) Pte Ltd. The demand was received on Sept 26 and requires payment within 21 days to avoid bankruptcy applications. This follows an earlier announcement that the company had received a similar demand letter from ANZ for S$1.74 million as guarantor for JPSS, its principal operating unit.

site_title: Oil breaks above US$50 a barrel as investors warm to Opec deal
summary: Oil prices rose to their highest since August above US$50 a barrel on Monday, driven by Opec's planned production cut. December Brent crude futures reached US$50.61 a barrel, while US crude futures rose to US$48.61 a barrel. The Opec deal aims to reduce output between 32.5-33 million barrels per day, but analysts caution that the existing supply overhang could temper a longer-lasting rally. Despite concerns, Barclays expects oil prices to rise due to improving Asian economic growth, falling oil supplies, and rising investor interest.

site_title: New Jersey Transit was under probe before last week's crash
summary: The US Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) began investigating safety problems at New Jersey Transit before the recent fatal train crash, which killed a woman and injured over 100 people. An audit in June found an increase in safety violations and a leadership vacuum at the top, leading to a series of violations issued to the railroad. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the cause of the crash, which may have been prevented by positive train control technology. New Jersey Transit had faced recent challenges, including funding shortfalls and a lack of a permanent executive director, and had agreed to pay $70,000 in penalties for safety violations found by the administration.

images.alt_text: New Jersey Transit, the third-busiest commuter railroad in the US, has recently faced a series of challenges, from funding shortfalls to the lack of a permanent executive director.

site_title: Noble takes full control of ethanol unit for US$2.47m
summary: NOBLE Group has acquired its 50% stake in Noble Mansfield Renewable Energy for US$2.47 million, taking full ownership of the ethanol and biodiesel distributor. The acquisition was financed with internal resources, with the book value and net tangible asset of Noble Mansfield at US$3.3 million as of August 30, 2016. This move comes after Noble shares closed at 15.5 Singapore cents, a 2% increase.

site_title: Working together to make a difference
summary: Globalfoundries Singapore and Edwards Technologies Singapore have received an Honourable Mention in the Best Practices category at the EENP Awards 2016 for a joint project to reduce LPG consumption in combustion chamber replacement abatement units. The project involved retrofitting 35 units, resulting in a 31% reduction in LPG consumption and annual energy cost savings of US$200,000, as well as a 640-tonne carbon abatement. The redesign achieved this by halving the combustion chamber size and increasing the weir length to maintain gas residence time and destruction efficiency.

site_title: OLS Enterprise reverse takeover deal value drops to S$285m
summary: The reverse takeover deal for OLS Enterprise, a Singaporean investment holding company, has seen its value drop to S$285 million, down from an initial proposed S$300 million in 2015. OLS Enterprise plans to acquire Malaysian Phosphate Additives for the reduced amount. The company's shares ended 0.1 Singapore cent lower at 0.5 Singapore cent on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Molex's strong commitment pays off
summary: Molex Singapore Pte Ltd has won two awards at this year's Energy Efficiency National Partnership (EENP) Awards, recognizing its strong commitment to promoting energy efficiency. The company received the award for Excellence in Energy Management for implementing a comprehensive energy management plan and achieving a 10% year-on-year improvement in energy consumption. In the Best Practices category, Molex received Honourable Mention for its plating line blower project, which resulted in annual savings of S$0.68 million. This achievement demonstrates Molex's commitment to reducing energy consumption and promoting sustainability.

site_title: ECB will not ease policy further until 2017: traders
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will not ease monetary policy further until 2017, according to a majority of euro money market traders polled by Reuters. Despite cutting rates and buying bonds, inflation is not expected to reach the ECB's target until 2018 at the earliest. Only 13 of 17 traders predicted further easing in 2017, with the remaining four expecting action this year. This decision comes as the ECB has been under pressure to act, with a Reuters poll of economists suggesting an extension to its bond buying program in December.

site_title: Toyota Prius returns to plug-in market with US$3,000 price cut
summary: Toyota is reintroducing the Prius Prime plug-in hybrid to the US market with a US$3,000 price cut, starting at US$27,100. This move aims to undercut the Chevrolet Volt by US$6,000. The new Prius Prime can travel 25 miles in all-electric mode, compared to the Volt's 53 miles. The redesigned model is expected to go on sale later this year, offering a cleaner alternative to the gasoline engine.

site_title: G20 finance chiefs to discuss risks to economy, ending secret company ownership
summary: G20 finance chiefs will discuss risks to global economic growth and secretive company ownership at a working dinner in Washington on Oct 6. The meeting comes as global markets recover from the Brexit fallout, but uncertainties remain. China notes that global financial markets have recovered, but warns of uncertainties. The discussion aims to clamp down on tax avoidance and money laundering through secretive company ownership. The G20 finance ministers and central bank governors will also review global economic growth and make recommendations. The meeting will be held before the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: MAS and 5 polytechnics team up to groom young fintech potential
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has partnered with five local polytechnics to enhance their banking and IT-related curricula, aiming to groom a pool of skilled fintech professionals. The initiative, set to run for three years, will provide 100 fintech internships and mentorship opportunities, benefiting over 2,500 students. The move seeks to nurture Singapore's growing fintech sector and align with the country's SkillsFuture drive for the financial sector.

images.alt_text: In the latest sign of its financial technology (or fintech) ambitions, Singapore is starting them young.

site_title: Japanese scientist wins Nobel medicine prize for work on "self-eating" cell mechanism
summary: Japanese scientist Yoshinori Ohsumi won the 2016 Nobel Prize in Medicine for his groundbreaking research on autophagy, a process where cells degrade and recycle their components. His discoveries have led to a better understanding of diseases such as cancer, Parkinson's, and type 2 diabetes. Ohsumi's work has provided critical tools for scientists to understand the role of autophagy in human development, aging, and disease. The prize, worth 8 million Swedish crowns, recognizes Ohsumi's pioneering work in the field of autophagy, considered a key mechanism in the body's defenses.

site_title: China Reform Puissance acquires major stake in Citic Envirotech for S$390m
summary: China Reform Puissance Overseas GP has acquired a 23.85% stake in Citic Envirotech for S$390.1 million, purchasing 269 million shares at S$1.45 apiece. The acquisition was completed on October 2, and Citic Envirotech shares fell 3.7% to S$1.30 on Monday.

site_title: Great Eastern unit subscribes for additional shares in GEH subsidiary for S$24m
