Critics had argued that this transfer could allow authoritarian regimes to seize control, but a Texas federal judge refused to block the transition, allowing ICANN to operate as a self-regulating organisation.

site_title: Trump had US$916m loss in 1995, cutting taxes: NYT
summary: Donald Trump's 1995 US tax return shows a $916 million loss, potentially allowing him to cut federal income tax for 18 years. The New York Times obtained documents from state tax returns in New York, Connecticut, and New Jersey, citing tax analysts. Trump's campaign claims the documents were illegally obtained, but the Times reports they are genuine. The lack of transparency on Trump's tax returns has been criticized by the Clinton campaign, which seized on the report to highlight Trump's tax avoidance and business failures.

site_title: Iranian saffron fuelling growth of small German food business
summary: A German business, Miasa GmbH, is importing large quantities of Iranian saffron to produce fine food products, doubling its revenues every year. The company, founded by Michael Sabet, an Iranian-German executive, sees opportunities in post-sanctions trade with Iran. Saffron is used in various products, including saffron-infused sea salt, honey, and liquor, which are sold in luxury stores and online. The business is fueled by increasing demand for specialty "fine foods" and Middle Eastern cooking, with Sweden being a major consumer of saffron.

site_title: Like an open book, CDL discloses all
summary: City Developments (CDL), a real estate company, has been awarded the most transparent company award in the industry. Unlike many companies, CDL openly discloses sensitive topics such as remuneration and diversity policies. Its annual report and sustainability report provide detailed information on director salaries, workforce demographics, and other fees and benefits. This level of transparency is seen as crucial for corporate governance and informed decision-making. By being open and honest, CDL sets an example for other companies to follow.

site_title: KLW's CEO quits due to 'personal commitments'
summary: KLW Holdings' CEO, Quek Chek Lan, has resigned due to "other personal commitments." The 72-year-old was appointed in October 2015, following a boardroom fight. A replacement was not cited. This follows an announcement in June that Quek would sell his 19.4% stake in the company. KLW's independent auditor, Baker Tilly, gave a qualified opinion on the financial statement, citing unverifiable accuracy of contract work-in-progress.

site_title: Turkish Airlines looks to weather 2016 turbulence
summary: Turkish Airlines faces significant challenges in 2016 due to the country's traumatic events, including suicide bomb attacks and a failed coup attempt. The airline recorded a $647 million loss in the first half of 2016, with slower growth expected this year, carrying 63.4 million passengers, mostly in domestic flights. Despite efforts to maintain business as usual, the airline's stock has lost over 30% of its value, and tourism has plummeted due to the crises, with foreigner arrivals down 38% in August.

site_title: BP profit slides 49% on weaker oil refining
summary: BP reported a 49% decline in third-quarter earnings to $933 million, due to falling crude prices and shrinking refining margins. The decline marks the ninth consecutive quarter of earnings falls, putting pressure on CEO Bob Dudley to cut spending. Despite a recent OPEC output cut, oil prices have declined, forcing BP to renegotiate contracts and reduce project sizes to lower costs. The company plans to maintain 75% of cost cuts even when prices rise.

site_title: Children's Day treat for BT BAF beneficiaries
summary: 200 beneficiaries of the Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) in Singapore celebrated Children's Day at Resorts World Sentosa, thanks to childcare chain MapleBear Singapore. The event featured bouncy castles, carnival games, drawing and craft activities, and stage performances. Net proceeds from the event were donated to the BT BAF, supporting free arts education for financially disadvantaged children and youths. This was MapleBear Singapore's first corporate social responsibility outreach, with plans to make it an annual event.

site_title: All in the name of shareholder activism
summary: Singaporean shareholder activist David Gerald's Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has launched an initiative to provide pre-drafted questions to shareholders for AGMs, aiming to increase board-shareholder engagement. The group has reviewed 25 firms and plans to cover 250 companies by next year. SIAS also awards the Investors' Choice Awards to companies demonstrating good governance practices, which has been linked to outperforming the Straits Times Index. Gerald advocates for a balanced approach to dual-class shares, suggesting they could be allowed to list with safeguards, and calls for companies to conduct "soul searching" and articulate their dividend policies.

site_title: Alibaba's finance arm Ant says to expand in Asia first
summary: Ant Financial Services Group, Alibaba's online finance arm, plans to focus expansion in Asia before going global. Senior vice-president Douglas Feagin stated this at a Hong Kong event, citing no set plans for an initial public offering (IPO). Ant Financial raised $4.5 billion in April, valuing the company at $60 billion. The company aims to offer insurance and investment management products outside of China, with plans to expand in Asia first.

site_title: S'pore looks to cogen facilities, IoT to improve petchem energy efficiency
summary: Singapore aims to boost petrochemical industry energy efficiency by developing cogeneration facilities and leveraging the Industrial Internet of Things (IoT). The country's Economic Development Board (EDB) is exploring the possibility of creating a carbon chain on Jurong Island. This move follows Singapore's July target to cut greenhouse gas emissions from the manufacturing sector. Cogeneration plants enable petrochemical firms to generate their own electricity, improving energy efficiency. The initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to reduce its environmental impact.

site_title: Ricciardo beats Verstappen in a Red Bull one-two at Malaysian GP
summary: Daniel Ricciardo led a Red Bull one-two at the Malaysian Grand Prix, beating teammate Max Verstappen, as Lewis Hamilton's championship hopes were dashed after his engine exploded with 15 laps remaining. Hamilton was leading at the time of the incident, marking a significant setback in his bid to regain the world championship lead.

site_title: Suitors offer Takata bids of at least US$1b each
summary: Takata Corp, the Japanese air bag maker behind the industry's biggest recall, has received bids of at least US$1 billion from five suitors. The company is leaning towards three offers: from Daicel Corp and Bain Capital, and KKR & Co and Flex-N-Gate Corp. These bids are part of Takata's efforts to recover from the massive recall of its air bags. The company's future remains uncertain, but the bids provide a glimmer of hope for its stakeholders.

site_title: HSBC eyes trade finance gap in services sector
summary: HSBC is focusing on trade finance gaps in the services sector, driven by shifting global trade from physical goods to cross-border trade in labour and skills. The bank is financing e-commerce revenues and offering working capital to service firms, as it adapts to structural changes in trade.

site_title: Trump could have avoided paying any taxes for decades: NYT
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump declared a $916 million loss on his 1995 income tax return, allowing him to avoid paying taxes for decades. This revelation comes despite Trump's refusal to release his tax records. The loss was derived from the financial struggles of his Atlantic City casinos, airline business, and Plaza Hotel purchase. A $916 million loss in 1995 would have wiped out $50 million in taxable income per year for 18 years. Trump's campaign defended his tax payments, but did not address the loss.

site_title: German bank regulator warns of negative perception spiral: report
summary: Germany's financial regulator, Felix Hufeld, warned of a negative perception spiral that could lead to downward market spirals, citing Deutsche Bank's recent share price drops. He emphasized the need for banks to react quickly to the low interest-rate environment, which is eating away at their profitability. Hufeld also predicted several mergers in the German banking sector, mainly between smaller cooperative and savings banks, but cautioned against a "cure-all miracle merger" that would solve Germany's banking problems overnight.

site_title: Reaching the pinnacle of their profession
summary: The IBF Distinguished Fellow title recognizes six individuals for their expertise in the financial sector. The recipients share their views on the skills required to succeed in the industry today, but the provided article does not include the specific comments or discussions from the recipients. Instead, it appears to be a collection of unrelated news articles from July 10-11, 2025.

site_title: Indians disclose US$10b in hidden wealth
summary: India has declared almost $10 billion in hidden wealth under a government amnesty on tax evasion, with 64,275 declarations of previously undisclosed assets and income. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the move aims to increase tax compliance and generate additional revenue to fund public welfare schemes. The government introduced rules requiring tax declarations for purchases over $200,000 and promised not to pursue those who came clean on hidden wealth. The initiative is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to crack down on tax avoidance and tackle the country's inequality.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up on bargain-buying, China data
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.58% on Tuesday, driven by bargain-buying and positive Chinese manufacturing data. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,068.36, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased. The gains followed a five-day sell-off, as traders sought value in the market.

site_title: The tone from the top
summary: DBS Bank, CapitaLand, and Micro-Mechanics, three Singaporean companies, emphasize the importance of corporate culture and governance in driving business success. By aligning values across all levels and setting a strong tone from the top, these companies have created a culture of integrity, transparency, and accountability. They prioritize sustainable value over short-term returns, engage with stakeholders, and regularly review their governance practices. The companies also adopt various best practices, such as effective whistle-blower programs, lead independent directors, and sustainability reporting. They recognize that good governance is essential for long-term sustainable value creation and are committed to enhancing their disclosures and compliance processes.

site_title: Jason Holdings hit with more creditor claims
summary: Jason Holdings, a timber flooring maker, has received two more creditor claims, totaling about S$7.64 million, from ANZ Bank and ShareInvestor. The claims are due to outstanding debts, with ANZ seeking S$1.74 million and ShareInvestor seeking S$5,900. If not settled within the specified timeframes, ANZ can initiate a winding-up application in the High Court. This is the latest in a string of repayment claims the company has faced in recent months, following an investigation by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: Formula One: Ricciardo wins drama-filled Malaysian GP
summary: Daniel Ricciardo led a Red Bull one-two at the Malaysian Grand Prix, securing his first win of the season. Lewis Hamilton's hopes of regaining the world championship lead were dashed when his engine exploded with 15 laps to go, handing the lead to Ricciardo. Nico Rosberg took third place and extended the gap over Hamilton to 23 points with five races remaining. Ricciardo celebrated his win with a "shoey" on the podium, while Hamilton was left distraught after a dramatic and action-packed race.

site_title: Obama to hand digital keys to successor
summary: US President Barack Obama plans to transfer digital keys to his successor, including the @POTUS Twitter handle, on January 20, 2017. The White House has utilized social media to bypass journalists and directly engage with voters, logging nearly 30,000 tweets and thousands of hours of video footage. The new president will inherit a large digital following, with the @POTUS handle having over 11 million followers. This digital transfer marks a significant shift in how the US government uses social media to communicate with the public.

site_title: Saudi billionaire sells Toronto Four Seasons
summary: Saudi billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal's company, Kingdom Holding Company, sold the Four Seasons hotel in Toronto for US$170 million (225 million Canadian dollars) to Pakistani-American businessman Shahid Khan. This marks a 17 million Canadian dollar profit for KHC, which initially bought the hotel four years ago for 200 million Canadian dollars. Prince Alwaleed expressed satisfaction with the sale, stating he is pleased to pass ownership to Shahid Khan, a long-time fan of the Four Seasons brand. Kingdom will remain a stakeholder through its interest in the hotel's management company.

site_title: Occidental signs US$2b deal to expand Permian footprint
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp. agreed to pay US$2 billion for drilling rights and crude wells in the Permian Basin, expanding its dominant position in the US oil field. The deal includes 35,000 acres in the Delaware Basin area and wells pumping 11,000 barrels of crude daily. This acquisition follows Occidental's expansion strategy in the Permian Basin, where the company is shedding international assets to focus on the region. The deal is part of CEO Vicki Hollub's efforts to continue the expansion strategy of her predecessor, Stephen Chazen.

images.alt_text: Occidental Petroleum Corp, the world's largest independent oil explorer, agreed to pay US$2 billion for drilling rights and crude wells in the Permian Basin, expanding its dominant position in the biggest US oil field.

site_title: Japan shippers merge container units as downturn bites
summary: Japan's Kawasaki Kisen, Mitsui OSK Lines, and Nippon Yusen are merging their container businesses to counter an industry downturn, creating the world's sixth-largest container shipping business. The joint venture will have combined annual revenues of about $19 billion and will start operations in April 2018. The move comes after South Korean shipping giant Hanjin's bankruptcy plan was rejected, fuelling fears of further industry instability. The merger aims to increase profitability and competitiveness in a sector struggling with a decline in container growth rate and rapid vessel additions.

site_title: Britain to start EU exit process before April
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May announced that the country will start the formal process of leaving the EU before April, triggering Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty. This move aims to initiate a two-year departure process, with May hoping it will lead to a "smoother process of negotiation" with Brussels. However, European powers have warned that Britain cannot expect special treatment on trade and immigration, and May plans to curb the yearly influx of EU citizens. The decision is seen as a key step in defining the shape of Brexit.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to sell Shanghai business park for S$222m
summary: Ascendas Reit is selling its Shanghai business park, A-Reit City @ Jinqiao, to Vanke Property's unit, Wkland Investments II Limited, for S$222 million. The sale includes an assignment of a shareholder loan and is expected to be completed in the fiscal third quarter. The proceeds will be used to fund committed investments, repay debts, and extend loans to subsidiaries. If used entirely to repay debts, A-Reit's aggregate leverage will be reduced by about 1.4%. The sale marks the divestment of a property valued at S$204 million as of March 2016.

site_title: Australia says MH17 missile suspects might be confirmed by year-end
summary: Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop stated that the names of those responsible for shooting down Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 over Ukraine in 2014 might be confirmed by the end of the year. International investigators found the plane was downed by a Russian-made missile fired from a pro-Russian rebel village in eastern Ukraine. This contradicts Moscow's claim that Ukraine's military was responsible. The culprits could face an international tribunal, similar to the one used to prosecute those responsible for the 1988 Lockerbie bombing.

site_title: Private jet deliveries dive, 10-year outlook forecast cut by 600 planes
summary: Private jet deliveries are expected to drop, with a 7% reduction forecasted, or 600 aircraft, over the next decade due to economic uncertainty and low commodity prices. The number of new planes delivered from 2016 to 2026 is estimated to be 8,600, down from 9,200 in last year's outlook, with sales estimated at $255 billion. Deliveries are expected to decline this year and next, but are forecasted to rebound in 2018 with the introduction of new models.

site_title: ARA fund to invest in Shanghai property worth 20b yuan
summary: ARA Asset Management announced plans to invest 20 billion yuan (S$4.1 billion) in a Shanghai commercial property, Century Link, a premium-grade integrated commercial property in the Lujiazui Finance and Trade Zone. This investment will be the largest single-asset property transaction in the Asia-Pacific for 2016.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target, with an operating loss similar to the H1 loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Yellen imitates Greenspan in reversal of mid-1990s rookie role
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is resisting pressure to raise interest rates, echoing her predecessor Alan Greenspan's approach in the mid-1990s. With unemployment near 5%, Yellen is willing to explore how low joblessness can decline while watching wages and inflation. The Federal Open Market Committee is expected to hold policy steady for a seventh straight meeting, with a possible rate hike in December after the US election. Yellen aims to encourage disaffected Americans to rejoin the labor force and boost investment, aiming for a "high-pressure" economy to fix economic damage from the 2007-2009 recession.

site_title: Opec cuts will barely dent world's bloated oil stockpiles
summary: Opec aims to cut oil output by 11% next year to shrink record stockpiles, but data shows the move will barely dent existing excess. The bloc's efforts, despite being defied by a skeptical market, highlight the need for help from competitors like Russia to end the glut.

site_title: Malaysian KFC operator said to choose banks for US$500m IPO
summary: QSR Brands (M) Holdings Sdn, the Malaysian operator of KFC and Pizza Hut restaurants, has chosen banks to arrange a US$500 million initial public offering (IPO) in Malaysia. The banks selected are Citigroup Inc, Credit Suisse Group AG, Malayan Banking Bhd, CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, and RHB Bank Bhd. The IPO is the company's attempt to raise funds after a low US$270 million first-time share sale in Malaysia this year. QSR Brands manages over 730 KFC restaurants and 450 Pizza Hut outlets across Southeast Asia.

site_title: EU wants Google to stop anti-competitive Android practices, fine expected
summary: EU antitrust regulators plan to order Google to stop paying financial incentives to smartphone makers to pre-install Google Search exclusively on their devices and warned the company of a large fine. The European Commission accused Google of using its dominant Android mobile operating system to shut out rivals. The regulators also want to prevent Google from forcing smartphone makers to pre-install its proprietary apps. Google could face a large fine based on revenue generated from AdWords clicks, Google Search product queries, and Play Store apps purchases.

site_title: US warns Philippines' Duterte over rhetoric, crime war
summary: US Assistant Secretary of State Daniel Russel warned Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte over his "fiery rhetoric" and deadly crime war, sparking global concern. During a meeting in Manila, Russel expressed worry about the nation's seven-decade alliance with the US, following Duterte's statement of "separation." However, Duterte later clarified he didn't plan to sever ties. The US is closely monitoring the situation, with many people around the world becoming increasingly worried about the Filipino president's behavior.

site_title: Pursuing specialised knowledge
summary: Dashni Ravindran, a graduate of SIM University's MA in Applied Linguistics (TESOL), shares the benefits of her postgraduate program. Prior to the course, she was a part-time undergraduate mathematics student and a language teacher. Ravindran's sister encouraged her to pursue a master's program, which she did to develop her professional competence and acquire valuable skills. The program's flexible learning mode, including a flipped classroom, distinguished it from other similar programs. After graduation, Ravindran plans to continue working as a language teacher, with aspirations to pursue a PhD in the future. The program has equipped her with reflective, evaluative, and analytical skills, enabling her to craft effective teaching methodologies.

site_title: Zika causes infertility, lasting harm to testes in mice: US study
summary: US researchers found that Zika virus causes lasting damage to male reproductive cells in mice, resulting in shrunken testicles, reduced fertility, and lower sex hormone levels. The study, published in Nature, showed that Zika infects and kills Sertoli cells, which don't regenerate, leading to severe infertility. The findings, only in mice so far, warrant further study due to possible implications for human health. Zika infections in pregnant women have been linked to microcephaly and other brain abnormalities, and the virus can remain in semen for up to six months.

site_title: Uber's bruising battle in China is being refought with bicycles
summary: Uber's battle for dominance in China is being refought with bike-sharing startups. Ofo and Mobike, backed by major investors including Didi Chuxing and Tencent Holdings, are vying for market share in the bike-sharing market, which could grow to $5.8 billion by 2020. Each company targets a different market, with Mobike focusing on high-end branding and Ofo targeting students with affordable, smartphone-app based bikes. The competition is intense, with bike-sharing companies burning through billions of dollars to offer freebies and merge months later to take on the next competitor.

site_title: Obama's consequential presidency draws to a close
summary: Barack Obama's presidency, which began with promises of hope and change, has left a lasting impact on US politics and the world. During his eight years in office, the economy struggled with massive job losses and the threat of jihadist attacks, but Obama's efforts to cooperate with the international community and restore America's reputation helped mitigate these challenges. The Great Recession showed that the US could no longer afford to be the world's policeman, and Obama's "pivot to Asia" and "lead from behind" approach in foreign policy were met with mixed results. At home, Obama's presidency marked a shift towards a more nuanced approach to politics, with the left-right divide blurring and a growing focus on economic issues.

site_title: Singapore ranks 2nd in ease of doing business
summary: Singapore ranks 2nd in ease of doing business, improving from its 2015 ranking of 3rd after the World Bank revised its data and methodology. The country's overall score rose 0.55 points to 85.05 points, with improvements in four areas: starting a business, dealing with construction permits, registering property, and paying taxes. Despite slipping in one area, getting credit, Singapore remains a top-ranked country in protecting minority investors and enforcing contracts.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees 'tough' earnings season for Australian banking giants
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a "tough" earnings season for Australian banking giants, with National Australia Bank (NAB) and Australia & New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) expected to report lower cash profits amid higher funding costs and rising bad-debt charges. Westpac's profits may remain little changed. Analysts have trimmed their expectations for the three banks' results, citing margin contraction and increased bad-loan charges. The banks' net interest margins are at an eight-year low, and lending spreads are expected to remain under pressure.

site_title: US: Stocks slide amid health-care earnings, Apple sales outlook
summary: US stocks declined amid disappointing earnings from Apple and Edwards Lifesciences, with Apple's 2.8% drop and Edwards' three-year low. Boeing Co rose, the most in a year, and the KBW Bank Index reached its best level this year. Despite this, energy producers fell with crude oil, and health-care shares continued to slide. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, but investors remained cautious amid US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: In bustling Crimea, they love Putin
summary: Russian tourists flock to Crimea, drawn by President Vladimir Putin's annexation, with many viewing the region as a symbol of patriotism and a potential development boom. The peninsula's tourism industry has seen a surge, with hotels booked solid and locals capitalizing on the influx of visitors, including selling pro-Putin merchandise. However, the annexation remains a contentious issue, with Ukraine and Western countries condemning it. For many, the controversy has added to the region's allure, with some predicting Crimea will become a major tourist destination, rivaling the French Riviera.

site_title: BP, Shell help lift profitability of oil trading to 6-year high
summary: The trading arms of Royal Dutch Shell and BP enjoyed their best year ever in 2015, contributing to a six-year high in combined gross margins for oil merchants, reaching $19 billion. Volatile spot prices and contango opportunities fueled the surge, with independent traders also profiting from the low oil prices. However, the trading conditions have since changed, with contango narrowing and volatility dropping, and the consultancy Oliver Wyman warns that the number of commodities trading houses will shrink due to increased competition and decreasing margins.

site_title: China Medical (International) to raise S$5.5m from shares, warrants placement
summary: China Medical (International) Group Limited plans to raise S$5.48 million through a shares placement and warrants placement. Two share subscribers will subscribe for 500 million new shares at 1.03 Singapore cents, while three warrant subscribers will subscribe for up to 800 million non-listed warrants at the same price. The issue price represents a 10% discount to the company's volume-weighted average price. The estimated net proceeds will be used for stake acquisitions in two companies held by Asia Pacific Medical Group Limited.

site_title: Banks failing from coast to coast show Africa distress
summary: African banks are facing a crisis due to high interest rates, low commodity prices, and unpaid loans. The collapse of a Ugandan bank, Crane Bank Ltd, has sparked concerns about the stability of the continent's banking system. Several other countries, including Nigeria, Kenya, Zambia, Mozambique, and the Democratic Republic of Congo, are also experiencing banking troubles. Experts predict that more banks will fail in Nigeria and that the Kenyan banking sector will need to consolidate. The International Monetary Fund has warned of a slowdown in economic growth in sub-Saharan Africa, with some countries facing energy shortages and widening government budget deficits.

site_title: Look before you leap abroad
summary: Singaporean staff are hesitant to take overseas postings due to limited resources and concerns about career impact. Companies like multinational corporations (MNCs) have global operations, but small and medium enterprises (SMEs) struggle to provide comprehensive relocation support. Employees want to work overseas on their own terms, with fair compensation and career benefits. Short-term assignments and permanent transfers are becoming more common, and companies are rethinking relocation strategies to address employee concerns. Clear career planning and communication are essential for making overseas postings a win-win situation for both employers and staff.

site_title: AT&T-Time Warner to face big regulatory test
summary: AT&T's proposed acquisition of Time Warner, worth $85.4 billion, faces significant regulatory scrutiny due to the combined entity's massive wireless business and potential concentration of media power. Industry analysts and consumer groups express concerns over reduced competition, unfair pricing, and increased media consolidation. Regulators, including the Justice Department and FCC, will closely examine the deal, which may lead to stricter conditions or a possible blockage under a new administration, with Donald Trump already condemning the deal as a concentration of power in the hands of too few.

site_title: Australian outback scions bid A$386m for Kidman
summary: A group of Australian outback scions, known as BBHO, has bid A$386 million for all shares of S Kidman & Co, surpassing an offer from billionaire Gina Rinehart and her Chinese business partner valued at A$365 million. The group, comprised of prominent cattle and sheep ranchers, plans to more than triple the Kidman cattle operation to over 500,000 head. The proposal does not require Foreign Investment Review Board approval, as it is an all-Australian offer. The sale needs government approval due to Shanghai CRED's 33% stake in the company.

site_title: US calls on banks to set higher cyber security standards
summary: US bank regulators announced new cyber security standards to protect financial markets and consumers. Leading banks will be expected to use advanced anti-hacking tools and recover from attacks within two hours. The rules, set to be finalized after industry input, aim to raise cyber security to a top priority for corporate executives and boards.

site_title: Nissan to decide next month whether to build next Qashqai in UK
summary: Nissan is set to decide in November whether to produce the next Qashqai SUV model at its Sunderland plant in the UK, with the decision influenced by the country's decision to exit the European Union. The factory, which produces the popular SUV and other models exported throughout Europe, is Britain's largest car plant. Nissan chief executive Carlos Ghosn warned that the country's exit from the EU could halt investment at the plant. A decision will be made next month, with the outcome crucial for the UK's automotive industry.

site_title: Nissan to name CEO Ghosn as chairman of Mitsubishi Motors
summary: Nissan Motor Co has decided to appoint CEO Carlos Ghosn as chairman of Mitsubishi Motors Corp after taking a 34% stake in the Japanese automaker. Ghosn will also ask Mitsubishi Motors Chairman Osamu Masuko to stay on as president. Mitsubishi Motors will make a formal decision in December, with Nissan set to close the deal by the end of the year. The move comes after Mitsubishi Motors is mired in a mileage-cheating scandal.

site_title: S'pore could draw Chinese infrastructure deals
summary: Singapore could attract Chinese infrastructure deals due to its stable environment, favorable tax and regulatory climate, and access to a large and growing customer demand. A UOB survey found 32% of Chinese businesses plan to expand into Singapore in the next 3-5 years, with 29% from Japan. The survey also shows Asian companies are investing more in research and innovation, IT systems, and cross-border loans, with over half of their revenue coming from Asean countries.

site_title: Merkel says Putin confronted with blunt language on Syria role
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande confronted Russian President Vladimir Putin over the humanitarian situation in Syria, describing it as "inhumane." Putin proposed halting Russia's bombing in Aleppo as long as "terrorist forces" aren't active. He didn't specify the duration of the proposed cease-fire, which Merkel and Hollande saw as a positive step. The meeting in Berlin marked a shift in Putin's rhetoric on Syria, with Merkel's "blunt language" prompting a more conciliatory tone from the Russian leader.

site_title: Nintendo to offer first glimpse of new NX gaming platform
summary: Nintendo is set to unveil its new gaming platform, NX, with a three-minute video on its website at 11 pm local time on October 20, 2016. The platform, scheduled for release in March 2017, will offer a "whole new way to experience hardware and software together," according to Nintendo president Tatsumi Kimishima. A new Zelda game series has been confirmed, and analysts expect the device to sell 2.5 million units in its first month and 10.6 million units by March 2018, despite concerns about revolutionary features.

site_title: UK inflation surges as Carney rate-cut decision looms closer
summary: The UK's inflation rate surged to its fastest pace in almost two years in September, exceeding economists' forecasts of 0.9%. The core rate of inflation also reached a two-year high, driven by the weaker pound's 18% decline since the Brexit vote. Despite this, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is expected to cut the benchmark rate on November 3 to support the economy. Economists disagree on the timing of the rate cut, with some predicting a reduction in November. The inflation trend is expected to continue, fueling concerns about the impact on the economy.

site_title: Opec output cut may hasten oil market rebalance: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) chief, Fatih Birol, says a potential Opec output cut may hasten the rebalancing of the oil market, which is currently oversupplied. If producers meet next month to cap output, the market is expected to rebalance earlier than expected, potentially before the second half of 2017. The deal, agreed upon by Opec members led by Saudi Arabia, aims to stabilize prices, but some analysts, including Iraq's oil minister, question its implementation due to concerns about exempting certain countries from production cuts.

images.alt_text: The oversupplied oil market will be rebalanced earlier than expected if major crude producers implement a deal to cap output when they meet next month, the International Energy Agency chief said Tuesday.

site_title: JTC primed to be even bigger industrial player
summary: JTC Corporation, Singapore's industrial agency, is set to become a larger industrial player with the transfer of 10,700 industrial units and 540 industrial land leases from the Housing & Development Board (HDB) by Q1 2018. The consolidation aims to streamline resources, increase efficiency, and provide comprehensive master-planning of industrial estates and facilities. This move is expected to benefit industrialists, with JTC offering a wider range of industrial land and innovative facilities, including specialized spaces for cleantech and biomedicals.

site_title: Ascendas-HTrust no longer for sale (Amended)
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) has decided not to sell its properties after receiving several offers. The trust's chairman, Miguel Ko, stated that the trust still has room to grow, particularly in new markets. Assets in Tokyo and Osaka are benefiting from increased tourism, and hotel room rates are expected to rise before the 2020 Summer Olympics. The trust's valuation has increased, with its Japanese hotels valued at 21.8 billion yen. Ko believes the earnings stream can be further enhanced, and the trust will continue to grow alongside other public funds in the stable.

images.alt_text: "I spent 30 years in the business," says Mr Ko. "I am one of the more established veterans in the hotel space in Asia-Pacific or even globally."

site_title: Won leads Asia gains, ringgit rises as US dollar dips on mixed data
summary: South Korea's won rose 0.4% to 1,133.58 a US dollar, while Malaysia's ringgit strengthened 0.2% to 4.2125, following mixed US economic data that weakened the US dollar. US manufacturing contracted, but factory production grew, casting doubt on a Federal Reserve rate hike. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 0.2%, and Asian currencies, including the Chinese yuan, continue to depreciate.

site_title: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos says Trump is 'eroding our democracy'
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos stated that Donald Trump is "eroding our democracy around the edges" by threatening retribution against critics and hinting at a loss in the election. Bezos expressed regret for underestimating Trump's candidacy after joking about sending him to space on Twitter. Bezos also criticized Trump supporter Peter Thiel, calling contrarians "usually wrong." Despite their differences, Bezos emphasized the need for people with opposing views to work together. Bezos' comments were made during the Vanity Fair New Establishment Summit in San Francisco.

site_title: Charter Hall pulls IPO on expected listing date
summary: Charter Hall Group, an Australian property trust, has abandoned its initial public offering (IPO) due to lack of institutional support. The IPO was projected to raise A$1.12 billion but was deemed too expensive for big investors. This move comes after the Reserve Bank of Australia warned of a supply glut in the sector and a decline in the Reit index. The firm will now consider alternative options for its 296 properties, valued at A$17.5 billion. The IPO is expected to be repriced, with a potential yield boost.

site_title: Suicide prompts Japan advertising giant to limit overtime
summary: Japan's advertising giant Dentsu Inc has limited overtime for its employees to 65 hours a month, down from 70, following the death of a 24-year-old employee who suffered a mental breakdown due to excessive work. The move comes as the government explores policies to improve working practices, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stating that revised overtime rules could lead to better work-life balance. This decision is part of a growing trend of companies in Japan, including Yahoo Japan and Daiwa Securities, to limit overtime and promote employee well-being.

site_title: United's costs shoot up after new labour contracts
summary: United Airlines' costs are expected to rise 4.75-5.75% in the fourth quarter due to new labour contracts, exceeding industry norms. The airline's costs per seat flown a mile are projected to increase, potentially slowing efforts to boost profit margins. United's labour costs have been a significant challenge, with the airline seeking to close the gap with rivals like Delta and American Airlines. Analysts have expressed concerns, citing a "disappointing cost outlook" and questioning United's ability to offset the higher employee costs.

site_title: China Sept government spending up 11.3% y-o-y
summary: China's government spending rose 11.3% in September from a year earlier, while revenue grew 5.9%. This follows a slight increase from August, with spending up 10.3% and revenue up 1.7%. For the first nine months, spending grew 12.5% and revenue rose 5.9%. The data suggests China's economy is still expanding, but growth may slow.

images.alt_text: Government spending in China rose 11.3 per cent in September from a year earlier, while revenue rose 5.9 per cent, the Ministry of Finance said on Wednesday.

site_title: Australian carriers ban recalled Samsung phone
summary: Australian airlines Qantas, Jetstar, Virgin Australia, and Tigerair Australia have banned the recalled Samsung Note 7 from all planes due to its "potential fire risk". The ban applies to devices in carry-on, check-in, and checked luggage, and passengers are strongly advised not to bring the phone to airports. This follows a similar ban imposed by US officials, and the move is expected to cost Samsung billions in lost profits. The crisis is a blow to the South Korean electronics giant, which prides itself on producing cutting-edge technology.

site_title: Exxon boss, Saudi minister differ on oil supply outlook
summary: Exxon Mobil CEO Rex Tillerson and Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih have differing views on the outlook for oil supply. Tillerson believes that North American shale oil production, which has become a swing producer, will be able to respond rapidly to global supply shortfalls, while al-Falih warns that declining investment in the sector could lead to a supply crunch. The two men's comments contrast with predictions from Total CEO Patrick Pouyanne, who expects supplies to fall short by 5-10 million barrels per day by the end of the decade due to insufficient investment.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil's boss Rex Tillerson and Saudi Arabia's energy minister on Wednesday took opposing views on declining investment in the oil sector setting the stage for a possible major supply crunch.

site_title: Macau casino staff flee China after VIP marketers detained
summary: Macau casino staff are fleeing China after the detention of employees from Australia's Crown Resorts, prompting a decline in casino shares. The detentions, including the head of Crown's international high-roller operations, are part of China's crackdown on foreign companies trying to woo its citizens to gamble overseas. The move is expected to disrupt Macau's VIP and high-end mass segments, as it becomes harder to market and facilitate business. Authorities have been curbing the activities of junket operators, who take Chinese high-rollers overseas to gamble and loan them money to play with.

site_title: Veritas study highlights concerns over data hoarding
summary: A Veritas study in Singapore found 79% of IT decision makers admit to data hoarding, with 91% saving "harmful" files. The study highlights concerns over data hoarding, with 82% respondents storing potentially harmful data and 32% never deleting old files. Veritas managing director Victor Cheng advises firms to implement policies to query the usefulness of stored data to prevent compliance issues and organizational problems. The study suggests that employees struggle to determine data value, fearing they may need it in the future, and that data clean-up is a priority to prevent breaches.

site_title: Economists warn China's property bubble will be difficult to resolve
summary: China is experiencing a severe property bubble, with housing prices rising nearly one-third from a year ago and a growing amount of US-style debt. Economists warn that resolving the bubble will be difficult due to the large amount of debt involved, particularly long-term household loans. The bubble has fueled a frenzy of homebuying, with many couples filing for divorce to buy more properties, and has also led to the involvement of underground lenders. The potential global repercussions of a Chinese housing market collapse are significant, with the sector accounting for roughly one-fifth of China's economic activity.

site_title: HK property prices more affordable compared with some China cities: BAML
summary: Hong Kong's property prices have become relatively more affordable compared to some major mainland Chinese cities, analysts from Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAML) say. Chinese buyers are stepping up home purchases in Hong Kong, driven by a surge in home prices in China, which may support the territory's property market. Hong Kong's housing affordability ratio is at 58%, compared to 80-124% in three Chinese cities. This has narrowed the home price gap between Hong Kong and China, attracting mainland investors to diversify or protect wealth.

site_title: Buying falls for third week, selling rises sharply
summary: Singapore's buying activity declined for the third consecutive week, while selling surged sharply, according to the Singapore Exchange. In the second week of October, 10 companies bought shares worth S$3.3 million, while four firms sold shares worth S$0.48 million. Buyback activity rebounded with 11 companies repurchasing shares worth S$6.58 million. The trading was mixed, with significant trades on both buying and selling sides, and insider buys recorded in several firms.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 6.5% in August
summary: Singapore's retail sales excluding vehicles declined 6.5% in August from the previous year, while sales including cars dropped 1% year-on-year. Food and beverage services also saw a 2.5% year-on-year decline.

site_title: Japanese brands surge on private-hire demand
summary: Honda has surpassed Toyota as Singapore's top car brand, with 13,909 registrations from January to September 2016, driven by strong demand from private-hire companies for the Vezel compact SUV. Mazda and Mitsubishi also saw significant gains, with Mazda rising to third place and Mitsubishi jumping to seventh. Total car registrations in Singapore increased by 68% in the first nine months of 2016, with 65,412 vehicles registered. The shift towards SUVs is evident, with the Nissan X-Trail entering the top 10 and the Nissan Sylphy dropping out.

site_title: Singapore leaders express condolences on the death of Thailand's King Bhumibol
summary: Singapore leaders have sent condolence letters to the Thai government over the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej. President Tony Tan Keng Yam, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan expressed their respects and acknowledged King Bhumibol's tireless efforts to improve Thailand's lives during his long reign.

site_title: Rock poet Bob Dylan wins Nobel Literature Prize
summary: Bob Dylan, a 75-year-old US music legend, won the Nobel Literature Prize for creating new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition. This marked the first time a songwriter was awarded the prize, surprising many who had not seen him as a contender. The Swedish Academy recognized Dylan's influence on generations of fans with his poetic lyrics, sparking applause from journalists at the announcement.

site_title: Japan withholding Unesco aid over Nanjing Massacre documents
summary: Japan is withholding $59 million in financial contributions to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (Unesco) due to disagreements over the listing of Chinese documents related to the 1937 Nanjing Massacre. The Japanese government claims Unesco registered the documents without allowing verification, while Beijing disputes the number of civilian and military casualties. This move could impact Unesco's operations, with Japan being the leading donor for the past five years.

site_title: Growth won't pick up significantly in 2017; mid-term core inflation seen slightly below 2%: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has tempered expectations for the country's economy in 2017, citing a weakening economy and growth expected to be only slightly higher than forecast. Core inflation is expected to trend towards but average slightly below 2% over the medium term, while full-year GDP growth is projected to be at the lower end of the 1-2% forecast range. The MAS also notes that growth in the second half of 2016 has weakened, and is not expected to pick up significantly in 2017.

site_title: Samsung stock rout fails to deter foreign investors
summary: Samsung Electronics' stock slumped 10% in its biggest three-day drop since 2012, shaving $23 billion off its market value, amid concerns over the Galaxy Note 7's battery issue. However, foreign investors, including TT International and Skagen, see the weakness as a buying opportunity for long-term investors, citing the company's efforts to restore its brand. Experts predict a temporary impact, with some viewing the current price as attractive for investors.

site_title: South Korea central bank: We don't see Samsung Note 7 issue hitting GDP growth
summary: The Bank of Korea stated that the recall of Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 smartphones will not affect South Korea's GDP growth this year, despite some production taking place domestically. The bank estimates that Samsung produces 400 million phones annually, while South Korea produces less than 30 million. Although the Note 7 is a premium product, the bank believes the impact will be minimal.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 0.56 points to 2,804.92. Trading volume was high, with 118.7 million shares changing hands. Noble Group rose S$0.005 to S$0.178, while gainers outnumbered losers 74 to 54. The flat market was ahead of Chinese consumer and producer price data release.

site_title: SoftBank tech fund to invest up to US$100b with Saudis
summary: SoftBank Group Corp announced plans to form a new $100 billion tech fund, partnering with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund to invest in influential tech companies. SoftBank will invest $25 billion, while the Saudis may invest up to $45 billion over five years. The fund, called SoftBank Vision Fund, will target tech companies at all stages, aiming to accelerate the information revolution and contribute to the development of the tech sector.

site_title: Angelene Chan
summary: Angelene Chan, CEO of DP Architects, reflects on her 52-year career with the Singapore-based architecture firm. Born in 1970s Johor Baru, Chan grew up in a close-knit community and was inspired by the firm's "kampong spirit" when she joined in 1990. Under her leadership, DP Architects has expanded globally and is now ranked 12th in the world. Chan prioritizes family values and design excellence, and has overseen high-profile projects such as The Dubai Mall and Resorts World Sentosa. She aims to propel the firm to the next league globally while maintaining its unique culture and values.

site_title: Johnnie Walker rebound rests with Emma Walker
summary: A 37-year-old chemist, Emma Walker, is tasked with reviving the Johnnie Walker whisky brand, which was first introduced in 1820 by Scotsman Johnnie Walker. Born 121 years after Johnnie Walker's death, Emma's job is to create new incarnations of the world's best-selling Scotch brand using thousands of test tubes and equipment.

site_title: Australia government cyber attack came from foreign intelligence service: report
summary: A foreign intelligence service, likely from China or Russia, carried out a malware attack against Australia's Bureau of Meteorology in December 2015, potentially spreading to other government networks. The Australian Cyber Security Centre attributed the attack to a foreign intelligence service, citing the presence of Remote Access Tool malware commonly used by state-sponsored cyber adversaries. This report adds credibility to warnings of malicious online attacks from these countries and raises concerns about the security of Australian government networks.

site_title: Few pickings on SGX for those seeking to ride disruption wave (Amended)
summary: Analysts warn that few Singapore-listed stocks are well-positioned to capitalize on the disruption theme, with many old-economy sectors, such as transport and retail, at high risk of disruption. Only a handful of companies, including DBS, Singtel, and SATS, have shown potential to adapt to the new landscape. Despite some large companies investing in accelerators and VC arms, their initiatives have yet to bear fruit. Analysts advise investors to look outside the SGX for disruptive companies and consider alternative funding sources, such as private equity and crowdfunding, as the exchange itself faces disruption.

site_title: Pos M'sia in delivery talks with Alibaba
summary: Malaysia's postal company, Pos Malaysia, is in talks with Alibaba Group to bypass middlemen when shipping goods sold on Alibaba's platforms, tapping into the boom in online retailing. The company aims to cut costs and provide more direct logistics services to Chinese e-commerce giant, as online shopping drives a 40% jump in profit. Pos Malaysia plans to expand its services overseas, with a focus on China, and is valued at 25 times its projected earnings, beating rival UPS.

site_title: Anxious prayers for ailing Thai king outside hospital
summary: Thailand's King Bhumibol Adulyadej, 88, remains hospitalized due to worsening health, sparking anxiety among devotees. The king's health has been declining over the past two years, with recent grave health statements from the palace. Devotees gathered outside the hospital, holding prayers and wearing pink, believed to bring good luck. The king's passing would be a significant shock to the nation, with his son and successor, Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn, struggling to gain popularity. The palace maintains tight control over news about the king's condition, exacerbating anxiety over his health.

site_title: Swiber's JM says company unable to pay coupon due next week on S$160m notes
summary: Swiber Holdings' judicial managers announced the company is unable to pay its S$160 million coupon payment due on October 18 for its 7.125% fixed rate notes due in 2017. This comes as Swiber faces financial difficulties, further exacerbating the beleaguered oilfield services company's woes.

site_title: China adds fuel to speed up "Railway Express" to Europe
summary: China's state planner has proposed a five-year plan to develop the China Railway Express to Europe, aiming to improve customs clearance and infrastructure. The network, crucial to China's "One Belt, One Road" policy, will focus on three routes and 43 transit hubs, and will strengthen regulation to address high costs and disorderly competition. The plan is part of Beijing's efforts to rebrand the network under the "China Railway Express" brand, which currently offers rail services over 39 lines linking Chinese cities to European destinations.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks down on Fed cues, weak China data; BOK stands pat
summary: South Korea's won and stocks slipped early Thursday following US Federal Reserve minutes and weak China export data, which may have hurt risk sentiment. The won fell 0.1% to 1,125.3 against the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 0.7% to 2,019.07 points. The Bank of Korea held interest rates steady as expected, with economists attributing the market's reaction to the dollar's movement and upcoming US economic data.

site_title: Shares flat, pennies enjoy hectic churning
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a hectic session on Monday, with unit turnover reaching 2.2 billion units, the highest in three months. Despite the high volume, the Straits Times Index declined 5 points to 2,870.24. Noble Group's shares rose 6 cents to S$0.198 after announcing the sale of its US subsidiary for US$1.05 billion. Other notable movers included Sapphire Corp and Vard Holdings, with the former rising 10.6% and the latter increasing 7.7%. The market awaits key economic data, including retail sales and US data, for the week ahead.

site_title: CEO of Morgan Stanley International says jobs will go if loses market access post-Brexit
summary: Morgan Stanley International CEO Rob Rooney warns that banks will need to relocate staff if the UK loses access to the European single market post-Brexit. He states that this could lead to significant job losses and a more expensive business model. Many investment banks rely on London's hub to run EU operations, and the Brexit vote threatens these arrangements. Rooney emphasizes that the jobs that go may be significant, and the impact on the business model will be substantial.

site_title: Dubai begins building 'world's tallest' tower
summary: Dubai has begun construction on The Tower at Dubai Creek Harbour, set to become the world's tallest tower upon completion in 2020. Designed by Santiago Calatrava Valls, the 828m-tall structure will have 360-degree observation decks and be anchored to the ground with sturdy cables. The project, valued at around $1 billion, aims to surpass the current Burj Khalifa, which stands at 828m high. Construction began on October 11, 2016, and is expected to be completed before the Expo 2020 trade fair in Dubai.

site_title: JR Kyushu invests in S-E Asia property to cut reliance on Japan
summary: JR Kyushu, a state-owned Japanese railway company, plans to invest in South-east Asian properties to reduce its reliance on Japan. The company aims to spend 80 billion yen over three years on non-rail sectors and expects at least as many tourists to visit Kyushu this year as last year. JR Kyushu plans to expand non-rail sales to 62% of revenue by 2019 and forecasts a 20% rise in sales to 400 billion yen. The company's IPO, which will raise up to S$5.5 billion, is the fourth by a JR firm and will test a market with dwindling returns due to negative interest rates.

images.alt_text: Mr Karaike says that JR Kyushu is looking to South-east Asia to help diversify and increase its revenue.

site_title: Tesla's Musk says will not have to raise funds in Q4
summary: Tesla's CEO Elon Musk stated on Twitter that the company will not need to raise funds in the fourth quarter for its planned acquisition of SolarCity Corp, contradicting a previous SEC filing. Musk also said "probably not then either" for a potential funding in the first quarter of 2017. Tesla has a combined $3.3 billion in cash and cash equivalents, but expects to pay $426 million in convertible debt securities in the third quarter. The company plans to use additional funds for the Tesla Model 3 production and assembly lines.

site_title: Rude awakening in the UK over Brexit cost sends pound down
summary: The UK pound has plummeted to its lowest level against the dollar since 1985, dropping 1.4% at US$1.2433, amid concerns over the economic impact of Brexit. The pound's decline is attributed to Prime Minister Theresa May's focus on immigration control over single market membership, and the EU's hardline stance on free movement of people, goods, services, and capital. Investors worry about the potential costs to manufacturers, the economy, and the financial sector, with a record current-account deficit also causing alarm.

site_title: Australia shares sluggish ahead of US jobs data; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.2% to 5,471.3 ahead of US job numbers, as investors awaited clarity on a potential Federal Reserve rate hike. The S&P/ASX 200 index initially gained but ended lower. A lower-than-expected US unemployment benefits report suggested 175,000 new jobs were created in September.

site_title: Malaysia says debris found in Mauritius is from missing flight MH370
summary: Malaysia confirms that debris found in Mauritius is from missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which disappeared in March 2014 with 239 people on board. Analysis by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau found that the debris is consistent with the trailing edge of an aircraft wing. This is the second piece of debris confirmed to be from the missing jet, following discoveries in Reunion and Tanzania. The search for MH370 has turned up few leads after a two-year search.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, falling 1.02% or 174.03 points to 16,850.73, due to energy shares edging down. The broader Topix index also fell 1.04% or 14.16 points to 1,342.19.

site_title: China raps US interventions in Asia at regional forum
summary: China's Defence Minister Chang Wanguan criticized the US for its interventions in Asia, particularly in the South China Sea and North Korea, at the 7th annual Xiangshan regional defence forum in Beijing. China claims the South China Sea and has built artificial islands, while the US has conducted freedom of navigation operations and deployed a missile defence system in South Korea. The US seeks to "pivot" to Asia, raising concerns in Beijing that it's working to contain China's growing power. Tensions are high, with a former Australian Prime Minister warning that the disputes could become a flashpoint for US-China conflict.

site_title: Opportunities in AEC, but SMEs face challenges: report
summary: A report by ACCA finds that Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) in the Asean region can benefit from the Asean Economic Community (AEC), but face challenges in accessing finance, technology, and talent. The AEC's liberalization of trade tariffs and access to global value chains offer significant opportunities, but also intensify competition and require SMEs to innovate and improve productivity to stay competitive. Financing and talent recruitment remain significant challenges, particularly for SMEs in Singapore.

site_title: UBS sets up real estate venture in Brazil as prices dive
summary: UBS is launching a real estate venture in Brazil, capitalizing on the country's declining property prices. The venture, Real Estate Capital, will offer funds and advice to institutional clients and wealthy individuals, focusing on built properties. With an office vacancy rate above 22% in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, the market is seen as a low-risk opportunity for investors, with potential returns of 10-12% per year. The venture aims to bring liquidity back to the market and is part of UBS's strategy to focus on core businesses, including real estate management.

images.alt_text: Sao Paulo ranked 50th in a global list of the most expensive office markets in June, down from as high as eighth in 2012, according to CBRE.

site_title: Cadillac of CVs
summary: The Volkswagen Caddy 1.4 TSI is a seven-seater alternative to the expensive Touran, priced at S$140K less, at S$15K. The Caddy nameplate, previously known as a light commercial vehicle, is now available as a passenger vehicle.

site_title: Greek consumer prices drop in September after three-month rise
summary: Greek consumer prices dropped 1.0% year-on-year in September, the first decline in three months, as housing, food, and durable goods costs led the decrease. The annual inflation rate turned negative at -0.1%, beating market expectations. This marks the longest period of deflation in Greece since 2013, with the country's economy still recovering from recession and wage/pension cuts. The data follows a 0.4% inflation rate in August and a 0.4% eurozone inflation rate, which remains below the European Central Bank's target of just below 2%.

site_title: Baijiu getting its moment as makers mix it up
summary: Baijiu, a traditional Chinese grain liquor, has seen a decline in sales after President Xi Jinping ordered public servants to cut expenses. The 13% decline in sales has led to store price drops by half. As the liquor expands overseas, spirits companies are experimenting with new flavor combinations, including pairing baijiu with 7-Up. This shift is a response to the changing market and the need to adapt to the changing tastes of consumers. The decline in baijiu sales highlights the challenges faced by traditional liquor brands in the face of changing consumer preferences.

site_title: Fed rate hike views hurt Asia FX sentiment; yuan bearish bets climb
summary: Investors have become more pessimistic about emerging Asian currencies due to rising expectations of a US interest rate hike in December. The Chinese yuan has seen the largest bearish positions since July, with the Singapore dollar and Thai baht also experiencing significant pessimism. The Philippine peso has the largest short positions since 2008, while the South Korean won and Malaysian ringgit have seen their largest pessimistic bets since May. These moves are attributed to a firmer US dollar and concerns about economic growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Sentiment towards most emerging Asian currencies turned bearish in the last two weeks as investors grew more confident in the likelihood of a US interest rate hike in December, a Reuters poll showed.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says US$60 oil 'not unthinkable' by year-end
summary: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih stated that an oil price surge to $60 per barrel by the end of the year is "not unthinkable" but warned against drastic production cuts that could shock the market. The kingdom is committed to its economic reform program, which includes a planned IPO of Saudi Aramco, and is prepared to adapt to any price fluctuations. Al-Falih emphasized the importance of maintaining a balanced supply and demand, rather than focusing solely on price.

site_title: Greener infrastructure said key to Paris climate deal: study
summary: A global commission on the economy and climate has stated that investing in sustainable infrastructure is key to greener economic growth and limiting global warming and pollution. The commission projects $90 trillion in global infrastructure investments by 2030, mostly in developing nations and cities. To achieve this, the commission calls for a rapid phase-out of fossil fuel subsidies and wider pricing of emissions. This, they say, is crucial for the success of the Paris climate agreement.

site_title: SATS a good long-term bet but sit tight for now
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground-handler, has seen its stock price climb to a peak of S$5.11, despite being at rich valuations. Analysts recommend a "hold" rating, citing long-term growth prospects, particularly in the Middle East and Asia. SATS has secured a tender to run a cargo terminal in Saudi Arabia and is expanding into non-aviation businesses. However, investors may want to wait for overseas ventures to take effect, as near-term growth is expected to be limited by slowing air traffic.

site_title: It's about time for meaningful progress on diversity
summary: Singapore's corporate governance is pushing for meaningful progress on diversity, recommending disclosure and target setting for boardroom gender equality. Despite a 1.4% increase in women's board seats to 9.7% since 2013, progress has been slow. The Diversity Action Committee's recommendation aims to change this by requiring companies to set diversity policies and report on progress, which could lead to rapid change. However, regulators must take stronger action against non-compliant companies and ensure meaningful explanations for non-compliance to make the policy effective.

site_title: SATS Indian joint venture starts trial operations for perishable cargo handling centre
summary: A joint venture between Air India Limited and SATS has started trial operations for India's first integrated perishable cargo handling centre at the Kempegowda International Airport in Bengaluru. The 11,000 square metre facility, called AISATS Coolport, aims to meet increasing demands for temperature-sensitive cargo. It features 17 cold rooms, a drug controller laboratory, and a plant quarantine inspection office, with a handling capacity of 40,000 tonnes per annum. The facility is expected to cater to perishable commodities such as pharmaceutical products and flowers.

site_title: Rules should apply equally to all players - big and small
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced a new Trade Surveillance Handbook and Members' Surveillance Dashboard to combat false market activities. The guides aim to educate trading representatives and their firms on identifying suspicious behavior and alerting them to potential issues. However, critics argue that the rules are not consistently applied, with smaller players often being targeted while larger ones are rarely penalized. To address this, SGX must ensure fair application of the rules to maintain investor confidence and credibility.

site_title: Gold rebounds from 3-month lows as US dollar eases
summary: Gold prices rebounded from 3-month lows, rising half a percent to $1,273.40 an ounce, as the US dollar eased back from a two-month high and stocks fell. This comes after a 3% drop on Tuesday, the lowest price since June 24.

site_title: Australia shares rebound on strong US data, oil prices; NZ down
summary: Australia's shares rebounded 0.32% to 5,470.3, driven by financial stocks and strong US economic data, including a sharp recovery in US services sector activity and rising oil prices, which hit a one-month high. Gains were also seen in energy and mining stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.6% for a third straight session.

site_title: Tax amnesty to cleanse Indonesia underground economy, Riady says
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty program has collected 97.2 trillion rupiah (S$10.2 billion) since its launch in July, with President Joko Widodo aiming to increase the country's tax base. Billionaire Mochtar Riady, chairman of Lippo Group, believes the program will help clean up the "underground" economy, as people build trust in the government. The program offers tax rates ranging from 2% to 10% for declared assets, with those who repatriate money and invest in Indonesia eligible for lower rates. The government may consider lowering tax incentives for real estate investment trusts to attract more foreign investment.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Bhd received an indicative offer of financing from a financial institution, with part of the funds earmarked for a mutually acceptable proposal with bondholders. China Reform Puissance Overseas GP acquired a 23.85% stake in Citic Envirotech for S$390.1 million. Meanwhile, Lion Global Investors subscribed for 2.41 million shares in LGlobal Funds for S$24 million. Jason Holdings clarified that S$1.74 million is due and owing by non-executive directors as guarantors for banking facilities.

site_title: "No question" UK will address London bankers' EU-exit worries: minister
summary: The UK government has assured London bankers that it will negotiate an exit deal with the EU to address concerns about the impact of Brexit on the financial sector. Minister David Davis said the future of Britain's global financial centre will be a major negotiating point, with banks seeking to retain "passporting" rights to sell financial services across the EU. The talks are set to begin by the end of March, with the goal of avoiding disruption to financial markets.

site_title: Pan-United's founding family buying its tug & barge business for S$29.92m
summary: Pan-United Corporation's founding family has proposed buying its loss-making tug and barge business for S$29.92 million. The business, which includes 12 tugboats and 10 barges, has been incurring losses since 2013 due to low freight rates and oversupply in vessel capacity. The proposed disposal will enable the group to focus on its core businesses, including logistics, ship chartering, and ship agency services. The deal, subject to shareholder approval, will use funds for future projects and working capital.

site_title: Robots set tone for revival of Japan dairy
summary: Japan's dairy industry is experiencing a revival, thanks in part to the use of robots. Entrepreneur Jin Kawaguchiya transformed his 20-cow farm into Asia's largest automated milking factory, increasing raw-milk production from 2015 to 4,500 tonnes this year, and 5,600 tonnes next year. Automation has reduced labor costs and enabled more efficient data analysis. The industry is expected to continue growing, with the number of dairies increasing and productivity per cow rising. The Japanese government has also increased subsidies for milking robots, supporting the adoption of technology in agriculture.

site_title: Perfecting Singapore's system of governance
summary: The Singapore government is introducing constitutional and legislative changes to perfect the country's system of governance. The changes, which include new eligibility criteria for the elected presidency, aim to promote good governance, multiracialism, and stability. The government has accepted recommendations from the Constitutional Commission, which included increasing the minimum paid-up capital for private sector candidates to $500 million. However, the government is taking a cautious approach, erring on the side of being safe rather than sorry, and is not rushing to entrench the changes. The changes are intended to be tested for one or two elections before being further modified or entrenched.

site_title: Millions flee inland as South-east US braces for Hurricane Matthew
summary: Hurricane Matthew, a Category 3 storm with sustained winds of 185 km/h, is expected to intensify as it approaches the south-east US coast. Millions of residents in four states, including Florida, Georgia, and North and South Carolina, have fled inland due to warnings of storm surges, heavy rain, and potential destruction. The US National Hurricane Centre predicts landfall in eastern Florida on Thursday night, prompting a mass evacuation. Over 12 million US residents are under hurricane watches and warnings, with shelters opening and residents boarding up their homes in preparation for the storm.

images.alt_text: The fiercest Caribbean storm in nearly a decade slammed into the Bahamas early on Thursday and was expected to intensify as it barreled towards the south-east US coast, where a mass exodus was under way in four states.

site_title: German minister, in Tehran, urges Iran to push for Syria ceasefire
summary: German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel urged Iranian officials during a visit to Tehran to push for a ceasefire in Syria, citing the bombing of hospitals and civilian areas. Gabriel stated that everyone who supports the Syrian government, including Iran, shares responsibility for ending the fighting. His comments come as the US broke off talks with Russia on a ceasefire agreement, highlighting the challenges in resolving the 5.5-year-old conflict. Gabriel's visit is also aimed at encouraging business deals after the historic nuclear accord lifted sanctions.

site_title: SIAS should be more careful before picking sides
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has been criticized for being too quick to intervene in general offers, potentially benefiting one side of the deal over another. In the case of Halcyon Agri Corp's offer for GMG Global, SIAS questioned the fairness of the offer, but its argument may have come at the expense of Halcyon's minority shareholders. SIAS president David Gerald acknowledged that some independent financial adviser reports may contain caveats that should be considered, and the organization may need to apply a wrongdoing test before getting involved in issues. This could help prevent inadvertently hurting its constituents.

site_title: Leading the way in energy management
summary: ASM Technology Singapore's corporate facilities director, Eric Leung, has been named Outstanding Energy Manager of the Year for achieving a 23.1% energy reduction from 2012 to 2015. Leung's holistic approach to energy management, which involves setting targets, conducting regular meetings, and promoting teamwork, has been recognized for its effectiveness. As a certified energy manager, Leung emphasizes the importance of energy efficiency in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating global climate change. His company's success in energy efficiency is attributed to his leadership and dedication to promoting energy-saving practices among employees.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Tuesday but poor volume persists
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 13.8 points to 2,884.64 on Tuesday, driven by a 40-point gain in Dow futures, but poor volume persisted. The market's turnover was 1.5 billion units worth S$766 million, the seventh time it fell below S$1 billion in the past eight sessions. Despite the low volume, 19 of the 20 most active stocks posted gains, with the average value per unit traded at S$0.51. The index's rise pushed it two points into the black for 2016.

site_title: Supporters defend Trump in wake of tax revelations
summary: Donald Trump's supporters defended him after reports that he may have avoided paying taxes for 20 years, despite not confirming or denying the claims. Trump called the reports a sign of his "absolute genius" and said he maximized profits, while Bernie Sanders criticized Trump's lack of transparency on his tax returns. The controversy comes as Trump's campaign is facing a slump, with a recent poll showing Hillary Clinton leading in the polls, and Trump's unpopularity rating reaching 64%.

site_title: SMU practises responsible energy management
summary: SMU, a Singapore Management University, has successfully implemented an ISO 50001 certified energy management system, achieving a 33% reduction in energy consumption over nine years despite a nearly doubling student population. The university has overcome challenges to build a strong energy efficiency culture, with measures such as installing over 200 power meters, promoting sustainability awareness, and establishing a dedicated energy management team. SMU's efforts have resulted in significant cost savings and a strong track record of energy efficiency, with plans to continue exploring new ways to improve energy efficiency.

site_title: Brexit boosts British watchmaker Bremont as Swiss suffer
summary: Bremont, a British watchmaker, has seen a surge in sales since the UK voted to leave the EU, with exports increasing by 15% due to a weaker pound. This contrasts with Swiss watch brands, which have struggled with falling exports and rising costs due to the stronger franc. Bremont's success is attributed to its focus on British watchmaking and its ability to adapt to the changing market. The company is working to reduce its reliance on Swiss parts and is investing in new processes to improve efficiency.

site_title: US, China said to discuss choking off North Korea energy
summary: The US and China are negotiating to restrict North Korea's energy trade in response to its fifth nuclear test, with the US seeking to tighten sanctions to prod Kim Jong Un's regime into abandoning nuclear ambitions. China, which accounts for 70% of North Korea's trade, is considering restrictions on coal, iron ore, and crude oil imports, but a ban on energy trade could lead to the regime's collapse. The US and its allies are pushing for China's support to implement sanctions, with other nations considering separate measures once the UN Security Council acts.

images.alt_text: The US and China are locked in negotiations over curbing North Korea's energy trade in response to its fifth nuclear test last month, according to four diplomats from United Nations Security Council countries with direct knowledge of the talks.

site_title: Millennials.
summary: A study conducted by The Business Times in Singapore tracked the spending habits of 13 young millennials, aged 13 to 28, over four weeks. The results showed that despite being stereotyped as entitled and lazy, millennials' spending habits were diverse and influenced by their parents' wealth and financial support.
